headline: Transfer Deadline: Dempsey Heads to Spurs
text: United States forward Clint Dempsey secured his move away from Fulham in the final hours of the transfer window on Friday, signing a three-year contract with Tottenham Hotspur that will keep him in England’s Premier League.

headline: Pakistan’s Premier Televangelist
text: Aamir Liaquat Hussain is a broadcasting sensation and a contentious figure.

headline: Way Cleared for November Vote in Texas
text: A federal three-judge panel in San Antonio ruled on Friday that the November elections in Texas would proceed, ending uncertainty about whether a Washington court’s earlier ruling would delay the elections.

headline: View at Practice Courts an Intimate but Possibly Endangered Perk
text: When Sandra Unger heard that Roger Federer was headed to the practice courts at the United States Open, she immediately texted her sister Laurie McLeod, who was having lunch at the food court.

headline: Debt Collector Misled Borrowers, Court Says
text: For borrowers struggling to pay off their student loans, getting rid of the debt in bankruptcy is difficult because they need to convince a judge that it constitutes an “undue hardship.”

headline: Republicans, in Search of a Foreign Policy
text: Washington

headline: Cardinal Carlo Martini, Papal Contender, Dies at 85
text: ROME — Cardinal Carlo Maria Martini, one of the Roman Catholic Church’s most influential progressive thinkers, who once was considered as a possible successor to Pope John Paul II, died in a Jesuit retreat near Milan on Friday. He was 85.

headline: Rushing to See Roddick, If Not to Praise Him
text: When Andy Roddick announced his impending retirement Thursday, Ann Morrissey texted Lisa O’Neil: “Turn on the Roddick press conference.”

headline: Feline Film Festival
text: Thousands of cat lovers and cineastes gathered at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis to celebrate the Internet sensation that is cat videos.

headline: Only the Good Get Rich
text: As the Republican convention fades into oblivion, the one thing everybody is still talking about is, of course, the party platform.

headline: The G.O.P. Fact Vacuum
text: Tampa, Fla.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: The Occupy Wall Street protest in Hong Kong ignored a deadline to leave HSBC’s headquarters, European leaders worked again to reassure investors on the debt crisis and Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chief, committed to aiding the economy.

headline: Aug. 31: TV Ratings May Be Leading Indicator of Convention Bounce
text: It remains too early to tell exactly what effect the Republican National Convention has had on the polls. But television ratings are one measure that come in almost instantaneously. Ratings for the final two nights of the Republican convention were down quite a bit from 2008, declining by about 30 percent overall.

headline: Giving to a Newborn’s College Savings Plan
text: The best gift any of us can give to newborn babies is to point their sleep-deprived parents in the direction of a good 529 or other college savings plan and then seed the account with a little bit of money.

headline: A Superstar Televangelist in Pakistan Divides, Then Repents
text: KARACHI, Pakistan

headline: Families’ Bond Is Severed as Blood Spills
text: This is the story of two modest, crowded apartments in two buildings in the Tompkins Houses in Brooklyn: 5C at 65 Tompkins Avenue; and around the corner and 10 stories higher, 15G at 919 Myrtle Avenue. The Hartley family lives in one, the Mann family in the other. They share a timeline that spans 30 years.

headline: Trying to Recapture Normal at Penn State
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — This year, more than most, felt like a long overdue reunion: Penn State students converging, the professors awaiting, all savoring their own slice of normalcy.

headline: Sex Charges Cast a Pall on a College Town
text: MISSOULA, Mont. — Students are back in their classrooms this week, the heat of summer has cooled and new chalk lines have been placed on the football field as the University of Montana Grizzlies and their devoted fans prepare for the opening kickoff on Saturday.

headline: Risky and Getting Riskier
text: Just what grandpa needed. Soon retirees and other investors will be barraged with advertisements for private stock offerings — via mail, cold calling, television, radio, billboards, the Internet and so on.

headline: Facebook Plays It Safe
text: I read with some amusement the news that Facebook had brought on the architect Frank Gehry to design an expansion to its Menlo Park, Calif., headquarters. Or more specifically, a new warehouse for engineers at its Menlo Park headquarters. Plans for the Silicon Valley site include a 420,000-square-foot, single-story warehouse topped with a garden that will span the entire roof. A tunnel will connect “Facebook East” to the company’s existing headquarters in the former space of Sun Microsystems, whose more hierarchical floor plan has been demolished to make way for Facebook’s open-plan ethos. (As one British blog so delicately put it, “Facebook moves into Sun Microsystems carcass.”)

headline: Cleaner Cars, a Safer Planet
text: The federal automobile efficiency standards announced this week are an important step on America’s path to a lower-carbon and more-secure energy future. They are expected to yield multiple benefits: reduced dependence on foreign oil, fewer greenhouse gas emissions, consumer savings at the pump and a more competitive auto industry. They may also serve as proof that well-tailored government regulation can achieve positive results and that consensus among old enemies — in this case environmentalists and the car companies — is possible even at a time of partisan discord.

headline: Campaigns Play Loose With Truth in a Fact-Check Age
text: In his very first television advertisement last year, Mitt Romney highlighted the nation’s dire unemployment crisis, its record number of home foreclosures and the rising national debt, and showed video of President Obama delivering this arresting remark: “If we keep talking about the economy, we’re going to lose.”

headline: Why College Money Is the Best Baby Gift
text: This week’s Your Money column about the ins and outs of giving money as a gift to someone’s 529 college savings account wasn’t meant to be an etiquette lesson. But I do think giving money is totally defensible, even if it means pushing the parents to open a 529 or other savings account to use the gift.

headline: Rage by Miners Points to Shift in South Africa
text: JOHANNESBURG — When 360,000 gold and coal miners walked off the job in South Africa in 1987, protesting the poor pay and grim working conditions of apartheid-era mines, a charismatic young man named Cyril Ramaphosa, the firebrand leader of the National Union of Mineworkers, led the charge.

headline: Romney Shows Support in Storm-Battered Bayou
text: KENNER, La. — Mitt Romney on Friday used the first day since accepting his party’s nomination for president to tour hurricane-ravaged regions of the Louisiana bayou, a visit that seemed intended to convey an unmistakable air of presidential authority.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Woods Finds a Groove and Stays There
text: NORTON, Mass. — What the butterfly effect is to science, the Tiger effect is to golf. On Friday, a 6-inch putt rolled in the hole at No. 5 and caused a commotion between the 9th and 10th holes at T.P.C. Boston. The roar that punctuated Tiger Woods’s eighth birdie of his morning round of the Deutsche Bank Championship prompted a mass dash to the front nine by fans wanting to catch a glimpse of the new old Woods.

headline: A Fight Over Spending in New York State
text: Twice in August, judges declared unconstitutional or otherwise rejected state laws because, they said, the laws ran afoul of a provision in the New York State Constitution known as home rule. Both decisions involved transportation, and both could cost the public a lot of money: New York City in one case; the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in the other.

headline: Suits That Accused Sloan-Kettering Chief of Stealing Research Are Settled
text: Two lawsuits that accused the president of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center of absconding with groundbreaking research from the University of Pennsylvania to start a biotechnology company have been settled.

headline: Mexico: Drug Gang Suspect Extradited to the U.S.
text: A 20-year investigation into one of Mexico’s largest drug trafficking organizations came to a close Friday with the extradition of Eduardo Arellano-Félix, a top operative of the gang, to San Diego. After exhausting his legal appeals in Mexico, he will face a variety of charges, including racketeering and money laundering, in a United States court. The Mexican government sent Mr. Arellano-Félix, a capo in the Arellano-Félix organization led by his family members, to the United States more than four years after his arrest following a shootout with Mexican police. His brothers are already serving long sentences in the United States, and the Drug Enforcement Administration contends that the gang has largely been crippled, though several others have taken its place as top suppliers of cocaine and marijuana to the United States. Still, Lanny A. Breuer, a Justice Department official, called the extradition “a milestone in our fight against the Mexican drug cartels.”

headline: The Bullet That Changed History
text: It was late afternoon on Aug. 30, 1862, the concluding day of the Second Battle of Bull Run, and the largest simultaneous massed assault of the Civil War was about to be unleashed. The Confederate general James Longstreet’s corps was in position on the left flank of the Union general John Pope’s unsuspecting Army of Virginia, and when the signal was given 25,000 Rebels surged forward, catching the surprised Federals in an immense “hammer on anvil” movement.

headline: New York City to Pay in Another Prisoner Suit
text: New York City will pay $850,000 to settle a lawsuit stemming from the beating of an inmate at Rikers Island that fit a rogue disciplinary pattern cited by law enforcement officials in which favored prisoners, in a system known as the Program, received tacit approval to keep order by assaulting and threatening other prisoners.

headline: Outfielder, Like Team, Detoured To Success
text: At the start of this season, Lew Ford, five years removed from his last stint in the majors, had a single goal: to bring a championship trophy to Central Islip, N.Y., the home of the Long Island Ducks of the independent Atlantic League of Professional Baseball.

headline: The Ice Pick Seems Antiquated, but It Still Shows Up on the Police Blotter
text: The young man staggered down a city street as blood flowed from a puncture wound. The weapon used in the steely attack — an ice pick — was sticking out of his lower back.

headline: A Killing on a Brooklyn Block Known for Its Violence
text: The morning after his mother was killed in Brooklyn, Chinnarie Gordon, 5, took his grandmother’s hand and walked to Parkside Playground. As his cousins played in the fountains, Chinnarie climbed up to a checkers table and began drawing a picture of his mother in blue chalk, giving her long blue hair and a mermaid’s tail.

headline: Mainstreaming Efforts Praised in Schools Study
text: A study released on Friday said that the New York City Department of Education had done a good job of preparing for significant special education reforms that will begin in earnest next week, but it expressed concerns about whether schools had enough money and teachers had enough training to carry out the changes.

headline: It’s Roddick’s Opponent Bowing Out
text: As if it were not enough to have to face Andy Roddick the day after he announced his retirement, Bernard Tomic had a tough act to follow even entering Arthur Ashe Stadium on Friday night. The stadium lights were not yet on, but Roddick’s enormous face glowed from a video montage with clips of his electric serve and equally electric smile.

headline: Mercury’s Core
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I am of two minds about today’s puzzle, by Tim Croce.

headline: Federal Judge in Ohio Restores Early Voting
text: A federal judge in Ohio on Friday ordered the state to give all voters the right to cast their ballots in person on the final three days before Election Day.

headline: A New Guide to the Democratic Herd
text: A look at the major blocs of the Democratic Party going into the 2012 election.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Aviation History

headline: Giants’ Terrell Thomas Will Miss Another Season
text: Giants cornerback Terrell Thomas will miss a second consecutive season after the team placed him on injured reserve Friday because of a knee injury. Earlier in training camp, he  aggravated the right knee that cost him the 2011 season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament.

headline: Student Reviews of Introduction to Congress
text: Online evaluations of the Harvard class taught by Matthew B. Platt reflect largely scathing opinions of the course. Nearly half of the 279 students enrolled in the spring class were accused of cheating.

headline: An Easier Way to Find Adult Classes
text: My girlfriend is a teacher and a graduate student, and every year around this time, I get a pang of nostalgia for the school life as she runs around buying new notebooks and checking class schedules while I prepare for another day at the office.

headline: Harvard Students in Cheating Scandal Say Collaboration Was Accepted
text: Harvard students suspected in a major cheating scandal said on Friday that many of the accusations are based on innocent — or at least tolerated — collaboration among students, and with help from graduate-student teachers who sometimes gave them answers to test questions.

headline: Giving the Yankees Reason for Pause
text: A few starts ago, Hiroki Kuroda threw a seven-inning shutout in a rain-shortened victory over the Toronto Blue Jays. The win, on July 18, increased the Yankees’ lead in the American League East to a whopping 10 games. The margin has been slashed to two, in part, by a rash of injuries and inconsistent performances.

headline: Pro Medium Repents for Life of Cons
text: Don’t mistake Mark Edward for John Edward. The two men, who are not related, are both professional mediums, men who charge money for their supposed skill at transmitting messages from the dead. But whereas John Edward had a nationally syndicated television show and still plays to large crowds in Las Vegas and across the country, Mark Edward’s biggest gigs were a baby shower at Eddie Murphy’s house and Buddy Hackett’s 70th birthday party.

headline: Striking a Work-Life Balance
text: Sara Horowitz, 49, the founder of the Freelancers Union, has a commitment to workers’ rights that runs several generations deep: her paternal grandfather was vice president of the International Ladies’ Garment Workers’ Union, and her father was a union lawyer. She received a MacArthur Fellowship in 1999. Ms. Horowitz, who grew up in Brooklyn Heights, lives in a brownstone in Park Slope with her husband, Peter DeChiara, 47, a lawyer whose firm represents unions, and their daughter, Rachel, 12. Like many of the freelancers whose champion she has become, she mixes work and home life on Sundays.

headline: Dickey Blanks Marlins for 17th Win
text: MIAMI — The Mets have been anything but a certainty this season, except perhaps when they send R. A. Dickey to the mound against the Miami Marlins.

headline: Old Friends and Oysters
text: When the wife-and-husband team of Jennifer and Shane Covey opened their 28-seat East Village restaurant, Upstate, last July, the concept was monkishly minimal: beer and oysters. “We’re relatively uncomplicated people,” Ms. Covey said, though she also said her husband used three types of beer glasses at home. Not that more complicated people have found a better way to salute a late summer sunset. The Coveys have since added a few cooked dishes, some wine and free slices of Ms. Covey’s whiskey cake, but it is still the original pairing that brings the customers in — some calling it a light dinner, others pre-dinner ballast, an evening equivalent of elevenses. The décor is spare, and the menu would almost fit in a Twitter post. From 5 to 7 p.m., you get a beer and six oysters for $12. One evening at the end of August, a crowd waited on the sidewalk for seats to open up. Inside, the early birds slurped and slugged. Were oyster happy hours everywhere this summer? Yes, they were. What took them so long?

headline: 2 Campaigns Differ Sharply on Medicaid, Seeking Vast Growth or Vast Cuts
text: The way Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan frame it, the debate over social programs that has become a dominant theme of the presidential race is all about the future of Medicare, the government health insurance program for retirees.

headline: Weapons Plant Security Issues Are Described in U.S. Audit
text: WASHINGTON — The contractors in charge of guarding the national stockpile of bomb-grade uranium in Tennessee knew well before an 82-year-old nun and two other pacifists broke through three barriers this summer that a lot of the security equipment was broken, and government managers knew it too, according to an internal audit of Energy Department operations at the weapons facility. The inspector general’s investigation found “troubling displays of ineptitude.”

headline: As a Catalog of Pain Shows, She Isn’t Riding Just for Show
text: NORTH SALEM, N.Y. — Georgina Bloomberg, 29, the younger daughter of New York’s mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, practiced in a white T-shirt and dark helmet, jumping her bay mare Radio City over imposing panels and open water in a grass field at her farm here.

headline: Guiding Golfers to Rock Their Shots
text: TO find the head professional at the Marine Park Golf Course in Brooklyn, look for a flamboyant outfit of plaids and pastels, and follow the smoke.

headline: Tipsarevic Beats Baker at Own Game
text: Janko Tipsarevic, the eighth seed from Serbia, outplayed  Brian Baker on Friday, winning, 6-4, 6-3, 6-4, to advance to the third round of the United States Open.  Tipsarevic used his superior movement to thwart Baker, who struggled to return his serve, especially his accurate, deceptive second delivery.  By contrast, Tipsarevic broke Baker five times, including the final game, when Baker had a chance to draw even late in the third set.

headline: First Death Is Reported From New Pig Flu Strain
text: The first human death from a new strain of pig flu was reported Friday by state health officials in Ohio.

headline: Ryan’s Budget Proposal Is Pitting G.O.P. Troops Against Top of the Ticket
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Even as Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan exhort Republicans to embrace their proposed Medicare changes and spending cuts, the party’s rank and file is growing less enthusiastic about the fight than the top of the ticket.

headline: At Paralympics, First Thing Judged Is Disability
text: LONDON — Anthony Dawson, who has cerebral palsy and little muscle function on his right side, rode for South Africa in the first round of the equestrian dressage competition at the Paralympics on Thursday, guiding his horse through an intricately choreographed series of movements.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Too Busy or Just Too Tired, Some Floridians Paid Convention Little Mind
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Kaye Collie really wanted to pay attention to the last night of the Republican National Convention, particularly the big moment when the nominee, Mitt Romney, would step out on the huge stage in Tampa, Fla., and make the speech of his lifetime.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Far From Action but Right at Home
text: From where Denise Starr was playing on practice court No. 13, she could see the upper reaches of Arthur Ashe Stadium, and hear the roars of the crowd during Novak Djokovic’s victory over Rogerio Dutra Silva there. Or perhaps it was the cheers coming from Louis Armstrong as Laura Robson beat Li Na.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Inquiry Finds No Misdeeds by Sheriff in Arizona
text: PHOENIX — The United States attorney’s office announced on Friday that it had closed an investigation over abuse-of-power allegations against Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, some of his current and former employees, and the former Maricopa County attorney, concluding that none of them had done anything wrong.

headline: A History of New York in 50 Objects
text: An artichoke and an elevator. A Checker taxicab and a conductor’s baton. A MetroCard and a mastodon tusk. From ancient artifacts to common everyday accessories, which objects tell the story of New York City?

headline: Who Will Be the Next in Line to Replace Roddick?
text: Within hours of Andy Roddick’s announcement on Thursday that he would retire after the United States Open, the focus of American tennis turned to the next generation.

headline: Jets Trim Roster as Season Opener Nears
text: The Jets cut three draft selections: receiver Jordan White, running back Terrance Ganaway and offensive lineman Robert Griffin.

headline: Teenager Dies After Sticking Head Through Bus Hatch and Striking Underpass
text: A teenager was killed when he popped his head out of a rooftop hatch on a double-decker bus and struck an underpass near the George Washington Bridge on Friday night, an official at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

headline: Corrections: September 1, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Breathing Life Into a Dead Language
text: LONDON — It seems that Latin is a dead language that refuses to lie down.

headline: What I Saw at the Republican Convention
text: The outcome of American elections affect the entire world — yet most people outside the United States (and many inside) don’t understand American politics. In an effort to bring greater understanding to the process, the politics, the personalities and the policies, The New York Times, for the first time, livestreamed coverage from the Republican National Convention. I was one of the anchors of that coverage.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Recent amendments to the Right to Information Act of 2010 have weakened the State Information Commission, a watchdog agency tasked with safeguarding the law’s provisions, Hindustan Times reported. Civic groups and opposition politicians criticized the changes; the chief information commissioner, G.R. Sufi, accused the state government of trying to make the commission a “toothless body.”

headline: The Weekend Word: Political Theater
text: Today’s Times

headline: How Greek Taxpayers Hide 11 Billion Euros a Year
text: After a brief summer holiday, the euro crisis is back. Adam Davidson’s latest column previews seven dramas coming to the Euro zone this fall. As usual, things begin with Greece, which has to cut its budget by an additional 11.5 billion euros in order to secure the next round of debt relief. In a surprising twist, that may be the exact amount of money that Greece loses from tax evaders each year.

headline: In Vietnam, Message of Equality Is Challenged by Widening Wealth Gap
text: HANOI, Vietnam — She wore a pink outfit and matching high heels as she toured the dusty construction site. Soon after To Linh Huong’s visit in April, photos that captured the moment went viral on the Internet, but not because of Ms. Huong’s sense of style.

headline: Three Hours, Four Hours, Whatever
text: Ahem. (Via Mark Thoma, who has more).

headline: What to Watch on Saturday
text: Down a set and trailing 3-2 in her second round match Thursday, nothing seemed to work for Sloane Stephens. Her first serve was off, her forehand shaky. Tatjana Malek’s route to victory seemed easy enough: Keep balls in play and wait for the inevitable miss.

headline: Woodford on Monetary Policy (Sort of Wonkish)
text: I’m not in Jackson Hole — actually, I appear to have been blackballed for a long time, probably because I had the temerity to criticize the great Greenspan before it was fashionable. No matter. I can still read the papers — and the most important one was by Mike Woodford (pdf).

headline: Live Updates: First Saturday
text: The stars have aligned for the first Saturday of the college football season. Paul Myerberg is in Manhattan. Tim Rohan is in Happy Valley to watch Penn State host Ohio. Later tonight, Tom Spousta will be in Arlington, Tex., to provide feedback on Alabama’s date with Michigan. Keep close tabs throughout the day for updates and analysis.

headline: A Brief History of Timelines
text: 385 million B.C. During the Middle Devonian Period of the Paleozoic Era, a prehistoric fern adds a new growth ring to its trunk, creating the world’s first timeline. A trilobite third-grade teacher immediately assigns it to her class as busywork.

headline: Alice Waters
text: A pioneer in the organic, locally grown and slow-food movements, Alice Waters is a chef, cookbook author and owner of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Angola’s Governing Party and Its President Are Poised to Win Election
text: LUANDA, Angola — Angola’s governing party was poised on Saturday to sweep parliamentary elections, winning a landslide victory that would ensure President José Eduardo dos Santos a five-year extension to his 33 years at the country’s helm.

headline: N.F.C. South Preview: Saints, Stained by Scandal, Have Staying Power
text: Player to Watch It’s possible that no quarterback has had to shoulder as much as the Saints’ Drew Brees will this season with Coach Sean Payton suspended and the interim coach Joe Vitt benched for the first six games.

headline: A.F.C. South Preview: Houston Is in Line to Win Division, and Maybe More
text: Player to Watch The Colts may not go far this season, but follow quarterback Andrew Luck anyway. We’re probably going to be watching him win for a long time.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — At one point in the not-too-distant past, I was critical of the Puns and Anagrams puzzles because I thought they were too easy. I had compared them in my mind to the cryptics we work on occasion, and perhaps that was my mistake. Perhaps I was feeling cranky that day.

headline: Excluded From Inclusion
text: Tampa, Fla.

headline: The U.S. Open Chronicles: A Loss, but It’s Cool
text: Irina Falconi, who is playing at the United States Open this year, will write posts throughout the tournament for Straight Sets. She has her own tumblr page, and can be followed on Twitter.

headline: Bombers Strike Outside U.S. Military Base in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban suicide bombers staged what appeared to be a carefully coordinated attack southwest of Kabul on Saturday that killed at least a dozen Afghans and wounded 58 more just outside the same American military outpost where a similar attack one year ago wounded scores of American soldiers.

headline: California’s ‘Willful Disobedience’
text: Last year the Supreme Court took the extraordinary step of ordering California to reduce the dangerous overcrowding in its prisons. The state had challenged an earlier ruling requiring it to meet a specific limit on the number of state prisoners. The court firmly rejected that challenge.

headline: Nets Show Interest in Blatche
text: The Nets’ ongoing search for frontcourt depth has led them to Houston and a meeting with Andray Blatche, who was cut this summer by the Washington Wizards.

headline: Franklin Delano Romney
text: THE last time the United States held a presidential election amid the mass unemployment left in a financial crisis’s wake, the challenger offered only a partial glimpse of what he would actually do in office. Mostly, he played the opportunist, attacking the incumbent party for spending too much and helping too little, for being indifferent to human suffering and for failing to balance the budget, for overtaxing and undertaxing and everywhere in between. He claimed to be offering a bold contrast of visions, but mostly he just relied on the unemployment rate to do his work for him.

headline: Syrian Rebels Say They Have Seized an Air Defense Post and Its Missiles
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Opposition fighters in Syria said early Saturday that they had captured an air defense base in the eastern province of Deir el-Zour, taking at least 16 soldiers captive and seizing weapons and ammunition in what appeared to be part of a broader rebel offensive against Syrian military installations in several parts of the country.

headline: Tuning Out Taunts but Not Escaping Doubt, Braun’s Back in Top Form
text: CHICAGO — As the Milwaukee Brewers’ Ryan Braun jogged to left field in the first inning of a game against the Cubs last week, the catcalls cascaded from the Wrigley Field bleachers.

headline: Loopholes in Tobacco Regulation
text: Give the tobacco industry credit for ingenuity. Just when it looked as if federal regulators could block their ability to addict children and young adults, several companies that make cigars and pipe tobacco have sidestepped the barriers by taking advantage of loopholes in federal law.

headline: Altidore Hears Coach’s Message to U.S. National Team: Get Tough
text: In some quarters, Jurgen Klinsmann’s admonition that the United States national team needs to be less gentle has been discussed and dissected, called unsporting by some, too cynical and severe by others.

headline: It Began With a Bang
text: If you haven’t started following the 2012 Summer Paralympic Games, which began Wednesday in London, you’ve missed some good stuff, including an opening ceremony that was truly cosmic. It featured the physicist Stephen Hawking as master of ceremonies and Sir Ian McKellen as Prospero, wearing a gown of stars and telling Miranda, who was floating above the stadium in a wheelchair, to “shine your light on the beautiful diversity of humanity,” which wasn’t Shakespeare but sounded enough like it. The ceremony, whose theme was “Enlightenment,” re-enacted the Big Bang and featured an appearance by the Large Hadron Collider, the Higgs boson, giant falling apples and a choir singing a new piece, “Principia.”

headline: The Envelope Please: Chandler Buckingham
text: Chandler Buckingham, a student at Rogers High School in Rogers, Ark., is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.

headline: Still No Justice for Mortgage Abuses
text: It has been six months since the big banks settled with state and federal officials over evidence of widespread foreclosure fraud, promising to provide $25 billion in mortgage relief in exchange for not being sued over past foreclosure abuses.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Obama Takes a Page From an Unexpected Victory in Colorado
text: DENVER — As President Obama navigates the battleground states that will determine whether he wins a second term, his campaign strategists have unfolded a road map for one in particular. And they are following it closely as the best route to their destination.

headline: Mrs. Clinton’s Asia Mission
text: Mitt Romney has identified Asia as one place where he wants to focus more attention if elected, but the truth is that President Obama has already staked out a forceful position there with his commitment to rebalance American interests from the Middle East to the Pacific.

headline: In 1972, Hockey’s Cold War Boiled Over
text: Forty years later, it remains seared in the Canadian consciousness. The Summit Series of September 1972: eight games that not only changed hockey but also became a defining national event.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: How Corporations Behave
text: Readers discuss business ethics and priorities over the years.

headline: Reagan’s Personal Spying Machine
text: IN 1961, when Ronald Reagan was defining himself politically, he warned that if left unchecked, government would become “a Big Brother to us all.” But previously undisclosed F.B.I. records, released to me after a long and costly legal fight under the Freedom of Information Act, present a different side of the man who has come to symbolize the conservative philosophy of less government and greater self-reliance.

headline: Road Shows Get Rolling for Romney and Obama
text: CINCINNATI — Big crowds cheered both of the presidential candidates on Saturday as Mitt Romney began a cross-country campaign swing here testing his momentum coming out of the Republican convention, and President Obama started his own tour heading into his convention this week.

headline: Ode to the List
text: Michael Jackson’s show notes, Picasso’s recommendations and other lists up-close.

headline: A Trial on Death Row
text: An extraordinary trial is scheduled to begin Wednesday in Connecticut, held at the prison housing the state’s death row. The petitioners are inmates sentenced to death for violent felonies, who are seeking to have their sentences reduced to life without parole on the ground that the death penalty in Connecticut is unconstitutional because it has been randomly imposed on a small group of people.

headline: Cruel Conservatives Throw a Masquerade Ball
text: TAMPA, Fla.

headline: Our Longing for Lists
text: WITH school starting and vacations ending, this is the month, the season of the list. But face it. We’re living in the era of the list, maybe even its golden age. The Web click has led to the wholesale repackaging of information into lists, which can be complex and wonderful pieces of information architecture. Our technology has imperceptibly infected us with “list thinking.”

headline: Where’s Walden? GPS Often Doesn’t Know
text: LYNN, Mass. — Walden Pond, Henry David Thoreau’s idyllic retreat in the woods of Concord, Mass., has long been one of the most famous day trips in New England, drawing droves of visitors seeking the tranquil beauty immortalized in the 19th-century philosopher’s writings.

headline: A Heady Nightcap in a City Not Known for Sleeping
text: Night tennis began at the United States Open in 1975 with certain stars trying to beg out and certain patrons trying to dump unwanted tickets on scalpers.

headline: The Vengeance of the Lard
text: I spent a lot of time in England during the early 1990s (Robin was teaching there, while I was at MIT). And when there I regularly watched Have I Got News For You, a quiz show in which two teams competed to answer questions about the week’s headlines. Each timeteam consisted of a show regular and a newsmaker guest.

headline: Drawing With a Purpose, By Michael Graves
text: Michael Graves explains, through his art, why drawing is still an important architectural skill.

headline: Monetary Versus Fiscal Policy, Revisited
text: One recurring complaint from commenters on this blog is that they can’t figure out where I stand on monetary versus fiscal policy as a response to a deeply depressed economy. Sometimes, they say, I declare that monetary policy is ineffective once you’re at the zero lower bound; other times I berate Ben Bernanke for not doing more. Which is it?

headline: Architecture and the Lost Art of Drawing
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: U.S. Women’s Stars Hope, Cautiously, That a New Pro League Will Form
text: ROCHESTER — Three weeks after a gold medal victory at the Olympics, the United States women’s soccer team gathered here Friday for a leisurely practice in advance of Saturday’s first game of a 10-game celebratory tour.

headline: Hate-Crime Trial Offers a Crash Course in Amish Folkways
text: CLEVELAND — When Nancy Mullet entered a federal courtroom here on Thursday to testify in the hate-crimes trial of her father-in-law, Samuel Mullet Sr., and followers of his renegade sect, the jury knew at a glance which side she favored in this wrenching clash among Amish.

headline: Scaring the Voters in the Middle
text: THE claims of Representative Todd Akin that women don’t get pregnant from “legitimate rape” now live in infamy. But a few things you may not know:

headline: It’s Still Halftime in America
text: Tampa, Fla.

headline: Islamists Struggle to Run North Mali
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The radical Islamists who control northern Mali appear incapable of managing basic services — including electricity, water and schools — and in some cases are asking for the return of state functionaries to run them, according to a delegation that went to the region for talks recently.

headline: N.F.C. West Preview: Makeover Continues for Rejuvenated 49ers
text: Player to Watch Randy Moss. You haven’t traveled a decade back in time. Moss may not put up the numbers he did in his best years, or even in 2007 with the Patriots. But if he can still stretch the field, he can make San Francisco even more potent.

headline: In Louisiana, the Water Gives, and Takes Away

headline: A.F.C. West Preview: Broncos’ Success Hinges on Manning’s
text: Player to Watch Don’t overthink this. Peyton Manning.

headline: Tracking a Subtle Scent, a Dog May Help Save the Whales
text: OFF THE COAST OF SAN JUAN ISLAND, Wash. — A dog named Tucker with a thumping tail and a mysterious past as a stray on the streets of Seattle has become an unexpected star in the realm of canine-assisted science. He is the world’s only working dog, marine biologists say, able to find and track the scent of orca scat, or feces, in open ocean water — up to a mile away, in the smallest of specks.

headline: Salty Dog
text: Scientists analyze the scat of orca whales to monitor their health. But finding samples isn’t easy unless Tucker, a black lab mix who can sniff out the droppings from a mile away, is on board.

headline: In Russia, Opening Inquiries and Settling Scores
text: MOSCOW — When the Russian authorities began a series of investigations this spring into the business affairs of a prominent opposition lawmaker, it was widely viewed as thinly veiled political retribution.

headline: With New Owners, Padres Bullish on Future
text: The San Diego Padres officially announced their $800 million sale last week to a group headed by Ron Fowler, the chairman of a beverage-distribution company in California and Colorado, and four grandsons of Walter O’Malley, the Hall of Fame owner who took the Brooklyn Dodgers to Los Angeles in 1958. The group takes over a team that is probably better than most fans realize.

headline: Between the Acts
text: GAIL COLLINS David, we’re halfway through the convention process. We’ve spent quite a bit of time conversing about it in different venues and now — print! I’m enjoying the conversing. It’s just the conventions themselves I’ve come to hate.

headline: Is This Title O.K.?
text: Beginning – check. Middle – check. End – check. But, hold on a sec, isn’t there something missing? Something rather vital? In fact, couldn’t it be the key to your book’s selling or not? Ah, yes, the title.

headline: At Journey’s End
text: Before a game during the Mets’ last homestand, Terry Collins emerged from the dugout, picked up a baseball and began warming up his arm as he walked toward second base to watch batting practice. Three decades earlier, Collins, 63, would have performed a similar routine, when he was a utility player in the minor leagues.

headline: Clear Goals Matter More Than Mission
text: This interview with  Tracy Streckenbach, president and chief operating officer of Innovative Global Brands, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Why Campaign Reporters Are Behind the Curve
text: It becomes popular around this time of year to lament the fact that media coverage treats the presidential campaign as little more than a “horse race.” Journalists, this line of argument goes, choose to fixate on which candidate is a superior campaigner or savvier strategist, not on who has sounder ideas or is better prepared to govern. From time to time, the journalists themselves concede that to maintain daily or hourly tension in the contests they promote, they have little choice but to elevate minor poll shifts into major developments.

headline: Mortgage Registry Muddles Foreclosures
text: MORE good news from the housing front last week. Pending home sales rose 2.4 percent in July, to their highest level since April 2010. Mortgage delinquency rates are down: the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported a decline of 6.3 percent at the end of June from the March quarter.

headline: Czech Town’s Other Pride
text: The Czech Republic, with a little more than 10 million people, has produced a disproportionate number of tennis champions. Aside from tennis trophies, another thing the Czechs hoist in disproportionate amounts is beer. Unlike in tennis, the Czechs have little competition in this category, with the average citizen consuming 131 liters a year, more than Germany, Austria and Ireland by 25 liters.

headline: Letters: A Task Unfinished, a Lesson Learned
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: Breaking the Silence on a Carbon Tax
text: To the Editor:

headline: Harrison Brothers Advance to Third Round
text: The American brothers Christian and Ryan Harrison defeated the veteran Israeli doubles team of Jonathan Erlich and Andy Ram, 6-4, 6-4, on Saturday in the second round of the United States Open.

headline: Lengthy Deal, Shrinking E.R.A.
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — In 1996, the year he turned 7, Matt Moore moved with his family to Kadena Air Base in Okinawa, Japan. His father, Marty, worked on Special Operations helicopters and was transferred there from Florida.

headline: Can Europe Survive the Rise of the Rest?
text: Oxford, England

headline: Sharing the Stage
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — As quarterback Greg McElroy conducted an interview after the Jets’ preseason finale Thursday in Philadelphia, Mark Sanchez started plotting the prank. Nodding toward McElroy, Sanchez motioned to the teammate standing between them to pass an orange wedge. Sanchez crept behind McElroy and shoved the fruit down the back of his T-shirt. While McElroy squirmed, Sanchez bumped fists with his co-conspirator, Tim Tebow.

headline: A Weight-Loss Strategy From an Unlikely Pair
text: WHEN Myles Berkowitz first met Steven Kates through a mutual friend in 2006, Mr. Berkowitz had serious doubts about him.

headline: When GPS Confuses, You May Be to Blame
text: The turn-by-turn instructions of GPS-based navigation systems, ingeniously designed though they may be, can’t always save us from ourselves.

headline: German Drug Maker Apologizes to Victims of Thalidomide
text: LONDON — Decades of campaigning by victims of thalidomide, a morning sickness drug, have taken a new turn, with the first apology in 50 years to the victims and their families by the drug’s German manufacturer — and an incensed rejection of the apology as too little and too late from many of those it was intended to placate.

headline: On Top, but Off Radar
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In previous years, the Giants have been quick to embrace Coach Tom Coughlin’s seasonal slogan as a mantra, with the two most notable refrains — “Talk is cheap, play the game” and “Finish” — being featured prominently in the 2007 and 2011 Super Bowl championship seasons.

headline: Troubled Times for Plaquemines Parish
text: Venice sits at the end of the road in Plaquemines Parish, the peninsula of southeastern Louisiana that was the first landing point of Hurricane Isaac and the scene of perhaps its most thorough destruction.

headline: Murray Holds It Together in the Heat, and Federer Cruises to a Win
text: The Big Four in men’s tennis came to New York minus Rafael Nadal, and for stretches of Saturday afternoon it looked as if the three present might be reduced to two.

headline: Two Americans Are Buried a Year After a Train Crash in China
text: A year ago, Cao Erxing and his wife, Chen Zengrong, both 56, were killed in a high-speed train crash in China. But it was not until Saturday that their relatives in New York City were finally able to gather to mourn their loss and bury their loved ones.

headline: Music of the Unquiet Mind
text: John Cage’s 1944 piece “Four Walls” translated the innermost rooms of my obsessive-compulsive mind into sound.

headline: Mitt Romney and Abortion Politics
text: My Sunday column looks at the GOP and reproductive health, from abortion to sex education. As you can see from the column, I think it’s a pathetic sight — but in fairness, one point I wish I had had space for in the column is to note that if the Republican platform is baffling in its message to centrist voters, it’s also arguably a rare example of political courage. Republicans are looking at the same polls I am, and presumably they realize that their reluctance to back exceptions in abortion bans for rape or the health of the mother risk losing voters. It’s not often that politicians risk losing votes for something that they believe in, and I give them credit for that — even though I think their positions are utter nonsense. Your thoughts?

headline: ‘Framing’ Prevents Needed Stimulus
text: WHY have so many teachers, police officers, firefighters and other public workers been laid off since the financial crisis hit — and why are so few being offered new jobs now?

headline: Obama Visits Swing States Before Convention
text: URBANDALE, Iowa — With his party’s nominating convention approaching next week, President Obama started a four-day, four-state campaign trip on Saturday in Iowa, the state where he opened his quest for the presidency five years ago.

headline: Ryan’s Latest Reclamation Project Stands Out Right Away
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets and the Rams thought that by swapping tackles, each could salvage an underperforming player and improve in pass protection. After putting tackle Jason Smith through a crash course on the playbook and evaluating his performance in the preseason finale, the Jets proclaimed themselves satisfied with the deal.

headline: Trying to Win Race He Helped Save
text: BALTIMORE — J. P. Grant III knows far more about financing than he does about auto racing. But he is a big civic booster, and he believes that the Indy-car race on the streets around the Inner Harbor can become like the Preakness — only with more horsepower.

headline: 30 Seconds With Fredy Montero
text: After coming off the bench in four of the previous six games, Fredy Montero returned to the Seattle Sounders’ starting lineup last weekend against Chivas USA and scored his first hat trick in his 100th game in Major League Soccer. That increased his season total to 11 goals, giving him four consecutive seasons with 10 or more for the Sounders.

headline: Duquette and Orioles Back in the Game
text: More than most, Dan Duquette understands the need to share credit for a team’s success. As the general manager of the Boston Red Sox from 1994 to 2001, Duquette acquired many of the players who would win the team’s first championship in 86 years, in 2004. While his successor, Theo Epstein, got the glory, Duquette spent nearly a decade without a job in the majors.

headline: In a Ban, a Measure of European Tolerance
text: PARIS — During a recent protest in Marseille, seven people were suddenly surrounded by the police, bundled into a van and brought in for questioning. Their offense was not the demonstration itself but the balaclavas they were wearing, a violation of the French law banning full-face veils in public places, passed in April 2011.

headline: In a Post-Convention Bump, Romney Draws Huge Crowds in Cincinnati
text: CINCINNATI – A crowd of thousands cheered Mitt Romney at a rally here during the opening leg of a cross-country campaign swing on Saturday, testing for the first time whether he can sustain political momentum coming out of the Republican National Convention.

headline: Forward Progress
text: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — “The perfect time to tell this story is after we win the Super Bowl this year.”

headline: ‘Good Girls’ Fight to Be Journalists
text: WHEN I graduated from college, before the Civil Rights Act of 1964 took effect, sex discrimination was legal. I wanted to write for a newspaper or newsmagazine, but despite an armload of credentials and skills, I soon learned the score: Women could do research, be secretaries and, if very lucky, work for the ghetto called the women’s page. But other than that, the guys were hired as the writers, and that was that.

headline: Unified, in America, by an International Sport
text: On a makeshift court in Minneapolis, victorious players locked arms around one another’s necks and broke into an unusual cheer.

headline: Don’t Shy Away From Growth Stocks
text: WHEN economic worries rattle the markets, some investors take cover in defensive areas, like slow-but-steady utilities. This is what has driven the “risk-off” trade that Wall Street types talk about.

headline: Inquiry on Tax Strategy Adds to Scrutiny of Finance Firms
text: The New York attorney general is investigating whether some of the nation’s biggest private equity firms have abused a tax strategy in order to slice hundreds of millions of dollars from their tax bills, according to executives with direct knowledge of the inquiry.

headline: 30 Yards in the Air or 3 Yards in the Dust?
text: The Giants had finished the first practice of training camp this summer when Coach Tom Coughlin, in a moment that might have seemed to come out of the mid-1970s, announced his hopes for the new season.

headline: Hopes Are Dashed to Have Regular N.F.L. Officials Back for First Week
text: Negotiations between the N.F.L. and its locked-out officials broke off Saturday morning, all but ensuring that replacement referees would work at least the first week of the regular season, which starts Wednesday. No further talks were scheduled.

headline: When the Work-Life Scales Are Unequal
text: KELLY Azevedo used to work upward of 70 hours a week.

headline: In Flexible-Work Debates, Parents Have Unique Position
text: When it comes to workplace flexibility, fair doesn’t always mean equal.

headline: Yankees Get a Lift from the Newcomer Pearce
text: Steve Pearce was surprised when the Baltimore Orioles designated him for assignment July 21, but he believed the demotion was temporary. He was fully prepared to report to Class AAA Norfolk with the expectation that he would soon be recalled to join the Orioles in a pennant race.

headline: At Age 59, Interning to Fulfill Old Dream
text: ONE of the things I’ve learned is that career plans often go awry. Industries change, health problems arise, a baby comes along or other events intervene. I had always planned to become a mental health counselor, but I veered off course years ago and am interning in the field for the first time at age 59.

headline: The Value of Starting Small
text: I GREW up in Minneapolis. My mother, a former teacher, went back to work when my younger brother went to kindergarten. I was 8. She had a friend whose child had a disability, which inspired the two of them to start the nonprofit Pacer Center. They wanted to help parents of children with disabilities and expand the opportunities for these youngsters. My mother still runs the organization today.

headline: New Era at Penn State Starts With Loss at Home
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — The Penn State faithful would have stood here even if they could not see a thing. Thousands of them did. They held their sons and daughters on their shoulders for a glimpse. Down the street they lined up, holding signs that read, “You stayed with us ...,” and on the back, “... We stand with you.”

headline: Obama on Reddit, Ryan in Tweets
text: Ben Smith of BuzzFeed talks with The Times’s Jim Roberts about headlines in social media at the 2012 Republican National Convention.

headline: Hal David, Songwriter, Is Dead at 91
text: Hal David, the Oscar- and Grammy-winning lyricist who in the 1960s and ’70s gave pop music vernacular the questions “What’s it all about?,” “What’s new, pussycat?,” “Do you know the way to San Jose?” and “What do you get when you fall in love?,” died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 91 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: Tony Hayward Gets His Life Back
text: LONDON

headline: After Fed Action, Then What?
text: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — The Fed is on the verge of expanding its stimulus policies. We learned that much during the meetings in Jackson Hole, Wyo. But what may be more interesting is the undercurrent of discussion about what happens when those measures prove insufficient.

headline: The Summit Series of 1972: Talking With J.P. Parise
text: September marks the 40th anniversary of the Summit Series, the unforgettable clash between the N.H.L. professionals of Team Canada and the titans of international hockey, the Soviet national team.

headline: Pardon Ze Interruption
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Who knew there were so many ways to spell the sound “zee”?

headline: The Agenda: Foreign Policy
text: The Times’s Cairo bureau chief David Kirkpatrick discusses the future of foreign policy. Mitt Romney’s foreign policy adviser Kristen Silverberg weighs in with The Times’s Marcus Mabry.

headline: Syrian Refugees Pour Into Jordan
text: Nearly 2,000 Syrians are flooding nightly into Jordan, which says it has accepted about 180,000 refugees since the conflict began.

headline: Airstrikes Push Waves of Syrians to Jordanian Camps
text: ZAATARI, Jordan — The five Jamous brothers were early recruits to the Free Syrian Army, eager to oust President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: A Nose for Research
text: A dog named Tucker has become an unexpected star in the realm of canine-assisted science.

headline: A Delayed Mourning
text: After more than a year of fighting with Chinese government officials, the sons of two Americans killed in a train crash finally buried their parents in Queens.

headline: Alexander Saxton, Historian and Novelist, Dies at 93
text: Alexander Saxton, who would go on to become a prominent historian of race in America, summed himself up in a blurb on the dust jacket of his first novel, “Grand Crossing,” published when he was 24.

headline: Isaac’s Vestiges Bring Midwest Rain
text: The remnants of Hurricane Isaac, the slow-moving storm that disrupted the Republican National Convention and flooded towns along the Gulf Coast, brought much-needed rain to the Midwest on Saturday, along with scattered reports of tornadoes.

headline: Party Intrigue Seen in China as Official Is Demoted
text: SHANGHAI — Ling Jihua, a senior Chinese official and a close ally of President Hu Jintao, was named Saturday to a new post in a move that some Communist Party experts said was a demotion and a surprising development ahead of this year’s leadership transition.

headline: Byard Lancaster, Jazz Alto Saxophonist, Dies at 70
text: Byard Lancaster, an alto saxophonist who took part in the great wave of free jazz inspired by John Coltrane and then diversified far into other music and cultures — living in Nigeria, France and Chicago, playing blues, reggae and Afrobeat — but kept returning to Philadelphia, his hometown, died on Aug. 23 at a hospice in Wyndmoor, Pa. He was 70.

headline: The Summit Series of 1972: Talking With Vladimir Petrov
text: Forty years ago Sunday, on Sept. 2, 1972, in Montreal, one of the most stunning upsets in the history of sports took place. Team Canada — an N.H.L. all-star team led by Phil Esposito, Brad Park, Yvan Cournoyer, Frank and Peter Mahovlich, Bobby Clarke,Ken Dryden and the Rangers’ GAG Line of Jean Ratelle, Rod Gilbert and Vic Hadfield — met the Soviet national team, the world and Olympic champion but a group that had never played a game against professional opponents.

headline: Almagro Ends Sock’s Run in Four Sets
text: Nicolas Almagro of Spain will advance to the fourth round of the United States Open for the first time after fighting off a spirited challenge from the up-and-coming American teenager Jack Sock on Saturday afternoon. Almagro, seeded 11th, pulled out a 7-6 (3), 6-7 (4), 7-6 (2), 6-1 victory in the sultry afternoon heat of the half-sunbaked, half-shaded Grandstand Stadium.

headline: Peter Shelton, Architect Who Made Luxury Minimal, Dies at 67
text: Peter Shelton, an award-winning architect whose sleek yet luxurious interior designs won his firm commissions for the homes of wealthy people and for corporate showcases like the headquarters of Polo Ralph Lauren, died on Aug. 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.

headline: In Battle for Round of 16, Cilic Prevails Over Nishikori
text: Early in the third set, into a sky bright with a blistering sun, Kei Nishikori of Japan tossed the ball high and aced Marin Cilic of Croatia to take a 4-3 lead. For nearly 2,800 spectators, there was hope that the contest might extend beyond three sets.  They got their wish.

headline: Once They Stopped Laughing, Things Got Serious Fast
text: On a September afternoon in Montreal in 1972, I stood next to the Rangers’ Brad Park at the Forum as we watched the Soviet Union’s best hockey players go through their bizarre practice rituals. In one routine, they swarmed at center ice like mad bees.

headline: Sept. 1: Romney’s Convention Bounce Appears Middling So Far
text: The Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla. received mediocre television ratings — and the polling data so far suggests that it may produce only a modest bounce in the polls for Mitt Romney.

headline: Giving Juveniles Intensive Counseling
text: MART — The green-black lines of prison life are scrawled on 16-year-old Luis’s face: a cross on his left cheek, three dots arranged in a triangle under his left eye and “cholo” written vertically on his right cheek.

headline: McIlroy Attracts Following at TPC Boston, but Not All Are Watching Him
text: NORTON, Mass. — The willowy woman with the blond ponytail and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis oversize sunglasses was standing outside the gallery ropes Saturday morning at the T.P.C. Boston waiting for Rory McIlroy to walk past when one man produced a tennis ball for her to sign. He was followed by another fan with another tennis ball. She obliged both with a smile while a bystander observing the scene from a few feet away turned to a friend and asked, “Why the tennis balls?”

headline: Taking a Break From Poker to Win a Championship
text: The French championship was notable for the outcome on the women’s side and for a stirring display of sportsmanship among the men in the face of tragedy.

headline: Top Official at ICE Quits Over Discrimination Claims
text: WASHINGTON — A senior official at the Department of Homeland Security resigned on Saturday after accusations that she had created a sexualized office culture that was hostile to men. The official, Suzanne Barr, is a longtime aide to the department’s secretary, Janet Napolitano, and had been on leave from her position as chief of staff to the director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement because of the allegations.

headline: Singing Her Way Toward Exit, Sundhage Steps Down as U.S. Coach
text: ROCHESTER — Before the first game of a victory tour by the gold-medal-winning United States women’s soccer team, Coach Pia Sundhage decided it was time to go home to Sweden.

headline: Sometimes Being a Fighter Isn’t Enough
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Sundhage Leaving U.S. Women’s National Team
text: Pia Sundhage is taking her tactics, her teaching and her singing voice home to Sweden.

headline: U.S. Open: Day 6
text: Serena Williams and Roger Federer advanced, but Jack Sock, a 19-year-old unseeded American, was ousted in the third round.

headline: Reflecting on Ambitious Education Plan
text: At a tense meeting of the University of Texas System Board of Regents on Aug. 25, 2011, after several months in which the board was at the center of a tug of war between groups with differing approaches to higher-education reform, Chancellor Francisco G. Cigarroa unveiled his Framework for Advancing Excellence.

headline: TimesCast Politics | August 30, 7 P.M.
text: Part one of Thursday evening's broadcast of the Republican National Convention.

headline: Clinton Begins Asia Trip, Trying to Ease Tension With China
text: RAROTONGA, Cook Islands — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton began a 10-day, 6-nation visit to Asia pledging to broaden American diplomatic, economic and security support in the Pacific, but also offering conciliatory remarks toward China at a time when tensions are rising over territorial disputes.

headline: Big-Box Store Has New Life as an Airy Public Library
text: McALLEN, Tex. — The hulking husk of a vacant Walmart here in the Rio Grande Valley is enjoying an unlikely second act. When the big-box retailer moved to a larger location down the street, the building might have been destined to house yet another large chain or to fall into disrepair. But rather than let it become an eyesore, the city scooped it up and spent $24 million transforming the drab structure into a 123,000-square-foot public library that serves as a vibrant space for residents here.

headline: Kurt Maetzig, Pioneering German Director, Dies at 101
text: Kurt Maetzig, a pioneering East German director whose socialist films scrutinized anti-Semitism, explored corporate complicity in the rise of fascism and helped compel Germans to come to terms with their Nazi past, died on Aug. 8 at his home in Germany. He was 101.

headline: Radwanska, Seeded Second but Nearly Unknown, Beats Jankovic
text: The second seed in women’s singles at the United States Open finally played in Arthur Ashe Stadium on Saturday. Even then, she remained largely unknown outside the more hard-core tennis fans.

headline: Conversations With Andy Murray: Questions From Readers
text: Andy Murray defeated Feliciano Lopez, 7-6 (5), 7-6 (5), 4-6, 7-6 (4), on Saturday to reach the fourth round of the United States Open. In his regular postmatch interview with Straight Sets, Murray took questions from readers of The New York Times who sent their inquiries from all over the world.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 2
text: Presidential politics will again dominate the conversations on the news shows on Sunday, on the weekend between the closing of the Republican National Convention and the opening of the Democratic National Convention.

headline: The Other Power in the West Wing
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama was in a bind, and his chief of staff could not figure out how he had ended up there.

headline: In a Tactical Test, Romney Stakes Hopes on Ohio

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: TimesCast Politics | August 30, 7 P.M.
text: Part two of Thursday evening's broadcast of the Republican National Convention.

headline: Ninth-Inning Rally Sends Mets Past Marlins
text: MIAMI — It looked as if the good vibes that had been carrying the Mets through late August would not last one game into September.

headline: Clijsters, Whose First Retirement Didn’t Take, Says Her Latest One Will
text: Kim Clijsters walked onto the Court 17 at the United States Open on Saturday night with her signature smile, waved to the crowd and to her family in the stands and wielded her tennis racket for what was very likely the last time as a professional.

headline: Lottery Numbers
College Football Replay
text: The nation watched to see a new era of Penn State football begin, and the Ohio State Buckeyes, led by Coach Urban Meyer, open the season with a win.

headline: Anne Szeker, Leif Detlefsen
text: Anne Elizabeth Szeker and Leif Arthur Detlefsen were married Saturday evening at the Riverfront Boathouse in Hartford. Steven S. Mitchell, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

headline: Dana Litowitz, Nathaniel Stokoe
text: Dana Dubin Litowitz, the daughter of Robert D. Litowitz of Bethesda, Md., and the late Karen A. Dubin, is to be married Sunday evening to Nathaniel Lee Stokoe, the son of Caroline Lee and James Stokoe of Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi William Rudolph is to perform the ceremony at the Sixth and I Historic Synagogue in Washington.

headline: Lily Sutton, Ryan Hagen
text: Lily Anna Bers Sutton, the daughter of Edith D. Bers and Paul J. Sutton of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday evening at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass., to Ryan Alansson Lee Hagen, the son of Judith K. Hagen of Rhinebeck, N.Y., and Kevin A. Hagen of Albuquerque. The bride’s father, who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, is to officiate.

headline: Meredith Wall, David DeCarlo
text: Meredith Rita Wall and David William DeCarlo are to be married Sunday at Holy Family Parish in Inverness, Ill. The Rev. Patrick Brennan, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony.

text: Leela Sarathy, a daughter of Beth S. Goldstein and Ravi Sarathy of Newton, Mass., is to be married Sunday to David William Smith, the son of Star and Christopher Smith of West Windsor, N.J. Rabbi David Kudan will officiate at the Museum of Science in Boston.

text: Rachel Fellner Cotton and Philip Berkeley Trout are to be married Sunday at the weekend home of the bride’s mother in Washington Depot, Conn. Judge Amy Berman Jackson of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia is to officiate, with Maria P. Rivera, an associate justice on the California First District Court of Appeal, taking part.

headline: Hillary Robbie, Maximillian Cavaleri
text: Hillary Kay Robbie and Maximillian Camillo Cavaleri are to be married Sunday evening at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Cantor Edward Robin is to officiate.

headline: Francesca Wilmott, James Stanley
text: Francesca Carol Wilmott, a daughter of Cathryn M. Wilmott and Dr. Robert W. Wilmott of St. Louis, was married Saturday to James Edward Stanley, a son of Dr. Ellen Li and Dr. Samuel L. Stanley Jr. of Old Field, N.Y. The Rev. Margaret H. Allen, a Unitarian Universalist minister, led the ceremony at Sunwood Estate in Old Field.
