text: Alison Elisabeth Fisher, the daughter of Nancy Collins Fisher and Richard W. Fisher of Dallas, is to be married Sunday to William Ware Smith III, the son of Isabella Williams Smith and Mr. Smith Jr. of Roanoke, Va. The Rev. Henry H. Edens III, an Episcopal priest, will officiate at the Moran, Wyo., vacation home of Roger Altman, a former deputy secretary of the Treasury and the bride’s godfather.

headline: Beth Reisfeld, Charles Lesch
text: Beth Lynn Reisfeld, the daughter of Carol L. Reisfeld and Dr. Peter L. Reisfeld of Dix Hills, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Charles Harry Taylor Lesch, the son of Prof. Paula S. Fass and Prof. John E. Lesch of Berkeley, Calif. The wedding is to be held at Bridgewaters in Manhattan, with Rabbi Shlomo Shulman officiating. Rabbi Richard G. Hirsch, a cousin of the groom, is to take part.

headline: Campaign References to Afghanistan Are Missing In Action
text: HONG KONG — The war in Afghanistan — the longest conflict in U.S. history at 128 months and counting — was barely mentioned onstage at the Republican National Convention last week. The actor Clint Eastwood made a loopy and apparently unscripted reference to the war, but in his acceptance speech the presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, did not once bring up the A-word.

headline: U.S. Hopes Dimming as Stephens Falls Short
text: America’s tennis fans were full of hope at the start of the third round of the United States Open on Saturday.

headline: Rookie Chen Stays Steady in Rotation for Orioles
text: Last April, Wei-Yin Chen had a rough initiation into the major leagues. Minutes after he stepped onto the mound to make his first start for the Baltimore Orioles in April, he watched as his fifth pitch whipped off the bat of Derek Jeter and landed 421 feet from home plate at Camden Yards for a home run.

headline: Alabama Shows It May Not Be No. 2 for Long
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — That Alabama was ranked No. 2 as it opened defense of its 14th national championship did not register much ire heading into Saturday night’s clash with No. 8 Michigan. Still, a fan joyously held aloft a sign deep into the fourth quarter that read, “Road to 15 starts in Big D,” a reference to the only mission that matters to Crimson Tide faithful.

headline: U.S. Halts Training Program for Some Afghan Recruits
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The training of Afghan Local Police and special operations forces has been put on hold while their American trainers conduct stricter vetting to try to root out any infiltrators or new recruits who could pose risks to the coalition troops working with them, American officials say.

headline: Has the ‘Burqa Ban’ Worked in France?
text: PARIS — The French law banning the full-face veil from public spaces has been controversial from the start, with loud debates about the meaning of liberty, individual rights, the freedoms of religion and expression, and the nature of laïcité, or secularism, in the French republic.

headline: How the Top 25 in College Football Fared
text: 1. SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA (1-0) beat Hawaii, 49-10.

headline: What Would a President Romney Mean for the Arab Spring? For Europe?
text: In our video piece above, David Kirkpatrick, the Cairo bureau chief of The New York Times, explains the challenges and contradictions of America’s Mideast policy — whoever wins the election in November. And the Bush administration’s last ambassador to the European Union, Kristen Silverberg, a foreign policy adviser to Mitt Romney, outlines to me how a Romney foreign policy would differ from that of President Barack Obama.

headline: After Verdict, Assessing the Samsung Strategy in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — When a jury in San Jose, Calif., ordered Samsung Electronics to pay $1.05 billion in damages for violating Apple’s patents for the iPhone and iPad, it did more than decide who had infringed upon whose intellectual property. To South Koreans, the legal battle highlighted the strengths and weaknesses of both Samsung and their economy in general.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: The Supreme Court’s decision to uphold Ajmal Kasab’s death sentence has once again brought into focus the death penalty debate in India. Frontline, in its cover story, “A Case against the Death Penalty,” analyzes some gray areas in the debate.

headline: What to Watch on Sunday
text: Retirement looked like the furthest thing from Andy Roddick’s mind on Friday night as the former No. 1 dismissed the tricky Bernard Tomic in just under 90 minutes.

headline: Mitt Romney, Weaponized Keynesian
text: OK, I missed this. From Romney’s acceptance speech, attacking Obama:

headline: Bronx Community College Gets a Library, and Building, Truly Its Own
text: The new North Hall and Library at Bronx Community College had scarcely been open a day when Dorian Whyte, 21, and Jang Sung Soo, 22, sat down last week to study physics on the light-filled balcony wrapping around an enormous central reading room. Neither had any books in front of him. But they were evidently enjoying the place.

headline: In Pivotal Week for Euro Zone, a Test for the Central Bank’s Leader
text: FRANKFURT — The last time Mario Draghi addressed the news media after a meeting of the European Central Bank, on Aug. 2, he disappointed investors who wanted him to crack his whip and immediately bring bond markets to heel. The markets dropped even before Mr. Draghi was done speaking.

headline: Henry Herx, Film Critic for Catholic Publications, Dies at 79
text: Henry Herx, who over three decades wrote thousands of movie reviews for Roman Catholic publications, assessing the moral complexities raised on screen through the prism of church tenets, died on Aug. 15 at his home in Ramsey, N.J. He was 79.

headline: Parties Do Some Convention Spin on Sunday Talk Shows
text: WASHINGTON — It would probably be safe to say, based on the reviews of the Republican convention offered Sunday by some of President Obama’s top advisers, that the gloves are officially off as Democrats look forward to their own turn on the convention stage in Charlotte.

headline: Scenes from a Subculture
text: A look inside the world of youth dance competitions.

headline: South Africa Lifts Charges of Murder in Mine Strike
text: JOHANNESBURG — Prosecutors provisionally dropped murder charges against the 270 jailed miners who had been accused under an obscure legal doctrine of killing 34 of their own colleagues when the police opened fire on them while engaged in a wildcat strike.

headline: Tap-Tap-Tapping Into a National Obsession
text: On a Sunday morning in February — Super Bowl Sunday, as a matter of fact — out past the strip malls and the auto dealerships and worlds away from nearby Seattle, families streamed into the Highline Performing Arts Center in Burien, Wash., for a traditional American orgy of razzmatazz and rivalries.

headline: Afghans Protest Vengeful Militias
text: KANAM, Afghanistan — On the bed of this village’s only pickup truck, three bullet-riddled bodies were laid out on Sunday, hastily wrapped in sheets. Behind the truck, several cars, their hatchbacks propped open as they bounced down the dirt roads, carried one or two bodies each. All 15 of the village’s vehicles, most of them shabby and old, joined the grim convoy, stuffed with 200 distraught relatives and 11 of their dead.

headline: Mishmash Not
text: Props to Eddie Lazear; he’s a loyal Republican who’s been saying a lot of things I consider totally wrong lately, but his paper for Jackson Hole (pdf) is a professional, well-done piece that offers little aid and comfort to his political allies.

headline: Golf Shoes for on the Course and on the Town
text: Watching golf on television, you may have noticed that golf shoes are shrinking. The minimalist movement is most obviously exemplified by the casual, street-style shoes some professionals have begun wearing in competition.

headline: The Greg Norman Fan Club Is a Mutual Admiration Society
text: Greg Norman’s name still comes up an awful lot even though he has played in only three PGA Tour events in the last five years.

headline: Shorter Days and a Chill in the Air Can Warm Fate’s Heart
text: I have a theory that the golf gods go on vacation in the fall. In the summer, they are much too busy to take time off. They have the major championships to keep an eye on, all the amateur tournaments and thousands of club championships.

headline: With ’08 on Their Minds, Democrats Gather in Charlotte
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Democrats will gather here on Tuesday to nominate President Obama for a second term in the White House, setting in motion the final sprint to Election Day.

headline: Isaac Brings Touch of Relief, and Hope for Next Season, to Corn Belt
text: WARRENTON, Mo. — All through the scorching summer, as their crops withered under cloudless skies, Corn Belt farmers waited and prayed for this moment. Now, courtesy of Hurricane Isaac, it has finally arrived: three days of rain to soak their parched fields and soften the cracked soil.

headline: Aliens With Dance Moves and the Midas Touch
text: There might be a utopian vision inside Shirish Kunder’s “Joker,” a Bollywood comedy about establishing contact with extraterrestrials. But if so, it’s buried under a mountain of static.

headline: A SEAL’s Own Story, Bin Laden and All
text: The Navy SEALs who killed Osama bin Laden on May 2, 2011, learned from ABC News that they had “gazelle legs, no waist, and a huge upper body configuration,” not to mention calloused hands and gigantic egos. They learned from other American news sources that they had taken part in a 45-minute firefight and that an armed bin Laden, once cornered, had tried to defend himself in his final moments, staring straight at the fighters who would shoot him. Their raid was being turned into a bad action movie.

headline: Mormon Says Romneys Are Leading Church Into Mainstream
text: BOSTON – With Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, looking on, a prominent member of the Mormon church, J.W. Marriott Jr., told his congregation on Sunday that the Romneys were helping to lead the church “out of obscurity” and into the mainstream.

headline: Despite Eviction, Settlers of West Bank Outpost Maintain Goal
text: MIGRON, West Bank — The police officers went door to door on Sunday morning in this hilltop settlement outpost east of the West Bank city of Ramallah, handing out final eviction notices and waiting patiently for residents to come out.

headline: Double Faults Prove Verdasco’s Undoing
text: Double faulting is absolutely the worst way to lose a point in tennis.

headline: Dark Tale Told in an Atmospheric Tongue
text: Janacek’s “Jenufa,” which Opera Slavica presented in a wrenching performance on Thursday evening at the Bohemian National Hall, has always struck me as a thoroughly wintry work. That may be because of its almost ceaseless grimness, or because its final act includes the discovery of a murdered baby, buried in ice. But then, much of the music that Opera Slavica specializes in — the Russian and Czech repertory — is set in dark, chilly landscapes. So a challenge that faces the company’s young singers, along with bringing the music and characters to life, is evoking a suitably icy spirit for an audience that has just wandered in from the summer heat.

headline: Seeing One Child Off to Preschool, Another to High School
text: When my daughter, now 4, was born, I was 44 1/2. The half is important — or was, to me, at the time, as I imagined the late summer morning I would drop her off five and a half years hence to start kindergarten, when she’d be 5 1/2.

headline: For Stephens, Lessons in a Loss to Ivanovic
text: Ana Ivanovic raised her level of play late in the second set, then stayed on the attack to come from a set down to beat Sloane Stephens at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Saturday night to advance to the fourth round of the United States Open. The match turned Ivanovic’s way when Stephens’s first-serve percentage plummeted and Ivanovic moved inside the baseline to attack the second serve. This led to four breaks of serve for Ivanovic, a pivotal break at 4 all in the second set followed by three service breaks in the final set. And as the pressure on her second serve mounted, Stephens began to visibly struggle with her serve, giving away six points on double faults in the third set as the tall, lithe Ivanovic moved even further inside the baseline.

headline: U.S. Companies Brace for an Exit From the Euro by Greece
text: Even as Greece desperately tries to avoid defaulting on its debt, American companies are preparing for what was once unthinkable: that Greece could soon be forced to leave the euro zone.

headline: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, Self-Proclaimed Messiah Who Built Religious Movement, Dies at 92
text: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the Korean evangelist, businessman and self-proclaimed messiah who built a religious movement notable for its mass weddings, fresh-faced proselytizers and links to vast commercial interests, died on Monday in Gapyeong, South Korea. He was 92.

headline: Everybody Does It
text: That seems to be the new Beltway line, now that the shock over the lie-fest in Tampa has died down a bit. At the Washington Post (except at Ezra’s blog), at Politico, and so on, it’s excuse time — sure, Ryan and Romney told a few whoppers, but isn’t that just how politics is?

headline: In Swing State, Ryan Shows His Ohio Chops
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Before Mitt Romney announced a running mate, many political strategists predicted he would choose Senator Rob Portman of Ohio, if for no other reason than his home state is a must-win state for the Romney campaign.

headline: Bay’s Power Makes Rare Appearance for Mets
text: MIAMI — Things have been going well for the Mets of late. They have not for outfielder Jason Bay.

headline: Rivals Jostle Before Apple Announces New iPhone
text: Back when Apple was an underdog, it had an easier time shrouding its product announcements in mystery and perhaps catching its competitors off guard.

headline: The Hippocratic Oath, With Fingers Crossed
text: There was a moment when it seemed as if Lauren Ambrose would be taking on 2012’s scariest acting assignment. She was cast in the Barbra Streisand role in a revival of “Funny Girl” that was to hit Broadway in April. Reprising the career-defining role of a legend? Yeah, that’s scary.

headline: Electronic Dance Music Goes Hollywood
text: Once marginalized as a novel European import, electronic dance music, or E.D.M., has become the dominant trend in American pop these days. Its lively synthetic beats and booming bass lines are inescapable, and its top D.J.’s draw sold-out crowds to outdoor raves like Electric Daisy Carnival and even rock bastions like Lollapalooza and Coachella, earning them thousands, if not millions, of dollars for a single set.

headline: Eat and Run to Another Channel
text: In the world of lifestyle television, few people get as much attention as Anthony Bourdain, and it’s fair to ask why a middle-aged former chef whose TV show draws fewer than 500,000 viewers deserves so much ink. (Figuratively speaking.)

headline: Yankees Still Have the East Lead, but the Orioles Have the Momentum
text: The third question to Manager Joe Girardi about his ill-fated choice to leave Phil Hughes in to face Mark Reynolds in the sixth inning drew his ire.

headline: Is Riff Raff Eccentric? Yes. Next Question?
text: The Riff Raff concert on Thursday night at Santos Party House began with a news conference, podium and all, except it wasn’t nearly a news conference. It was after midnight in a sweaty, crowded nightclub, and Riff Raff, wearing a pink neon windbreaker, mostly took banal questions from the crowd: Will Riff Raff bring the rice out? “Rice shall be brought.” (More on the rice later.) Does Riff Raff play basketball? “I hoop so good I damn near could’ve been Sheryl Swoopes.”

headline: Telluride Film Festival: Geoff Dyer, Tarkovsky’s ‘Stalker,’ Chaplin and More
text: Late Saturday night, near the end a lively dinner at a local restaurant, Tom Luddy, one of the Telluride Film Festival’s triumvirate of directors, was lamenting that journalists covering the festival focus too much on the Oscar race. Timing has something to do with this. Telluride, synchronous with Venice and just ahead of Toronto, is inevitably one of the first steps on the long march to the Dolby Theater. For the past two years it has presented the eventual Best Picture winner. The presence of movie stars stopping through to receive tributes, answer audience questions and humbly promote their new movies may also contribute to the hype. Bill Murray, Ben Affleck, Dennis Quaid and Marion Cotillard are all here doing just that, sometimes accompanied by thunder and lightning at Elks Park in the center of town.

headline: Left Alone by Its Owner, Reddit Soars
text: There are many ways to measure the traction of a social media platform: time spent, page views or unique users. But it might be useful to add one more metric: if the leader of the free world stops by to answer questions from your users, you’re probably doing O.K.

headline: In Praise of the Clash of Cultures
text: We humans are deeply divided on fundamental moral, religious and philosophical questions. But that can be a good thing.

headline: Obama Casts Republicans as Stuck in the Past
text: BOULDER, Colo. — As President Obama heads into the Democratic National Convention this week, he is seizing on the just-concluded Republican convention to ramp up his argument that Mitt Romney and his party are stuck in the policies of the past and are afraid to spell out the details of their plans.

headline: Roddick Staves Off Retirement With a Win
text: For stretches after Andy Roddick’s latest victory, the one that extended his farewell tour at least another two days, he seemed unsure how to react — what to do and how to celebrate.

headline: Twitter’s Free Speech Defender
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Alexander Macgillivray, Twitter’s chief lawyer, says that fighting for free speech is more than a good idea. He thinks it is a competitive advantage for his company.

headline: Roddick Is Having His Last Laugh
text: Sure, Andy Roddick said he was retiring, but have you noticed the bounce in his step in his victories against Bernard Tomic and Fabio Fognini?

headline: Be of Use
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Happy Labor Day to all! This will be a brief one today, since I am desperately trying to squeeze every last bit of summer out of this weekend. Also, this is a Monday, and you really don’t need my help for that, do you?

headline: Storm Coverage Online Hints at Future of Times-Picayune
text: As the staff at The Times-Picayune in New Orleans applied their well-developed hurricane-reporting skills last week, it was not just flooded roads and power failures that they contended with. Hurricane Isaac struck the region a month before the paper is to cut back print publication to just three days a week, lose part of its newsroom staff and merge into a new company with the Web site Nola.com.

headline: Ryan Admits Misstating Marathon Time
text: Representative Paul D. Ryan has taken back his claim that he had run a marathon in under three hours, an assertion that had drawn great skepticism in the running community and one that came after his convention speech faced scrutiny for some questionable and misleading statements.

headline: Second World Mind Sports Games, in France
text: At the Second World Mind Sports Games in Lille, France, last month there was a subsidiary event of the subsidiary event.

headline: A Chance to Dance
text: A look at the world of dance competitions for youngsters.

headline: National Geographic Takes Hunter Off TV Show
text: The National Geographic Channel said on Friday that Melissa Bachman, an animal hunter who writes for a blog called “Hardcore Huntress,” will no longer be a participant in the coming reality series “Ultimate Survivor Alaska,” after an online petition protesting her involvement received more than 13,000 signatures in less than 24 hours. According to the Hollywood Reporter’s Web site the petition posted on Change.org by Tim Martell, a Florida resident, called for a boycott of National Geographic and stated that the cable channel had abandoned its “traditional stance of conservation and protection” by working with Ms. Bachman, who also has her own Web site that contains hunting videos, tips and a photographic trophy room. “The National Geographic Channel has carefully considered the public discussion of our series on surviving the wilds of Alaska currently in production and premiering sometime next year,” the cable channel said in a statement. “Upon further reflection we plan to eliminate one of the survivalists from the ensemble cast, Melissa Bachman. Hunting is not the focus of the show, and we regret the misinformation that has clouded what we hope will be an exciting adventure series set in the incredible Alaskan landscape.”

headline: Spanish Filmmaker Wins Prize at Online Festival
text: The Spanish filmmaker David Victori was the grand prize winner of the first Your Film Festival, an online competition sponsored by YouTube, Scott Free Productions and Emirates airlines, for his short film “The Guilt,” about a man out for revenge after his wife’s murder. The announcement was made at the Venice Film Festival on Sunday after his film was selected from a pool of 10 finalists by a jury that included the director Ridley Scott and the actor Michael Fassbender.

headline: ‘Live Read’ Series at Toronto Festival
text: The Toronto International Film Festival will host the latest installment of the director Jason Reitman’s “Live Read” series — in which popular movie scripts are performed by contemporary actors — with an unrehearsed reading of Alan Ball’s screenplay for the 1999 film “American Beauty.” The performance will take place on Thursday at the Ryerson Theater in Toronto; Mr. Reitman, above, will announce the cast for the reading on his Twitter account, @jasonreitman, in the days before the event. Tickets can be purchased at tiff.net/festival. Mr. Reitman created the series last year in collaboration with Elvis Mitchell, a former film critic for The New York Times, for the film society at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Previous entries included presentations of “The Apartment” with Paul Rudd and Emma Stone at the TimesCenter in Manhattan, and “The Big Lebowski” featuring Seth Rogen in Los Angeles, among others.

headline: Garden & Gun Claws Its Way Back From the Brink
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Among the many magazines that were battered by the recession, few survived such a precarious financial state as Garden & Gun.

headline: Young U.S. Player Relishes First Taste of Spotlight
text: At 16, Victoria Duval of Boca Raton, Fla., is signing autographs and basking in the warmth of attention and curiosity befitting a United States girls 18-and-under champion and wild-card entrant in the United States Open women’s singles championship.

headline: A High Line That’s Good for New York
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Hate Attacks in Israel
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Klinsmann Includes Dempsey for Jamaica Qualifiers
text: Clint Dempsey may be out of practice, and possibly out of form, but he is not out of the United States national team.

headline: The Arms Trade Treaty
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Reasons for Public Ire Toward Big Banks
text: To the Editor:

headline: For the Giants, a Leader and Some Fresh Followers
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Michael Coe, who has never started an N.F.L. game, will probably be called upon Wednesday night to help shut down Cowboys receivers Dez Bryant and Miles Austin.

headline: N.F.L. and Officials Still at Odds
text: The N.F.L. sent a memo to its teams Sunday indicating that it thought Friday that it was close to a deal to end the lockout of officials but that negotiations broke off the next day after a brief meeting in which officials made clear that retirement benefits remained the key sticking point. Now, people on both sides say it is doubtful a deal can be completed in time to use regular officials for Week 1, which starts Wednesday when the Giants host the Cowboys.

headline: What Muffins Say About Mitt Romney
text: SOME supporters of Mitt Romney, in an effort to make him seem more human (or at least humanoid), have been disseminating a story, first told by a biographer, about how their candidate has a charmingly eccentric habit: he eats only the tops of muffins. His theory is that during the baking process, the butter sinks to the bottom. This story conveys so many things: our guy is an everyday Joe — he eats muffins, not crumpets. And look, even his breakfast is an opportunity to make disciplined decisions — just think how he’ll do with the budget.

headline: HBO Will Offer Channel by Internet in Northern Europe
text: The pay television service HBO is about to make a lot of Internet users in Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden very happy.

headline: When Capitalists Cared
text: Washington

headline: Small Music Labels to Court Asia
text: To compete in the global marketplace, the major record companies have branches and subsidiaries all over the world. Most small labels do not have that advantage, so for help they are turning to federal and state government agencies.

headline: Rebels Bomb Heavily Guarded Damascus Neighborhood
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rebels set off two bombs among a cluster of military headquarters buildings in the Syrian capital, Damascus, on Sunday, as the new United Nations envoy for Syria pointedly refused to call for President Bashar al-Assad to give up power.

headline: Rounding the Seasonal Mark
text: Other holidays are celebrated for the day and the season itself — Thanksgiving, Christmas, the Fourth of July. But Labor Day, as most of us know it, is a holiday about what comes next.

headline: Alan M. Kriegsman, Who Won Pulitzer for Criticism, Dies at 84
text: Alan M. Kriegsman, a longtime dance critic for The Washington Post and the first dance critic to win a Pulitzer Prize, died on Friday at his home in Washington. He was 84.

headline: At Least Fun in the Sun Isn’t Banned. For Now...
text: LOS ANGELES — “Whatever it is, I’m against it!” Groucho Marx sang in a 1932 picture filmed on the Paramount lot here.

headline: Advertisers Join the Social Video App Showyou
text: As marketers debate the efficacy of online display advertising and users ignore the standard blocks of ads found on many Web sites, many advertisers are turning to videos that blur the line between content and marketing.

headline: Egypt Abuzz as Newsreader on State TV Wears Hijab
text: CAIRO — In what was called a first for Egyptian state television, a woman wearing a head scarf presented headlines in a newscast on Sunday, breaking with a code of secular dress that for decades effectively barred the wearing of Islamic head coverings.

headline: A Pitch-Perfect Voice for a Team in Need of Fine-Tuning
text: When Pia Sundhage became coach of the United States women’s soccer team in November 2007, she gathered her players and sang “The Times They Are A-Changin’.” Sour notes were evident, not in Sundhage’s voice, but in the team’s internal discord.

headline: Pakistani Blasphemy Case Shifts as Cleric Is Arrested
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Muslim cleric at the forefront of a campaign to prosecute a Christian girl for blasphemy has suddenly found himself at risk of facing the same charges, after one of his colleagues went to the authorities and accused him of falsifying evidence of burned holy papers.

headline: Gen. William W. Momyer, Celebrated Pilot, Dies at 95
text: Gen. William W. Momyer, a celebrated World War II fighter pilot who helped plot postwar tactics for the Air Force and commanded aerial combat and bombing operations during the early years of the Vietnam War, died Aug. 10 at an assisted-living center in Merritt Island, Fla. He was 95.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the Institute for Supply Management manufacturing index for August and construction spending for July (Tuesday); revised second-quarter productivity, Automatic Data Processing employment for August, weekly jobless claims, and the I.S.M. service index for August (Thursday); and unemployment for August (Friday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Account Says Navy Author Wrote Book After a Slight
text: The former Navy SEALs member who is a co-author of a first-person account of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden was willing to break “the code of silence” honored by many commandos because of “bad blood” with his former unit, the elite SEAL Team 6, according to a new e-book written by other Special Operations veterans.

headline: For Times Square Patrol, a Stage the Tourists Don’t See
text: The tour began just after dusk, as the lavender sky dissolved into night, backlit by the pulsing luminescence of Times Square.

headline: Likely Successor to Disgraced Brooklyn Party Leader Is a Friend and Protégé
text: Each time a Brooklyn kingmaker falls in this borough of the back-room deal — the tenures of three of the last four Democratic bosses have ended in scandal — the outrage turns to an outcry for one of New York’s last political machines to be dismantled.

headline: Oosthuizen Catches McIlroy With Early Flurry of Birdies
text: NORTON, Mass. — As he stood over his 23-foot birdie attempt on the ninth green Sunday, Louis Oosthuizen never doubted that his stroke would be pure. Playing TPC Boston as if it were a putt-putt course, Oosthuizen made birdies on 8 of the first 10 holes, including seven in a row, on his way to an eight-under-par 63 in the third round of the Deutsche Bank Championship.

headline: After Wedding, Money Box Is the Something Borrowed
text: The bride and groom had said their “I dos,” the guests had danced the night away and the goodbyes were being exchanged as a glorious Saturday night was winding down. And then the maître d’hôtel at the West Sayville Country Club on Long Island noticed something amiss in the coat room: someone inside was clutching the “money box,” the white box in which the guests had deposited envelopes, many filled with cash, intended for the newlyweds.

headline: Ticket Sales Fail to Make Hollywood’s Summer
text: LOS ANGELES — This is one summer Hollywood would like to remake.

headline: Trust, Immigrants and Gov. Brown
text: There is a significant and immediate step Gov. Jerry Brown of California can take to protect community safety and civil liberties in his state.

headline: A Growing Nuclear Program
text: Iran has been developing its nuclear enrichment program since 1985.

headline: As Democratic Convention Nears, Demonstrators Take to the Streets of Charlotte
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Protesters from scores of groups around the country filled the streets of Charlotte on Sunday afternoon to push their agenda as Democrats gathered in the city for their convention.

headline: Success at Open Bodes Well for Britons’ Chances at Wimbledon
text: Whatever happens from here on out at the United States Open, the tennis summer of 2012 shall in no small part be remembered for compelling evidence of a country’s climate change. Those dark clouds of defeatism that hovered for decades over the famed Wimbledon lawns and British tennis have finally rolled out and been replaced by a sky of gold and silver hue and hope.

headline: To Calm Israel, U.S. Offers Ways to Restrain Iran
text: WASHINGTON — With Israel openly debating whether to strike at Iran’s nuclear facilities in the coming months, the Obama administration is moving ahead with a range of steps short of war that it hopes will forestall an Israeli attack, while forcing the Iranians to take more seriously negotiations that are all but stalemated.

headline: When a Coach Called a Shift
text: Frank Solich’s faith in the option offense had been forged and confirmed over an almost three-decade association with Nebraska. Solich played fullback there under Bob Devaney. He coached under Tom Osborne, winning three national championships with the same reliable, grinding attack. When he replaced Osborne, the option helped him win 49 games in his first five seasons, more than either Devaney or Osborne over a similar stretch.

headline: Health Care Where You Work
text: In the scramble to find ways to slow rising health care costs, experts are finding good ideas from organizations that are virtually unknown beyond their hometowns.

headline: Siblings’ Throats Slit by Intruder; Boy, 6, Dies
text: A knife-wielding attacker broke into the bedroom of a boy and a girl in Camden, N.J., early Sunday and slit their throats, killing the boy, the authorities said.

headline: Mexico City’s Aztec Past Reaches Out to Present
text: MEXICO CITY — The skeleton is that of a young woman, perhaps an Aztec noble, found intact and buried in the empire’s most sacred spot more than 500 years ago. Almost 2,000 human bones were heaped around her, and she is a mystery.

headline: A Spotlight With Precedent Beckons a Mayor From Texas
text: SAN ANTONIO — Mayor Julián Castro will be closely watching two elections on Nov. 6.

headline: Rosie Ruiz Republicans
text: Remember Rosie Ruiz? In 1980 she was the first woman to cross the finish line at the Boston Marathon — except it turned out that she hadn’t actually run most of the race, that she sneaked onto the course around a mile from the end. Ever since, she has symbolized a particular kind of fraud, in which people claim credit for achieving things they have not, in fact, achieved.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 2
text: A look at the day in sports around the world, from auto racing in Belgium to baseball in Chicago.

headline: A House Speaker Proves a Mighty Fund-Raiser
text: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa — Speaker John A. Boehner, tanned, relaxed and seeming slightly giddy, slid up to the microphone and tossed off some one-liners to a small group of Iowans who had paid $100 for the pleasure of 12 minutes of his company on a recent Friday evening.

headline: Hitting Pause in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An American commander’s decision to suspend the training of new Afghan Local Police recruits for at least a month was the first tap on the brakes for what has been a headlong drive to fill out a police force. From the very beginning, the program has been one of the most controversial in the Afghan security plan.

headline: U.S. Open: Day 7
text: Andy Roddick put off retirement for at least two days by winning his third-round match, but Lleyton Hewitt saw his Open run come to an end.

headline: Federer Is Busiest After the Match
text: The questions started almost as soon as Roger Federer’s last match ended, same as always, the news media gantlet often longer and more intense than what happened on the court.

headline: Data Show a City’s Car Sharing May Be Working, but Doubts Persist
text: HOBOKEN, N.J. — It has been more than two years since officials in this parking-starved city placed a counterintuitive bet: Hoboken would create parking spaces, they said, by taking them away.

headline: Football’s Future Rests on Parents as Much as Players
text: Sherman Howard, 87, played professional football for five years and was a longtime high school coach in Chicago. “The biggest problem you have now is in coaching,” he said. “I don’t think the kids now have the best of coaching.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
After Daring Restart, Hunter-Reay Holds On at Grand Prix of Baltimore
text: BALTIMORE — Stacks of tires lined the sharp right turn at the end of the long main straightaway at the Grand Prix of Baltimore, and Ryan Hunter-Reay probably lucked out after the biggest restart of Sunday’s chaotic race by not barreling into them.

headline: Muslims From Abroad Are Thriving in Catholic Colleges
text: DAYTON, Ohio — Arriving from Kuwait to attend college here, Mai Alhamad wondered how Americans would receive a Muslim, especially one whose head scarf broadcasts her religious identity.

headline: The Cost of Living Blues
text: Last year, on Feb. 10, in the kind of pronouncement that has become all too familiar, Richard Kramer, the chairman and C.E.O. of Goodyear Tire & Rubber, announced the closing of a plant in Union City, Tenn:

headline: To the Boys, Her Role Is Simple: Teammate
text: South Plantation High School’s third-string quarterback was warming up on the sideline before the fourth quarter of a recent preseason game, and each pass was quick, concise and purposeful. The quarterback’s nervous mother, Kathleen DiMeglio, was capturing the moment on video from the bleachers. Then, in an instant, the quarterback vanished from the frame, lost amid the sea of white jerseys.

headline: Corrections: September 3, 2012
text: Corrections appearing in print on September 3, 2012.

headline: Slugger Guides Orioles on Strange Path Toward Playoffs
text: Because of Mark Reynolds, certain notions about the Baltimore Orioles may need to be reconsidered.

headline: School Choice Is No Cure-All, Harlem Finds
text: When it came time to pick a Harlem middle school for her daughter, Eula Guest did her research. She inquired with friends, principals and PTA presidents, and talked to students inside art studios and auditoriums. “I got down to the nitty-gritty,” she said. “I asked about everything.”

headline: Presidential Zeal
text: Whether shooting pool, reading to children or working to raise his bowling scores, President Obama cannot contain his competitive nature.

headline: The Competitor in Chief
text: As Election Day approaches, President Obama is sharing a few important things about himself. He has mentioned more than once in recent weeks that he cooks “a really mean chili.” He has impressive musical pitch, he told an Iowa audience. He is “a surprisingly good pool player,” he informed an interviewer — not to mention (though he does) a doodler of unusual skill.

headline: Sharapova Finally Returns to Quarterfinals
text: When Maria Sharapova and Nadia Petrova met at the net for the coin toss before their match Sunday night, it was hard to tell which player was more focused.

headline: Breaking It Down: Querrey vs. Berdych
text: Being up a set and a break in a tennis match is not all it’s cracked up to be.

headline: Sporting News
text: Where was a time, not so long ago, when my girlfriend, Rose, and I had the sort of conversations couples across the globe have when reuniting at the end of a long day. We talked about work, about whether to eat in or go out, about trivial gossip regarding the lives of our friends and (more trivially) those of celebrities. All this, however, has come to be replaced by a peculiar, often snippy back-and-forth that begins the moment we see each other and that, to the uninitiated, would sound a whole lot like gibberish.

headline: Training Day
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Picasso Online for Just $450? Yes, It Is a Steal
text: Bargain hunting online? How about an original Rembrandt for $900 (“you can clearly tell its age by the paper,” the seller of this etching attests), or a signed piece in ink by Matisse for $1,250. (The artist’s work is, the online seller notes, “radical and unprecedented in the history of Western art.”)

headline: In China, a Ferrari Crashes and the Party Is Dented
text: HONG KONG — When the chief of staff to President Hu Jintao was moved to a lesser position last week, it sounded like so much inside baseball, a ho-hum reshuffling of personnel as the Chinese Communist Party prepares for a leadership change this autumn.

headline: Pitch on the Pasture: Cricket in the Cowboy State
text: The heart of the University of Wyoming’s campus in Laramie is Prexy’s Pasture, a big, grassy area surrounded by blue spruce and mountain pine. According to university lore, the pasture was where students grazed their horses in the late 19th century; a standing university rule dictates that the president, or “prexy,” has sole rights to the area for livestock grazing.

headline: Hey, Teacher, Leave Those Kids Alone
text: HONG KONG — Students all around the world have been preparing for the start of the school year this month, and what a start it has been, with protests and scandals in Hong Kong, in London, in the Ivy League.

headline: Gasquet Tops N.C.A.A. Champion Johnson
text: When Steve Johnson’s final shot sailed long on Sunday, Richard Gasquet of France lifted a fist and shook it wearily in triumph as he walked to shake hands with him.

headline: Aliens With Dance Moves and the Midas Touch
text: “There might be a utopian vision inside Shirish Kunder’s ‘Joker,’ a Bollywood comedy about establishing contact with extraterrestrials,” Andy Webster wrote in The New York Times. “But if so, it’s buried under a mountain of static.”

headline: Twitter’s Free Speech Defender
text: “Alexander Macgillivray, Twitter’s chief lawyer, says that fighting for free speech is more than a good idea,” Somini Sengupta wrote for The New York Times. “He thinks it is a competitive advantage for his company.”

headline: When People Stood on Soapboxes
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Avoiding Chaos in His Wake, Button Wins at Spa
text: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium — The great track here has seen some of Formula One’s most exciting races, but that excitement has often come from the predictably unpredictable weather, which sometimes has it raining on one part of the track while other parts remain dry.

headline: Dodging the Police at the 1968 Democratic Convention
text: One of our favorite photos on the picture desk at The New York Times is a black-and-white image (below) that shows three young men in the back of a police wagon.

headline: In Mumbai, Open Spaces Are Rare, and Rarely Open
text: With over 13 million residents, Mumbai has earned its reputation for being a  congested city, one where being jostled in crowded spaces is part of daily life.

headline: U.S. Vehicle Is Rammed by a Bomber in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A suicide bomber rammed his explosives-laden vehicle into a sport utility vehicle belonging to the United States Consulate in the northwestern city of Peshawar on Monday morning, Pakistani and American officials said, in one of the most brazen attacks against Americans in the country in recent years.

headline: The Early Word: Playing for Keeps
text: Today’s Times

headline: Bartoli Blitzes Kvitova for Spot in First Open Quarterfinal
text: No. 11 seed Marion Bartoli roared back to beat fifth-seeded Petra Kvitova, 1-6, 6-2, 6-0, on the Grandstand court Sunday to reach her first United States Open quarterfinal. Bartoli, who won the girls’ singles title in Flushing Meadows in 2001, has now reached the quarterfinal stage of all four Grand Slam tournaments.

headline: What to Watch on Monday
text: It’s hard to find the right word to describe what Milos Raonic did to James Blake on Saturday.

headline: The Twilight of the Public Corporation
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: St. Louis Rams, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. He’s entering the home stretch with the last division, the N.F.C. West. First up are the St. Louis Rams.

headline: Sept. 2: Split Verdict in Polls on Romney Convention Bounce
text: My view is that the consensus of evidence so far points toward Mitt Romney having received a small bounce in the polls of perhaps two or three percentage points from the Republican convention in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Q&A: Replacing a Sealed MacBook Pro Battery
text: Q.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Hanna Rosin on Women Who Support Their Husbands
text: Hanna Rosin wrote this week’s cover story about middle-class women in Alabama who are supporting their out-of-work husbands. The article is adapted from her new book, “The End of Men: And the Rise of Women,” to be published this month by Riverhead Books. Rosin is a senior editor at The Atlantic and at Slate, where she co-founded the “DoubleX” blog.

headline: Angered Isner Is Upset in Five Sets
text: For John Isner, the 2012 United States Open will be remembered for its major missed opportunities.

headline: Fuel Efficiency Standard Could Jump-Start Electric Cars
text: The White House announced last week a significant tightening of future fuel efficiency standards.

headline: In Beijing, Clinton Will Push for Talks Over Disputed Islands
text: BEIJING — As tensions mount with its neighbors over islands in nearby strategic waterways, China has scored some subtle victories, making the United States and its allies increasingly uneasy about the potential for violent confrontations.

headline: E.U. Trade Commissioner Is Getting a Raw Deal
text: BERLIN — Being the European Union trade commissioner must sometimes be a thankless job, as Karel De Gucht is finding out. He has been fighting long and hard to establish a level playing field with China.

headline: In-Store | House Blend
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Britain’s Paul Ryan
text: In a lot of ways George Osborne, the Chancellor of the Exchequer (finance minister) is Britain’s answer to Paul Ryan. True, he’s a toned-down version — no Ayn Rand, please, we’re British — but other aspects of package are there in full force: he’s articulate, has a vision that’s completely at odds with everything we actually know about macroeconomics, and he was for a while the darling not just of the right but of self-proclaimed centrists on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Monday Reading: They’re Souvenirs, Not Stuff!
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Dolgopolov Says His Timing Left Him
text: Alexandr Dolgopolov is a chameleon.

headline: David Lindsay-Abaire and Naomi Wallace Receive Horton Foote Prize
text: The playwrights David Lindsay-Abaire and Naomi Wallace have been named the 2012 recipients of the Horton Foote Prize, a biennial award named for the playwright and screenwriter who died in 2009 at 92. Mr. Lindsay-Abaire’s “Good People” was chosen as the outstanding new American play, and “The Liquid Plain” by Ms. Wallace received the award for promising new American play. Each winner will receive $15,000 and a photograph of Mr. Foote.

headline: Activists Against Corruption Claim Police Harassment
text: Arvind Kejriwal offered himself up for arrest Monday as part of a “Jail Bharo” or “Fill the Jails” protest, designed to draw attention to what anti-corruption activists say is police harassment of the movement’s supporters.

headline: On the Lens Blog: Dodging the Police and Tear Gas at the 1968 Democratic Convention
text: When they convened in 1968 in Chicago, the Democrats, like the nation, were deeply divided. Outside the convention, protests got out of hand and the police came down hard — Barton Silverman, a Times photographer, captured it all, including an arrest.

headline: Seasonal Parking Bans Please Rockaways Residents but Irk Visitors
text: The houses in Neponsit and Belle Harbor, Queens, out past the last stop on the A train on the Rockaway Peninsula, are not what you picture when you think of New York City. Sandwiched between Jamaica Bay and the Atlantic Ocean, the homes have cedar shingles or vinyl siding, wraparound porches or, occasionally, a modern, boxy structure that stands Hamptons-ready. They are lovely and suburban, and feel very far from the frenetic boom-boom-boom of Midtown footsteps.

headline: Welcome to Charlotte, a City of Quirks
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – Politicians, delegates, lobbyists, journalists and protesters were gathering on Monday in Charlotte for the Democratic National Convention, which begins on Tuesday. They will find an Old South gold rush town that grew up to be a New South banking center with tall, shiny buildings, artsy statues and a few quirks — from a statue believed to be modeled after Alan Greenspan’s face to the “Disco Chicken.”

headline: The Week in Political Pictures: August 27-31
text: A look back at the week in politics at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla.

headline: The Quiet American
text: On a quiet street in an unfashionable East Boston neighborhood not far from Logan Airport lives an 84-year-old man whom dictators around the world fear and despise. On the morning I go to meet Gene Sharp, the taxi driver cannot even find his house, and there is no sign on the door to mark the building as headquarters of the Albert Einstein Institution, the nonprofit organization he founded in 1983. When I arrive, Jamila Raqib, the institution’s executive director, answers the door dressed in jeans and a T-shirt. “We want to be low-key,” she says. “And keep it that way.”

headline: Image of the Day: September 3
text: University awards diploma and degree certificates to 79 prisoners at Ahmedabad Central Jail in Gujarat.

headline: Chess Gets the Artistic Treatment in a New Saatchi Show
text: Since the new Islamic art galleries opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last fall, one of the most popular objects on display has been a chess set dating from 12th-century Iran, one that looks surprisingly modern because the pieces are highly abstracted. The Shah (king), for example, is represented by a large throne.

headline: 100 Years After the Titanic, Still Wondering Who Got the Story
text: If newspaper articles had routinely carried reporters’ bylines 100 years ago, there would be no question now about who got one of the biggest scoops of the early 20th century, the April 18, 1912, interview with the surviving telegraph operator from the Titanic.

headline: To Beat the Execution Clock, the Justices Prepare Early
text: WASHINGTON — John Balentine was an hour away from being put to death in Texas last month when the Supreme Court granted him a stay of execution.

headline: The Day of Knowledge
text: MOSCOW — My kids are first-class citizens, and so are the children of about half of my friends. The other half’s children are second-class citizens. The second-class citizens had to cut their summer vacations short and rise at the crack of dawn this past Saturday to take part in a brief but bizarre ritual.

headline: To Back Democracy, U.S. Prepares to Cut $1 Billion From Egypt’s Debt
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly 16 months after first pledging to help Egypt’s failing economy, the Obama administration is nearing an agreement with the country’s new government to relieve $1 billion of its debt as part of an American and international assistance package intended to bolster its transition to democracy, administration officials said.

headline: Venice Film Festival: Audiences Cheer P.T. Anderson Film, Jeer Terrence Malick’s Entry
text: VENICE — The middle weekend of the Venice Film Festival saw the premieres of the two most eagerly awaited films in the official competition. Both, as it happens, are unorthodox love stories — as well as tales of spiritual crises — by American auteurs with perfectionist reputations and loyal followings.

headline: The Stonewall of the West
text: As Generals Robert E. Lee and Thomas J. “Stonewall” Jackson were winning their smashing victory at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia, another Confederate army triumphed even more decisively at the little known battle of Richmond, Ky., led in part by the man destined to be known as the “Stonewall of the West”: Gen. Patrick Cleburne. Richmond was potentially even more decisive than Bull Run — it opened Kentucky to Confederate invasion, giving the rebels a possible route to the aorta of the Union war effort, the Ohio River.

headline: Too Young to Have a Stroke? Think Again
text: Six years ago, Todd McGee was a lean, athletic 34-year-old working in construction and living with his wife and toddler daughter on Martha’s Vineyard, where he spent summer weekends surfing. A stroke changed his life forever.

headline: Empire Boulevard, Brooklyn, 5:40 A.M.
text: The scene on Empire Boulevard in Brooklyn on Monday morning during an unofficial parade that precedes the West Indian Day Parade.

headline: Plan for Change in Schools Stirs Protest in Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG — A plan by the Hong Kong government to require schools to teach courses in contemporary Chinese history has set off an acrimonious dispute here with political implications. The controversy may threaten the prospects of pro-Beijing candidates in the legislative elections scheduled for this Sunday, and it has opened a broader discussion over the city’s future.

headline: All You Can Eat, All Over Mumbai
text: The Gujaratis are best known in Mumbai’s culinary scene for thalis, restaurants offering several courses of all-you-can-eat platters of food with a variety of subtle flavors. The restaurants take pride in leaving their customers full; one has a Web site that claims, “We serve as long as you can eat.”

headline: White House Beer: A Brewer Weighs In
text: Now that the White House has revealed its recipe for Honey Brown Ale, brewed by cooks in the White House kitchen using honey from its own hives (along with releasing a nifty video of the beer-making process), I thought it would be worth assessing the recipe and methods, and conjecturing on how the beer would taste. This required a beer-making professional, so I called on Garrett Oliver, brewmaster at the Brooklyn Brewery and editor of the encyclopedic “Oxford Companion to Beer.”

headline: G.O.P. Seizes on a Question: Are You Better Off Than You Were 4 Years Ago?
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican vice presidential nominee, slammed President Obama’s handling of the economy on Monday, seizing on hesitant responses by Mr. Obama’s top strategists when asked whether the country was better off than it was four years ago.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Returns to Yankees’ Lineup
text: 11:09 p.m. | Updated

headline: Arborio and Friends: Multigrain Risottos
text: These days chefs get away with calling all sorts of grainy dishes risottos. I’ve seen farro risottos, barley risottos and even quinoa risottos on plenty of menus. The problem with calling these dishes risottos is that if they’re made with grains other than starchy rice like arborio, carnaroli or the rice from the Camargue I used when I was in Provence this summer, they don’t have the creamy texture that makes classic risottos so appealing.

headline: Warhol Soup Cans, Now at Your Local Target
text: Christie’s may have been able to get nearly $10 million for a 1962 painting of Andy Warhol’s “Four Campbell’s Soup Cans’’ back in November, but now everyday shoppers can buy their own piece of the Pop artist for just 75 cents. On Sunday Target started selling a special edition of 1.2 million Warhol-themed tomato soup cans.

headline: Really? Some Plants Can Filter Airborne Chemicals
text: THE FACTS

headline: Obama Ad Reprises Theme That Romney Would Hurt Middle Class
text: As President Obama kicks off his convention week in Charlotte, N.C., his campaign has a new ad that doubles down on his charges that Mitt Romney‘s economic policies would harm the middle class.

headline: Mitt Romney's American Pictorial
text: New York Times photojournalist Richard Perry has been covering Mitt Romney's presidential bid since 2008. Here, Perry gives insight into the difference in visuals from the two campaigns.

headline: The Caucus Click: Madame President?
text: “The American Presidential Experience,” a traveling exhibit, has landed in Charlotte, N.C., to coincide with the Democratic National Convention. Above, Jyoti Vashee taking a photograph of her children, Shivali, 13, and Rushil, 9, at the exhibit’s mock Oval Office.

headline: Citing Health Reasons, Fish Pulls Out
text: Mardy Fish withdrew from the United States Open on Monday, hours before his scheduled fourth-round match against No. 1 Roger Federer, citing “health concerns” probably related to his continuing heart problems.

headline: At Democratic Convention, Rove Can Cause a Stir, Simply by Being Here
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — All was pleasant aboard the shuttle bus ferrying New York Democratic convention delegates to the convention center here Monday morning.

headline: Squirrel Watch
text: Q. What has happened to all the squirrels in Central Park? I have not seen any this summer.

headline: In Ruined Apartments, a Symbol of Ireland’s Fall
text: DUBLIN — To visit Graham Usher’s dream apartment in Priory Hall, the most notorious of Ireland’s ruined ghost developments, is to see what Ireland aspired to be, and what it became instead.

headline: Inside the Royal Society
text: A selection of objects and images from inside the archives.

headline: Anticonvulsant May Relieve Chronic Cough
text: A medicine commonly used for seizures and nerve pain may help treat chronic cough, a new study has found.

headline: Abortions Linked to Risk of Preterm Birth
text: Induced abortions may raise the risk for very preterm birth in subsequent pregnancies, a new study reports.

headline: Setting the Mood for Smaller Meals
text: A change in fast-food restaurant ambience can affect the amount of food consumed by customers, an unusual study has found.

headline: China Faces New Scandal Over Crash of a Ferrari
text: BEIJING — China’s carefully scripted leadership transition appears to have suffered another glitch: a fatal car crash involving a Ferrari, a privileged son and two women.

headline: On Labor Day, Obama Talks Up Auto Bailout in Ohio
text: TOLEDO, Ohio – President Obama pointed to his bailout of the auto industry, which Mitt Romney opposed, as a major argument for his re-election over the Republican rival as he spent a fourth Labor Day with union workers in a swing state.

headline: In Pursuit of Truth, Corporeal and Cosmic
text: In the Royal Society’s early years, scientists wrote of research both bizarre and elegant, made seemingly uncanny predictions, and sought to reconcile their findings with prevailing beliefs about God. A few samples from the archives:

headline: A Redoubt of Learning Holds Firm
text: LONDON — To stroll out of Carlton Gardens into the elegant confines of the Royal Society is to find a trove of centuries-old wonders, from Sir Isaac Newton’s reflecting telescope to the first electric machine to fantastical illustrated catalogs of fish and birds.

headline: Farm Use of Antibiotics Defies Scrutiny
text: The numbers released quietly by the federal government this year were alarming. A ferocious germ resistant to many types of antibiotics had increased tenfold on chicken breasts, the most commonly eaten meat on the nation’s dinner tables.

headline: European Proposal Presses for Women to Join Boards
text: BRUSSELS — Companies allocating fewer than 40 percent of seats on supervisory boards to women could face serious sanctions later this decade, according to a proposal made Monday by Viviane Reding, the European Union justice commissioner.

headline: Syrian Minister Assails Egyptian and Turkish Leaders
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s top government spokesman declared Monday that the refugees fleeing its borders were welcome back “at any time,” mocked the leaders of Egypt and Turkey for their condemnations and called the armed opposition unfit for negotiations.

headline: Mustard’s Spiciness Related to Its Hardiness
text: A small family of genes regulates not only the spiciness of mustard plants but also their prospects for survival, scientists report.

headline: Jordan’s King Cancels Fuel Price Rise in Face of Protest
text: AMMAN, Jordan — King Abdullah II of Jordan moved quickly to block a recent increase in fuel prices after angry protesters took to the streets over the weekend, raising the specter of renewed social and political unrest in the cash-poor kingdom.

headline: Ancient Warriors Unearthed in Denmark
text: A fractured skull and a thighbone hacked in half were found at the lake.

headline: Taking the Measure of a Single Molecule
text: For the first time, a device can measure the mass of a single molecule.

headline: A Glimpse of Lobbyists’ Convention Exile
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Lobbyists are beside themselves: the president’s public cold shoulder has exiled them to the fringes of the convention. Just how far afield?

headline: Literature in Any Language: Journal Takes That Literally
text: When the first issue of its new Chinese-language edition appears next month, the London-based literary journal Granta, a publication that has existed in English since the Victorian era, will have a presence in four of the five most widely spoken languages. But plans for the globalization of a leading quarterly that proudly calls itself “the magazine of new writing” don’t stop there.

headline: Tuberculosis: Stubborn and Expensive to Treat, Drug-Resistant Strains Show Growth
text: A new study has confirmed, once again, that hard-to-cure drug-resistant tuberculosis is a growing problem.

headline: School Bullies Prey on Children With Autism
text: Connie Anderson didn’t know what was bothering her 17-year-old son, a Baltimore-area high school senior with Asperger’s syndrome, a form of autism. He was usually a diligent student, but his grades began to plummet.

headline: Battling Progress and Other Demons
text: The title of Michael Chabon’s pungent new novel, “Telegraph Avenue,” refers, of course, to the famous Telegraph Avenue that bridges Berkeley and Oakland, Calif., that frisky, clamorous thoroughfare so identified, since the 1960s, with the counterculture and community life.

headline: Dreamers Who Sell Out on the Road to Success
text: Whether you love or hate “Dreamgirls,” the vintage Michael Bennett musical about the rise and death of a 1960s singing group that strongly resembles the Supremes, you cannot deny the power of its signature number. When Jennifer Holliday opened her mouth to sing “And I Am Telling You I’m Not Going” at the Imperial Theater in 1981, Frank Rich wrote in The New York Times, Broadway history was made. And Dion Millington’s performance as Effie at the Harlem Repertory Theater’s inviting chamber production of the show is a thrilling reminder of how and why. The lyricist, Tom Eyen (who also wrote the book), and the composer, Henry Krieger, gave theater an undeniable moment of greatness.

headline: Overtreatment as Myth (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Focus Hocus Pocus, Redux
text: Oh, dear. Dean Baker is on the case; we’re back to “Obama should have ditched health reform to focus on the economy”.

headline: Rodriguez Returns; Lead Slips to One
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — As the Yankees’ once-formidable lead in the American League East continues to slip from their hands like melting ice on a hot day, they continue to talk about it as if it is still something they can hold onto. They may be able to, but if the lead continues to dwindle at its current rate, the Yankees will be in second place by Wednesday.

headline: Remnants of Japan’s Tsunami Attract an Archaeological Interest
text: ABOARD THE SEA DRAGON, 1,000 miles east of Japan — After narrowly avoiding a typhoon, battling seasickness and being pelted by rain for days on end, crew members aboard the Sea Dragon were galvanized by the sight of a stranded boat.

headline: Floating Debris
text: The tsunami that hit Japan in March 2011 swept an estimated 5 million tons of debris into the ocean.

headline: Crops in India Wilt in a Weak Monsoon Season
text: MURUMA, India — Vilas Dinkar Mukane lives halfway around the world from the corn farmers of Iowa, but the Indian sharecropper is at risk of losing his livelihood for the same reason: not enough rain.

headline: Ryan Adds Some Loaded Examples to Question of ‘Better Off?’
text: 9:02 p.m. | Updated  A revised version of this post is available here.

headline: New Virus Tied to Ticks Poses Puzzle for Doctors
text: For a year and a half, scientists have been swarming over a 100-acre farm in northwestern Missouri, catching ticks and drawing blood from raccoons, possums, turkeys and deer.

headline: With Diversity Still Lacking, Industry Focuses on Retention
text: FOR many in the advertising business, the results of the 2010 census were a tipping point in terms of highlighting the growing importance of minority consumers. It showed that there were more than 50 million Latinos in the United States, nearly 40 million African-Americans and almost 15 million Asians. Nine million people identified themselves as belonging to more than one race.

headline: A Conversation with Michelle A. Rhee
text: Michael D. Shear speaks with former commissioner of D.C. schools, Michelle Rhee, at the Democratic National Convention. She is now the C.E.O. of the education reform advocacy group, "StudentsFirst."

headline: The Caucus Click: Michelle Obama on the Convention Floor
text: Michelle Obama toured the stage on Monday at the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Eating Right Between Meetings
text: The stereotype of business trip dining consisted of an artery-clogging succession of meeting-room pastries, oversize restaurant portions and fast food snagged at the airport. Anyone on a vegetarian or gluten-free diet had an especially hard time.

headline: Stanford Scientists Cast Doubt on Advantages of Organic Meat and Produce
text: Does an organic strawberry contain more vitamin C than a conventional one?

headline: Romney Spends Labor Day at Home
text: BOSTON — On Monday, the traditional start of the general election campaign, President Obama rallied a crowd of thousands in Toledo, Ohio. Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. drummed up support in Detroit. And Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, spoke to an overflow audience in North Carolina, the state where the Democrats were set to open their national convention this week.

headline: Dimensions of Data, Turned Into Art That Speaks
text: Scientists and engineers have a tremendous capacity to detect, track, measure and otherwise observe phenomena of all kinds. This growing capacity is perhaps their most powerful tool. But it presents problems, too, because it is no easy task to marshal this flood of data and present it in ways that others — or sometimes even they themselves — can understand and make use of it.

headline: Use of Inhalers May Affect Growth
text: Children who use glucocorticoid inhalers to prevent asthma attacks may be shorter as adults, researchers said on Monday.

headline: Relief for Severe Asthma, at a High Price
text: For two decades, Patricia DiGiusto struggled with severe asthma. Powerful medications and frequent use of her inhaler could not prevent repeated trips to the emergency room.

headline: Rare Infection Prompts Neti Pot Warning
text: Neti pots — those odd teapotlike vessels used to wash out the nasal passage — have won legions of fans who rely on them for relief from allergies, congestion and colds.

headline: How to Cope at the Airport Without a Wallet
text: DESPITE all the traveling I do, I’m still a bit of a nervous flier. Therefore, it doesn’t really make any sense that I flew with the Blue Angels last year after they offered the University of Rochester one seat on one of their planes. Several of us at the university received an e-mail invitation, and the first person to respond would get to go. I responded first. I figured it would be a good thing to do, until the day started approaching.

headline: Science Times Podcast
text: The Royal Society; and a food safety conundrum.

headline: Flying Nonstop to Bangkok? Time for Airborne Theater
text: I WAS at the airport in Singapore some years ago chatting with an oil company roustabout who was waiting to board Singapore Airlines for its 19-hour nonstop flight to Newark. He was traveling in business class, which features sumptuous food and free-flowing drink, seats that recline into lie-flat beds and an in-flight entertainment system with 80 on-demand movies available on personal high-definition screens.

headline: A Conversation With the Keynote Speaker
text: Houston Bureau Chief Manny Fernandez talks to rising Democratic star Julián Castro, the mayor of San Antonio.

headline: Music From Matchbox Twenty, Animal Collective and Jason Lescalleet
text: MATCHBOX TWENTY“North” (Atlantic)

headline: Think You Know Loud? Try Throbbing Sound as the Body Vibrates
text: The live sound of Sunn O))) can draw you toward a kind of negative listening: paying attention to the movements between notes rather than the notes themselves. On Sunday — in hooded robes and in front of 18 amplifier cabinets — the two guitarists in the band, Greg Anderson and Stephen O’Malley, made those movements, slow slidings up or down the neck, sound like buildings crumpling in slow motion. A fantastic, physical, indeterminate sound.

headline: Five Questions for Michelle Rhee
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Michelle A. Rhee, the former schools chancellor in Washington, D.C., is now pushing education reform through her organization Students First — and continuing to annoy the teachers’ unions along the way.

headline: With First-Round Open Juniors Victory, Less Teasing by the Other Kids
text: Tornado Alicia Black, 14, of Boca Raton, Fla., won her first-round match in the United States Open junior girls tournament with a bandaged left thigh and a stiff back that required a trainer’s assistance.

headline: Stevie Wonder Backtracks on Comments About Frank Ocean
text: Stevie Wonder has issued a statement clarifying comments he had made about the R&B singer Frank Ocean, who recently surprised the hyper-masculine world of urban music by acknowledging on his Tumblr site that he’d fallen in love with a man several years ago.

headline: The Agenda: Climate Change
text: New York Times environment reporter John Broder says Mitt Romney is not a proponent of government action on climate change, while President Obama knows a climate change bill won't realistically pass.

headline: Film Festival With Truths to Tell
text: TELLURIDE, Colo. — A film festival held almost 9,000 feet above sea level on a holiday weekend may not be the likeliest setting for philosophical speculation, but for the past four days the Telluride Film Festival has offered something like a seminar on the nature of truth. In an age of reality television, journalistic fakery and political mendacity everyone knows that words and images can distort and mislead. And film is a particularly unstable medium, alluring us with a promise of honesty while it feeds us ever more elaborate fantasies.

headline: Staying Back Is a Losing Strategy for Isner
text: The writer uses statistics to show that John Isner should put more emphasis on his net game over his baseline game to produce the best results.

headline: Social Media Site Creates Buzz With Convention Parties
text: At the Republican convention last week, the big bash sponsored by BuzzFeed at the Florida Aquarium in Tampa was among the most exotic and most talked about, featuring mermaids (undulating in full fin alongside fish in glass tanks) and penguins (sitting adorably in little wagons, with a helpful handler reminding revelers that, yes, even cute penguins do bite).

headline: Mets’ Comeback Hopes Hindered by Disputed Call in Loss to Cardinals
text: ST. LOUIS — As reporters filed into the visiting manager’s office at Busch Stadium on Monday morning, one mentioned to Terry Collins that the Mets were roughly the same number of games outside a playoff spot that the St. Louis Cardinals were one year ago during their exhilarating World Series-winning run.

headline: Expectation of Stimulus Lifts European Markets
text: European stocks rose for a second day on Monday, and copper advanced on speculation that central banks would take more steps to stimulate growth, as reports signaled that the global economic slowdown was deepening. The markets in the United States were closed for the Labor Day holiday.
