headline: News Plus Verse: Our Weekly Poetry Pairings
text: With the start of the school year, we usher in a new season of Poetry Pairings, a feature we first introduced in 2010.

headline: Egypt’s Economic Struggle
text: Eighteen months after Egypt’s revolution, President Mohamed Morsi, the United States and the International Monetary Fund finally seem to be pulling in the same general direction on the question of how best to revive the country’s devastated economy. Their efforts are long overdue and will require a sustained commitment as Egypt struggles with its transition to democracy.

headline: ‘Are You Better Off?’ The Answer Is Less Clear Than It Was in 1980
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — When Ronald Reagan asked voters a week before the 1980 election whether they were better off than four years earlier, he turned a race that had been nip-and-tuck for months into a landslide victory — and showed how a pointed question can be a lethal political weapon.

text: ST. LOUIS — The Mets’ clubhouse seemed louder, happier and significantly more crowded Tuesday afternoon.

text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Democrats opened their convention here on Tuesday night with a parade of officials telling voters that Mitt Romney does not get it and with a rousing speech from Michelle Obama making the case that President Obama does.

headline: Out on a Pier, Putting On a Concert for the Birds
text: On Tuesday morning, Jose Modesto Castillo, retired from a job in a plastics factory, walked just about as far west in northern Manhattan as it is possible to go, to the end of a long pier fingering into the Hudson River at Dyckman Street. A harmonica rigged to his head was just a breath away from his lips. Lashed to his hands with hair ties were 17 miniature percussion instruments made from items like a Snapple cap, the lid of a prescription bottle, a Spider-Man figurine, the shells of plastic eggs that once held toys from supermarket vending machines.

headline: ‘I Love My Husband. So Vote for Him’ — The Sequel
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — They both talked about their husbands. They both talked about love and children and family and their marriages and their parents. But that’s where the similarities ended between the speeches delivered by Ann Romney last week and Michelle Obama tonight at their husbands’ nominating conventions.

headline: A’s Are Hitting Home Runs and Beating the Odds

It is printed on a canvas that will come off Monday, when the Raiders open their N.F.L. season, and obscures what was once a crisp view of the Oakland hills.

headline: It’s Mitt’s World
text: Mitt Romney has been criticized for not discussing foreign policy. Give him a break. He probably figures he’s already said all that he needs to say during the primaries: He has a big stick, and he is going to use it on Day 1. Or as he put it: “If I’m president of the United States ... on Day 1, I will declare China a currency manipulator, allowing me to put tariffs on products where they are stealing American jobs unfairly.”

The incidence of a variety of chronic diseases, like diabetes and heart disease, has also been growing dramatically, particularly among people who are not yet elderly.

headline: Massachusetts: Sex Change Is Ordered for Inmate
text: A federal judge in Boston on Tuesday ordered the Massachusetts Department of Correction to provide an inmate with a sex change. Doctors for Michelle L. Kosilek, a transsexual prisoner who was convicted of murdering his wife in 1990, say gender reassignment surgery is the only way to treat his severe gender identity disorder. Corrections officials had denied the surgery, saying that it could create security problems. In his decision, Judge Mark L. Wolf found that the denial of the surgery, which would be financed with state taxes, amounted to a violation of the Eighth Amendment, which prohibits cruel and unusual punishment. He is believed to be the first federal judge to order gender reassignment. Mr. Kosilek is serving a life sentence without parole. He sued the Department of Corrections over the matter in 2000.

text: Governor Martin O’Malley of Maryland spoke about the differences between President Obama and Mitt Romney at the 2012 Democratic National Convention.

headline: Pentagon Says Book Contains Classified Information
text: The Pentagon press secretary, George Little, said on Tuesday that the Defense Department believed there was classified information in a new first-person account of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden. Mr. Little did not specify what the information was or do more than repeat threats of legal action. The book, “No Easy Day,” written by a former member of the Navy SEALs, Matt Bissonnette, with a co-author, Kevin Maurer, went on sale on Tuesday. Pentagon officials say Mr. Bissonnette violated nondisclosure agreements he signed with the government, but Mr. Bissonnette and his lawyer say he did not. Penguin, the publisher, is printing 575,000 hardcover copies, placing “No Easy Day” among the biggest books of the year.

headline: Hong Kong Airline Bans Shark Fin as Cargo

headline: Jets Make Late Punting Switch
text: The Jets changed punters Tuesday, jettisoning T. J. Conley in favor of Robert Malone. Conley’s inconsistency frustrated the Jets, whose hope for a spirited competition in training camp never materialized. After Conley beat out two challengers, Travis Baltz and Spencer Lanning, the Jets went with Malone, who ranked higher in both yards per punt (44.8 to 44.0) and net average (39.9 to 37.9) during the preseason. Malone, released two weeks ago by San Diego, has appeared in 13 N.F.L. games across the past two seasons with Tampa Bay and Detroit. The Jets also swapped defensive tackles, waiving Isaako Aaitui and re-signing Marcus Dixon.

headline: News Quiz | September 5, 2012

headline: Pictures of the Day: D.N.C. Day 1

headline: Sharp Criticism for Mamata Banerjee in Muslim Officer’s Book
text: KOLKATA — In just over a week since its launch, Musalamander Koroniyo (What Muslims Should Do),  a book in written in Bengali by a senior police officer, has attracted national attention and raised new questions about intolerance in West Bengal, where Mamata Banerjee is chief minister.

headline: The Obamas’ Party
text: After Ann Romney spoke in Tampa, Fla., last week, much of the next day’s conversation revolved around whether the convention organizers had made a big mistake by having her precede Chris Christie to the lectern. Her speech was praised to the skies, his was criticized for being self-serving and self-absorbed – and by leaving the last word to the New Jersey governor, critics argued, the convention swept the spotlight off her husband and undercut the power of her pitch.

headline: Relations Between India and Sri Lanka Sour
text: Last week, while traveling down the coast of Tamil Nadu for  my article about the fishing wars between India and Sri Lanka, I noticed pilgrims walking along the side of the road. They trudged along, despite the heat, as they walked kilometers on a pilgrimage to Christian shrines in the state of Tamil Nadu. What I had not realized is that some of the pilgrims visiting the state were from Sri Lanka.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Sept. 5, 2012

headline: Did Barack Obama Save Ohio?
text: The way John Kasich sees it, he is fulfilling a grand design, a mission for which he was chosen by God, to save Ohio. “It’s like what what’s-his-name told the hobbit,” Ohio’s Republican governor told me as we flew on the plane that ferries him around the state. “What’s that guy’s name? Gandel? Gandorf?” A pair of young aides seated across from Kasich called out helpfully over the drone of the engine. “Gandalf,” Kasich repeated. “Do you remember what he told the hobbit?”

On Wednesday, to celebrate that run’s 60th anniversary, Charles Greene III will set off in the tire tracks of his father.

headline: Medicare Part D Premiums Holding Steady
text: A morsel of good news about Medicare drug coverage for the coming year:  Selecting a Part D plan might drive you crazy, as Jane Gross, the founding New Old Age blogger, wrote earlier this summer, but at least the average 2013 premiums will remain basically level for the fourth year in a row.

headline: The Enduring Legacy of China’s Great Famine

headline: Quebec’s Near Win
text: MONTREAL — Quebec, Canada’s majority-French-speaking province, elected its first woman premier on Tuesday night. Pauline Marois, the leader of the separatist Parti Québécois (known as the PQ), will head a minority government, having fallen nine seats short of the 63 needed for a majority in the National Assembly, Quebec’s legislature.

headline: Still No New Pynchon Photo, but Here’s Emily Dickinson
text: In her own words, Emily Dickinson said she was “small, like the wren; and my hair is bold, like the chestnut burr; and my eyes, like the sherry in the glass that the guest leaves.” (She also had a strange propensity for accepting rides from carriage drivers who are the physical embodiment of Death.) But what did that celebrated Massachusetts poet, who died in 1886 – long before the ubiquity of Instagram – actually look like? Until now only one authenticated portrait of Dickinson as an adult, a daguerreotype showing her sitting upright in a chair, was known to exist. But as The Guardian reports, a second image of Dickinson, with a smile on her face and a friend by her side, may have been confirmed.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Slate: A gravely obsessive Pepperidge Farm fan samples every variety of the label’s cookies and emerges with alarming insights like this: “I don’t quite understand how a Milano slice is really a Milano — it would seem an open-faced Milano would be a contradiction in terms, seeing as the sandwich structure of the original is the defining feature.” Willie Wonka, meet Jacques Derrida. — Patrick Farrell

headline: Canine Conservationists on the Move
text: The high energy levels of many dogs in animal shelters can be off-putting to some people seeking to adopt one as a family pet. When that happens, the dogs can end up as candidates for euthanasia. But wildlife conservationists have found a way to capitalize on that intensity, enlisting canines to track threatened species and thereby help protect ecosystems.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Fall Book Bonanza and the New Cosmo Girl
text: The book industry is looking forward to some good news for a change. This fall, the big publishers are unleashing a murderer’s row of authors – including Salman Rushdie, Zadie Smith and Junot Díaz – in what it hopes will be a huge season. The two biggest swings: Tom Wolfe writing his first novel in eight years and a work of adult fiction by J.K. Rowling, the creator of Harry Potter.

headline: Obama Convention Speech Moved From Stadium
text: 11:09 a.m. | Updated CHARLOTTE, N.C. – President Obama’s plans to deliver his acceptance speech on Thursday evening at an outdoor stadium rally has been foiled by a forecast of rain and heavy thunderstorms, aides said Wednesday, forcing organizers to scramble and move the final night of the Democratic National Convention indoors.

headline: A Real Tea Party
text: Now that “Schoolhouse Rock!” is no longer around to whip young children into heady waves of patriotism, nonfiction picture books are doing the job — only far more accurately and without putting songs in your head.

headline: Kurds and (the Turkish) Way
text: ISTANBUL — When I first started covering Turkey in the early 1990s, my foreign colleagues and I were sometimes mocked for referring to the brewing resentment in southeastern Turkey as “the Kurdish problem.” There was no sectarian or ethnic discrimination, we were told; the problem was terrorism. The Kurdistan Workers Party, better known as the PKK, resorted to violence and extortion, which no civilized society could abide.

headline: A Tool for Those Who Fall Behind on Student Debt
text: Have you fallen behind on your student loan payments? The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau this summer introduced an online tool to help you evaluate your options.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Dress in High Definition
text: IT says a lot about politics today that it was possible, during a speech by Michelle Obama that was described as “genius” for its subtlety by both David Brooks and Mark Shields, that a parallel conversation was happening online, and in real time, about her shimmering brocade dress and matching fingernails. If you were following along on Twitter, where comments reportedly reached a peak of 28,000 a minute by the end of her speech, you might wonder how many people were really listening to what she was saying.

headline: Shifting Views on Climate Change
text: President Obama and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, have spelled out their views on climate change in a bit more detail than they usually do on the campaign trail in response to questions from a group of scientific organizations.

headline: Roundabout to Revive ‘Talley’s Folly’ in February
text: A revival of Lanford Wilson’s two-character romance “Talley’s Folly” will be part of the Roundabout Theater Company’s 2012-13 season, the theater announced on Wednesday.

headline: Stereotypes in Toeshoes
text: Calendars for the coming ballet season have now been announced across much of America. As usual, story ballets abound. But what stories do they tell? Narrative ballet remains a heritage park: an Old World never-never land. How many of us would actually like to inhabit those onstage worlds? Which choreographers are telling stories for our time?

headline: Desert Stories: Claire Vaye Watkins Talks About ‘Battleborn’
text: Claire Vaye Watkins’s first book, “Battleborn,” a collection of short stories, arrives with notable provenance (the stories originally appeared in The Paris Review and elsewhere) and an unusually compelling author biography. Ms. Watkins’s father, Paul Watkins, was once a member of Charles Manson’s “family.” In Vincent Bugliosi’s “Helter Skelter,” he’s described as “a good-looking youth with a way with women” who “had been Manson’s chief procurer of young girls.” In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Watkins discussed learning about her father’s life, the hold Nevada has on her imagination, her “obsessive and controlling” sense of play when she was a child and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: In China, Drogba Draws Crowds and Controversy
text: BEIJING — With five defenders smothering him at the top of the penalty box, Didier Drogba, the former star player for Chelsea in England’s Premier League, calmly slid a lead pass to his new Shanghai Shenhua teammate Cao Yunding, who was dashing full-speed through the box. The nifty pass caught the defenders and the goalkeeper off guard. With a near-open net, Drogba’s teammate hesitated, perhaps perplexed by how easy it had seemed, then fired the ball past the dumbstruck goalkeeper.

headline: Eating Where It Feels Like Home (But You Don’t Have to Do the Dishes)

headline: Tiger Triplets Make Their Debut in the Bronx
text: It is a busy time for local youngsters. Just as the city’s children prepare to go back to school, three 4-month-old Siberian tiger cubs made their debut on Wednesday at the Bronx Zoo (see video below or click here).

headline: New Yorker Festival to Include ‘Cloud Atlas’ Premiere
text: The first United States showing of the film version of “Cloud Atlas” – as well as a rare showing-up by its co-directors Andy and Lana Wachowski – will be one of the marquee events of the 2012 New Yorker Festival. On Wednesday organizers announced the lineup for the annual festival, which runs this year from Oct. 5 through 7 and features public events with various cultural luminaries and contributors to The New Yorker magazine. Among its highlights is a premiere screening of “Cloud Atlas,” adapted from the David Mitchell novel, followed by a conversation with the Wachowski siblings (“The Matrix,” “Speed Racer”) and their co-director, Tom Tykwer. (The “Cloud Atlas” team will be interviewed by Aleksandar Hemon, who wrote about them in this week’s issue of The New Yorker.)

text: In Atlanta, where hip-hop rubs up against notorious strip clubs, rappers who want to make it big get their start by making it rain.

text: Designers like Martin Greenfield and Peter Frew charge thousands of dollars for a single custom-made suit. So why aren’t they rich?

headline: What Should the President Say?
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.–Only 38 percent of respondents in a new Gallup poll said Mitt Romney’s performance at the Republican Convention was good or excellent, the lowest approval rating for any presidential candidate’s acceptance speech since Gallup started asking the question.

headline: Breaking It Down: Ferrer vs. Gasquet
text: In Malcolm Gladwell’s 2005 best-seller, “Blink,” he focused on the subject of “thin-slicing” – the ability to understand what is important from an extremely narrow moment in time.

headline: Why the Minimum Wage Doesn’t Explain Stagnant Wages
text: Until the mid-1980s, only a single state – and one of the smallest in population, Alaska – had set a minimum wage higher than the federal minimum. But with the federal minimum remaining unchanged at $3.35 an hour for most of the 1980s, more states began to set higher floors for wages.

headline: Start-Up Offers a New Way to Shop for Office Supplies
text: The renaissance of e-commerce has brought us new ways to shop for pants, diapers and eyeglasses. Next up: office supplies.

headline: Yankees Borrow a Page From the Mets
text: In New York, it’s the Mets who normally have a copyright on collapses. They fell apart after the All-Star break this season, going 11-29; they blew an easy shot at the postseason in 2008 with some unbelievable bullpen mayhem in the final weeks of September; and they made history by blowing a seven-game division lead with 17 games to go in 2007.

headline: Obama Counts on Clinton to Help Sway Independents
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Former President Bill Clinton tried to rebut Republican arguments against the re-election of President Obama in a major speech at the Democratic National Convention Wednesday night, saying Mr. Obama has taken steps to turn around an economy left in shambles by Republicans.

headline: Pruning Hedge Fund Regulation Without Cultivating Better Rules
text: Fresh from having declined to constrain money market funds, the Securities and Exchange Commission has moved to loosen marketing constraints on hedge funds.

headline: Video of Quebec Gunman’s Rant After Shooting at Separatist Rally
text: As my colleague Ian Austen reports, the leader of Canada’s separatist Parti Québécois was hustled offstage during a speech after her party’s victory in a provincial election Tuesday night when a 62-year-old man opened fire outside the rally, leaving one man dead and another in critical condition.

headline: Safeway Plans I.P.O. of Gift Card Unit
text: Safeway, the supermarket chain based in California, said on Wednesday that it planned to file for an initial public offering of a minority stake in its fast-growing gift card unit, Blackhawk Network Holdings. Shares of Safeway were up 5 percent by midday.

headline: The Get | Van Cleef & Arpels Touch Wood Vintage Alhambra Pendant
text: After discovering a trove of letter wood in the attic of the brand’s Place Vendôme maison, Van Cleef & Arpels’s North America president and CEO Nicolas Bos and team decided to honor the find and use it to create the touch wood Vintage Alhambra collection. Each necklace, bracelet and earring in the collection is limited and numbered and set in rose gold — a first for the brand’s signature, four-leaf clover-shaped Alhambras. “It’s a warm color and the modern alternative to yellow gold,” Bos says of the choice to use rose gold. “With the wood it was an interesting feeling — more of a vintage feeling that still felt like a very new combination.” Charmed, for sure!

headline: Polls: Little to No Bounce for Romney
text: Several new polls show that in the immediate days after the Republican National Convention, Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, did not see much of a boost to his campaign, although slightly more Americans now see him as someone who can understand the needs of the middle class.

headline: Lincoln’s Handwitten Draft of the Emancipation Proclamation Is Coming to Harlem
text: The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem will be the first stop for the New York State Museum’s traveling exhibition of the only surviving draft of the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation in Abraham Lincoln’s handwriting.

headline: Barbara Marcus to Lead Random House Children’s Books
text: Barbara Marcus, the children’s publishing veteran who acquired the seven Harry Potter books when she was an executive at Scholastic, has been chosen to lead Random House Children’s Books, the company announced on Wednesday.

headline: The Envelope, Please: Candice Childress
text: Candice Childress, a student at Las Vegas Academy of International Studies, Visual and Performing Arts in Nevada, is one of eight high school seniors who are blogging about their college searches.

headline: Folk Art Museum Picks New Director
text: The American Folk Art Museum in New York, which almost went out of business last year because of financial struggles, has appointed a new director, the museum announced Wednesday.

headline: How Hard Is It to Make a $4,000 Suit?
text: When the rich get richer, luxury-goods proprietors often see their fortunes rise, too. (For evidence, check out the decidedly pre-Lehmanesque heft of the September issue of Vogue.) But as Adam Davidson notes in this week’s column, bespoke suit makers, maybe the world’s second-oldest profession, are struggling to survive. This is puzzling on a number of levels, the most obvious of which is that there are huge markets of wealthy guys who care about whether their jacket is double-breasted or single-vented, and for whom $4,000 is not an ungodly sum to spend on a garment. So why wouldn’t they want the best possible value for their dollar — a suit hand-sewn just for them?

headline: Mo’Nique  Lends Support to  Ailey Gala
text: The actress and comedian Mo’Nique will serve as the honorary chairwoman of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s gala benefit performance on Nov. 28. The evening will kick off the company’s five-week season at City Center and will also feature Ailey’s signature 1960 work “Revelations,” with special guest musicians. Featured vocalists will include the Tony Award-winning actors and singers Audra McDonald, Brian Stokes Mitchell and Anika Noni Rose. Ticket and additional information is available at www.alvinailey.org.

headline: W Hotels Seek to Attract Local Residents, Too
text: W Hotels has announced that 11 of its 28 North American properties are undergoing a $100 million renovation, the biggest overhaul in the nearly 15-year history of the brand. But guests aren’t the only ones in mind: much of the change is focused on public spaces.

headline: How to See Fall’s Leaves for Less
text: IT feels like summer in the Northeast, but if you have yet to make reservations for a fall foliage getaway, you’re behind schedule.

headline: A Sandal Samaritan
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Bits of Mystery DNA, Far From ‘Junk,’ Play Crucial Role
text: Among the many mysteries of human biology is why complex diseases like diabetes, high blood pressure and psychiatric disorders are so difficult to predict and, often, to treat. An equally perplexing puzzle is why one individual gets a disease like cancer or depression, while an identical twin remains perfectly healthy.

headline: Close Encounters With Homo Sapiens’ Closest Kin
text: In recent months I’ve become familiar with the work of the nonprofit group Seacology, which scours the world for opportunities to conserve island ecosystems and cultures. Investments are made in infrastructure — from solar panels to school equipment or medical clinics — in return for community commitments to protect environmental assets. Duane Silverstein, the group’s executive director since 1999, recently sent a Dot Earth “postcard” following a visit to two different projects in sub-Saharan Africa working to conserve Homo sapiens’ primate kin, chimpanzees and gorillas:

headline: McDonald’s Vegetarian Restaurants: Latest in Long, Tough Battle to Woo India
text: The announcement by McDonald’s on Tuesday that it would open a few vegetarian-only restaurants in India next year marks the fast-food chain’s latest attempt to appeal to consumers in an unlikely market.

headline: Newspaper Publisher Journal Register Files for Bankruptcy and Plans for a Sale
text: The Journal Register Company, whose newspapers include The New Haven Register and The Trentonian, has again filed for bankruptcy protection and hopes for a quick sale, said Digital First Media, which operates the company along with the MediaNews Group.

headline: Ryan Cites Policy Kinship With Bill Clinton
text: ADEL, Iowa — From tying President Obama to the economic stagnation under one former president, Jimmy Carter, the Romney-Ryan campaign has moved on to offering rosy recollections of another Democrat in the White House, Bill Clinton. In both cases the aim is to paint an unflattering contrast with Mr. Obama.

headline: Wicksell Goes To China
text: The idea that we are at the mercy of the Chinese — that terrible things would happen if they stopped buying our bonds — is very influential. Yet it’s just wrong.

headline: Survey Deems JPMorgan’s Investment Bank Best Place to Work
text: A multibillion-dollar trading loss and multiple regulatory investigations apparently haven’t made life too miserable at JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Volkswagen Previews Redesigned Golf Ahead of Paris Motor Show
text: The Golf, the backbone of Volkswagen’s global product lineup since its debut in 1974, with more than 29 million units sold, has received a complete redesign for the 2014 model year. The seventh generation of the Golf was unveiled in an elaborate ceremony on Monday in Berlin, at the city’s Neue Nationalgalerie.

headline: In Clinton and Warren, Competing Messages for the Middle Class
text: If you’re a candidate for president, the convention affords you a fleeting window of opportunity, about three hours total of network airtime, to present speakers who will get across your one central message to the wide section of America. In the case of this Democratic convention, though, Wednesday’s lineup reveals the essential dilemma that has often made President Obama’s re-election campaign, and much of his presidency, seem as muddled as a Clint Eastwood monologue.

headline: Former Goldman Executive Joins Strategic Value Partners
text: Stephen J. McGuinness, the former co-chief operating officer of Goldman Sachs Asset Management, has joined the investment firm Strategic Value Partners as a senior managing director.

headline: The New Season in Theater: Fall 2012
text: A look at some of the season’s new shows.

headline: The UndocuBus
text: The UndocuBus, a rolling platform for immigration activism, painted aqua and covered with butterflies, has reached Charlotte, N.C., after more than a month on the road. It started in Arizona in late July and wove its way through states where there have been immigrant crackdowns: New Mexico, Colorado, Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia and Tennessee.

headline: The New Season in Art
text: A look at artworks and exhibitions of the fall.

headline: Eastwood Reconsidered
text: From a Pew Research Center poll on the viewer reactions to the G.O.P convention:

headline: Michelle Obama’s Children Come First. Should They?
text: “At the end of the day, my most important title is still ‘mom in chief.’ My daughters are still the heart of my heart and the center of my world.”

headline: Running a Business With Staff Scattered Around the World
text: When Ralph Dandrea needed to hire a handful of employees for his rapidly growing Web design business, he figured he would have no trouble finding information technology professionals. It was 1998, and the technology boom was in full swing. But even though Mr. Dandrea, founder and chief executive of ITX Corporation, based in Pittsford, N.Y., looked all across the country, he struggled to find candidates.

headline: Viva la Villa | Palatial Near Pienza
text: Adventures in house-hunting: a writer chronicles her attempt to find the perfect home in Italy.

headline: Obama Faces Test From Voters Who Drifted Away
text: Dahlgren and Robert McElwain, retired business owners who live outside Kansas City, were in agreement in 2008. Despite their nearly lifelong support of Republican candidates, they made a bold move together and cast ballots for Barack Obama, enchanted by what they saw as his intelligence and charm.

headline: TimesCast Politics and Democratic Convention Day 2 at a Glance
text: 5:57 p.m. | Updated Democrats on Wednesday will try to continue to build on the energy from Tuesday night’s speeches, highlighted by an emotional address from the first lady, Michelle Obama.

headline: Are Your Employees Really More Productive Working at Home?
text: Ralph Dandrea’s company, ITX Corporation, has 128 employees but only 46 of them report to the main office in Pittsford, N.Y. The rest are scattered internationally (72 in Argentina, plus Peru, Spain, Uruguay and Venezuela) as well as in the United States (California, Missouri, Oregon, Washington,  Virginia). “It’s a lot of fun working this way,” Mr. Dandrea said. “But there are always challenges.”

headline: A Plebe First, a Player Second
text: Larry Dixon was looking for someone to hug. He had just scored the first touchdown of his collegiate career, a 2-yard burst straight up the guts of the Tulane defense to tie the game.

headline: As Iran Assists Syria, Iraqi Airspace Becomes a Diplomatic Battleground
text: Michael R. Gordon reports in Tuesday’s Times that the airspace over Iraq is becoming a complicated proxy of Iraq’s relations with the United States and with its neighbors across the Middle East.

headline: Before Heading Into Space, Photos Will Land at Bryant Park
text: While the Curiosity rover searches the surface of Mars, an artist will be sending his own microvision of life on Earth into space this fall.

headline: When Fairness Opinions Are Used Outside of Mergers
text: Jill R. Goodman is a managing director at Rothschild, where she leads the firm’s practice representing special committees of independent directors in M.&A. transactions.

headline: Exploring Islam, Pompeii and the Factory
text: Dates and touring sites are subject to change.

headline: Anna Dello Russo’s Fashion Shower
text: Teaser videos are the new thing in viral marketing, as H&M demonstrated with the introduction of its Lanvin collection two years ago, using clips that showed the humorous side of Alber Elbaz. But after its latest campaign, you will never look at Anna Dello Russo the same way again. Ever. Not if you poke your eyes out.

headline: A Button for Every Delegate
text: Are you left-handed? A cat lover? If you’re at the Democratic National Convention and you support President Obama, there is a button for you. No group is too obscure to profess support for the president’s re-election. Pearl divers, rejoice.

headline: 2 Injured at Power Plant in France
text: PARIS — A steam release from a chemical reaction on Wednesday at the Fessenheim nuclear power plant, France’s oldest, gave two workers slight burns on their hands but did not cause a fire or radiation problem, government and fire officials said.

headline: Motorola Introduces First Phones of Its New Google Era
text: After being quiet for nearly a year, Motorola Mobility, recently acquired by Google, is returning to the mobile market with three new smartphones.

headline: Women, Women, Everywhere — but Not Much About Their Paychecks
text: The stage at the Democratic National Convention was awash in women Tuesday night. And it’s no wonder, since President Obama needs women desperately to win in November. Female voters tend to like Mr. Obama more than Mitt Romney — though Mr. Obama’s popularity among women has fallen sharply.  So women were very much in the mix.  (A nifty interactive graphic on NYTimes.com shows that “women” was the keyword mentioned third most often Tuesday night – after Obama and work.)

headline: Emanuel to Raise Money for Democratic ‘Super PAC’
text: Rahm Emanuel, the mayor of Chicago, said on Wednesday that he had stepped down from his honorary position as co-chairman of President Obama’s re-election campaign to help raise money for Priorities USA Action, a super PAC founded by two former Obama aides.

headline: Fashion’s Night Out and About
text: WHAT do Justin Bieber, Taylor Swift and Kendall Jenner have in common?

headline: U.S. to Retain Role as a Jailer in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — The United States military will maintain control over dozens of foreign detainees in Afghanistan for the indefinite future, even as the two countries prepare to ceremonially mark the hand-over of detention operations to the Afghan government, officials from both countries say.

headline: As Arenas Go Green, Will Fans Follow?
text: Can sports make environmentalism more popular?

headline: Democrats Restore Language Declaring Jerusalem Israel’s Capital
text: 6:43 p.m. | Updated  CHARLOTTE, N.C. – President Obama, seeking to quell a storm of criticism from Republicans and pro-Israel groups over his support for Israel, directed the Democratic Party to amend its platform to restore language declaring Jerusalem as the Israeli capital.

headline: Philip Roth to Cooperate With New Biographer
text: Philip Roth has a new biographer: Blake Bailey, the author of highly regarded biographies of Richard Yates and John Cheever.  Mr. Bailey said on Wednesday that in June he and Mr. Roth signed a collaboration agreement guaranteeing him unlimited access to Mr. Roth’s archives and correspondence, and help in encouraging friends to cooperate, and that he had already spent several marathon sessions interviewing the 79-year-old novelist.

headline: Two for the Runway
text: DURING New York Fashion Week, editors will seek standout microtrends like the long, tousled side braid of Alexander Wang’s spring 2010 collection or the glowing sun-kissed complexion and feathery full brow that went with it.

headline: Wacky Meets Khaki
text: UPON meeting the design duo behind the men’s wear label Duckie Brown, it is hard to learn who is who. Daniel Silver and Steven Cox, who are partners in business and romance, call each other “Duckie.” If they use their actual names, watch out: it might get awkward.

headline: Harrison Brothers Lose in Doubles Quarterfinals
text: The dream of a showdown between the Bryan brothers and the Harrison brothers at the United States Open will have to wait.

headline: U.S. Open Food of the Day: Fish Tacos
text: This is the latest in our daily series of food reviews of items at the United States Open concession stands.

headline: Southern Supergroup to Bring Its Barbecue to Meatopia
text: Meatopia, that nine-year-old be-in for carnophiles, is migrating to Randalls Island for the first time, anticipating 3,000 attendees this Saturday at its four-hour bacchanal of pork, beef, lamb, chicken, duck, turkey and quail.

headline: Romney to Appear on ‘Meet the Press’
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Mitt Romney will make his first appearance of the campaign season this Sunday on NBC’s “Meet the Press,” a move clearly intended to thrust himself back onto the main stage of the presidential campaign after ceding it to President Obama.

headline: Regulators Clarify Timing of New Derivatives Rules
text: As Wall Street gears up for an overhaul of the $600 trillion derivatives business, big banks have grumbled that regulators failed to specify when the new policies will take effect.

headline: On The Road With Uber
text: After 23 years, Shadid Mahmood traded in his cab to work for Uber, a start-up company that runs an app to help people hail cars more efficiently.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: New Raspberry Pi and Revamping Google
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Wearing Two Uniforms at West Point
text: Athletes at West Point, like running back Larry Dixon, have to adjust to the speed of the college game and to the rules and traditions of a military academy.

headline: A Christian Album Tops the Charts
text: For the first time in 15 years, a Christian album is No. 1 on the Billboard chart.

headline: Apple Denies Giving F.B.I. Device Information
text: Apple on Wednesday denied claims that it had worked with the government to share millions of device identification numbers, a day after the hacking group known as AntiSec claimed to have obtained numbers from an F.B.I. laptop.

headline: What the Democrats Didn’t Say
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – After years of waiting for Democrats to acknowledge President Obama’s pre-eminent achievement – health care reform – it was good to hear them talk about it with pride from the convention stage on Tuesday night. Speaker after speaker reminded the audience of the law, vigorously refuting the Republican dogma that it is an Orwellian disaster.

headline: Bank of America Adopts Simpler Checking Account Disclosure
text: Bank of America recently became the last of the three biggest United States banks to adopt simplified checking account disclosures, as advocated by an arm of the Pew Charitable Trusts.

headline: Consumers Say No to Mobile Apps That Grab Too Much Data
text: The Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday nudged application developers to take steps to protect consumer privacy. But many consumers seem to be already taking steps to guard their personal information from data-grabbing apps.

headline: An Award for Oscar de la Renta
text: A week after Ann Romney wore a cherry red Oscar de la Renta dress to deliver her speech at the Republican National Convention, the designer himself was being honored with a lifetime achievement award at Lincoln Center.

headline: Scene City: A New Benefit in the Hamptons Ecosystem
text: Cindy Sherman hosts the inaugural fundraiser for the Azuero Earth Project.

headline: Leaving a Footprint for a Cause
text: THE word “sustainable” has become very popular in recent years, almost as popular as benefit parties in the Hamptons. Last Saturday, the Azuero Earth Project, a nonprofit organization with the lofty mission of preserving the earth’s ecosystems and protecting biodiversity, broke into the very competitive fund-raising ecosystem of East Hampton.

headline: Engine Coolant Leak Prompts 3rd Recall of 2013 Ford Escape
text: Ford is recalling about 6,100 of its 2013 Escape crossovers because a coolant leak may cause fires, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. It is the third recall of the redesigned Escape and the second involving a fire risk.

headline: For Blue Dog PAC, Cash but Few Candidates
text: The “super PAC” supporting Blue Dog candidates has a problem that on the surface would seem enviable: tons of cash on hand! But the reason is one no one would wish for a group — it does not have enough viable candidates to support.

headline: Greek Government and Public at Odds Over New Cuts
text: ATHENS — Anastasia Kastaniotou, a struggling mother of three, stood near the Greek Parliament building on Wednesday and threw up her hands as she contemplated an €11.5 billion austerity package that her country’s government was trying to tie up this week to keep Greece in the euro.

headline: Excluded From Democratic Convention List, Liu Tours Asia
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Two months ago, John C. Liu, New York City’s comptroller, said he was “heartbroken” that the state’s top Democrats, skittish about a federal investigation into his campaign fund-raising, had excluded him from their delegate list to the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Organic by John Patrick
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Great Free Web Sites for Teaching Election 2012
text: If you’re like us, you see the election everywhere on the Web. But finding useful Web sites for teaching the election? That’s a different story.

headline: Bill Clinton in 1988
text: Bill Clinton gave the nominating speech for Michael Dukakis in 1988.

headline: Congresswoman Time-Travels, and Eyebrows Are Raised
President of Madison Square Garden Sports Leaving Post
text: Scott O’Neil, an energetic executive who helped stabilize the Knicks after the controversy and tumult of the Isiah Thomas era, has left his post as president of Madison Square Garden Sports, after only four years on the job.

headline: Egyptian President Warns Assad That ‘Your Time Won’t Be Long’
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt on Wednesday warned the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, that “your time won’t be long,” as Syrian warplanes and artillery shelled the battleground city of Aleppo and opposition groups reported heavy fighting around the Euphrates River city of Deir el-Zour.

headline: Shell to Test Capturing of Carbon in Canada
text: HOUSTON — In a bid to make oil sands production less polluting, Royal Dutch Shell announced on Wednesday that it would go forward with the first carbon capture and storage project ever tried in the fields of western Canada.

headline: Leaning Into the Learning Curve
text: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — From the moment my dad bought me my first pair of cleats (he actually called them spikes, thanks to his running background … at least he didn’t call them boots) and shin guards, I have been bombarded with instructions and advice. Some things I’ve learned from coaches, videos and various experts have stuck with me over the years, and others I’ve chosen to throw by the wayside. In the spirit of my love of lists, here’s another!

headline: Al Jazeera Wrests Back Its Web Sites From Pro-Assad Hackers
text: Updated | 6:15 p.m. Hackers said to be supporters of the Syrian government temporarily seized control of the Arabic and English news sites of Al Jazeera, the Qatari satellite network, which has been accused of bias in favor of protesters and rebels by the government of President Bashar al-Assad and its supporters.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Africa, Syria, Portugal and India.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Cowboys 24, Giants 17
text: Follow this post for live updates and analysis of the N.F.L.’s opening night game between the Dallas Cowboys and the Giants from The Times’s Justin Sablich, who also provides fantasy football advice on The Fifth Down. Follow Sablich on Twitter at @JSablichNYT and @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Is the Venue Change Good for Obama?
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – Obama campaign aides are mightily disappointed that a bad weather forecast has forced them to cancel President Obama’s plan to deliver his acceptance speech at a stadium, just as he did in Denver in 2008. Instead he’ll speak indoors at the smaller Time Warner Cable Arena.

headline: The Caucus Click: Gabby Douglas at the D.N.C.
text: Gabby Douglas, the gold-medal-winning gymnast from the London Olympics, walked across the stage during rehearsal for Wednesday’s events at the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Reaping Secrets Ancestors Sowed
text: The slaves stand around the Louisiana plantation house wearing tattered calico and head scarves. They’re greeting party guests at Belle Vie, an antebellum manse turned tourist attraction. For $10.75 an hour, it’s not bad work.

headline: Sharapova Advances, With Rain to Rescue
text: Rain may have made a mess of the United States Open for many players, but Maria Sharapova is a big fan.

headline: Kaushik Basu Named to World Bank Post
text: On Wednesday, the World Bank announced its new chief economist: Kaushik Basu, a Cornell University economist and the former chief economic adviser to the Indian ministry of finance.

headline: Warhol Foundation Will Donate or Sell Its Whole Collection
text: Beginning this fall the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts will disperse its entire collection of Warhols, donating some and selling others through Christie’s auction house as it shifts almost exclusively into a grant-making organization, foundation officials said in interviews.

headline: Bill Clinton’s Night at the D.N.C.
text: Amy Chozik of The New York Times talks about how this moment will highlight just how far Former President Bill Clinton has come to restore his relationship with the Democratic Party.

headline: Bill Clinton in 1992
text: Bill Clinton accepted his nomination at the 1992 Democratic National Convention.

headline: The No-Waste, More-Work Lunch Box
text: What’s in your child’s lunch box? If you’re a good parent, that lunch meets all of the big three requirements: it’s healthy, no-waste and allergen-free. The classic brown-paper-bag lunch of your childhood (P.B. & J. on white, chips, Twinkie, soda) is so last-century. It’s not just the nutrition-free content, it’s the packaging. (Although a few weeks of that lunch would surely get you a note from the school politely suggesting that less sugar might make for more learning.)

text: The new Fox series starts on Sept. 17.

text: The new ABC series starts on Sept. 27.

text: The New NBC series starts on Sept. 11.

headline: A Cadillac XTS for All Occasions
text: In his recent review of the 2013 Cadillac XTS for the Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman noted that Cadillac’s new luxury sedan would soon colonize the curbside check-in areas of airports throughout the United States, supplanting the discontinued Lincoln Town Car as the country’s livery workhorse.

headline: Excerpt: 'Guys with Kids'
text: The new NBC series starts on Sept. 12.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Animal Practice’
text: The new NBC series starts on Sept. 26.

text: The new NBC series starts on Oct. 10.

headline: Smartphone? Presto! 2-Way Radio
text: Cave drawings, smoke signals, letters, Pony Express, telegrams, phone calls, text messages. From the dawn of civilization, man has experimented with different modes of communication, each with pros and cons. Smoke signals, for example, contribute to far fewer car accidents than text messages. Text messages, on the other hand, leave much less soot.

headline: Despite New Fame, Still Struck by Stars
text: THE bloggers behind TomandLorenzo.com have been to countless fashion shows, but one stands out as surreal. It was Oscar de la Renta’s pre-fall collection last December, a tough ticket to score. Not only were the pair seated front row, but Anna Wintour was six seats away.

headline: ‘War Horse’ Is to Close in January
text: In choosing to close the Tony Award-winning hit play “War Horse,” Lincoln Center Theater and its producing partners decided that the costs of running the show, with its elaborate production and cast of 37, were too big to guarantee profitability. The show is midway through its second year, an unusually long run for a nonmusical on Broadway.

headline: Ryan Says Prayer in Schools Is a State Issue
text: PROVO, Utah — Prayer in public schools was prohibited by the United States Supreme Court in 1962, but Representative Paul D. Ryan said on Wednesday that he believed that states should have the right to decide whether it should be allowed.

headline: Report Assails Palm Oil Project in Cameroon
text: On Tuesday, we told you about land grabs by timber companies in Liberia that are threatening that country’s tropical rain forest. Today environmental groups and forestry experts are abuzz about a project in nearby Cameroon that is overseen by Herakles Farms, an affiliate of the New York-based company Herakles Capital that pursues agricultural initiatives in Africa.

headline: Homes for $925,000
text: Properties in Virginia, Miami Beach and Hawaii.

headline: What You Get for ... $925,000
text: ALEXANDRIA, VA.

headline: House Hunting in ... Denmark
text: FOUR-BEDROOM VILLA NEAR A FOREST OUTSIDE COPENHAGEN

headline: Four-Bedroom Villa Near a Forest Outside Copenhagen
text: A wood house built in 1917 and located on the edge of a forest north of Copenhagen, Denmark, is on the market for $2.5 million.

headline: Fact-Checking the Democratic Platform
text: The Democratic Party platform, released this week during the convention in Charlotte, N.C., contained a number of exaggerated or misleading claims in civil liberties and housing.

headline: Bill Clinton’s Democratic Convention Speeches
text: Former President Bill Clinton has spoken in prime time at every Democratic National Convention since 1988, in roles from rising star to former president, candidate to party luminary. The following is a collection of all of those speeches.

headline: Spotify Is Said to Profit From Its Subscribers, but Lose More Luring Them
text: Media Decoder recently looked at the books of Spotify and Pandora, two of the most popular digital music services, and noted that both companies — despite having very different business models — wind up paying most of their revenue in music royalties.

headline: Painting by the Beatles Heads to Auction
text: A painting created collaboratively by all four Beatles in 1966 is being offered as part of a music memorabilia sale by Philip Weiss Auctions, in Oceanside, N.Y., on Sept. 14. The auction house estimates that the painting, now called “Images of a Woman,” will sell for between $80,000 and $120,000.

headline: Despite Rainy Day, Dickey Records 18th Victory
text: ST. LOUIS — R. A. Dickey added more credibility to his campaign for a Cy Young Award and took another step toward a 20-win season Wednesday afternoon, as he guided the Mets to a 6-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

headline: For a Baby, Mobile Screens to Shake and Rattle
text: My two babies have one thing in common that they don’t share with me. Some of their first toys were software apps on mobile devices that are more powerful than the computers that took Neil Armstrong to the moon.

headline: Two Veterans Give a Nod to a Talented Youngster
text: Michael Feinstein, Marilyn Maye and Justin Bieber, together at last. Well, not quite. But at the opening on Tuesday night of Mr. Feinstein and Ms. Maye’s show “Swingin’ the Night Away” at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, the big surprise was the appearance of a fresh-faced 16-year-old crooner, Nick Ziobro.

headline: Cliff Hanger | Chris Sharma
text: The California native (who lives in Catalonia, Spain, the sport’s new epicenter) on the challenges of rock climbing.

headline: Putin Pulls Off Latest Feat: Flying With the Birds
text: MOSCOW — Vladimir V. Putin is the unquestioned supreme leader of Russia, known for his icy stare and steely ways. But now Mr. Putin has taken on a new, perhaps more tender, leadership role. He has guided a flock of birds — through the air.

headline: Football, Yes Sir!
text: The reporter Joe Drape looks at the challenges of playing college football at West Point.

headline: Rock Star
text: The climber Chris Sharma tackles the toughest peaks in the world. But when it comes to skin care, he’s totally down to earth.

headline: Working a Crowd Is Part of the Act
text: Ten minutes after Mitt Romney finished his speech at the Republican National Convention last week Judah Friedlander walked onstage at the Comedy Cellar in Manhattan and got to work solving the world’s problems.

headline: Live Updates From the Democratic Convention
text: The Times will be providing updates and analysis from Charlotte on our live dashboard. You can also follow along on Twitter @thecaucus, or follow our list of Times journalists covering the convention.

headline: Study Finds Increased Risks for N.F.L. Players
text: A disproportionate number of men who played at least five seasons in the N.F.L. from 1959 to 1988 developed Alzheimer’s disease or Lou Gehrig’s disease, according to a study released Wednesday.

headline: Two Amsterdam Museums to Reopen After Major Renovations
text: For years, two major Amsterdam museums — the Stedelijk and the Rijksmuseum — have been largely closed for renovations, with only some of their prized artworks on public view. But that is about to change.

headline: Jodi Picoult Changes Publishers
text: The best-selling author Jodi Picoult has jumped to Ballantine Bantam Dell from Atria for her next book deal, a three-book acquisition that the company announced on Wednesday. The first novel is scheduled for release in 2014. Ms. Picoult is the author of 19 novels including “Sing You Home” and “House Rules.” Her novels have more than 22 million copies in print.

headline: Excerpt: 'Made in Jersey'
text: The new CBS series starts on Sept. 28.

headline: Web Sites With a Historical Bent Join a Place to an Image
text: Jon Voss went to Washington last year with a very specific plan: to pose for a photo at the Jefferson Memorial with the Washington Monument in the background.

headline: Stone Links: Is Doping Cheating?
text: Human enhancement has been high on the minds of philosophers in the wake of the Lance Armstrong affair. At The Atlantic, Evan Selinger wonders how the argument “that Armstrong still deserves our sympathy even if he is guilty of using banned substances” might affect our approach to problems like sustainability and climate change. Feeling bad for Lance, Selinger suggests, is roughly analogous to “feeling bad for the present state of the world,” and thus less conducive to attacking its problems.

headline: Filial Piety: From Strangling Tigers to Taming the Internet
text: A selection of 14th-century parables reworked by the Chinese government to encourage parental devotion in modern times.

headline: The Buzz
text: A PREVIEW of the A-list parties and dinners during New York Fashion Week. Strictly invitation only, unless otherwise noted. Photographs from last night’s parties are at nytimes.com/fashion.

headline: For U.S. Open Grounds Crew, an Arsenal to Combat Wet Courts
text: For most of last week, they were out of sight, out of mind. This week, they have been working around the clock.

headline: Inside the Actor’s Abode
text: The actor B.D. Wong has taken several years to settle into his loft on East Fourth Street.

headline: Every Last Thing Finally in Its Place
text: BRADLEY DARRYL WONG is finally settling into his apartment. Not that the place, a ground-floor loft with a subterranean bedroom on East Fourth Street, is new, exactly. Mr. Wong, otherwise known as B. D., bought it in 2005 and moved in, sort of, four years ago.

headline: Hearing Voices in the Clutter
text: HOUSES, if we look and listen, have secrets to tell us. I didn’t fully understand my parents until I finally faced up to emptying their house. Doing so would have been hard at any time, but it was even harder because I had waited 20 years after their deaths.

headline: It’s Time to Leave the Farm
text: A couple’s farm, overgrown with memories.

headline: Saying Goodbye to the Farm
text: IT’S time to leave the farm in Maryland.

headline: Shopping for Kitchen Counter Stools
text: The founders of the Brooklyn design firm Workstead go shopping for special-height stools for kitchen islands.

headline: Counter Stools
text: IN planning kitchens for clients, the founders of the Brooklyn design firm Workstead have discovered there’s one piece of furniture that is particularly hard to find: the counter-height stool.

headline: Open Teams at Second World Mind Sports Games
text: The performance by Sweden in winning the Open Teams at the Second World Mind Sports Games in France last month was remarkable.

headline: Designing Sets for Oprah, Ellen, Tyra and Now Ricki
text: Ricki Lake, who next week begins her second go-round as a daytime talk-show host with “The Ricki Lake Show,” lives in a house that’s beautiful but “not too precious,” likes the color purple and follows “a somewhat green lifestyle.” She also wanted her new set to feel less like a stage and more “like someone’s living room, where everyone’s opinion is heard.”

headline: Turning the Tables on Gravity
text: Marcello Pozzi, the Italian architect and designer now living in Los Angeles, has designed his first mass-produced piece for the home. Commissioned by Restoration Hardware for its fall line, the Stack 50 table consists of 50 discs of plywood. Forty-eight inches wide, it has a metal disc embedded in the tabletop that secures a metal rod to keep the discs in place, and an asymmetrical base that juts hither and yon in the spirit of a bonsai. The table costs $2,495, and much is made in the promotional materials of its design: “Stack 50 taunts gravity by shifting each disc away from the rod’s axis.”

headline: Eye Candy With a Sweet Center
text: Stephen Johnson’s goal in designing Kiss for Artecnica was to create a lamp that demands to be touched. “It was important for me to give it a real physicality,” said Mr. Johnson, a London-based designer, adding that the versatile piece can be plunked on a desk as a task lamp or dangled over a table as a pendant. “It’s something you want to pick up and explore.”

headline: Explorations in Glass, Deceptively Simple
text: In 2009, the Belgian designer Sylvain Willenz began working with CIRVA, a research center in Marseilles, France, to explore new ways to manipulate glass. Today, in a show called “Glassworks,” the Victor Hunt gallery in Brussels will unveil the results of his experiments with the moody material: Shift, an asymmetrical side table (about $11,100); Spot, a globe-shaped lamp sprinkled with glass shards (about $4,160); and Block, above, a collection of geometric containers (from about $1,575).

headline: Accessories That Can Withstand a Little Steam
text: Since the release of his first collection of bathroom accessories for Kontextür earlier this year, Josh Owen has been exploring what he calls other “overlooked opportunities” for that often overlooked room. Four of them were introduced last month at the New York International Gift Fair: two mirrors, a toilet-paper holder and a towel rack/accessories holder, all in silicone. “The bathroom is such a wet environment, and most things are made of materials that are fighting the relationship with moisture,” Mr. Owen said. Silicone “can live on in perpetuity in those challenging conditions.”

headline: Sales at Sferra, Desiron, Westin Hotels and Resorts and Others
text: Sferra will offer up to 75 percent off first-quality discontinued and overstocked bedding from Wednesday to Sept. 16 (a queen-size Sasha 100-percent Egyptian cotton sateen jacquard duvet set, above, usually $890, will be $445; a queen-size Franco 600-thread-count cotton sheet set, usually $190, will be $75); Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), sferra.com.

headline: Orioles Expecting Sellouts for Yankees Series
text: The Baltimore Orioles are expecting sellouts, or close to them, when they host the Yankees beginning Thursday night for what is arguably their biggest four-game series since 1997.

headline: As China Ages, Beijing Turns to Morality Tales to Spur Filial Devotion
text: BEIJING — Reading it now, six centuries after Guo Jujing wrote this paean to parental devotion, “The 24 Paragons of Filial Piety” comes off as a collection of scary bedtime stories. There is the woman who cut out her own liver to feed her sick mother, the boy who sat awake shirtless all night to draw mosquitoes away from his slumbering parents and the man who sold himself into servitude to pay for a father’s funeral.

headline: Chavez Takes Part in Pregame Ritual
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Eric Chavez wants to be a major league manager one day, and he got some practice Tuesday night when he was asked, minutes before the first pitch, to carry the lineup card to the home plate conference with the umpires.

headline: Same Museum, but a Brand-New Look
text: FOR a few years there, museum construction projects seemed to be synonymous with lavish and expensive new architecture. But lately the thoughtful renovation of existing buildings has enjoyed something of a renaissance, and this fall a few notable examples are coming to fruition.

headline: Making Room for Returning Offspring
text: OUR 23-year-old daughter, Rikki, recently returned home from nursing school to embark on her career, and found she had been downsized by her loving siblings to the worst bedroom in the house: a dark 63-square-foot green vise that’s less than half the size of her previous room.

headline: A Lot of Fuss for Just Sitting and Watching at New York Fashion Week
text: LAST September, Beyoncé Knowles, with budding baby bump swaddled in the shimmering gold sequins of her plunging cocktail dress, turned up at Lincoln Center for the J. Crew Spring 2012 presentation with her sister Solange.

headline: Reaction to Change of Venue for Obama’s Speech
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — While a decision to move President Obama’s speech at the Democratic National Convention to a smaller venue might have left some volunteers and visitors here feeling left out in the cold — or the rain, as the weather forecast was predicting — many took it in stride, their support for the President undiminished.

headline: Romney Focus Is on Preparing for the Debates
text: WEST WINDSOR, Vt. — The sessions begin at 9 a.m. in the living room of a friend’s mountainside getaway here in Vermont’s verdant interior. There are three folding tables: one for Senator Rob Portman of Ohio, who plays President Obama; one for Peter Flaherty, a senior aide who plays the moderator; and one for Mitt Romney, who plays himself.

headline: The N.F.L.'s Conundrum
text: William C. Rhoden discusses how one of the game’s most popular attributes is bound to lead to changes that will cause the National Football League’s downfall.

headline: Spy Chief for Qaddafi Is Extradited to Libya
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s intelligence chief was extradited to Libya by Mauritania on Wednesday, handing a victory to the new Tripoli government in an international tug of war over the chance to put him on trial for murder and war crimes.

headline: A Clarification to My Prior Post
text: I wrote vaguely. I wrote badly. I was misconstrued, and it was entirely my fault.

headline: A Day of Protests, Spared of Confrontations
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – Protesters returned to the streets of Charlotte for a fourth consecutive day on Wednesday, but this time without confrontation or arrests as the Democratic National Convention continued.

headline: Head Injuries Pose a Serious Problem for the N.F.L.
text: William C. Rhoden discusses how one of the game’s most popular attributes is bound to lead to changes that will cause the National Football League’s downfall.

headline: Friends Remember a Big-Hearted Broadcaster
text: Some of his friends chose a New York nightclub rather than a tennis court to bid a proper farewell to Barry MacKay, who died in June at age 76.

headline: Yankees’ Mood Not Shaken
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Shortly after 4:30 p.m. on Wednesday the visitor’s clubhouse at Tropicana Field emptied and the players and coaches went into a side room for a meeting to address their recent crises.

headline: Jodi Picoult Changes Publishers
text: The best-selling author Jodi Picoult has jumped to Ballantine Bantam Dell from Atria for her next book deal, a three-book acquisition that Ballantine announced on Wednesday. The first novel is scheduled for release in 2014.

text: The new CBS series starts on Sept. 25.

text: The new CBS series starts on Sept. 24.

headline: Qatar Imperils Big Merger of Commodity Companies
text: A huge merger in the natural resources business is close to falling apart.

headline: Germany: Officials in Berlin Clarify Guidelines on Circumcision
text: In the first move to create legal clarity since a court ruling in June equated circumcision with bodily injury, justice officials in Berlin laid out guidelines on Wednesday to allow the practice to continue in the city pending nationwide legislation that is expected to back the procedure. The move comes after an outcry from doctors who feared they could be prosecuted for carrying out circumcisions after the June 26 ruling in a Cologne court. While it is not applicable in other jurisdictions, it created legal confusion across the country. The ruling also provoked strong protests from religious communities in Germany and abroad. The Berlin guidelines stipulate that both parents must confirm they wish to have their son circumcised because of religious beliefs and that the practice must be performed in a sterile environment.

headline: $1 Pizza Slice Is Back After a Sidewalk Showdown Ends Two Parlors’ Price War
text: The signs have been changed. The invectives have softened. The products remain, well, unlikely to win any culinary awards.

headline: Gay Democrats Celebrate a Newfound Visibility
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — After years of struggling for attention and recognition from the nation’s political parties, gays and lesbians have catapulted to the forefront of the Democratic convention here, prominent on the stage, in speeches, in the platform and at parties that go on after the proceedings have finished.

headline: Rachel Comey: Spring 2013 RTW
text: New York

headline: Like the Army Itself, Recruiters Prepare to Make Do With Less
text: WASHINGTON — From Uncle Sam saying “I want YOU” through “Be All You Can Be” to today’s “Army Strong,” the United States Army has tailored its recruiting strategy to fill its ranks in war and in peace, in the years of the draft and with an all-volunteer force. It has reframed its education targets, sometimes opening its doors to high school dropouts, at other times pursuing college graduates and, more recently, finding a way to assess home-schooled students.

headline: Russia: Police Convoy Is Attacked in Restive Ingushetia
text: Five people died and at least one was wounded when a police convoy came under attack on Wednesday in the volatile southern Russian republic of Ingushetia. A hidden explosive device ripped through the first of the convoy’s two vehicles as it moved through the republic’s Sunzhen district, said a local official of the Investigative Committee. Unidentified fighters then opened fire from a nearby wooded area before fleeing, the Investigative Committee said. Officials have begun an investigation and are searching for the attackers. The bombing came after several weeks of increased violence in the North Caucasus region.

headline: Republicans Use Lopez Case as a Weapon
text: ALBANY — New York Republicans, sensing that the sexual harassment allegations against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez could become a liability for Democrats, are moving to make the scandal a campaign issue.

headline: Leak Prompts Netanyahu to Cancel Security Cabinet Meeting on Iran Issue
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu abruptly canceled a meeting of his security cabinet on Wednesday, saying information was leaked from the highly confidential deliberations, a security failure that could undermine his efforts to project a unified front to the West about how to deal with Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Illinois: Man Sues Over Terrorist Status
text: A Bridgeview man has filed a lawsuit in federal court seeking to lift restrictions placed on him by the Department of Treasury when it deemed him a “specially designated terrorist” in 1995. In the suit the man, Muhammad A. Salah, says, in essence, that it is impossible for him to lead a normal life — to open a bank account, get a job or donate to his mosque — without seeking approval from the government. In 2007, Mr. Salah was convicted of lying in a civil lawsuit about ties to Hamas, the Palestinian organization, but he was acquitted of more serious charges of racketeering conspiracy after prosecutors accused him of helping to funnel aid to Hamas. A spokesman for the Treasury Department, named as a defendant in the suit, said he could not comment on pending litigation.

headline: Young Golfer Makes Progress in Focusing on Process
text: CARMEL, Ind. — It started with a shy request, made last week on the eve of the Deutsche Bank Championship. Kyle Stanley found himself on the practice green alongside Steve Stricker, one of the best putters in the game, so he asked if he could look at his stroke.

headline: Emanuel Takes On New Role as a ‘Super PAC’ Wrangler
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Senior Democrats put aside any remaining qualms about jumping into the “super PAC” era, enlisting Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago to focus on raising money for outside groups that are seeking to help the White House rather than keep a leadership role in President Obama’s re-election campaign.

headline: Gaza: Israeli Airstrike Kills Three Militants
text: An Israeli airstrike killed three Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip late Wednesday and seriously wounded a fourth, according to Palestinian and Israeli officials. Israel said the militants had been preparing to launch a rocket to attack Israel. The raid came days after Palestinian militants fired about a dozen rockets into southern Israel from Gaza, the coastal enclave controlled by Hamas. Groups affiliated with Al Qaeda claimed responsibility for those attacks and criticized Hamas this week for cracking down on them.

headline: Manning Fails to Solve Cowboys’ New Look on Defense
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Eli Manning got a different look when he surveyed the Dallas defense in the season opener. For the most part, he did not like what he saw in a 24-17 loss to the Cowboys on Wednesday night.

headline: Missouri: Bishop Will Face Judge, Not Jury
text: The trial of Bishop Robert W. Finn and the Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph on charges of failure to report suspected child abuse has been moved up to Thursday and will be decided by a judge, not a jury. The change was made public in a court filing on Wednesday, and avoids a lengthy public trial that was set to start Sept. 24. Bishop Finn is the first Roman Catholic prelate in the country to be indicted in the sexual abuse scandals. He and the diocese each face two misdemeanor counts of failing to report hundreds of lewd photographs of young girls on a laptop computer belonging to the Rev. Shawn Ratigan. Father Ratigan pleaded guilty to pornography charges in August.

headline: Texas: Mosquito Spraying Shows Results
text: State health officials said Wednesday that the death toll from West Nile virus continues to rise, but they were encouraged by data that suggested the virus had peaked in the Dallas area. The mosquito-borne disease has sickened hundreds of people there and killed 13. A recent spraying operation in the area appeared to reduce the population of mosquitoes. Officials said the insects had declined by 93 percent in places that received two consecutive nights of spraying. Nationwide, 1,993 cases have been reported, including 87 deaths, a 25 percent increase over last week’s numbers. In Texas, there have been 1,113 cases, including 40 deaths, the most fatalities of any state.

headline: U.S. Presses Iraq on Iranian Planes Thought to Carry Arms to Syria
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department said Wednesday that Iraq has an obligation under United Nations Security Council resolutions to insist that Iranian planes that are suspected of flying arms to Syria over Iraqi airspace land so the cargo can be inspected.

headline: Empowerment
text: I’ve spent most of the day with a parent in the hospital; and my thoughts turned to the GOP platform, which boasts that

headline: Georgia: Fraud Suspected at Family Services
text: The state is investigating whether child-protection officials falsified records to qualify for millions of dollars in federal money. Agents raided a Division of Family and Children Services office in Columbus on Wednesday and issued arrest warrants for two former officials. The former director, Deborah Cobb, and a protective services supervisor, Phyllis Mitchell, were charged with destroying, changing and falsifying child abuse reports. They are suspected of having falsified reports to make it seem as if they had met federal rules for investigating abuse in a timely way.

headline: Pushed by Obama, Democrats Alter Platform Over Jerusalem
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — President Obama, seeking to quell a storm of criticism from Republicans and pro-Israel groups, directed the Democratic Party on Wednesday to amend its platform to restore language declaring Jerusalem the Israeli capital.

headline: Learning as Freedom
text: Middletown, Conn.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Mindy Project'
text: The new Fox series starts on Sept. 25.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,093 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Roddick, at a Loss for Words, Leaves Behind a Career of Superlatives
text: It looked quite misleadingly like business as usual at the United States Open on Wednesday: Andy Roddick with a microphone in his hand and sweat dripping off the bill of his cap onto the blue court inside Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Jack Cermak, a Wind Tunnel Innovator, Dies at 89
text: Jack E. Cermak, an engineer who was among the first to use a wind tunnel to gauge the wind’s impact on skyscrapers and who did consulting work on the World Trade Center and the Sears Tower, among other projects, died Aug. 21 at his home in Fort Collins, Colo. He was 89.

headline: A Controversial Reference to Jerusalem
text: Jim Rutenberg discusses the Democratic Party platform’s controversial reference to Jerusalem as the capital of Israel.

headline: Wide Area of Nation Still Parched After Storm
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The remnants of Hurricane Isaac that blew through the middle of the country over the weekend softened the worst drought in decades in some areas, but a large portion of the nation remains desiccated with ponds still too shallow to water cattle, fields too dusty for feeding and crops beyond the point of salvage, meteorologists and agriculture experts said Wednesday.

headline: A Clash Over a Spine Treatment
text: Dr. Daryl F. Fourney’s role as a lead researcher in a clinical trial for a device to treat back pain began normally enough.

headline: Is Bad Weather Really the Reason to Move Obama’s Speech Indoors?
text: On Wednesday, Democrats announced that they would move President Obama’s Thursday night acceptance speech indoors, citing a threat of stormy weather at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Agent Orange Victims Get Scientology Treatment
text: BANGKOK — The Vietnamese government is treating some people exposed to Agent Orange, the defoliant sprayed by American troops during the Vietnam War, using a detoxification method developed by the founder of the Church of Scientology, according to doctors involved in the program.

headline: Joe South, Singer and Writer of Hit Songs, Dies at 72
text: Joe South, a singer-songwriter who wove confrontational lyrics into bouncy pop hits of the late 1960s and early ’70s, including “Games People Play,” “Walk a Mile in My Shoes” and “(I Never Promised You a) Rose Garden,” died on Wednesday at home in Flowery Branch, Ga., north of Atlanta. He was 72.

headline: Voter ID Wars
text: If you’ve only got 30 seconds to make your case in the debate over photo ID laws — which require voters to show up at the polls with a government-issued photo ID — it’s much easier to argue in favor of the laws.

headline: Voter ID Wars
text: In the second episode of an Op-Docs series, “Electoral Dysfunction,” the political humorist Mo Rocca explores controversial voter identification laws, which could benefit Republicans.

headline: A Never-Ending Story
text: An article in the paper the other day caught my eye and led me to ponder something I’d rather not have to think about at all: the Republican Party platform.

headline: Standing on the Precipice, a Strange Place for the Yankees
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Red Sox do collapses: memorably in 1978, destructively just last fall. The Mets do collapses — regularly, even what can feel like annually. The Phillies collapsed so dramatically in 1964, losing 10 games in a row to blow a six-and-a-half-game lead, that the performance stood for decades as a benchmark for choking.

headline: The Better Economic Question
text: Democrats have been nervous about the inevitable election-year question, “Are you better off than you were four years ago?” Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland even stumbled over it a few days ago, saying “no,” before quickly blaming President George W. Bush.

headline: Biden’s Speech Likely to Spotlight Strengths, or Foibles
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Folksy and loose, passionate and sometimes off script, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrives onstage Thursday night as the president’s most important political partner, policy enforcer, conscience, scold and occasional albatross.

headline: Despite Protections, Botanists Fear Drought’s Toll on a Pink-Petaled Rarity
text: MONTAUK, N.Y. — At the eastern end of Long Island, on the South Fork, tucked among the wobbly clam shacks and the steroidal homes, there are a few small grassy plots sectioned off by short chicken-wire fences. The wire is rusty, and the wooden posts that hold it upright are weathered to a milky gray. One plot is not far from a cliff that drops straight to the sea. Another is within eyeshot of a condominium association’s swimming pool.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Sept. 6
text: Fall’s opulent looks show up on shoes; Annelise Michelson designs dangerous-looking jewelry; and other shopping related news.

headline: With Sales Sagging, Campbell Hands Off to a Powerful Spokeswoman
text: CAMPBELL’S CHUNKY soup introduced its Mama’s Boy campaign in 1997 with a commercial featuring the N.F.L. star Reggie White on the sidelines as his mother (played by an actress) sneaks onto the field dressed as a cheerleader to make sure that he has eaten his soup.

text: Philadelphia

Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago
