headline: Hunts Point Market Deal Runs Into a New Obstacle
text: New York City’s Hunts Point Produce Market, which threatened to move to New Jersey in 2010, finally got the subsidy it wanted from the Bloomberg administration to revamp and expand its longtime home in the Bronx.

headline: U.S. Court Halts Some Cuts for Medicaid Home Care
text: Charles Strouchler, a former publicity agent for classical-music management companies, has such severe multiple sclerosis that he has to be washed, fed, secured in a wheelchair during the day and turned in bed at night. For the past 15 years, he said, he has been able to live at home only because Medicaid pays for aides to take care of him around the clock.

headline: College Coaches Keep Busy at Junior Tournament
text: By Wednesday, most of the college coaches had drifted back to their campuses, but by one rough estimate there were as many of them watching junior players here as there were junior players to watch.

headline: Angels Continue Turnaround With Sweep of the Athletics
text: OAKLAND, Calif.

headline: A Touchy Relationship
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton was in a philosophical frame of mind on Wednesday as she surveyed the impasse between the United States and China on a daunting range of issues. “Our two nations,” she said, “are trying to do something that has never been done in history, which is to write a new answer to the question of what happens when an established power and a rising power meet.” As the secretary’s fifth trip to China demonstrated, that is proving to be a complicated process.

headline: An AK-47 in a Tennessee Park
text: In camouflage gear one Sunday afternoon, Leonard Embody went into a state park near Nashville carrying a Draco AK-47 pistol fully loaded with 30 rounds to test his constitutional rights. Frightened visitors reported that a man was in the park with an “assault rifle.” A park ranger, thinking the weapon might be ready to fire, sensibly ordered Mr. Embody to the ground, removed his gun, patted him down for other weapons and detained him.

headline: They Provide the Music to Sashay By
text: WHAT would a fashion show be without music?

headline: Quebec Attack May Have Been Assassination Attempt, Police Say
text: MONTREAL — The return to power of the separatist Parti Québécois continued to be overshadowed on Wednesday by a shooting here that the police said might have been an assassination attempt on Quebec’s premier-designate.

headline: More Tax Tricks, Private Equity Style
text: Gawker.com was onto something big last month when it raised questions about Mitt Romney’s taxes by putting online confidential documents from Bain Capital, the private equity firm co-founded by Mr. Romney.

headline: Steel Leads Revival in Ohio River Valley
text: PADUCAH, Ky. — On a mile-wide reach of the Ohio River, just upstream from where it converges with the Mississippi, Ray McKinney, the first mate aboard a towboat named the Mike Weisend, pounded the slack out of steel cables that lash 15 barges together in a 1,000-foot-long tow.

headline: New Wrinkle in Men’s Wear: Shops Just for Men
text: The conventional wisdom about guys and shopping has always been that they go together like paisley and plaid, which is to say not very well. There is a reason men’s wear in most stores is relegated to the back walls and the basements, while women’s wear is front and center.

headline: Picking Up Tennis Balls, and Attention
text: As the television cameras canvassed the scene and the fans glued their eyes to Serena Williams as she crushed Andrea Hlavackova of the Czech Republic, 6-0, 6-0, on Monday, another actor on the court was feeling the glare of the spotlight at the United States Open.

text: The discord among the three Athanasatos brothers was nearly four decades deep, and it centered on the family’s two-story brick house in Borough Park, Brooklyn.

headline: Rethinking ‘Junk’ DNA
text: A large group of scientists has found that so-called junk DNA, which makes up most of the human genome, does much more than previously thought.

text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.–So much for keeping up the pretense that super PACs are independent from campaigns.

text: In the smartphone market, Apple and Samsung have become the two giants. Is there room for a third?

headline: For Farms in the West, Oil Wells Are Thirsty Rivals
text: GREELEY, Colo. — A new race for water is rippling through the drought-scorched heartland, pitting farmers against oil and gas interests, driven by new drilling techniques that use powerful streams of water, sand and chemicals to crack the ground and release stores of oil and gas.

headline: Berdych Upsets Federer in Quarterfinals
text: In the third set, momentum swung back toward Roger Federer, winner of 17 Grand Slam singles titles, candidate for best player of all time. He felt it. Tomas Berdych felt it. The crowd, which obviously felt it, roared. The stands shook. The question lingered.

headline: Immigration and the Democratic Party
text: A bus carrying undocumented immgrants rode from Phoenix, Ariz., to Charlotte, N.C. And Marcus Mabry and Representative Charlie Gonzalez of Texas discuss immigration and Latino voters at the D.N.C.

headline: Louisiana: Storm Churns Up Oil Off Coast
text: Hurricane Isaac churned up enough oil in a part of south Louisiana that was among the hardest hit by the BP spill that state wildlife officials announced the emergency closing of some coastal waters to commercial fishing. Six heavy tar mats were found just offshore of a 13-mile stretch of sandy and marshy coastline, and tar balls were found on the beach as well. Tests are being performed to determine whether the oil belongs to the well drilled by the Deepwater Horizon, and results are expected within days. “It possibly could be our oil, but we don’t know,” said Ray Melick, a spokesman for BP, adding that crews were engaged in cleanup activities in the area only days before the storm.

headline: Shoe Designer Can Protect Its ‘Pop’ of Red, Court Says
text: The case of Louboutin v. Yves Saint Laurent has been one of high stakes in high heels.

headline: Andrew Rosenthal and Charles M. Blow
text: The Op-Ed columnist Charles Blow and the Editorial Page Editor Andrew Rosenthal discuss Bill Clinton’s, and other speakers’, roles at the Democratic Convention.

headline: In a Tax Case, a Debate: Is Lap Dancing an Art?
text: New York State’s highest court, the Court of Appeals, is used to considering weighty issues, like same-sex marriage and the death penalty. But on Wednesday, its august chambers entertained a debate of perhaps less significance but far more prurience: whether lap dancing constitutes a form of art.

headline: Court Rulings Help Illegal Immigrants’ College-Bound Children
text: Several states with financial difficulties have moved quietly in recent years to reduce spending on college education by denying low tuition rates and financial aid to American citizens who are the children of illegal immigrants.

text: Karen Geronimo, a member of the Mescalero Apache tribe in town for the Democratic convention, knows what she wants from Elizabeth Warren, the Senate candidate from Massachusetts: a blood sample.

headline: Yankees Top Rays, and the Division
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Yankees’ streak of 84 days in sole possession of first place in the American League East ended with a thud Tuesday, but their time as co-holders of the division lead lasted barely one day.

headline: Opinion: Charles Blow and Mo Rocca

headline: Djokovic Is Still Talking About Tarps
text: Novak Djokovic, the defending men’s champion at the United States Open, seems to be waging a one-man campaign for tarps at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center. At last year’s Open, after two days of play were wiped out by rain, Djokovic said, “What I have to say is I just don’t understand why, you know, if you have ‑‑ for example, if you don’t have a roof, O.K., on this Grand Slam, why you don’t have covers on the court, you know?”

headline: The Buddy to Shop With
text: SOMETIMES you have occasion to look inside a stranger’s closet (hey, it happens), and you can see what they’re about. I recently had that opportunity and, affixed to the inside of the door, the gentleman in question had a Mr Porter sticker with his name on it. I didn’t know very much about the guy, but quickly, I understood him.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg Announces Winners of Project Pop-Up N.Y.C.
text: On Wednesday, in an effort to support fashion and technology entrepreneurs Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced the winners of Project Pop-UP N.Y.C., a competition that the mayor’s office and the Economic Development Corporation. Would-be winners had four weeks to get their applications in starting from the end of June. The nine application questions solicited thetype of information that one would put on a business plan: Who is your competition, and how are you different or better? Who is on your management team? What market does it address, and how big is thismarket?

headline: A Look Back at Roddick’s Career
text: At the time of his retirement, Andy Roddick was the most decorated active American male tennis player. He remains the last American to win a Grand Slam final.

headline: A Street Sense on Exhibit
text: WHILE designers parade their creations this week and next on the New York runways, the Danziger Gallery in Chelsea is bringing fashion back to street level with an exhibition by the photographer Scott Schuman, whose blog, The Sartorialist, has made him one of fashion’s most notable documentarians.

headline: Gin Palace
text: WHILE gin makes you sin, a juniper-based cocktail in Manhattan can also make you poor.

headline: A Fashion Week Party, Without the Fashion
text: IT takes a lot of nerve to have an art opening on the first night of Fashion Week — which is also Fashion’s Night Out, in case you hadn’t heard. Andy Valmorbida isn’t worried. This is the fourth time that Mr. Valmorbida, the young pop-up exhibitionist and cocky Australian-born art entrepreneur, has crashed the all-important night with a big party. He says the timing is coincidental. Oh, sure.

headline: After Pregame Pomp, a Pratfall

headline: How Dangerous Is Your Couch?
text: In September 1976, a mail runner from Katmandu arrived at Base Camp on Mount Everest with a package for Dr. Arlene Blum, a member of the American Bicentennial Everest Expedition. The package had nothing to do with the climb, or Blum’s status as the first American woman to attempt the world’s highest peak. It concerned pajamas. Inside were the proofs of an article she co-wrote for the journal Science about a chemical then widely used in children’s sleepwear. The subtitle was unusually blunt for a scientific paper: “The main flame retardant in children’s pajamas is a mutagen and should not be used.”

headline: Tip of the Week: Linux on a Stick
text: An aging computer that cannot quite meet the requirements for a Windows 7 upgrade can sometimes find a few more years of usefulness with a switch to the Linux operating system. Ubuntu, which makes a free and easy-to-use version of Linux, has traditionally made it easy to try out the system by posting instructions for making a compact disc that can boot up and run Linux for a test drive before installing it. But for old computers with broken disc drives, Ubuntu Linux can also be run from a USB flash drive. The Ubuntu site has detailed instructions here for making a bootable USB stick (or CD) with the current version of Ubuntu from either a Windows or Mac computer, and an online demo here.

headline: Bill Clinton and Structural Unemployment

headline: Summer’s (More or Less) Out. School’s In.

headline: Ford Transit and Transit Connect Make Landfall in Amsterdam

Susan Stroman (“The Producers”) will be the director and choreographer.

headline: The Clinton Magic
text: In a sweeping, sprawling, drawling 48-minute stemwinder of a speech last night, the former President of the United States drove a rhetorical truck through the biggest opening that Mitt Romney and the Republicans created for Democrats last week. The G.O.P. convention promised to make difficult choices and hard calls and be bracingly honest with the public, but the Republican speakers discussed policy in only the broadest and loosest terms, eschewing detail in favor of generalizations and creativity in favor of boilerplate. In response, Bill Clinton did everything they didn’t, diving deep on policy detail, covering issues ranging from Medicaid to welfare to prescription drugs to student loans, and effectively defining the Republicans — defining them negatively, it need hardly be said — on a range of issues where they declined to define themselves. Writing on Paul Ryan last week, I said that we shouldn’t be surprised that his speech was less wonky than his reputation, since a VP address is “hardly the time to talk about block grants and premium support and whether to peg spending rates to inflation or G.D.P. plus one percent.” But Clinton reminded us that this need not be true — that it’s possible to get wonky without losing your audience, and to embrace policy detail as a weapon against your opponents. Journalists tend to assume that voters tune policy substance out, and when the substance is delivered droningly or too abstractly no doubt they often do. But for the most effective rhetoricians, the mere act of talking in detail about the work of government can be a more effective way to persuade the public that you’re serious than a hundred vague promises to “make the hard choices” and “level with the American people.”

text: Measurements in recent years of naturally occurring methane in New York State wells could serve as a base line for assuring the quality of water supplies if and when fracking for natural gas gets under way in the state, the United States Geological Survey reported this week.

headline: Ludo Lefebvre Is Coming to New York
text: Ludo Lefebvre, the French chef who relocated to Los Angeles years ago and has made a name for himself doing pop-up dinners there called LudoBites, will be coming to New York to celebrate the publication of his new cookbook based on those dinners. “LudoBites” will be published on Oct. 9, and to celebrate the occasion he will do a dinner at Blue Ribbon Bakery in Greenwich Village, cooking with Bruce Bromberg, whom he met when they were in the Michelin three-star kitchen at Pierre Gagnaire in Paris.

headline: From Passion to Transcendence
text: THREE of the world’s greatest dancers, each from a different continent, each from a different dance idiom, come to New York this fall. The Spanish flamenco artist Soledad Barrio returns, with her troupe Noche Flamenca, to the Joyce Theater for two weeks starting Sept. 18. Nov. 1 through 3 the Indian Bharata Natyam dancer Malavika Sarukkai performs at the Baryshnikov Arts Center. And the Argentine tango master Gabriel Missé returns to New York from Nov. 23 through December, teaching workshops and appearing in the city’s milongas, or social tango gatherings.

headline: The Postmodern Revolution, Redefined
text: IT’S hard to imagine there was a time when postmodern dance was considered extreme, but on a hot July night in 1962 at Judson Memorial Church, the fireworks happened onstage. Judson Dance Theater was born: now, 50 years later, the dance world is looking back to the artistic movement that inspired generations to come.

headline: On Our Radar: Tar Balls on the Gulf Coast
text: The state of Louisiana closes a 12-mile section of the gulf coastline after Hurricane Isaac washes up oil and tar balls in an area that was a hot spot for inundations of oil during the Deepwater Horizon spill of 2010. Testing must be conducted to verify that the oil is from the Macondo well; if it is, BP will have to help finance the cleanup, officials say. Meanwhile, Greenpeace photographs oil washing up in Alabama and Mississippi. [The Times-Picayune, Greenpeace]

headline: John F. Stacks, Writer and Editor, Dies at 70

headline: Art Modell, Influential N.F.L. Owner but Not Always Beloved One, Dies at 87
text: Art Modell, who helped make professional football more popular than baseball and rich beyond its wildest dreams but who broke Cleveland’s heart by killing his money-losing team, the Browns, to give birth to the Baltimore Ravens, died on Thursday in Baltimore. He was 87.

headline: Danish Art-Rock, and Beethoven, Too
text: THINK of the new concert season at the Metropolitan Museum of Art as the Met Remixed. Limor Tomer, who was appointed in 2011 to run the museum’s concerts and lectures department, has already staged several concerts at the museum, most notably a 10th-anniversary commemoration of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and a celebration in April of the composer Philip Glass and the violinist Timothy Fain in the Temple of Dendur. But the season about to open is the first she planned fully.

headline: 36 Hours in Galway, Ireland
text: FREQUENTLY called Ireland’s most Irish city, this coastal metropolis is a place where Celtic culture and literature have long thrived, often in the traditional Gaelic language. But these days you’re just as likely to hear Spanish, Polish or Japanese along Galway’s crowded streets in this increasingly international college town (the National University of Ireland, Galway, is here). While the fall is less crowded than the tourist-clogged summer, Galway’s festival culture keeps going strong, with the 10,000-person Galway International Oyster and Seafood Festival in late September and the Galway Theater Festival in early October, to name just two events. Of course, the city’s notoriously lively pubs can provide a few pints and plenty of craic (Irish slang for “a good time”) any night of the year.

headline: A Rare Breed: New Operas at the Met
text: ON Oct. 23 the Metropolitan Opera will offer something that has been too infrequent during Peter Gelb’s six years as general manager: a new production of an opera by a living composer.

headline: Going to Galway, Ireland
text: An ancient arch, shopping on Shop Street and pints at a former dance hall in this city on the country’s western coast.

headline: A Watershed Moment For Early Music
text: THE early-music culture skirmish is long over. Proponents of historically informed performances have won, their movement now in the mainstream and their anti-Romantic, anti-self-indulgent principles apparent everywhere.

headline: Excerpt: 'Go On'
text: The new NBC series starts on Sept. 12.

headline: Spotlight Illuminates Work by 2 Composers
text: APART from dark, tousled hair; a taste for fashionably understated eyewear; and a knack for overturning musical conventions, the composers David T. Little and Olga Neuwirth do not seem to have much in common. Mr. Little, a 33-year-old American composer based in Weehawken, N.J., is known for bracing, rock-infused, politically pointed works; Ms. Neuwirth, 44 and Austrian, is among Europe’s leading postmodernists, with operas, orchestral works and chamber pieces that demonstrate a formidable grasp of history and technique.

headline: An Art Scene Blooms in a Toronto Neighborhood
text: Industrial spaces are turning into galleries in once-neglected Bloordale Village.

headline: A Way With Bach, Or Two Or Three
text: THE pianist Angela Hewitt, a wonderful Bach interpreter, once said that the greatest compliment about her playing had come from her father, who said: “I didn’t hear you. I only heard Bach.”

headline: Image of the Day: September 6
text: Environmentally friendly rickshaws distributed to women from poor families in New Delhi.

headline: What to See Next? Gaze at the Horizons
text: “What should I see?”

headline: Fore!
text: This issue’s artist-created ‘‘T’’ comes from the 81-year-old conceptual artist John Baldessari, who took inspiration from his days as a grade-school art teacher. Instead of gluing beans or macaroni onto construction paper, he used golf tees, which, he readily admits, made for a bad pun: a ‘‘T’’ made of tees. “The ideal form of this T,” he says, “would be that every copy of T magazine would have real tees glued onto it. But this is as close as I can come. It’s kind of like trompe l’oeil tees.”

headline: First-Week Lessons: How to Breathe and Wait for the Bathroom
text: At Harlem Village Academies off East 120th Street, the second stop on Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott’s back-to-school tour, Mr. Walcott spent some time helping kindergartners draw and leading a ninth-grade English class in a discussion of the question, “Is man a victim or agent of his fate?”

headline: World Premiere by Craig Lucas Added to Atlantic Theater Company Season
text: “The Lying Lesson,” a new play about a movie star who may or may not be Bette Davis, written by the Pulitzer Prize finalist Craig Lucas (“Prelude to a Kiss”), will have its world premiere off Broadway this winter at Atlantic Theater Company, executives for the organization announced on Thursday.

headline: What Obama Should Say
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.–Yesterday I asked readers what Obama should say tonight at the Democratic Convention. Here’s a small selection of their responses. (To see the rest, go to the comments section of the original article.)

headline: Not a Cancer Survivor
text: I am not a cancer survivor, and neither are the women in my cancer support group.

headline: The House That Hova Built
text: It’s difficult to know what to ask a rapper. It’s not unlike the difficulty (I imagine) of being a rapper. Whatever you say must be considered from at least three angles, and it’s an awkward triangulation. In one corner you have your hard-core hip-hop heads; the type for whom the true Jay-Z will forever be that gifted 25-year-old with rapid-fire flow, trading verses with the visionary teenager Big L — “I’m so ahead of my time, my parents haven’t met yet!” — on a “rare” (easily dug up on YouTube) seven-minute freestyle from 1995. Meanwhile, over here stands the pop-rap fan. She loves the Jiggaman with his passion for the Empire State Building and bold claims to “Run This Town.” Finally, in the crowded third corner, stand the many people who feel rap is not music at all but rather a form of social problem. They have only one question to ask a rapper, and it concerns his choice of vocabulary. (Years pass. The question never changes.) How to speak to these audiences simultaneously? Anyway: I’m at a little table in a homey Italian restaurant on Mulberry Street waiting for Mr. Shawn Carter, who has perfected the art of triangulation. It’s where he likes to eat his chicken parms.

headline: It’s Official: Facebook Closes Its Acquisition of Instagram
text: 11:50 a.m. | Updated  Adding details.

headline: The Family Barge, Minus a Flotilla of Personal Technology
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — It’s one thing to take a 41-year-old station wagon for a Sunday drive, quite another to put it on the road for a six-day, 1,400-mile family vacation.

headline: Soldiering Amid Hyacinths and Horror
text: Kevin Powers joined the Army when he was 17 and served as a machine-gunner in Iraq in 2004 and 2005. Drawing upon those experiences, he has written a remarkable first novel, one that stands with Tim O’Brien’s enduring Vietnam book, “The Things They Carried,” as a classic of contemporary war fiction.

headline: Film Is Dead? Long Live Movies
text: IN the beginning there was light that hit a strip of flexible film mechanically running through a camera. For most of movie history this is how moving pictures were created: light reflected off people and things would filter through a camera and physically transform emulsion. After processing, that light-kissed emulsion would reveal Humphrey Bogart chasing the Maltese Falcon in shimmering black and white.

headline: Three Days in the Fishbowl, and Here to Tell the Tale
text: “Welcome to the fishbowl,” the corporate spokeswoman Eileen Murphy told me a few weeks back when I was named public editor at The New York Times. She was right. The scrutiny began immediately, in the form of interviews, commentary from pundits, welcoming messages on Twitter and the dredging up of old stories I’d written and forgotten.

headline: World’s First Pizza Museum Opening in Philadelphia
text: Visit any of the nation’s more than 60,000 pizza joints, and you will find plenty of people who believe that the perfect pie is a work of art. Certainly, pizza has become as embedded in American cuisine and culture as the hamburger and apple pie.

headline: The God of Marriage
text: After a month in San Francisco, Townies returns to New York City.

headline: ‘Annie’ for Sun, a New ‘Woolf’ for Fear
text: Dates are subject to change.

headline: Stage Girls in Hard-Knock Competition
text: OF the three coming Broadway musicals about plucky girls persevering against cruel adults and grim circumstances, which show will break out of the pack and become a box office hit?

headline: Pakistan May Be Expelling Aid Group’s Foreign Staff
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani government appeared Thursday to have moved to expel international staff members at the aid agency Save the Children, apparently over accusations that one of its employees helped the C.I.A. recruit a Pakistani doctor who played a role in tracking Osama bin Laden last year.

headline: For Madrid, a Few Encouraging Words From Germany
text: MADRID — Even as the European Central Bank was taking further steps to help Spain and other struggling euro economies, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said Thursday that she had “full confidence” in the Spanish government and its efforts to deal with the debt crisis.

headline: Installation View of Los Angeles
text: THE past year has been a roller-coaster ride for the Los Angeles art scene. First there were thrills galore offered by “Pacific Standard Time: Art in L.A. 1945-1980,” a celebration of the city’s postwar art history to which some 60 institutions contributed exhibitions extending from October through March. Then there was Jeffrey Deitch’s bumpy second year as director of the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, culminating in the departure of the museum’s much admired chief curator Paul Schimmel and the resignation of artists like Barbara Kruger and Ed Ruscha from the museum’s board.

headline: ‘Ken Price Sculpture: A Retrospective’
text: Images from the new exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

headline: French Institute Alliance Francaise to Unveil Gould Hall Renovation
text: The French Institute Alliance Française, a New York French cultural center, will officially unveil its major renovation of Florence Gould Hall on Sept. 14 with a concert featuring the jazz musician Bill Frisell along with his groups, the 858 Quartet and the Beautiful Dreamers.

headline: From ‘We Can’ to ‘We Can’t’
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.–Among the more startling lines in Bill Clinton’s keynote address last night–for this listener, anyway–was “we can’t let it happen,” which seemed to encapsulate the Democratic Party’s shift in pitch from 2008 to 2012.

headline: National Ad Campaign for Citibank Reward Program to Feature Alicia Keys
text: Add being boring to the list of reasons to break up with someone. While there are many women who would gladly jump at the chance to date a “boring” guy, a new television ad for a Citibank reward program features one woman who has had enough of her boyfriend’s staid ways.

headline: Rosemarie Trockel
text: A look at some of the work from the artist’s retrospective at the New Museum.

headline: Here’s Looking at You, Conceptualism
text: CONTEMPORARY art is occupying hallowed halls this season: Andy Warhol at the Met, Matthew Barney at the Morgan Library.

headline: Going Beyond Marquee Names on Museum Walls
text: IT may be a mite simplistic to divide artists into usual and unusual suspects. But the truth is there are names that don’t surprise when it is announced that they are to be the subjects of coming exhibitions, and others that do, and pleasantly. This year such surprises are on the rise.

headline: Ai Weiwei
text: In Washington, the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden will mount the first American retrospective of the Chinese artist.

headline: Bartoli’s Signatures: Power and Intensity
text: Marion Bartoli hits both her forehand and backhand with two hands. She volleys with two hands and bounces the ball between serves with two hands on her racket. During changeovers, she raises her bottle of water to her mouth using both arms.

headline: A Theme Change on Opening Night
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: A ‘Dreamer’ Addresses the Democratic Convention
text: Benita Veliz was only at the lectern at the Democratic convention for a few minutes on Wednesday night. CNN did not even turn its cameras on the stage during her brief speech. But for many Latinos in the hall, her moment under the lights was a stunning surprise.

headline: Obama Girls’ Role: Not to Speak, but to Be Spoken Of
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — On Friday, Malia Obama will be at her desk at Sidwell Friends School for the fourth day of high school — hours after waving onstage at the Democratic National Convention with her sister, Sasha.

headline: A White House Childhood
text: Sasha and Malia Obama are rarely seen, but they remain an important part of President Obama’s public image.

headline: Doctor Is Charged in Death of Slipknot Bassist
text: An Iowa doctor who helped run a pain clinic has been charged with involuntary manslaughter in connection with the death of Paul Gray, the Slipknot bassist and co-founder who died of an overdose of narcotics in May 2010, The Des Moines Register reported.

headline: Why Such Suspicion of the ‘Submerged State’?
text: NEW YORK — In my column this week I write about Suzanne Mettler’s idea of the “submerged state” — the government benefits that Americans receive, like tax credits, or support channeled through nonprofits, which is paid for by the state but which are either invisible or feel as if they’ve come from some other source.

headline: The Get | Stephen Russell Earrings
text: Known for exceptional estate gems, the fine jeweler Stephen Russell has created a pair of mesmerizing monochromatic earrings that put Old World glamour back in the moment. Modeled after an 18th-century pendeloque shape, they’re made of almost 200 sapphires, their setting upstaged by all that brilliant blue. And about that setting: Russell chose 18-karat blackened gold to augment the vintagelike quality.

headline: What Goes Up, if Only in Stages
text: ARCHITECTURE is slow. So slow it sometimes appears not to be moving forward at all. Projects get bogged down — more now than ever, it seems — by financial shortfalls, public opposition, disputes over labor or design. All on top of the mundane difficulties of putting together, piece by piece, the stuff that makes a building.

headline: The U.S. Open Chronicles: Summer in the City
text: Irina Falconi, who is playing at the United States Open this year, will write posts throughout the tournament for Straight Sets. She has her own tumblr page, and can be followed on Twitter.

headline: Appeals Court Revives Insider Trading Case Against Obus
text: One of the country’s longest-running insider trading lawsuits has just gotten longer.

headline: Traveling With Children, With Help From Apps
text: Figuring out an itinerary for children can feel like a game of Whac-A-Mole. That puppet show in Boston that your niece loved during her last stay? She’s aged out of it. Your 17-year-old son is happy to crash lectures at Georgetown during a trip to Washington? His 10-year-old brother is not so into it.

headline: Live Updates From Amazon’s Press Event
text: Amazon.com invited journalists to Santa Monica, Calif., for a briefing on new Kindle products. It showed off the Kindle Paperwhite with a new whiter screen, and a new Kindle Fire HD that is a more direct competitor to the iPad than the old Kindle Fire. The company gave a sneak preview of some new Kindle devices in a TV commercial that was broadcast Wednesday night.

headline: The Caucus Click: Axelrod Getting Anxious
text: David Axelrod, center, seated with other top advisers to the Obama campaign, tapped his watch during Bill Clinton’s address to the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday.

headline: The Peanut Gallery Takes On the Democrats
text: Let the historians decide who was the greatest president in American history; I would argue that the best modern commander in chief for comedians is pretty clear. Sure, Nixon is a solid contender, but Bill Clinton, a man with big appetites and a distinctive accent, has given joke tellers a wealth of material. So it’s no surprise that his return to the spotlight at the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday night in Charlotte, N.C., inspired an avalanche of jokes on Twitter. (Just as the Republicans’ gathering did last week). Here are a few highlights:

headline: France Sends Funds to 5 Syrian Civic Groups in Rebel-Held Areas
text: PARIS — The French government is providing funds to five revolutionary councils in rebel-held parts of Syria to help them restore water supplies, sanitation, health services and bakeries, a senior French diplomat, Éric Chevallier, said Thursday.

headline: Migrants Die as Boat Sinks Off Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — At least 58 migrants drowned in the Aegean Sea just off the Turkish coast after the fishing boat that was carrying them sank early Thursday morning, local officials told a Turkish news agency.

headline: JPMorgan Names New Head of Chief Investment Office
text: As it works to move past a multibillion-dollar trading loss tied to a complex credit bet, JPMorgan Chase has been reshuffling its management ranks — focusing specifically on the chief investment office, the powerful unit at the center of the soured trade.

headline: In One Class, Time to Draw, and in Another, a Return to the Olympics
text: The first graders at Young Scholars’ Academy for Discovery and Exploration in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, know how to write their first names, though not necessarily their last names, as they demonstrated for reporters on their first day back to school. A group of them sat around a tiny table Thursday morning, frowning with concentration as they tried to decide how to draw themselves.

headline: BMW Motorrad and Bloomingdale’s, Riding Tandem
text: In the men’s department at Bloomingdale’s, featured fashions this fall include a $795 Michael Kors Leather Utility Jacket, a $45 Vince V-Neck Tee and a $15,675 BMW R1200R Classic.

headline: The Baffling Nexus of Climate Change and Health
text: In 2004, a rare tropical fungus caused a string of respiratory failures and neural disorders along the Pacific Northwest coast, baffling the health community. That same year, Alaskan cruise ship passengers dining on local oysters fell sick with a gastric virus typically found in warm water estuaries. Now Texas, after an unusually wet spring and dry summer, is battling what may become the country’s worst recorded outbreak of West Nile virus.

headline: Breaking It Down: Berdych vs. Federer
text: Roger Federer more than doubled his forehand errors from any of his previous three United States Open matches to lose in four sets to sixth-seeded Tomas Berdych, 7-6 (1), 6-4, 3-6, 6-3, Wednesday.

headline: Cuomo, in Convention City, Gives Spirited Speech From Small Stage
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Giant clusters of red, white and blue balloons hung overhead and an imposing black rope line stretched across the room. Campaign-style bunting festooned the podium and Bon Jovi’s “Working for the Working Man” blared through loudspeakers. A seasoned political spouse leapt to her feet at applause lines, and the candidate shouted to be heard over an adoring crowd.

headline: Clinton Was a Bipartisan President, Except When He Wasn’t
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – Perhaps only Bill Clinton could deliver one of the most brutal partisan poundings of the other party in recent memory and come out of it with people talking about how bipartisan he is.

headline: Singaporean Tells China U.S. Is Not in Decline
text: BEIJING — In an unusual public airing of strategic problems surrounding China’s rise, the prime minister of Singapore, Lee Hsien Loong, warned China on Thursday that it should view the United States not as a declining power, but as a nation with the ability to innovate and bounce back.

headline: What to Watch For in Obama’s Speech
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — President Obama takes the stage Thursday night competing against a formidable array of convention speakers: Mitt Romney, Michelle Obama, Bill Clinton — and Barack Obama.

headline: E-Mail Birthday Intrigue
text: The other day, I got snookered.

headline: Small Plates Are a Big Surprise
text: NO one at the table notices the duck leg confit trailed by a retinue of chanterelles and peaches; or the whole dorade, dappled with olive oil; or the tangle of linguine, lump crab, grilled corn, mascarpone and rendered bacon. We are too busy eating our broccoli.

headline: Focusing on What Is Local, Not Just Organic
text: Like a lot of Americans, Jenn Louis wasn’t raised on a noble diet of organic food.

headline: Culture Clash With Afghans on Display at Briefing
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — It was billed as a news briefing by American and Afghan commanders on what the allies are doing to stop insider attacks by Afghan forces against NATO troops. The first question, though, was just about the last thing the three generals on the dais wanted to hear.

headline: Judge Approves E-Book Pricing Settlement Between Government and Publishers
text: 8:35 p.m. | Updated In a decision that could start an e-book price war in the publishing industry, a federal judge on Thursday approved a settlement between the Justice Department and three major publishers in a civil antitrust case that accused the companies of collusion in the pricing of digital books.

headline: Obama Praises Clinton and Talks Stadium Move in Call With Supporters
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Bill Clinton’s prosecutorial speech to the Democratic convention on Wednesday night went as far as anyone has this year in delineating the differences between the Democratic and Republican agendas, President Obama said on Thursday.

headline: Venice Film Festival: Olivier Assayas Returns to the 1970s
text: VENICE — In his previous movie, “Carlos,” the French filmmaker Olivier Assayas tackled a few big themes of the 1970s — the demise of idealism and the rise of terrorism — through a biopic of the international guerrilla and media star known as Carlos the Jackal. Mr. Assayas’s new film, “Something in the Air,” which had its world premiere in competition at the Venice Film Festival, is another immersion in those tumultuous times, but from a very personal perspective. (The film is also being shown at the Toronto and New York festivals, and will be released in the United States by IFC.)

headline: Why Can’t School Be More Like Summer?
text: From their perspective, the worst thing that happens to my two daughters at the conclusion of each summer is that they have to leave their friends and their joyous days of exploration at their mountain summer camp and come home. The next worst thing that happens to them is that they have to immediately start an experience — school — that feels almost exactly the opposite. The onset of camp-sickness is immediate.

headline: A Look Behind the U.S. Decline in Global Competitiveness
text: For the fourth consecutive year, Switzerland is the most competitive economy in the world, according to a ranking from the World Economic Forum. And, for the fourth consecutive year, the United States fell in the rankings — largely because of worsening criticism of the American government — and is now in seventh place.

headline: Bernadette Corporation
text: A show at Artists Space gathers together the prolific output of this influential and intentionally enigmatic quasi-corporation.

headline: Conversations with Voters: The Economy
text: In a Google+ Hangout, the Op-Ed columnist Frank Bruni and the editorial board writer David Firestone talk to voters from around the country about their views on the economy.

headline: Weighing Prepaid Cards vs. Checking Accounts
text: Prepaid cards can be a better deal than checking accounts for some people, but the cards need more consumer safeguards, a new report from the Pew Charitable Trusts finds.

headline: Clinton Was Not Always an Obama Fan, Romney Ad Recalls
text: 3:12 p.m. | Updated Bill Clinton proved Wednesday night to be one of President Obama’s most forceful and substantive surrogates, but he has hardly been the most consistent. In fact, in a new ad, Mitt Romney’s campaign is reminding voters that Mr. Clinton was once a sharp critic of Mr. Obama, in 2008.

headline: Blasting Your Way Into the Fall
text: FOR video game players the summer begins after Labor Day. The preceding months have the prestige titles and the intriguing independent projects. In that category 2012 has served up Dear Esther, Fez, Journey and Papo & Yo, to name a few. The fall is the time for blockbusters, many of them sequels with big explosions.

headline: New York City Marathon, in Reversal, Will Ferry Bags
text: After criticism from marathoners, New York Road Runners reversed itself and said it would allow runners to check a bag at the starting line of the New York City Marathon on Nov. 4.

headline: Navigating Darkness, or Enlightenment
text: HERE’S the challenge for Eric Kripke, the producer in charge of “Revolution,” an NBC series set on a future Earth without electricity: Take a horror story and make it a fantasy.

headline: Putin Says Missile Deal Is More Likely With Obama
text: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia sauntered into American presidential politics on Thursday, praising President Obama as “a very honest man” and chastising the Republican nominee, Mitt Romney, for describing Russia as “without question our No. 1 geopolitical foe.”

headline: Going Straight (or Otherwise) for the Center
text: GAY is the new straight.

headline: Video Shows Killer of Gas-Station Worker
text: Police officials are offering a $12,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the two men who carried out the fatal armed robbery of a gas station in the Bronx, the chilling exchange captured by video surveillance cameras.

headline: A Writer’s Inspiration? Oh, Brother!
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Amáli
text: Inside the Mediterranean restaurant once known as Persephone.

headline: French Police Nearby, Girl Hides in Car for Hours Under Relatives’ Corpses
text: PARIS — Apparently frozen in terror, a 4-year-old girl crouched silently for eight hours below her dead mother and grandmother in the back of a BMW on a forest road in the French Alps while just steps away investigators hunted for clues, officials said Thursday.

headline: New Jerusalem
text: Mitt Romney and the Republicans have been working overtime to make fealty to Israel a wedge issue in the campaign and to grossly misrepresent President Obama as insufficiently loyal to the Jewish state. So why did the Democrats give the Republicans an opening to pounce?

headline: Week 1 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
text: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Traveling at the Speed of Molasses
text: ZZ TOP has been idling for a while. It tours regularly, playing the road and radio-tested base of its blues and boogie 1970s and ’80s catalog with such delicious control over sound and feel and medium-to-slow tempos that you wonder whether this band, in earthly-purpose terms, needs to do much else.

headline: Whole New State of Mind
text: ALICIA KEYS’S recording studio, the Oven, is on a high floor of a West Chelsea building, with a panoramic city view. The little alcove used for vocals gazes out toward the Empire State Building.

headline: Woody Johnson Says Circus Isn’t in Town
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – Woody Johnson, the Jets’ owner, said he was “very optimistic” that the team would rebound from its disappointing 2011 season but declined to discuss the consequences for Rex Ryan and Mike Tannenbaum if the team misses the playoffs for a second consecutive year.

headline: U.S. Open Food of the Day: Burrata
text: Another installment in our daily reviews of food from the United States Open concession stands.

headline: Rise and Shine for Richard Chai
text: Pulling up to Lincoln Center this morning for the first day of New York Fashion Week, the first thing that caught the eye was the incredible number of people standing in the plaza to gawk at the fashionistas. There had to be 100 people out there, half with cellphone cameras. Somehow, people just know when there’s a big fashion happening.

headline: President Obama’s Girls
text: Jodi Kantor of The New York Times talks about the vital role that President Obama’s daughters, Malia and Sasha, have played in his political life.

headline: Errani Tries to Distance Herself From Barred Spanish Doctor
text: Reaching the singles semifinals and women’s doubles final in New York continues a career season for Sara Errani, who was also a finalist at the French Open. But she has had to face questions about her connection to the Spanish doctor Luis Garcia del Moral, who recently was barred by the United States Anti-Doping Agency as part of the case against Lance Armstrong, a punishment recognized by the International Tennis Federation.

headline: Envelope, Please: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf
text: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf, a Somali student at African Leadership Academy in Johannesburg, South Africa, is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.

headline: News and Verse: Our Weekly Poetry Pairings
text: With the start of the school year, we usher in a new season of Poetry Pairings, a feature we first introduced in 2010.

headline: The Fraying Hospital Safety Net
text: Slender and in his 60s, the patient had been short of breath for several days, a result of untreated heart failure causing fluid to build up in his lungs. Despite his wife’s entreaties, he had refused to go to the hospital, one of the biggest in the city, and waited at home, gasping, until his appointment at our clinic.

headline: President Obama’s Second Chance
text: President Obama’s dilemma has always been that he has been far more successful a president than his opponents claim, but far less successful than he needs to be at making voters see that. Powerful speeches by former President Bill Clinton, Vice President Joe Biden and others did a lot to fix that impression during the convention. But it was up to Mr. Obama to make the case for another term, with a speech that was every bit as fraught with uncertainty and risk as his 2008 convention address.

headline: Before School Lets Out, a Basketball-Playing Robot Takes the Court
text: The first day of school was coming to an end at Staten Island Technical High School, but the members of the school’s robotics team, Team 375: The Robotic Plague, still had one hurdle to clear. They couldn’t wait to demonstrate their champion basketball-launching robot to Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott and other dignitaries who had dropped by.

headline: Making the G.I. Bill Work for Veterans
text: Today’s veterans have faced incredible challenges, but have also received extraordinary opportunities – like the Post 9/11 G.I. Bill. Each year, it helps tens of thousands of veterans attend college by helping pay for tuition and living expenses. Through this program, many veterans have been able to transition successfully from combat back to civilian life.

headline: Romney Isn’t Planning to Watch Obama’s Speech
text: CONCORD, N.H. – Tens of millions of people are expected to tune into President Obama’s acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention on Thursday night. But Mitt Romney doesn’t plan on being one of them.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 6
text: A view of the day in sports, including the Paralympic Games in London and the 18th stage of the Tour of Spain cycling race.

headline: Blistering Bands and Bingo
text: Along with innumerable other starry-eyed provincials, the Miser moved to New York more or less because of “downtown.” The allure of figures like Laurie Anderson and Spalding Gray, Cindy Sherman and Jean-Michel Basquiat, John Zorn and Jim Jarmusch was difficult to resist for us yuppie-oppressed, MTV-addled Generation Xers desperate for deliverance.

headline: Rodents Too Cute Not to Share
text: Our friends at the Wildlife Conservation Society have been inundating us with cute baby animal pix lately, and at some point it might be time to call a moratorium, but Baby Patagonian Cavy Day is definitely not the time.

headline: Amazon Updates Its Kindle Line of E-Readers
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Amazon announced a barrage of new tablets and e-readers on Thursday that makes its challenge to Apple’s iPad a little more serious.

headline: At 91, a Photo Legend Looks Back

headline: Ryan Does Not Bite Back After Clinton Attack
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — A day after Bill Clinton attacked Representative Paul D. Ryan‘s Medicare plan by saying “it takes some brass” to make the claims he has, Mr. Ryan did not mention the former president at a rally here on Thursday.

headline: Honda Introduces an Accord Buffet in New York
text: On Wednesday, Honda introduced the 2013 Accords at Chelsea Piers, on Manhattan’s West Side. The sedan and coupe were joined by the company’s first plug-in hybrid.

headline: ‘The Double Dirty Dozen (& Friends’
text: Freight + Volume

headline: Fashion Week Parties, Warm Up
text: Proenza Schouler and Brian Atwood open new stores, on the eve of New York Fashion Week.

Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist charged in the shooting rampage at the Fort Hood base here in 2009, a move that is likely to delay the start of his trial for weeks as his defense lawyers appeal the ruling.

headline: Theater Talkback: Finding Inspiration in Improvisation
text: During the summer, ArtsBeat invited members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. Trav S. D., a historian of vaudeville, talked about the long bare-knuckles history shared between the boxing ring and the stage; Alexis Soloski, a critic and theater professor, highlighted unforgettable stage entrances; and the playwright Sarah Ruhl explained why critics were not invited to review her “Melancholy Play.”

headline: Putin’s Ambitions Turn to the Far East
text: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is seizing on the Asia-Pacific economic summit conference being held here this weekend to turn assertively to the Far East, hoping to strengthen ties with the Pacific Rim and pursuing ambitious development in Russia itself, starting with this formerly secret naval fortress turned shipping hub on the Sea of Japan.

headline: First Day of School, Brooklyn
text: So today is the first day of public school in New York City. My three kids are all old hands at this by now, so the drop-off was easy. They’re going into second, fifth and eighth grades. For some reason, the eighth grader doesn’t begin school until tomorrow, so he got to go back to his elementary school to see off his younger brother and sister. He was fawned over by his old teachers, who seemed truly amazed that he is now a very tall 13-year-old. I could tell he was enjoying the attention until it happened that the director of his middle school has a second grader he was dropping off; my 13-year-old quickly vanished.

headline: Harriet Jacobs’s First Assignment
text: Harriet Jacobs arrived in Washington in June 1862, she later reported, “without molestation.” Lots of people traveled in and out of the capital at the time, but for Jacobs it was quite a feat. By then a correspondent on assignment for William Lloyd Garrison’s newspaper The Liberator, Jacobs was a former slave and author of the book “Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl,” which she wrote under the assumed name Linda Brent. Traveling through Maryland, where slavery was still legal, and Pennsylvania, where anti-black animus still ran high, would have made for tough going for most free blacks. Even fewer could have taken in the squalor that Jacobs found among the thousands of refugees from the South now huddled in the capital.

headline: The Dangerous Center
text: Many of the Democrats who thrilled to Bill Clinton’s defense of an active government last night have conveniently forgotten how angry they were every time he tacked to the center, most notably by drastically reducing welfare benefits in 1996. President Obama shares some of those instincts toward ideological concessions, creating a bit of suspense regarding the nature of the second-term agenda he intends to unveil tonight.

headline: Partners Create a Superdealership
text: When was the last time an expert from a top auction house dispensed with longtime allegiances and joined forces with someone from the enemy camp? In the fiercely competitive world of Sotheby’s and Christie’s, such an occurrence is rarer than a prized Vermeer.

headline: Lost Tracks
text: “Telegraph Avenue,” Michael Chabon’s rich, comic new novel, is a homage to an actual place: the boulevard in Northern California where Oakland — historically an African-American city — aligns with Berkeley, whose bourgeois white inhabitants are, as one character puts it, “liable to invest all their hope of heaven in the taste of an egg laid in the backyard by a heritage-breed chicken.” The novel is equally a tribute to the cinematic style of Quentin Tarantino, whose films its characters study and discuss, and whose preoccupations pepper its pages: kung fu, cinematic allusions and the blaxploitation films of the 1970s; and an interest in African-American characters and experience. Chabon and Tarantino make an unlikely duo; while the latter’s films tend toward gaudy eruptions of violence, Chabon bends Tarantino’s sensibility to a warmhearted novel about fatherhood in which the onstage violence consists of two graphic childbirth scenes and a 15-year-old boy whacking a chubby thug with a wooden sword. A self-help book in the style of Andrei Tarkovsky would be hardly more oxymoronic.

headline: How Does Denzel Washington Take Off?
text: THE art of acting is so peculiar that even its most skillful practitioners (and the co-workers who love them) can’t quite explain how they do what they do. When you watch a performance like Denzel Washington’s in Robert Zemeckis’s “Flight” (opening Nov. 2), you want to get under the hood of it somehow, to understand what this remarkable thing is made of and what keeps it, improbably, aloft for two perilous hours. But when you ask Mr. Washington or his co-stars how it’s done, they’re mostly at a loss for words, or rather, they talk around it, trying to get at its mysterious workings by way of metaphors, anecdotes and the odd sweeping generality.

headline: Bill Clinton Draws More Viewers Than N.F.L. Opener
text: More people watched former President Bill Clinton’s speech to the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday night than tuned in to see the N.F.L. season opener.

headline: An Unfit Friend
text: I am inviting several friends on a week’s vacation abroad, all expenses paid. All of the guests (but one) are extremely fit, and I’m planning lots of hiking and biking. But I fear that the unfit guest, who is also needy, will ask others to stay behind with her, depriving them of wonderful experiences. The villa has a pool and is near the village, so she should be able to entertain herself. May I discourage her from asking others to keep her company, or ask guests to take turns baby-sitting, or should I let the chips fall where they may? Anonymous

headline: Adrift With a Tiger and the Film God
text: “YOU become the movie you are making,” the Oscar-winning director Ang Lee said in a recent telephone interview. Given that the movie in question is “Life of Pi,” based on the award-winning, fantastical novel about a boy and a Bengal tiger marooned on a boat for 227 days, Mr. Lee is feeling a bit more at sea than usual these days.

headline: Hello, Mummy! We’re Here About That Inheritance
text: The curtain rises in “The Eye of the Storm” with the old lady in bed, angrily grasping at the covers and a life that she refuses to relinquish. Much as she has in the past, Elizabeth Hunter (Charlotte Rampling), an Australian matriarch, lords over all, including her servants and two children, Basil (Geoffrey Rush) and Dorothy (Judy Davis), who have returned to her, reluctantly, skittishly, to secure their inheritance. During their visit Elizabeth fades in and out, by turns raging and murmuring as she fights the world, her seemingly ungrateful children and maybe herself.

headline: A Chinese Dealer, Trafficker in Mystery
text: The Chinese art dealer C. T. Loo held court at his galleries in Paris, New York, Shanghai and Beijing. From the 1910s through the 1940s, he spoke mysteriously of his “friends” who could acquire artifacts in the countryside, while he angled spotlights on stone Buddha heads and opalescent jade bowls for sale.

headline: Treasures of an Heiress From a Personal Paradise
text: The 1930s modernist home at the center of “Doris Duke’s Shangri La: Architecture, Landscape and Islamic Art,” at the Museum of Arts and Design, is a masterpiece of refined eclecticism. Designed for its site in Honolulu by an architect from Palm Beach, Fla., and filled with treasures from the Islamic world, it unites diverse styles and periods with great taste and, it must be said, great wealth.

headline: Israel to Admit 3 of 21 Africans Waiting in Desert

On Thursday night President Obama — along with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator John F. Kerry of Massachusetts — will draw on the administration’s foreign policy record to make the case.

headline: Complaints Against Lenders

And, not surprisingly, just over half the complaints centered on the problems borrowers encountered when they were unable to make payments.

When the Broadway singer Marin Mazzie (“Kiss Me, Kate,” “Passion”) was growing up in Rockford, Ill., she recalled on Wednesday evening at 54 Below, she was in the thrall of the Monkees’ Davy Jones and of David Cassidy and fantasized about being “the long-lost Partridge” on “The Partridge Family.”

headline: Step and Lunge and Forge Bonds
text: AS a fan of old-school workouts, I find many fitness classes too fancy and gimmicky. But once in a while, something comes along that excites and intimidates the skeptical, hard-core exerciser in me. That something right now is Relentless, a 75-minute class held on Tuesday nights at the 92nd Street Y on the Upper East Side.

headline: A Few Hungry Writers, Playing Fast and Loose
text: “The Words” is a clever, entertaining yarn that doesn’t bear close scrutiny. Even superficial examination of this film reveals myriad flaws, despite a compelling performance by Jeremy Irons as a fictional writer in a book also called “The Words.” At the heart of this story-within-a-story is a tale of plagiarism and ambition.

headline: The Enduring Erotic Life Cycle of an Unpromising Relationship
text: When we first meet Erik (Thure Lindhardt), a Danish filmmaker living in New York in 1997, he is on the telephone looking for a casual sexual hookup. He seems fickle and impatient, hanging up on potential partners at the first hint that the chemistry might be wrong, but eventually he finds more or less what he is looking for. Quite a bit more, actually, in the person of Paul (Zachary Booth), even though Paul says he has a steady girlfriend, and Erik is not interested in commitment.

headline: Generations United for Improvisation, Refined but Violent
text: “You take when a high note comes through, lifting and going and then stopping because there’s no place else for it to go,” the saxophonist Sidney Bechet explained some time in the 1950s. “That’s stepping music — it’s got to rush itself right off your voice or your horn because it’s so excited.”

headline: A Centennial, With Toy Pianos and a Coffee Table
text: For a composer who was a true rebel, a pioneering American maverick, John Cage was frequently celebrated in programs and festivals at the world’s most prestigious concert halls. But he surely would have been delighted to see the centennial of his birth commemorated in New York at “Cage100,” a three-day festival at the Stone, the nonprofit performance space in the East Village dedicated to experimental and avant-garde music.

headline: A Towering Career; a Collision With War
text: THE mass imprisonment of Japanese in World War II remains a painful blot on our history. There were no internment camps for the Japanese on the East Coast, but you didn’t need to live in the West to be touched by the hand of fear, as Yasuo Matsui found out. Even though he had lived here for four decades, designed one of New York’s tallest buildings and ran a major construction company, the Japanese-born architect was rousted out of bed on the night of the Pearl Harbor attack, held at Ellis Island for two months and spent the war under house arrest.

headline: Collaborative and Solo, With a Certain Feminist Bent
text: Collaboration is one of the hallmarks of feminist art and scholarship. The art system doesn’t really accommodate this, however. Instead, criticism, art history and institutions are set up to canonize (historically male) individual artists. And for curators, it’s considerably easier to work with one artist than a hundred.

headline: A Walk on Fire Island
text: “Island Night” is part philosophic dialogue, part poetic reverie and part nature walk.

headline: Socrates on the Beach: An Island Walk
text: EVERY summer thousands of New Yorkers go to Fire Island, a narrow barrier island off the South Shore of Long Island, in search of sun, sand, sex and sea breezes. But this year, on the last weekend in August, a motley group of nine disembarked at the Pines, the famous gay resort at the island’s midpoint, hellbent on Socratic dialogue.

headline: New 9/11 Programs Are a British Task
text: Sept. 11 is approaching, and American television is maintaining a polite distance. Since last year, when more than two dozen new documentaries and memorials were presented for the 10th anniversary of the 2001 attacks, our attention has receded again. Apparently the most appropriate gift for an 11th anniversary is reruns.

headline: Intricate and Odd, With Little Child’s Play
text: The strange, often beautiful beings in the animated feature “Toys in the Attic” exist in a faraway land located somewhere between Czech surrealism and Pixar communitarianism. A simple story intricately told, it centers on a small familial group — a doll named Buttercup, a teddy bear, a marionette and a blob — whose happy life is threatened by a bust of a bald man that looks as if it once sat on a pedestal in Communist Party headquarters. The bust is attended to by a motley assortment of minions, including what looks like a termite with a human head, and a severed arm wearing a black leather glove, which suggests that the director Jiri Barta is a Stanley Kubrick fan.

headline: A New Marriage License and Each Other, and Little Else

headline: Visas-for-Dollars Program a Boon to Hotel Developers
text: When Marriott International wanted to open a new hotel in downtown Seattle, the company’s developers didn’t sell bonds, take out a mortgage or tap other traditional forms of financing for the $88 million project. Instead, it raised the bulk of the money from wealthy immigrants who wanted a green card.

headline: Unhappy Hooligans, Dripping With Lust
text: In “Among the Thugs,” Bill Buford’s horrifying nonfiction book about the brutal excesses of British soccer hooliganism, he writes about gangs of fans who travel to European cities like Turin ostensibly to support their teams. In one unforgettable scene Mr. Buford watches as hordes of Manchester United followers swarm out of a Turin stadium and into the streets in a frenzy of violence, savagely beating anyone, children included. In the middle of the mayhem, in between the stomping and punching, he overhears one of the rampaging goons say, “The city is ours” and repeat the word ours, ours, ours. There’s a sense that the rioting is a kind of postcolonial invasion for at least this one thug, an idea that’s cemented when later he says, “We took the city.”

headline: Draghi
text: I’m still bogged down in family health-related stuff, hence limited interventions here. Still, I guess I’d better weigh in on what would, if it weren’t for the DNC, be the story of the day: the latest announcement from the European Central Bank.

headline: In Speech, Obama to Plead for Patience
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — President Obama prepared to accept the Democratic nomination to run for a second term on Thursday night, and planned to say that “our problems can be solved,” while making a forceful case that in four years, he has brought the economy from disaster to a recovery which would be imperiled by a return to Republican stewardship.

headline: The Coming Tug of War Over a New State Budget
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Divorce Blues, Waylaid by a New Infatuation
text: The ostensibly grown-up man residing in the parental nest — usually in a boyhood bedroom full of movie posters, video games and action figures — is a staple of American comedy. He is a figure to be pitied and ridiculed, but also envied, since he still dwells in a juvenile paradise that the rest of us, with our jobs and kids and dreary domestic routines, supposedly long to recapture.

headline: A New Way to Tackle College Algebra
text: Alexzandria Siprian, a senior at the University of Texas at Arlington who is double-majoring in Spanish and theater, is not a math person. Early in her college career, she squeaked through her required algebra course with a D.

headline: Where Bronze Transforms Into Fine Art
text: THE brick-walled workshop is dark and quiet. Fine white dust hangs in the air and coats the walls and floor. A small group of men work intently, dressed in silver spaceman jackets and long leather aprons that cover their bluejeans.

headline: Far Beyond ‘Playhouse,’ Artist Remains Playful
text: The creativity grows like kudzu in “Beauty Is Embarrassing,” Neil Berkeley’s enlightening and often hilarious portrait of the Los Angeles artist Wayne White. And it yields a thousand blossoms. Mr. White, an Emmy-winning puppeteer for “Pee-wee’s Playhouse,” has had his share of career dips, only to arrive as a popular painter of some very amusing canvases. Tracing his evolution, the film gets at larger issues — about imagination, relationships and laughter.

headline: Rap Rivalry and Twitter Outrage Lead Pitchfork to Pull Video
text: Pitchfork, the usually irreverent music blog, has apologized for publishing a videotaped interview with the Chicago rapper Chief Keef that was filmed at a shooting range and features images of the young hip-hop star firing a gun. “This concept was rushed and never should have happened,” Pitchfork’s editor, Mark Richardson, said in an online statement. He called the episode, one of the site’s “Selector” interviews with rappers, “insensitive and irresponsible.”

headline: His Last Battle for Chelsea, or So He Says
text: WHEN Edward Kirkland gazes out the windows of his 16th-floor apartment at Seventh Avenue and 23rd Street, he zeros in, no binoculars necessary, on the construction cranes lately commandeering the western horizon. It is not a view he treasures.

headline: For International Students, College Checklists for September
text: This week, The Choice published our monthly Counselor’s Calendar, designed to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

headline: Woodward Book Details Battles Over Deficit
text: WASHINGTON — A new book by the journalist Bob Woodward chronicles the descent of Barack Obama’s Washington into partisan trench warfare and mines the minutiae of the largely failed negotiations between House Republicans and the White House to tame the nation’s deficit problem over the last two years.

headline: These Wedding Crashers Are Zombies
text: “[REC] 3: Genesis,” the latest in the “[REC]” franchise and the first without the co-director Jaume Balagueró, strips away the strengths of its predecessors — among them a spooky sound design and gloomy, warrenlike location — to deliver an altogether brighter, jokier blood bath. In doing so, however, the remaining director, Paco Plaza, may have murdered his fan base along with his film’s victims.

headline: Back to China, Clueless Child in Tow

headline: Insurance Chief Answers Industry Bias Charges

headline: Jets Seem Ready to Unveil Closely Guarded Wildcat

headline: Moody Shots of Detroit’s Urban Decay
text: Late in “Detropia,” Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady’s dreamy documentary about a slowly crumbling Detroit, a Swiss tourist confesses an appreciation for the aesthetics of decay. That interest is not only shared by the filmmakers, but it also may be their driving force: in this visual caress of postindustrial blight, disintegration has never looked so gorgeous.

headline: Softening a Trucker’s Rough Edges
text: Beating a sweet retreat from exposition and event, the Argentine director Pablo Giorgelli turns his minimalist road movie, “Las Acacias,” into a swelling meditation on wounded hearts and rekindled hopes.

headline: Russia: Pussy Riot Lawyer Questioned
text: The police summoned a lawyer for the punk band Pussy Riot for questioning in a criminal case that the authorities say is unrelated to the Pussy Riot case. They plan to question the lawyer, Mark Feygin, about disturbances during a large street protest last spring in Moscow. The wide-ranging investigation has led to the arrests of many opposition figures. Mr. Feygin was one of the speakers at the protest, but he said that he never scuffled with the police and that he thought the summons was indeed related to his work as a defense lawyer for the band members, three of whom were recently convicted of hooliganism for a protest in a Moscow cathedral. “I link this with the Pussy Riot case, there are no doubts about it,” he said in an interview. “I think this is simply an attempt to pressure us.”

headline: An Ad Agency Crowdsources Its Own Employees’ Morale

headline: Russia: Fighter Jet Crashes, Killing Pilot
text: A Russian Air Force MiG-29 fighter jet crashed Thursday afternoon near Chita, a city in Eastern Siberia, slamming into a hill close to a local airport and killing the pilot. Flights of MiG-29 fighters have been grounded pending further investigation, a Defense Ministry spokesman, Igor Konashenkov, told the RIA Novosti news agency. The pilot’s body was found by a search party, and there were no weapons on board, Mr. Konashenkov said. The Interfax news service reported that a second fighter plane crashed Thursday near the Siberian city of Novosibirsk, this one a Sukhoi Su-27.

headline: Cleaning Up the Economy

Perhaps the best of those zingers was his sarcastic summary of the Republican case for denying President Obama re-election: “We left him a total mess. He hasn’t cleaned it up fast enough. So fire him and put us back in.”

headline: New York’s Moonlighting Lawmakers

Eighteen Albany lawmakers have left office as a result of criminal charges or ethical misconduct since 1999, according to the government-reform organization Citizens Union — a run that the organization appropriately terms a “crime wave.” There are many reasons to account for this dismal record, but one in particular concerns a practice that, at first glance, may seem endearingly quaint: the legislators are part-timers.

headline: Defunct Law Firm Keeps Its Troubles Off the Softball Field

They were ballplayers, but in a sense, they were also ghosts, casualties of an immense corporate collapse, with the name of their defunct former employer emblazoned on their torsos: Dewey.

headline: Louisiana: Oil Linked to BP

While the oil led to the closing of some waters to commercial fishing, samples taken elsewhere in the Louisiana marsh also matched the oil from the spill, said Edward B. Overton, an environmental sciences professor at Louisiana State University. BP said that it was performing its own tests, but that the cleanup of oil was continuing.

headline: The President Plays It Safe
text: The strongest impression left by Mitt Romney’s convention speech last week was that the Republican nominee’s campaign sees itself on pace for a narrow victory in November, with no risks or course corrections needed. The impression left by President Obama’s convention speech tonight was that incumbent’s campaign feels exactly the same way. This was a pure stay-the-course speech, workmanlike and occasionally somewhat distant, with a few inspired and moving passages standing out amid a litany of rhetorical moves that the president has made many times before. There was only the most general sketch of a second term agenda, only a relatively cursory defense of the president’s economic stewardship, and mostly assertions, rather than sustained arguments, to back up his claim that the country is headed (slowly) in the right direction. The strongest and most detailed portions of his remarks came on foreign policy (where his record is more popular and easier to defend) and in his late-in-the-speech attacks on the Republican ticket, which did effectively exploit some of the vulnerabilities that Romney’s rather content-free address created. And yes, maybe if Bill Clinton hadn’t covered so much of that territory so effectively last night, these strengths would have been enough to make the speech feel successful as a whole. But in the shadow of Clinton’s performance, the president often felt flat, rote, and unconvincing — almost as though he wasn’t quite convinced by his own arguments and promises, and felt a little awkward selling them to us.

headline: The Weatherman Is Not a Moron
text: From the inside, the National Centers for Environmental Prediction looked like a cross between a submarine command center and a Goldman Sachs trading floor. Twenty minutes outside Washington, it consisted mainly of sleek workstations manned by meteorologists working an armada of flat-screen monitors with maps of every conceivable type of weather data for every corner of the country. The center is part of the National Weather Service, which Ulysses S. Grant created under the War Department. Even now, it remains true to those roots. Many of its meteorologists have a background in the armed services, and virtually all speak with the precision of former officers.

headline: In an Age of Likes, Commonplace Images Prevail
text: PERPIGNAN, France — Photographers attending the Visa Pour l’Image festival in this small medieval city stroll through the winding streets, stopping to view carefully crafted news and documentary images exhibited inside ancient buildings.

headline: Extreme Weather
text: In the hocus-pocus realm of predicting the future, weather forecasting is an area of progress. Your own experience may differ.

headline: Glencore’s Bid to Buy Xstrata Is Increased at the 11th Hour

headline: Reflections of a Mets Killer
text: ATLANTA — On May 9, 1995, at Shea Stadium, the Braves’ left fielder, Chipper Jones, singled in the third inning off the Mets’ Bret Saberhagen. Later, with the score tied at 2-2, Jones led off the ninth inning with a solo homer off reliever Josias Manzanillo. It was the game-winner and the first home run of Jones’s major league career. The next night, he homered again, this time off Pete Harnisch.

headline: Earthquakes in China Kill Dozens
text: BEIJING — A series of earthquakes shook two rural provinces in southwest China on Friday, killing at least 64 people and destroying more than 6,600 homes, provincial authorities said.

text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan —  A  Christian girl accused of burning a religious textbook was released from jail on Saturday after a judge in Pakistan had granted her bail, a significant step in a controversy that has renewed scrutiny of the country’s blasphemy laws.

text: On Sept. 1, 1914, the last passenger pigeon on earth died in captivity at the Cincinnati Zoo. The species, once numbering in the billions, had been hunted to extinction.

headline: A Game Kristen Stewart Walks the Red Carpet
text: TORONTO — Talk about heat. Kristen Stewart had it, took it and spread it around as she appeared here Thursday night for the North American premiere of “On the Road” at the Toronto International Film Festival. Her red-carpet walk was her first professional public appearance since the meltdown of her relationship with “Twilight” co-star Rob Pattinson.

headline: Romney Team Announces Major Ad Campaign
text: The Romney campaign announced on Friday the beginning of a major advertising campaign in eight battleground states — Colorado, Florida, Iowa, Nevada, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Ohio and Virginia. The effort will include 15 new commercials, each tailored specifically to the state in which it will run and focused on a particular issue, like the deficit, defense, manufacturing and energy.

headline: Dozens of Migrants Said to Be Missing From Boat Near Italian Coast
text: ROME — Rescue teams on Friday were searching the waters off a southern Italian islet for survivors of a boat loaded with migrants that apparently ran into difficulties a day earlier while crossing from Africa.

headline: 4 Years After Starry Romance, Trying to Save the Marriage
text: President Obama’s acceptance speech on Thursday wasn’t a sweeping romantic overture, it was the cautious declaration of a chastened husband trying to save a troubled marriage. He doesn’t want to lose the electorate — he’s been to couples counseling, he’s learned to listen, and he knows what to say, and most of all, what not to say.

headline: Daily Report: Apple Plans a Move Into Streaming Music
text: In a move that could shake up the growing field of Internet radio, Apple plans to develop a service that would compete with Pandora Media and similar services by sending streams of music customized to users’ tastes, report Ben Sisario and Nick Wingfield on Friday in The New York Times.

text: LONDON – Sudi Mariappa, the former global head of portfolio management at Pimco, the world’s largest bond fund manager, has joined the Man Group, the embattled London-based hedge fund that is looking to expand its bond investments.
