headline: Murder Mystery Stuns France and Britain
text: LONDON — In news terms, murders are often local affairs, taking a straight line from the police blotter to the city pages and remaining there only as long as it takes for public interest to fade.

headline: Problems, More Than Solutions, On Screen in Toronto
text: TORONTO— Like journalists, filmmakers, especially the documentary kind, are generally better at spotting problems than solutions. So it was no surprise that problems loomed large, solutions less so, in one of the first movies to screen at the Toronto International Film Festival as it opened here on Thursday.

headline: Hiring Slows in U.S., Putting Pressure on Obama and Fed
text: The nation’s employers eased up on hiring in August, making it clear that the economy was stuck in low gear.

headline: If Only This Goes On
text: A while back I mentioned, in a quite different context, an essay by Isaac Asimov (?) on Soviet science fiction, in which he argued that the two main themes of Western sci-fi — “what if” and “if only” — were ruled out; instead, writers wrote on the theme “if only this goes on”.

headline: Carlyle Buys Power Plants From Goldman Sachs
text: The Carlyle Group said Friday that it had bought Cogentrix Energy’s North American power plants from Goldman Sachs, as the private equity firm seeks to build up a presence in the energy business.

headline: No News On Jobs
text: The headline number came in a bit below expectations, but that’s probably just the noisiness in the data. The best hypothesis about the US economy this past year and more is that it has been steadily adding jobs at a pace roughly fast enough to keep up with but not get ahead of population growth. Today’s report was consistent with a continuation of that story. Nothing to see here.

headline: Audiobook Publisher Issues 120-Disc Version of Proust
text: Lovers of Proust, get out your headphones: Naxos AudioBooks, a British division of the classical music label, has recorded all seven volumes of “Remembrance of Things Past” on CD — 120 discs, which will take 153 hours to get through. The last one comes out on Oct. 29.

text: Steps from the red carpet in Cannes, the festival’s brightest lights show off their season’s premier essential: a non-red-carpet coat.

headline: Unfit for Any Post
text: Narendra Modi, the chief minister of Gujarat and the “poster boy for growth in India, may be in trouble finally,” Hartosh Singh Bal wrote in The New York Times’s Latitude blog. “At least he should be.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: New Amazon Devices, and Apple’s Plans for Digital Radio
text: The intimate connection between digital media and the devices that play them was in full effect on Thursday, as the online store Amazon.com announced a range of new Kindles for reading, listening and watching. Also on Thursday, it was learned that Apple was working on adding an Internet radio service to its devices, along the lines of Pandora.

headline: Before Blanchett Leaves Sydney Theater Post, Some Housekeeping
text: Cate Blanchett will bid farewell to her role as co-artistic director of Sydney Theater Company by starring with Isabelle Huppert in a new production of “The Maids” as part of the company’s 2013 season, it was announced on Thursday. The Jean Genet play, about a pair of house servants with murderous designs on their employer, will be directed by Benedict Andrews, who previously directed Ms. Blanchett in “Gross und Klein (Big and Small)” and “The War of the Roses” for Sydney Theater Company. Its new translation is by Mr. Andrews and Andrew Upton, Ms. Blanchett’s husband and co-artistic director. At the start of the year Ms. Blanchett and Mr. Upton said they would step down from their posts at Sydney Theater Company, after presenting several internationally acclaimed productions including “A Streetcar Named Desire” (which starred Ms. Blanchett as Blanche DuBois) and “Uncle Vanya” (which featured her as Yelena). But last month the theater company said it had appointed Mr. Upton to stay on alone in a new term that begins next year.

headline: Jennifer Granholm's Speech
text: Former Governor of Michigan, Jennifer Granholm, gives a fiery address at the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Friday Reading: How to Add Missing Titles to iTunes Tracks
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: U.S. Blacklists Militant Haqqani Network
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani officials reacted cautiously on Friday to news that the United States had designated the Taliban-affiliated Haqqani network as a terrorist group, allaying fears that the move could drive a fresh wedge between the two uneasy allies.

headline: Steady Progress or More of Same? Politicians React
text: WASHINGTON — A modest improvement in the unemployment rate and a marginal increase in job creation were greeted by Democrats as signs of slow but steady progress and disparaged by Republicans as another month of sluggish economic underperformance.

headline: Off to Broadway and Back to School
text: JESSICA CHASTAIN has turned up lately in so many movies all at once that audiences may be forgiven for imagining that with her ethereal manner (in “The Tree of Life,” anyway) and Botticelli looks — the alabaster skin, huge green eyes and cascade of auburn hair — she wafted into Hollywood on a seashell. In fact Ms. Chastain, who makes her Broadway debut in “The Heiress” on Nov. 1, is a trained stage actress who spent four transformative years at Juilliard, from which she graduated in 2003.

headline: Lawless in Srinagar
text: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — On the morning of Aug. 21, during the foremost Muslim festival of Eid al-Fitr, I drove through Srinagar, the summer capital of the disputed Indian-controlled region of Kashmir.

headline: Parliament’s ‘Monsoon Session’ Ends in Washout
text: The Indian Parliament’s “monsoon” session ended Friday after repeated disturbances, with little to show for its 19-day stretch in the way of bills passed or legislation debated.

headline: Big Data in Your Blood
text: “Stretchable electronics” will be able to measure heart rate, brain activity, body temperature and hydration levels.

headline: Niu Noodle House: Not Quite New, but Up to Speed
text: Niu Noodle House, a Chinese noodle and dumpling parlor done in 1940s style, opened in late June. But the chef, Lo Lung Kit, had to return to China to straighten out his visa and did not return until late August. Now the restaurant is in full swing.

headline: ESPN Radio to Broadcast Jets Games in Spanish in New York
text: 11:56 a.m. | Updated The New York Jets had a rough preseason this year, but they will soon have a chance to make a fresh start, this time in Spanish.

headline: Who Made That Spray Tan?
text: In the 1950s, Eva Wittgenstein, a researcher at a Cincinnati hospital who had been treating children with a rare metabolic disorder, noticed that when the medicine she was using splattered, it stained the patients’ bodies but not their clothes. Curious, Wittgenstein painted her own skin with the solution, which contained dihydroxyacetone (DHA). Within hours these patches turned brown. Soon the miraculous substance was bottled into products like Coppertone QT, which promised 1960s-style convenience: bronze yourself while you sleep; “tan groom” your legs, so you won’t need stockings. DHA produced the color changes by what was called a Maillard reaction, browning the top layer of human skin much the same way a steak browns as it cooks. The reaction turned some people as orange as Oompa-Loompas.

headline: Jane Harman Can Take a Punch
text: Last April, your 92-year-old husband, Sidney Harman, the owner of Newsweek, died after being given a diagnosis of leukemia a month before. Was there anything left he wanted to do?  He left an unfinished manuscript for a book called “Geezer Golf,” about how golf is a metaphor for life, and if you have an excellent short game, you can play with people 20 or 30 years younger, because although your drives are shorter, the rest of your game is better.

headline: 30 Variations and a Microphone
text: Glenn Gould was booked into 30th Street Studio for the two middle weeks of June in 1955. The weather in New York was sunny, the temperature in the 60s. He arrived at the studio by taxi from a hotel near Central Park, wearing an overcoat, a beret, a scarf and gloves, and carrying a leather suitcase and his folding chair. He stripped down to a dress shirt and a sleeveless V-neck sweater. Opening the suitcase, he set out pills, bottled water and towels. Rolling up his sleeves, he ran hot water in a sink, the sort of deep-basin porcelain sink that mops are wrung out in, and soaked his hands and forearms until they were red.

headline: Voting for Dad
text: My 92-year-old father has entered hospice care. He is a lifelong member of one particular political party and is always the first one in line on voting day. There’s no way I can get him to his polling place this November, and while he couldn’t begin to fill out an absentee ballot on his own, is it ethical if I fill it out for him provided he’s still alive in November? JAN SHULMAN-CLEMENT, WEST HOLLYWOOD, CALIF.

text: WEDGED between a strip-mall chiropractor and a cluster of optometrists in Rochester, N.Y., the offices of the DePrez Group of Travel Companies hardly seems like the kind of place where someone would begin a journey to the stars.

headline: At One With the Earth, and the Clients
text: The skeleton of the straw bale house has risen with remarkable speed. In little more than a week, we framed out the walls and almost finished the roof. Now there is no doubt that a house is coming into being, although at this point it is not obvious that it will be anything out of the ordinary. The trained eye will notice the lack of the evenly spaced studs that are normally needed to hang drywall, as well as the presence of a second set of wooden sill plates to support the inside edge of the 18-inch-thick straw bales.

headline: In Maine, Walking Where Waves Moved Winslow Homer’s Brush
text: IN the summer, when the sun played on the juniper bushes, and in the fall, when the air was clear enough to see to the white lighthouse on Wood Island, and in the winter, when the sea battered the granite rocks, Winslow Homer thrived at Prouts Neck, a spit of land off the Southern coast of Maine.

headline: Underwater Paradise at a Pacific Eco-Resort
text: WHEN, after two days of flying, one reaches the island of Bali only to realize that more days of travel lie ahead — from Denpasar to Makassar, then to Sorong in West Papua on one dodgy Indonesian airline after another, and finally a five-hour boat trip — a traveler begins to wonder whether a stay at an eco-resort on a remote Pacific Island will make all the jet lag, chaotic airports and carbon dioxide emissions seem worth it.

headline: Restaurant Report: Nota Bene in Prague
text: Tracking down great beer in Prague has never been a problem. Finding a decent meal has certainly gotten easier. But for years, good food and good brews were like the Czech capital’s version of Clark Kent and Superman: you never saw them in the same place.

headline: Ska Groove, Teen Vibe and Glam-Punk Fury
text: WAYLON JENNINGS Waylon Jennings cut some voice-and-guitar only songs in 1999 at the home studio of his steel guitarist, Robby Turner, intending to add instruments to them later. He never did, and died in 2002. Finally, here’s the posthumous 12-song result produced by Mr. Turner: “Goin’ Down Rockin’: The Last Recordings,” your basic outlaw-country mix of dire and tenderhearted songs for sports bars and campfires. Tuesday. Saguaro Road. (Ben Ratliff)

headline: Police Seeking Man Who Abused Dog in Elevator
text: For at least the fifth time in less than three years, the police are seeking the public’s help in tracking down someone caught on video beating a dog in a housing-project elevator. The latest incident happened Aug. 26 at the Wagner Houses in East Harlem, site of a similar episode in 2011.

text: The Times reports this morning on states’ efforts to rein in Medicaid costs with managed care programs and how these may affect the elderly in nursing homes.

text: You may have noticed that “unlimited” data plans usually come with an asterisk – the speed at which you get the data slows to a crawl after you have used a certain amount of data. But T-Mobile is reversing the trend.

text: In This Week’s Movies, the New York Times critics share their thoughts on “Bachelorette,” “The Inbetweeners” and “Keep the Lights On.” Full reviews can be found here.

headline: Obama Counterpunches on Climate Change
text: Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, took a not-too-subtle jab at President Obama in his convention speech last week, mocking Mr. Obama’s soaring 2008 campaign language about rolling back the rising seas and healing the planet. Mr. Romney’s gibe drew thunderous applause from the Republican delegates, many of whom express doubt about the existence of climate change.

headline: Quirky Gets Backing From Andreessen Horowitz and Kleiner Perkins
text: Social media has transformed many areas, including real estate and online communications. Now, venture capitalists are betting the sector can even tackle product manufacturing.

headline: Six Days After 9/11, Another Anniversary Worth Honoring
text: In the coming days, the calendar will bring the anniversaries of two signal events. One, of course, is Sept. 11, a Tuesday this year, as it was in 2001, when Al Qaeda terrorists in four hijacked planes killed more than 3,000 Americans. With public memorial services and private tears, those deaths will be recalled and mourned.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: To celebrate the start of the new school year, free soft serve yogurt will be handed out from 2 to 6 p.m. Friday at Chelsea’s Table, located at Pier 62 (just west of the 23rd Street entrance to Chelsea Piers). One free small cup of the yogurt with one topping will be available to each customer at the café or the Stonyfield Organic Dairy Bar.

headline: Family Property Means Managing for a Legacy
text: SOME wealthy people will have to make a decision soon if they are to take advantage of the $5.12 million gift tax exemption that is due to expire at the end of the year.

headline: Off the Charts
text: At the onset of last summer, the magazine that employed me as a rock critic decided to continue publishing without me, no longer supplying a salary or respite from the office water cooler. My dismissal came via a private equity group situation — “No hard feelings, right?” — yet I couldn’t help taking offense. For the next several months, I steered clear of the music world that for years I had cherished.

headline: Share of Men in Labor Force at All-Time Low
text: Friday’s jobs report for August was chock full of all sorts of bad news. Among the most distressing: The share of men actively participating in the labor force — that is, working or looking for work — was at an all-time low.

headline: A Soldier on the Tennis Court
text: The players aren’t the only ones breaking a sweat on the courts at the United States Open.

headline: Up Front
text: This week, Jennifer Gilmore reviews “The Revised Fundamentals of Caregiving,” a novel by Jonathan Evison, in which a former stay-at-home dad who lost his children in a grisly accident becomes a caregiver for hire. “Caretaking is often stereotyped as women’s work,” Gilmore wrote in an e-mail, but in Evison’s book, “caring deeply, dealing with grief, transcends gender.”

headline: Inside the List
text: DOCTOR, LAWYER, WRITER? The suspense novelist Tess Gerritsen — her latest Rizzoli and Isles mystery, “Last to Die,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3 — told The New Zealand Herald last year that she had been reluctant for more than 20 novels to introduce elements of her Chinese-American heritage into her fiction. That’s because early in her career, when she had just quit medicine to write romantic thrillers, editors warned her there was no market for Asian characters, and the advice stayed with her even as she moved away from the romance genre.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: MORTALITY,  by Christopher Hitchens. (Twelve, $22.99.) Like virtually everything Hitchens wrote over his long career, these dispatches from “Tumorville,” written after he learned of his ultimately fatal esophageal cancer, are diamond-hard and brilliant.

headline: Paperback Row
text: BUSY MONSTERS,  by William Giraldi. (Norton, $15.95.) Speaking in a pastiche of idioms (Southern, Victorian, Western), Charles Homar, the cuckolded hero of Giraldi’s first novel, wrestles with notions of manliness. Pledging to win back his errant fiancée, who has run off with a squid hunter, Charles chronicles his haywire schemes — involving Bigfoot, U.F.O.’s and an oversexed Italian bodybuilder — in installments for a weekly magazine.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: THE ORCHARDIST  By Amanda Coplin.  Harper/HarperCollins, $26.99.

headline: Indecent Exposure
text: Privacy is a topic that tends to inspire discursive essays rather than philosophical treatises. In “A Bachelor’s Complaint,” in 1823, Charles Lamb deplored the exhibitionism of married couples who “perk up” their public displays of affection when in the company of single friends. In 1890, Samuel Warren and Louis Brandeis lamented that American law, which protects privacy indirectly through laws safeguarding property, contains no remedies for the mental suffering that results from an offense against honor. Rather than attempting a comprehensive treatment of the subject, the privacy essayist identifies a distinctive value that privacy protects (ranging from dignity and autonomy to intimacy and friendship) and defends its value by using concrete examples and anecdotes from daily life.

headline: Outback Outcasts
text: Kate Grenville’s latest novel, “Sarah Thornhill,” provides a wrenching conclusion to a tough-hearted trilogy about the colonizing of Australia. In her previous excursions into this rough, unforgiving land, shiploads of transported convicts, indentured servants and down-on-their-luck gentry were seen carving out English-style estates and tangling with aboriginals who somehow — to the newcomers’ astonishment — couldn’t accept the fact that they’d been conquered. By the time the heroine of this new book is born, in 1816, the country’s future is almost settled.

headline: Why Were We in Vietnam?
text: During the Casablanca conference in January 1943, Franklin Roosevelt spoke bitterly to his son about European imperialism: “Don’t think for a moment, Elliott, that Americans would be dying in the Pacific tonight if it hadn’t been for the shortsighted greed of the French and the British and the Dutch.” Earlier, he had spoken openly to the White House correspondents: “There has never been, there isn’t now and there never will be, any race of people on earth fit to serve as masters over their fellow men. . . . We believe that any nationality, no matter how small, has the inherent right to its own nationhood.” That was the core of the Atlantic Charter in 1941, which both Churchill and Roosevelt signed. It called on “the right of all peoples to choose the form of government under which they will live.”

headline: Haunted Highways
text: What would highway killers do without highways?

headline: Panic Buttons
text: The long list of things that, over the years, have made Daniel Smith nervous includes sex, death, work, water, food, air travel, disease, amateur theater, people he’s related to and people he’s not related to, so the prospect of a book review probably wouldn’t seem like a very big deal to him. Or would it?

headline: Effect of Jobs Numbers on Presidential Race Is Uncertain
text: Friday’s jobs report was a weak one — with August’s job growth more in line with the tepid growth of the spring than the stronger numbers in July or over the winter months.

headline: Side Effects
text: When 14-year-old Nora gets a pair of diamond earrings in the mail from the father she’s never met, her mother, Ruby, looks at them and dryly remarks, “They’re the size of birth control pills.”

headline: Assisted Living
text: “Failure makes me hungry,” Ben Benjamin says in “The Revised Fundamentals of Caregiving,” Jonathan Evison’s third novel. Ben responds to defeat with a Mr. Goodbar and a bag of chips, which is just part of what makes his funny and relatable voice the linchpin of this engaging book.

headline: Two Cuts of Brisket
text: With Rosh Hashana approaching, Melissa Clark talks about how to select a brisket perfect for your family dinner.

headline: Long Divisions
text: Rajiv Chandrasekaran has done it again. Like “Imperial Life in the Emerald City,” his chronicle of Washington’s hapless management of the Iraq war in its early days, “Little America” is a beautifully written and deeply reported account of how a divided United States government and its dysfunctional bureaucracy have foiled American efforts abroad, this time to suppress the Taliban insurgency and bring stability to Afghanistan. It tells a story of political foibles, overly ambitious goals and feckless Afghans and Americans. The United States seems condemned to lurch between disastrous quick fixes and unrealistic visions of remaking countries overnight in its own image, never finding a middle road. No doubt most readers of this book will come away with the conclusion that our principal enemy in all this is ourselves.

headline: Many Wars in One
text: Toward the end of this powerful narrative of World War II, Antony Beevor quotes a report, by the Australian war correspondent Godfrey Blunden, of an encounter with some American troops who had just been released from German P.O.W. camps. They had been in Europe only a few months, thrown into combat and almost instantly captured during the Ardennes offensive, Hitler’s last big throw of the dice. The men now had “xylophone ribs” and “gangling arms.” Some of their fellow prisoners had been beaten to death by their guards for attempting to take sugar beets from fields. Blunden wrote: “They were more pitiful because they were only boys drafted from nice homes in a nice country knowing nothing about Europe, not tough like Australians, or shrewd like the French or irreducibly stubborn like the English. They just didn’t know what it was all about.”

headline: These Wild Solitudes
text: Paul Auster was a novelist in Brooklyn before there were novelists in Brooklyn. (When I was growing up there in the 1980s, my father used to point him out to me as we did the grocery shopping in Park Slope — this was a rare kind of sighting.) Back in those days, his novels — the New York Trilogy, “Leviathan,” “Moon Palace” — seemed postmodern and fresh. They mingled the tropes of detective fiction with a kind of European quasi-philosophical ambiguity. “Kafka goes gumshoe,” as one of his editors described it. The novels comprised stories nested within stories; there were characters named Paul Auster, and there were doppelgängers even for the ­doppelgängers.

headline: Murder in the Cathedral
text: “The biographer’s trap,” John Guy remarks in “Thomas Becket,” his portrait of that foremost friend turned foremost foe of Henry II, “is to look for a decisive moment of change.” But, he adds, “to do that is to write the history of the saint without his shadow.” With ­Becket, this temptation often seems to have been irresistible, from the very night of his murder, Dec. 29, 1170, near the high altar of Canterbury Cathedral. As a crowd swooped down on the battered corpse of the archbishop, tearing off pieces of clothing to dip in the gruesome puddle of his blood and brains, the outlines of the story of Becket’s sudden conversion from ­luxury-loving chancellor to ascetic defender of the church were already being rehearsed, soon to be followed by tales of his miraculous powers.

headline: When Audio Books Do and Don’t Count for School
text: Does listening to an audio book count for school reading, and if it does, when? I ran across this quandary when helping my rising third grader fill out her “summer reading” list before going back to school. She wanted to include the books she’s listened to (I’d like to say it was to show her teacher what she enjoyed, but I know full well it was to make her list look longer), and I hesitated. Did a book listened to, I asked here last week, really count as a book “read?”

headline: Killing Time
text: “The temptations that will beset you will be very great,” a Mississippi man, already a veteran in the Civil War, warned his newly enlisted younger brother. The evil he warned of wasn’t treason or desertion or theft. It was cards. “Of all the evil practices that abound in Camp, gambling is the most pernicious and fraught with the most direful consequences.”

headline: Bonus Tracks: Bruuuuuuuuce!
text: This summer, Lizzy Goodman wrote about the New Jersey band the Gaslight Anthem. Her article highlighted the Gaslight Anthem’s anxiety — if you can call it that — of being seen as the heirs to Bruce Springsteen’s legacy. Last weekend, she got to see the real thing. Her dispatch from the floor seats follows.

headline: Invite Brisket’s More-Tender Brother for the Holidays
text: FOR years, I thought brisket was by nature a somewhat stringy, dry and chewy cut of beef. No matter how exacting the recipe or how careful the cook, the leanness of the meat dictated the texture.

headline: Peter Som: Spring 2013 RTW
text: New York

headline: Book Review Podcast: Michael Chabon’s ‘Telegraph Avenue’
text: This week in the New York Times Book Review, one Pulitzer Prize winner reviews another as Jennifer Egan considers Michael Chabon’s “Telegraph Avenue.” The novel is set in and around a used-record store on the boulevard where Oakland aligns with Berkeley. Ms. Egan writes:

headline: At Peter Som’s Show, Birds Suddenly Appear
text: The first few notes of “Close to You” by the Carpenters played at the beginning of the Peter Som show Friday morning. That was enough to suggest a little bit of romantic nostalgia, the kind that usually describes Mr. Som’s dreamy floral prints. For spring, he made jeans in a pink print that looked like bubble gum, part of a collaboration between Mr. Som and Earnest Sewn, the jeans company, and a series of multicolored pieces, like a T-shirt, a coat and a skirt, each made of a patchwork of snakeskin in an oversize herringbone pattern.

headline: Collect Call | Steven Kolb’s Owls
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Judge Widens Scope of Prosecutor’s Investigation in Lopez Case
text: A judge authorized a special prosecutor on Friday to expand his criminal investigation into sexual harassment claims that two female staff members brought against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, giving the prosecutor the power to examine whether crimes were committed when public and private money was paid to settle similar complaints brought by two other female staff members.

headline: The Sweet Spot | The Film Festival
text: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk Telluride, Toronto and the taxonomy of the film festival.

headline: What Ails the U.S.?
text: NEW YORK — Like hawkers on a crowded street, observers of all persuasions are busy peddling the notion that America is in big trouble.

headline: Managing a Child’s Allowance, the Online Version
text: Giving children an allowance always seems like a good idea at first. But just try following through in practice.

headline: Sept. 9 — 15
text: THE Zimbabwe-born NORA CHIPAUMIRE, now working out of New York, has spent most of her (still relatively short) choreographic career exploring ideas about African identity — and even more specifically, ideas about female African identity. Until now her pieces have been largely abstract, even if they have dealt with Zimbabwean history and her experience of it. But in “Miriam,” which opens on Wednesday in the Fishman Space of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s new Fisher Building, Ms. Chipaumire turns to the life of the South African singer MIRIAM MAKEBA, taking inspiration from her dramatic narrative — first as an exiled, worldwide symbol of protest against the apartheid government, later as the beloved artist known as Mama Africa.

headline: What My Father’s Dementia Told Me
text: I was the copy editor assigned to work on Alex Witchel’s memoir about her mother’s dementia. I was fortunate because her writing is compelling and didn’t need any help from me, and also because it forced me to focus on the quality of my father’s dementia, maybe for the first time.

headline: What Citizenship Means
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – He didn’t deliver a clear second-term agenda, or a speech that thrilled. He didn’t explain how his re-election will spell an end to Washington’s policy stalemate. But President Obama did offer a sort of consolation prize in his convention speech: a new theme to sum up his case against Mitt Romney.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Sept. 7, 2012
text: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk Telluride, Toronto and the taxonomy of the film festival.

headline: As PC Sales Turn Down, Intel Trims Its Outlook
text: SAN FRANCISCO — With the personal computer market stalled, Intel, the primary maker of computer chips, warned its investors Friday that revenue would be lower than expected, as would profit margins.

headline: Image of the Day: September 7
text: Women protest a dam project in Madhya Pradesh by standing in neck deep water for almost two weeks.

headline: Study Finds Some African Farmers Adapting to Withstand Climate Stresses
text: It’s been clear for many years that the stresses that come with extreme climate conditions have an outsize impact on poor communities, and nowhere more so than in sub-Saharan Africa. Given the studies projecting how greenhouse-driven warming will worsen drought and heat in regions that already tend to be dry and hot, it’s encouraging to see signs in one hard-hit African region of farmers’ capacity to shift practices to deal with intensifying climatic stresses.

headline: Influence of Money Market Funds Ended Overhaul
text: Four years after the fall of Lehman Brothers, and with a presidential campaign in full swing, everyone can surely agree on one thing: we shouldn’t risk another financial crisis.

headline: The Employment Situation
text: My current favorite gauge of the jobs picture is the employment-population ratio for prime-age adults (25-54). EP ratio instead of unemployment rate, because U may be distorted by workers dropping out. Prime-age not because the old and young don’t matter, but to take demographic change out of the picture.

headline: After a Disappointing Jobs Report, Romney Attacks Obama
text: SIOUX CITY, Iowa – Seizing on a disappointing jobs report, Mitt Romney questioned on Friday whether President Obama “knows what he’s doing” when it came to fixing the economy.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Blue Girl Solved!
text: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 17-year-old girl who was turning blue. We received more than 400 colorful responses that ran from Smurfitis and the occasional reference to Willy Wonka to the very serious suggestion of methemoglobinemia, a disorder in which patients turn blue intermittently because of abnormal red blood cells that cannot hold on to oxygen.

headline: Lowercase Minimalists
text: THE day that “Coexist,” the second album by the miserabilist British band the xx, was mastered, the group’s three members — Romy Madley Croft, Oliver Sim, Jamie Smith — went out for McDonald’s. Each day during the months of recording the album, on the way to the studio with black velvet-covered walls they were hunkered down in, they’d walk past McDonald’s and sigh, tempted by the smell but not giving in.

headline: Freezing Brisket
text: This week’s column is about braising brisket for a holiday meal. For years, my mother often cooked her brisket ahead and froze it. This was extremely convenient and the results were good. She would transfer the cooked and cooled meat to a plastic Ziploc, spoon in the sauce and then close the bag, squeezing out the air. Squeezing out the air is the key step. Sometimes she created a faux vacuum by inserting a straw into the bag, inhaling the air and quickly closing it. Of course a vacuum sealer works even better if you have one.

headline: Former Tennis Star Makes a Mark at Columbia Law School
text: Every fall, Columbia Law School admits a couple hundred students to its prestigious master’s program. This year’s crop includes a civil rights activist from Armenia, a terrorism-finance expert from Bangladesh and a Croatian lawyer with a win over Roger Federer.

headline: Truck Driver in Kerry Kennedy Crash Pleads Not Guilty
text: ARMONK, N.Y. -- The driver of a tractor-trailer who was involved in an accident with a car driven by Kerry Kennedy two months ago pleaded not guilty on Friday to leaving the scene of an accident and vowed to fight the charge.

headline: Remembering Ashe, in Triumphs and Images
text: Tennis has produced many champions but few heroes — winners whose accomplishments have merged with or even shaped the larger currents of their time.

headline: Andrea Hailey and David Williamson
text: THERE was very little Andrea Hailey disliked about David Williamson when she first met him through friends nearly six years ago.

headline: Deciding What to Leave to Heirs
text: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about the $5.12 million gift tax exemption that is due to expire at the end of the year.

headline: On Whether to Use Allowance-Tracking Web Sites
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I write about Tykoon, the newest of a group of Web sites and apps that help parents dole out allowances, track chores and encourage saving.

headline: Fashion Week Parties, Night 1
text: Richard Chai, Futura and Supreme kicked off New York Fashion Week.

headline: In Midtown, Pedestrians’ Secret Shortcut Is Now Official
text: For years, it was an open secret — a midblock portal that kept the savviest travelers away from the pedestrian gridlock of Midtown avenues, even if they had to jaywalk a bit to execute the shortcut.

headline: Out of the Box
text: Among the houses that Philip Johnson designed in New Canaan, Conn., the suburban enclave that became a laboratory for postwar Modernist design, the Robert C. Wiley house, completed in 1953, remains one of his most elegant. It is a strikingly simple composition of two rectangular boxes: one, a glass and wood pavilion with a single, 15-foot-tall living, dining and kitchen space, is cantilevered over the other, a stone and concrete base that contains, among other things, four small bedrooms, bathrooms and a sitting room. The 3,000-square-foot house typifies Modernism’s insistence on efficient use of space, but by the advent of the McMansion era, despite its architectural pedigree, it merely seemed quaintly, and unsalably, tiny.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Jason Wu
text: Jason Wu showed a very pretty and semiformal collection full of sex-pot signatures (leather harnesses, lace and leopard, lots of transparency) that, under Wu’s command, took a turn toward boudoir dressing without falling into bed. Some of the stilettos had nail-sharp heels studded with rhinestones. Others featured black netting bejeweled with circles and stars. These with tiny pearls dotting the contrasting ankle strap were the ones that T editors would, if they could, take home tonight.

headline: So That’s How They Do It
text: Workers cleaning the exterior of the Guggenheim Museum on Friday morning, the first such work since the museum’s restoration was completed in 2008. View a larger version.

headline: French President Must Cut Deficit, but How?
text: PARIS — Samir Chaffar shook his head slowly on a recent weekday as he scanned a raft of newspapers at a kiosk near the Louvre.

headline: Through Fire, Glimpsing the Next Mercedes-Benz S-Class
text: Mercedes-Benz has unveiled a sculpture hinting at the lines of the marque’s redesigned flagship sedan.

headline: Life Without Indian Point, Redux
text: The consequences of running the Indian Point nuclear reactors or shutting them down run from easy-to-spot to hard-to-calculate.

headline: Now the Rutgers Coach, but Still a Teacher
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — The blinds in the corner office at the Hale Center abutting the Rutgers football stadium are always shut, keeping the square room dim, the dark leather couches cool and the flat-screen monitors shaded, so that Coach Kyle Flood can see his PowerPoint presentations.

headline: What Happens When the Two Israels Meet
text: Kfar Vradim, Israel

headline: Jobs Numbers Prompt Obama to Account for Anemic Recovery
text: IOWA CITY — His convention speech was only hours old when President Obama, confronted by a weak new jobs report, found himself Friday having to use precious time on the campaign trail to account for the country’s continued anemic economic recovery.

headline: Outdoor Ad Company Already Had Planes, Now Adds Blimps
text: A leading outdoor advertising company is expanding its air force by adding ad blimps to its fleet of planes that carry ad banners.

headline: Excerpt: 'Nashvile'
text: The new ABC series starts on Oct. 10.

headline: Excerpt: '666 Park Avenue'
text: The new ABC series starts on Sept. 30.

headline: Venice Film Festival: James Franco and Harmony Korine on ‘Spring Breakers’
text: VENICE — Harmony Korine made his first splash as the screenwriter of the 1995 sensation “Kids,” which was both hailed and denounced for its in-your-face depiction of sexually active, substance-abusing teenagers. His latest film, “Spring Breakers,” is another generational portrait of youthful debauchery, but Mr. Korine, at 39, is observing from the outside this time.

headline: Tiny Lifesaver for a Growing Worry
text: It has become an all-too-familiar story in schools across the country: a child eats a peanut or is stung by a bee and suffers an immediate, life-threatening allergic reaction known as anaphylaxis.

headline: Trying on an Old Soul With Some Alterations
text: MESHELL NDEGEOCELLO is wary of giving the wrong impression with “Pour Une Âme Souveraine: A Dedication to Nina Simone” (Naïve), her 10th studio album, due out on Oct. 9. “I don’t want to necromance,” she said recently. “I feel like that’s going on a lot.”

headline: Nokia’s Misleading Video Dents Lumia’s Image
text: Taking the stage a week before Apple, Nokia had the chance to put on a bold and confident performance with its demonstration of new smartphones. Instead, a misleading promotional video has left the company looking a little desperate. Its underwhelming presentation and a big drop in its stock price added up to a less than stellar week for Nokia.

headline: Scenes From the New Season
text: A look at the new network series debuting this fall.

headline: Riff Bonus: A Night in the Life of the Culture
text: This week’s bonus feature to Paul Elie’s Riff on using recording-studio equipment for classical music is just that: a bonus excerpt from Paul Elie’s book, “Reinventing Bach,” in which he surveys the American cultural landscape around one night that Glenn Gould was recording the “Goldberg” Variations in New York City.

headline: The Old Mix and Match Inspires New Fall Shows
text: THE new fall season makes one thing clear: The television industry’s Random Show-Idea Generators have been getting quite a workout.

headline: Three Searches for a First Apartment
text: Four new graduates kept track of the ups and downs of their search from the moment they began looking for a place to the day they signed the lease.

headline: Launching Space Tourism
text: Companies are competing to take amateur astronauts into space.

headline: Williams and Azarenka Will Play in Open Final
text: No. 1 Victoria Azarenka and No. 4 Serena Williams will meet in the 2012 United States Open final, after winning semifinals Friday of very different difficulty levels.

headline: Soldiers’ Friendship, Shared Across Generations, Ends With More Gained Than Lost
text: My friend Bob Kotlowitz died two weekends ago. He was 87 — lucky enough to live a long, rich life — but he just as easily could’ve been killed before the age of 19. Death is an integral part of an infantryman’s life, floating around us in a thin, grim fog. We’re trained and conditioned to kill, we go to war to kill: that’s the heart of the life. There’s a cosmic balancing act to all this: death is pretty impartial. Our friends are killed in the war — whether they’re shot, blown up or snuffed out in accidents — or during training. It doesn’t get easier, all this dying, even after leaving the Army. After all, we’re still at war and friends still die overseas. At the same time, some, faced with the cumulative weight of all this, seek their own quietus.

headline: The Launching Pad
text: FOR countless newly minted college graduates, it’s a rite of passage. After the mortarboards have been tossed into the air, they head for New York City, ready to embark on the next chapter of their lives. In 2010, some 40,000 graduates age 22 to 28 moved to the city in search of jobs, according to the latest figures from the Census Bureau’s American Community Survey.

headline: African-American Theater in Minnesota Suspends Programming
text: Penumbra Theater in St. Paul, Minn.,which describes itself as the country’s largest African-American theater, has announced that it is suspending programming this season until it can resolve a severe budget crunch.

headline: Ratings Gold for Gordon Ramsay’s Reality Empire
text: The reality television stars Simon Cowell, Nicole “Snooki” Polizzi and the Kardashian clan may have hoarded most of the headlines this summer, but the chef Gordon Ramsay has quietly (at least for him) cemented his spot as one of TV’s most popular personalities. His three shows on Fox – “Hell’s Kitchen,” “MasterChef” and the recently launched “Hotel Hell” – all rank in the Top 10 of all summer programs in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, the age group most coveted by advertisers.

headline: To Contend at the Paralympics, Race Brave
text: The wheelchair racer Joshua George will be competing in the 2012 Paralympic Games in London and writing for the 2012 London blog.

headline: After High Note for Euro Plan, Discord Emerges
text: PARIS — In the long euro crisis, there is almost always a sobering morning-after whenever European leaders appear to have made a major breakthrough. And so it went again on Friday.

headline: A Possible Renoir Surfaces at a Virginia Flea Market
text: Calling “Antiques Roadshow.” It was a Paul Bunyan doll that captured her eye, but the Virginia flea market buyer, who paid less than $50 for the box lot that held it, also purchased what could turn out to be a painting by the French artist Pierre-Auguste Renoir.

headline: Not Looking, but Still Wanting to Work
text: The number of people not in the labor force — that is, neither working nor looking for work — rose by almost 600,000 in August.

text: A view of the day in sports, including the continuation of the Tour of Spain cycling race and the London Paralympic Games.

text: Mamie Gummer, ‘Emily Owens, M.D.’

headline: All Is Forgiven as Jets Lineman Re-Signs After Being Cut
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — On Tuesday, four days after he thought he made the Jets’ roster — and three days after the team cut him to make room for another defensive tackle — Marcus Dixon was at his home in Morristown when his phone rang.

headline: Week in Review: Off to the Principal’s Office
text: A company tries to win over investors for a huge merger in the natural resources business. We visited multinationals staking a claim in venture capital. And Andrew Ross Sorkin pointed to the man behind Facebook’s initial public offering debacle.

headline: Wholesome Risotto With Whole Grains
text: If you love creamy risotto but want to make it more wholesome, try these tips from Martha Rose Shulman. This week’s Recipes for Health explores new ways to add whole grains to risotto.

headline: Close to the City, but With a Life of Its Own
text: AFTER 13 years in a house in Oradell, N.J., Florence Fleischman and her husband, Glenn, were ready to return to high-rise living. In May, the couple moved back to the same Fort Lee apartment building where they had lived as newlyweds and raised two children, now teenagers, through toddlerhood.

headline: Chevy Thinks Small
text: The small 1.2-liter 84-horsepower Chevrolet Spark is thrifty and says something about G.M.’s ability to adapt to the current marketplace.

headline: Wheels Calendar for Sept. 7-9
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $6.3 Million
text: A luminous TriBeCa penthouse at 45-47 Warren Street, acquired in 1999 by Thomas Krens during his provocative tenure as the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation in New York, sold for $6.3 million and was the most expensive residential sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Korean-Flavored Chevy Is Thrifty and City-Smart
text: AT the 2001 Detroit auto show, before he was pulled back into the family business like the movie mobster Michael Corleone, General Motors’ godfather-for-hire, Robert A. Lutz, gravely assessed the design studies on display: “A whole family of angry kitchen appliances, demented toasters, furious bread machines and vengeful trash compactors.”

headline: Singer Gets His Van Back, but Pays a Price
text: Joseph Arthur, the Brooklyn-based singer and painter whose touring van was towed and sold at auction last month, has tracked down and retrieved his vehicle, full of amplifiers and artwork. But it cost him $5,500.

headline: Taking the ‘Cheap’ Out of the Small Car
text: THE idea that good things come in small packages has rarely played well with American car buyers. And who can blame them?

headline: Q&A
text: Still Awaiting Financial Statements

headline: Syrian Rebels Say They Freed 350 Prisoners, as Others Appeal for Unity
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian rebels claimed Friday night that they had freed 350 prisoners held in a security building in the divided city of Aleppo, while in the opposition stronghold of Homs the rebels’ supporters held a public protest against the disorganization and lack of unity among their forces.

headline: Jason Wu: Naughty or Nice
text: The photographer Helmut Newton is a touchstone for any designer who’s in the mood for the naughty, the kinky or the downright dark. So what’s a sweetie pie like Jason Wu doing in that territory? His show today had models in glove-tight leather dresses, exposed bras and a lot of thin leather harness straps.

headline: U.S. Open Food of the Day: Niman Ranch B.L.T.
text: This is the final installment of our daily reviews of food from the United States Open concession stands.

headline: Black Voter in a Blue Dog District
text: Congressman Larry Kissell represents a white, rural district in North Carolina. He is not endorsing President Obama. Marcus Mabry talks with Walter Rogers, a black voter in the district.

headline: Enjoying Results of Summer’s Labor
text: LABOR DAY is long past, but I’m not ready to say goodbye to summer, and I’m certainly not ready to give up on late-summer produce, most of which is still quite glorious. It would be a shame to fast-forward prematurely into autumn fare.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photos from India, Hong Kong, Syria and Iowa.

headline: Small Cars Are Changing; Will They Fit in the U.S.?
text: CARS have scale; they look different depending on the background they are set against. The Smart that seemed dashing when driven around Paris by Tom Hanks may look like a recycling container in the setting of a Montana highway.

headline: Fixes to Get You Started and Cool
text: INFINITIS and Volvos with air-conditioning troubles and Chevrolet Silverados with failing starter motors are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: ‘The Invisibles’ at the Top
text: “The Invisibles Omnibus,” a collection of the entire run of the Vertigo series from DC Comics created by Grant Morrison and originally serialized in the 1990s, lands at No. 1 on our hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week.

headline: The Trouble With Numbers: Complaints on a Much Anticipated Jobs Report
text: There’s a drumroll beforehand and a great crashing of cymbals as it happens. It’s the federal government’s monthly report on the nation’s employment – a matter that’s given huge political weight in the current presidential campaign, as Jim Rutenberg’s news analysis on today’s front page makes clear. The Wall Street Journal and many other news organizations also gave it front-page treatment, before the fact.

headline: Bahraini Activists Document Crackdown on Protest
text: Security forces again fired tear gas and arrested demonstrators in Bahrain’s capital on Friday, as protesters renewed their calls for reform and the release of political prisoners in the island kingdom that is home to the United States Navy’s Fifth Fleet.

headline: R. A. Dickey Signs Deal for Three Children’s Books
text: The knuckleball pitcher R. A. Dickey is putting together a historic season for the Mets. He’s also been busy building a literary career. Mr. Dickey, the author of an acclaimed memoir, has now signed a deal to publish three children’s books with Dial, an imprint of the publisher Penguin.

text: New York
