headline: Ups and Downs on Roster’s Fringes
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Last Tuesday, four days after he thought he made the Jets’ roster — and three days after the team cut him to make room for another defensive tackle — Marcus Dixon was at his home in Morristown, N.J., when his phone rang.

headline: Searching for a Speed Limit in High-Frequency Trading
text: CHATHAM, N.J.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 9
text: With the conventions in the rearview mirror, the general election is off and running. The Romney campaign is wasting no time, branching out from the nominee’s almost exclusive appearances on “Fox News Sunday” to date by scheduling Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, for an interview with NBC’s “Meet the Press.”

headline: Hervé Léger: Spring 2013 RTW
text: New York

headline: Romney Uses Lines From Pledge to Criticize Obama
text: VIRGINIA BEACH — Mitt Romney is fond of reciting things.

headline: Venice Film Festival: ‘Pieta’ and ‘The Master’ Come Up Winners
text: Fittingly for a festival where about half the titles in the official competition had religious themes, the 69th Venice Film Festival awarded its top prize, the Golden Lion, to “Pieta,” a mother-and-son drama with a sadistic streak from the prolific Korean director Kim Ki-duk. The film sharply divided critics — as do most of Mr. Kim’s confrontational movies — but it was deemed the best of the 18 competitors by a jury led by the filmmaker Michael Mann. Other members of the jury included the actress Samantha Morton, the filmmakers Matteo Garrone and Pablo Trapero and the artist Marina Abramovic.

headline: Game Maker Without a Rule Book
text: BELLEVUE, Wash.

headline: Envoy for the Game
text: Viswanathan Anand, the world champion, is a natural ambassador for chess. He has promoted the game all over Europe and has fostered programs in many schools across his native India.

headline: Penn State Hits Road, Only to Stumble
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — The Penn State football team, dressed all in white, sprinted out of the visitor’s tunnel veiled by a plume of silvery smoke.

headline: Packers Against 49ers: Adjust the Contrasts
text: 49ers at Packers

headline: threeASFOUR: Spring 2013 RTW
text: New York

headline: Young Talent Gives Mariners Hope for a Revival
text: Nothing has ever come easily for the Seattle Mariners. Even in their glory years, when they had Ken Griffey Jr., Randy Johnson and Alex Rodriguez in their primes, the Mariners could not win a pennant. When all three left and the Mariners won 116 regular-season games, they still lost in the American League playoffs.

headline: Gabriel Vahanian, Professor, Dies at 85; Was Linked to ‘Death of God’ Movement
text: Gabriel Vahanian, a theologian whose 1961 social critique, “The Death of God: The Culture of Our Post-Christian Era,” gave a name to a seemingly atheistic but widely misunderstood theological movement, died on Aug. 30 at his home in Strasbourg, France. He was 85.

headline: Panthers Make Best of Hitch in Preparations for Their Campaign
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The Carolina Panthers abandoned Bank of America Stadium last week after the chain-link fences went up and security personnel moved in. The stadium was preparing for what was supposed to be President Obama’s acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention on Thursday night.

headline: Circling the Job Listings
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — This was a cute idea. I liked the way the job qualifications matched each successive listing, so that while a BASEBALL PLAYER might need to “wear gloves in the field,” so would an ARCHAEOLOGIST, and that ARCHAEOLOGIST would also need to be “experienced in surveying for sites,” as would an ONLINE MARKETER.

headline: Physical Therapists Turn to Wii Golf
text: In the world of health care, Nintendo Wii golf is more than a high-tech toy. The video game has become a tool in physical, occupational and neurological rehabilitation.

headline: Max Bygraves, Jovial British Entertainer, Dies at 89
text: Max Bygraves, whose smart-alecky humor, Cockney charm and myriad renditions of easy-listening hits made him a British show-business institution, died on Aug. 31 in Queensland, Australia. He was 89.

headline: A Big Default Problem, but How Big?
text: The Department of Education plans to release its official default rate in the next few weeks. Prepare to be underwhelmed.

headline: Bad Student Debt Stubbornly High as Collection Efforts Surge
text: The amount of student loans that are delinquent has remained constant or increased at a time when delinquencies on mortgages and other types of consumer credit have declined.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Constance Jablonski at Helmut Lang
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Constance Jablonski before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Hannah Murray and hair by Paul Hanlon.

headline: Debt Collectors Cashing In on Student Loans
text: At a protest last year at New York University, students called attention to their mounting debt by wearing T-shirts with the amount they owed scribbled across the front — $90,000, $75,000, $20,000.

headline: Rescued by Music, Happy to Mail Out His Own CDs
text: Just two years ago, “Junky Star,” the album by Ryan Bingham & the Dead Horses, was released by the celebrated Nashville label Lost Highway Records. It was the most commercially successful album of Mr. Bingham’s career, reaching No. 2 on the Billboard country charts. But on Sept. 18, when he releases its follow-up, “Tomorrowland,” the record will not appear on Lost Highway or any other major label. It will be put out by his own label, Axster Bingham Records, which has  no track record and no other artists on its roster.

headline: Martin Continues to Find His Groove
text: BALTIMORE — Russell Martin said he had not made any drastic changes to his swing of late and had not gotten over any serious injury to help explain his recent offensive productivity. In fact, he has been playing through a nagging neck strain that has limited his mobility, especially turning his head to the right.

headline: In School Finance Tangle, Wealth Doesn’t Necessarily Mean More
text: ​Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Turkey’s Female Athletes, Like Women Nationwide, Reap Rewards
text: BODRUM, Turkey — The gifts started pouring in for Asli Cakir Alptekin almost as soon as she sprinted across the finish line at London’s Olympic Stadium on Aug. 10, becoming Turkey’s first female track and field gold medalist.

headline: Program Gives Migrant Students Extra Help
text: Eighteen-year-old Alfonso Lucio remembers the sun beating down on the back of his neck as he toiled in asparagus fields in Michigan, something he began doing at age 12. His cousin Jazmine Hernandez, who is the same age and also came from a family of migrant farm workers, was often at his side.

headline: Considering Death Row for Organs
text: Before Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon established a moratorium on his state’s death penalty last year, Christian Longo, a death row inmate, started a campaign to allow the condemned to donate their organs.

headline: Afghans Wary in Push for Mineral Riches
text: Afghanistan’s estimated $1 trillion in untapped mineral resources seems imperiled by corruption and violence.

headline: Potential for a Mining Boom Splits Factions in Afghanistan
text: KALU VALLEY, Afghanistan — If there is a road to a happy ending in Afghanistan, much of the path may run underground: in the trillion-dollar reservoir of natural resources — oil, gold, iron ore, copper, lithium and other minerals — that has brought hopes of a more self-sufficient country, if only the wealth can be wrested from blood-soaked soil.

headline: Sy J. Schulman, Planner for New York City Parks, Dies at 86
text: Sy J. Schulman, who smoothed the way for a controversial sewage plant in Harlem by offering state financing for a park with playgrounds and ball fields atop the structure, now known as the popular Riverbank State Park, died on Sept. 1 at his home in White Plains, where he once served as mayor. He was 86.

headline: Obama Makes Birth Certificate Joke
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Birthers, you’re not going to like this one.

headline: Mow Yard. Drop Off Kids. Take a Drive on Mars.
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Matt Heverly, 36, started a recent workday as any young father might: up at 5:30, gulping coffee, fixing a bottle for the baby. He threw on jeans and a T-shirt and drove his two sons to day care. He stopped to get the brakes on his Toyota checked and swung by the bank.

headline: Yanks Eye Pettitte’s Return
text: BALTIMORE — As the Yankees head into the final weeks of the season, engaged in a tight race for the American League East title with the Baltimore Orioles and the Tampa Bay Rays, they could be adding one of the most game-tested pitchers in baseball to their rotation for the final two weeks.

headline: Super Saturday Skies: Cloudy, Partly Happy
text: On Super Saturday at the United States Open, weather dominated instead of Serena Williams. This included torrential downpours, wind gusts so powerful they picked up chairs, a postponed women’s final, a postponed men’s semifinal and even an evacuation for an impending tornado.

headline: Townsend Wins Doubles Title
text: Taylor Townsend, 16, of Boca Raton, Fla., won her third junior Grand Slam doubles title of the year on Saturday, claiming the United States Open title with Gabrielle Andrews, 15, of Pomona, Calif. They scored a 6-4, 6-3 victory over Belinda Bencic of Switzerland and Petra Uberalova of Slovakia.

headline: A Rave at an Alexander Wang Show
text: A booming voice on the loudspeaker at Alexander Wang’s show on Saturday asked guests to refrain from using flash photography, “and that includes cellphones.” What was that about?

text: New York

headline: Gators Recover in Second Half to Spoil SEC Start for Aggies
text: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. — The Florida Gators appeared rocked by Texas A&M’s initial burst of energy, caught by the Aggies’ intent to make an immediate impact in the Southeastern Conference and their own struggles to forge their identity.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 2
text: Barneys dines for gay marriage, and Thom Yorke DJs for Rag & Bone.

headline: Mickelson’s 64 Shouts: Remember, I Can Play
text: CARMEL, Ind. — Nobody in this week’s BMW Championship field played at Crooked Stick Golf Club when it hosted the 1991 P.G.A. Championship, a major point of contention for Phil Mickelson, who qualified, or so he thought, by virtue of his win at the tour stop that year in Tucson.

headline: Players’ Support of Gay Marriage Alters N.F.L. Image
text: Baltimore Ravens linebacker Brendon Ayanbadejo has been a consistent supporter of legalizing same-sex marriage. In 2011, he filmed his own video backing this November’s ballot initiative in Maryland and posted it on YouTube, and he recently donated Ravens tickets to a Marylanders for Marriage Equality fund-raiser.

headline: Tornado Videos From Queens and Brooklyn
text: As a swirling mass of black cloud swept over the Rockaways on Saturday morning, a perplexed New Yorker, his video camera rolling, wondered aloud about the cloud formation forming in front of his balcony.

headline: Conversations With Andy Murray: Sean Connery and the Wind
text: After Andy Murray advanced to another United States Open final, his windy, wacky, 5-7, 6-2, 6-1, 7-6 (7) victory complete, he hustled through his interviews. He heard a tornado might be coming, and he wanted to get back to his hotel. He still spent a few minutes with Straight Sets.

headline: Why Are the Mets on Fox?
text: Passengers riding the 7 train had one or two choices upon arriving at the Mets-Willets Point stop Saturday — walk north toward Citi Field or head south in the direction of the United States Open at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center.

headline: College Football Replay
text: Week 2 in college football action included Texas A&M’s loss in its first game in the SEC, second-half rallies and a rendition of “Carmen Ohio.”

text: Chipper Jones remained hitless in his last series in New York, but the bats of his Braves teammates came to life Saturday in an 11-3 victory over the Mets at Citi Field.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Day 13
text: The rain and wind added excitement and frustration in the opening semifinal between Andy Murray and Tomas Berdych.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Romney to Appear on ‘Meet the Press’
text: Mitt Romney, in an appearance on “Meet the Press” to be aired on Sunday morning, praised former President Bill Clinton’s speech at the Democratic National Convention, suggesting that his performance outshone President Obama’s speech accepting his party’s renomination. He also criticized Mr. Obama and Congressional Republicans for agreeing to automatic cuts in defense spending as a way to force a deal on deficit reduction, in a process called sequestration.

headline: Altuzarra: Stoking the Engine
text: Before the start of Joseph Altuzarra’s show, at Industria Superstudio, the buzz was all about the front row — Kate Bosworth, Mamie Gummer, Jessica Chastain and Tyson Chandler, the Knicks center, who hit several shows on Saturday. But within minutes, attention shifted to the clothes — and the fantastically loopy boots — as editors began raving on Twitter.

headline: Monique Lhuillier: Spring 2013 RTW
text: New York

headline: Yanks Miss a Chance to Distance Themselves
text: BALTIMORE — Mark Teixeira, his calf aching and anger boiling, pulled up on his knees and fired his helmet into the dirt. The first-base umpire, Jerry Meals, had just made an incorrect call, according to both the naked eye and television replays, and instead of the Yankees completing a comeback with Chris Dickerson crossing the plate to tie the score, the game was over.

headline: Corrections: September 9, 2012
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: L.S.U. Crushes Washington Without Having to Strain
text: BATON ROUGE, La. — There was nothing flashy or fancy about how Barkevious Mingo charged at and through Washington tackle Erik Kohler as Kohler fell down, stayed down and then left the game because of injury in the first quarter. Neither Kohler nor his teammates could deny Louisiana State’s blend of power, speed and skill.

headline: Altuzarra: Spring 2013 RTW
text: New York

headline: Toronto Gets a Look at Cloud Atlas
text: TORONTO — How to describe “Cloud Atlas”? Picture “Brazil” meets “The Matrix” meets “The English Patient” meets “Forrest Gump,” with a little bit of “The Hobbit,” which we still haven’t seen, thrown in.

headline: Sept. 8: Conventions May Put Obama in Front-Runner’s Position
text: On Friday, we began to see reasonably clear signs that President Obama would receive some kind of bounce in the polls from the Democratic convention.

headline: Storm and Syracuse Can’t Stop No. 2 U.S.C.
text: The offenses of Southern California and Syracuse were expected to put on passing clinics at MetLife Stadium on Saturday. Instead, the offenses were for the most part stiff and inconsistent and the aerial spectacle was torrential rains.

headline: Amanda Jacobs, Reid Ballard
text: Amanda Kate Jacobs and Reid Norman Ballard were married Friday in Middletown, Conn. Darlene M. Rice, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated at the Wadsworth Mansion.

headline: Joanna Wilson, Brett Green
text: Joanna Hayes Wilson and Brett Samuel Green were married Saturday evening at Memorial Church on the campus of Stanford University. The Rev. Susan Scott, an Evangelical Lutheran minister and an associate minister at the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Leslie Boghosian, Paul Murphy
text: Leslie Karen Boghosian and Paul Andrew Murphy were married Friday evening at St. Leon Armenian Church in Fair Lawn, N.J. The Rev. Mardiros Chevian, an Armenian Apostolic priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Diran Bohajian, an Armenian Orthodox priest and the church’s pastor, taking part.

headline: Anna Zelig, Joseph Weilgus
text: Anna Shira Zelig and Joseph Michael Weilgus were married Monday at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J. Rabbi Shaul Robinson officiated.

headline: Catherine Deneke, Sarah Winawer-Wetzel
text: Catherine Congdon Deneke and Sarah Winawer-Wetzel were married Saturday at the Crown & Anchor, an event space in Provincetown, Mass. Tristan E. Guarini, a friend of the couple who received a one-day solemnization certificate from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, officiated.

headline: Bryan Hale, Nicholas D’Angelo
text: Bryan Erwin Hale and Nicholas Sebastian D’Angelo were married Saturday in Tarrytown, N.Y. New York State Supreme Court Justice Emily S. Pines officiated at the Lyndhurst mansion.

headline: Elle Choe, George Ristow
text: Elle Eunhee Choe and George Andrew Martin Ristow were married Saturday evening at the Bolingbroke Mansion in Radnor, Pa., in a Quaker-style ceremony under Pennsylvania’s self-uniting marriage statute.

headline: Aleesha Nissen, Stephen Ast
text: Aleesha Beth Nissen, the daughter of Morton R. Nissen of Brooklyn and the late Joan C. Nissen, was married Saturday to Stephen John Ast, a son of Dr. Alan Ast and Joan T. Ast of Davie, Fla. Rabbi Bennett H. Greenspon officiated at Fox Hollow in Woodbury, N.Y.

headline: Julia Marter, Carter Collison
text: Julia Marter, the daughter of Joan M. Marter and Walter H. Marter of New York, was married Saturday to Carter Philip Collison, a son of Mary W. Collison and Harry W. Collison Jr. of Winter Park, Fla. The ceremony, at Most Holy Trinity Parish church in East Hampton, N.Y., was performed by Msgr. Donald M. Hanson, a Roman Catholic priest and the church’s pastor.

headline: Cristina Altamura and Adam Sliwinski
text: Cristina Clara Maria Altamura, the daughter of Carmela Altamura and Leonard J. Altamura of Union City, N.J., was married Saturday to Adam Gilbert Sliwinski, a son of Eve Diehl Sliwinski and Thomas D. Sliwinski of London. The Rev. Stephanie G. Kershner, a Lutheran minister, led the ceremony at the Altamura Center for Arts and Cultures, a summer festival performance center attached to the bride’s parents’ summer house in Round Top, N.Y.

headline: Laura Silverstein, Joshua Reef
text: Laura Kim Silverstein, the daughter of David B. Silverstein and Carol L. Silverstein of Orangeburg, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Joshua Samuel Reef, the son of Susan Heidi Reef and Steven T. Reef of Andover, Mass. Rabbi Jon R. Haddon officiated at Catlin Gardens in Slate Hill, N.Y.

headline: Jennifer Rivera, Michael Rice
text: Jennifer Michelle Rivera was married Saturday in New York to Michael Jason Rice. Herschel D. Garfein, a librettist and composer who is a friend of the couple and who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Ladies Pavilion in Central Park.

headline: Britt Sandler, Peter Weeks
text: Britt Julia Sandler and Peter Joseph Weeks were married Saturday evening at Jonathan Edwards Winery in North Stonington, Conn. Mary A. Coburn, a Universal Brotherhood minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony.

headline: Sara Wexler, Marcus Koblitz

headline: In Toronto, Moviegoers Waiting to See ‘The Master’ Ask What It’s About
text: 8:39 a.m. | Updated  TORONTO — What is it with all the talk of time travel up here? “Looper” and “Cloud Atlas,” both introduced at the Toronto International Film Festival in the last few days, are loaded with migrating souls or leaps across the years. And Paul Thomas Anderson used the phrase “time travel” at least three times as he described his movie, “The Master,” at a press conference here on Saturday afternoon.

headline: Taliban Rages Over U.S. Decision on Terrorist Group
text: HONG KONG — Washington has formally branded the Haqqani network a foreign terrorist organization for its attacks against American and NATO forces and for its role in the Taliban superstructure in Afghanistan. The Taliban’s response? Angry, swift and deadly.

headline: The ‘Control Freaks’ Behind the Wheel
text: MONZA, Italy — For the third time this season the two McLaren Mercedes drivers qualified first and second on the grid — Lewis Hamilton edging out his teammate, Jenson Button, for pole position at the Italian Grand Prix. The two drivers are certainly on a roll, as Hamilton won the Hungarian Grand Prix at the end of July before the summer break, and Button won the Belgian Grand Prix last weekend, the first event after racing resumed.

headline: Tim Tebow Plays Football Today
text: “I think you can never have too much Tebow.” — Woody Johnson, the Jets’ owner, in August.

headline: On Being Nothing
text: I know that the world only tramples me as a street crowd does an earthworm — not out of malice or stupidity, but because no one sees it.

headline: This Week This Week
text: Actually today. My head will be talking on Stephanopoulos again; I understand that we’ll be discussing Honey Boo Boo, and maybe also economics and politics.

headline: Another Way to Take Your iPad Underwater
text: LifeProof, which claims to make the thinnest waterproof iPhone case, has gone one step further for its iPad case by doing away with the plastic membrane that goes over the screen.

headline: Arms And The Mitt
text: A week ago I noted that Mitt Romney’s convention speech included a sudden lurch into weaponized Keynesianism, the doctrine that government spending destroys jobs unless it’s spending on defense contractors, in which case it’s the lifeblood of the economy.

text: The Look: Fallen Angel

headline: Construction and Real Estate Hinder China’s Growth
text: CHENGDU, China — With more than 100 tall cranes on the skyline, this metropolis in western China looks vibrant at first glance despite the country’s sharp economic slowdown.

headline: Europe Plan Faces Threat in Germany
text: FRANKFURT — With a few choice words last week, the European Central Bank and its president, Mario Draghi, managed to tame bond markets and inspire a market rally. But the coming week may reveal whether the rescue plan for Spain and Italy was a turning point in the euro zone crisis or just a short-lived spell of relief.

headline: Death Sentence for a Top Iraqi Leader in a Day of Bloodshed
text: BAGHDAD — A vice president of Iraq, a prominent Sunni Muslim, was convicted of murder and sentenced to death on Sunday in a trial conducted in absentia. The verdict coincided with a wave of bombings and insurgent attacks that claimed at least 100 lives, making Sunday one of the bloodiest days in Iraq since American troops withdrew last year.

headline: Off Court, Tennis Stars Are Putting Pressure on the Grand Slams
text: There were rain delays and lost sessions at the United States Open, pushed again to a Monday men’s final. There was a tornado warning and a chair blown onto the court in the midst of the men’s semifinal between Tomas Berdych and Andy Murray, the eventual champion.

headline: Should Parents Impose a Dress Code?
text: In 2009-10, about 57 percent of public school principals reported that their schools enforced a dress code. The codes themselves vary; some rules are intended to promote modesty (skirts and shorts must extend beyond fingertips; there can be no spaghetti straps) and others to encourage a respectful learning environment (no jeans; no screen prints or text on shirts).

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Politics and political leaders dominated the magazine covers this week. Prime Minister Manmohan Singh found himself at the center of many stories that highlighted his government’s predicament and his own loss of credibility. Outlook’s cover carried the words “King is Singed,” a play on the title of a popular Indian movie. “Manmohan Singh’s integrity was the Congress’s USP in 2009,” it read. “By making the P.M. the target of the coal scam, the BJP has turned the middle-class mascot into an electoral liability ahead of 2014,” when the country will hold its next national elections.

headline: Americans Abroad: Aron Johannsson Starts Strong
text: While most of the top leagues in Europe are taking an early break for the FIFA international window, the first eight games of the Danish Superliga season already has some great stories.

headline: Romney Has Conciliatory Remarks on Obama and Health Overhaul
text: 3:09 p.m. | Updated Mitt Romney said Sunday that he would retain elements of President Obama’s health care overhaul, blamed Republicans as much as Democrats for the “mistake” of agreeing to automatic cuts in military spending to avoid a fiscal crisis and acknowledged that Mr. Obama’s national security strategy has made America in “some ways safer.”

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Alexander Wang
text: The Look: Modern MinimalismThe Makeup: The makeup artist Diane Kendal opted for a clean, matte complexion to complement the minimalist nature of Alexander Wang’s Spring 2013 collection. Skin was first primed with NarsSkin Optimal Brightening Concentrate, then coated with the brand’s Pure Radiant Tinted Moisturizer SPF 30/PA+++. Next, using a contoured blush brush (in place of the classic, dome-shaped powder brush), Kendal applied two shades of Nars Sheer Glow Powder Foundation — a lighter one on the outside of the face and a darker one across the cheeks — to perfect. (At press time, Kendal was not at liberty to disclose why, but a selection of models were given a more futuristic finish using Nars Light Reflecting Loose Setting Powder and Albatross Highlighting Blush on the high points of their cheeks, with some also sporting bleached or whited-out brows.) Eyes were contoured using Cayenne eyeshadow, while the same product in Blondie (light) or Bali (dark) were used to fill in the brows. Lashes were left bare.The Hair: “Ponytails are always very prevalent in New York,” says the stylist Guido Palau. “Half my career has been based on trying to reinvent it.” For Wang’s presentation, Palau used a variation on a look he’d originally conceived in the early ’90s: the taped center-part. To modernize the look, the stylist opted for dual texture — a sleek top with movement in the back — and low positioning. To achieve this, the top of the head (to behind the ears) was first dampened, then parted and treated with Redken Satinwear 02 Ultimate Blow-Dry Lotion before being blown straight. Once secured into a ponytail, the ends were sectioned and curled.

headline: Government Employment
text: During today’s round table on ABC, Rand Paul seemed shocked at my claim that government employment is down under Obama. Of course, it is. But maybe he’s thinking of the fact that since govt employment rose under Bush, we’re still at higher absolute levels than we were a decade ago.

headline: A Fix for Tennis Elbow
text: Gretchen Reynolds, the Phys Ed columnist, talks about the latest research and a promising exercise to combat the pain of tennis elbow.

headline: Djokovic Defeats Ferrer to Advance to Final
text: Defending champion Novak Djokovic of Serbia has advanced to his third consecutive United States Open final with a 2-6, 6-1, 6-4, 6-2 win over David Ferrer of Spain. Djokovic, the No. 2 seed, will play No. 3 Andy Murray of Great Britain in the Monday final, which will begin at 4 p.m. E.S.T.

headline: Teaching the F.A.A. That Dogs Don’t Buckle Up
text: If you’ve ever flown Virgin America, you will have seen the cartoonlike safety video that plays before the flight takes off.

headline: A Slow Weekend at the Box Office
text: The fall movie season got under way, just barely, with what may turn out to be one of the least-attended weekends at cinemas in years. The only new release of note was “The Words” (CBS Films), a poorly reviewed drama about a plagiarizing novelist. It placed third, taking in about $5 million; CBS paid $2 million for domestic distribution rights. The No. 1 movie was a holdover: “The Possession” (Lionsgate) took in an estimated $9.5 million, for a two-week total of about $33.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. The Weinstein Company’s “Lawless” was second, selling about $6 million in tickets, for a two-week total of $23.5 million. In its fourth weekend “The Expendables 2” (Lionsgate) placed fourth, grossing about $4.8 million and lifting its total to $75.4 million. “The Bourne Legacy” (Universal Pictures) was fifth, taking in an estimated $4 million, for a five-week total of $103.7 million. Deadline.com summed up the weak box-office results this way: “The weekend of Sept. 5, 2008, was the last time no films grossed over $10 million. Ouch!”

headline: A Sunny Sunday for Victoria Beckham
text: The Sunday weather brought a break in the humidity for New Yorkers, and the first fashion show of the day, that of Victoria Beckham, also spelled relief. It was a pleasant surprise to see the opening looks of the collection actually included a few loosely fitted blouses and skirts, rather than the usual skintight dresses that can look rather constricting. (Those came later.)

FiveThirtyEight spoke with James R. Henson, the director of the Texas Politics Project at the University of Texas at Austin; Robert D. Miller, the chairman of the Public Law Group at Locke Lord L.L.P.; and Steve H. Murdock, a professor in the department of sociology at Rice University in Houston.

text: The first large and comprehensive study of the genetics of a common lung cancer has found that more than half the tumors from that cancer have mutations that might be treated by new drugs that are already in the pipeline or that could be easily developed.

headline: Spotlight on Safety for Shows Outdoors
text: Jim Digby, the tour manager for Linkin Park, knows better than most how dangerous a rock ’n’ roll show can be. In 1983 he was a 19-year-old technical director at a new nightclub outside Philadelphia when a piece of equipment he was operating came off a faulty overhead track, plummeted toward the floor and killed a young woman standing just a few feet from him.

headline: Syria Criticizes France for Supporting Rebels, as Fears Grow of Islamist Infiltration
text: CAIRO — The Syrian government accused France of “schizophrenia” on Sunday for pledging to support a peaceful resolution to the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad and simultaneously aiding the armed groups driving the insurrection. At the same time, a French doctor returning from a rebel-controlled hospital raised new alarms about the presence of foreign Islamist militants in Syria, stoking fears that have discouraged the West from more forceful support for the rebels.

headline: Ryan Defends His ‘Yes’ Vote on Automatic Defense Cuts
text: WASHINGTON – Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican nominee for vice president, on Sunday defended his decision to support automatic cuts in defense spending as a way to force a deal on reducing the deficit, an approach that was sharply criticized by his running mate, Mitt Romney.

headline: Obama, Invoking Clinton, Says Romney Budget Doesn’t Add Up
text: MELBOURNE, Fla. — President Obama, picking up where former President Bill Clinton left off, said Sunday that the budget proposals offered by Mitt Romney and Paul D. Ryan do not add up.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Ava Smith at Lacoste

headline: Teixeira Out Indefinitely After Reinjuring Calf
text: BALTIMORE — Mark Teixeira was not in the lineup for Sunday’s series finale against the Baltimore Orioles, and he probably will not play in the three-game series against the Boston Red Sox this week, either. Beyond that, there is no telling when he will return.

headline: I’m Jumping Jack Flash, It’s a Gas Gas Gas
text: The joys of speech recognition continue. An irate caller left a message after my appearance on This Week; according to the software, he called me a “liberal jack gas”.

headline: Weather Is Nice; Djokovic Is Fierce
text: At the end of his United States Open semifinal, Novak Djokovic hardly celebrated. He let out a small scream, pumped a quick fist and skipped across the court at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Altuzarra
text: The Look: French (With a) TwistThe Makeup: “Imagine Catherine Deneuve meets Monsieur Yves Saint Laurent,” says the makeup artist Tom Pecheux. “The girl is perfectly done, but in a very simple way.” M.A.C. Face and Body Foundation was applied to even skin tone and conceal imperfections, followed by the brand’s Sculpting Powder Pro in Definitive (as needed, to contour). The eyes were dressed first with shadows from the M.A.C. Archie’s Collection Spoiled Rich palette in Ron Ron Ron (using the #266 brush),then finished with a line of Technakohl Liner in Auto-de-Blu — drawn to the curve of the lid, with no extension — and a swipe of Haute & Naughty Lash mascara.

headline: Congress Comes Back to a Face-Off With Angry Farmers
text: WASHINGTON — When Congress returns to business this week, it will be met not by the Code Pink antiwar protesters or the Tea Party supporters who often gathered near the Capitol last year. Instead, farmers will be out in force, rallying for a bill that lawmakers failed to pass before they recessed five weeks ago.

headline: Why Weather Forecasters Are Role Models
text: An excerpt from my forthcoming book, “The Signal and the Noise,” was published this week in The New York Times Magazine. You can find an online version of the excerpt here.

headline: Envelope, Please: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf
text: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf, a Somali student at African Leadership Academy in Johannesburg, South Africa, is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.

headline: Williams Beats Azarenka for U.S. Open Title
text: Serena Williams rallied back from the brink of defeat to win the women’s singles championship of the 2012 United States Open with a 6-2, 2-6, 7-5 victory over Victoria Azarenka. It was her fourth Open title and 15th Grand Slam title overall.

headline: Take These Bawdy Ditties as Balms for Melancholy
text: The classical-music club scene in New York grows ever livelier. Though “grows” may seem an odd word applied to the tiny performance space at Jimmy’s No. 43, a basement bar and restaurant in the East Village. Musica Nuova, a spunky Boston-born early-music ensemble, opened its second New York season at Jimmy’s on Thursday evening with a fast-paced, 50-minute program, “Men, Maids and Mischief: Bawdy English Songs,” and delivered the goods (bads?) handsomely.

headline: Obama Gets a Lift on the Trail
text: FORT PIERCE, Fla. — Scott Van Duzer, pizza parlor owner and blood donator, can bench press 350 pounds. So he had no trouble with the 6-foot-1, 176-pound, skinny President Obama.

headline: Frayed Man of Action With a Head for Figures
text: “A Wanted Man” is Lee Child’s 17th Jack Reacher novel and the last to be published before Reacher goes Hollywood with “Jack Reacher,” a big Christmas movie based on book No. 9, “One Shot,” and starring — can’t say it ain’t so, because it is — Tom Cruise. Mr. Cruise seems such a wrong choice to play this jumbo vigilante that this is a good moment to contemplate the essential Reacher: not just what he looks like but also what he really is.

headline: With a Composer as Your Umbrella
text: The weather on Saturday was seething and unsettled. Tornadoes even touched down in Queens and Brooklyn.

headline: For Putin, a Flight of Fancy at a Summit Meeting’s Close
text: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia — At times, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia seemed to be limping and in pain this weekend, but as the annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting wrapped up here on Sunday, the Russian leader showed some of his trademark swagger, hitting back at political opponents who mocked his latest stunt: flying a motorized glider to help lead endangered cranes from Siberia on their migration south.

headline: Before ‘Chickadee’ Fame, Fields Had Canary Trouble
text: The scene unfolded like something out of one of W.C. Fields’ movies. A quick-handed, wisecracking entertainer wowed a packed house, only to find himself grabbed by two police officers after the show, paraded before the flashbulbs, and hauled before a judge, where he was charged with torturing a canary.

headline: Any Other Questions?
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A miserable winter for the Jets bled into an optimistic spring, which gave way to a summer bursting with promise and possibility — at least from their perspective. For months, they were besieged with questions about the potential for a quarterback controversy, then dismissed them with a steely glance. They absorbed criticism for a sputtering offense, for curious personnel decisions — an unproven right tackle, an inexperienced receiving corps, a sociocultural phenomenon as Mark Sanchez’s backup — for being equal parts carnival attraction and football team.

headline: Crawford, Unseeded, Wins Junior Girls Title
text: Unseeded Samantha Crawford of Atlanta won the 2012 United States Open Junior Girls’ Championship on Sunday with a 7-5, 6-3 victory over Anett Kontaveit of Estonia.

text: New York

headline: Innovation in Journalism Goes Begging for Support
text: Journalism has a shortage of many things: capital, advertisers and, in some instances, readers. But certainly its most precious commodity is innovation.

headline: Third Annual Charity Pro-Am for BackStoppers
text: The BackStoppers, a nonprofit organization in St. Louis, gives money to the families of police officers, firefighters and emergency medical personnel who have been killed in the line of duty. A pro-am bridge event at Bridge Haven in Hazelwood, Mo., on Aug. 26 raised almost $5,000 for BackStoppers. The winners, John Samsel and Alan Lemley, scored very well in the diagramed deal.

headline: Glamour Campaign Tries to Claim a Generation
text: FOR almost three decades, Hearst attracted younger readers, and the advertisers who crave them, to Cosmopolitan magazine with a campaign carrying the theme “I guess you could say I’m That Cosmopolitan Girl.” Now, a principal Cosmo competitor, Glamour, is seeking to reach the readers and advertisers of 2012 and beyond with a campaign that presents a contemporary take on the youthful woman.

text: Carine Roitfeld’s news “book” and Alexander Wang’s rap-themed rave.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Jones and Braves Depart With a Sweep
text: The fans in Queens have developed a complicated relationship with Chipper Jones of the Atlanta Braves, their enduring and frequent tormentor, who this year announced he would retire at the end of the season. As evidence, consider their response to him Sunday afternoon, when he entered as a pinch-hitter in the ninth inning of a tied game.

headline: Transcending Real Sound in Real Time With the Unexpected
text: The first thing you notice about the young guitarist Rafiq Bhatia’s music is its hunger to combine, though it never sounds like established tradition A plus established tradition B. He’s merging more volatile tendencies — propositions, not facts — and he’s in a hurry.

headline: Spotlighting Prizewinning Composers
text: The music program of Trinity Wall Street, which was largely suspended and seemed in jeopardy in the spring as the church’s vestry was reassessing its costs and purposes, has come roaring back for the new season, more varied than ever. Under the direction of Julian Wachner the program has become a hotbed of early music, and Mr. Wachner has said that among other innovations he plans to do the same for contemporary music, giving greater scope to Trinity’s instrumental ensemble Novus NY.

headline: On Facebook, Bullies ‘Like’ if You Hate
text: For the digitally native generation, self-worth is accrued in likes.

headline: The Sadness of a Wife Mistrusted
text: Rama is the hero of the ancient Indian epic the Ramayana, but heroes don’t always behave admirably.

headline: Treasury to Cut A.I.G. Stake Below 50%
text: The Treasury Department said on Sunday that it was planning its biggest sale of shares in the American International Group to date, making the federal government a minority shareholder in the bailed-out insurer for the first time since it took control of the company four years ago.

headline: Britain Exports Its Soul
text: The desperate center of Jessie Ware’s debut album, “Devotion,” is “Taking In Water,” a languorous and arresting tragedy about punishing oneself so that someone less worthy might live. Over gaseous, melancholy synths Ms. Ware unfurls her tale heavily.

headline: Little Guy in the Garden
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — BACFill (formerly the Bay Area Crossword Tournament) was held on Saturday to benefit the Families of SMA, a support and fund-raising group dedicated to finding a cure for Spinal Muscular Atrophy. The Monday through Thursday New York Times puzzles that you will be doing this week were generously donated by Will Shortz.

headline: Victorian London, Hypocrisy and Filth Included
text: The Victorian London on display in “The Crimson Petal and the White,” a four-hour mini-series beginning Monday on Encore, is not the one we’re accustomed to seeing on American television. Chamber pots, and the rear ends of those using them, figure prominently, as do blood, vomit, foul odors and the fully naked bodies of men and women who have not been to the gym in a long time, if ever.

headline: Fighting Off Biggest Names, McIlroy Again Tops the List
text: CARMEL, Ind. — As Phil Mickelson and Vijay Singh stalked their putts on the 18th green, Rory McIlroy stood outside the scoring trailer scrolling through his congratulatory messages. McIlroy, ranked No. 1 in the world, had secured his second title in two weeks and his third in his last four starts with a two-stroke victory in the BMW Championship. Among the first texts he retrieved on his smartphone was one from the tennis superstar Rafael Nadal, who wrote, “Well done.”

headline: Lawmakers Push to Increase White House Oversight of Financial Regulators

headline: ‘Soda Ban Explained’
text: I don’t drink much soda, I don’t buy Big Gulps, and my body mass index is right where it should be. Until the public hearing on July 24, I had largely ignored Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposed ban on large, sugary drinks because it would have no effect on my daily life. It was watching supporters of the ban struggle to articulate exactly what it would mean that motivated me to educate myself and ultimately make a movie about it. The proposal is best conveyed visually, not verbally.

headline: Soda Ban Explained
text: The filmmaker Casey Neistat presents a guide to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to restrict sales of big sugary drinks in New York.

headline: Nuclear Mullahs
text: IRAN has returned to the front pages after a summer hiatus. Negotiations aimed at preventing the dreaded Persian Bomb have resumed their desultory course. Iran, although suffering from the international sanctions choreographed by the Obama administration, keeps adding new arrays of centrifuges while insisting the program is strictly nonmilitary. Israel is — or maybe isn’t — edging closer to a unilateral strike. The U.S., we learn from The Times’s reliable David Sanger, is considering more and bigger bouts of cybersabotage. Meanwhile, the mullahs are shipping arms to their embattled fellow despots in Syria.

headline: German Envoy Goes to Greece, Leaving Lectures Behind
text: RHODES, Greece — To long-suffering Greeks, German officials embody the diktats from abroad that have deepened their country’s descent into insolvency and depression. Listening to Angela Merkel, Germany’s Iron Chancellor, her tough-talking finance minister or the uncompromising head of the Bundesbank, it often feels like a game of bad cop, worse cop, worst cop.

headline: Y-3: Spring 2013 RTW
text: New York

headline: The Roar of the Night
text: In 1899, Dr. Robert Thaxter Edes, a Harvard graduate and Civil War veteran, noted that “the tree cricket does not say much in the daytime.” Dr. Edes was trying to calibrate the change in the pitch of a tree cricket’s note as the temperature changes. He offered a graph but not the actual pitches. F. H. Hall, writing in 1912, was more specific. The song is “a clear mellow whistle resembling the words treat, treat, treat, pitched about in C, two octaves above middle C, on a warm evening rising to D.” One species sings a half pitch higher and another “about F# on an average summer evening.”

headline: Interactive One’s Site for Latinos
text: Interactive One, a digital media company best known for creating content for African-Americans, is set to announce on Monday that it has started a Web site aimed at urban Latinos.

headline: Separatist Victory, but Not Separation
text: For the past four decades, proponents of an independent Quebec have fought a political battle with the federalist Liberals without achieving, or putting to rest, the separatists’ dream of an independent French-speaking state. Last Tuesday, Quebecers again voted into office the Parti Québécois, whose purpose since its formation in 1968 has been separatism. This time separatism is not a serious prospect. Nor was it the main issue in the election.

headline: Pro-Beijing Candidates Outmaneuver Opponents as Hong Kong Votes

headline: A New Kind of Warfare
text: Cybersecurity efforts in the United States have largely centered on defending computer networks against attacks by hackers, criminals and foreign governments, mainly China. Increasingly, however, the focus is on developing offensive capabilities, on figuring out how and when the United States might unleash its own malware to disrupt an adversary’s networks. That is potentially dangerous territory.

headline: With Balanced Offense and Physical Defense, 49ers Control the Packers
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — Even after quarterback Alex Smith directed five fourth-quarter comebacks in last year’s regular season and one more in the playoffs, the San Francisco 49ers emerged with a reputation as a dynamic defensive team with a one-dimensional, functional offense. Smith threw only five interceptions and managed the offense decently, but he certainly was no Aaron Rodgers, the electrifying Green Bay Packers star with whom he shares draft history.

headline: Man Surrenders in Police Shooting

headline: Obstruct and Exploit
text: Does anyone remember the American Jobs Act? A year ago President Obama proposed boosting the economy with a combination of tax cuts and spending increases, aimed in particular at sustaining state and local government employment. Independent analysts reacted favorably. For example, the consulting firm Macroeconomic Advisers estimated that the act would add 1.3 million jobs by the end of 2012.

text: The family of the bodega worker killed by a police bullet met with the Bronx district attorney on Sunday to request that a grand jury investigate the actions of the police officer who fired the fatal shot on Friday, representatives for the family said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Tortured Empathy, a Ghost Hovers
text: A ghost haunts the graveyard setting of “The Train Driver,” the latest play by Athol Fugard, which opened Sunday night at the Pershing Square Signature Center in a production directed by the playwright. This particular specter is made of flesh and blood. Roelf Visagie (Ritchie Coster) is unquestionably a living man, and yet there is something hollowed out about his presence, as if the soul that once inhabited his body has withered away, leaving an echoing emptiness behind.

Toward the end of the Civil War, the only local men not carrying a musket for the South were elderly, blind or disabled.

headline: Contador Wins Second Vuelta

Contador easily navigated the largely processional final leg, into and around Madrid, to edge out Alejandro Valverde and Joaquim Rodríguez in the 21-stage race. Valverde, the 2009 winner, finished 1 minute 16 seconds behind. Rodríguez was 1:38 back.

headline: Iraq’s Vice President Calls Death Sentence ‘Unjust’
text: BAGHDAD — Tariq al-Hashimi, a vice president of Iraq and a prominent Sunni Muslim who was convicted of murder and sentenced to death in a trial conducted in absentia, denounced the verdict on Monday as “false and unjust,” depicting the court’s finding as “an acquittal, confirming my innocence.”

headline: On Our Radar: Shell Begins Preparatory Drilling Off Alaska
text: A Royal Dutch Shell vessel sends a drill bit into the ocean floor in the Chukchi Sea in the Arctic, beginning preliminary work on an exploratory well 70 miles off the northwestern coast of Alaska. The Interior Department approved the preparatory move but has not yet certified Shell’s oil spill response barge. [Associated Press]

headline: Amazon and Apple’s Giant Markups on Flash Storage
text: Apart from the look and feel of their products, there’s a key difference between Amazon’s new tablets and Apple’s iPads: the amount of money each company charges for storage. Apple customers typically pay more to get extra gigabytes, but over all, both companies do a major markup on memory.

headline: North Korea Is Ready to Discuss Aid From Seoul
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Monday that it was ready to discuss humanitarian aid from the South to alleviate damage caused by flooding and typhoons.

headline: Flying Putin, Fired Editor
text: MOSCOW — Losing my job as editor of one of the world’s oldest popular-science magazines, Vokrug Sveta (Around the World), was faster and less painful than I had imagined. And I had spent a couple of months imagining how this might happen.

headline: Stan Lee, Still a True Believer, Spends a Day on AMC’s ‘Comic Book Men’
text: RED BANK, N.J. – Friday seemed like a special morning in the life of Jack Davis, a towheaded boy who had been granted entry to Jay and Silent Bob’s Secret Stash, a comic-book store here. Though a familiar sign in the window said “I Assure You We’re Open,” the shop was in fact closed for a taping of “Comic Book Men,” the AMC reality series about its proprietors.

headline: Sept. 9: Call It as You See It
text: I’ve been picking up some sentiment from analysts and journalists in my Twitter feed recently, who correctly note that polling around the party conventions can be volatile. They suggest that we ought to wait for more data before concluding very much about the bounces that the conventions have produced.

headline: An Obvious Shyster
text: Tom Edsall has a very good piece on one of the key evasions in the Ryan budget plan, the huge unspecified cuts in discretionary spending. Edsall goes into more detail than anyone else I’ve read about just how much is hidden in that “sinkhole” and how it calls everything else Ryan claims into question.

headline: Teachers’ Strike in Chicago Tests Mayor and Union
text: CHICAGO — This city found itself engulfed on Monday by a sudden public school strike that left 350,000 children without classes, turned a spotlight on rising tensions nationally over teachers’ circumstances, and placed both the powerful teachers’ union and Mayor Rahm Emanuel in a risky, politically fraught standoff with no clear end in sight.

text: Design Sponge: Desserts that maximize and magnify the last of the season’s berries. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Journalism’s Big Tent, and Google vs. Amazon on Search
text: An experiment in journalism education at Mercer University in Macon, Ga., will also inject life and resources into the professional journalism in the city, Christine Haughney writes. Backed by a $4.6 million grant from the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, Mercer’s Center for Collaborative Journalism will be home to reporters and editors of the city’s 186-year-old paper, The Telegraph, and the local public radio station. Students will do reporting legwork, with guidance from professors and working journalists, in what the university’s president compares to the way medical schools use hospitals to train their students.

headline: Kathy Ryan Honored by Royal Photographic Society
text: At a ceremony last week in London, the magazine’s photo director, Kathy Ryan, was one of several people recognized by The Royal Photographic Society for their significant contributions to photography. Kathy received the society’s annual award for Outstanding Service to Photography.

headline: One Hour Photo? Try One Minute.
text: Although we get digital photos instantly, it generally takes a quite a bit longer – days, in fact – to send away for prints of your shots.

headline: Stoops Grow in Value, and Not Just as Seating
text: When Alex Barrett bought a four-story brick town house in Cobble Hill five years ago, on a picturesque stretch of Henry Street in Brooklyn lined with idyllic homes, it was, he recalled fondly, “the worst one of the block.”

headline: Worker Killed in Brooklyn Building Collapse
text: Updated, 3:51 p.m. | A worker was killed and another seriously injured on Monday when a third-story construction floor overloaded with cinder blocks collapsed beneath the men and they fell 30 feet at an apartment building under construction in Brooklyn, officials said.

headline: Leading Off: Manning Wins Big; Irsay Loses Bigger
text: The resounding conclusion of the circus that was Indianapolis’s jettisoning of quarterback Peyton Manning after last season was that the Colts’ owner, Jim Irsay, had better be right about this. He had better be right that Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck would be franchise savior No. 2, as polished and poised as the original. And he’d better be right that Manning was finished because, even if Luck is all that, Colts fans were always going to fume every time Manning engineered a winning drive for the Broncos, were always going to blame Irsay for shipping their beloved hero out of town, were always going to cringe when they thought of the man who cut Peyton Manning.

headline: In the Caribbean Coral Die-Off, Myriad Wrinkles
text: At its ongoing conference in South Korea, the International Union for Conservation of Nature released a report on Friday indicating that live coral coverage on reefs in the Caribbean has plummeted from nearly 50 percent in the 1970s to less than 10 percent today. Yet describing the entire Caribbean as a region where reefs are in a state of general collapse tends to cloud the problem’s complexity, the study suggests.

headline: Daily Report: Google Fights Amazon for Shoppers’ Clicks
text: Amazon.com and Google are waging a war to become the pre-eminent online mall, Claire Cain Miller and Stephanie Clifford report in Monday’s New York Times. And e-commerce sites large and small are caught in the cross-fire.

headline: Bomber Kills 16 in Attack on Afghan Protest Site
text: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber attacked the police on Monday at the site of a planned demonstration in Kunduz, a northern provincial capital, killing 16 people, Afghan officials said.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Field Is Set for Nascar Sprint Cup Chase
text: As some of Nascar’s most formidable drivers were shut out of the Sprint Cup postseason, others were bid passage in unlikely fashion.

headline: Apple as the Last Hope for Growth in Business PCs
text: There was a time when spotting an Apple product in the average corporate workplace was only slightly easier than catching a glimpse of a unicorn. Now comes a report saying that Apple will most likely be the main reason the corporate computer hardware market will show any growth at all this year.

headline: N.H.L. Lockout Looms; Contract Enters Final Week
text: The final countdown begins Monday, and the N.H.L. work stoppage that everyone has expected since mid-July impends, less than six days away. Unless something unforeseen and astoundingly cooperative happens between the deadlocked parties on or before Saturday the current collective bargaining agreement will expire, and Commissioner Gary Bettman will follow through on his promise to lock out the players for the third time in 18 years.

headline: Share Your Traditional Family Recipes
text: Some recipes have a way of spanning oceans, miles and generations, connecting us to people who may be long gone. In connection with an upcoming article on the power of family recipes, please share yours — traditional dishes in your family that evoke another time and place, like Jamaican sweet plantains, Cuban oxtail stew or Italian red sauce.

text: Students in Amritsar, Punjab offered prayers ahead of the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: Williams Rallied Behind a Switch in Tactics
text: In a prizefight of a match, Serena Williams came back from a 3-5 third-set deficit to defeat Victoria Azarenka on Sunday in a thrilling United States Open women’s singles final at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Undies to Match the Season
text: Monday morning at 9, for a change of pace from the runways, I stopped by the Spanx by Sara Blakely presentation to see another side of fashion. The phenomenally successful innerwear company is best known for its compression garments, and somehow there is always the impression that products like bras and panties are designed in a world far removed from what is happening at the shows in Lincoln Center.

headline: In Northwest Corner of India, the Work of Centuries
text: “In scattered hamlets, weavers, embroiderers, textile painters, tie-dyers, bead workers, potters, carvers, cobblers and bell-makers work as they have for centuries, often taking weeks, even months to finish a single flawless piece,” Claire Spiegel wrote in The International Herald Tribune of the craftsmen of Kutch, in the northwestern state of Gujarat.

headline: Polo Dobkin to Leave the Kitchen at Dressler
text: Polo Dobkin has announced that he is leaving Dressler, the restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where he has been the executive chef for seven years. Mr. Dobkin, a graduate of the French Culinary Institute, said his plans were still evolving, but were likely to involve opening his own place.

headline: Cartoonist Charged with Sedition in Mumbai
text: A Mumbai court sent Aseem Trivedi, a young cartoonist, to judicial custody for two weeks on charges of sedition and violating the information technology act after he drew a cartoon that mocked the corruption in the Indian government.

text: India’s governing Congress Party received the largest donations of any political party in the last seven years, and donations to the party’s primary opposition, the Bharatiya Janata Party, were less than half of Congress’s.

headline: Big Step in Selling A.I.G. Stake, but Other Bailouts Remain
text: The Treasury Department announced on Sunday the biggest sale of its holdings in the American International Group yet, taking its stake below 50 percent for the first time since 2008.

text: Last week’s App Smart column was all about apps for babies, because they really will love playing with your tablet and smartphone as much as you do (though you may need to pay a lot of attention lest they drop your expensive electronic item onto the floor or dribble on it).

text: BEIJING — Independent filmmaking is tough anywhere in the world, but in China, especially, it is not a vocation for the faint of heart.

headline: Communist Leader’s Absence Sets Off Rumor Mills in China
text: BEIJING — The strange disappearance from public view of China’s presumptive new leader is turning a year that was supposed to showcase the Communist Party’s stability into something of an annus horribilis.

headline: Crabs May Rely on Color to Tell Food From Poison
text: Two species of crabs that live on the seafloor have color-coding abilities that help them detect food, a new study suggests.

headline: Michael Pietsch of Little, Brown to Be Hachette Book’s Chief Executive
text: 2:41 p.m. | Updated Michael Pietsch, the publisher of Little, Brown and Company and a hands-on editor known for his work with both literary titans and mass-market commercial authors, has been named chief executive of the Hachette Book Group.

headline: Numberplay: Catbird Seat
text: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Numberplay reader Matthew Albright, who had come across the puzzle among a collection of compendious amusements at the blog Futility Closet. I asked Futility Closet’s creator Greg Ross where he happened to find the puzzle, and what he liked about it.

headline: Designed in Iran
text: Nothing has captured my attention as much lately as the graphic design coming out of Iran. While I’ve been familiar with the incredible work of more established designers like Reza Abedini, recently I’ve been mesmerized by the generation of designers who were born around the time of the Islamic Revolution of 1979 — those who grew up at a time when Iranians were grappling with an Islamic society. You can see this most notably in the work of Homa Delvaray, Iman Raad and Farhad Fozouni, who combine disparate cultural influences as well as technology and traditional applied arts. They utilize Farsi script as imagery, rather than simply as type.

headline: Issues Linger as Afghans Take Control of a Prison
text: BAGRAM, Afghanistan — It was supposed to be a ceremony to celebrate the full transfer of Afghan detainees and prison operations to Afghan control. But top American commanders were absent on Monday, hundreds of Afghan prisoners remained under American detention, and details of the deal remained in dispute.

headline: Company Says It, Not F.B.I., Was Hacking Victim
text: A company in Orlando, Fla., said on Monday that it — not the F.B.I. — was the source of a file hackers posted online last week that contained a million identification numbers for Apple mobile devices.

headline: An Updated Great Lakes Accord
text: The United States and Canada have amended a 40-year-old environmental accord on the Great Lakes, expanding its goals to tackle problems like invasive species, pollution and climate change.

headline: Video of Police Encounter May Play Lead Role in Lawsuit
text: The shaky and frenetic video, lasting less than a minute, appears to show two New York police officers holding a man on the floor, with one repeatedly slamming his right fist into the man’s face.

headline: Can the S.E.C. Win an Insider Case the Old-Fashioned Way?
text: Over thirty years ago, the actor John Houseman intoned about brokerage firm Smith Barney: “They make money the old-fashioned way. They earn it.”

headline: Millennials, in Uniform or Not, Come of Age in the 9/11 Decade
text: “Raise your hand if you know someone serving in the military,” my political anthropology professor asked one day during a senior seminar. I looked around the room and saw a few scattered hands in the air, then down at my own, firmly planted in my lap. It was the fall of 2007, and the United States military had been engaged in two theaters of war for the better part of a decade. I was about to graduate with a degree in global security, and I could not think of a single person I knew who was serving — nor had the thought even crossed my mind until the question was posed so directly. While public service was featured prominently in my schools and community growing up, and certainly among my peers in college, the thought of service was always relegated to the civilian sphere — Peace Corps, Teach for America, infrastructure projects in South America. Military service, though not portrayed in a negative way, was simply absent from discussions of post-graduation endeavors.

headline: Romney Criticizes Teachers’ Union and Obama
text: Mitt Romney issued a statement Monday criticizing the teachers’ union in Chicago for going on strike, and faulted President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. for their words in support of labor, suggesting that the president has already taken sides in the fight.

headline: Reader Ideas | Teachers and the 9/11 Anniversary
text: Last year, for the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, we asked teachers to share their plans for teaching about it. Ideas poured in, and we published scores of suggestions from disciplines across the curriculum and teachers on every level from early childhood to college.

headline: Sweet Tooth
text: Q. Are there certain sugar substitutes that are as corrosive to dental enamel as sugar?

headline: Why ‘User Friendly’ Is So Friendly: A Tribute to Bill Moggridge
text: Some considered it an inspired choice, others simply surprising, when Bill Moggridge was appointed director of the Smithsonian Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in 2010. The 115-year-old New York institution is a treasure house of decorative objects, from panoramic wallpapers to dessert forks. Mr. Moggridge, who died Saturday at the age of 69,  was an industrial designer who invented the first laptop computer, the Grid Compass, in 1980, and was a founder, in 1991, of the global industrial design company IDEO. A British-born resident of Silicon Valley, with the intellectual curiosity of Nikola Tesla and the affability of Father Christmas, he had investigated the modes through which people manipulate machines, and used this research to pioneer a field known as interaction design.

headline: Public Theater Announces ‘Giant’ Casting
text: Public Theater executives said on Monday that their fall production of the new musical “Giant,” based on Edna Ferber’s epic novel about a powerful Texas ranching family, will star the Tony Award nominees Brian d’Arcy James (“Shrek”) and Kate Baldwin (“Finian’s Rainbow”) as the patriarch Bick Benedict and his wife, Leslie, the roles played in the 1956 movie by Rock Hudson and Elizabeth Taylor.

headline: TimesCast | Sept. 10, 2012
text: Michael Slackman, a deputy foreign editor at The Times, looks at the impact of Syria’s civil war both inside the country and around the Middle East.

headline: Steel-Cut Oats, Sweet and Savory
text: A couple of years ago in the course of touring Bob’s Red Mill, the whole-foods purveyor based in Portland, Ore., I learned a new word: spurtle. A spurtle is a wooden dowel-like implement used to stir oatmeal. They are common in Scotland, where an international porridge-making competition called the Golden Spurtle is held every year in October. There are two sections to the competition: one for plain porridge made with steel-cut oats (also known as pinhead oats) and nothing more than water and salt; and one for specialty porridges, in which the steel-cut oats are used in a dish with other ingredients, sweet or savory.

headline: Science Times Podcast
text: Organic food, a lion invades the suburbs, and seeking medical connections between humans and animals.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Jonny Bauer and Ted Florea were named to new posts at Droga5, New York. Mr. Bauer, head of strategy, becomes chief strategy officer, and Mr. Florea, group strategy director, becomes head of brand planning.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: U-20 World Cup: A Glimpse Into the Future
text: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — I love watching athletes celebrate. It’s that moment of pure joy in accomplishment and extreme relief that the nerves, fatigue and struggle were worth it. Seeing these celebrations gives me chills every time. As the young American women ran to embrace — sweaty braids and ponytails swishing across their faces — they acknowledged the fact that together they had achieved the ultimate feat: being the best in the world at what they do.

headline: Ads for the Standard Are Far From Standard
text: A lodging brand known for being unconventional is taking a particularly offbeat tack with a campaign that seeks to burnish its cool-kid credentials by celebrating the eye-opening — and eyebrow-raising — work of an Austrian artist.

headline: Why Facebook Is Paying the Tax Tab on Employee Compensation
text: Facebook announced last week that it planned to use cash to pay off a $1.9 billion tax bill related to restricted stock units that Facebook had granted to employees over the years. It’s odd timing for a tax bill. Why would Facebook, not the employees, owe tax on compensation income?

text: A recipe for Angus beef slices from the butcher Pat LaFrieda as prepared at Meatopia, the festival of more than 40 chefs and 2,600 carnivores that staged a five-hour invasion of Randalls Island on Saturday evening, undeterred by rain.

text: The Look:  To Each Her Own

headline: Elliott Carter to Join Legion of Honor
text: The composer Elliott Carter, who turns 104 in December and is still composing prolifically, has collected his share of prestigious awards over the decades, among them two Pulitzer Prizes and the National Medal of Honor in the United States, Germany’s Ernst von Siemens Music Prize and the Commander of the Order of Arts and Letters, from France.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Andy Murray Wins U.S. Open
text: Andy Murray won his first Grand Slam title, surviving a mid-match collapse to outlast defending champion Novak Djokovic 7-6 (10), 7-5, 2-6, 3-6, 6-2 in four hours and 54 minutes for the men’s singles championship at the 2012 United States Open.

headline: God and the Troops
text: Mitt Romney has about had it with reporters and politicians asking why he didn’t mention American troops (who are still dying in Afghanistan for a war that he thinks they should be fighting) during his speech at the Republican convention in Tampa.

headline: Driving the Volkswagen Golf GTD
text: The sixth generation of the Volkswagen Golf has been on American roads for three years. That may seem like sufficient time for a vehicle not named Murciélago, Zonda or Veyron to shake off the incredulous gasps and covetous glares of passers-by. But the Golf I drove over Labor Day weekend, painted a Kermit-like shade of green, was on a tourist visa, its German license plate gleaming below its honeycomb grille. The car prompted children to squeal and fanboys to fumble for their camera phones.

headline: Ask a Hostage Negotiator
text: Updated | We are no longer accepting questions.

headline: A 1973 Hostage Situation, Revisited
text: “We know some of you are hurt. We want to help you,” boomed a bullhorn on top of an armored police vehicle. “Please come out with your hands on your heads and you will be treated. There is no place for you to go. The building, the block and the entire area is surrounded.”

headline: The Perfectly Fried Egg
text: José Andrés demonstrates his method for cooking an egg in the kitchen of the International Culinary Center in Manhattan.

headline: Toronto Film Festival: Partying With Ben Affleck and Reactions to ‘The Master,’ ‘Cloud Atlas’ and More
text: TORONTO – The front-loaded schedule at the Toronto International Film Festival  has yielded a few expected payoffs and a few unpredicted ones. Eagerly-awaited movies like Ben Affleck’s “Argo” (which earned good word-of-mouth at a sneak preview at the Telluride Film Festival last month) delivered, earning a standing ovation at its packed premiere on Friday. Reviews called the film, about the Iranian hostage crisis in the 1970s, Mr. Affleck’s coming-of-age moment as an actor-director. At the after-party last week, Mr. Affleck was jovial, ordering pizza and chatting with friends like Matt Damon, John Krasinski and Emily Blunt late into the night. He talked eagerly about shooting at CIA headquarters in Langley, Va., but admitted to some worry that the geo-political theme would make the film “challenging” to market. “I’m working harder to promote this movie,” he said. “I can furnish you with endless” material. (We will expect it.)

headline: Lasker Awards to Honor 7 Scientists
text: The Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation announced on Monday that seven scientists would be honored with the 2012 Lasker Award, one of the world’s most prestigious scientific prizes.

headline: Putting Spain Back in Spanish Food
text: IT seems an impossible dream, if not the one that the Man of La Mancha crooned onstage. But here it goes: Over the next decade, dozens of American cooks schooled in the authentic cooking of Spain and trained in Spanish restaurants will begin to populate the United States. In due time, hundreds, then thousands, will serve up a cuisine that is not Mexican, or Caribbean, or Latin American, but one faithful to Spain. Not only will they staff a national roster of credibly Spanish restaurants, but they will go on to create new ones. Ultimately, that will ramp up American demand for the wine and products of Spain.

headline: Netherlands Encounters Ghosts and Shadows in Budapest
text: Political racists and soccer revolutionaries haunt the clash between Hungary and the Netherlands as the Dutch team arrives in Budapest on Tuesday ready to decide who will top the fledgling Group D table in World Cup qualifying.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee, a Former Hunger Striker, Dies
text: WASHINGTON — A detainee at the American prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, died over the weekend, the United States military announced on Monday.

headline: Really? Using a Computer Before Bed Can Disrupt Sleep

headline: Nation Rich in Land Draws Workers From One Rich in People
text: OSTANINO, Russia — When a Chinese investor bought a farm outside this village a few years back, he was pleased enough to name it Golden Land. The soil was rich, the sunshine and rain bountiful.

headline: Samurai Shopper | High and Dry
text: The Samurai Shopper takes her skin care very seriously, but hair care is barely a blip on the radar. I’m more focused on fighting follicles that bloom outside the scalp zone; when fuzz attacks, I’m already in the lounge chair at Browhaus, 56 Spring Street. The hair on my head simply requires occasional pruning, regular washing and daily brushing. Every so often, though, a hair product comes along that proves noteworthy. Take dry shampoo: apparently I’m the last earthling to discover that dry shampoo does double duty as a waterless cleaning machine and a styling aid. Best of all, the cheap ones are pretty good, even if the good ones are better.

headline: An Empathetic Eye on the Paralympics
text: The first Paralympic Games since 2009, when Emilio Morenatti lost his foot to a roadside bomb in Afghanistan, ended in London on Sunday night. For Mr. Morenatti, who does not consider himself a sports photographer, the Paralympics were a priority, a more personal assignment that better connected him with a community he recently joined.

headline: Fashion Week Stargazing: Days 3 and 4
text: On a sticky Saturday morning, with heavy rain and humidity that turned ponytails into pom poms, the Lacoste show kicked off a long weekend of celebrity sightings.

headline: Walkabout – 9/10: Berlin’s Airport Is Late, and Indian and Pakistan Get Friendlier
text: Worse Than a Plane Delay: the Airport Is Late A look at what the numerous delays in the opening of the Berlin-Brandenburg Willy Brandt Airport mean for Germany. (The New York Times)

headline: Geithner Holds His Own on Triathlon Front
text: Paul D. Ryan may not have finished a marathon quite as fast as he initially recounted. But Timothy F. Geithner can point to a respectable time for his latest triathlon.

headline: Scourge of the Lionfish, Part 3: The Newest Fish in the Kitchen
text: Carl Safina is founder of Blue Ocean Institute at Stony Brook University and a MacArthur Fellow. His books include “A Sea in Flames: The Deepwater Horizon Oil Blowout,” and “The View From Lazy Point; A Natural Year in an Unnatural World,” which won the  2012 Orion Award. His series “Saving the Ocean” will be premiering this fall on PBS television.

headline: Greece Wrestles With Cuts to Unlock Bailout Funds
text: ATHENS — Greek officials had another day of tough negotiations Monday with representatives of its so-called troika of European lenders, trying to agree to an €11 billion package of budget cutting measures that would enable Greece to receive its next allotment of bailout money.

headline: A Crop Dividend: Restored Bird Habitat in New Jersey
text: Farmers and wildlife advocates don’t often see eye to eye; each can look at a field and see widely divergent possibilities. Yet by encouraging farmers to plant fields of flowers, an innovative program in New Jersey is helping to finance the rehabilitation of wildlife areas for endangered species of birds.

headline: Political Hurdles Clog Spain’s Path Out of Debt
text: Don’t expect Mariano Rajoy, the Spanish prime minister, to leap without looking.

headline: No, Nicki Minaj Did Not Endorse Mitt Romney
text: Lest there be any lingering confusion: sometimes performers say things in the context of their work that they do not mean literally – political endorsements included.

headline: Head Injury to Revis Could Leave Jets Vulnerable
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — A newcomer to football whose only exposure to the sport consisted of the Jets’ victory Sunday might have come away convinced that Mark Sanchez is an elite quarterback, better than those Manning fellows; that Austin Howard resembled a young Dan Dierdorf at right tackle; and that a sculptor would be visiting team headquarters this week to survey the rookie receiver Stephen Hill’s facial features — you know, for his Hall of Fame bust.

headline: After Summer of Turmoil, Oxford American Appoints Roger Hodge Editor
text: After enduring weeks of unflattering attention over the firing of its editor, The Oxford American has hired a successor: Roger D. Hodge, a Texas-born editor and veteran of New York media.

headline: Wisconsin Ranks First in Extreme Heat
text: Which state had the most extreme heat this summer? Wisconsin, according to the organization Climate Central.

headline: Chuck Close Makes Art in a Fund-Raiser for Obama
text: Actors aren’t the only stars trying to help the president get elected. Artists are doing their bit, too. In a Talk of the Town piece in this week’s New Yorker, Calvin Tomkins reports that Chuck Close — who made a tapestry based on a larger-than-life size portrait of the president that was on view at the Mint Museum in Charlotte, N.C., throughout the Democratic National Convention — is making other artworks to raise money for the Obama campaign.

headline: Member of Manhattan Political Royalty Celebrates a Birthday
text: It had the feel of a nominating convention, or an Election Day victory party. The big-name Manhattan politicians were there, and so were hundreds of rank-and-file voters. Hundreds of balloons lined the ceiling, the food and drink were free, and a jazz combo belted out “Happy Days Are Here Again.”
