headline: Academy Finds Mixed Climate Impacts on Himalayan Glaciers, Water Supplies
text: Given all the oversimplified assertions over the years about Himalayan glaciers in a warming global climate, it’s great to see a committee assembled by the National Academy of Sciences weigh in on the question with some data-based findings in a new report, “Himalayan Glaciers: Climate Change, Water Resources, and Water Security.” The bottom line — in sync with other recent analysis — is that the region is seeing a mix of changes, with glaciers growing in some places and shrinking in others and impacts on water supplies mostly inconsequential for decades to come. In most regions, monsoon patterns, population and consumption pressures and dependence on groundwater pumping will remain the dominant source of water-related risks, the report concludes. Read on for an excerpt from the news release and link to the full report, followed by related background:

headline: Voting Information: Legislative Primaries
text: Primary elections for the State Legislature and some local offices will be held across New York State on Thursday. The Legislature moved the primary from Tuesday so that voters would not have to go to the polls on the anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: Russian State TV Claims Exiled Tycoon Behind Pussy Riot
text: Update | Friday, 10:00 a.m. MOSCOW — A report broadcast Tuesday on the state-owned Rossiya 1 channel claimed to have found the mastermind behind the Pussy Riot controversy: Boris A. Berezovsky, the exiled Russian tycoon living in London. The second installment of “Provocateurs,” a film by the journalist Arkady Mamontov, suggests that Mr. Berezovsky financed the punk band in order to destabilize Russian society.

headline: TimesCast Tech | September 12, 2012
text: Apple introduces the iPhone 5. | Bionic suits help paraplegics walk again. | Nostalgic apps.

headline: Ryan's Comments on Libya
text: Representative Paul D. Ryan commented on the crisis in Libya at a campaign event on Wednesday in Wisconsin.

headline: Shakespeare and Home Movies With Joss Whedon
text: TORONTO — Introducing his new film at a screening here on Saturday afternoon, the director Joss Whedon had this to say about the source material: “I’m really fond of this writer. I think he’s gonna be big.”

headline: New York Life Commercial
text: An advertising agency working for New York Life has made a new commercial.

headline: M.L.S.: The Shirts on Your Back
text: The various iterations of David Beckham’s Los Angeles Galaxy jersey remain most popular with soccer fans who have made shirt purchases on the MLSgear.com Web sites in the United States and Canada.

headline: TimesCast Tech: The New iPhone
text: Apple introduces the iPhone 5. Also, bionic suits help paraplegics walk again and a look at nostalgic apps.

headline: Crew-Neck Sweaters Are the Look for Men
text: Crew-neck sweaters could be spotted all over this week’s New York fashion shows — that is, on men in the audience.

headline: Professor Suspended Over Colorado Shootings Joke
text: A United States Merchant Marine Academy professor who was facing termination for a joke about the Colorado movie theater shootings has been given a 45-day suspension instead, along with a requirement for five hours of sensitivity training.

headline: A Crew Now Ready for Most Any Job
text: LAST January, as Eric Jennings, the men’s fashion director of Saks Fifth Avenue, watched the models amble down the fall 2012 runways, he realized he had seen a lot of great crew-neck sweaters at houses like Jil Sander and Prada, and he should buy them for Saks.

headline: Somalia’s New President Survives Suicide Bombings
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Three suicide bombers attacked the temporary residence of the new president of Somalia as he was giving a news conference on Wednesday, killing an African Union soldier but failing to assassinate any political leaders, witnesses and officials said.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 12
text: A view of the day in sports, including indoor climbing in Paris and elephant polo in Thailand.

headline: On New Arena’s Big Night, a Rebuttal Down the Street
text: Updated, Sept. 21 |  The organizers of the planned Sept. 28 outdoor screening of “Battle for Brooklyn” have been given final approval to screen the film by the police and the parks department.

headline: Staking a Claim Backstage
text: BUFF security guard. Heavy black curtain. Mingling, angling V.I.P.’s.

headline: Open Season on Politicians at ‘SNL’
text: “Saturday Night Live” returns this weekend to assume its prominent place in the late-night satirical commentariat leading up to another presidential election, and Lorne Michaels has been giving a great deal of thought to who will play which politician this season.

headline: Omnifone Posts Rare Profit in World of Streaming Music
text: How do you make money streaming digital music? One way is to provide the electronic guts that allow other services to operate — and to take the financial risk.

headline: Treasury Backs Plan for Standard Chartered Settlement
text: Lawyers within the Treasury Department have recommended a preliminary settlement with Standard Chartered, clearing the path for the British bank to pay a penalty to state and federal prosecutors and to move beyond claims that it flouted laws governing international money transfers.

headline: Mitt and Bibi: Diplomacy as Demolition Derby
text: It turns out Bibi Netanyahu and Mitt Romney have more in common than a background in management consulting and an unswerving devotion to the security of Israel. When it comes to international diplomacy, we are reminded this week, both have the subtle grace of cattle on loco weed.

headline: Medvedev Says Rockers Have Served Enough Jail Time for Cathedral Performance
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev said Wednesday that he believed that three female punk rockers jailed for a profane stunt in Moscow’s main Russian Orthodox cathedral should be released rather than serve out their two-year sentences, weighing in on a case that has drawn widespread condemnation in the West.

headline: Homes for $1.2 Million
text: Properties in Vermont, Illinois and Northern California.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.2 Million
text: CAMBRIDGE, VT.

headline: A New Blog: Booming
text: An online destination aims to capture the voice of the baby boomers.

headline: Buffett Cup in Omaha
text: At the fourth Buffett Cup in Omaha, after the pair and team events, Europe leads the United States by 70 points to 62. So there is all to play for in the 66-board individual on Wednesday and Thursday, in which every player partners each teammate for six deals. The United States won the pairs by 36 points to 24. But Europe rebounded in the teams, taking it by 46 to 26.

headline: Rachel Zoe and Reality
text: There was a baby Skyler sighting in the front row of the über-stylist Rachel Zoe’s runway show, but he got a little fussy and had to be removed. Otherwise, things looked more or less like any other runway show, rather than a reality spectacle.

headline: The Well Quiz: Cutting Health Costs
text: This week, the Institute of Medicine issued a new report documenting the waste and misuse that is rampant in the American health care system. The good news is that there is a lot of room for improvement.

headline: Exclusive: For One Raiders Fan, the Pain Continues
text: A few weeks ago, Steve Almond wrote a Riff essay about the torment of being a life-long fan of a perennially incompetent sports team: in his case, the Oakland Raiders. In the essay, he wrote of the (then-forthcoming) season opener for the Raiders: “There is no doubt in my mind that they will lose in some new and innovative fashion,” which, it turns out, they did. Here, in a 6th Floor exclusive, Almond records his feelings following that opening game:

headline: A Georgian Manor House in County Laois, Ireland
text: A nine-bedroom home on 30 acres was built about 200 years ago on the outskirts of the village of Durrow.

headline: House Hunting in ... Ireland
text: NINE-BEDROOM GEORGIAN MANOR HOUSE ON 30 ACRES IN COUNTY LAOIS, IRELAND

headline: Jeremy Scott: Spring 2013 RTW
text: New York

headline: Ryan Says Obama Leaks Led to Doctor’s Sentence
text: ASHWAUBENON, Wis. — Representative Paul D. Ryan accused the White House on Wednesday of leaking information that led to a 33-year prison sentence for a Pakistani doctor who helped American intelligence locate Osama bin Laden.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Softens Her Image in New Ad
text: Elizabeth Warren’s campaign released a new television commercial on Wednesday,  just as some of her supporters have expressed unhappiness with her ad campaign.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Washington, Libya, Tunisia and Pakistan.

headline: An iPhone 5 Case Arrives Before the iPhone 5
text: Before the announcement of the new iPhone 5 was made, the first protective case for the 5 arrived on my desk. I also got a news release promising me that another case was available as well.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: An Artist Who Delineated the Money
text: The intricate Conceptualist drawings of Mark Lombardi attempted to map the vast, convoluted networks of money and power behind the likes of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International scandal or the Iran-contra affair. One begins to wish for a similar explication of Mr. Lombardi and his work during Mareike Wegener’s frustratingly self-evident documentary, “Mark Lombardi: Death-Defying Acts of Art and Conspiracy.”

headline: Lang College Offers Academic Credit for Taking a Gap Year
text: Sometimes, after a hectic high school experience overshadowed by a competitive — or perhaps, disappointing — college admissions process, seniors just need a break.

headline: Murder in Benghazi
text: Libya and its pro-democracy revolution had no better friend than J. Christopher Stevens, the United States ambassador who was killed along with three other Americans in Tuesday’s attack on the consulate in Benghazi. It was an outrageous act that deserved the strongest condemnation.

headline: Rachel Zoe: Spring 2013 RTW
text: New York

headline: Matchbox Twenty Tops Album Chart
text: Matchbox Twenty has reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for the first time with “North” (Atlantic), its first studio record in a decade. “North” sold 95,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and leads a handful of high-charting new titles as the music industry begins releasing its fall albums. Imagine Dragons, an alternative-rock band from Las Vegas, is No. 2, with 83,000 sales of “Night Visions” (Interscope), its first full-length album. The Christian rapper Lecrae is No. 3, with “Gravity” (Reach), which sold 72,000 copies. Last week’s No. 1, “Eye on It” (ForeFront), by another Christian rapper, TobyMac, fell to No. 8 in its second week out, with 26,000 sales. Cat Power opened at No. 10 with 23,000 sales of “Sun” (Matador).

headline: The iPhone 5: My First Impressions
text: Apple unveiled the new iPhone 5 today in San Francisco. As it turns out, most of the individual rumors about it were true — but even so, they didn’t describe the whole package.

headline: Take This Job and Obsess About It (Sing, Too)
text: Adam Szymkowicz’s office comedy “The Why Overhead” has some genuinely funny moments and an odd sensibility. It’s a decent play that pushes against its own boundaries with varying success.

headline: D.J.’s Stretch Out and Find More Fans
text: When the police showed up at the Fool’s Gold Day Off party this month, it wasn’t completely clear why. Sure, the lines for the event, held in an empty lot behind City Winery, in TriBeCa, had been long for much of the afternoon, but not evidently rowdy. There were some loose cannons: at least one person climbed a 20-foot-high fence and jumped over, only to get netted by security and removed.

headline: Long-Forgotten Picasso Is a Museum’s Windfall
text: When Arlan Ettinger, the president of Guernsey’s auction house in New York, first called the Evansville Museum of Arts, History and Science back in February to ask about a layered glass mosaic by Picasso that he had traced to the museum, officials there said, in effect, “Sorry, wrong number.” They had never heard of it.

headline: Pop Striver From Britain Arrives for a Debut in Full Regalia
text: The search for the next Adele is a full-time quest in the British — and worldwide — music business. That would be a singer steeped in American soul music, a songwriter who touches on pop universals and is retro enough to draw grown-up listeners, a charmingly uninhibited stage personality, a fashion-conscious entertainer and an unambivalently ambitious trouper.

headline: A Challenger’s Criticism Is Furiously Returned
text: WASHINGTON — The deadly attack on an American diplomatic post in Libya propelled foreign policy to the forefront of an otherwise inward-looking presidential campaign and presented an unexpected test not only to the incumbent, who must manage an international crisis, but also to the challenger, whose response quickly came under fire.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Inside Foxconn, and Technology’s Limits
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Combining Taped Voices From 9/11 and Live Strings
text: When a composer takes up the theme of unthinkable man-made tragedy as the impetus for a new piece, what is the proper tone to adopt? Richard Strauss, responding to the World War II bombing of Munich with “Metamorphosen,” fashioned a lament not only for a city but also for a culture vanished in violence and guilt. John Adams, asked to imagine a response to the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, produced “On the Transmigration of Souls,” a complex, contemplative work that used personal mementos as a springboard to transcendental concerns.

headline: Fashion Week Street Style Is Often a Billboard for Brands
text: Was it only a couple of years ago that these showily outfitted swans — stylists, bloggers and fashion editors — click-clacked on the pavements in what used to be seen as a commerce-free zone?

headline: Decades Later, a Vision Survives
text: The park — a memorial to Franklin Delano Roosevelt — was conceived four decades ago. The visionary architect who designed it died in 1974. The site, a landfill along one of the more dramatic stretches of waterfront in New York City, remained a rubble heap while the project was left for dead.

headline: Of Chryslers, Fashion Plates and Beards: ZZ Top Introduces 300C John Varvatos Limited Edition
text: Whether by positioning Eminem behind the wheel of a 200, Clint Eastwood in a dank, dimly lighted tunnel or Jennifer Lopez in an imaginary Bronx, Chrysler has strove to associate itself with totems of popular culture since emerging from bankruptcy in 2009. That impulse was given full rein on Tuesday night in SoHo when the automaker organized a meeting of ZZ Top, Jack Daniels, John Varvatos and GQ magazine under one roof.

headline: Update: The Times Denies State Department Request to Remove Photo From Web Site
text: The State Department asked The New York Times on Wednesday afternoon to remove a photograph of the dying ambassador to Libya from a gallery on the newspaper’s Web site. The ambassador, J. Christopher Stevens, was killed Tuesday in an attack on the American Consulate in Libya.

headline: Who Am I Wearing? Funny You Should Ask.
text: PIVOTING smartly, a hand on her hip, the better to show off her pipette jeans, Laura Ellner seemed the incarnation of street style. As she posed at Lincoln Center Plaza on Day 1 of New York Fashion Week last Thursday, a brace of cameras clicked and whirred, each competing to catch her performance.

headline: A Closer Look at Four Freedoms Park
text: Images of Louis Kahn’s memorial on Roosevelt Island.

headline: J. Mendel: Spring 2013 RTW
text: New York

headline: Democrats Apologize for Image of Russian Ships at Convention
text: On full display in all the pageantry of the Democratic National Convention as veterans gathered onstage last week was an odd backdrop: an image of the Russian naval fleet. And for this, convention planners have now apologized.

headline: A Vreeland Library
text: Why don’t you ... buy any number of books about Diana Vreeland for a fashionista in your life?

headline: The Daily Shoe | Reed Krakoff
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Mapping a Path to Vreelandia
text: YOU might think that dating a grandson of Diana Vreeland would lead to scintillating dinner conversation, especially if he and you both work in the fashion industry. But according to Lisa Immordino Vreeland, who did just that and went on to marry him, the late, legendary editor hardly loomed over their relationship.

headline: Yankees Go West for 2013 Interleague Play
text: BOSTON — The Yankees’ preliminary schedule for 2013 was released Wednesday, and it features several interesting new twists.

headline: ATP Adopts Rules Changes to Address Pace of Play
text: The ATP Board of Directors announced two rule changes Wednesday that would allow for the quickening of matches, a growing priority given the consistently increasing length of matches on the men’s tour.

headline: In Fruitland, Wash., Where Dreams Began
text: A tour of Donnie and Joe Emerson’s home studio and farm after the recent cult success of their 1979 album.

headline: Off the Runway: Day 7
text: Scenes from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Census Bureau Chart and Report on Income Change and Poverty
text: Poverty leveled off but median household income lowered between 2010 and 2011.

headline: A Time Capsule Set to Song
text: FRUITLAND, Wash.

headline: Old Standbys, New Stand-Ins
text: EVEN through the latest cloud of glitter dust backstage at Fashion Week one can see a handful of beauty products, some on the market for over a century, that continue to pop up again and again. Herein, makeup artists weigh in on why these classics have never gone out of style, whether they deserve the reputation and which newer items are qualified to unseat them.

headline: Photographer and Subject
text: Images from a new retrospective of the artist Carrie Mae Weems.

headline: Photographer and Subject Are One
text: WHEN Carrie Mae Weems was first teaching photography in the late 1980s at Hampshire College in Massachusetts, she was struck by the difference in how her male and female students presented themselves in pictures. “The women were always turning away from the camera, always in profile,” said Ms. Weems, demonstrating by obscuring her face seductively with her graceful hands. “They never squared themselves. The boys were squaring themselves.”

headline: The Cult of Disappearing Design
text: THE first thing you see when you walk into Patrick McInerney’s living room is that there’s nothing to see. The walls are bare, and ditto for the ceiling. You try to switch on the lights, but there doesn’t appear to be a switch. There’s music playing, but where is it coming from? The lamp is obviously working — the bulb is lighted, after all — but it seems to be plugged into ... the plaster?

headline: A Disappearing Act
text: A sampling of furniture and accessories that embrace the all-invisible aesthetic.

headline: Tell the Dishwasher to Be Quiet
text: AN appliance may be hidden from the eyes, but that doesn’t mean it escapes notice entirely. Manufacturers of household machinery are also taking heed of the demand for quiet.

headline: A Sound System as Resonant as a Concert Hall
text: Chances are, your sound system isn’t very good at math. It would sound a lot better if you could make it a little smarter, and you can.

headline: In 2013, Mets Open at Home and Host All-Star Game
text: Mets fans looking toward next season may be pleased to hear that Major League Baseball has released its 2013 schedule. The Mets will get a fresh start on April 1, when they open the season at home against the San Diego Padres.

headline: Reported Handwritten Union Proposal
text: Chicago Public Schools said this handwritten page of notes was the only proposal the Chicago Teachers Union had placed in writing during talks so far.

headline: After ‘Today’ Criticism, NBC News Chief Apologies to Affiliates
text: As it promised, NBC did not apologize on the air Wednesday for its decision not to observe a moment of silence during the “Today” show on Sept. 11.

headline: Hiding in Plain Sight
text: ASPEN, Colo.

headline: Vanishing Into Nature
text: This five-level house in Aspen, Colo., allows the brilliant landscape to take center stage.

headline: Staten Island Pond Produces an Unexpected Catch
text: Kaitlyn Crabbe, 11, was fishing for sunfish and catfish last week at Brooks Pond in Clove Lakes Park in Staten Island when she hooked into something ferocious.

headline: Shopping for Mirrored Accessories
text: The designer Miles Redd shopped for mirrored objects that introduce the right amount of reflection to an interior.

headline: Abercrombie Hires Goldman
text: Abercrombie & Fitch has retained Goldman Sachs as an adviser as the troubled clothier assesses potential responses to moves by one of its investors, the activist hedge fund Relational Investors, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Mirrored Accessories
text: TEN years ago, the designer Miles Redd spotted an entire bath and dressing room at a salvage warehouse in Chicago. And it wasn’t just any bathroom: it was from the home of the banker Lester Armour and had been designed by the architect David Adler, with interiors by Mr. Adler’s sister, Frances Elkins. It was also almost completely mirrored.

headline: Reed Krakoff: Spring 2013 RTW
text: New York

headline: Why The Vileness Matters
text: I haven’t weighed in on Romney’s awesomely awful intervention on events in Egypt and Libya; with even Republicans joining in the chorus of shocked disapproval, not much I can add.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. I own a historic home that has its original windows. Should I replace them with insulated windows to save energy or keep the originals for their aesthetic value?

headline: Nate Berkus on Writing the Story of a Home
text: The interior designer Nate Berkus first appeared on the national scene in 2002 as a guest on “Oprah.” He was such a hit with the audience and the star that he became the show’s featured design expert. Since then, his career has boomed. He has written a book, “Home Rules: Transform the Place You Live Into a Place You’ll Love,” and starred in his own television program, “The Nate Berkus Show,” which ended this spring. In October, Mr. Berkus, 40, will have two major introductions: a 150-piece collection of furnishings for Target, and a new book, “The Things That Matter” (Spiegel & Grau, $35). Speaking from his office in Chicago (he has another in New York), he spilled details about both projects.

headline: Lawmakers Delay Plans to Increase Oversight of Regulators
text: Lawmakers postponed plans to advance a bill that could curb the influence of Wall Street regulators, a move that came as some federal officials mounted opposition to the effort.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Michael Kors
text: The Look: Sharp Lines.

headline: Feeding Believers and Doubters Alike
text: Manners dictate that one avoids politics at mixed partisan gatherings, but if you are determined to annoy certain family members, what better gift than the Obama Birth Certificate dish, which arrives today at the Manhattan housewares store Fishs Eddy? At $19.95, it’s not excessively expensive (though admit it, you’d spend a lot more to zetz Uncle Frank), and at 8 by 7 inches, it’s not so big that when Uncle Frank slams it down on your head he’ll be able to do any real damage. And if you’re thinking that it represents a point of view of the store’s owners, you’re right.

headline: Mixing Man’s Work With Nature’s
text: The Italian designer Andrea Branzi, 73, has been integrating rocks and trees into household objects for some 30 years. His Animali Domestici collection from 1985 featured laminate chairs with backrests of raw birch. A decade later, he hollowed containers out of stones and lumps of wood.

headline: A Ghostly Glow in Paper and Steel
text: Harry Allen deals in twisted household archetypes. The New York-based designer’s ongoing Reality series includes a fruit bowl cast from a bunch of bananas, a coat hook shaped like a hand and a roller skate playing the role of door stop. For his latest project, Paperwork lanterns for Hive, he has transformed an old barn lantern into a ghostly light fixture. “It’s humble, like a found object,” Mr. Allen said. Cast in papier-mâché and mounted on black or chromed steel, the collection includes a table lamp, floor lamp and chandelier, all designed to hang from hooks attached to an armature. The lights are illuminated with LED bulbs. A single lantern measures 15 ½ inches high, 9 5/8 inches wide and 4 ¾ inches deep, and costs $350. Information: (888) 889-9005 or designbyhive.com.

headline: Designer Seating Made of Recyclables
text: Jean Nouvel, one of a handful of marquee architects who also design noteworthy furniture, has collaborated with Emeco, the Pennsylvania-based manufacturer of high-design seating, on the So So collection of chairs and stools.

headline: Sales at Molla Space, Property, Jensen-Lewis and Others
text: Molla Space is taking up to 60 percent off some accessories, while supplies last (the Printing Vase bottle cover, shown, usually $26, is about $10); (888) 665-5277, mollaspace.com.

headline: Travel Day Tomorrow
text: Also, I have a nasty cold — the perfect combination. Expect few if any posts.

headline: When You Want to Say That’s How to Dress
text: Fashion Week has been a lavish rat race, an incredible assault on the nerves, with people rushing down to Chelsea, up to Lincoln Center, back to Chelsea while being bombarded by aimless weirdos with cameras and clothes you can’t forget fast enough.

headline: Pettitte Stays on Track for Return
text: BOSTON — No sooner was Bobby Valentine asked about the challenge posed by Andy Pettitte’s impending return to the Yankees than he was asked a follow-up question about Roger Clemens and his comeback in independent minor league baseball.

headline: Punk Merged With Quirky Decoration
text: Long story short: “I kind of linked up Madeleine Castaing with punk,” Anna Sui said of her spring collection shown Wednesday night.

text: San Francisco

headline: A Sugar High?
text: Democrats are riding a wave of enthusiasm. Republicans are dreading a Romney wipeout.

headline: The Country Beckons Spaniards as Jobs in Cities Grow Scarce
text: VILLANUEVA DE LA VERA, Spain — A chemist by training, Silvia Barcenilla searched for a job in Madrid for almost a year. But in March, she decided to try a different approach, moving here to the village of Villanueva de la Vera, a two-and-a-half-hour drive to the west.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 31
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: Board of Education Proposal
text: A proposal from the Chicago board outlines measures to achieve a new contract and end the teachers’ strike in public schools across the city.

headline: The Girl Wonder of Golf
text: HOYLAKE, England — The golf prodigy Lydia Ko was asked how she would cope with being the youngest competitor this week at the Women’s British Open, which was like asking Sean Lennon how he deals with being the son of a Beatle. The 15-year-old Ko knows no different.

headline: The Old Dependable Is Depended Upon Once Again
text: A NEW campaign for New York Life, from its new creative agency, expresses an idea that is tried and true.

headline: Denouncing City’s Move to Regulate Circumcision
text: The grandmother carried the sleeping infant boy on a white pillow toward the synagogue’s altar, and passed him to her son. Her son carried the infant toward the mohel, or Jewish ritual circumciser, who stood amid a cluster of chanting men.

headline: 23 Years After Soccer Tragedy, an Apology and a Shift in Blame
text: LONDON — Nearly a quarter of a century after 96 Liverpool soccer fans were crushed to death in one of the worst stadium disasters in history, Prime Minister David Cameron formally apologized on Wednesday to the victims’ families, saying their “appalling deaths” were compounded by an attempt by the police, investigators and the news media to depict the victims as hooligans and to blame them for the disaster.

headline: Through Primaries, Embattled Assemblyman Seeks to Shore Up Clout
text: Vito J. Lopez may be preparing for his last hurrah as Brooklyn’s pre-eminent power broker.

headline: Fewer Uninsured People
text: The number of Americans who lack health insurance declined last year, the first drop since 2007. This is, in large part, the result of the health care reform law and better coverage under public programs like Medicaid. This also shows why repealing the health care law or revamping and shrinking Medicaid, as many Republicans want to do, would be disastrous moves.

headline: My Map of New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pennsylvania’s Bad Election Law
text: On Thursday, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court is scheduled to hear arguments about the state’s strict new photo ID law, which is allegedly intended to prevent voter fraud. A voter must present a government-issued or other approved photo ID at a polling place to vote or can file a provisional ballot, which must be validated later by a submission of a photo ID or proof that the voter is indigent.

headline: Is ‘Bundled’ Medical Care a Good Idea?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Vote Thursday in New York
text: With a low turnout expected, voters have a chance to make a big difference in Thursday’s primary elections for judgeships and state legislative seats in New York City. Here are our endorsements in some judicial races and in a few heavily Democratic legislative districts, where a victory in the primary would be tantamount to election. Polls are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

headline: Lessons in the Chicago Teachers’ Strike
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Ban on Flavored Tobacco Products
text: To the Editor:

headline: 18 Are Arrested in Theft of Tiny Liquor Bottles
text: The question is no doubt asked about minibars in hotel rooms across the world: If just one of those tiny liquor bottles were to go missing, would anyone notice?

headline: Design Thrills Apple’s Partners, but Will Cost Users
text: The iPhone 5 has plenty of new features to keep Apple fans happy. But there is one feature Apple unveiled on Wednesday that is likely to annoy many: a new connector on the phone’s base.

headline: New Features for iPhone 5
text: While Apple has been reluctant in the past to radically alter its smartphone, the new iPhone 5 has several significant design changes.

headline: Reports Say Calhoun Is Retiring as Coach
text: Jim Calhoun — a three-time national champion, a three-time cancer survivor and a renowned coach whose verve and talent turned a mainly regional program into a national college basketball powerhouse — will retire Thursday as Connecticut’s coach, according to multiple news media reports.

headline: State Comptroller Office Wrote Part of Lopez Settlement, Documents Show
text: ALBANY — The office of the state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, wrote portions of a controversial sexual harassment settlement involving a prominent assemblyman, according to documents the office released on Wednesday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Obama Grows More Reliant on Big-Money Contributors
text: Kirk Wagar, a Florida lawyer who has raised more than $1 million for President Obama’s re-election bid, had his choice of rooms for the Democratic convention at Charlotte’s Ritz-Carlton or Westin hotels and nightly access to hospitality suites off the convention floor.

headline: Marchesa: Spring 2013 RTW
text: New York

headline: Clinton Sticks to Domestic Issues While Campaigning for Obama
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — On a rare day when both parties were focused on foreign affairs after the explosion of anti-American tumult in North Africa, former President Bill Clinton stuck to domestic issues of the economy and middle-class struggles on Wednesday as he continued his roadshow to re-elect President Obama.

headline: Does Mideast Democracy Complicate Diplomacy?
text: Can  the United States stay engaged with modern democratic Middle Eastern countries that have sizable anti-Western populations?

headline: Offers Rejected as Players Ponder Europe as Option
text: The N.H.L. on Wednesday continued to move toward its third lockout in 17 years, with each side offering a new proposal that the other called insignificant.

headline: Off-Duty Police Officer Stabbed by Intruder
text: An off-duty police officer was stabbed Wednesday afternoon by a knife-wielding man who apparently forced his way into the officer’s second-floor apartment in Jamaica, Queens, the police said.

headline: Opportunity Knocks at Death’s Door
text: “Just hear me out.” This innocuous phrase, spoken by one young Irishwoman to another, betokens another painful turn of the screw in “Fly Me to the Moon,” a dark comedy written and directed by Marie Jones that opened Tuesday night at 59E59 Theaters as part of the 1st Irish festival. When Francis (Katie Tumelty) turns to her fellow caregiver Loretta (Tara Lynne O’Neill) and utters those four imploring words, chances are that both are going to find themselves drifting ever closer to calamity.

text: Portland, Ore., which never fluoridated its water supply and over time earned the distinction as the biggest city in the country to just say no, reversed course on Wednesday with a unanimous vote by the City Council to add fluoride beginning in early 2014.

headline: Deal on a Farm Bill Appears Unlikely
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional agreement on a stalled farm bill seemed increasingly out of reach on Wednesday, as a few hundred farmers gathered near the Capitol to press for its passage. They were greeted by an unusually bipartisan group of lawmakers pushing for action in the House, where Republican leaders have declined to pursue legislation.

headline: Ryan Plays Up Wisconsin Pride as Obama TV Ads Begin in State

headline: Eli Zborowski, 86, Leader in Holocaust Remembrance, Dies
text: Eli Zborowski, a survivor of the Holocaust who made it his mission to ensure that it would never be forgotten, founded an American organization to support Israel’s official Holocaust memorial and raised more than $100 million for it, died on Monday in Queens. He was 86.

headline: After Mistakenly Purging Citizens, Florida Agrees to Let Them Vote
text: MIAMI — In a partial victory for voter rights and immigrant groups, Florida residents who were mistakenly removed from the voter rolls this year because the state classified them as noncitizens will be returned to the rolls and allowed to vote in November.

headline: Struggle for Ideological Upper Hand in Muslim World Seen as Factor in Attacks

headline: Missteps Don’t Become Stumbles
text: BOSTON — The Yankees have been sitting precariously atop the American League East standings for a week. One misstep could cast them into second place for the first time in three months. That misstep appeared to have cropped up Wednesday night when Derek Jeter landed awkwardly on first base while trying to beat out a double play ball in the eighth inning.

headline: Spotlight Is on Libya, but Bigger Challenge for White House May Lie in Egypt

headline: France: New Leader Is Named for the Socialist Party
text: Harlem Désir, a member of the European Parliament and former leader of an antiracism organization, was designated Wednesday as the next leader of France’s governing Socialist Party, replacing Martine Aubry, who is stepping down. Mr. Désir, 52, is an Aubry ally and replaced her as interim party leader when she ran unsuccessfully for the party presidential nomination. She and Prime Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault nominated Mr. Désir; next month’s party vote on the nomination is considered a formality.

headline: Young Children’s Deaths Said to Drop Again in 2011
text: Fewer than seven million children around the world died before their fifth birthday from disease and birth complications in 2011 — a new low — the World Health Organization, the United Nations Children’s Fund and other agencies announced Wednesday. About 12 million children that age died in 1990, and the number fell below 10 million for the first time in 2007, so the pace of saving children’s lives is accelerating, experts said. Half of all the deaths occurred in five countries: India, Nigeria, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Pakistan and China. The leading causes, in descending order, were pneumonia, premature birth, diarrhea, birth complications and malaria. Most of those deaths were preventable with relatively cheap interventions, the United Nations agencies said.

headline: Quality Defense a Key to U.S. Victory
text: Of all the positives coming out of the United States’ 1-0 victory over Jamaica in Tuesday’s World Cup qualifier in Columbus, Ohio — the way the Americans  dominated the first half, Danny Williams’s quality showing, another strrong match from Geoff Cameron, Graham Zusi’s solid performance, the number of chances the team created, Herculez Gomez’s free kick for the game’s only goal — perhaps one has been overlooked: the confident and strong play on defense.

headline: Must All U.S. Embassies Now Be Fortresses?

The attacks this week on the consulate in Benghazi, Libya, and the embassy in Cairo almost require a review of how U.S. diplomatic facilities are sited, designed, built and guarded.

headline: Delhi Don’ts: High Heels in Khan Market
text: Khan Market looks like many other outdoor markets in Delhi – a crowded inner lane, uneven pavement, spontaneous potholes and an occasional pile of garbage or stray dog. Like the others, this U-shaped market is not the easiest to navigate, but many of its patrons wouldn’t dream of shopping there without the “right” footwear – high, high heels.

headline: A Farewell to India’s Milkman
text: My latest column is an inadequate eulogy to one of the most useful Indian men ever, Verghese Kurien, who died this week. Mr. Kurien, who helped make India into the world’s leading milk producer, was among a generation of extraordinary social revolutionaries who are the proof that sometimes some Indian politicians do fully back good people and give them complete freedom.

headline: Boomers vs. Millennials: Who’s Really Getting Robbed?
text: The only way to save America’s children is to lock up the baby boomers. We are robbing the next generation’s future.

headline: Looking Toward Retirement
text: In case you missed the special retirement section on Wednesday, it’s worth having a look, particularly if you’re a boomer heading that way. It’ll give you a lot to think about. Paul Sullivan has a more than a little worrisome story on how hard it is for retirees to rely on Social Security alone, “The Tightwire Act of Living Only on Social Security.” The numbers are not on our side.

headline: Getting Back to Work
text: While the unemployment rate for baby boomers is lower than for younger workers, once boomers lose a job, it takes them longer to find a new one.

headline: Mellow Drinks in a Surprising Neighborhood
text: Unless you live there, the East Village is usually not the first neighborhood that comes to mind when you want a drink after work. The East Village is where your kids go with their friends — or where they rent an apartment (also with their friends).

headline: Welcome to Your Living Room, Boomers
text: This isn’t the best thing to admit, but the term “baby boomer” makes me a little queasy. In my mind it conjures images of 65-year-old hippies skipping through meadows on their way to the local Social Security office.

headline: If Football Is So Dangerous to Players, Should We Be Watching It?
text: Devon Walker, a Tulane University football player, broke his neck last weekend while making a tackle during a game. Three days earlier the journal Neurology reported that football players are three to four times more likely than the rest of us to die from brain diseases. If football, America’s most popular spectator sport, is inherently dangerous to players, should we be watching it?

headline: Why Can’t I Read This AARP Bulletin?
text: Your arms can push that book only so far away before you have to admit there is a problem, and it isn’t with your arms: it is with your eyes. It’s called presbyopia, and let’s not sugarcoat it. “That’s a Greek word for old eyes,” said Dr. James J. Salz, a Los Angeles ophthalmologist.

headline: Baby Boomers Who Celebrate Birthdays This Week
text: Baby boomers are aging gracelessly. It’s exhausting listening to us. How many times have you heard a boomer say, “I can’t believe I’m this old” — as if we are the first people in the history of the planet to turn 58. According to the Yankelovich research firm, the average boomer thinks old age begins at 79. Since average life expectancy is 77, this means boomers believe that first they will die, then they will get old.

headline: For Better, for Worse, Couples Who Endure
text: In Tom Brokaw’s best seller “The Greatest Generation,” he makes the case that the men and women who survived the Depression and led America to victory in World War II — the baby boomers’ parents and grandparents — made a contribution to this country like no other in history. Among the many reasons he cites is their commitment to family. Only one in six of their marriages ended in divorce; for the boomers it has been one in two.

headline: I’m Not Getting Any Better
text: I’m turning 58 next month, and the birthday present I’m giving myself is to call a halt to all of my efforts at self-improvement. I’m done trying to better myself. This is as good as I’m going to get. From now on, the goal is to try to hang on to what I’ve got.

headline: Introducing the Latin Euro

headline: A Long View of Afghanistan’s Wars
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — One of the most troubling things about the national conversation about Afghanistan is that it tends to focus almost solely on the decade since the 2001 American-led invasion. Perhaps this is understandable, since the Afghan conflict marks the longest stretch of time that the United States has actively been at war. And as always, the latest crisis­, any of them, dominates attention: the growing threat posed by Afghan forces who kill their NATO colleagues, the unwillingness of Pakistan to stop sheltering militants who carry out attacks in Kabul, the plague of official corruption that undermines Western trust and the Afghan public’s support.

headline: The Early Word: Fallout

But Mr. Romney’s attempt to use the event to draw a contrast with Mr. Obama on foreign policy started a confrontation that landed him on the defensive and drew attention away from questions about Mr. Obama’s handling of uprisings in the Arab world.

headline: Searching U.S. Colleges, Doubt Creeps In Amid the Confidence

My school did not offer much in that subject, so I spent my time building Web sites and silly apps on Visual Basic, and exploring random software. In high school, when I could finally take programming classes, I fell in love with programming. It was the perfect mix between art and science. I knew just what I wanted to do.

headline: Silent Echoes
text: It’s the rare campaign skirmish that barely makes a splash. headline: Tip of the Week: Photos in Full Screen View
text: The ability to see photos in full-screen mode on the computer cuts down background distraction from icons cluttering the desktop. In Windows, when you open a photo in Windows Explorer, press the F11 key on the keyboard to expand the picture to the full screen. If it does not work, the manufacturer may have modified the keyboard function; try pressing the Function key and F11 or check the computer’s manual.

headline: Instruments of Young Dreams

We were staring at a diagram on a piece of paper I had handed to Hank Lentfer, a lifelong Alaskan and longtime resident of the tiny town of Gustavus.

headline: Balanchine’s Enduring Pact With Stravinsky
text: FOR over a hundred years now the music of Igor Stravinsky has been central to ballet. In 1909, while still a virtual unknown, he orchestrated a Chopin number for the ballet “Les Sylphides” as part of the opening season of Diaghilev’s Ballets Russes. The next year Diaghilev presented the premiere of “The Firebird” with Stravinsky’s new score. The 20th century certainly spawned modernist composers, but none of them matched his profound instinct for dance rhythm; and none kept on so restlessly unlocking aspects of the new.

headline: Sept. 16 — 22
text: The weekend-long festivals by the London promoter All Tomorrow’s Parties have often been in faded vacation spots — English holiday camps and their counterparts in the Catskills and Atlantic City. As musical experiences the American events have been blissful but not boffo; costs ran high and attendance ran low. So the company is trying a new model with ALL TOMORROW’S PARTIES AMERICA PRESENTS I’LL BE YOUR MIRROR  — nearly 40 acts across three days at Pier 36, an entertainment complex on the Lower East Side. Frank Ocean, the R&B man of the hour, headlines on Friday, after a day including the comedian Hannibal Buress, a collaboration between Tyondai Braxton and Philip Glass, and Lee Ranaldo’s “Hanging Guitar” project, involving suspended, swinging Fender Jaguars. The reunited Afghan Whigs headline next Saturday, and other bands that day include the Roots, José González, Dirty Three and Chavez; for next Sunday the organizers have a slate including Godspeed You! Black Emperor, along with the Make-Up, the Washington punk-soul band, in reunited form. 5 p.m. to 1 a.m. Friday; noon to 1 a.m. next Saturday and Sunday; South and Montgomery Streets; atpfestival.com; $60 to $199.

headline: Cambodia’s Most Unwanted
text: PHNOM PENH — The municipal council recently hung a neon sign across Sisowath Quay, on the capital’s popular riverfront. “Phnom Penh — The Charming City,” it boasted.

headline: Kids Draw the News: Peacock on the Loose
text: The escape and capture of Kevin, a peacock kept by John Bowne High School in Queens, is the subject of drawings submitted by children.

headline: The Death of a ‘Butterfly’ in Kabul
text: Parwana means butterfly in Dari, and that is exactly what she was, fluttering around the grit and gloom of the green zone. She was killed last week, along with several other children, as they tried to call attention to a suicide bomber a few blocks from my house in Kabul. They were killed in part because I and so many well-meaning people drew them to a place where we could not keep them safe.

headline: Fresh Hopes for End to Chicago Teacher Strike by Weekend
text: CHICAGO — Meeting behind closed doors into the evening, leaders on both sides of this city’s teacher strike voiced optimism on Thursday that a deal could soon be reached, bringing an end to a walkout that has halted classes for 350,000 students in the nation’s third-largest school system.

headline: Daily Report: An iPhone Tweak That Could Cost You
text: The iPhone 5 has plenty of new features to keep Apple fans happy. But as Brian X. Chen reports in Thursday’s New York Times, there is one feature Apple unveiled on Wednesday that is likely to annoy many: a new connector on the phone’s base.

headline: Do Romney’s Budget Pledges Threaten S.B.A. Loans?
text: Should Mitt Romney become president next year, he will face a difficult question pitting his eagerness to help small businesses against his eagerness to shrink the government: What to do with the Small Business Administration?

headline: There Will Be Megalomania
text: “The Master,” Paul Thomas Anderson’s imposing, confounding and altogether amazing new film, is partly concerned with the life and work of one Lancaster Dodd, leader of a therapeutic, quasi-religious cult known as the Cause. Dodd’s “process,” a stew of Freud, hypnosis and carnival sideshow mumbo-jumbo, is based on a kind of mental time travel. The subject is led, by a series of pointed, painful questions, on a search for past trauma — earlier in life, before birth, in a previous existence — that can be identified as the source of negative emotion and destructive behavior in the present.

headline: Kids Draw the News: Tornadoes in New York

headline: Checking Social Security Benefits Online
text: 12:52 p.m. | Updated  To add how much higher benefits would be at age 70 than at age 62.

headline: At Apple Event, With Secrets Spilled, No Surprises
text: One of the big surprises at Wednesday’s Apple Event was the lack of surprises.

headline: The Label Says Organic — But Is It?
text: Business Day Live: California ballot initiative has national implications for food labels. | Standard Chartered prepares to settle in money laundering case. | Controversy over movie about Nina Simone.

headline: At UConn, It’s Time to Go
text: These aren’t necessarily good days to be a sporting icon, or at least one who clawed his way to the top with help from some moral or ethical sidestepping along the way, which in college sports, we now have come to expect, is just about everyone. But even a few years ago Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun could have expected his retirement to be greeted by universal acclaim. He did, after all, lead a basketball backwater to the big time and establish himself as a great coaching mind, all while professing to be above the unethical muck dragging down lesser mortals in the sport.

headline: If You Like Crosby, Stills and Nash . . .
text: Five years ago, Val Haller, a suburban Chicago mom, started valslist, a Web site aimed at exposing her generation — she’s 55 — to the music of the generation of her sons, ages 20 to 27. Unlike Pandora, a digital music recommendation service governed by an algorithm, Ms. Haller is governed by her ear, long hours of listening and serendipity. At Lollapalooza Chicago 2012, she was 25 years older than the average music reporter. “My goal every single day is to find that one new track that speaks to me and won’t let me go,” she says.

headline: Health Panel Approves Restriction on Sale of Large Sugary Drinks
text: Seeking to reduce runaway obesity rates, the New York City Board of Health on Thursday approved a ban on the sale of large sodas and other sugary drinks at restaurants, street carts and movie theaters, the first restriction of its kind in the country.

headline: Right Begins to Rally Around Romney’s Response to Attacks
text: Republicans were not exactly rushing to defend Mitt Romney’s brisk critique of the Obama administration’s response to a controversial Web video and the protests it seemed to help spawn. However, by Thursday, the right’s  establishment was starting to circle the wagons around Mr. Romney, the Republican presidential candidate.

headline: Answers to Your Questions About Apple’s iPhone 5
text: 4:40 p.m. | Updated Adding more questions and answers.

headline: Image of the Day: September 13
text: American flag at the American Center in New Delhi flown at half-mast after the attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: Taking the Preferences Out of Preferred Stock
text: You have to marvel at the lengths to which the radio station operator Emmis Communications has gone to strip its preferred stock of voting rights and accrued dividends worth millions. And deal watchers will salivate over the clever legal structures devised by Emmis’s lawyers.

headline: Soros’s Wisdom and Markets’ Ignorance
text: In my column this week, I discuss George Soros’s headline-grabbing insistence that the euro will survive only if Germany “leads or leaves.” My column focuses on his passionate conviction that a united Europe’s value goes beyond economics — this is also a political, and even moral, story.

headline: Wheelies: The Dr. Sid Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Promotion for Francesca Zambello at Washington National Opera
text: The Washington National Opera said on Thursday it had promoted Francesca Zambello  from artistic adviser to artistic director, solidifying its reorganization after the departure of Plácido Domingo and its merger with the Kennedy Center. Mr. Domingo stepped down as artistic director at the end of the 2010-2011 season, and the company became a Kennedy Center affiliate in response to serious money problems. Ms. Zambello, who is also the artistic and executive director of the Glimmerglass Festival in Cooperstown, N.Y., had stepped in at Washington to fill the void after Mr. Domingo’s departure. She now will have complete oversight of casting, repertory, the young artists program and a new commissioning project. She will continue to direct one production a year, the company said. She will assume the position in January.

text: New York

headline: Another Murder on the Resource Frontier – This Time a Journalist in Cambodia
text: Speaking truth to power is never easy. In some places, particularly where valuable resources are pursued in places with limited governance, it can be deadly.

headline: Business Day Live | Casting Controversy
text: A casting choice for a biographical film about the singer Nina Simone spurs protests.

headline: Federal Reserve Expected to Act to Spur Economy
text: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials are expected to conclude a two-day meeting Thursday and announce new measures to aid the ailing American recovery.

headline: My Night as a Billionaire
text: This summer, a case of mistaken identity earned me a seat at a formal dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Led Zeppelin to Release Concert Film
text: Led Zeppelin, the hard-rock and seminal heavy metal band, will release a concert movie in October, just two months before the band is scheduled to be honored at the Kennedy Center in Washington for its weighty role in transforming rock music.

headline: Nicholson Baker: By the Book
text: The author of “The Way the World Works” suspects Shakespeare is the most overrated writer of all time. “Although I must say his sonnets are incredible.”

headline: ’60 Minutes’ to Produce a Monthly Sports Show for Showtime
text: “60 Minutes” is extending itself to another network, Showtime, for a monthly newsmagazine called “60 Minutes of Sports.”

headline: J.&J. Names Outsider to Run Its Troubled Consumer Unit
text: Johnson & Johnson named an outsider on Thursday to fill a top leadership role overseeing its troubled consumer health unit, a break from the company’s longstanding tradition of promoting executives from within.

headline: E-Book Planned on Embattled Russian Punk Group
text: The women of Pussy Riot, the Russian punk group protesting President Vladimir V. Putin, will have their message out in a new medium: an e-book. “Pussy Riot! A Punk Prayer for Freedom,” to be released in about two weeks by The Feminist Press, part of the City University of New York, will include previously unavailable material, including prison letters from the three Pussy Riot members who have been jailed for “hooliganism inciting religious hatred” after a brief performance in an Orthodox cathedral in Moscow. The book will also include statements by their defense attorneys, poems and tributes from performers and artists, including Yoko Ono, Karen Finley and the poet Eileen Myles. Proceeds will go to the legal defense fund for the group.

headline: Turmoil at U.S. Posts Abroad
text: Protesters angered by an anti-Islam film attacked the American Embassy in Sana, the Yemeni capital, on Thursday, two days after the American ambassador to Libya was killed.

headline: Fed Ties New Aid to Jobs Recovery in Forceful Move
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve opened a new chapter Thursday in its efforts to stimulate the economy, saying that it intends to buy large quantities of mortgage bonds, and potentially other assets, until the job market improves substantially.

headline: 15-Year-Old Trails by Two at Women’s British Open
text: HOYLAKE, England — Lydia Ko was climbing the first-round leader board Thursday at the Women’s British Open when her group was put on the clock for slow play. The move was probably funnier to her than any punch line delivered by her coach and caddie, Guy Wilson, who told her jokes between shots at Royal Liverpool Golf Club to relax her.

headline: Hey, Señorita!
text: Olympic swimmers Conor Dwyer and Ryan Lochte attended the Ralph Lauren show this morning, suggesting all is forgiven over the designer’s production in China of ceremonial uniforms for the athletes this year. But if you thought Mr. Lauren might make a big pro-America statement on the runway, you would have thought wrong.

headline: Kevin Costner Plans Book Project
text: The director and actor Kevin Costner has signed a deal with Atria Books for a book project — an illustrated adventure series titled “The Explorers Guild” that will be released in 2014.

headline: A Red Tide Epidemic?
text: As we mentioned here in an On Our Radar item this week, the Yangtze River in China changed from a warm brown to a deep, rusty orange a few days ago. Striking photographs showed a   crimson current advancing alongside a stretch of untainted water. One Green reader wrote in to describe what she saw as  a spate of red tide events around the world and inquired about the cause.

headline: Watch List: How Film Might Look After Google’s Glasses
text: For a preview of how we all may be making movies in a few years, take a look at “DVF Through Glass,” a short video made for, and partly shot by, the fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg. Other camera operators included employees of Ms. von Furstenberg’s label, DVF, and models who walked in her recent Fashion Week show. All were wearing Google’s futuristic “Glass” glasses, which come equipped with tiny cameras (as well as tiny computer monitors) and are poised to take us a big step closer to the cyborg age, once they become available to the public.

headline: Dreamliner Makes Its Debut in Chile
text: Boeing’s 787 Dreamliner, the lighter, more-fuel efficient and purportedly more comfortable aircraft that has forged fans of hopeful fliers, recently made its American debut with the Chilean carrier LAN Airlines.

headline: Fashion Week Stargazing: Day 7
text: And on the seventh day, there was Kanye West and Kim Kardashian. From the mayhem caused by the couple, first at Marchesa and later at Louise Goldin, you would have thought Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor had been reincarnated.

headline: Bookshelf
text: Han Han, China’s smart-aleck blogger (who’s also a pro racecar driver), uses satire to skewer philandering pols and media censors. His posts are now translated in ‘‘This Generation’’ (Simon & Schuster, $24). Set in New York, London and Maine, Christine Schutt’s novel ‘‘Prosperous Friends’’ (Grove, $24) tracks a young couple lost in a game of psychosexual brinkmanship. ‘‘The Grand Tour’’ (Harper, $28) collects Agatha Christie’s unpublished letters from an epic 1922 journey from South Africa to Hawaii. Neil Steinberg’s ‘‘You Were Never in Chicago’’ (University of Chicago, $25) is both a rollicking newspaperman’s memoir (he’s a Chicago Sun-Times columnist) and a strong case for Second City exceptionalism — belied, a bit, by the city’s inferiority complex: Chicago, Steinberg notes, ‘‘once conducted a study to prove its pedestrians walk faster than those in New York.’’

headline: The Nile Special
text: A particular patch of turbulent water on the Nile River in Uganda attracts the world’s best freestyle kayakers.

headline: A Source of Thrills
text: HAIRY LEMON ISLAND, Uganda — There is a wave, far from passable roads and deep in the center of Africa, where those who seek to become the best of the best freestyle kayakers come to train.

headline: Many Struggling With Prescription Drug Costs
text: While health insurance premiums may be increasing more modestly than they were a year or two ago, consumers who take multiple drugs but lack prescription drug coverage are nearing a “crisis point” because they can’t afford to pay for them, a new report finds.

headline: Man of Many Names Is Tied to a Video
text: LOS ANGELES — The spotlight in the search for the creators of an incendiary video mocking Islam that set off a wave of anti-American violence in the Middle East shifted Thursday to a shadowy gas station owner with a record of criminal arrests and bankruptcy, who associates said expressed anti-Muslim sentiments as he pushed for the making of the film.

headline: Taking Pointers From Web Sites, USA Today Modernizes Its Look
text: McLEAN, Va. — It’s face-lift time for the newspaper known for its pie charts.

headline: Living With Cancer: The Trials of Cancer Trials
text: I spent last week trying to hope for the recurrence of a malignancy, a tumor of at least 1.5 centimeters (a bit more than half an inch) that would be visible on a CT scan.

headline: How to Find (or Make) Real Buttermilk
text: Many thirsty readers wrote in to Dining on Wednesday after reading about the pleasures of buttermilk, asking how to get their hands on the good stuff.

headline: Google Glass and the Future of Technology
text: New gadgets — I mean whole new gadget categories — don’t come along very often. The iPhone was one recent example. You could argue that the iPad was another. But if there’s anything at all as different and bold on the horizon, surely it’s Google Glass.

headline: Legitimate Criticism
text: Stung by the furious response to Mitt Romney’s attack on President Obama over the killings in Libya, some right-wing commentators have defended Mr. Romney’s right to challenge Mr. Obama on foreign policy. Just for instance, Jennifer Rubin wrote in The Washington Post that “Obama has no right to insist he is beyond criticism.” She added: “If [the media] are going to insist that holding a president accountable for his national security is out of bounds, then perhaps journalism is now farce.”

headline: Lionfish for Lunch, But Also Here For the Long Haul
text: Just in case you missed it, my friend and occasional fishing tutor Carl Safina has a string of posts on Mark Bittman’s blog on the continuing invasion of American waters by lionfish, a reef denizen, studded with toxin-tipped spines, that was most likely brought here from Asian waters by the aquarium trade.

headline: 36 Hours in Managua, Nicaragua
text: FOUNDED just before the Spanish left the country in the early 19th century, Managua, the capital of Nicaragua, is a city without a center, and, bizarrely, without conventional addresses; instead there are locations, many referring to Lake Managua, which the city, otherwise, doesn’t much celebrate. The 1972 earthquake shattered Managua’s once glorious boulevards, and today building styles vary wildly, from the squat residential buildings that popped up after the tremors, to older, more majestic neo-Classical and modern edifices. But despite an initial impression of chaos, you will find smooth roads and a full range of hotels and restaurants serving hearty local fare. The years of political upheaval marked by the 1979 revolution and then the brutal civil war of the 1980s have finally given way to stability. Yet travelers on their way to the coasts or quaint colonial towns still rush away from the capital upon arrival. That’s too bad. There is a blossoming of culture in this city that is the key to understanding modern Nicaragua.

headline: Now Streaming | Calvin Klein Spring 2013 Women’s Collection
text: The Spring 2013 women’s collection show from Calvin Klein at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Palace in Haiti, Damaged by Quake, Is Being Razed
text: MEXICO CITY — Armed mobs have marched on it. Desperate presidents have fled it. Crowds have partied outside its majestic gates.

headline: Children of Aging Parents Are Often Nearby, Study Finds
text: Who moves?

headline: Gagosian and Perelman File Suits Against Each Other Over Artworks
text: The billionaire investor Ronald Perelman and his longtime friend and art dealer Larry Gagosian both filed lawsuits in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Wednesday, with each man claiming the other cheated him out of millions of dollars over art purchases, Bloomberg reported.

headline: Bobwhite Lunch & Supper Counter
text: Inside the no-fuss Alphabet City storefront that makes a mission out of Southern fried chicken.

headline: A Southern Spot on a Mission
text: FIRST the chicken is baptized in sweet tea, a Southern elixir giddy with sugar, in which tea is an afterthought. It is left to brine overnight, then dredged in milk, flour, salt, pepper and mystery spices that the chef refuses to divulge. Into the pressure fryer it goes, then onto your plate.

headline: Romney Delivers Broad Criticism of Obama on Foreign Policy
text: FAIRFAX, Va. — Speaking to a modest-sized crowd in Northern Virginia on Thursday, Mitt Romney sought to move beyond his criticism of President Obama’s response to the turmoil in Libya and Egypt and instead broadly paint the president as weak on foreign policy.

headline: Paul Ryan Gets His Own Meet-and-Greet Room on Capitol Hill
text: Only a few months ago, Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, was just another member of the House of Representatives, shuffling to the floor for votes with his iPod earphones stuck in his ears, or walking among colleagues in the Longworth House Office building.

headline: Board Votes to Regulate Circumcision, Citing Risks
text: The New York City Board of Health passed a regulation on Thursday that will require consent from parents before an infant can have a form of Jewish ritual circumcision, prevalent in parts of the ultra-Orthodox community, in which the circumciser uses his mouth to remove blood from the incision.

headline: Wisconsin Uses New N.C.A.A. Rule to Solve Quarterback Woes, Again
text: Confronted with devastating injuries to quarterbacks for the second consecutive season, Wisconsin has employed an inventive method to replenish its stock, far from college football’s conventional approach to cultivating the position.

text: To the Editor:

headline: At Film Society, Two Programmers Will Take Over From Festival Veteran
text: Nearly a year after the longtime programming director of the New York Film Festival said he was stepping down, the organization that runs it has chosen not one but two replacements. The Film Society of Lincoln Center on Thursday announced the appointment of Kent Jones as director of programming for the festival and Robert Koehler as director of programming, year round.

headline: TimesCast Politics | Sept. 13, 2012
text: Romney's reaction to Benghazi. | Another foreign policy hurdle: Israeli relations. | Same-sex marriage and the New York primaries. | A deeper look at Obama's bundlers.

headline: Theater Talkback: Flattened
text: Maybe it sounds a little perverse, but I usually try to avoid seeing any movies made from stage plays or musicals I have particularly enjoyed. A natural curiosity about how the material has been translated into a new medium tends to be outweighed by a general foreboding born of past experience. Too often the particular delights of a stage production evaporate considerably — if not entirely — in the translation.

headline: Fiercest Competition This Season May Be Among Singing Competitions
text: Wednesday night brought further evidence that network television may be saturated with singing competitions, even as news reports circulated about which celebrated recording artists the Fox network would be adding as judges to revive the flagging flagship of singing shows, “American Idol.”

headline: Carlyle Buys Controlling Stake in Brazilian Furniture Retailer
text: SAO PAULO, Brazil – The Carlyle Group said Thursday that it had acquired a 60 percent stake in Tok & Stok, a Brazilian furniture company, in a move that positions it to take advantage of the country’s consumer retail market.

headline: Disney Unexpectedly Reveals Movie Write-Down and Sluggish Ad Revenue
text: James A. Rasulo, Disney’s chief financial officer, unexpectedly revealed two important tidbits at a gathering of Wall Street analysts on Thursday: The company will take a $50 million write-down at its movie studio, and summer advertising revenue at ABC was softer than expected.

headline: Warm-Weather Leathers
text: Set on making the most of a good thing, a clutch of designers has reprised last season’s swoony romance with leather, trotting out unlikely springtime variations. Counterintuitive though it first seemed, the decision to experiment with skins proved an apt one, underscoring the starchy, crisply formal feel of some collections, and handily brightening others.

headline: In His Narrative, Time to Get Back ‘Into the Game’
text: IN the 1980s the Israeli-born painter and sculptor Izhar Patkin often seemed to be everywhere in the New York art world. He was a star in the stable of the flamboyant dealer Holly Solomon, for whom he made not only art but occasional apartment décor (painted dining-room curtains); an adventurous free floater among the worlds of art, fashion and design; and a standout in the 1987 Whitney Biennial, which featured his “Black Paintings,” an ominously beautiful series of images on pleated, hanging neoprene that is now in the collection of the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Americans Look to Be Conquistadors on Clay
text: The United States Davis Cup team upset Roger Federer and the Swiss on red clay in February. The Americans upset Jo-Wilfried Tsonga and the French on red clay in April.

headline: Reaction to Libya Attack Could Color Poll Analysis, and Vice Versa
text: Earlier on Thursday, I suggested that we have now gotten some pretty good guidance on the size of President Obama’s convention bounce. For the next week or two, most of our attention will be focused on how much of that bounce he maintains — and how it translates into swing states — and not on trying to gauge its magnitude.

headline: Diplomats Pulled 2 Ways, Between High Walls and Open Doors
text: Security breaches at American diplomatic compounds in the Middle East this week highlight the two competing challenges that United States diplomats confront: keeping safe in a world full of anti-American extremism and interacting with foreign populations outside the towering walls of government installations overseas.

headline: Why These Kids Get a Free Ride to College
text: Wings Stadium, a dim, beery sports barn in Kalamazoo, Mich., is an appropriate home for the K-Wings minor-league hockey team and the Killamazoo Derby Darlins. Yet every year, in June, the site hosts a spectacle more uplifting than a season of flip checks. This is when it is the setting for the graduations of the city’s two main high schools. A couple of nights after Kalamazoo Central High fills the arena, it’s Loy Norrix’s turn. The rink is covered, and students, friends and family take over most of the 5,100 seats.

headline: In Toronto a Number of Films Find Homes
text: The Toronto International Film Festival is wrapping up with a spate of sales. Lionsgate and Roadside Attractions bought Joss Whedon’s adaptation of “Much Ado About Nothing,” which played well with “Buffy” fans at the festival. Shot in black-and-white in just 12 days, it has a modern tone (and a cast full of Whedon favorites, from “Angel,” “Dollhouse” and “Firefly”).

headline: Britain’s National Theater To Open New York Office
text: Following the financial and critical success of their London-to-Broadway productions of “War Horse” and “One Man, Two Guvnors,” executives at the National Theater of Great Britain announced on Thursday that they are opening their first office in New York next month to oversee future shows and deepen relationships with theaters and donors in the United States. While no new National shows are in the immediate offing for Broadway, the executives said, the new office is poised to make the National even more of a force in American theater than it already is.

text: GOLDEN, Colo. – President Obama spent the second day of what was to be an upbeat swing through the politically vital Mountain West on Thursday balancing the somber tone that a foreign policy crisis demands and the hyper-partisan rhetoric that eight thousand Coloradoans came to hear.

headline: Would You Take a Pregnancy Test in a Bar?
text: If you make a  beeline to the stalls, you might miss the pregnancy test dispenser fastened to a wall in the women’s restroom of Pub 500 in Mankato, Minn. There, with the swipe of a credit card, for a $3 fee, you can use a nearby toilet and learn whether you may proceed in good conscience with the martini you were about to order.

headline: ‘The Truth Is Out Today, but We Begin Looking for Justice Tomorrow’
text: LONDON — The most shocking experience imaginable in a sports venue is to witness the suffocation to death of 96 fans — men, women and children — in the stadium.

headline: Week 2 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
text: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

headline: 4 Years After Lehman’s Demise, Regulators Debate Overhaul
text: Four years after Wall Street teetered on the brink of collapse, regulators are struggling to rein in foreign risk-taking that imperils American banks.

headline: On Our Radar: Putin’s Wildlife Exploits
text: Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, acknowledges that many of his outdoor adventures with wildlife have been carefully staged. For example, a tiger he was shown shooting in the wild with a tranquilizer gun was apparently a captive one that had been transported to the scene. [Reuters]

headline: Profile in Style | Ulrika Lundgren
text: Whether she’s designing her rock ’n’ roll-romantic fashion label, Rika, decorating the Amsterdam apartment she shares with her family or choosing art for the walls of Maison Rika, her tiny canal-side guesthouse, this Swedish-born, Netherlands-based tastemaker stays true to her roots — for the most part. “I’m super-Scandinavian in my style,” she says, “but because I haven’t lived there for so long, I’m influenced by other cultures and the places I go, like London, Paris, Mexico, Mallorca and Bali.” A common visual vein that runs through all of Lundgren’s work is her signature palette: black and cream punctuated by jolts of primary color in the form of art and accessories. “My interiors, like my clothes and bags, are quite urban,” she says. “But I don’t like coldness, so I soften the edges and add warmth.” More…

headline: Dusting Off a Horseman for New Battles
text: The Great Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is such a busy place that it’s easy to miss the artworks periodically on view there. Two 1967-68 silk-screens of Warhol’s “Flowers” — a teaser to “Regarding Warhol: Sixty Artists, Fifty Years,” opening on Tuesday — were recently hung on the eastern side of the hall. A colossal statue of a pharaoh, weighing about nine tons, sits regally on the north side.

headline: Defending ‘Conscience,’ Restricting Rights
text: Having lost the fight over Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell—repealed a year ago this month— Senators James Inhofe of Oklahoma and Roger Wicker of Mississippi are trying to make it as hard as possible for gay men and lesbians to exercise their civil rights while serving their country in the armed forces.

headline: The Cost of Adapters Adds Up
text: In my post about the new iPhone 5, I grumbled about the new power/sync connector, which doesn’t fit any of the millions of existing cords, docks, speakers and accessories. Unless, that is, you buy an insanely overpriced $30 plug adapter or a $40 cable adapter from Apple.

headline: A Tax Tactic That’s Open to Question
text: “Anyone may arrange his affairs so that his taxes shall be as low as possible; he is not bound to choose that pattern which best pays the treasury. There is not even a patriotic duty to increase one’s taxes.”

headline: The New York Finale at Calvin Klein
text: Francisco Costa brought the New York collections to a close this afternoon with a Calvin Klein collection that showed a new take on the geometric black-and-white graphics that have been all over the runways in the form of stripes, grids and checks.

headline: Video: Primary Day in New York State
text: Thursday was Primary Day in New York, and some state legislative and judicial races were on the ballot. Though primaries tend to attract a small number of races, some of the day’s races could have national implications.

headline: Protests Spread as Anger Over Anti-Islam Film Mounts
text: Protests spread across the Middle East and North Africa on Thursday, most of them directed at American Embassies and offices linked to United States diplomatic activities, as anger mounted over a video denigrating the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Ralph Lauren
text: The Look: South American Aristocrat.

headline: Suspect Sought in Rape of Occupy Wall Street Protester Near South Street Seaport
text: The police released a photo on Thursday of a man wanted for raping a woman and throwing her over a second-story railing near the South Street Seaport on Monday, breaking her pelvis.

headline: A New Kind of Monkey, With Colors That Set It Apart
text: Scientists have identified a new species of African monkey whose coloring “is unlike anything I’ve ever seen,” as one of them put it.

headline: In Japan, a Bird’s-Eye View
text: The Tokyo design studio Nendo has created a treehouse for the Ando Momofuku Center in Japan that is part birdhouse, part human observation deck.

text: Photos from Egypt, Yemen, Syria and Afghanistan.

headline: SFJazz Names Artists to Open Its Permanent Home
text: SFJazz, the Bay Area jazz institution which has for nearly 30 years presented concerts and festivals in rented spaces, announced on Thursday the lineup for a series of opening concerts and a wide-ranging full-season schedule in its new permanent space — with concerts by local as well as international artists and educational programming.

headline: Bloodstains With a Story: The Allure of Artifacts Linked to Famous Crimes
text: A bloodstained tan stocking was unrolled across a Manhattan cafe table the other day. It had belonged to Bonnie Parker, the murderous robber, and was found in her getaway car in 1934 after she and her partner, Clyde Barrow, died in a hail of police bullets.

headline: In Chinatown, Martial Arts Alfresco
text: ON a recent Saturday morning, I joined eight kung fu students and their master, David Kaplan, in Chinatown for a lesson in martial arts. It was 8 a.m. and raining, but Mr. Kaplan’s outdoor classes run six days a week, year-round and without regard for weather.

text: 41 Cooper Gallery
