headline: One Has Left Arkansas, but Football Still Bonds Petrinos
text: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — One of Paul and Bobby Petrino’s favorite ways to have fun was far less complicated than the offensive strategies it produced.

headline: Sinful Ways to Start the Day
text: SEPTEMBER means back to school and back to work — and back to morning regimens of low-fat yogurt and sensible breakfast cereals. But before you can say “stress factor,” we’ll be craving that big glazed doughnut or monster muffin, and triple or quadruple shots of caffeine. Here, in anticipation of slipping back into old habits, are three new places in or near Westchester County that offer excellent high-calorie and high-octane reasons to get out of bed. All are child-friendly and have good spots to tie up your dog.

headline: Contenders for America’s Most Popular Car: The Latest Wave of Midsize Family Sedans
text: Contenders for America’s most popular car.

headline: Bill Cunningham | On Their Feet
text: New York Fashion Week guests at the clothing shows provided a dazzling display of today's shoe designs.

headline: Once a Vagabond Driver, Now an IndyCar Title Contender
text: Ryan Hunter-Reay was a racecar driver who needed a road map. He was not yet 25 when he lost his third ride in three years in the flagging Champ Car series in 2005, and he had to contemplate his future, perhaps one without racing.

headline: Fashion Week Inside and Out
text: The views from inside fashion shows, and outside on the sidewalk, during New York Fashion Week.

headline: The Cavemen Embrace Aprons and Whisks
text: I RECENTLY had a long-postponed dinner with a dear male friend of mine. After comparing cholesterol scores and the frequency of workouts, we got down to business.

headline: What Books Said to One Another
text: If you listen closely at the subtly startling new exhibition at the Jewish Museum, “Crossing Borders: Manuscripts From the Bodleian Libraries,” you can hear manuscripts murmuring across millenniums.

headline: Movie Frenzy, but Still Comfy, Eh?
text: TORONTO — The Toronto International Film Festival is where towering achievement meets buckets of blood, where the cinematic highbrow jostles alongside the middle and lower realms for 11 crammed, ecstatic, enervating days and nights. The essential industry event of the fall, now in its 37th year, it is the promised land for distributors looking for product, producers hunting for money and journalists looking for the next big films and faces. Despite the red carpet events and what feels like a tighter embrace of the mainstream, the festival continues to feel appreciably less glamorous than Cannes. It’s homier, more relaxed, which is why you may end up seated near David Geffen at dinner one night or find yourself waiting for vegetarian takeout alongside Paul Dano and Zoe Kazan.

headline: Georgia: In Suing State, A.C.L.U. Defends Klan
text: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit against Georgia on Thursday for denying the Ku Klux Klan’s application to participate in an “adopt a highway” program. The lawsuit says the state violated the freedom of speech of a chapter of the Klan in Union County, near the North Carolina border. State transportation officials in June denied the chapter’s application to clean trash along a stretch of Route 515 in the Appalachian Mountains, saying the program was for only “civic-minded organizations in good standing.” Debbie Seagraves, the executive director of the A.C.L.U. Foundation of Georgia, said: “There will always be speech and groups conveying hateful messages that are distasteful to some. That is why the First Amendment protects free speech for all.” The State Transportation Department said it had expected the lawsuit and stood by its decision to deny the application.

headline: Colleges in Three States Report Bomb Threats
text: Three college campuses in North Dakota, Ohio and Texas were evacuated on Friday after receiving bomb threats. The false alarms forced students and staff members to flee in the middle of classes at the University of Texas, Austin; North Dakota State University, Fargo; and Hiram College in northeast Ohio. In Austin, Rhonda Weldon, a spokeswoman, said a man called claiming “to have placed bombs all over campus” that would detonate in 90 minutes, and officials decided to order the university’s 51,000 students and 24,000 staff and faculty members to evacuate “out of an abundance of caution.” Classes were canceled for the day. At North Dakota State, which has 14,000 students, officials ordered an evacuation after receiving a bomb threat, but the campus was reopened by 1 p.m., officials said. At Hiram, with 1,300 students, crews with bomb-sniffing dogs checked all of the buildings. It was not clear who made the threats or whether they were connected, officials said.

headline: Taking It to the Grave
text: I married the love of my life at a young age. We were high school sweethearts, together for 12 years and married for 6. Sadly, she passed away when we were 26. Five years later, I met a wonderful woman to whom I am now married, and we have two beautiful children. My second wife understands the deep love I shared with my first wife and respects our bond. When I die, should I be buried with my true love or in a family plot with my second family? Brian, New York

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 8 through 12 with 1,301 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,170 said they were registered to vote.

headline: The First Issue in Any Massage
text: IT’S often the first, and most awkward, question at a spa: “Do you prefer a male or female massage therapist?”

headline: As Succession Talk Stirs, Ford Focuses on New Car
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — If Mark Fields is ruffled by speculation that he is the favorite to become the next chief executive of Ford Motor, he isn’t showing it.

headline: The Lion, the Artist and the Studio
text: Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

headline: He Struck Gold in Cast Iron
Cracks Spur Board to Urge Check of Dreamliner Engines
text: The National Transportation Safety Board on Friday called for frequent inspections on engines in Boeing’s new 787 Dreamliner planes after cracks were found in an engine shaft on two jets and possibly on a 747-8 cargo plane.

headline: Still Dreaming Her Dream
text: Pay attention to Charity Hope Valentine’s middle name. The heroine of the musical “Sweet Charity” is prone to wishful thinking. She’s also a giving person, and the object of her striving is love, so Charity and Valentine are also cleverly apt names. Or painfully obvious ones.

headline: Standing Up at an Early Age
text: In recent weeks, Baltimore Ravens linebacker Brendon Ayanbadejo has been praised in many quarters for supporting the legalization of same-sex marriage. His stance is not new, but it reached a wider audience after a Maryland legislator urged the Ravens owner Steve Bisciotti to silence him.

headline: A Label That Has Regained Its Luster
text: REMEMBER the Chrysler K-car? Dave Schiff, a founder of Made Collection, a new flash-sale site that sells only American-made goods, hopes not.

headline: Throwing Stones at Glass Ceilings
text: “The Good Girls Revolt: How the Women of Newsweek Sued Their Bosses and Changed the Workplace.” By Lynn Povich. 288 pages. PublicAffairs. $25.99.

headline: When Good Things Happen to Bad Seasons
text: If you live in a baseball market where your team is already out of it, it’s likely that for a while there has been talk about next year, about “rebuilding.” I played for my share of those teams, and I know that this is the time of year when you can get a sense of what that rebuilt team might look like once they stop rebuilding. Because, as team rosters expand from 25 to 40 in September, this is when many young players get a true shot. They are penned into the lineup and allowed to play, to make mistakes, to compete against the best, every single night. The team is playing for the future, but the future gets to play, now.

headline: The Willing Nanny, the Happy Family: Too Good to Be True
text: The e-mail arrived two weeks ago.

headline: Standing Out From the New Girls
text: ON Sept. 5, the day before New York Fashion Week began, she shimmered onstage at the Style Awards at Lincoln Center, glamorous in an above-the-knee white cocktail dress by the designer Christian Siriano, ballerina bun piled high and burgundy lips.

headline: California Tries to Guide the Way on Health Law
text: SACRAMENTO — The meeting came to order, the five members of the California Health Benefit Exchange seated onstage with dozens of consumer advocates and others looking on. On the agenda: what to name the online marketplace where millions of residents will be able to shop for medical coverage under President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Fed Responds to a Grim Reality
text: WASHINGTON — When the Federal Reserve’s vice chairman said in a 1994 speech that the central bank “had a role in reducing unemployment,” colleagues were publicly dismissive. The very word “employment” did not appear in a policy statement until 2008. The Fed was focused on inflation, officials said time and again.

headline: Feeling the Oompah as Oktoberfest Beckons
text: FRANKLIN SQUARE, N.Y.

headline: Cutting Government, Blindfolded
text: Mitt Romney has been rousing military-minded voters with warnings of giant defense cuts in January, but he’s only telling half the story. An alarming White House report issued Friday shows that the full impact of next year’s ham-handed budget cuts would affect virtually every government function, not just the Pentagon.

headline: County Judge Strikes Down Some Restrictions on Public Unions in Wisconsin Law
text: A county judge in Wisconsin on Friday struck down much of the 2011 state law pushed through by Gov. Scott Walker that severely restricts the ability of public employees to bargain collectively.

headline: Mets Put Brewers’ Surge Into Wild-Card Picture on Pause
text: MILWAUKEE — The flat-screen televisions in the middle of the Milwaukee Brewers’ clubhouse were strangely dark on Friday afternoon.

headline: Lottery Numbers
No Rush to War
text: Amid the alarming violence in the Arab world, a new report about the costs of a potential war with Iran got lost this week. It says an attack by the United States could set back Iran’s nuclear program four years at most, while a more ambitious goal — ensuring Iran never reconstitutes its nuclear program or ousting the regime — would involve a multiyear conflict that could engulf the region.

headline: Ospreys in Okinawa
text: Tens of thousands of people rallied on Sunday in Okinawa to protest plans to deploy the MV-22 Osprey, the trouble-plagued tilt-rotor aircraft, at the United States Marine Corps base in the city of Ginowan. The Marines want to bring in 24 Ospreys to replace a fleet of Vietnam-era helicopters, but Okinawans, turning out in one of the largest anti-American protests in years, are bristling.

headline: Walmart Opts Out of New York Mall After Facing Labor Opposition
text: The prospect that Walmart, the world’s largest retailer, would open its first big-box store in New York City suffered a setback on Friday, with the company saying it would not be a part of a new mall being constructed in Brooklyn.

headline: American Retailers Face Challenges in Expanding to Canada
text: TORONTO — Nordstrom and Target are about to open stores in Canada, J. Crew and Tory Burch just did so, and Ann Taylor and Kate Spade are scouting locations.

headline: Turkish Cooking in a Friendly Setting
text: “BEREKET,” our waitress explained, means “good luck,” — not a bad name for a venture that is less than three years old. The friendly, unpretentious staff and surroundings made me want to second that wish. In a later phone conversation with the restaurant’s manager, I was told Bereket also means “an excess,” as in “more than enough of a good thing.” Take your pick.

headline: Legislators Tainted by Scandal Find Defeat at the Polls
text: In a state with a scant history of electoral upsets, it was not in any job description, but it might as well have been: Once an incumbent, always an incumbent.

headline: Money-Laundering Inquiry Is Said to Aim at U.S. Banks
text: Federal and state authorities are investigating a handful of major American banks for failing to monitor cash transactions in and out of their branches, a lapse that may have enabled drug dealers and terrorists to launder tainted money, according to officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Two Days in September
text: Anniversary No. 1: Exactly four years ago, Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy protection. In the days and weeks that followed, we saw the unfolding of the dramatic — and ultimately successful — effort by the federal government to rescue the banking system. But, once the dust settled, we began to see something else: like the stock market crash of 1929, Lehman wasn’t an isolated event. Rather, it was a signal that deep problems had enveloped our economy — problems that wouldn’t be solved quickly or easily. That is why the Lehman bankruptcy still resonates. It was the moment everything changed.

headline: Votes Aren’t All Tallied, but Conclusions Are Drawn
text: Senator Stephen M. Saland, a lawyer from Poughkeepsie, has served in the New York State Legislature for 32 years. In 2010, he won re-election by 19 percentage points. And since then, he has raised $788,000 for his campaign war chest — more than 40 times what his challenger in the Republican primary raised.

headline: No Fury Like a Woman Bored
text: On average, Oslo gets about 2.5 inches of rainfall in September — around one inch less than Hartford. But you wouldn’t know that from the loud onstage downpour underway as you take your seat for Jennifer Tarver’s production of “Hedda Gabler” at Hartford Stage.

headline: While Ryan Throws Hardballs, Romney Makes Friends on Morning TV
text: PAINESVILLE, Ohio — One of the advantages of the partnership between Mitt Romney and Paul D. Ryan is their ability to offer varied messages on the campaign trail — unusually varied, as shown on Friday. The running mates punched a list of campaign goals — rallying the conservative base, turning up the heat on President Obama and reaching out to women watching morning television — when each day counting down to Nov. 6 matters.

headline: Bed-Stuy Pride
text: The garish yellow awning out front still says, “B’s West Indian,” but the restaurant Do or Dine, which opened in June 2011 in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, has outgrown its original winking misdirection. In July, one of the chef-owners, Justin Warner, won Season 8 of the cable reality show “Food Network Star.” And by now the high-concept, lowish-budget restaurant has become a destination for Manhattanites, as well as a standby for locals, with or without oversize baseball caps. How do you tell the difference? “Manhattan customers are very used to being catered to in their whims,” said Luke Jackson, 33, another owner, whereas locals are more concerned with essential pleasures: the food and the atmosphere. All choose from a menu whose puckish inventiveness (foie gras doughnuts, banana split-pea soup) has drawn sighs of delight and exasperation. Last Tuesday, the disco mirror ball spun and the sound system played ghosts of hip-hop past.

headline: Prosecutors Still Interviewing Campaign Donors in Liu Fund-Raising Inquiry
text: A federal prosecutor said on Friday that investigators were continuing to interview donors to the campaign of the New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, which suggests that the authorities are trying to amass more evidence to put pressure on the defendants in the fund-raising case.

headline: Olajuwon Will School Knicks in Low-Post Moves
text: Hakeem Olajuwon, a two-time N.B.A. champion and a leading teacher of low-post moves, usually conducts his instruction on his ranch in Katy, Tex. But next week, Olajuwon will visit the Knicks’ training facility in Greenburgh, N.Y., to give lessons to the team’s big men.

headline: Soul-Searching in a Christian Community Over Views on How to Live
text: BREMERTON, Wash. — In 2005, John and Linda Parsons decided to downsize. They were each about 50 years old, with two sons nearing college age. The time seemed right to leave their house on Bainbridge Island, near Seattle. They would sacrifice square footage for a lower mortgage.

headline: Organizers Say Ironman Will Not Return to New York City
text: Ironman, the organizer of the world’s best-known triathlon, will shut its race in the New York area after just one year.

headline: Meet the Quiet Jets, Who May Be a Lot Like the Old Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The new Jets ditch practice to attend leadership retreats. They score 48 points in victory and then act as if they were shut out. They speak of good vibes and great feelings and how last year was last year and this year is just, well, different.

headline: How the Chicago Public School District Compares
text: The Chicago Teachers Union ended its strike on Tuesday after reaching a tentative deal with Chicago Public Schools.

headline: Twitter Turns Over User’s Messages in Occupy Wall Street Protest Case
text: Twitter on Friday turned over to a judge a printed stack of messages written by an Occupy Wall Street protester in October, around the time he and hundreds of others were arrested after walking on the roadway of the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: Cherry Ice Cream Smile
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s a lot going on in this puzzle for me, and that’s a big compliment considering that we are talking about a themeless Saturday puzzle.

headline: As N.H.L. Nears Lockout, Doan Re-Signs With Coyotes
text: With N.H.L. teams on track to begin a lockout at midnight Saturday, the league engaged in a bevy of activity almost everywhere except the bargaining table.

headline: Diplomats’ Bodies Return to U.S., and Libyan Guards Recount Deadly Riot
text: WASHINGTON — As four flag-draped coffins bearing the bodies of the Americans killed in Libya arrived in the United States on Friday, new details emerged of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens’s final hours, alone, locked in a smoke-filled room in a diplomatic mission under siege.

headline: Talking to the City With Chalk
text: ON Thursday evening, Robin Lane was out there with his stick of chalk, standing at his spot on the northeast corner of Second Avenue and 33rd Street in Kips Bay, Manhattan.

headline: South Africa Warns Against Violence as Protests Fester
text: JOHANNESBURG — In an attempt to stanch a spreading crisis in South Africa’s platinum and gold mining regions, the government said Friday that it would crack down on illegal gatherings and arrest people who congregate with weapons.

headline: A Concert Finder for the Open-Minded
text: APP Timbre

headline: The Brooklyn Game Had Its Own Beat
text: Before I was to play in the public school gym or the local Y, and at about the same time I had my first crush on Annette, the Mouseketeer, I used to gaze at the tall, gray steel backboard with the orange rim. For my first shot, I used a dodgeball. I didn’t have, let alone own, a real ball, a Voit.

headline: After Life in New York, Banker Returns to India for Turn at Fashion
text: NEW DELHI

headline: Lia Lee Dies; Life Went On Around Her, Redefining Care
text: In 1988, when Anne Fadiman met Lia Lee, then 5, for the first time, she wrote down her impressions in four spare lines that now read like found poetry:

headline: The American Diplomatic Compound in Benghazi
text: Libyans found the body of J. Christopher Stevens in a safe room in the American Diplomatic Compound in Benghazi.

headline: A Suicide in a Troubled Jail Mirrors New Orleans’s Ordeals
text: NEW ORLEANS — Over the past year, in churches full of citizens railing at the state of the city jail, and in courtrooms where the thousands of young men who populate that jail rotate glumly through the sentencing process, a middle-aged woman could be seen sitting quietly. Her name is Donna Gauthier and she had not given much thought to the criminal justice system, other than to assume that if you had the misfortune of ending up in it, they would at least take care of you.

headline: Some Romney Proposals Await Fuller Detail
text: Mitt Romney says he will cut government spending by some $500 billion a year by the end of his first term, while protecting military spending. But he has not detailed many of the deep cuts to domestic programs that budget analysts say would be needed to achieve that.

headline: Google Has No Plans to Rethink Video Status
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google said on Friday that it would not comply with a White House request to reconsider the anti-Islam video that has set off violent protests in the Arab world in light of its rules banning hate speech on YouTube, which it owns.

headline: Romney Stumbles in Explaining Iran Policy
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney has a clear “red line” in mind, a point beyond which Iran cannot go toward producing a nuclear weapon. It is sharply different, his campaign insists, from President Obama’s.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Debtors’ Delight

headline: Afghan Insurgents Attack Base Where Prince Harry Serves
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Insurgents using guns and rockets or mortars launched an audacious attack on the largest NATO base in Helmand Province shortly after midnight Saturday morning, killing two American service members, according to a spokesman for the international forces here.

headline: School Confronts Porn Arrest of Doctor
text: A prestigious Massachusetts prep school and a pediatric hospital said on Friday that they had no indication that any of the children they served were harmed by a doctor who worked for both institutions and now stands accused of receiving child pornography.

headline: Shave, Shul and Schumann
text: David M. Posner is retiring next year as senior rabbi at  Temple Emanu-El on Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, a Reform Jewish synagogue that counts Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg among its 3,000 members. Rabbi Posner, 64, who grew up in Brownsville, Brooklyn, started there immediately after his ordination from Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati, in 1973. He lives with his wife and childhood sweetheart, Sylvia — he calls her Syl — in a building that is a 15-minute walk from work, and said he expected to feel both happiness and relief after delivering his last High Holy Days sermons beginning on Sunday.

headline: Advantage, Obama
text: Elections often turn on character moments and the slopes of lines.

headline: Two Aces, One Unsettling Pattern
text: Since making his first start against the Yankees in early June 2009, David Price has held up his billing as the Tampa Bay Rays’ unquestioned ace — a 6-foot-6 left-hander and former top overall draft pick with the jerky delivery and the fastball that sings.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: The Champs-Élysées, a Mall of America
text: PARIS — André Malraux, the novelist and minister of culture under Charles de Gaulle, told a French-American journalist in the 1960s that the Champs-Élysées — then considered the most beautiful avenue in the world — had “an American basement.” Today, American business and its brands are prominently aboveground on a Champs-Élysées that has largely lost its distinctive character and has become far less French.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: SEAL Veteran With Zest for Adrenaline
text: LAS VEGAS — Tyrone S. Woods, one of four Americans killed this week when militants stormed a diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, was “one of those adrenaline junkies” who was “built to do what he did,” said Dr. Timothy Rasmusson, his former brother-in-law.

headline: Peter Lougheed, Ex-Premier of Alberta, Dies at 84
text: Peter Lougheed, the Alberta premier who harnessed his province’s vast oil and gas resources to transform its economy, died Thursday in Calgary, Alberta. He was 84.

headline: Inflatable Dams
text: To help prevent the dumping of raw sewage into New York’s waterways during a storm, the city has installed inflatable dams in two locations.

headline: The Face of Indefinite Detention
text: BEFORE he died on Sept. 8, Adnan Farhan Abdul Latif had spent close to 4,000 days and nights in the American prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. He was found unconscious, alone in his cell, thousands of miles from home and family in Yemen.

headline: A Leader in China Reappears in Public
text: BEIJING — China’s next designated leader, Xi Jinping, reappeared in public on Saturday, two weeks after mysteriously disappearing from view.

headline: Mexico: Bodies Found on Bridge
text: The bodies of nine men, one of them hanging from a bridge and all shot in the head, were found Friday in Nuevo Laredo, across from Laredo, Tex., the authorities said. Ruben Darío, a spokesman for the Tamaulipas State prosecutor’s office, said the bodies were all found near the bridge, with a message left near them, though he would not disclose what it said. In May, five men and four women were found hanging from another bridge in the city. This latest crime occurred a day after the top leader of the Gulf Cartel, one of Mexico’s largest, was captured by the Mexican Navy in Tamaulipas, leading security analysts to warn of possible violence resulting from the power vacuum.

headline: In the Bowels of the City, Blocking Wastewater Overflows
text: It happens dozens of times a year, undermining water quality, closing beaches and endangering aquatic life: Hit by major rainfall, New York’s sewers release raw sewage and polluted storm water into New York Harbor. These “overflow events” account for an estimated 27 billion gallons of pollutants annually in the city’s waters.

headline: Corrections: September 15, 2012
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: A Lonely Redemption
text: ESSEX, N.Y. — Striding barefoot through the fields of his farm in the Adirondacks, S. B. Lewis, known as Sandy, is talking without pause, gesturing this way and that in a soft summer rain.

headline: Seeking Chic, Brilliant Intern to Thread Needles (No Pay)
text: In February, Xuedan Wang, a 2010 graduate of Ohio University, received modest attention after she filed a lawsuit against the Hearst Corporation claiming that the company violated labor laws when it did not pay her for the work she had done as an intern at Harper’s Bazaar, one of its magazines, over four months last year. Speaking to New York magazine last week, on the occasion of Fashion Week, Ms. Wang, who goes by Diana, explained that she had spent more than half of her life dreaming of Bazaar and approximately 12 months working at a pharmaceutical company in Columbus in order to save enough money to realize her Manhattan vision.

headline: Billboards Protecting Their Heads
text: Dr. Marcus M. Reidenberg, 78, has for a few years been engaged in an ongoing photographic project: documenting the uniquely decorated hard hats of welders, carpenters, bricklayers and others around New York.

headline: Sid Watkins, Safety Innovator in Formula One Racing, Dies at 84
text: Formula One racing is one of the world’s fastest motorsports, and in the 1970s it was one of the most dangerous. Fiery crashes occurred so frequently that drivers were often seriously injured or killed.

headline: A Comedian and a Cardinal Open Up on Spirituality
text: The comedian Stephen Colbert and Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan of New York bantered onstage Friday night before 3,000 cheering, stomping, chanting students at Fordham University, in what might have been the most successful Roman Catholic youth evangelization event since Pope John Paul II last appeared at World Youth Day.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: A man suspected of helping to plot the 1999 hijacking of an Indian civilian aircraft, Indian Airlines Flight 814, was arrested by the police Thursday in the Kishtwar district of the state, IBN Live Web site reported. Mehrajuddin Dand, who is in police custody for four days, admitted to working with the organized-crime boss Dawood Ibrahim, who is one of the most wanted men in India, the report said, quoting unnamed sources.

headline: Beginning a Journey That Could Make Family History
text: My full name is Leobardo Espinoza Jr., but everyone here calls me Leo. It’s shorter to say and easier for everyone to understand. I was born in California and moved to Topeka, Kan., when I was in the sixth grade.

headline: The Early Word: Toss-Up
text: Today’s Times

headline: Sept. 14: Obama Forecast Declines on Poor Manufacturing Report
text: President Obama’s odds of winning the Electoral College fell for the second consecutive day on Friday according to the FiveThirtyEight forecast. His chances of winning the Electoral College are now listed at 76.2 percent, down from 78.6 percent in Thursday’s forecast.

headline: Morocco Emerges as Key U.S. Ally in Troubled Region
text: LONDON — Anti-American protests that have spread across the Arab world are overshadowing Washington’s latest steps to cement its ties with one of its closest allies in the region, Morocco.

headline: Small Business Health Insurance: Costs Still Going Up
text: The news for small businesses — not particularly surprising and not particularly good — in the Kaiser Family Foundation’s latest study of employer-sponsored health insurance is that the trend lines are unchanged. Costs continue to go up, and the number of companies offering insurance does not.

headline: Do Tax Cuts Lead to Economic Growth?
text: Washington

headline: Undaunted by Arrests, the Opposition Marches Against Putin
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s opposition movement drew tens of thousands to another large anti-Putin demonstration on Saturday, sending the message that its ranks are undaunted by a battery of new government sanctions and the two-year prison sentences handed down last month to the punk-rockers of Pussy Riot.

headline: Tax Cuts and Economic Growth
text: My Capital Ideas column in this week’s Sunday Review mentions a new report from the Congressional Research Service — a nonpartisan government group that provides analysis to Congress — on the relationship between tax cuts and economic growth.

headline: Mitt Romney, Liquidationist
text: How times have changed. Back in 2004, Greg Mankiw declared, in the Economic Report of the President, that

headline: An Inside Look, but Through the Club’s Lens
text: The Fox Sports executives behind “Being: Liverpool,” a six-part series about the British soccer club that starts Sunday afternoon, recognize that it will be compared to HBO’s “Hard Knocks” and “24/7.”

headline: A Rally for Warren, as Massachusetts Senate Race Intensifies
text: Elizabeth Warren, the Democratic candidate who has seemed on the ropes in the hard-fought Massachusetts Senate race, has planned a major rally for Saturday in Boston with Gov. Deval Patrick.

headline: After Days of Unrest in Muslim World, a Fragile Calm Takes Hold
text: CAIRO — Under intense pressure from Washington, Egyptian security forces arrested hundreds of protesters around the American Embassy in Cairo on Saturday as political leaders struggled to deal with the fallout caused by the week of unrest.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: House Honors Americans Killed in Attack on Consulate in Libya
text: A bipartisan resolution is expected to pass through the House next week, recognizing the four Americans killed in the attack this week on the American Consulate in Benghazi, Libya. Speaker John A. Boehner and Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the Republican leader, drafted the resolution late Friday evening, along with Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader, and Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the Democratic whip, to honor those killed in the attack and to condemn the anti-American violence that rippled throughout Egypt and Yemen.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Third Saturday of College Football
text: The stars remained aligned for another Saturday of college football. Paul Myerberg is in Manhattan. Tim Rohan is in East Lansing, Mich., for tonight’s game between Notre Dame and Michigan State. Ray Glier is in Fayetteville for Arkansas-Alabama. Stick around for updates and analysis.

headline: Forward Passing, Behind the Back
text: It has always amazed me how little literary attention has been paid to professional football’s early days. Baseball historians have put the game under a microscope. There is probably a book out there that will tell you what Babe Ruth ate for breakfast on the day he swatted his 714th home run. The story of the N.F.L.’s formative years, on the other hand, is still largely untold.

headline: For a 2011 Draft Pick, the Sitting and Fretting Could Finally Be Over
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Marvin Austin thought about it. How could he not? As the days and weeks and months went by, Austin, the Giants defensive tackle who was drafted in the second round in 2011 but has not played an N.F.L. regular-season snap, could not help wondering if his professional career might end before it ever began.

headline: Take the Bus, and Watch the New Ideas Flow
text: This interview with  Jarrod Moses, founder and chief executive of the United Entertainment Group, a marketing agency, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: A Player’s Concussion, a Family’s Ordeal
text: FORT WORTH — Mitch White watched football last Sunday, a framed New Orleans Saints jersey mounted on a wall over his shoulder at his home. White watches football differently from most people. He likes to analyze the offensive line, fitting for a tackle out of Oregon State who was a sixth-round draft pick of the Saints in 2001. And on most days, around the hour the early games reach halftime, White needs to lie down for a nap.

headline: New International Envoy, Meeting With Syrian President, Says Crisis Is Worsening
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The new United Nations peace envoy to Syria, Lakhdar Brahimi, said after a meeting with President Bashar al-Assad on Saturday that the civil war held consequences for “the region, and the whole world,” while acknowledging that he had not yet formulated a plan to address the escalating violence.

headline: On the Sideline, the Jets’ Odd Couple Coach Alike and Think Alike
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Two football coaches go shark fishing off the coast of Florida. One is Rex Ryan, the other is Mike Westhoff. They sit on Westhoff’s boat for hours, sharing laughs while casting lures, but the sharks are not biting. They catch nothing. Well, almost nothing.

headline: South Africa Raids Homes for Weapons of Miners
text: CALITZDORP, South Africa — Hundreds of police officers swarmed the living quarters of workers at a platinum mine 60 miles northwest of here on Saturday, searching for illegal weapons as part of a new push by the government to end a series of violent wildcat strikes that have unsettled the nation.

headline: Mira Nair’s ‘Reluctant Fundamentalist’
text: The director Mira Nair discusses her latest film, “The Reluctant Fundamentalist.”

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Many people look forward to the Split Decisions puzzles, and it’s really a shame that they don’t come along more often.

headline: Pope Makes Plea for Religious Freedom
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Pope Benedict XVI on Saturday implored young Christians not to emigrate from Lebanon, saying they were “meant to be protagonists” as the country moved forward, and urging them to forge closer bonds with Muslim youth.

headline: A Wide-Open Field, and the Nascar Chase Is On
text: The Nascar driver Jeff Gordon vowed to grow a mustache if he managed to climb from deep in the standings to earn a berth in this year’s Chase for the Sprint Cup. After he eked out the final spot in the 12-car field in the last race of the regular season, Gordon’s stubble is showing heading into Sunday’s playoff opener at Chicagoland Speedway.

headline: Fundamentals From Mira Nair
text: TORONTO — The director Mira Nair has  comedies, multicultural dramas and period pieces in her filmography, but she hadn’t tackled the thriller genre until now. Her latest film, “The Reluctant Fundamentalist,” opened at the Venice Film Festival before playing here in a gala presentation. It was acquired by IFC Films this week for distribution. An adaptation of of Mohsin Hamid’s novel, the film follows a young Pakistani man (Riz Ahmed) who goes to the United States to pursue the American dream. But after the 9/11 attacks, the way he is perceived in the country, and subsequently the way he perceives the country, shifts. In the video above, Ms. Nair, who hails from India, speaks about the film and ways she hopes its subject will create both a dialogue and a bridge of understanding between the United States and Pakistan.

headline: No Deal in N.H.L. Dispute as Lockout Deadline Passes
text: After weeks of fitful negotiations, rejected offers and prickly rhetoric, the deadline for the N.H.L. to avoid a lockout passed without a resolution.

headline: Man Linked to Film in Protests Is Questioned
text: LOS ANGELES — One of the men behind the anti-Muslim film trailer on YouTube that has set off violent protests at Western embassies across the Middle East was taken in for questioning by federal probation officers early Saturday morning, law enforcement officials said.

headline: U.S. Is Preparing for a Long Siege of Arab Unrest
text: WASHINGTON — After days of anti-American violence across the Muslim world, the White House is girding itself for an extended period of turmoil that will test the security of American diplomatic missions and President Obama’s ability to shape the forces of change in the Middle East.

headline: A U.S. Envoy Who Plunged Into Arab Life
text: J. Christopher Stevens, the American ambassador to Libya who was killed in an assault on a diplomatic mission there last week, was happy to gossip, but was revered for listening. A northern Californian with a toothy grin, he had a passion for the Arab world and its language, and he went out of his way to use it, whether with officials or shopkeepers, in an effort to show respect.

headline: Now, Wie Seeking to Be First on the Leader Board
text: HOYLAKE, England — With no golf to occupy her, Michelle Wie went shopping Friday in Liverpool and bought two pairs of pants. Not unlike other labels she has acquired, one pair did not fit.

headline: A Chinese Leader Returns Amid Tumult
text: BEIJING — The reappearance on Saturday of Xi Jinping, a top Chinese leader who had vanished from public view, removes one question mark facing the Communist Party, but a wave of protests against Japan is a sign that internal power struggles are far from over.

headline: Kendrick, Phillies Handyman, Sparks Playoff Push as Starter
text: The end of July had been so seismic for the Philadelphia Phillies that it was easy to miss their first trade of August. By then, they had already traded two veteran outfielders, Shane Victorino and Hunter Pence, and re-signed an ace starter, Cole Hamels, for six years. They were rebuilding for the future and recommitting to their present, all at once.

headline: Finding What Needs Fixing
text: WHEN I was in seventh grade, my father sold his word processing company in Washington, D.C. My parents always wanted to live on a boat in retirement, and I was the last child at home, so it was feasible.

headline: In Britain, a Stunner of a Summer, Quite
text: HOYLAKE, England — British sports are in the midst of a glorious Indian summer, the tennis player Andy Murray’s victory in the United States Open final taking place on the same day Britain’s 65 Olympic medalists and 120 Paralympic medalists were honored in a London parade. Then the best golfers in the world descended on Royal Liverpool Golf Club for the Women’s British Open, the year’s final major.

headline: How to Solve a Career Cliffhanger
text: THE numbers didn’t add up: Ten years of writing soap operas on network television. Four Emmy Awards. One Writers Guild Award for script of the year. Then four months out of work. And zero job offers.

headline: With the Crowds Gone, It’s Down to Serious Fishing
text: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — Striped bass are nocturnal, and every year at this time, Kathi Pogoda becomes nocturnal too.

headline: Texas Tech Confronts Coaching Turbulence
text: Kirby Hocutt’s first major public appearance as the athletic director of Texas Tech in March 2011 was to introduce the men’s basketball coach, Billy Gillispie.

headline: After Injury, Beard Embraces New Outlook, and Team
text: During Alana Beard’s pregame introduction and after every basket she made, the crowd at Verizon Center in Washington cheered.

headline: 30 Seconds With Dwyane Wade
text: Dwyane Wade, a seven-time N.B.A. All-Star, has won two championships with the Miami Heat and an Olympic gold medal. But he wants the top of his résumé to read like the title of his new memoir, “A Father First: How My Life Became Bigger Than Basketball.”

headline: Some Republicans Try Out a New Campaign Theme: Bipartisanship
text: WASHINGTON — A woman who appears in an advertisement supporting Representative Jon Runyan, a New Jersey Republican, boasts about how he works “with both parties.”

headline: Padres to Honor Jerry Coleman
text: The Milwaukee Brewers unveiled a statue of their longtime radio voice on Aug. 31, and now the San Diego Padres are doing the same. The Brewers honored Bob Uecker, and the Padres planned to honor Jerry Coleman on Saturday.

headline: Forgoing College to Pursue Dreams
text: EDEN FULL should be back at Princeton by now. She should be hustling to class, hitting the books, acing tests. In short, she should be climbing that old-school ladder toward a coveted spot among America’s future elite.

headline: Death at Guantánamo Bay
text: Adnan Farhan Abdul Latif, a Yemeni citizen and one of the first detainees sent to Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in January 2002, died there earlier this month. There is no official autopsy report yet, but in his decade in prison he had gone on hunger strikes and made several suicide attempts.

headline: In Dueling Ads, Candidates Seek to Politicize Issues of China and Manufacturing
text: United States-China relations continue to surface as an issue on the campaign trail, particularly in battleground states like Ohio where manufacturing is a major force in the local economy. Now both President Obama and Mitt Romney are running television commercials that trade accusations over who is softer on China, and who is more to blame for sending American jobs there.

headline: Role-Playing at the Range, Bin Laden in Their Sights
text: NEW HOPE, Minn. — Gripping a modified AR-15 assault rifle, Nathan Schneider threw open a bedroom door and crossed the threshold, his barrel blazing as a man dressed like Osama bin Laden fell motionless on the floor.

headline: European Bank Overhaul Meets Opposition From Finance Ministers
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — A plan by the European Union to overhaul bank supervision and help troubled lenders directly ran into a wall of opposition on Saturday as finance ministers from major nations like Germany, Poland and Sweden raised objections.

headline: Keeping Score: Steals Drought Unlikely to End Soon
text: Billy Hamilton, a shortstop in the Reds minor league system, thrilled the baseball world this season by stealing 155 bases, a professional record. But as exciting as his play was, there remains the question of how he would fit in the majors now that stolen bases are largely a thing of the past.

headline: A Push for Clemency as an Execution Nears
text: PHILADELPHIA — The scheduled execution of a convicted murderer has prompted pleas for clemency from thousands of people who argue that he should be spared because he had been sexually abused by his victim.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 16
text: Rising unrest in the Arab world will dominate this week’s Sunday shows, with each broadcast focusing almost exclusively on diplomacy and the fallout from the attack that killed four Americans at the United States Consulate in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: Tucson Schools Overhaul a Program to Help Struggling Hispanic Students
text: TUCSON — The forecast for the year ahead is dire, so officials in the public school district here, the oldest in the state, summoned parents to an urgent meeting one evening to lay out the options: close schools and increase class sizes or impose across-the-board pay cuts, making it harder for the district to recruit quality teachers.

headline: The Talk of China
text: Beijing

headline: It’s Not About the Video
text: THE greatest mistake to be made right now, with our embassies under assault and crowds chanting anti-American slogans across North Africa and the Middle East, is to believe that what’s happening is a completely genuine popular backlash against a blasphemous anti-Islamic video made right here in the U.S.A.

headline: Neocons Slither Back
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Scandal Poses a Riddle: Will India Ever Be Able to Tackle Corruption?
text: NEW DELHI — His business rivals never fully understood how Manoj Jayaswal got so rich so fast, except that he often seemed joined at the hip with powerful politicians. He hosted them at lavish parties, entertained them at his daughter’s opulent Thai wedding and stood among them at India’s presidential palace, where a year ago he was praised as a leader in the India growth story.

headline: The Foreign Relations Fumbler
text: DIPLOMACY is a minefield, and Mitt Romney spent the last week blowing up his foreign policy credentials to be president. He raised doubts about his capacity to deal with global crises, and we were left hoping that if that 3 a.m. call ever went to him, he’d have set up call forwarding.

headline: Young Lives, Lost in the Fog of War
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — These days, Abdul Farhad tries to sleep with the lights on in his bedroom and his eyes wide open, because as soon as he closes them he is back in his shop in central Kabul and it is 11:30 a.m. on the eighth of September.

headline: Sometimes, a Candidate Is Meant to Look Plastic
text: Those cashing in on the Republican and Democratic conventions included vendors selling pins, T-shirts and dolls. Will saving these trifles make anyone rich in the future?

headline: Afghans Act to Fill Top Security Posts
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan lawmakers approved all three of the president’s nominees for the government’s top security jobs on Saturday, avoiding a prolonged power vacuum as the country confronted multiple reminders of the fragility of its security.

headline: World Hunger: The Problem Left Behind
text: THE drought-induced run-up in corn prices is a reminder that we’re nowhere near solving the problem of feeding the world. The price surge, the third major international food price spike in the last five years, casts more doubt on the assumption that widespread economic development leads to corresponding gains in agriculture.

headline: G.M.O.’s: Let’s Label ’Em
text: IT’S not an exaggeration to say that almost everyone wants to see the labeling of genetically engineered materials contained in their food products. And on Nov. 6, in what’s unquestionably among the most important non-national votes this year, Californians will have the opportunity to make that happen — at least in theory — by weighing in on Proposition 37.

headline: Berlusconi Magazine to Publish Duchess Photos
text: ROME — An Italian magazine owned by former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi announced Saturday that it planned to publish photographs of the former Kate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, sunbathing topless, just as its sister French magazine did on Friday.

headline: The Road to Retirement
text: Even before the Great Recession, Americans were not saving enough, if anything, for retirement, and policy experts were warning of a looming catastrophe. The economic downturn and its consequences — including losses in jobs, income, investments and home equity — have made that bad situation much worse.

headline: Kick-Starts From a Phone and the Fed
text: HELP for the beleaguered economy came last week from two powerhouses: the Federal Reserve and ... Apple.

headline: Surviving the Pain at the Roots
text: I came out of the womb scratching. Mitts had to be put on my hands so I would stop clawing my skin. When I was seven and got mad I would bite myself, raising welts on my arms. This was already well into the time when I would have to touch certain spots on the cabinets, on the sidewalk, with my fingers and toes. At 12, after a seriously traumatic event, I began to pull out my hair. Every day since then, for the past 18 years, the hairs on my body have gone one by one, in the thousands, as I have tried to cope with overwhelming anxiety from a chaotic series of experiences that from birth have made me feel inside as if my very life is at stake if I do not pick and pull and bite and scratch.

headline: In Britain, One Player Blows Away the Field
text: HOYLAKE, England — Fairways as narrow as tongue depressors did not much bother Jiyai Shin, who hit all but one Saturday during the delayed second round of the Women’s British Open. Royal Liverpool Golf Club’s humpback greens were no worry, either; Shin did not miss any en route to a masterly eight-under-par 64, which left her at minus nine at the tournament’s halfway point.

headline: Mitt Romney and Foreign Policy
text: My Sunday column argues that Mitt Romney’s foreign policy lapses last week are indicative of a larger problem: This is a world he doesn’t get, or gets wrong. Romney has clearly thought a good deal about domestic issues in the six years he’s been studying to be president, but there’s not much indication of interest or expertise in foreign affairs. And that’s putting it mildly.

headline: Don’t Show Me the Money!
text: THESPIAN friends perform “The Seagull” in their garden. Only minutes into the first act, a lovely young woman named Masha, sick of hearing the lovesick schoolteacher Medvedenko whine about his penury, blurts out, “All you ever do is talk and talk about money.” That’s when it dawns on me: I’m sick of the subject, too. For the rest of Act I, I find myself ruminating about the glut of financial data that daily clogs the news: Libor and MF Global Holdings; HSBC’s money-laundering of Mexican drug-cartel money; “the London Whale” whose huge trades cost J.P. Morgan Chase billions; leveraged buyouts and mortgage-backed securities and derivatives and stimulus packages, Bain Capital and the tottering euro and the Greek bailout. Saul Bellow referred to this quotidian fretting about world affairs as “crisis chatter.” Today’s crises are all about what is euphemistically called “the financial services industry” — that is to say, they’re all about money.

headline: The Vast Potential of Data-Driven Discovery
text: To the Editor:

headline: When It’s on Paper, It Belongs to You
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Search of Political Champions for the Poor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Has America Lost Its Way?
text: Readers discuss whether the country is on the right track.

headline: When the Privacy Button Is Already Pressed
text: IT could usher in a new era of online privacy. Or it might bowdlerize the Internet as we know it.

headline: A Synthetic Windpipe
text: Doctors have begun performing surgeries to replace windpipes, or tracheas, with plastic scaffolding seeded with a patient’s own cells.

headline: Smartphone Ads and Their Drawbacks
text: AT two inches wide and one-third of an inch tall, a display ad shown on a smartphone isn’t much of a canvas for a creative marketer seeking to promote a product or service.

headline: A Condo Was Sold, Until It Wasn’t
text: HORROR stories abound across Foreclosure Nation. But once in a while, a new one comes along to remind us just how dysfunctional our mortgage market is.

headline: Mining the Power (and the Profit) of Conversation
text: BEFORE there were TED Talks, there were Della talks.

headline: For India’s Children, Philanthropy Isn’t Enough
text: MEENA DEVI is only 10 years old, but she’s the head of her household. She cooks, cleans and takes care of her 11-year-old brother, Sunil, while a 14-year-old brother, Anil, works at a faraway brick kiln in a neighboring state. The three have been orphans since their mother died of starvation three years ago. They have an aunt in their village, but the most she’s ever done is send over food to their mud hut.

headline: An Adverb That Defies Certainty
text: The word ‘almost’ is like blush after makeup, just that requisite fuzziness, like ambiguity in an instance of total candor.

headline: Thousands Attend Rally for Chicago Teachers as Union Nears Contract
text: CHICAGO — As union and school board lawyers toiled in private here on Saturday to finish a contract that could soon lift the first teacher strike this city has seen in 25 years, a rally — not quite victory party, not quite vitriolic protest — was roaring just miles away.

headline: The Computer as Music Critic
text: THANKS to advances in computing power, we can analyze music in radically new and different ways. Computers are still far from grasping some of the deep and often unexpected nuances that release our most intimate emotions. However, by processing vast amounts of raw data and performing unprecedented large-scale analyses beyond the reach of teams of human experts, they can provide valuable insight into some of the most basic aspects of musical discourse, including the evolution of popular music over the years. Has there been an evolution? Can we measure it? And if so, what do we observe?

headline: At Rally, Elizabeth Warren Takes More Aggressive Stance
text: 9:35 a.m. | Updated BOSTON — During a rally on Saturday, Elizabeth Warren questioned the record and credibility of Senator Scott P. Brown, energizing a crowd of more than 700 people as the Senate race in Massachusetts turned more aggressive and pointed.

headline: Obama Ad Tries to Answer: Are You Better Off Than Four Years Ago?
text: A new ad from President Obama confronts head on one of the most potentially damaging questions lingering over his re-election hopes: Are you better off than you were four years ago?

headline: Dear Bankers: Thanks for Wrecking Our Lives ...
text: TOMORROW is the first anniversary of the Occupy Wall Street movement’s encampment at Zuccotti Park. Some of the protesters there created a Web site for Americans who couldn’t join them in Lower Manhattan. Called Occupy the Boardroom, the site invited people across the country to write detailed letters to the executives and directors of banks. The site’s developers promised to deliver them as e-mail and in person.

headline: Ed Hochuli
text: Ed Hochuli is a trial lawyer and one of the 121 referees the N.F.L. has locked out of work because of disputes over pay and pensions. Known for his bodybuilder biceps, he was the model for the official in the Madden N.F.L. video games. After some  replacement referees’ blunders in season-opener games, fans are calling for his and his colleagues’ swift return.

headline: A Military Success Story
text: As the country approaches the first anniversary of the repeal of “don’t ask, don’t tell” on Sept. 20, politicians and others who warned of disastrous consequences if gay people were allowed to serve openly in the military are looking pretty foolish.

headline: Must Great Leaders Be Gregarious?
text: DISTANT. Aloof. Concealed inside “a layer of self-protective ice,” as Jonathan Alter put it. President Obama has been roundly criticized for his introverted personality.

headline: Don’t Tell Anyone, but the Stimulus Worked
text: Republicans howled on Thursday when the Federal Reserve, at long last, took steps to energize the economy. Some were furious at the thought that even a little economic boost might work to benefit President Obama just before an election. “It is going to sow some growth in the economy,” said Raul Labrador, a freshman Tea Party congressman from Idaho, “and the Obama administration is going to claim credit.”

headline: The Power of Political Communion
text: AS the 2012 presidential race enters the homestretch, both parties vow that this election is not just a choice between different policies. It is a cosmic decision between “two different visions, two different value sets,” as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told delegates at the Democratic National Convention. Behind the competing catchphrases lurks another contest, one that illuminates this war of worldviews. It is a tale of two Catholicisms.

headline: Attack by Fringe Group Highlights the Problem of Libya’s Militias
text: CAIRO — Ansar al-Shariah, the brigade of rebel fighters that witnesses say led the attack on the United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi, holds that democracy is incompatible with Islam. It has paraded the streets with weapons calling for an Islamic state, and a few months ago its leader boasted publicly that its fighters could flatten a foreign consulate.

headline: Yankees Beat Rays to Keep Pace in East
text: In the Yankees’ clubhouse on Friday, Ivan Nova fidgeted. He said he felt restless and anxious, believing he had more to prove in his rocky season.

headline: Challenged on Medicare, G.O.P. Loses Ground
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Maria Rubin is one of the coveted independent voters in this swing state — so independent that she will not say whether she is voting for President Obama or Mitt Romney. She does share her age (63) and, more quickly, her opinion on Medicare: “I’m not in favor of changing it, or eliminating it.”

headline: Jerome Kilty, Who Made a Career of Interpreting Shaw, Dies at 90
text: Jerome Kilty, an actor and playwright known for writing epistolary dramas — most notably “Dear Liar,” his adaptation of 40 years of amorous correspondence between George Bernard Shaw and one of the London theater’s most temperamental actresses — died on Sept. 6 in Norwalk, Conn. He was 90.

headline: Several Arrests at Occupy Wall Street March
text: On the first of three days of events planned for the one-year anniversary of Occupy Wall Street, about 250 people marched down Broadway from Washington Square toward Zuccotti Park, accompanied by a large number of police officers on foot, in marked and unmarked cars, and riding scooters.

headline: Michael Wreszin, Biographer of American Radicals, Dies at 85
text: Michael Wreszin, a biographer of radical 20th-century American intellectuals who were prominent antiwar activists, among them the social critic Dwight Macdonald, died on Aug. 12 in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Tide Put Beating on Razorbacks; So Do Razorbacks
text: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — Tyler Wilson, Arkansas’s No. 1 quarterback, marched into the auditorium where the Razorbacks hold their postgame news conferences still in his shoulder pads and still wearing his No. 8 jersey. He did not play in Saturday’s humiliating 52-0 loss to No. 1 Alabama because of a concussion, but he had plenty to say in a 67-second rant.

headline: A First: Organs Tailor-Made With Body’s Own Cells

headline: Struggling at Plate Since Injury to Head

headline: Tony Goldman, SoHo Pioneer, Dies at 68
text: Tony Goldman, whose investor’s eye for spotting battered neighborhoods prime for rejuvenation led him to help revive SoHo in Manhattan in the 1970s and South Beach in Florida in the ’80s, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 68.

headline: A Gentle Giant Stays Behind
text: On Sept. 15, 1862, Gen. Thomas J. “Stonewall” Jackson and his Confederates trapped the 12,700-man federal garrison in Harpers Ferry, Va. “We were as helpless as rats in a cage,” moaned one Union soldier. The federal commander, Col. Dixon S. Miles, had little choice but to surrender. Moments after the decision, the explosion of a stray artillery shell resulted in his mortal wounding. A subordinate made the final arrangements.

text: In 2002, Representative Paul Sadler of Henderson, one of the most powerful Democrats in the Texas Legislature, announced he was not running for re-election. headline: In Event of Lockout, Swedish League Faces Challenge in Attempt to Bar N.H.L. Players
text: The Swedish Elitserien has been the only top European league to say that it will not sign N.H.L. players to short-term contracts if the N.H.L. locks them out, as is expected to happen when the current labor deal expires at midnight Saturday. But many believe the Elitserien would have to join other leagues in welcoming N.H.L. players under contracts of any length, since the Elitserien’s contract with its players union does not include bans on short-term deals.

headline: Mejia Bunts Well and Pitches Poorly in Mets’ Loss
text: MILWAUKEE — The suicide squeeze bunt that Mets pitcher Jenrry Mejia dropped down in the fourth inning Saturday night not only gave him a lead against the Milwaukee Brewers, but also gave him an odd distinction. Thirty-five games into his major league career, Mejia picked up his first major league run batted in before his first major league win.

headline: Notre Dame Makes a Statement by Stuffing Michigan State
text: EAST LANSING, Mich. — Two years ago here, a smirking Mark Dantonio shook Brian Kelly’s hand. In Kelly’s third game as Notre Dame’s coach, Dantonio had called a fake field goal in overtime to win, beginning a two-year run that redefined Michigan State as calm, cool and clutch. After that, the Spartans won 10 of their next 11 games decided by 10 points or fewer, while Kelly’s Fighting Irish went 8-5 in each of his first two seasons as Notre Dame faltered in its seemingly endless quest to regain a place atop the college football mountain.

headline: College Football Around the Country

headline: Audacious Raid on NATO Base Shows Taliban’s Reach

headline: Letter From Bad Check Restitution Program
text: Thousands of letters are sent each year to people across the country who have written bad checks, threatening them with jail if they don’t pay up. They often bear the seal and signature of the local district attorney’s office but are actually from debt-collection companies.

headline: A Call From The Kremlin
text: MOSCOW — Secretly I had felt that I had made Vladimir Putin up. I had spent years studying his interviews, his speeches and his ad-libbed statements, and he had come out flat and gray. Some people claimed he had a secret dimension, others said he possessed charm — I saw no evidence of it. But then, I had never talked to the man: As a journalist, I had apparently been blacklisted by the Kremlin at the very beginning of his reign — I could not even get accredited to a press conference.

headline: Russia’s Political Weekend: ‘We Will All Answer for This.’
text: The anti-Putin opposition was on the streets again on Saturday in Moscow, as our colleagues Ellen Barry, David Herszenhorn, James Hill and others documented in full. One of the people they quoted, Gennady Gudkov — described by Ellen as a rumpled veteran of Russia’s post-Communist fray — was stripped of his parliamentary seat on Friday. In this video of his farewell speech, in Russia (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n8c_vqEdI0o&feature=youtu.be), he told the attentive if scant members of the Duma, Russia’s parliament, exactly what he thinks is going on behind the scenes in their country.

headline: Underwater, a Train, a Dinette and Don’t Forget the Chevy
text: Nicki Pombier Berger, who is listed as one of the speakers at an event called Underwater New York, is unequivocal: She is “terrified” of diving. She has never wanted an up-close-and-personal look at what she will be talking about at the South Street Seaport Museum, namely, the stuff that has piled up over time at the bottom of the Hudson River or the East River or New York Harbor — the jetsam of New York.

headline: For Both Campaigns, a Need to Control the Message
text: There is almost nothing more valuable to a presidential campaign than controlling the message.

headline: Disruptions: Let Silicon Valley Eat … Ramen Noodles?
text: You don’t have to spend much time in Silicon Valley to start hearing that the people don’t care about money. People here are just trying to make the world a better place. Entrepreneurs and venture capitalists eat ramen noodles for dinner and drive old, clunky Hondas to work. If they do make money, that’s just a tiny cherry on top of their altruistic Tofutti soy whip sundae.That’s what people here would like the world to think. Let’s be realistic, these start-ups aren’t nonprofit organizations.

headline: Israeli Leader Says Iran Is Closer to Building a Nuclear Bomb
text: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel reiterated on Sunday that the best way to prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon was to draw a “red line” that, if crossed, would trigger military intervention. He also denied that he was injecting himself into one of the most divisive foreign policy issues of the American presidential campaign.

headline: Israeli Leader Makes Case Against Iran on U.S. TV
text: WASHINGTON — Having been rebuffed privately by President Obama last week, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel took to the airwaves in the United States on Sunday to warn that Iran was only six or seven months from having “90 percent” of what it needed to make an atomic bomb.

headline: Romney Cancels Appearance After Crash
text: BOSTON — Mitt Romney abruptly canceled his sole campaign event on Sunday, in the swing state of Colorado, after an airplane crash at the small airport where he had been scheduled to land.

headline: ‘Resident Evil: Retribution’ Leads Box Office
text: “Resident Evil: Retribution,” the fifth installment of this video game-based series, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, while two art-house films — “The Master” and “Arbitrage” — attracted crowds in limited release, a reflection of how starved filmgoers are for sophisticated cinema.

headline: No Easy Answers on How to Fix the Banks in Europe
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Beleaguered countries like Spain have been counting on a quick and neat way to fix their banks without taking on more crippling debt.

headline: Acne: Spring 2013 RTW
text: London

headline: Replacement Official Removed From Crew for Being a Saints Fan
text: The N.F.L. said it has been generally pleased with the performance of replacement officials. They were not pleased Sunday, however, to see one of them wearing New Orleans Saints apparel on his Facebook page — hours before he was supposed to be part of the crew at the Saints’ game against the Carolina Panthers.

headline: Earnings in United States Are Beginning to Feel a Pinch
text: The boom in American corporate profits, which has far outpaced the gains in the broader economy since the end of the last recession, is faltering.

headline: A Doctor Tied to Her Patients and the Mob
text: The Fox series “The Mob Doctor,” which begins on Monday night, is an odd hybrid, a medical drama merged with a Mafia morality play. It’s hard to tell from one episode how sustainable this gimmick will be, but from the pilot one thing is sure: the writers never encountered the adage “less is more.”

headline: Butterflies Roam at a Concert Hall in Infancy, Still Without a Roof
text: You will not immediately be able to know, when it opens a little over a year from now, that there is anything very special about the Original Music Workshop. Aside from a few large windows, from the outside it will look like any of the old factory buildings scattered throughout Williamsburg.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Acne
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: In Connecticut, Wall Street Community May Limit Obama Victory
text: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Connecticut, the Constitution State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Paul Bass, the editor of The New Haven Independent; Gary Rose, an associate professor of political science at Sacred Heart University; Ronald Schurin, an associate professor of political science at the University of Connecticut; and Kevin F. Rennie, a columnist for The Hartford Courant and a former Republican state senator and representative.

headline: A Little Bit of Europe Big Enough for New York
text: Twice on Friday night, Andreas Stadler, the director of the Austrian Cultural Forum in New York, delivered the same speech, more or less, at the Czech Center on the Upper East Side. Each time, he was welcoming an audience to a concert presented on the second night of Moving Sounds, a festival of contemporary-classical and electronic music that the forum has mounted annually since 2009.

headline: I Get Mail
text: Yes, it’s a psychology journal.

headline: For Open Winner, It Only Looks Easy
text: HOYLAKE, England — A wave that formed 35 years ago with the Japanese star Chako Higuchi’s victory in the 1977 L.P.G.A. Championship crested on the Wirral Peninsula on Sunday when Jiyai Shin of South Korea won the Women’s British Open in a rout.

headline: LeGrand,  ‘Buc for Life,’ Receives Warm Ovation Before Giants-Bucs Game
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Eric LeGrand might be the only person who can wear a Tampa Bay Buccaneers jersey for the coin toss at MetLife Stadium and be cheered by Giants fans.

headline: Ron Paul on Money Market Funds
text: Brad DeLong has a post on Paul Ryan’s hysterical reaction to QE3, which is worth reading just for this:

headline: Heck, He’s Abandoned the Whole Austro-Hungarian Empire
text: Liz Cheney Claims Obama Has “Abandoned” Czechoslovakia (Which Hasn’t Existed Since The Early ’90s).

headline: Choosing All of the Above, the Yankees Stay on Top
text: It was in Tampa Bay earlier this month that questions flared up regarding how the Yankees’ offense should play the rest of the season. Should they bunt more, as the hitting instructor Kevin Long initially advocated after a tough loss at Tropicana Field? Should they employ the small-ball tactics that Alex Rodriguez espoused a day later after a victory, or should they continue to play the way they had, slugging their way to victories as Manager Joe Girardi insisted they would?

headline: Mary Katrantzou: Spring 2013 RTW
text: London

headline: With Frantic Fourth, Manning and Giants Slip Past Bucs
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants Coach Tom Coughlin’s sideline histrionics are legendary moments of football cinema. The death stares, the icy glares and the occasional (but impressive) hurling of perfectly creased play charts all dovetail nicely with Coughlin’s perpetually ruddy complexion, making for an entertaining spectacle as he upbraids his charges.

headline: Pakistanis Try to Storm U.S. Outpost; One Is Killed
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — One person was killed and dozens of people were injured when anti-American protesters tried to storm the American Consulate in the southern port city of Karachi and clashed for several hours with the police and paramilitary troops on Sunday evening, rescue workers and police officials said.

headline: Why I Love Mormonism
text: I’ve spent what is rapidly becoming nine years in New York City. It’s been a total blast. But as a transplanted Englishman one thing to which I’ve become rather sensitive in that time is which prejudices New Yorkers are permitted to express in public. Among  my horribly overeducated and hugely liberal friends, expressions of racism are completely out of the question, Islamophobia is greeted with a slow shaking of the head and anti-Semitism is a memory associated with distant places that one sometimes visits — like France.

headline: A ’60s Landmark in the Eyes of Children
text: It’s fitting that “40 Dancers do 40 Dances for the Dancers,” a project conceived and directed by Clarinda Mac Low, was ruled by children — at least on opening night. Part of Ms. Mac Low’s intention for the event, as she states in program notes, is to recreate “a child’s-eye view of the 1970s New York ‘avant-garde’ arts world.” As the daughter of the poet, composer and performance artist  Jackson Mac Low, who died in 2004, she writes from experience. The children performing on Thursday evening at Danspace Project at St. Mark’s Church — notably, the adorable Ignacio Achugar-Granoff — offered some of the evening’s most genuine encounters.

headline: In a Dark Church, Nuances of Sound Turn Symphonic
text: Eleh, as he is called, walked down the aisle of Our Lady of Lebanon Cathedral in Brooklyn Heights after all the lights had been shut off and sat cross-legged before his equipment: an old Sequential Circuits analog keyboard synthesizer; a modular synthesizer about the shape of a large cash register, with red, yellow, orange, purple and black patch cables; and a hand-held digital multimeter to measure sound frequencies. You could see his outline only in the tiny readout lights of his gear. He is compact, of middling height and has short hair. Healthy. Maybe mid-30s.

headline: Surging Brewers Beat Mets as Braun Hits Career-High 40th Homer
text: MILWAUKEE — Like many players who reach milestones, Ryan Braun tried to frame his accomplishments in the context of a victory. The Milwaukee Brewers needed to beat the Mets on Sunday afternoon to maintain their place in the clacking multicar train of the race for the second National League wild card, and Braun helped that along with two of Milwaukee’s three solo home runs off Chris Young in a 3-0 victory.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Temperley
text: The Look: Grace Kelly gone London rogue.

headline: At Harlem Hospital, Murals Get a New Life
text: When the Works Progress Administration commissioned murals for Harlem Hospital Center in 1936, it easily approved the sketches submitted by seven artists, which depicted black people at work and at play throughout history. The hospital, however, objected, saying four of the sketches focused too much on “Negro” subject matter and that blacks “may not form the greater part of the Community” in years to come.

headline: Time Travel With Einstein: Glass’s Opera Returns to the Stage
text: As the audience milled into the Brooklyn Academy of Music for Saturday night’s performance of “Einstein on the Beach,” an exhilarating revival of the pathbreaking 1976 opera by the composer Philip Glass and the director Robert Wilson, the piece seemed already to have started.

headline: Itsy Bitsy Bit
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome back to another week of puzzling! I always enjoy Mondays. Well, not the concept (getting up for work or school after a relaxing weekend), but the puzzles. It feels like a fresh start after wrestling with the increasingly difficult week, tackling the Friday and Saturday grids, investing time in the Sunday … and then, poof! All that is gone, and we have a nice, simple Monday puzzle to sail through. It restores my faith in humanity, I tell you.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include the current account deficit for the second quarter (Tuesday); housing starts for August and existing home sales for August (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims, the Philadelphia Fed index for September and leading economic indicators for August (Thursday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Jonathan Saunders: Spring 2013 RTW
text: London

headline: A Future With Swords, Not iPhones
text: Armageddon comes in every shade of black: nuclear war, global warming, pandemic, alien invasion, zombie takeover or, even in some cases, a quirk of physics.

headline: History Measured in War, Sex and Berets
text: The second volume of Ken Follett’s Century Trilogy, “Winter of the World,” improves on “Fall of Giants,” the first. For one thing, it weighs in at 940 pages, which by Follett standards is concise. For another, it dispenses with some of the waxenness of its 985-page predecessor and breathes life into its fictional characters, many of whose parents appeared in the first book. The second-generation “Winter of the World” crew does enough procreating to ensure that Mr. Follett’s third installment will be crowded too.

headline: Distinguished Family Turns Out in Force
text: The name Sirota has been one to reckon with in New York musical circles for some years now. Nadia Sirota, a stellar young violist who has served as muse to prominent composers like Nico Muhly and Judd Greenstein, also cuts a high profile as a presenter on the Web-radio station Q2. Jonah Sirota, another violist and Nadia’s older brother, is a member of the respected Chiara String Quartet. The Rev. Dr. Victoria R. Sirota, Nadia and Jonah’s mother, is an accomplished organist and the canon pastor of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

headline: Woman’s Day Turns 75 While Looking Forward
text: A MAGAZINE that was introduced when the newest technology to reach consumers was the radio soap opera wants to demonstrate its relevance to readers — and advertisers — with a commemoration of its 75th anniversary that is focused as much on the present and future as the past.
