text: LOS ANGELES — Can smartphone apps become hit movies and television shows?

headline: ‘Einstein on the Beach’
text: Scenes from the revival of Philip Glass’s opera at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: The Puppetry of Quotation Approval
text: Now that it’s become clear that many journalists covering politics and government agree to quotation-approval as a condition of access, it’s tough not to see the pageant of democracy as just that: a carefully constructed performance meant to showcase the participants in the best light.

headline: Selexicons: Your Contributions to ‘That Should Be a Word’
text: One of the great pleasures — and perils — of my “That Should Be a Word” column in The One-Page Magazine comes from the requests I receive to coin a word, generally stemming from an irritation that my suggestions, it seems, cannot mollify. (“I need a word for that person who stands at the party with you and is just nodding — they’re not even listening!” “Okay — nodinage?” “No, that’s not it!”)

headline: Kurdish Separatists Suspected After 8 Turkish Police Officers Are Killed in Blast
text: HATAY, Turkey — Eight police officers were killed and nine were wounded when a land mine exploded early Sunday in southeastern Turkey, the semiofficial news service Anatolian Agency reported.

headline: Shock Value
text: Does art retain the power to shock? Must artists contrive to provoke? Join the discussion with artists, critics, reporters and readers.

headline: Teachers Union in Chicago to Extend Strike Into 2nd Week
text: CHICAGO — The Chicago Teachers Union extended its strike into a second week on Sunday, after significant divisions emerged among union delegates over a deal that only a day before had been described by the union’s leader as “a good contract.”

headline: Despite a Slowdown, Smartphone Advances Are Still Ahead
text: The arrival of the original iPhone in 2007 was a quantum leap for cellphones. Phones had never worked or looked like that.

headline: Andre Brown Breaks Through for Giants
text: A capsule look at the Giants’ victory over the Bucs on Sunday.

headline: As Grocery Dies Off, Down-and-Out Town Lives On, if Barely
text: MENDOTA, Calif. — Westside Grocery, serving this self-described Cantaloupe Center of the World since the 1940s, removed its gasoline pumps around 1980, the result of increased regulation. Fresh steaks and pork chops went by the wayside in the 1990s: too few could afford them.

headline: Canada Auto Workers Chief Renews Threat Strike
text: OTTAWA — Despite making progress with the Ford Motor Company of Canada during contract talks over the weekend, Ken Lewenza, the president of the Canadian Auto Workers union, renewed his threat on Sunday to strike all three Detroit automakers.

headline: Outside the Ring
text: Thirty years after the Korean boxer Duk-koo Kim died following his loss to Ray “Boom Boom” Mancini in Las Vegas, their families continue to heal.

headline: London Fashion: Rethinking Luxury
text: LONDON — It’s good to see Tom Ford nail down a hot look again. Two years ago he staged a private little show in his New York store, asking friends like Julianne Moore, Rachel Feinstein and Rita Wilson to model his first women’s line since leaving Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent. It was a memorable night. Each outfit was a return-to-elegance occasion, as individual as the women involved, and Mr. Ford got a lot of press for withholding photos until the clothes arrived in stores. But then last fall he seemed to reprise styles from his YSL days. Editors expected more. So did Mr. Ford.

headline: Patriot Game
text: The Gregory Brothers present a video-game-inspired musical mash-up of President Obama and Mitt Romney’s speeches from the recent nominating conventions.

headline: ‘Patriot Game’
text: The Republican and Democratic nominating conventions are over and the race for the general election is under way in earnest.

headline: Online Mentors to Guide Women Into the Sciences
text: Hundreds of prominent women working in science, technology, engineering and math will become online mentors for college students next month, part of a six-week program to encourage young women to pursue careers in STEM fields.

headline: New Territory for Ads, With a Moving Target
text: In the next month or two, subway and bus riders will find advertising where they have never seen it before: on the face of their MetroCards, always with them and inescapable — at least for that moment they pay their fare.

headline: On Web, a Fine Line on Free Speech Across the Globe
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For Google last week, the decision was clear. An anti-Islamic video that provoked violence worldwide was not hate speech under its rules because it did not specifically incite violence against Muslims, even if it mocked their faith.

headline: For a Fee, Streaming Local TV
text: On the ninth floor of an old tire factory in Downtown Brooklyn, Joe Lipowski, chief technology officer of a company called Aereo, proudly showed off a steel sheet covered with TV antennas.

headline: Steelers and Errors Send Jets’ Offense Back to Reality
text: PITTSBURGH — It was perhaps inevitable that the Jets, whose surprisingly easy season-opening victory over the Buffalo Bills prompted at least one player to proclaim that the Jets had put the league on notice, would eventually slip back a bit toward the competition.

headline: A Step Back
text: As a boy, Ray Mancini would pore over his father’s scrapbook, a collection of brittle-brown newspaper clippings and sepia-toned glossies, inevitably pausing to study the photograph of his father as a young fighter, his features bloodied and swollen, the right eye clenched shut like the seam of a mussel shell.

headline: Beyond Obamacare
text: WE need death panels.

headline: Karzai Denounces Coalition Over Airstrikes
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two of the most contentious issues dividing the United States and President Hamid Karzai’s administration re-emerged as the Afghan leader condemned American-led forces for killing eight women in airstrikes on Sunday and denounced his American allies for continuing to hold hundreds of Afghan prisoners.

headline: Rallies Planned for Occupy Wall Street Anniversary
text: The crowd sat in a circle at the edge of Battery Park on Friday, as two young women held up a large map of the financial district that had been divided into sectors and marked with assembly points. They explained the plan for early Monday: protesters will gather at those points, then converge in an attempt to surround the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: A Big Void, and Closing It Well
text: It has been 140 days since Mariano Rivera last threw a pitch, and the unspoken reality is that the Yankees have not missed him. For all of Rivera’s brilliance, the Yankees could not have expected him to do more than his successor has done.

headline: London Fashion: Electric Millinery
text: LONDON — In a way, Philip Treacy’s hat show on Sunday night paid homage to the camp extravaganza that used to be common in London and Paris. The last great instigators were Alexander McQueen and Isabella Blow, both close friends of Mr. Treacy’s. He dedicated the show to them, and to Michael Jackson.

headline: Where Daniel the Cuckold and Zig Zag Clown Vie for Office
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Batman is running for office in the Brazilian city of Uberlândia. Not one but two James Bonds are seeking city council seats, in Ponta Grossa and Birigui. Elsewhere in Brazil, voters are being urged to cast ballots for candidates with names like Daniel the Cuckold and Elvis Didn’t Die.

headline: An Unscenic Urban Walk: From Lower Manhattan to Kennedy Airport
text: The neighborhoods turn starkly at first, from the prix fixe brunches and kitchen appliance stores of the tour’s initial leg in Manhattan to the dominoes games and dimly lighted bars that follow.

headline: Hating on Ben Bernanke
text: Last week Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, announced a change in his institution’s recession-fighting strategies. In so doing he seemed to be responding to the arguments of critics who have said the Fed can and should be doing more. And Republicans went wild.

headline: Human Muscle, Regrown on Animal Scaffolding
text: PITTSBURGH — In the months after a roadside bomb in Afghanistan blew off part of his left thigh, Sgt. Ron Strang wondered if he would ever be able to walk normally again.

headline: Extracellular Matrix
text: After 12 operations, Sgt. Ron Strang of the Marines was chosen for an experimental therapy to regrow some of his thigh muscle using a material called extracellular matrix, or E.C.M.

headline: Declassified Documents Shed Light on a 1982 Massacre
text: Declassified documents reveal conversations between high-level American and Israeli officials before, during and after a massacre in Beirut’s Sabra and Shatila refugee camps in 1982.

headline: A Preventable Massacre
text: ON the night of Sept. 16, 1982, the Israeli military allowed a right-wing Lebanese militia to enter two Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut. In the ensuing three-day rampage, the militia, linked to the Maronite Christian Phalange Party, raped, killed and dismembered at least 800 civilians, while Israeli flares illuminated the camps’ narrow and darkened alleyways. Nearly all of the dead were women, children and elderly men.

headline: Getting Your Prescriptions, Without a Prescription
text: Should more medications be made available over the counter, like Claritin was in 2002?

headline: The First Test for Albany’s Ethicists
text: More than a year ago, Gov. Andrew Cuomo and New York’s State Legislature passed a long-overdue ethics law to clean up Albany. The law contained one grave flaw, a supposedly independent Joint Commission on Public Ethics that is made up entirely of political appointees. The tangled controversy surrounding Assemblyman Vito Lopez has presented the commission with its first big test.

headline: Republicans vs. Veterans’ Jobs
text: If you made a list of things lawmakers of both parties profess to value at all times — like “jobs,” “opportunity,” “veterans,” “law enforcement,” “firefighters,” “safe streets,” “small business” — and plugged them into a Congressional bill-writing app, you would probably end up with something like the Veterans Job Corps Act of 2012.

headline: Giants’ Waiting Game Is a Work in Progress
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Seven months later, the Giants did better when it came to handling an opposing defense trying to let them score. But it still wasn’t perfect.

headline: Video Shows Libyans Retrieving Envoy’s Body
text: CAIRO — An amateur video that surfaced Sunday appears to show a crowd removing the motionless body of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens from a window of the American mission in Benghazi, Libya, after it was attacked last week by Islamist militants, adding new details to reports that Mr. Stevens had died of smoke inhalation while locked in a safe room.

headline: Scandal at Florida A&M Leaves a Football Season Without Its Soundtrack
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — It felt like family inside the football stadium at Florida A&M University on Saturday night. Old friends shouted greetings and delivered tight hugs; students clustered in the stands, snapping photos with their cellphones. Grandparents adjusted their orange cushions on the metal bleachers in more or less the same spots they had claimed for decades.

headline: In Lebanon, Pope Laments Strife in Syria, Where the War Rages On
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Standing near what was once the dividing line of Lebanon’s bygone civil war, Pope Benedict XVI said a prayer on Sunday for the victims of the conflict in Syria, where the end is hard to see.

headline: Police Reports Suggest Officers May Sometimes Portray Crimes Less Seriously
text: On a Friday night two years ago, a 17-year-old fired a pistol at a group of young men on the street near Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx; two were struck in the leg.

headline: Show of Strength for Brooklyn Democratic Machine
text: He was one of Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez’s most conspicuous opponents, the young upstart who muscled his way into a district leader’s job in the machine-driven Brooklyn Democratic Party and then used his perch to denounce Mr. Lopez for what he called his patronage and corruption.

headline: As N.H.L. Lockout Begins, So Does a Likely Exodus of Players to Europe
text: Sunday was Day 1 of the N.H.L.’s latest lockout, but its aftershocks already reverberated through professional hockey.

headline: Nicks Limps And Leaps To Big Day For Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Wide receiver Hakeem Nicks displayed the quickness and speed he is renowned for in making 10 catches for a team-leading 199 yards in the Giants’ dramatic 41-34 come-from-behind victory against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

headline: Mideast Unrest Intensifies Debate on U.S. Intervention in Syria
text: DOHA, Qatar — In recent weeks, the growing death toll in Syria pushed that country’s civil war to the top of the Obama administration’s agenda, with some Arab leaders pressing harder for a greater American role in toppling Syria’s leader, Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Longing for a Return to the Beauty of Imperfection
text: My first experience with instant replay was not in sports.

headline: Parking Rules
text: On Monday and Tuesday, because of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Series of Select Guests to Highlight iVillage
text: It might take a village to turn NBC around. Or, at least, an iVillage.

headline: Cultural Clash Fuels Muslims Angry at Online Video
text: CAIRO — Stepping from the cloud of tear gas in front of the American Embassy here, Khaled Ali repeated the urgent question that he said justified last week’s violent protests at United States outposts around the Muslim world.

headline: Jets Replay: Week 2
text: The Jets managed to score just one touchdown in the 27-10 loss to the Steelers in Pittsburgh.

headline: Prevention Magazine to Revamp Its Direction
text: Like many print publications, Prevention, a staple of supermarket checkout lines, has suffered from a drop in ad pages in the last year.

headline: The Detroit of California
text: Unemployment has long been a reality in Mendota, but the town is also being buffeted by poverty, alcohol abuse and other problems.

headline: Giants Replay: Week 2

headline: In Search of Excellent Teaching
text: The Chicago teachers’ strike was prompted in part by a fierce disagreement over how much student test scores will weigh in a new teacher evaluation system mandated by state law. That teachers’ unions in much of the country now agree that student achievement should count in evaluations at all reflects a major change from the past, when it was often argued that teaching was an “art” that could not be rigorously evaluated or, even more outrageously, that teachers should not be held accountable for student progress.

headline: Eva Figes, Author and Feminist, Dies at 80
text: Eva Figes, a refugee from Nazi Germany who became an acclaimed novelist, memoirist and critic best known for an influential feminist treatise, “Patriarchal Attitudes,” published in 1970, died on Aug. 28 at her home in London. She was 80.

headline: The Grand Old Straight White Men’s Party
text: In a Time magazine column the other day, Joe Klein scolded the Democrats for being overly preoccupied with identity politics. In its admirable drive to be inclusive, he argued, the party has treated its constituents not as a population united by common ideals and interests, but as an array of caucuses to be pandered to: African-Americans, gays, Latinos, women, youth and so on. Klein wrote that “if I’m a plain old white insurance salesman, I look at the Democratic Party and say, What’s in it for me?”

headline: Amid Discord, Romney Seeks to Sharpen Message
text: With time dwindling for him to gain an edge in the presidential race and with an outbreak of finger-pointing signaling trouble in his campaign, Mitt Romney plans to begin an offensive this week, his aides said, seeking to give voters a clearer picture of where he wants to take the country.

headline: Voter Registration
text: To the Editor:

text: Andrew Luck earned his first victory as the Colts beat the Vikings, 23-20, and the Cardinals surprised the Patriots, 20-18.

headline: Mary Rose McGeady, Nun Who Led Youth Homes, Dies at 84
text: Sister Mary Rose McGeady, the Roman Catholic nun who resuscitated Covenant House, the nation’s largest network of shelters for homeless youngsters, in the wake of a sex abuse scandal involving its founder, died Thursday at her order’s convent in Albany. She was 84.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Project Veritas Targets North Carolina
text: In an effort to prove that noncitizens were registered to vote in North Carolina, Project Veritas sent operatives to polling places with hidden cameras. The plan backfired.

headline: Code Red Explains Its Mission
text: Part of a promotional video distributed by Code Red USA describes the project’s mission as removing President Obama, and accuses Democrats of conspiring to commit widespread voter fraud.

headline: Engelbrecht Talks Principle Over Party
text: Catherine Engelbrecht addresses Tea Party members in Phoenix at last year’s Tea Party Patriots American Policy Summit.

headline: As U.S.C. Tumbles From the Elite, a Longtime Rival Looks to Fill the Void
text: Southern California, having endured a two-year postseason ban, seemed on its way to a dream season, with convincing victories over Hawaii and Syracuse. The Trojans were ranked second nationally and on their way back to the top of college football.

headline: So Which Jets Offense Is the Real One?
text: A capsule look at the Jets’ 27-10 loss to the Steelers on Sunday.

headline: U.S. to File W.T.O. Case Against China Over Cars
text: The Obama administration plans to file a broad trade case at the World Trade Organization in Geneva on Monday accusing China of unfairly subsidizing its exports of autos and auto parts, a senior administration official said late Sunday, in a move with clear political implications for the presidential elections less than two months away.

headline: Refereeing the Referees
text: Replacement referees will be under the microscope early this season. The New York Times will monitor games for plays that appear to be incorrectly called.The play: In the fourth quarter, on second-and-1, Eagles quarterback Michael Vick dropped back and threw an incomplete pass while being hit by the Ravens’ Haloti Ngata. Despite the ball’s having left Vick’s hand cleanly, it was ruled a fumble rather than an incomplete pass. Ma’ake Kemoeatu recovered for Baltimore.The dispute: The replay assistant challenged the ruling and it was reversed.

headline: Police Contain Afghan Rage Over Film, as Protests Spread Elsewhere

headline: Jimmy Carter’s Brief Shining Moment
text: By the time you’ve reached your 50s, you’ve lived through a good deal of history, although when it’s happening, it often seems to be just another edition of the nightly news. Of all the video clips linked here, the ones that struck me most were of former President Jimmy Carter, in September 1978, looking so vital at the Camp David peace accords, and then, just 10 months later, so deflated during his “crisis of confidence” speech. It’s a dramatic example of history taking its toll on a president.

headline: Should the Private Lives of Famous People Be Off Limits?
text: News broke last last week that paparazzi photographs of Kate Middleton, wife of Britain’s Prince William, had been taken while she sunbathed topless at a private villa in France. The photos, which appeared in tabloids in France, Ireland and Italy, appear to have been taken with a long-lens camera. Do you think public figures should expect to be ambushed by photographers, or should they be off limits when they aren’t in public?

headline: Shell Stymied in 2012 Arctic Oil Quest
text: Saying that a spill response dome aboard a vessel has been damaged, Shell announced Monday that it would defer its plan to drill for oil in the Arctic off the Alaskan coast this year. In seeking approval to drill, the company fought a long battle against environmentalists and others who say that doing so in the pristine icy region is too risky. In a statement, Greenpeace claimed vindication and called Shell’s high-stakes program a “monumentally reckless gamble.” But the company says it will press on and seek a safety permit for the vessel next year.

headline: Mission Viejo
text: In Panama City’s oldest standing neighborhood, the rooftops are bright red. Some are made of tile, in the style of the conquistadors who established the quarter in 1673, others of corrugated metal — temporary patches rusted crimson during decades of neglect. Together, they represent the storied past and seedy present of Casco Viejo, a neighborhood Panamanians call Casco and view as both a shrine and slum. These days, empty lots once home to squatters and stray dogs are giving way to valet parking, part of a process that may make the neighborhood more popular, if less compelling. Even hotel developers are torn.

headline: The Bull Tied to Occupy Wall Street
text: With a full year having passed since it came into being, Occupy Wall Street is noting the moment in a manner that reflects one of the things it does best. It is celebrating itself.

headline: Concord Conned, Etc.
text: Alec MacGillis has a long, interesting piece on the Paul Ryan phenomenon — on how Washington managed to convince itself that he was a Serious, Honest Conservative when he was nothing of the sort. There’s a lot of useful information in the piece. But I’d question MacGillis’s central thesis — namely, that Ryan was mainly exploiting the Beltway’s innumeracy.

headline: As Chicago Strike Goes On, the Mayor Digs In
text: CHICAGO — As the president of the Chicago Teachers Union emerged from a meeting of her union delegates on Sunday night to announce that, no, school would not be starting up again and that, no, the delegates were not ready to sign off on what had seemed like a deal, Mayor Rahm Emanuel watched her on a television in City Hall.

headline: A Fight to the Death to Commemorate Sherlock’s Birth
text: You “Downton Abbey” enthusiasts who express your dedication to that show by gathering at parties, enjoying finger sandwiches and engaging in drinking rituals will have to step up your game, because the Sherlock Holmes fans have got you beat. BBC News caught up  with 70 members of the Sherlock Holmes Society (a group that claims more than 1,200 members worldwide) who celebrated the 125th anniversary of the novel in which Arthur Conan Doyle introduced his famous fictional consulting detective by traveling — in costume — to the waterfall in Switzerland where Holmes was believed, for a time, to have met his demise.

headline: On Our Radar: Nuclear Plants and Flood Risks

headline: What We’re Reading

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: YouTube’s Balancing Act, and an App Aims for Stardom
text: Google rejected a request from the White House last week to pull “The Innocence of Muslims” from its YouTube service in light of the spreading protests of the video in the Muslim world. At the same time, it did temporarily block the video from Egypt and Libya, where the protests have been the most fierce – and that, in a nutshell, is the tricky situation Google faces in trying to fashion a policy on the acceptability of content viewed around the world, Somini Sengupta writes. Google quickly determined that the video — which depicts the Prophet Muhammad as a child molester and thug, among other things — did not violate its hate speech rules or any law, but nonetheless took it down in Egypt and Libya “given the very sensitive situation” there.

headline: What’s in a Label? Not Necessarily Sustainability
text: As consumers increasingly vote with their wallets for sustainable goods and groceries, producers are doing more to signal the eco-friendliness of their wares. But amid the many different certification logos, package designs and environmental claims, experts warn that all that glitters is not green.

headline: The Times Needs a Policy on Quotation Approval, and Soon
text: David Carr wrote a great column in Monday’s New York Times on the topic of news sources demanding that they approve quotations in stories. Mr. Carr’s “The Media Equation” had the headline “The Puppetry of Quotation Approval,” and it laid out just what an unfortunate practice has developed. He wrote: “Inch by inch, story by story, deal by deal, we are giving away our right to ask a simple question and expect a simple answer. It may seem obvious but it is still worth stating: The first draft of history should not be rewritten by the people who make it.”

headline: Introducing The Next Level: Can You Teach Entrepreneurship?
text: Talk about needing an exit strategy. I needed one from the humidity, heat and mosquitoes of the Okefenokee Swamp. But how does one go from Swamp Road in Waycross, Ga., to running a global company? I’m sure there are other routes, but for me the fastest roads out were entrepreneurship and education.

headline: Report Faults Military’s Strategies on Drug and Alcohol Abuse

headline: Embracing a Bit of the Garden Variety

headline: Couscous Dinners, Ready When You Are
text: When I was researching my book “Provençal Light,” I went to Yom Kippur services at the Orthodox synagogue in Avignon for purely secular reasons: I wanted to sit upstairs with the women and eavesdrop on their discussions about what they had cooked for the meal to break the fast. If I was lucky, I would strike up a conversation and perhaps get an invitation to dinner. As it turned out, I was successful on both counts.

headline: America’s Bloodiest Day
text: In a letter to his wife, the Union general Alpheus Williams recorded his feelings on the eve of the fighting at Antietam Creek, Md. “There was a half-dreamy sensation about it all,” he wrote, “but with a certain impression that the morrow was to be great with the future fate of our country. So much responsibility, so much intense, future anxiety.” The morrow was indeed great — a pivotal moment in the struggle between North and South.

headline: Baby Boomers Who Celebrate Birthdays This Week
text: Nothing makes the average baby boomer feel better than to know that a famous boomer is getting older, too. Of all the names on this week’s birthday list, I think Twiggy turning 63 is the hardest to keep in my mind alongside the image of the 1960s pixie model who looked about 12. Sept. 23 is Bruce Springsteen’s birthday. In an appreciation, Matt Richtel, a Times colleague, writes that one of the finest things about Mr. Springsteen’s music is his stories, which show, rather than tell. “He let me fill in the blanks, interpret, reach my own conclusions about life, keep my dignity intact,'’ Matt writes. “He turns 63 this week. A gift to us.”

headline: Orca Mothers Coddle Adult Sons, Study Finds
text: Humans, pilot whales and killer whales are the only known species in which females have a prolonged period of menopause — a time of life when they cannot reproduce. Now, a study in the journal Science reports the purpose that menopause serves in orcas: for females to care for their sons and make sure their genes are passed on to future generations.

text: Jonas Abney joined Maxifier, New York, in a new post, vice president for United States sales. He had been head of publisher development and publishing operations at Zumobi. Maxifier is minority-owned by the Dentsu Digital Holdings division of Dentsu.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Sandor Katz Is Answering Your Fermentation Questions
text: He isn’t a chef, but in recent years Sandor Ellix Katz has become one of the unlikely rock stars of the American food scene. At 50, the author of the Web site “Wild Fermentation” and the how-to guide “The Art of Fermentation” has emerged as an evangelist for the pleasures and health benefits of sauerkraut, kimchi, kefir, kvass, umeboshi plums and hundreds of other fermented delights.

headline: Filing Trade Suit, Obama Raps Romney on China
text: CINCINNATI – President Obama, under renewed fire from Mitt Romney for not standing up to China on behalf of American workers, used a rally in this battleground state on Monday to announce a new trade case against Beijing. He said it was Mr. Romney who had sent jobs to China through his zealous practice of outsourcing at Bain Capital.

headline: Adele Records the Theme for the New James Bond Film
text: Forget Adele’s Grammy Awards and the fact that every teenage woman in the world knows the lyrics to most of her blockbuster album, “21.” You know the singer has finally arrived because she has recorded the theme for the new James Bond film, “Skyfall,” according to the Total Film Web site.

headline: Walkabout – 9/17: Travelers to the Middle East Ponder Plans, and Students Go Abroad
text: Wait and See While protests against an American-made online video mocking the Prophet Muhammad continue in the Middle East, North Africa and South Asia, experts are not encouraging Americans to abandon their travel plans to those countries (except for Libya, which the  State Department recommends avoiding). Rather, they suggest that travelers be patient while events unfold. (The Washington Post)

headline: Myanmar Releases Hundreds of Prisoners
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Myanmar’s government said Monday that it was releasing more than 500 prisoners, the latest in a series of amnesties by President Thein Sein’s administration.

headline: Welcoming Gretchen Rubin to the Motherlode Blog
text: One unexpected thing that makes Gretchen Rubin, author of “The Happiness Project” and “Happier at Home,” happy?

headline: Examining Pre-Packaged Conventions
text: Politicians today live in the era of the sound bite, which may give way to the Twitter message (and then something else altogether) — either way, instantaneous news seems to be the only way our news is consumed now, and this ravenous cycle guarantees that stories sometimes fly by unnoticed, undigested.

headline: An App to Help You Find Parking On the Spot
text: Parking Panda, an online service that helps you find and reserve parking spaces, has added the San Francisco market to its inventory and introduced a mobile app to help you find parking on the spot.

headline: Why ‘Little Bear’ Made Me Burst Into Tears
text: “What kind of story would you like to hear?” said Mother Bear.“Tell me about me,” said Little Bear. “Tell me about things I once did.”–Else Holmelund Minarik, “Little Bear”

headline: Brewing Obama’s Ale, Step by Step
text: This month, after word got out that the White House was brewing its own beer, President Obama’s staff released its recipe for White House Honey Ale. Diner’s Journal asked Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster at Brooklyn Brewery, to make a batch that we could sample and assess. And on Friday, Mr. Oliver started the brewing – a monthlong process that we’ll occasionally drop in on, offering a glimpse of brewing both for those who know the art and for those who don’t.

headline: Stelter and Carter on This Fall’s Search for the Next Oprah
text: Katie Couric has begun a daytime talk show, joining a crowded field that is becoming more crowded with newcomers like Steve Harvey and Jeff Probst and a returning host like Ricki Lake. In this video clip, Brian Stelter and Bill Carter discuss the high rewards, and the high hurdles, to becoming a dominant figure in daytime television, as Oprah Winfrey once was.

headline: Expanding Ball Toy Poses Hazard to Children and Pets
text: They are known as Water Balz, and at first glance they look like marbles: small and spherical, brightly colored. But these balls are made of superabsorbent polymer, and they are capable of rapidly expanding to the size of a racquetball when doused in water.

headline: ‘We’re Not Perfect,’ a Synagogue’s Ads Proclaim
text: Madison Avenue loves to extol the perfection of products, from a whipped icing that is “the perfect blend of fudge and vanilla” to a luxury car that is devoted to “the relentless pursuit of perfection.” A new campaign, however, takes a much more modest tack by declaring, “We’re not perfect.”

headline: Look of The Moment | Astrid Bergès-Frisbey
text: The Look: In the Navy. A glittering drop-waist dress with a powder-white pouf skirt and coordinating collar and cuffs offers a lesson in how to wear nautical at night.

headline: ‘Silver Linings Playbook’ Wins People’s Choice Award in Toronto
text: “Silver Linings Playbook,” the latest film from David O. Russell, received the BlackBerry People’s Choice Award at the Toronto International Film Festival. The movie, based on a novel by Matthew Quick, stars Bradley Cooper  and Jennifer Lawrence as unstable Philadelphians.

headline: Really?: Adding Milk to Tea Destroys its Antioxidants
text: THE FACTS

headline: House Tours in Manhattan and Brooklyn
text: Ten homes in Manhattan and Brooklyn will be open for tours on Oct. 6 and 7 as part of a collaboration between Dwell Media and New York Magazine to showcase New York’s design and architectural talent.

headline: Tip Sheet | 5 Ways To Find Your College Fit
text: Mim L. Runey is president of the Providence Campus and chief operating officer of Johnson & Wales University.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Mary Katrantzou
text: The Look: Blue-eyed Speedracer.The Makeup: “A ballpoint-blue inky eye that feels like a tattoo,” is how the makeup artist Val Garland described the look at Mary Katrantzou. To create this effect, she used a custom mix of M.A.C. Lipmix in a blue and a pinky red. “One simple idea,” Garland said. The rest of the face was M.A.C. mineralized foundation and a flesh-colored lip.

headline: Chicago Board of Education’s Request for Injunction Against the Chicago Teachers Union
text: Lawyers for the Chicago Board of Education have filed a motion seeking a legal injunction to end the teachers’ strike that has entered its second week.

headline: When the Ice Melts
text: Q. Could the melting of ice at the poles affect the tilt and rotation of the Earth?

headline: Wasps Find One Way to Support Humans
text: An Australian wasp provides an important service to humans, researchers report: It paralyzes a poisonous spider, the redback.

headline: Where iPhone 5 Loses Its Way, Navigation Services Step In
text: In the battle between Google’s Android smartphone and the Apple iPhone, free navigation is one of the most fiercely contested fronts. At least one area where Apple might have created a decisive advantage over Google has gone begging, however, in the latest generation of the iPhone, unveiled last week.

headline: Trial Begins for Police Chief in Chinese Scandal
text: CHENGDU, China — The trial of the former police chief who was a key player in the fall of the politician Bo Xilai began in secret on Monday in this southwestern provincial capital, where he attempted to seek refuge in a United States Consulate in February.

headline: Ground Breaker
text: In a scorching summer day in Marseille, France, the architect Rudy Ricciotti races down a dirt path in his battered black vintage Porsche and pulls up in front of a dusty construction site on the city’s port-side docks.

headline: Protests Over Anti-Islam Film Taper Off, but Effects Linger
text: Protests against an anti-Islam film spilled into a second week on Monday, although they appeared to be tapering off in size and taking place in fewer countries compared with last week.

headline: Street Style: Saddlebags
text: The best of reader’s photos from the week of Sept. 10.

headline: Long Wait and Worry for a Visitor to Yosemite
text: Bears were the only thing to worry about during our stay at a tent cabin in Yosemite National Park in August, or so my husband and I thought. We scrupulously emptied the car of food and anything a bear might mistake for food, including empty wrappers and scented items like soap. We cleaned every crumb of trail mix from our tent. We stashed everything that might attract a bear in metal lockers provided by the park.

headline: Rushdie Relives Difficult Years Spent in Hiding
text: In 1989 the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini declared that Salman Rushdie’s novel “The Satanic Verses” was offensive to Islam and issued a fatwa against the author, sentencing him to death. For nine years Mr. Rushdie lived under the shadow of assassination, deprived of the freedom of ordinary life and made to fear for himself and his family. It was a nightmare weirdly like something out of one of his own surreal novels, and underscored the very themes he’d been grappling with for years in his fiction: namely, the emotional costs of exile and being cut off from one’s past; the consequences of globalization and the cultural clash between East and West; and the increasingly phantasmagorical nature of contemporary history.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Jonathan Saunders
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Despite Lack of Surprises, Apple Sells 2 Million New iPhones
text: Apple’s announcement of its new iPhone 5 lacked surprises. Most of its secrets spilled ahead of introduction, but that didn’t weaken early sales of the phone. People ordered more than two million iPhone 5s its first 24 hours on sale, double the previous record, held by the iPhone 4S, according to Apple.

headline: Answers About Hostage Negotiation, Part 3
text: This is the third and final set of responses from Capt. Frank A. Bolz Jr., a founder of the New York Police Department’s hostage-negotiating unit, to readers’ questions. We are no longer accepting questions.

headline: Masks Come Off for 2 Callers Who Gave WBAI Grief
text: For decades, the liberal talk radio station WBAI has been hounded by a couple of conservatives calling in to taunt program hosts about their left-leaning politics and telling them in their thick Brooklyn accents to – and this was their stock phrase — “Go back to Cuba, you commies.”

headline: Little Difference Seen in Asthma Strategies
text: There has been no general agreement on the best way to adjust the dosage of inhaled corticosteroids used by adults with asthma. Doctors determine the dose by assessing symptoms like lung function or by using biomarkers like exhaled nitric oxide, or they simply let patients decide how much is needed.

headline: In Greece, Restlessness Amid a Push for Cuts
text: ATHENS — Public opposition to austerity budgets deepened in Greece on Monday, with judges stopping work, doctors going on strike and public transport staff and schoolteachers planning action for later this week. The moves are a prelude to a general strike called by the country’s main labor unions for Sept. 26.

headline: U.S. Warns Judge’s Ruling Impedes Its Detention Powers
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration warned Monday that a judge’s ruling last week blocking a statute authorizing the indefinite detention of terrorism suspects has jeopardized its ability to continue detaining certain prisoners captured during the war in Afghanistan.

headline: When Journalists Are Dying to Expose Environmental Plunder
text: Mike Shanahan, the press officer for the International Institute for Environment and Development and an energetic participant in the invaluable Earth Journalism Network, sent a compelling reaction to my piece on the brutal murder of an environmental journalist in Cambodia that is posted here as a “Your Dot” contribution:

headline: Photos of The Moment | Pringle of Scotland
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Burberry Prorsum: Spring 2013 RTW
text: London

headline: Whom and What to Read to Make You Like Poetry (and Also Sci-Fi)
text: Stephen Burt, the Harvard professor and poet whom I wrote about in Sunday’s Education Issue, is a fanboy and an evangelist of poetry. As I wrote in the magazine, Burt defends his positivity by saying, “There’s so little airtime available for any poetry these days that when I get space and time in which I can do whatever I want, I don’t want to say, ‘X sucks.’ I almost always prefer to say, ‘Please check out Y,’ or ‘Z isn’t what you think,’ or ‘Look at what A, B and C have in common.’ ”

headline: Top Amateur in No Rush to Make Leap to Pros
text: HOYLAKE, England

headline: Talking All Around the Food
text: YOU know a movie is in trouble when a voice-over narrator has to explain the plot that the combined efforts of screenwriter, director and editor failed to make clear. Something like that is going on at Eleven Madison Park, which just eliminated its $125 prix fixe option and now offers only one menu, a $195 blowout that lasts about four hours.

headline: Deferred Prosecution Agreements and Cookie-Cutter Justice
text: Lanny A. Breuer, the head of the Justice Department’s Criminal Division, last week spoke to the New York City Bar Association, extolling the virtues of deferred and nonprosecution agreements as the new standard for how the Justice Department deals with criminal conduct by corporations.

headline: The ‘Anthropocene’ as Environmental Meme and/or Geological Epoch
text: Paul Voosen, who’s one of my favorite science journalists these days, has written a fine piece examining the scientific and societal debate over the Anthropocene, the proposed term for this era in which human decisions (or indecision) will leave a durable mark in planetary systems and even in the planet’s stratified rock.* (The video above explores the Anthropocene as environmental meme.)

headline: ‘Chaplin’ Off to Quiet Start at Broadway Box Office
text: The new Broadway musical “Chaplin” grossed a modest $460,925 in ticket sales in its first full week of performances since opening to largely negative reviews on Sept. 10, according to box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers.

headline: Vasiliev Joins American Ballet Theater as Principal Dancer
text: American Ballet Theater has recruited Ivan Vasiliev as a principal dancer, and will cast him during next year’s season at the Metropolitan Opera and on tours, the company said on Monday. Mr. Vasiliev and the ballerina Natalia Osipova created a stir nearly a year ago when they announced they were leaving Moscow’s Bolshoi Ballet for the Mikhailovsky Theater in St. Petersburg. Mr. Vasiliev, who was born in 1989 in Vladivostok, Russia, made his debut at the Bolshoi in 2006 as Basilio in “Don Quixote” and made guest appearances at Ballet Theater last year. His roles with the company included Solor in “La Bayadère,” Franz in “Coppélia” and Ali in “Le Corsaire.”

headline: Metallica in London
text: I loved this shot during the finale at Jonathan Saunders, capturing the movement and shine of some sequined dresses. Get ready for more metallic tones from Burberry.

headline: A Possible Breakthrough in Explaining a Mathematical Riddle
text: Numbers, addition, multiplication — the basic stuff of grade-school arithmetic — are suddenly the excited talk of cutting-edge mathematicians.

headline: Patriots’ Injury Highlights a Receiving Shift
text: When Bill Belichick selected tight ends Rob Gronkowski and Aaron Hernandez two rounds apart in the 2010 draft, the rest of the N.F.L. took note. At the time, the New England offense rarely focused on the tight end, instead revolving around wide receivers like Randy Moss and Wes Welker.

headline: Preparing to Tilt on Level Ground
text: Workers putting together “Armor for the Joust of Peace,” from about 1500, in the Great Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday. The armor was bought by the Met in 1904, one of the museum’s earliest acquisitions. It has not been on display in nearly 25 years. Click here to see a larger version..

headline: An Atom Smasher Is Squeezed Through a Museum’s Doors
text: If physics has to do with the actions and reactions of something, then this is about physics. But really it is about a thing — a thing that was at the heart of breakthrough physics experiments that led to the crash program for the atom bomb in World War II.

headline: Richard Nicoll: Spring 2013 RTW
text: London

headline: The Daily Shoe | Nicholas Kirkwood for Erdem
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: For Maimed Veterans, Animal Tissue Offers Hope of Repair
text: Thousands of veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars have been maimed in explosions and have lost so much muscle from an arm or a leg that amputation is sometimes the best alternative. But in today’s paper, our colleague Henry Fountain tracks a new treatment still in development that helped one Marine regain much of his lost mobility — using material from a pig’s bladder.

headline: An Extra Dose of N.F.L. Parity
text: There will be only six undefeated N.F.L. teams after Week 2 ends late tonight, with either Denver or Atlanta joining Houston, San Diego, Philadelphia, Arizona and San Francisco (provided that Denver and Atlanta don’t produce a rare tie).

headline: Driving Safety, in Fits and Starts
text: Auto fatalities have been falling for decades, but in a very interesting plateau-drop pattern.

headline: Over 2,000 Miles, Hauling the Memory of the Mother Road
text: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif.– The Historic Highway Convoy 2012, consisting of 30 vintage trucks of modest and mighty proportions, had spent eight days and 2,000 miles on the road, tracing the remnants of Old Route 66, before rumbling into the Inland Empire on Saturday morning.

headline: In the Studio | Peter Pilotto

headline: London: Stripe Tease
text: Hardly any surprise that Mary Katrantzou and Peter Pilotto showed prints, but the spring affair with stripes continues across the pond. Mr. Pilotto’s stripes looked fragmented or blended with checks. Jonathan Saunders did straight-forward versions but also some lovely diagonal bands on silk dresses.

headline: Dictionary Translates Ancient Egypt Life
text: Ancient Egyptians did not speak to posterity only through hieroglyphs. Those elaborate pictographs were the elite script for recording the lives and triumphs of pharaohs in their tombs and on the monumental stones along the Nile. But almost from the beginning, people in everyday life spoke a different language and wrote a different script, a simpler one that evolved from the earliest hieroglyphs.

headline: “The Citizens Have a Right to Know”
text: Along with the very interesting comments on my piece about California’s Prop 37 came this letter, from the chairman of Stonyfield Organic:

The Real Romney
text: Oh, my. Mother Jones has what it says is a video of Mitt Romney talking to donors; it sure looks and sounds real. And it reveals a candidate who despises half the country:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Drive or Fly? Depends on Your Tolerance for Risk
text: I HAD to travel to Southern California over the weekend, and I almost drove the 489 miles from my house in Tucson to my destination in Long Beach.

headline: Corporate Events, on Campus
text: The description of the meeting center was effusive: “The conference center has a million-dollar panoramic view of the Manhattan skyline that will leave you breathless.”

headline: My Grandmother’s Cappelletti
text: 1:54 p.m. | Updated By the time I came along, both my mother’s and my father’s families had been in the United States for two generations. I never felt particularly “Italian,” in spite of my very ethnic last name. Mine was not a family settled into an Italian-American enclave and gathered around weekly, shouting at one another in a style familiar from so many films, and eating pasta with the sauce they called “Sunday gravy.” No, they assimilated, and quickly.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Bad Piggies Trailer and Android App Art
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Exaggerating Your Race Results
text: It was my first half marathon, and I was anxious and jittery. I had never run more than 12 miles, and this race went on for 13.1. How was I supposed to hold a pace for that distance?

headline: Google Buys Nik to Lure Photographers to Google Plus
text: Google said on Monday that it had acquired Nik Software, a company that makes tools for editing and sharing photos. It is Google’s latest defensive move against Facebook and part of its strategy to become a photo-sharing hub.

headline: An Opera’s Real Story Is Its Choreography
text: Although “Einstein on the Beach,” the 1976 collaboration between Robert Wilson and Philip Glass that is in revival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is labeled “an opera in four acts,” the tag that Mr. Wilson gave to some of his earlier theatrical works might also serve: “dance play.”

headline: He’s Wild and Crazy, but a Subtle Guy, Too
text: No stand-up comic has arguably ever been bigger than Steve Martin. His albums sold in the millions. His act drew crowds in the tens of thousands. Critics adored him. Then, at the height of his success, he quit.

headline: The Politics of Intimacy
text: Every election season is a reminder that the personal is political; now, in Michelle Clunie’s “Us,” a two-person play at the Lion Theater, we see how the political can be very personal indeed.

headline: A Wave of Staggering Loss, in a Country Unprepared
text: PBS’s “American Experience” can feel formulaic, but the episode on Tuesday, “Death and the Civil War,” makes itself wrenching and riveting by throwing out some of the formulas that have become familiar in documentaries about the war.

headline: Suddenly There Came a Clapping
text: PHILADELPHIA — The last, distraught days of Edgar Allan Poe are charted with spellbinding vitality in “Red-Eye to Havre de Grace,” a highlight of the theatrical offerings at this year’s Live Arts Festival here. At times funny, at times heartbreaking, and from quirky start to haunting finish a feast of entrancing visual allurements, this exquisite show is among the most original musical theater works I’ve seen in years.

headline: Vaccine’s Power Wanes After Last Dose
text: Before age 7, children usually receive five doses of DTaP, the combination vaccine that protects against diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis. The acellular pertussis vaccine now in use has fewer side effects than the older whole-cell version.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Christopher Kane
text: The Look: Sleep…walking Beauty.

headline: Be a Star, Then You Can Judge
text: Years from now, Christina Aguilera will be remembered for her glamour, her scandalous take on femme-pop and her Brobdingnagian voice. But she should also be remembered as the person who almost single-handedly reshaped music-competition reality programming. Her legacy as a judge on “The Voice,” on NBC, may well turn out to be deeper and more profound than the one she’s forged in her music career.

headline: Trauma: Manga as Medical Tool
text: In his unending quest to get surgeons to adopt a little-known generic drug to save hemorrhaging patients, a British doctor has produced a new medical-education tool: a manga comic.

headline: Mariah Carey, ‘Never a Fan of This Type of Thing,’ Tells How ‘Idol’ Drew Her In
text: The new superstar-stocked judging panel of “American Idol” was already at work Monday auditioning hopefuls at Jazz at Lincoln Center in Manhattan for a second day, having begun on Sunday immediately after announcing its new additions for the season.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Afghanistan, India, Indonesia and South Korea.

headline: Music From Pink, Dwight Yoakam and Aimee Mann
text: PINK

headline: Village Voice Appoints a Music Editor
text: The Village Voice has named a new music editor, three days after it emerged that the weekly’s editor was departing and its music editor had been fired.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Makes Some Intriguing Bets on Romney
text: Mitt Romney may have had a bad run in polls in recent weeks, but he still has supporters who are bullish about his chances in some states that President Obama won handily in 2008.

headline: Ford and Canadian Workers in Tentative Deal
text: OTTAWA — The Canadian Auto Workers union reached a tentative contract deal with the Ford Motor Company of Canada on Monday just hours before a midnight strike deadline.

headline: Financial Strains Said to Threaten Stability of Palestinian Authority
text: JERUSALEM — As the Palestinian Authority marks the 19th anniversary this month of the signing of the Oslo Accords, the agreement with Israel that brought it into existence, the authority is facing a financial crisis that experts say could threaten its future operations and stability.

headline: All the TV News Since 2009, on One Web Site
text: Inspired by a pillar of antiquity, the Library of Alexandria, Brewster Kahle has a grand vision for the Internet Archive, the giant aggregator and digitizer of data, which he founded and leads.

headline: Christopher Kane Has a Gift for You
text: Shortly before the Christopher Kane show, in a high-rise near Oxford Street, the casting director Russell Marsh was playing Burt Lancaster to a bunch of blank-faced girls. He was giving them orders, drill-sergeant style, about not mussing up their clothes. Mr. Marsh probably gives such instructions routinely, but the spring collection of Mr. Kane was visibly delicate — in tissue paper-like silks and crepes, and in pale sugary pinks, yellow and dead white.

headline: Iranian Cleric Says Rushdie’s Murder Could Stop Insults to Islam’s Prophet
text: As my colleague Michiko Kakutani explains in her review of the novelist Salman Rushdie’s new memoir, an Iranian religious foundation reportedly raised the price on his head over the weekend to $3.3 million. The cleric who leads the foundation claimed that Mr. Rushdie’s murder would stop others from disrespecting Islam’s founder, The Associated Press reported from Tehran.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Burberry
text: The Look: Sunny English girl thrown into the ’40s.

headline: In Video Clip, Romney Calls 47% ‘Dependent’ and Feeling Entitled
text: 12:26 a.m., Sept. 18 | Updated

headline: Seeking Positives on a Final Homestand
text: The Mets returned to Citi Field on Monday to start one last homestand in a season that has wandered well off track.

headline: Grappling With Details of Medicare Proposals
text: When Claire Celsi’s father-in-law died in July, the one thing her mother-in-law did not have to worry about was the $300,000 hospital bill. Medicare covered most of it.

headline: Liu Supporters Invoke the Holocaust and Nixon in Faulting an F.B.I. Inquiry
text: A former congressman on Monday called the federal investigation into the fund-raising practices of John C. Liu, the city comptroller, a “Nixonian” form of “harassment and persecution.”

headline: Baseball’s 500,000th Error Finds Jose Reyes
text: As baseball approached its unofficial 500,000th error, one thing was clear: a shortstop would most likely make it, since that position is most closely associated with the statistic.

headline: A Child’s Cancer Story Inspires Taylor Swift
text: By now you may have heard Taylor Swift’s heart-rending song “Ronan,” about the too-short life of a little boy. Ms. Swift gave it an emotional performance on the Stand Up to Cancer telethon on Sept. 7, and it has been topping the charts ever since.

headline: Congressional Republicans Raise Questions About New York Investigations
text: Congressional Republicans on Monday issued a letter to Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, raising questions about his investigations into private equity firms and politically active tax-exempt groups.

headline: Burberry: View From a Bridge
text: Christopher Bailey may have opened the Burberry show with a creamy white cape over a pleated silk bodysuit — the perfect outfit for a bareback circus rider — but a trench coat remains the main event at the British company. In a collection called “Corsets and Capes,” Mr. Bailey gave a clean, tighter, sensual line to his many coats (including a style that bled from red into pink), cute satin shorts and handsome lace dresses. The winners were the sleek trenches in leather, satin or micropleated satin, though perhaps the optimistic colors — inky blue, fuchsia, copper, pink, lipstick red — were the centerpiece of a polished, newsy show. You half wondered if London, seen from a Thames River bridge at night, was the inspiration for the jewel palette.

headline: Assembly Releases Documents Listing Sexual Harassment Settlement
text: ALBANY — The State Assembly on Monday released a list of its 2012 expenditures from the part of its budget that was used to pay a secret sexual harassment settlement this summer.

headline: Catholics Then, Muslims Now
text: Toronto

headline: Maverick Minister in India Is as Perplexing as She Is Powerful
text: KOLKATA, India — When Mamata Banerjee, a 5-foot-tall dynamo in flip-flops, finally defeated the Communists last year after decades of misrule here, she became one of the most powerful but unpredictable politicians in India. Now the country is left to guess whether she will announce on Tuesday that she intends to try to pull down India’s governing coalition.

headline: Newsweek’s ‘Muslim Rage’ Cover Mocked Online
text: CAIRO — After a week of violent protests over an online video demeaning the Prophet Muhammad, the American news media has conducted a searching psychoanalysis of the Muslim mind to ask why such an offense should trigger such wrath. Essayists have generalized about resentments dating back to the 8th century, an anachronistic discomfort with modernity, or the excesses of Islamist politics, among other familiar themes.

headline: Czechs See Peril in a Bootleg Bottle
text: PRAGUE — The Czech Republic has banned the sale of liquor containing 20 percent or higher alcohol content after at least 20 people were killed and dozens of others were seriously injured from consuming methanol-tainted spirits.

headline: Louis Simpson, Poet of Everyday Life, Dies at 89
text: Louis Simpson, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet who told characteristically American tales of common people and often cast a skeptical eye on the American dream, died on Friday at his home in Stony Brook, N.Y. He was 89.

headline: My Grandmother's Cappelletti
text: To teach a cousin too young to learn to make cappelletti and ravioli from my grandmother, our family created a video recipe, and a memory.

headline: Savoring Success by Expanding the Brand
text: AS savings accounts shrank in recent years, spice racks expanded, with Americans cooking more to save money.

headline: Success of Crowdfunding Puts Pressure on Entrepreneurs
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — An effort to build a sleek aluminum charging dock for the iPhone generated fervor online when it was announced last December. The project’s creators raised close to $1.5 million through Kickstarter, a crowdfunding Web site, and promised to start shipping their Elevation Dock in April to those who had backed the project.

headline: Manhattan’s Power Breakfast Must Move
text: The breakfast room at the Loews Regency Hotel has long been a favorite forum for New York’s political elite. But is that daily gathering of power brokers over $24 omelets and $8 coffees a movable feast?

headline: In a School Built on Trust, Metal Detectors Inject Fear
text: It looms inside the door of the school on Palmetto Street, a hunk of metal and a rubber belt. Innocuous, right?

headline: Breaking Up the Echo
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Occupy Wall Street: A Frenzy That Fizzled
text: It will be an asterisk in the history books, if it gets a mention at all.

headline: Pennsylvania: Board Denies Clemency
text: Pennsylvania’s Board of Pardons in Harrisburg denied on Monday an application for clemency by Terrance Williams, a convicted murderer who is scheduled to be executed on Oct. 3. Clemency requires unanimous approval by the five-member board, and the vote was only 3 to 2 in favor of the application. Shawn Nolan, Mr. Williams’s attorney, argued that Mr. Williams had been beaten and sexually abused during childhood, and had killed Amos Norwood in Philadelphia in 1984 after the victim sexually abused him from the age of 13. Tom Dolgenos of the Philadelphia district attorney’s office said the allegations of sexual abuse were “hearsay” raised by Mr. Williams years after his 1986 trial in an attempt to prevent the execution. Mr. Williams is now seeking a stay of execution in a state court.

headline: Israeli Diplomat Is Man in Middle
text: WASHINGTON — With Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel engaged in an unusually public dispute with the Obama administration over Iran, Mr. Netanyahu’s man in Washington, Michael B. Oren, has been working rooms all over town.

headline: Friends You Can Count On
text: You spend your time tweeting, friending, liking, poking, and in the few minutes left, cultivating friends in the flesh. Yet sadly, despite all your efforts, you probably have fewer friends than most of your friends have. But don’t despair — the same is true for almost all of us. Our friends are typically more popular than we are.

headline: ‘Scream’ to Go on View at MoMA
text: Edvard Munch’s 1895 version of “The Scream” — which became the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction when it brought nearly $120 million at Sotheby’s in May — will go on view at the Museum of Modern Art, courtesy of its new mystery owner, for six months, starting on Oct. 24.

headline: Libya, Violence and Free Speech
text: Back when Salman Rushdie was made the object of a fatwa because his book “The Satanic Verses” was regarded by many Iranians as a blasphemy against the prophet, I went to a conference where a panel discussion was devoted to Rushdie’s situation. A member of the audience raised his hand and, without a trace of irony, asked, “What’s the matter with those Iranians? Haven’t they ever heard of the First Amendment?”

headline: Massachusetts: Health Official Resigns
text: The commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, John Auerbach, resigned on Monday amid allegations that a chemist at a state drug laboratory mishandled evidence samples, potentially affecting 34,000 criminal cases. Gov. Deval Patrick ordered the laboratory shut down late last month as prosecutors, the state police and the state attorney general’s office investigate whether Annie Dookhan, a chemist, breached protocol, potentially causing wrongful convictions in state cases. Mr. Auerbach is the most senior official to step down in the scandal; last week, the laboratory’s director resigned and another official there was fired.

headline: Speaking the Truth to the Vatican
text: After years of drug addiction, serial theft and hard prison time, a 54-year-old mother named Renee is entering a revolutionary phase of her life — transition from a rehabilitation sanctuary in Coney Island to the possibility of self-reliance in the outside world. The sanctuary is one of several outposts of Providence House, a recovery program run by the Sisters of St. Joseph, a society of street-tough, adaptive New York nuns. The program has nurtured more than 12,000 women parolees and their children back from the brink.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Pier to Pay for a Park
text: New Yorkers cherish their access to the piers and green spaces that make up the Hudson River Park, which stretches from Pier 99 near 59th St. to Battery Place. Established by state law in 1998, the park gives urbanites a chance to stroll along one the nation’s great rivers.

headline: Voters Annoyed by Hard-to-Read Ballots
text: Some states want their voters to take ID cards to the polls.

headline: Chicago Standoff
text: The Chicago teachers’ strike should serve as an object lesson about the dangers of incendiary language in labor negotiations. The strike, which appeared to be near settlement over the weekend, has continued after angry union delegates failed to vote to return to work on Sunday. The dispute need never have reached this point, with 350,000 students starting a second week out of classes.

headline: Iranian Official Says Blasts Targeted Nuclear Sites
text: WASHINGTON — Iran’s most senior atomic energy official revealed on Monday that separate explosions, which he attributed to sabotage, had targeted power supplies to the country’s two main uranium enrichment facilities, including the deep underground site that American and Israeli officials say is the most invulnerable to bombing.

headline: Stuck in the Present, Mets Look to the Future
text: Something big was brewing at Citi Field on Monday. At least that is how it looked. The Mets installed three rows of temporary seats behind the backstop, on either side of home plate, the way they did at Shea Stadium for the playoffs and World Series. There were so many folding chairs and so much plexiglass that you almost expected the league president to ask for Jay Howell’s glove.

headline: Russell E. Train, Conservationist Who Helped Create the E.P.A., Dies at 92
text: Russell E. Train, a renowned conservationist who played a central role in the creation of groundbreaking laws and effective enforcement in response to rising concerns about environmental protection in America, died on Monday at his farm in Bozman, Md. He was 92.

headline: Professors and the Students Who Grade Them
text: Are college students' evaluations of their instructors a useful way to assess professors? What might be more effective?

headline: Bucs’ Schiano Defends Final Play of Loss to Giants
text: Through Pop Warner, high school and college, football players are coached to compete until the final whistle and take nothing for granted. Greg Schiano instilled that kind of fight into his teams in turning around a downtrodden program during his 11 years at Rutgers. He has said he intends to bring that never-say-die philosophy to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in his first season as their coach.

headline: Widow Takes On Congressman Who Ousted Her Husband
text: Shelley Adler was still mourning her husband’s death when the thought hit her: Why not run for his old Congressional seat? But when she approached her husband’s longtime political adviser and close friend, he gently discouraged her.

headline: Restoring the Walls, and the History, at Hitler’s Wolf’s Lair
text: KETRZYN, Poland — For nearly three years, Hitler commanded the Third Reich from a vast network of bunkers and buildings hidden in the forest here, guiding his genocidal war effort from an encampment called the Wolf’s Lair.

headline: On a Challenging Day, Romney Seeks to Shift to His Policy Specifics
text: An effort by Mitt Romney to give his campaign new direction — built around new ads intended to highlight how a Romney presidency would take the nation on a better course than President Obama — was quickly overshadowed on Monday by the video of Mr. Romney’s unscripted remarks at a fund-raiser several months ago.

headline: New York’s Medicaid Reforms
text: New York State has substantially changed its Medicaid program in the past year and a half in ways likely to improve the health of its poorest residents and rein in the program’s enormous costs.

headline: M.T.A. Chief’s Latest Bold Move: Using Twitter by Himself
text: It began inconspicuously enough — a Ronald Reagan quote here, a whiff of harmless promotion there — the mark of a seasoned city official wading cautiously into social media.

headline: Jets Turn Backs on a Game That Slipped Right Through Their Hands
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — On the ninth play of a 14-play drive that ate up more than 10 minutes of the fourth quarter, Pittsburgh running back Isaac Redman took a handoff and proceeded to shrug off what seemed like half the Jets’ defense. His right knee appeared to scuff the grass at Heinz Field while he was trapped in the backfield, and safety Yeremiah Bell wrestled the ball from Redman as he made the tackle. After an officials’ review, the Steelers kept the ball, and Redman got 6 yards.

headline: Look How Far We’ve Come Apart
text: In the witches’ brew of fearmongering, unkeepable promises and poll-tested metaphors that both parties serve up to the electorate every four years, you can always find this predictable dash of inspiration: the image of Americans uniting and working together for the sake of the country. President Obama said in Charlotte, N.C. that America is “about what can be done by us, together.” In Tampa, Paul Ryan said, “Whatever your political party, let’s come together for the sake of our country.” And Mitt Romney closed his convention speech with three invocations of “That America, that united America.”

headline: Thurston Howell Romney
text: In 1980, about 30 percent of Americans received some form of government benefits. Today, as Nicholas Eberstadt of the American Enterprise Institute has pointed out, about 49 percent do.

headline: How to Fix the Schools
text: No matter how quickly the Chicago teachers’ strike ends, whether it is this afternoon or two months from now, it’s not going to end well for the city’s public school students. Yes, I know; that’s the hoariest of clichés. But that doesn’t mean it’s not true.

headline: College English Dept. Fights Class-Time Cuts
text: When members of the English department at Queensborough Community College voted last week against a plan to curtail their basic writing courses to three hours a week from four, they said they wanted to send the school a message: “We support our students,” Elise Denbo, a lecturer in the department, said Monday. “Sometimes they need extra time.”

headline: Pettitte Rejoins Jeter in Another Stretch Run
text: When the Yankees trotted onto the field to celebrate another victory in their ritual hand-slapping conga line on Sunday, Andy Pettitte grabbed Derek Jeter from behind in a bear hug, and the two players, both dealing with injured left ankles, laughed as they headed to the clubhouse.

headline: For Young Jews, a Service Says, ‘Please, Do Text’
text: MIAMI BEACH — Settling into their seats for Rosh Hashana service, the twentysomethings instinctively reached for their cellphones to turn them off, anticipating an admonition they hear often at synagogue.

headline: Stop Fretting
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — If you grew up when I did (I’m not going to be specific, but I will say that I am old enough to have been a devoted fan), you weren’t a fan of the rock and roll music unless you owned, played, memorized the liner notes of, and basically worshipped the album “Led Zeppelin IV.” This was the iconic album that contained the song “STAIRWAY TO HEAVEN,” which became the song of a generation and is celebrating the 40th (now 41st) anniversary of its release in November of 1971.

headline: Condé Nast Plans French Vanity Fair
text: Vanity Fair magazine, which has been battling declining newsstand sales in the United States, is looking for more readers in Europe. Next year, Condé Nast is starting a monthly edition of Vanity Fair in France. The magazine will share the name of the American publication, but nearly 90 percent of the content will be original.

headline: Gaza: Hamas Court Convicts 4 in Murder of Activist
text: A Hamas military court on Monday convicted four Palestinians of taking part in the 2011 kidnapping and killing of a pro-Palestinian Italian activist in the Gaza Strip. Two of the defendants received life sentences for kidnapping and killing the activist, Vittorio Arrigoni, in April 2011. A third man was sentenced to 10 years for taking part in the kidnapping, and a fourth defendant was sentenced to a year for sheltering the kidnappers, said Khalil Shahin of the Palestinian Center for Human Rights. At the time, an extremist Salafist group claimed responsibility for kidnapping Mr. Arrigoni, 36, and demanded that Hamas release all Salafists from its prisons. Mr. Arrigoni was found dead before the kidnappers’ deadline had expired. The suspects were later captured by Hamas’s security force. Mr. Arrigoni was a member of the International Solidarity Movement, a pro-Palestinian activist organization with foreign volunteers in the West Bank and Gaza.

headline: Mets, Unable to Help Dickey to His 19th Win, Continue to Struggle at Home
text: The Mets have returned to Citi Field, where they will have roughly a week and a half to leave some sort of lasting positive impression upon their fans before the off-season.

headline: One Day, Growing Spare Parts Inside the Body
text: LOS ANGELES — Dr. Tracy Grikscheit held a length of intestine in her gloved hands, examining it inch by inch as if she were checking a bicycle tube for leaks.

headline: Behind the ‘People Who Pay No Income Tax’
text: Mother Jones has published a video of Mitt Romney at a private fund-raiser making incendiary remarks about Obama voters – and, well, about half of the electorate.

headline: Parking Rules
text: On Tuesday, because of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Gulati Talks About New Women’s Coach and New Women’s League
text: U.S. Soccer president Sunil Gulati said Monday that he wants to have a coach in place for the women’s national team before Halloween, and that there is a still chance there will be a new league for the team’s players to work in as soon as next spring. Completing the first task, it seems, will be much easier.

headline: Last Chapter for a Court With a Place in History
text: MERIDIAN, Miss. — Across the street from a barbershop and upstairs from a post office sits a big empty room where Mississippi once began to face up to itself.

headline: Polls: Warren Ahead in Massachusetts
text: Despite criticism of her campaign by some of her Democratic allies, Elizabeth Warren may be gaining ground in her bid to unseat Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts, two new polls suggest.

text: A view of the day in sports, including cycling, baseball and a bit of nasty weather over Wrigley Field.

headline: Bomb Threat Empties a Fourth Campus
text: Thousands of people were evacuated from the campus of Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge on Monday after a bomb threat, the fourth such evacuation on a college campus in four days.

text: A people-friendly robot for the workplace, a dictionary for an ancient Egyptian language, and hantavirus exposure.

headline: Limits Placed on Immigrants in Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — The White House has ruled that young immigrants who will be allowed to stay in the United States as part of a new federal policy will not be eligible for health insurance coverage under President Obama’s health care overhaul.

headline: Romney Responds to Release of Secret Video
text: What follows is a transcript, as recorded by The New York Times, of remarks by Mitt Romney discussing a newly released, secret video of him speaking to campaign donors. Mr. Romney addressed reporters in Costa Mesa, Calif., on Monday night:

headline: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Back to Square 1
text: Chronic fatigue syndrome is not caused by a mouse retrovirus, according to a study initiated by the National Institutes of Health to settle what had become a contentious scientific question.

text: transcribe •\tran(t)-ˈskrib\• verb

headline: A Robot With a Reassuring Touch
text: BOSTON — If you grab the hand of a two-armed robot named Baxter, it will turn its head and a pair of cartoon eyes — displayed on a tablet-size computer-screen “face” — will peer at you with interest.

headline: The Co-Worker of the Future
text: The new frontier in robotics is machines like this one, named Baxter, which is designed to work alongside humans safely and cheaply.

headline: In Car Country, Obama Trumpets China Trade Case
text: CINCINNATI — In a vivid display of the powers of incumbency, President Obama on Monday filed a broad new trade case against China at the World Trade Organization, announcing the action in this industrial battleground where Mitt Romney has pressed his argument that the president has not done enough to protect American workers.

headline: Kansas Board Officially Puts End to Obama Ballot Challenge
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A challenge toPresident Obama’s eligibility to appear on the Kansas ballot officially ended on Monday after a state board adjourned without ruling because the objection had been withdrawn last week.

headline: Suicide Bomber in Afghanistan Strikes Minibus, Killing Mostly Foreign Workers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber killed 14 people on Tuesday, including 10 foreigners, most of whom worked as flight crew members under contract with the United States government, officials said. The attack brought to at least 28 the number of deaths attributed to unrest sweeping the Muslim world as a result of a video parodying the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: News Quiz | September 18, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Conversation With: Haryana Chief Minister Bhupinder Singh Hooda
text: NEW DELHI– Bhupinder Singh Hooda has been chief minister of Haryana since 2005, and is currently serving his second term. The state, which hugs India’s capital, is said to be the site of the epic battle described in the Mahabharata; it is now home to just over 2 percent of India’s people, some 25 million.

headline: Champions League: A Seasoned Dortmund Starts Fresh
text: Sixteen years is a long time in soccer. Between one decade and the next, players, coaches or even entire teams and leagues that came to dominate and influence the very sport have to eventually accept the simple facts of fate and step aside as time picks its next champion. On Tuesday, Borussia Dortmund hosts Ajax in their first Champions League encounter since a fateful quarterfinal in 1996, during a forgotten time when both clubs were considered big players in Europe’s premier competition. Today, both sides will be hopeful of three points, and another shot at European success.

headline: Benetton Ads Address Youth Unemployment by Offering Help to ‘Unemployees’
text: For decades, Benetton, the Italian apparel retailer, has been known for provocative advertising that attracts publicity by stirring up discussion of contentious topics like politics, religion and the treatment of AIDS patients.

headline: Smartphone Technology Pushes Forward
text: WHEN did the first iPhone (“a quantum leap for cellphones”) first arrive?
