headline: Claudine Mawby Walker Dies at 90; Hollywood ‘Triplet’
text: Hollywood publicity agents called them the Mawby Triplets. They were a set of adorably blond little English girls who appeared in some of the earliest talking films, cherubs adorning the celluloid canvases of the 1920s and ’30s. Cast in movies with stars like Douglas Fairbanks Jr., Gloria Swanson and John Barrymore, they were, for a time, among the most famous children in the world.

headline: Mets End Home Losing Streak
text: The Miami Marlins came to Queens on Friday night a walking, stumbling example for anxious Mets fans of how much worse the game of baseball can be played. The Mets, enjoying a much-needed reprieve from major league competition, broke a streak of nine consecutive home losses with a 7-3 win.

headline: Martin Rescues Lead in Extra Innings
text: Russell Martin hopped along the first-base line clicking his heels. Here is the scene that unfolded after his game-ending home run landed in the left-field stands: scrum of yapping teammates gathered at home plate; Alex Rodriguez sprinted like a schoolboy after Martin’s helmet, flung up the first-base line; Nick Swisher spiked his water bottle; Frank Sinatra blared on the speakers; Kevin Long embraced Martin in a headlock.

headline: New York’s 50: Wait! There’s More

headline: Healed From Injury, Greene Leads Rutgers in Tackles
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — Less than five minutes remained in the 2011 season when Rutgers linebacker Khaseem Greene charged through the Iowa State offensive line and forced an incomplete pass. Then he was flat on his back, surrounded by trainers.

headline: Rich as the Devil, but No Gordon Gekko
text: The television series “666 Park Avenue,” whose title invites little thematic speculation, arrives next week on ABC and will be, to the best of my knowledge, the second time an architecturally significant apartment building in Manhattan has been deployed as a fictional vessel for Satanism. The reason would seem fairly clear; you just can’t situate allegories of demonic venality or depraved ambition as persuasively in places like Philadelphia, White Plains or San Diego. Had New York City as we now know it existed in 1600, civilization would have been forever left to reckon with the Macbeths of East 78th Street.

text: Punjab: Gulzar Singh Ranike, a minister in the Punjab state government, resigned on Sunday in the wake of allegations that he misappropriated public funds, The Times of India reported. Mr. Ranike and an associate were accused of transferring 25 million rupees, about $ 460,000, from funds intended for a border area development program.

headline: Dame Patrol in Milan
text: Tanked with caffeine from the espresso bar that Bottega Veneta sets up before its morning shows, I regarded the opening dress — a silk floral print with shoulder pads and a thin belt — and wondered if the designer, Tomas Maier, had been reading James M. Cain over the summer. The jazzy music kept this thought going through several tough little day dresses with a 1940s slant. The impression gradually dissolved as Mr. Maier shifted to almost naïve-looking blouses and skirts in white poplin, and then a sporty tank dress in black jersey spliced with black snakeskin.

headline: A New Inning, Late in the Game
text: LIGONIER, Pa.

headline: Coming Out in the World of Sports
text: Kevin McClatchy, who spent 11 ½ years as the managing general partner and chief executive officer of the Pittsburgh Pirates, spoke extensively with me at his home in Ligonier, Penn., about why he hid being gay for so long and about the persistent secrecy in professional sports. Here, in addition to his comments in my Sunday column, are a few excerpts from our conversation.

headline: A Timeline of Incremental Progress
text: Big-time sports lag behind other areas of American society in terms of the number of gay and lesbian participants who feel they can be open about their sexual orientation. Not once, for example, has an active male player in any of the four major professional sports leagues in America publicly acknowledged being gay. But retired football, basketball and baseball players, along with active players in other sports, have come out. And there are plenty of lesbian athletes in women’s professional sports. Here are some milestones from the last four decades :

headline: The Barriers to Openness
text: It’s a statistical impossibility that there aren’t at least a few gay men playing in one of the four major American sports leagues right now. It’s an equal impossibility that there haven’t been hundreds of them over time.

headline: The Official Attendance Can Become Empty of Meaning
text: The Mets announced that the attendance at their game Thursday night against the Phillies was 20,010. Even a casual glance at the game on television, though, suggested that there were no more than a few thousand fans at Citi Field. Were the Mets fibbing?

headline: Time Running Short for the Nazi Hunters

headline: Mets’ Knuckleballer Has an Honor at His Fingertips
text: Terry Collins, the Mets’ manager, sat gloomily at a news conference after his team lost to Philadelphia on Monday. His staff ace, R. A. Dickey, had lost despite allowing only two earned runs in seven innings. The Mets badly want Dickey to reach 20 victories, the magic threshold for a starting pitcher.

headline: Inequality Kills
text: Kathleen Geier makes a point I should have noticed. She points to the shocking story in yesterday’s Times about sharply declining life expectancies for less-educated whites, and points out that these declines took place at a time of rapidly rising income inequality. And we have lots of evidence that low socioeconomic status leads to higher mortality — even if you correct for things like availability of health insurance.

headline: A Misguided Moral Crusade
text: BEATEN. Burned. Branded with a bar code or with a pimp’s name carved into her thigh. Thrown into the trunk of a car for punishment. Forced to provide sexual services for countless callous and violent men. This is the dominant image of young people in the sex trade, and it is fueling deeply flawed campaigns against prostitution.

headline: Relocation of A’s Has All the Plans but No Permit

He had a Knothole Gang pass and took the streetcar almost every day, watching the Cardinals of the National League and the Browns of the American League. On school days, he would take his homework.

headline: Double Payments Bedevil Veterans’ Pension System

What should have been an increase of about $2,000 in a monthly payment to the widow of a veteran showed up on her computer screen as $21,000.

headline: A Tiny Mediterranean Nation, Awash in Immigrants With Nowhere to Go
text: VALLETTA, Malta — On a recent evening, the immigrants living in the steel shipping containers out by the abandoned airport here began to bed down for the night, pulling their mattresses outside to escape the suffocating heat.

text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Those of us who make the New York Times crossword puzzle appear in your newspaper were up way past our bedtimes last night running the Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament benefiting the Pleasantville Fund for Learning, so this one will be short.

headline: Eating for Health, Not Weight
text: ALMOST half of Americans are on a diet — not surprising, since two-thirds are overweight or obese, a frightening statistic that inspired Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to push through a ban on large soft drinks in New York City. The country is preoccupied with calories. McDonald’s, for instance, is now posting them. But our widespread hope for weight loss makes us vulnerable to all kinds of promises, even ones that aren’t true, when it comes to food.

headline: In Shark-Infested Waters, Resolve of Two Giants Is Tested
text: SENKAKU/DIAOYU ISLANDS — The voyage to these remote islands at the center of one of Asia’s most heated territorial disputes is a bone-jarring seven-hour boat ride from one of Japan’s southernmost ports, a long enough journey that the fishermen who brave the often stormy seas regularly sail in pairs for safety. The trip from the mainland of China, which also lays claim to the islands, is even longer.

headline: Rebels Announce Move of Headquarters From Turkey to ‘Liberated’ Syria Territory
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Commanders of the Free Syrian Army, the main umbrella group for fighters opposing President Bashar al-Assad, said Saturday that they had moved their headquarters from Turkey into “liberated areas” inside Syria, in what they portrayed as a major step forward in their efforts to aid, coordinate and control disparate groups of rebels.

headline: Mitt Romney Says, “I Am The Confidence Fairy!”
text: I’ve coined a few successful turns of phrase over the years, but none, I think, as successful as the confidence fairy — a term I used to refer to the belief that things like austerity in the face of depression would actually be expansionary, because of … CONFIDENCE.

headline: A New Capital for U.S. Golf (Pop. 13,000)
text: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga. — The golfer Davis Love III is like the Spanish moss draped over the stately trees on the Avenue of Oaks. He has been hanging around this barrier island for so long that he has become part of the scenery, a low-maintenance presence invisible to the local residents.

headline: Virginia Republican Adopts Cuts in Defense as His Issue
text: STAFFORD, Va. — Just outside the gates of the storied Quantico Marine Base, George Allen, the Republican nominee for a Senate seat from Virginia, sat down in the offices of a moving van company with more than a dozen defense contractors from his state last Monday to listen to them fret over government spending cuts.

headline: Middle Schools Add a Team Rule: Get a Drug Test
text: MILFORD, Pa. — As a 12-year-old seventh grader, Glenn and Kathy Kiederer’s older daughter wanted to play sports at Delaware Valley Middle School here. She also wanted to join the scrapbooking club.

headline: Facebook Invitation Draws Thousands, and a Melee, to Dutch Town
text: A sleepy Dutch community was still recovering on Saturday from the aftermath of a sweet sixteen party whose invitation, for no clear reason, went viral, spawning a YouTube video, drawing impromptu partygoers by the thousands as well as riot police, and causing the young celebrant and her family to flee town.

headline: With Rich Donors, a More Candid Romney Emerges
text: LAS VEGAS — In Chicago, Mitt Romney regaled wealthy donors with a boyhood memory of volunteering to clean up a litter-strewn football field, the kind of humanizing tale he typically avoids on the campaign trail.

headline: Wind Sprints to the Cliff
text: The wind industry’s main trade association is predicting that new installations will fall to zero without a renewal of the production tax credit, which applies only to projects finished by New Year’s Eve. Since renewal is iffy, some wind machine factories are already shutting down, as my colleague Diane Cardwell reported on Friday.

headline: Miley Makes Case for N.L. Rookie of the Year
text: Ken Griffey Jr. was 19 as a rookie for Seattle in 1989. He hit .264 with 16 homers and 61 runs batted in, a strong showing for his age that foreshadowed greatness. But Gregg Olson, Baltimore’s closer, had a better season and was rookie of the year.

headline: University Is Uneasy as Court Ruling Allows Guns on Campus
text: BOULDER, Colo. — During her 19 years teaching English at the University of Colorado Boulder, Karen Jacobs never gave much thought to whether one of her students was carrying a gun.

headline: Free Speech in the Age of YouTube
text: San Francisco

headline: Washington Versus America
text: WHEN I moved to Washington, D.C., in 2002, you could sense that the nation’s capital had turned a corner after decades of decline. But the Washington of 10 years ago still looked basically like the city that had been scarred by riots in the 1960s and then emptied by white flight, with a prosperous northwest divided from a blighted south and east, and frontiers of gentrification that weren’t that many blocks from the Capitol itself.

headline: In Times Sq., Reminders of an American Missing in Iran
text: When President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran arrives in New York for the United Nations General Assembly, delegates may see the face of an American missing in Iran for more than five years.

headline: When a Severe Injury Shakes a Team to Its Heart
text: Ken Dallafior, a former Detroit Lions offensive lineman, froze in front of his television Sept. 8 when he saw Tulane safety Devon Walker lying on the field after a collision with a teammate.

headline: N.H.L. Fines Red Wings Executive for Lockout Remarks
text: The N.H.L. announced Saturday that it had fined the Detroit Red Wings an undisclosed amount for comments about the lockout made by Jim Devellano, a club senior vice president, in an interview published this week.

headline: The Son Also Sets
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Avoiding Student Loan Default
text: The federal student loan program offers flexible payment plans that are supposed to keep borrowers out of default even when they have lost their jobs and can afford almost nothing in monthly payments. But these programs will never serve their intended purpose until the government does a better job of getting out the word about them and makes them easier to use.

headline: When GPS Tracking Violates Privacy Rights
text: For the right to personal privacy to survive in America in this digital age, courts must be meticulous in applying longstanding privacy protections to new technology. This did not happen in an unfortunate ruling last month by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

headline: Anticipating the Next Pandemic
text: Bozeman, Mont.

headline: Underdogged
text: “I definitely think Mitt goes in as an underdog,” Ann Romney said in a television interview earlier this month. Mr. Romney’s campaign happens to be imploding at the moment, but his supporters have been calling him an underdog since the primaries. In February, Mr. Romney said he was the underdog in Michigan, his home state. In June, Gov. Scott Walker said Mr. Romney was the underdog in Wisconsin. Sometimes, being just any old underdog isn’t enough. “He’s the tremendous underdog,” said a Republican committeeman in New Hampshire.

headline: In Malta, Immigrants Left in Limbo
text: The tiny Mediterranean nation lacks the resources to adequately house them and by law cannot let them move to the mainland.

headline: 2 Islamist Militias Disband in Libya Amid Anger Over Killings
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Two Islamist militias in the eastern city of Darnah announced Saturday that they were disbanding, bowing to a wave of antimilitia anger that has swept parts of Libya since a deadly attack on an American diplomatic mission on Sept. 11.

headline: Exploiting the Prophet
text: “PISS CHRIST,” a famous photograph partly financed by taxpayers, depicted a crucifix immersed in what the artist said was his own urine. But conservative Christians did not riot on the Washington Mall.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Conflicts Over Religion
text: Readers discuss faith-based disagreement, vitriol and violence.

headline: Deciding When a Pet Has Suffered Enough
text: Lyons, Colo.

headline: ‘Defenders’ of the Faith
text: My Sunday column looks at the violent protests around the Islamic world after the airing of the inane video trailer mocking the Prophet Muhammad. I try to look at why there’s such outrage at blasphemy in the Islamic world, and whether extremists are trying to hijack the Arab Spring. If I’d had a bit more space, I would have made one more point. The history of Islam is largely of being the dominant religion in its sphere, closely allied with rulers, while Christianity and Judaism have long experience as minority faiths. I think that one consequence is that Christianity has more expectation of sacrilege or mockery, while that’s more of a shock to many Muslims, particularly to Sunnis living in Sunni countries.

headline: Hard Lines, Red Lines and Green Lines
text: Washington

headline: Edwin P. Wilson, the Spy Who Lived It Up, Dies at 84
text: Part spy, part tycoon, Edwin P. Wilson lived large.

headline: A Little Night Music
text: This is the season of the night fiddlers, when you know summer is fraying away. The air brims with their eerie music, although we rarely see the musicians — katydids and crickets playing their marimbas, as they lift their wings high and rub a sharp edge of one wing over a ridge of pegs on the other. It’s as if they’re combing strands of song from their wings.

headline: C.E.O.’s and the Pay-’Em-or-Lose-’Em Myth
text: CORPORATIONS are forever defending big executive paydays. If we don’t pay up, the argument goes, our sharpest minds will jump to our rivals.

headline: California Takes On the Retirement Crisis
text: When you think of California as a trendsetter, retirement policy is probably not the first thing that comes to mind, but that may soon change.

headline: Rethinking Sleep
text: SOMETIME in the dark stretch of the night it happens. Perhaps it’s the chime of an incoming text message. Or your iPhone screen lights up to alert you to a new e-mail. Or you find yourself staring at the ceiling, replaying the day in your head. Next thing you know, you’re out of bed and engaged with the world, once again ignoring the often quoted fact that eight straight hours of sleep is essential.

headline: Dr. William C. Dement
text: Considered the father of sleep medicine, Dr. William C. Dement, 84, has studied slumbering since the 1950s. He has written countless scientific papers and books and is the founder of the Stanford Sleep Disorders Clinic, the world’s first sleep laboratory. Undergraduates still pack into lecture halls every semester to take his “Sleep and Dreams” course, and he has a cameo role in the film “Sleepwalk With Me,” which is currently in theaters.

headline: The New World
text: We appear to be on the brink of a nation-state baby boom. These new countries will not be the product of a single political change or conflict, as was the post-Soviet proliferation, nor will they be confined to a specific region. If anything, they are linked by a single, undeniable fact: history chews up borders with the same purposeless determination that geology does, as seaside villas slide off eroding coastal cliffs. Here is an interactive map of what could become the world’s newest international borders.

headline: Assessing Manager of the Year Races
text: To win this award, a manager typically must do one of the following: win a lot more games than people expected (like the Padres’ Bud Black in 2010), overcome an unforeseen obstacle (like the Angels’ Mike Scioscia in 2009, after the death of pitcher Nick Adenhart) or win in historic fashion (like the Mariners’ Lou Piniella in 2001, when his team won 116 games).

headline: Jets Rookie Wide Receiver Is in a New World of Zigs and Zags
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Last Sunday in Pittsburgh, Stephen Hill grappled with the Steelers’ cornerbacks. He pushed to create separation on his routes. He shoved them as he blocked on running plays. They pushed and shoved him right back. By game’s end, Hill was exhausted. He had lined up at receiver for 40 of the Jets’ 51 offensive plays, and Mark Sanchez had thrown his way only twice — a deep ball that was broken up and a pass that bounced at his feet.

headline: America the Anxious
text: “The search for happiness is one of the chief sources of unhappiness.” — Eric Hoffer

headline: Unlikely Joint Effort by U.S. and Venezuela Leads to a Drug Lord’s Arrest
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — To President Hugo Chávez, the United States has long been The Enemy, the imperialist power that seeks to undermine his Socialist-inspired revolution, that plots to oust him from office — and that he loves to taunt.

headline: Paint by Numbers or Connect the Dots
text: This interview with   Mark B. Templeton, president and C.E.O. of Citrix, the Internet software company, was conducted and edited by   Adam Bryant.

headline: Commander of the Apps, Except the One for Guilt
text: IN San Francisco recently, I was running late for a meeting, desperate for a ride. But no buses or cabs were in sight.

headline: Critics Press Cambodia to Fight Violence on its Forest Frontier
text: [Sept. 23, 11:40 p.m. | Update | The Earth Journalism Network and Society of Environmental Journalists have launched a petition pressing the Cambodian government for a full investigation of the murder.]

headline: For the Home Workshop, a GPS for Power Tools
text: WOODWORKING is a tricky skill to master. Students learn to measure carefully before they reach for a saw, and to cut as true to the design as hand and eye allow. But, even so, precise cutting is a painstaking job, full of pitfalls and mismatched moldings.

headline: Princeton President Announces She Will Step Down
text: The president of Princeton University, Shirley M. Tilghman, announced on Saturday that she would step down in June. Dr. Tilghman, a molecular biologist and a professor, became the second woman to lead an Ivy League institution when she emerged as the surprise choice to head the university in 2001.

headline: App Smart Extra: An Auxiliary Memory
text: This week’s App Smart column introduced to you some journal writing apps for iOS and Android. Compared to the fuss of pen and paper, and considering that we tend to carry our smartphones and tablets more or less everywhere these days, these apps are very convenient. A good journal app may actually tempt you to write a diary even if you’ve never done so before.

headline: The Return of Joe the Greek
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — About “Joe Bidenopoulos.”

headline: Boogaard’s Parents File Lawsuit Against the N.H.L. Players’ Association
text: The parents of Derek Boogaard, the N.H.L. enforcer who died in May 2011 of an accidental overdose of prescription painkillers and alcohol, have sued the N.H.L. Players’ Association.

headline: Ryan Criticizes Obama’s Cuba Policy and Explains His Shift on the Issue
text: MIAMI — On a morning intended to reassure hard-line anti-Castro voters, who are a powerful force in South Florida Republican politics, Representative Paul D. Ryan made a pilgrimage to a restaurant here at the heart of the Cuban exile community in Little Havana. Part of the reason: to criticize what he called President Obama’s “appeasement” of the Cuban government.

headline: A Return to Minnesota, but Probably Not a Deli
text: NEWPORT, Minn. — The walls inside Tinucci’s deli and dining room are covered with family photographs dating to the 1930s, along with two decades of newspaper reviews. Nothing indicates the event that put the unpretentious establishment ever so briefly in the national spotlight almost two years ago.

headline: In New York, Reverence for Myanmar’s Opposition Leader
text: Just after midnight on Saturday, a crowd began descending on a narrow stretch of sidewalk at Queens College. The people came from all over New York and from as far away as Miami and North Carolina, but originally, they and their families were from Myanmar. They stood in line overnight to see the leader of that country’s opposition, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who came to New York on Saturday as part of her first visit to the United States in some 40 years.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Fendi
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: The Man Who Would Be Redstone
text: FROM up in the carob trees come the strains of great movie themes: the sad hum of “Love Story,” the creepy lull of “Rosemary’s Baby,” the jazzy screech of “Chinatown.” Below, just outside the grand entrance of the building where Adolph Zukor and Cecil B. DeMille once did business, Sumner M. Redstone’s retinue sips Champagne in the hot afternoon sun.

headline: Emilio Pucci: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Milan

headline: Pakistani Minister Offers Bounty Over Anti-Islam Video
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani cabinet minister offered a $100,000 reward on Saturday for the death of the person behind the anti-Islam video made in the United States that has roiled Muslims around the world, even suggesting that Taliban and Al Qaeda militants could carry out the killing.

headline: Mets Hang On to Give Dickey His 19th Victory
text: Contrary to some recent evidence, Citi Field can host life — and not just one form of it, either.

headline: Nation’s Choices Needn’t Be Painful
text: REFERRING to the host of painful economic choices the nation is said to confront, President Obama recently said, “I won’t pretend the path I’m offering is quick or easy.” The Romney-Ryan ticket has also repeatedly stressed that it won’t duck the tough issues.

headline: With Aid Cutoff, Kremlin Recalibrates
text: MOSCOW — It began as an urgent effort to stave off political chaos, build basic institutions, and even prevent starvation in the anxiety-ridden aftermath of the fall of the Soviet Union.

headline: Exploring Europe’s Options as N.H.L. Players Seek Work
text: Whenever Gary Bettman and the N.H.L. owners lock out their players, fans in North America have a chance to reacquaint themselves with European hockey. It happened in 1994-95, in 2004-5 and now again in 2012.

headline: Sander’s Return to Sander Receives a Warm Reception
text: The immediate reaction of buyers and editors to Jil Sander’s first women’s collection shown here since her latest return to the house that bears her name can be summed up thus: Better than they could have hoped.

headline: Blowing the Whistle on Online Returns
text: THE Haggler’s last column looked at a practice that employees at Staples call “walking the customer” — essentially, escorting shoppers out of the store, empty-handed, when it’s clear they have no intention of buying a warranty for some steeply discounted computer. You’ve heard of the bait and switch? This is the bait and ditch. Staples officials, you may recall, would say only that they don’t require sales staff members to sell warranties, but e-mails from other Staples employees that arrived after the column’s publication suggest that pressure to sell extras is intense.

headline: In Round 3 for the Fed, a Challenge for Investors
text: “DON’T fight the Fed,” the saying goes. In the current circumstances, with the Federal Reserve using monetary policy to try to spur economic growth, the adage implies that investors should go with the flow by betting on stocks.

headline: Finding the Roots of Your Office Anger

headline: New System for Patients to Report Medical Mistakes
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration wants consumers to report medical mistakes and unsafe practices by doctors, hospitals, pharmacists and others who provide treatment.

headline: Conqueror of the Kitchen
text: THE town where I grew up in India had limited electricity, a high crime rate and rampant corruption. I could have gone down the wrong path, but my parents inspired me to do otherwise. I had values and did well in school.

headline: Shumpert Dunks the iPhone 5
text: Iman Shumpert of the Knicks does not reveal much about his recovery from knee surgery, but he does answer the oft-asked question “Does the iPhone 5 work as a basketball?” in this new video from The NOC.

headline: Egypt’s New Leader Spells Out Terms for U.S.-Arab Ties
text: CAIRO — On the eve of his first trip to the United States as Egypt’s new Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi said the United States needed to fundamentally change its approach to the Arab world, showing greater respect for its values and helping build a Palestinian state, if it hoped to overcome decades of pent-up anger.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 23
text: Campaign surrogates for each of the candidates have been dispatched to the Sunday shows this week, focusing less on the unrest in the Arab world and more on the economy and current climate of the campaign trail. But first, the candidates themselves will appear on Univision’s “Al Punto” for an in-depth look at their policies and platforms. Telemundo’s “Enfoque” will air an extended version of a sit-down with Mitt Romney, who goes into detail about what some view as problems within his campaign and United States foreign policy toward Mexico and Latin America.   Representative Xavier Becerra of California will be on hand to deliver a Democratic rebuttal.

headline: Breathtaking
text: “Just you wait, ‘enry ‘iggins, just you wait!You’ll be sorry, but your tears’ll be too late!You’ll be broke, and I’ll have money;Will I help you? Don’t be funny!Just you wait, ‘enry ‘iggins, just you wait!” — ELIZA DOOLITTLE, My Fair Lady

headline: 30 Seconds With Nick Buoniconti
text: Nick Buoniconti was the linebacker who anchored the No-Name Defense for the Miami Dolphins when they went undefeated in 1972. His Dolphins teams made three consecutive Super Bowl appearances, winning two. Buoniconti, 71, was inducted to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2001.

headline: A Pipeline From Israel to Storrs
text: As Israel tries to qualify for next year’s World Baseball Classic, it has turned to a team of predominantly American players. It recalls the time when Jim Calhoun did just the opposite, looking to Israel for talent as he was building a men’s basketball powerhouse at Connecticut.

headline: The Caucus Click: Stopping for a Snack
text: President Obama, campaigning in Wisconsin with Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett on Saturday, stopped at Usinger’s, a local deli founded in 1880. He ordered a kielbasa, Italian sausage and a hot sausage.

headline: Police Divers Pull Man From Capsized Boat
text: Four adults and two children plunged into the water just south of the Atlantic Beach Bridge off Long Island on Saturday morning after a boat they were in suddenly capsized, the authorities said.

headline: With Sharon Stone as Auctioneer, amFAR Milano Has a Benefit
text: “Milan is one of my favorite cities,” the designer Kenneth Cole said Saturday night at a black-tie benefit for amFAR Milano, held for the fourth year straight at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: In Kennedy Recordings, History’s Raw Materials
text: BOSTON — President John F. Kennedy opened the newspaper one day in 1963 and learned to his horror that military aides had built a hospital bedroom for his pregnant wife at an air base on Cape Cod in case she went into labor. He thought the $5,000 spent on the furniture was wasteful and would be a public-relations disaster that would prompt Congress to cut his military budget. The angry president picked up the phone.

headline: Fighting for First, for as Long as It Takes
text: When the game seemed over, Ichiro Suzuki led off the bottom of the 13th inning with an infield single. A misty rain had begun to fall, like the soft spray in a carwash. The low sun through the clouds covered the stadium in a strange orange glow.

headline: Man Arrested in Rape Along the Hudson River
text: A young woman was raped in Hudson River Park in Lower Manhattan on Saturday, and shortly afterward the police arrested a convicted sex offender in the crime.

headline: U.S. League Is Loaded With Talent and Drama
text: If it were not for the Internet, there would be no United States Chess League, because it is the Web that allows teams from across the country to play one another without expensive airplane trips.

headline: Sept. 22: Little Agreement Among Pollsters on ‘Enthusiasm Gap’
text: Saturday brought a light volume of polling data, and the FiveThirtyEight forecast was not much changed. Barack Obama’s chances of winning the Electoral College are 77.5 percent, according to the model, slightly improved from 76.9 percent in Friday’s forecast.

headline: Jets Cut Bryan Thomas
text: The Jets made a surprising move Saturday by cutting the veteran linebacker Bryan Thomas to clear roster space for cornerback Donnie Fletcher ahead of Sunday’s game at Miami.

headline: With Playoff Berth Secured, Liberty Unload on Shock
text: NEWARK — Citing recent champions who capitalized on the momentum of late-season surges, Liberty Coach John Whisenant says his team is in the right spot to challenge for the W.N.B.A. title.

headline: Giving Viewers Some New Music to Treasure
text: Last month, just as Tim McGraw was about to sit down for his post-set interview in the “Austin City Limits” studio, his eyes wandered toward a framed photograph of George Strait’s first appearance on the PBS concert showcase. Mr. McGraw immediately ran back to his dressing room, grabbed his wife, Faith Hill, and showed her Mr. Strait’s baby face, beaming from beneath a tall white cowboy hat.

headline: In Ryan Country, Obama Keeps Up Attack Over ‘47 Percent’ Remarks
text: MILWAUKEE — President Obama traveled to the home turf of his opponent’s running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan, on Saturday, reprising his attack on Mitt Romney for remarks he made behind closed doors characterizing Obama voters as the 47 percent of the population who depend on government handouts and do not pay federal income taxes.

headline: Shumpert, Walking Without Limp, Says He Is Feeling Fine
text: The first guest speaker for Allan Houston’s Five Borough Basketball Tour was Knicks guard Iman Shumpert. When he was introduced, Shumpert was cheered by more than 100 children who participated in the event in Brooklyn. Shumpert smiled. He didn’t have a brace on his left knee. And he walked without a limp.

Buebel and Jeffrey N. Tuchman of Pleasantville, N.Y. Rabbi Scott Matous officiated at the Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y.

headline: How to Settle the Fight Over Some Guano-Covered Rocks
text: HONG KONG — No matter what they’re called by their claimants in China, Japan and Taiwan, the East Asian islands at the center of an angry dispute are little more than remote shards of guano-covered rock.

headline: College Football Around the Country
text: TAYLOR HEINICKE The quarterback set a Division I record by passing for 730 yards as Old Dominion beat New Hampshire, 64-61. Heinicke had 55 completions on 79 attempts, setting team records for both and coming two completions short of the Football Championship Subdivision record. Sam Durley of Eureka (Ill.) College set the N.C.A.A. single-game mark with 736 passing yards in a Division II game Sept. 1.

headline: Seminoles Stand Atop A.C.C. After Offense vs. Offense Duel
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — It was a harmless, clichéd joke — Florida State Coach Jimbo Fisher saying he had appealed to use 13 or 14 defenders to slow Clemson’s offense — that now seemed facetious. The same compliment could have been paid to Fisher’s offense, but no defender laughed now. If either No. 4 Florida State or No. 10 Clemson had such an advantage, it might not have mattered, as each offense hummed along Saturday.

headline: Notre Dame Improves to 4-0 for the First Time in a Decade
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Notre Dame’s return to national prominence took another step forward Saturday night. It was far from graceful, but the 11th-ranked Fighting Irish are 4-0 for the first time in a decade after knocking off No. 18 Michigan, 13-6.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Tehelka’s cover story this week, “The Invisible Dead,” is about malaria, which the magazine calls Chhattisgarh’s silent killer. Officially, the story says, there have been no malaria deaths in the state this year; investigating such claims, the writers found what they call “a snare of lies and Stalinist statistics.”

text: Rendezvous regular Mark McDonald asked for fresh U.S. embassy stories. Here is an old one from back when America waded into Vietnam, China was a forbidding foe, and Cold War rivals could have easily blown each other off the map.

headline: A New Home Advantage in the N.F.L.?

headline: ‘I’m Spoiled, but I’m Not a Brat’
text: While growing up, I would routinely choose to play Pokémon over doing the dishes. The fact that I had a choice never struck me as strange. While I certainly had chores — cleaning my room when it became unlivable, walking the dog I had begged for, attending the piano lessons my parents had paid for — I had very few household responsibilities. You could say I was spoiled. And thanks to the recent discourse surrounding my generation’s upbringing, I’ve just discovered that I’m one of millions of 21st-century American kids who have been shielded from hardship by overprotective parents.

headline: Nebraska G.O.P. Draws a Tougher Map for Obama
text: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Nebraska, the Cornhusker State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with John R. Hibbing, a professor of political science at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, and Paul Landow, a professor of political science at the University of Nebraska at Omaha.

headline: Getting Some Air in Milan
text: Everyone in Milan seems taken with minimalism this season. “Firmness… sparseness as elegance,” the Marni show notes began. Scraping away most of the Marni trinkets and funky layers, Consuelo Castiglioni presented a very spare collection indeed. The newsy portions included sleeveless dresses that floated over the body, with their shape enhanced by crisp fabrics and flattering pleats and folds. Nothing seemed too much in this appealing show. The checked outfits that opened the show had a slight 3-D effect, and Ms. Castiglioni included a few more eye tricks later with dresses in a green half-circle print cut and assembled on a diagonal. But she was right to concentrate on her sculptural A-line pieces in solid neutral tones, some as simple as a loose cotton top over flared matching shorts and others with a kind of crazily deconstructed peplum.

headline: Jil Sander: Minimalism With a Kick
text: One could find all kinds of meaning in Jil Sander’s show and her return to the label after an eight-year absence. There was the white set with a concave, spherical ceiling that resembled an architect’s idea of a modern, corporate conference room. One woman — Ms. Sander herself — was going to speak that day and the audience, seated around the square platform, was going to listen.

headline: Expectations and the Confidence Fairy
text: Some readers have asked whether there isn’t an inconsistency between my view that the Fed can promote economic recovery by changing expectations about future policy, and my ridicule of austerity proponents who invoke “confidence” as a reason to believe that austerity will actually be expansionary. But there isn’t really any inconsistency; it’s an orders of magnitude thing.

headline: Mr. Mental Recession
text: Brad DeLong is upset by the illogic of John Taylor and Phil Gramm’s attack on the Fed. Indeed: it boggles the mind that they believe that a downside of expansionary policy now is that it will require contractionary policy once the economy has recovered. Um, isn’t that exactly what you want monetary policy to do — boost the economy when it’s weak, take away the punchbowl when the party gets going?

headline: Bill Clinton Says He’s Unsure of Wife’s 2016 Plans
text: WASHINGTON — Former President Bill Clinton said Sunday that he had “no earthly idea” whether his wife might decide to run for the presidency in 2016, but that he had never met a more qualified public servant and that she would have his full support no matter what she decides.

headline: Betrayed by Those Wonderful People Out There in the Dark
text: Any Hollywood history can describe a star’s X factor. But not many film historians can see the whole equation as Ty Burr does in “Gods Like Us,” his lively and provocative chronicle of the genesis of movie stars and the metamorphosis of movie stardom. He offers original thinking about the audience factor.

headline: Films Tie for Top Box Office Spot
text: Clint Eastwood faced some empty chairs at North American movie theaters over the weekend: Two new movies, “End of Watch” and “House at the End of the Street,” tied for No. 1, followed by Mr. Eastwood’s “Trouble With the Curve.”

headline: Joy Turns to Despair at National Zoo as Newborn Panda Is Found Dead
text: WASHINGTON — A giant panda’s distress call sent keepers at the National Zoo rushing to the aid of her tiny, lifeless cub on Sunday, and the elation over the cub’s birth just a week earlier turned to despair over its death.

headline: With a Servant’s Pregnancy Comes a Man’s Chute From High Society
text: Class conflict gets a workout in the Mint Theater  Company’s lively, penetrating revival of “Mary Broome,” the troupe’s latest invigoration of a largely forgotten work. The play’s author, Allan Monkhouse (1858-1936), also a novelist and critic, was known for his acerbic dissections of the English bourgeoisie. “Mary Broome” — a comedy that first appeared in Manchester in 1911 and was last staged in Manhattan in 1919, at the Neighborhood Playhouse on Grand Street — cuts right to its heart.

headline: Visual Aside Accompanies Sounds of an Ensemble
text: The third movement of Mozart’s “Gran Partita,” his Serenade No. 10 for winds in B flat, is one of the most quietly, simply sublime passages in music. It begins with a simple four-note figure that rises and then falls into a gently pulsing, syncopated carpet of sound.

headline: Before Armani’s Show, a Look at the Past
text: Guests walking into the Giorgio Armani show tonight had the option to first take a detour into an exhibition of his designs spanning 20 years or more, loosely grouped around the theme “Eccentrico,” or “Eccentric.”

text: Shirley M. Tilghman, the president of Princeton University since 2001, will be stepping down from her post in June. She announced her decision on Saturday in an e-mail to the Princeton community, our colleague Ariel Kaminer reports:

headline: Robust Cello and Viola, With a Few Whoops
text: When the New Juilliard Ensemble made its debut in September 1993, Edward Rothstein, writing in The New York Times, described the splintered nature of the city’s new-music scene at the time and the intense competition for audiences and financing.

headline: After a Fitting Tribute, Liverpool’s Inspired Play Falls Short
text: LIVERPOOL, England — In the buildup to the Liverpool versus Manchester United match Sunday, there was little talk of the soccer game; the eyes of the world focused not on the field but the spectators surrounding it.

headline: Even When There’s a Him Around, Balanchine Is Still About Her
text: The biographies of George Balanchine tell us of his several wives, of his other loves, and of his devotion to the female dancer. His ballets, though, make his feeling for women yet more complicated. Even in moments of amorous surrender one part of his women stays unreachable. And one part of his men always craves, in female terms, what they cannot have.

headline: When Silenced, They Speak Out in Art
text: On Friday night at New York Live Arts the two-part “Voices of Strength: Contemporary Dance & Theater by Women From Africa” unveiled its second program, a shared evening of works by Maria Helena Pinto and Bouchra Ouizguen. These choreographic voices — the first from Mozambique, the second from Morocco — each had something to impart about the link between feminism and making art.

headline: You Have a Role in This Play: Peeping Tom
text: When I first looked in on them, around 4:30 p.m., they were all asleep. Or unconscious. Or dead. It was hard to tell. An hour and some minutes later, the three of them were knocked out again, but this time in different positions, different places and, come to think of it, different clothes. And that was when things started to get interesting.

headline: A Jazzman Looks at Loss and Finds Inspiration
text: Dave Douglas dealt sparingly with the emotional back story at 92YTriBeCa on Wednesday night, in the auspicious first outing by his new quintet. During a concert built around the Protestant hymns on his gorgeous and contemplative new album, “Be Still” — due out on Tuesday on Greenleaf, his independent label — Mr. Douglas spoke of his motivation only in passing. The album, he said simply, “came about because all these hymns and songs were songs that my mother recommended that I play.”

headline: Iraq, Afghanistan … Iran? We’ve Been Here Before.
text: WASHINGTON — Ten years ago, President George W. Bush and top officials in his administration assured Americans that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction and that an American invasion of that country was justified and wouldn’t be that difficult.

headline: Yankees End Homestand With Loss, but With Lead Intact
text: There would be no dramatic comeback or postgame delirium at Yankee Stadium, in contrast to the previous two days. The Yankees, for the third time this series, had an opportunity to win with a hit. But the Oakland Athletics held on for a 5-4 win Sunday.

headline: Kind of Like ‘Will & Grace,’ but Both Guys This Time
text: Some shows need a script doctor. The new sitcom “Partners,” based on the working relationship of its creators, David Kohan and Max Mutchnick, calls out for a couples counselor. Maybe he could explain why this celebration of friendship feels so sour and joyless.

headline: After Jail and Release, New Fame as an Author
text: On a Thursday afternoon walk along Canal Street, Damien Echols was reflecting on how this busy thoroughfare once nourished him in the first few months after his August 2011 release from a super-maximum-security prison in Arkansas.

headline: The Pettiness, the Paparazzi, the Pressure
text: Stardom is a vale of tears in Madhur Bhandarkar’s “Heroine,” about the ups and downs, and downs and downs of Mahi Arora (Kareena Kapoor), a Bollywood queen with a self-destructive flair for making headlines. Pulpy but attenuated, “Heroine” tries to do too much: deliver an exposé of the back-stabbing film business while also drawing a portrait of a woman caught in its vice.

headline: Jets Make the Most of a Second Chance
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — All the Jets wanted was for this game to end already, this ugly, sloppy, chaotic game that had claimed their best player, Darrelle Revis, confirmed that their Week 1 offensive eruption was an aberration and would send them scurrying afterward to gulp Pedialyte as if it were water in the desert.

headline: A Touch of Melancholy From the Top of the World
text: Time was, if you were an ambitious pop band looking to upholster your music with orchestral finery, you enlisted an arranger who traveled in similar circles: a Jack Nitzsche, Clare Fischer or Michael Kamen. Presumably, no rock star ever phoned Aaron Copland.

headline: Buffett Cup in Omaha
text: At the Buffett Cup in Omaha this month probably the best defense occurred in the diagramed deal. It was played in three no-trump four times, but the contract failed only once.

headline: Perpendicular to the Keel
text: Administrivial Unusual Puzzle Alert! The Tuesday, Sept. 25 puzzle will be offered in both Across Lite and as a PDF. Because of the unusual nature of this puzzle, some elements of the grid and the cluing will not reproduce the same way in Across Lite. If you normally solve online in Across Lite, we strongly recommend that you print out the PDF and solve it that way.

headline: Belarus Votes as Europe Keeps a Watch for Signs That Sanctions Can End
text: MINSK, Belarus — Belarus held parliamentary elections on Sunday, though the outcome was hardly in doubt: supporters of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko have traditionally won, and now hold, all 110 seats in the chamber.

headline: More ‘Treme’ Is on the Way
text: Fans of the HBO drama “Treme” were given multiple reasons to celebrate over the weekend as David Simon and Eric Overmyer, the creators of the series, announced that HBO had ordered a fourth and final season one day before the Season 3 premiere, The Times-Picayune of New Orleans reported. In a speech before a show screening at the Joy Theater in New Orleans on Saturday Mr. Simon told the audience that the fourth season would be shortened, with a total episode count to be determined. “We are going to be back for a season 3.5,” Mr. Simon said. He also announced that all of the actors who portray the varied characters that populate the show’s post-Katrina New Orleans, will return, “To a person they all came back,” he said. “We’re happy for a chance to finish the story on our own terms.”

headline: Television’s Fall Season Endures
text: For years, Alan Wurtzel, the head of research for NBC, has questioned the enduring validity of a television season — the ritual competition of network series, which begins again Monday night.

headline: A Connecticut Building for Sanaa
text: Designs for a new building by the architecture firm Sanaa, to be used as a spiritual and community center, are to be submitted for approval on Monday by Grace Farms Foundation in New Canaan, Conn. The plans for the building, called the River, which must be approved by the town’s Planning and Zoning Commission, call for construction on a sliver of the 75-acre Grace Farms property that the foundation is preserving as permanent open space. The building is to have landscaping by the Philadelphia firm Olin. Sanaa, founded in Tokyo in 1995, is the architecture firm of Kazuyo Sejima and Ryue Nishizawa, who received the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2010.

headline: Another Lesson in Consistency, as Vettel Wins in Singapore
text: SINGAPORE — It has been the leitmotif of the season: The key to who will win the drivers’ title will likely come down to consistency, not necessarily victories. Sebastian Vettel took only his second victory of the season in his Red Bull car at the Singapore Grand Prix on Sunday, but he moved back into second place in the series.

headline: To Complete a Sweep, the Mets Overcome the Sun, the Wind and the Marlins
text: The Mets’ struggling offense sprang to life Sunday as Ruben Tejada’s bases-loaded single with two outs in the ninth inning drove in Scott Hairston for the winning run in a 3-2 victory against the Miami Marlins.

headline: Kerik Is Leaving His Cell to Testify at a Bronx Trial
text: Bernard B. Kerik, the disgraced former police commissioner of New York, will return to the city in the coming days, though certainly not triumphantly, and not yet as a free man.

headline: Manchester United 2, Liverpool 1
text: Kristian Walsh was at Anfield on Sunday for Manchester United’s 2-1 victory over Liverpool. But of course the day was about much more than that. Read his article on the game, the Hillsborough tributes and the fans’ behavior here, and come back to comment.

headline: Schiano Does It Again
text: Tampa Bay Coach Greg Schiano remains unimpressed with your victory formation. He was criticized by Giants Coach Tom Coughlin and many others last Sunday for ignoring an unwritten rule about not attacking an offense when the quarterback is poised to kneel to kill off the final seconds of a game.

headline: For Vice President, a Heartbeat Away From the Public Isn’t Close Enough
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Yes, Joseph R. Biden Jr. gives a lot of stump speeches.

headline: Sept. 23: Does Omaha Matter?
text: It’s something of a tradition for newspapers to release polls on Sundays late in a presidential campaign. This Sunday, there were polls out in Ohio, Florida and Pennsylvania — but as it’s Nebraska day at FiveThirtyEight, let’s start with one from the Cornhusker State.

headline: Reinventing Ethics
text: What’s good and what’s bad? There are plenty of reasons to believe that human nature changes slowly, if at all — all’s still fair in love and war. For millennia, religious believers have attributed our nature to God’s image, as well as to God’s plan.  In recent years, evolutionary psychologists peered directly at our forerunners on the savannahs of East Africa; if human beings change, we do so gradually over thousands of years.  Given little or nothing new in the human firmament, traditional morality — the “goods” and “bads” as outlined in the Ten Commandments or the Golden Rule — should suffice.

headline: Mobile Services and Cable TV Are Unexpected Allies
text: BASKING RIDGE, N.J. — Tucked amid rows of office cubicles at the sprawling Verizon Wireless headquarters here and hidden behind a locked door sit the company’s best kept retail secrets.

headline: Obama and Romney Offer a Possible Preview of Their First Debate
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney criticized President Obama in remarks broadcast on Sunday for refusing to meet with Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, during this week’s United Nations General Assembly meeting, saying it sends a message that the administration is distancing itself from an important Middle East ally.

headline: Using Twitter to Promote the Fall TV Season
text: Lots of people are accustomed to watching television while simultaneously posting updates to Twitter or Facebook or looking up information online, or what is known in media circles as “the second screen experience.” But why watch two screens when you can start with one?

headline: Helicopter Coaching Hurts Could-Be Leaders

headline: Spotlighting Women Who Lead

headline: Conservatives Want to ‘Let Ryan Be Ryan’ on Campaign Trail

headline: Seminoles See Dawn of New Glory Days
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — What E. J. Manuel would call the biggest victory of his career had been secured when he galloped free down the sideline, with a clear path to the end zone. All night, he had listened to the former Florida State quarterback Charlie Ward’s advice — take what the defense gives you — and with this run, Manuel joined Ward as the only Seminole to throw for 300 yards and rush for 100 in a game.

headline: Skills Honed in Illicit Trades, and Put to Better Use
text: As a heroin dealer in Rhode Island, Jose Vasquez made $2,000 a day. He said he had a way with his customers. He took his best clients out for dinner and bought them presents on their birthdays.

headline: Yankees Not the Best in Tight Races
text: For all the American League and division titles in their glorious history, the Yankees were for decades seldom involved in a day-to-day, night-to-night pennant race that boiled down to the season’s final weekend, if not the final game.

headline: Proposed Bill Could Change Royalty Rates for Internet Radio
text: Willing buyer, willing seller. Those four words would seem innocuous, but in the world of Internet radio nothing is more contentious.

headline: Romney Blames Obama for His Campaign Challenges
text: DENVER — Mitt Romney, who has been criticized by members of his party in recent weeks for not campaigning aggressively enough and who trails President Obama in polls in most swing states, placed the blame for his campaign’s struggles squarely on the president himself Sunday afternoon.

headline: With Win, Snedeker Also Takes Tour Title
text: ATLANTA — Before the most critical round of his professional career, Brandt Snedeker stopped by the Shepherd Center, a rehabilitation hospital for patients with spinal cord or brain injuries, and spent 30 minutes with his longtime instructor’s son, Tucker Anderson.

headline: The Satanic Video
text: THE alchemy of modern media works with amazing speed. Start with a cheesy anti-Muslim video that resembles a bad trailer for a Sacha Baron Cohen comedy. It becomes YouTube fuel for protest across the Islamic world and a pretext for killing American diplomats. That angry spasm begets an inflammatory Newsweek cover, “MUSLIM RAGE,” which in turn inspires a Twitter hashtag that reduces the whole episode to a running joke:

headline: America’s Inevitable Retreat From the Middle East
text: THE murder of four Americans in Libya and mob assaults on the United States’ embassies across the Muslim world this month have reminded many of 1979, when radical Islamists seized the American mission in Tehran. There, too, extremists running wild after the fall of a pro-American tyrant had found a cheap way of empowering themselves.

headline: ‘Frankenweenie’ Digital Book Updates the Movie Tie-In
text: Coffee-table books, while entertaining to thumb through, tend to gather dust when they languish on said table. So to showcase the animated movie “Frankenweenie,” Disney Publishing Worldwide took an interactive approach, bypassing the traditional oversize tome and heading straight for the iPad.

headline: The Optimism Cure
text: Mitt Romney is optimistic about optimism. In fact, it’s pretty much all he’s got. And that fact should make you very pessimistic about his chances of leading an economic recovery.

headline: Government Issues Order to Disband Libya Forces
text: CAIRO — Libya’s interim government on Sunday ordered the breakup of all militias that do not fall under its authority, and demanded that those militias pull out of military compounds and public property within 48 hours.

headline: Discovery of Skeleton Puts Richard III in Battle Once Again
text: LEICESTER, England — For more than 500 years, King Richard III has been the most widely reviled of English monarchs. But a stunning archaeological find this month here in the English Midlands — a skeleton that medieval scholars believe is very likely to be Richard’s — could lead to a reassessment of his brief but violent reign.

headline: Jennifer Jaff, Advocate for the Ill, Dies at 55
text: Jennifer Jaff, a lawyer whose nearly four-decade struggle with a debilitating disease led her to become a leading advocate for people with chronic illnesses, died on Sept. 14 at her home in Farmington, Conn. She was 55.

headline: Public Television Takes Role in Curbing Dropout Rates

headline: The Cost of the N.F.L.’s Will to Win
text: One of the N.F.L.’s locked-out officials was at home Sunday waiting and watching, like everyone else, for the weekly blooper reel to begin.

headline: Rape in Hudson River Park Is Latest in a String of Jarring Crimes
text: Just after 6 a.m. on Sunday, Georgie Lau cut a solitary figure as he walked down Harrison Street toward the Hudson River in Manhattan, a fishing rod in one hand and a bucket in the other. Before him was a patch of Hudson River Park where, little more than 24 hours earlier, a young woman had been raped after going to sit near the water by herself in the early morning.

headline: A Vexing Flaw in the Subway Is Finally Fixed
text: For more than half a century, it has stood out as a singularly vexing flaw of the subway system, a glaring inequity that has frustrated generations of riders and has even puzzled transit officials, who have wondered how the situation ever came to be.

headline: Marv Kessler, Coach and Basketball Instructor, Dies at 80
text: Marv Kessler, a product of Brooklyn’s schoolyards who spent more than half a century in basketball as a player, a coach, a scout and, most prominently, a camp instructor who molded young athletes like Patrick Ewing and Stephon Marbury, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 80.

headline: Uncertainty in Wake of Injury to Revis
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Things figure to get a lot tougher for the Jets if cornerback Darrelle Revis cannot get back on the field. Revis, considered the league’s top cornerback, left Sunday’s 23-20 overtime victory against the Miami Dolphins in the third quarter with a left knee injury.

headline: Politics, Principle and an Attack on the Courts
text: Two years ago, in what should have been a quiet judicial retention election, Iowa voters threw out three State Supreme Court justices for taking seriously their duty to protect fundamental rights. The three had provoked right-wing wrath for joining a unanimous 2009 ruling overturning the state’s prohibition on same-sex marriage. Conservative forces succeeded in ousting them by tapping antigay sentiment and attacking “activist” judges. Those same forces — aided openly this time by the state’s Republican Party — are now calling for the removal of David Wiggins, another capable judge who joined in the marriage decision.

headline: What Do Teachers Deserve? In Idaho, Referendum May Offer Answer
text: BOISE, Idaho — In the struggle to fix the nation’s public schools, the old red-state, blue-state idea is looking as dated as Dick and Jane. You can hear the change in the voice of Gov. C. L. Otter, a Republican here in one of the most deeply conservative corners of the country, when he expresses a brotherhood bond with Rahm Emanuel, the Democratic mayor of Chicago and former Obama administration chief of staff.

headline: The Shocking News About Cod
text: The ideal fish for human consumption would mature quickly and reproduce in staggering numbers. This does not describe the Atlantic cod. Cod mature late — at 4 to 6 years old — and they can live as long as 25 years. Female cod do, in fact, produce astonishing numbers of eggs. But older cod lay two or three times as many eggs as younger cod. This means that a healthy cod population must include relatively large numbers of older fish.

headline: Deadly Attack in Libya Was Major Blow to C.I.A. Efforts
text: WASHINGTON — The attack in Benghazi, Libya, that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans has dealt the Central Intelligence Agency a major setback in its intelligence-gathering efforts at a time of increasing instability in the North African nation.

headline: On the Wrong Side
text: Leaders of Iraq’s Shiite-led government have often advised the United States not to worry about their ties with Iran, where Shiites are also in the majority. But the assurances are getting harder to swallow. Baghdad is showing a distressing willingness to side with the region’s most repressive regimes, not just Iran but also Iran’s chief ally, the brutal Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Woods and McIlroy Struggle in Final Round but Have Some Reasons to Celebrate
text: ATLANTA — Let the record show that before this past weekend, Tiger Woods could not have owned the East Lake Golf Club course more if he had held the deed to the property.

headline: Liking It or Not, States Prepare for Health Law
text: PHOENIX — Like many Republican governors, Jan Brewer of Arizona is a stinging critic of President Obama’s health care law. When the Supreme Court upheld it in June, she called the ruling “an overreaching and unaffordable assault on states’ rights and individual liberty.”

headline: Apple’s Feud With Google Is Now Felt on iPhone
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Once the best of friends, Google and Apple have become foes, battling in courtrooms and in the consumer marketplace. Last week, the hostilities took a new turn when they spilled right onto smartphone screens.

text: NORTH HUDSON, N.Y. — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, dressed in khaki cargo pants and a navy windbreaker that said “Team Cuomo/We Deliver,” paddled expertly from the rear seat of a canoe on Sunday afternoon. He had just gone fishing, catching an eight-inch brook trout, and now it was time for another adventure.

headline: Running as Outsiders, With a Catch: They’re In
text: WASHINGTON — In one of his campaign advertisements, Joe Heck emphasizes his long career as a physician taking care of elderly patients. Dan Benishek, in an ad, refers with a tinge of sadness to the “career politician” who is competing with him for a House seat. Ann Kirkpatrick informs viewers that she is extremely fond of driving.

headline: Uranium Substitute Is No Longer Needed, but Its Disposal May Pose Security Risk
text: WASHINGTON — At the dawn of the civilian nuclear age in the 1950s, one of the pressing questions was how to find enough fuel for reactors and bombs. The government and the private sector seized on a man-made substitute for natural uranium, producing about 3,400 pounds of an exotic and expensive material called uranium 233.

text: Members of Congress and civil rights groups are pushing the Federal Communications Commission to rein in telephone companies that, in many states, charge inmates spectacularly high rates that can force their families to choose between keeping in touch with a relative behind bars and, in some cases, putting food on the table.

headline: Sinai Group Claims Role in Attack on Israel
text: CAIRO — An obscure militant group based in Egypt’s North Sinai region claimed responsibility over the weekend for a cross-border attack that killed an Israeli soldier last week. headline: Israel Falls in Qualifier Final, but Team Plays for Much More
text: JUPITER, Fla. — Just an inning earlier, Jay Dermer waved the flag of Israel high over his head, holding both ends so that it stretched taut in triumphant fists. Israel had just taken a two-run lead against Spain in a World Baseball Classic qualifying game, and the 1,500 or so Jewish fans at Roger Dean Stadium on Sunday celebrated with equal parts pleasure and pride.

headline: Foxconn Factory in China Is Closed After Worker Riot
text: Foxconn Technology, a major supplier to some of the world’s electronics giants, including Apple, said that it had closed one of its large Chinese plants early Monday after police were called in to break up a fight among factory employees.

text: QUINCY, Wash. — Set in the dry hills and irrigated farmland of Central Washington, Grant County is known for its robust harvest of apples, potatoes, cherries and beans. But for Microsoft, a prime lure was the region’s other valuable resource: cheap electrical power.

headline: Aspiring U.S. Diplomats Stiffen Their Resolve After Ambassador’s Death
text: The recent killing of the U.S. ambassador to Libya, J. The deadly ambush reinforced the idea that many diplomats — even those guarded by security personnel and working in fortified buildings — can quickly find themselves in harm’s way.

Preparation is foremost on my mind.

headline: Green Day’s Billie Joe Armstrong Seeks Treatment After Rant
text: While the occasional onstage outburst or round of instrument destruction would seem to be well within the purview of a modern-day rock star, this behavior has led the Green Day front man Billie Joe Armstrong to seek rehabilitation after a profanity-laden rant at a performance over the weekend, the band announced on its Web site.

headline: A Voice From Myanmar, Worthy of a Hero’s Welcome
text: Long ago, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi lived for a few years in New York. On her arrival in the late 1960s, she was surprised to find a city that was exactly as she had pictured it, skyscrapers and all. “I thought, ‘Oh, it looks just like a postcard,’” Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi said on Saturday. “Somehow, I never really believed it would be quite like that.”

headline: Former Israeli Premier Gets Suspended Sentence
text: JERUSALEM — Ehud Olmert, a former prime minister of Israel, was sentenced by a Jerusalem court on Monday to a one-year suspended prison term and a maximum fine of about $19,000 for breach of trust. The relatively light sentence ended a long-running prosecution that forced Mr. Olmert from office. It also opened the way for a possible political comeback.

headline: Dsquared2: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Milan

headline: For the Love of Country
text: MOSCOW — “Why can’t you just love Russia?” a member of Parliament demanded of me during a recent talk show on Russian television after I said something about the difficulty of covering President Vladimir Putin. This is one of those questions that presumes the respondent is guilty. It is also a question that has become central to Russian political rhetoric.

headline: Can Jets Contend Without Revis?
text: The Jets will soon learn the severity of the knee injury that cornerback Darrelle Revis sustained in a victory at Miami on Sunday.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: NPR: Three things you always wanted to know about salt. Question 2: “Do I really need 10 kinds of salt in my pantry?” – Glenn Collins

headline: Maybe Another Economist With The Same Name?
text: I guess I should take it as a compliment that people who want to attack my record feel the need to make stuff up. Greg Mankiw posts the abstract of a piece claiming that Brad DeLong and I endorsed the early, optimistic Obama administration forecast for unemployment and growth. What? I was famously pessimistic at the time:

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Cable Reigns at the Emmys, and Power Games Behind the ‘Cloud’
text: The Emmys were awarded Sunday night, and there was an upset in the highly competitive drama category, as the newcomer “Homeland,” on Showtime, denied “Mad Men,” on AMC, an unprecedented fifth win, Brian Stelter reported. The ABC show “Modern Family,” however, increased its streak of Emmys as best comedy to three.

headline: Dave & Buster’s Sets Range for I.P.O.
text: Dave & Buster’s Entertainment, the restaurant and arcade chain, announced on Monday that it was seeking to sell 7.7 million shares at $12 to $14 a share during its initial public offering.

headline: Roberto Cavalli: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Milan

headline: Sympathy For The Doofus
text: Mitt Romney is catching a lot of flack from his own side now, which seems premature; although the odds are now against him, this is by no means over. But let me say that even if he does spend election night weeping in his car elevator, his critics from the right are being unfair. Yes, he’s a pretty bad candidate — but the core problem is with his party, not with him.

headline: Fast Forward to the Fierce ’90s
text: Minimalism is not for everyone. The Milan collections came to a close today with revved up runways at Cavalli and Dan and Dean Caten of the label Dsquared, which had little to do with the season’s dominant trends of clean lines and Japanese-influenced sparseness. But they still made for a lively ending.

headline: The Statistical State of the Presidential Race
text: With fewer than 45 days left in the presidential campaign, it’s no longer a cliché to say that every week counts. And there are a few polling-related themes we’ll be watching especially closely this week.

headline: Development’s Opponent Sets Off a Real Estate Battle of His Own
text: The Barclays Center will open its doors this week, buoyed by world-famous performers; slick new uniforms for its basketball team, the Brooklyn Nets; and a formidable advertising campaign.

headline: New Week, Same Ad Themes: China and Taxes
text: Both presidential campaigns have new ads out, but the themes are familiar. The Obama campaign is tying Mitt Romney’s tax returns to his “47 percent” comments, while the Republican has put out his second ad that attacks the president’s China policies.

headline: Avoiding West Nile
text: Q. Can you get West Nile virus more than once? Are there different strains? Is a vaccine possible?
