headline: For Reliever Aardsma, Two-Year Wait Is Almost Over
text: MINNEAPOLIS — David Aardsma’s next major league pitch will be his first since Sept. 19, 2010, after having surgery on his left hip and right elbow. That pitch, however, will not come Monday night. Even though the Yankees flew Aardsma here from their training complex in Tampa, Fla., in time for the game against the Minnesota Twins — presumably to add an arm to their heavily used bullpen — they did not activate him.

headline: The Conservative Mind
text: When I joined the staff of National Review as a lowly associate in 1984, the magazine, and the conservative movement itself, was a fusion of two different mentalities.

headline: 3 Georgians Accused of Trying to Stage Prison Videos
text: TBILISI, Georgia — Georgian officials tried Monday to take control of a week-old prison abuse scandal, arresting three activists from an opposition party, Georgian Dream, and releasing video clips that purported to show them offering the police money to stage scenes of horrific abuse.

headline: New Rules Upend House Re-Election Races in California
text: PLEASANTON, Calif. — Running against the Vietnam War, Representative Pete Stark entered Congress the year Richard M. Nixon was re-elected president. Since then, ensconced in Democratic strongholds here in the Bay Area, Mr. Stark was easily re-elected 19 times.

headline: Apple Maps Errors Send Japanese to Homegrown App
text: TOKYO — When Hikarie, Tokyo’s new must-visit shopping destination, opened in April, it was already old news on Mapion’s map application. An elite team at the company, which is based here, had marked the glass tower a year earlier, keeping the service a step ahead in this fast-changing city.

headline: Pirates Are Trying to Salvage a Promising Season Gone Bad
text: When the Pirates took the field Monday, they could have taken solace knowing that the Mets understood their pain. Misery has always loved company.

headline: Assembly Punishes Worker for Online Posts
text: The New York State Assembly on Monday reprimanded an employee who had used a pseudonym while posting comments on the Internet defending Speaker Sheldon Silver’s handling of a sexual harassment scandal.

headline: Before Palestinians Act at U.N., Israeli Officials Urge Other Steps
text: JERUSALEM — With the Palestinians planning to make their case this week to upgrade from organizational status to nonmember status at the United Nations General Assembly, one senior Israeli minister condemned the move as “the easy and wrong way out” on Monday, while another said the time had come for Israel to consider its own unilateral move toward a separate state: annexing parts of the West Bank and withdrawing from others.

headline: At Special Olympics, a Race for Better Health
text: When Special Olympics holds its competitions in the United States and around the world, it often enlists volunteer doctors and nurses to give its athletes basic health screenings. What they routinely uncover is evidence of a persistent gap in health care for people with mental disabilities. In basic areas — like dental work, eye and foot care and hearing exams — their unmet needs are appalling. Of 76,900 athletes examined between 2007 and 2011, more than 37 percent had untreated tooth decay. More than half had gait abnormalities, often a sign of ill-fitting shoes. More than 20 percent had never had an eye exam.

headline: A Smart Step for Justice
text: In a significant law enforcement breakthrough with likely national implications, the New York Police Department has adopted a broad policy of videotaping custodial interrogations in murder, serious sex crime and felony assault cases.

headline: Discarded Kidneys
text: More than 93,000 patients are on the waiting list for a kidney transplant, and last year more than 4,700 patients died while waiting. That makes it especially tragic that more than 2,600 kidneys were recovered from deceased donors last year and then discarded.

headline: Why Romney Is Slipping
text: Mitt Romney said in an interview aired on Sunday that his campaign “doesn’t need a turnaround.” He told CBS News’s “60 Minutes” that he is tied with President Obama; he has a “very effective campaign; it’s doing a very good job;” and all he needs to do to win is keep repeating his plan to restore economic freedom.

headline: The Trouble With Intentions
text: On their own, sentences are implacably honest. They may be long, short, simple, complex, clear, ambiguous, even incoherent. But they don’t try to hide those qualities. They are what they are and they say what they say. It’s as plain as the words on their faces. The trouble is that most sentences have writers, a fact that readers are well aware of. That makes it hard to consider sentences entirely on their own. Other questions arise. What’s she saying? What did he mean?

headline: Housing Authority Leader Offers Plan to Raise Money
text: Acknowledging the “considerable challenges” bedeviling his agency, John B. Rhea, the beleaguered chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, unveiled a plan Monday to squeeze hundreds of millions of dollars out of parking lots, walkways, open spaces and other areas.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Mayor of an Ailing Indiana Mill Town Turns to a Chicago Veteran for Advice
text: CHICAGO — When Karen Freeman-Wilson was elected the mayor of Gary, Ind., last year, she found herself confronting some grim truths about her hometown. Revenues in an already emaciated city budget were shrinking by millions of dollars. About a quarter of the buildings, she said, were empty. All the while, people were moving away.

headline: Safer Flights, but Risk Lurks on the Runway
text: Southwest Airways Flight 844 from Minneapolis had just landed at Chicago’s Midway International Airport last December and was about to cross a runway on its way to the terminal when the co-pilot noticed a business jet barreling toward him. He shouted for the captain to stop. The plane, carrying 74 passengers, screeched to a halt just short of the runway as the smaller jet crossed before their eyes.

headline: Romney and the Forbes 400
text: Last week, sandwiched between Monday’s leak of the video in which Mitt Romney dismissed “the 47 percent” and Friday’s release of the Romneys’ 2011 tax returns — showing that they had paid an effective tax rate of 14 percent — Forbes magazine published its annual list of the 400 wealthiest Americans.

headline: As Election Nears, Polls Are Better Predictors
text: With fewer than 45 days left in the presidential campaign, it is no longer a cliché to say that every week counts. This is probably the last week, for instance, in which Mitt Romney can reasonably hope that President Obama’s poll numbers will deteriorate because of a deflating convention bounce.

headline: How the Center of the Earth Got a Little Off Kilter
text: SAN ANTONIO DE PICHINCHA, Ecuador — Those who visit the Middle of the World, a government-owned park that pays tribute to the Equator, are not drawn by the trinket shops or cafes offering roasted guinea pig. They want to stand on a yellow line painted on the ground here that is said to be precisely at Earth’s midpoint — 0 degrees latitude, 0 minutes, 0 seconds.

headline: U.S. Hearings Again Sought for 3 Detainees
text: WASHINGTON — Lawyers for three men who have been imprisoned by the United States military in Afghanistan without trial for nearly a decade are renewing their quest for hearings in American courts. They say new information has emerged that undermines an appeals court ruling against them two years ago.

headline: Convicted Lobbyist Aids U.S. in Inquiry
text: A prominent New York lobbyist convicted of bribing former State Senator Carl Kruger has been secretly cooperating with the federal authorities and is asking a judge for leniency when he is sentenced on Friday, newly filed court documents show.

headline: For Suzuki, Respect for Bats Is Key to Hitting
text: MINNEAPOLIS — During a game for the Orix Blue Wave in Japan in 1999, Ichiro Suzuki struck out and returned to the dugout unusually frustrated. In a fit of anger, he destroyed his black Mizuno bat. Embarrassed, Suzuki wrote a letter of apology to the craftsman who had made his bats by hand from Tamo wood, grown on the Japanese island of Hokkaido. Such was the respect that Suzuki felt for the process that created the bats, which he wielded with such skill.

headline: Should the U.S. Be a Political Player in Russia?
text: Is it proper and useful for the United States to finance projects to promote democracy in Russia and elsewhere?

headline: Officials and League Remain Divided
text: After a weekend of negotiations between the N.F.L. — including Commissioner Roger Goodell — and its locked-out game officials, significant economic and noneconomic differences remain between the sides, according to a memo sent to the teams by Jeff Pash, the league’s general counsel and lead negotiator.

headline: Washington State, Women’s Rights and Big Cities
text: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Washington, the Evergreen State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Mark A. Smith, a professor of political science at the University of Washington.

headline: City to Add Pre-K Efforts in Poor Areas Next Year
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Monday that the city would open a new type of preschool in Brooklyn next year, introducing a cradle-to-kindergarten approach to education for very young children in poor neighborhoods.

headline: Formless Lump
text: Administrivial Unusual Puzzle Alert! The Tuesday, Sept. 25 puzzle will be offered in both Across Lite and as a PDF. Because of the unusual nature of this puzzle, some elements of the grid and the cluing will not reproduce the same way in Across Lite. If you normally solve online in Across Lite, we strongly recommend that you print out the PDF and solve it that way.

headline: A Buried Family Secret, Not for the Faint of Heart
text: Generally speaking, when you hear a mournful folk melody played on a violin as the lights go down at the theater, it is wise to set aside any expectations of frothy pleasures — debonair quipping, pratfalling, tap-dancing chorus girls — and prepare for something more somber.

headline: She’s Old and Faded; He’s Young and Trapped
text: CHICAGO — First glimpsed writhing buglike beneath satin sheets, she looks awfully small to be a towering legend of the screen. Breakable, too, as if a pair of strong arms could crush those fine bones to dust, leaving behind only a trail of mascara and remnants of that last, botched appointment with the hairdresser. Hey, this dame can’t even breathe without the help of an oxygen mask.

headline: Corrections: September 25, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Congressman’s Campaign Office Vandalized
text: The campaign headquarters of Representative Michael G. Grimm on Staten Island was broken into over the weekend, and a computer server containing “confidential campaign files and polling data” was erased, the campaign said in a statement.

headline: Ex-Informer to Serve 20 Years for Dealing Drugs and Guns
text: A former confidential informer for the New York Police Department pleaded guilty on Monday to dealing drugs and selling guns illegally as part of a plea deal under which he will be sentenced to 20 years in prison.

headline: While U.N. Beckons Clinton, Obama Takes In ‘The View’
text: President Obama on Monday flew up to New York from Washington, rode in his motorcade to ABC’s studios and sat down for an interview on “The View.” Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton was not far away, in the Waldorf-Astoria, meeting with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan.

headline: Court Session in Patz Case Is Delayed for 6 Weeks
text: The next public court appearance for the man who confessed to killing Etan Patz in 1979 has been put off for six weeks, a move that has the effect of giving prosecutors and his defense lawyer more time to investigate before the case is presented to a grand jury for indictment.

headline: Slight Dip in SAT Scores for the Class of 2012
text: For the high school class of 2012, the average score on the critical reading section of the SAT college entrance exam, 496, was down 1 point from the previous year, as was the average writing score, 488. The average math score, 514, was unchanged. Also unchanged: only 43 percent of the 1.66 million test-takers achieved the benchmark score, 1550, that indicates readiness for college. Among students whose parents have bachelor’s degrees, though, 60 percent were college ready. The College Board, which administers the test, says those with the benchmark score have a 65 percent likelihood of achieving a B- or higher grade average in their first year in college.

headline: Louisiana: Accord Is Reached on Prison Overhaul
text: The Justice Department and the sheriff who runs the Orleans Parish Prison have reached an agreement on changes at the institution, where violence, suicides, unclean conditions and poor medical treatment are commonplace, said Thomas E. Perez, assistant attorney general for the civil rights division. The department said on Monday that it sought to intervene in a class-action lawsuit brought on behalf of prisoners. Sheriff Marlin Gusman, who oversees the prison, supported the federal involvement, which set the stage for the negotiated changes. The next step toward a final settlement will be finding money to pay for the overhaul.

headline: Alabama: Ex-Professor Gets Life Term in Shooting
text: A former professor was sentenced on Monday to life in prison without parole for fatally shooting three colleagues and wounding three others at the University of Alabama, Huntsville, in 2010. The professor, Amy Bishop, pleaded guilty to avoid the death penalty. Jury deliberations — which state law requires in capital cases, even in plea deals — lasted for 20 minutes on Monday. Ms. Bishop opened fire during a meeting after being denied tenure. She could still face a trial in Massachusetts, where she is charged with killing her brother in 1986.

headline: Grant Will Aid Effort to Find Old DNA Evidence
text: In an unusual partnership, the New York Police Department and a legal organization dedicated to exonerating people who have been wrongfully convicted have jointly received federal grant money to overhaul how the police store evidence in old cases.

headline: With Doubleheader Split, The Orioles Lose Ground
text: As the baseball season moves into its final stretch, the story lines are becoming clearer. Three National League teams — San Francisco, Cincinnati and Washington — have clinched spots in the postseason, and Atlanta seems assured of joining them as a wild-card team. That leaves St. Louis fighting off Milwaukee and the Dodgers for the second wild-card slot. The Brewers’ loss to the Nationals on Monday afternoon made the Cardinals’ task a little easier.

headline: Syrian War’s Spillover Threatens a Fragile Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — The civil war in Syria is testing Iraq’s fragile society and fledgling democracy, worsening sectarian tensions, pushing Iraq closer to Iran and highlighting security shortcomings just nine months after American forces ended their long and costly occupation here.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,105 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Two Nets Take Stock of Future in Brooklyn
text: Two guys with Brook in their name opened the Nets’ first team store in Brooklyn, which seems almost poetic until you consider how close they were to becoming former Nets.

headline: Mets Top the Pirates for Mejia’s First Win
text: The Mets prolonged the Pittsburgh Pirates’ swoon Monday night with a 6-2 victory that featured a solid performance by Jenrry Mejia and two home runs by Ike Davis. The win was the Mets’ fourth in a row, their longest winning streak since they took four in a row in late June.

headline: New Ruling on Katrina Favors Corps of Engineers
text: A federal appeals court reversed itself, ruling Monday that the Army Corps of Engineers is not liable for devastation caused in Hurricane Katrina from a government-built navigation canal.

headline: Pettitte Lifts Yankees in Another Scoreless Effort
text: MINNEAPOLIS — After witnessing another impressive performance by a former teammate and a fellow quadragenarian, Joe Girardi reached out from the dugout steps and shook Andy Pettitte’s right hand, congratulating him for the superb work Pettitte had done with his left.

headline: Are Financial Fair Play Rules Destined to Be Broken?
text: As the UEFA president Michel Platini preached prudence and wisdom to Europe’s soccer elite last month, the setting seemed rather incongruous, almost undermining the words he spoke.

headline: Word of the Day | translucent
text: translucent •\tranz-ˈlü-sənt\• adjective

headline: ‘Rebecca’ Sees Investor Fade, as if Dreamt
text: The business of Broadway has always been cloaked in mystery. Most of its 40 theaters are run by three private organizations that operate out of public view. Producers keep deal-making under wraps. The biggest mystery of all is why so many sophisticated investors go along with business-as-usual on Broadway when few shows turn a profit.

headline: Striking Chicago Musicians Reach Tentative Agreement
text: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra strike appears to have ended after two days. The orchestra and its players, in a joint statement released Monday night, said they had reached a tentative three-year agreement that would take effect retroactively to Sept. 17 if the board of trustees and musicians ratify it.

headline: Harsh Prison Sentences for 3 Vietnamese Bloggers
text: HONG KONG — Vietnam has hit three prominent bloggers with lengthy prison terms, reinforcing its reputation as one of the world’s most restrictive countries for freedom of speech and the press.

headline: Swisher Leads Yankees’ Power Surge at Minnesota
text: MINNEAPOLIS — It took almost 32 years, but Nick Swisher is finally a grown man.

headline: News Quiz | September 25, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: North Korea’s Leaders Promise Improvements to Educational System
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leadership ended a rare second session of Parliament in a single year on Tuesday without making the announcements on economic reforms that many analysts had expected.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Tuesday, Sept. 25
text: NEWS As Greece enters a pivotal week in its economic crisis, tensions between the Greek government and the country’s international lenders have reached a boiling point. The government is resisting a push by the International Monetary Fund to impose additional austerity measures that Greek leaders fear could destabilize the shaky coalition government. Liz Alderman and Landon Thomas Jr. report.

headline: UB Group Companies’ Stock Up on Deal Talk
text: United Spirits, part of Vijay Mallya’s cash-strapped group of companies, confirmed Tuesday it was in deal talks with global alcohol giant Diageo in a notice to the Bombay Stock Exchange. United Spirits’ stock price rose on the news, to 1098.80 rupees a share at noon in India, up 3.6 percent for the day. United Spirits stock hit a 52 week high of 1,099.95 rupees a share on Monday on rumors deal talks were underway.

headline: Bat Cave to the Rescue?
text: WHO is Cory Holliday?

headline: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 25, 2012
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Shrink to Fit.”

headline: India Enters ‘Era of Regionalism’
text: The Indian government has, for the moment, averted a political crisis. Despite full-throated resistance from the Bharatiya Janata Party and at least a dozen regional parties, which organized nationwide protests last week to oppose economic policy changes introduced by the government, it managed to cobble together sufficient support in Parliament to stay afloat.

headline: History in Little Rock
text: The day marks an important milestone in civil rights history and the birth of one of the best known television personalities of our lifetime.

headline: Hey, Big Saver!
text: If you want to know what the future of the American economy looks like — when the unemployment rate will return to below 6 percent, or when annual growth will climb back above 3 percent — it’s helpful to stop thinking for a moment about those families in serious financial distress. That’s because the future of the U.S. economy relies, in large part, on another group of people living in fear: the millions of Americans who have a little disposable income.

headline: Retreating to Memory With a Song
text: Every morning these last few weeks, my 3-year-old son digs through a pile of old CDs on a bookshelf in our guest bedroom. He toddles between rooms, carrying one and then another of the plastic cases to the breakfast table, asking, “You like this one, Mama?”

headline: Fragments of Fukushima
text: The first time the Tokyo-based photographer Kosuke Okahara visited a town near the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in Japan, he grabbed his dosimeter, a device used to measure radiation levels, and looked at his watch to see how much time he could spend at the location.

headline: Is Trying Too Hard to Be Happy Making You Sad?
text: In her opinion piece “America the Anxious,” Ruth Whippman argues that Americans’ relentless pursuit of happiness is actually causing us much anxiety. She begins her piece with a quote by the author-philosopher Eric Hoffer: “The search for happiness is one of the chief sources of unhappiness.”

headline: A Conversation With: Landesa Founder Roy Prosterman
text: More than four decades ago, Roy Prosterman left a high-paying job at a white-shoe law firm in search of a different kind of job satisfaction. He ended up finding it in Landesa, a Seattle-based nonprofit that he founded, which works to secure land rights for the rural poor in countries around the world. Founded in 1966, the group is better known by its former name, Rural Development Institute.  Today, Landesa has 120 employees; it has operated in more than 50 countries, including China, Vietnam and Russia, and says 100 million families have benefited from its work. Thirty percent of the group’s $13 million annual budget is spent in India.

headline: Syrian Shells Land Near Israeli Border
text: JERUSALEM — Several mortar shells launched from Syria landed in the Golan Heights near Israel’s northern border on Tuesday morning, prompting the Israeli military to file a complaint with United Nations forces operating in the area.

headline: Part 2: Answers From Princeton’s Dean of Admission
text: Updated: Ms. Rapelye is no longer taking questions.This week, The Choice has invited Janet Lavin Rapelye, the dean of admission at Princeton University, to stop by our virtual Guidance Office and answer your questions about college admissions. Ms. Rapelye, who received a bachelor’s degree from Williams College and a master’s degree from Stanford University, has 30 years’ experience in college admissions.

headline: Republicans Champion ‘Voluntary Taxes’
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: After Monday Night Fiasco, a Call for Goodell to Apologize
text: A roundup of reaction to one of the most embarrassing episodes in N.F.L. history, when some egregiously poor calls in the fourth quarter culminated with a disputed last-second touchdown heave that gave the Seattle Seahawks a 14-12 victory over the Green Bay Packers on “Monday Night Football.”

headline: Diageo in Talks to Buy Stake in United Spirits
text: LONDON – Diageo, the world’s largest spirits company, said on Tuesday that it was in talks to buy a stake in United Spirits of India.

headline: Bond Investors Register Nervousness About Spain
text: PARIS — Spain’s borrowing costs rose on Tuesday at an auction of short-term debt, showing investors’ uncertainty about the country’s strategy for emerging from crisis.

headline: On Our Radar: Toyota Retrenches on Electric Cars
text: Toyota scraps plans for wide sales of a new all-electric minicar, saying that it had misread the market and the ability of battery technology to satisfy consumers. Now it plans to sell only about 100 battery-powered eQ vehicles in the United States and Japan. [Reuters]

headline: Near Disputed Islands, Japan Confronts Boats From Taiwan
text: TOKYO — The Japanese Coast Guard used water cannons on Tuesday to disperse fishing boats from Taiwan in waters claimed by Japan in the East China Sea, widening a territorial dispute that has already pitted Japan against China and threatened vital trade relations in the region.

headline: The Big Banks Say They Are Meeting Their Lending Commitment
text: Earlier this month, I published a post entitled, “Are the Big Banks Keeping Their Commitment to Small Businesses?” It had to do with a commitment that 13 of the largest banks in the country made last September to increase their small-business lending by $20 billion over the following three years.

headline: Early and Often
text: Even if the nonstop commercials and coverage didn’t tip you off, there are certain words in the air that unmistakably say, “It’s election time!”

headline: Opinion Report: Videotaped Interrogations
text: From the editorial page

headline: China Launches Carrier, but Experts Doubt Its Worth
text: BEIJING — In a ceremony attended by the country’s top leaders, China put its first aircraft carrier into service on Tuesday, a move intended to signal its growing military might as tensions escalate between Beijing and its neighbors over islands in nearby seas.

headline: Qatar’s Latest Investment Stirs the French
text: LONDON — A decision by the French government to allow Qatar to invest millions of euros in France’s depressed and neglected suburbs has prompted concerns across the political spectrum about the motives of the wealthy Arab emirate.

headline: Relations between Egypt and the U.S.
text: Mohamed Morsi, Egypt’s first democratically elected president, said that it is up to Washington to revitalize the alliance with Egypt.

headline: The Future of Big Law
text: The Future of Big Law  |  With business still tepid in the aftermath of the financial crisis, and with the industry reeling from the failure of Dewey & LeBoeuf, DealBook looks at the future of lawyering in a special section, “Big Law Steps Into Uncertain Times.” That future may involve an entirely new business model, one without any partners, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin in his column.

headline: The Upscale Treatment
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Love Potion Opens Season at the Met
text: Another Metropolitan Opera opening night, another new production of a Donizetti opera starring the charismatic soprano Anna Netrebko. Or so it seems these days.

headline: Tuesday Reading: When Surgeons Leave Objects in Your Body
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Coulda Been Worse
text: Josh Lehner does something I’ve been meaning to do: he compares US economic performance since the financial crisis with other episodes of major financial crisis. And guess what? We actually look better than most (sorry about the small print):

headline: EconoTrolls
text: Noah Smith has a very funny and highly accurate description of the menagerie. If you think he’s making fun of you, he probably is.

headline: A Monster, but No Epic Battle
text: The author Michael Lewis once rebuffed the notion that he should write a novel by saying, “Whereas journalists once felt humbled by the novel, we now live in an age in which the novelist lives in a state of anxiety about nonfiction.” Mr. Lewis, the writer of “Liar’s Poker” and “Moneyball,” was talking to Robert S. Boynton for the interview anthology “The New New Journalism.”

headline: Obama Tells U.N. New Democracies Need Free Speech
text: UNITED NATIONS — President Obama on Tuesday used his last major address on a global stage before the November election to deliver a strong defense of America’s belief in freedom of speech, challenging fledgling Arab and North African democracies to ensure that right even in the face of violence.

headline: Turkey’s Military Politics
text: ISTANBUL — A Turkish court’s conviction on Friday of 325 senior military officers for plotting to overthrow the state has left me with mixed feelings. Like many Turks, I’ve been pondering a host of questions: Was this justice or revenge? Is this the final curtain on a military that for decades believed it knew better than the elected politicians? Or was the 21-month courtroom drama the latest show trial, manipulated by a government that itself entertains delusions of grandeur?

headline: Fashion, the Next Dimension
text: With Lily Kwong as his 3-D model, the photographer Simon Cave imagines a fashion world that is anything but flat. How close is this to becoming a reality? In an exclusivevideo, Cave takes The Moment behind the scenes of his epic shoot to get the full 360 degree view. And to experience the final results, go to sc-3d.com.

headline: Daily Report: Riot at Foxconn Factory Highlights Labor Unrest
text: A riot at a factory in Taiyuan, China, late Sunday was noteworthy because the site is managed by Foxconn Technology, one of the world’s biggest electronics manufacturers and an important supplier to major Western technology companies, David Barboza and Keith Bradsher report in Tuesday’s New York Times.

headline: Leading Off: A Fiasco to End the Referee Fiasco?
text: To be sure, the conga line of complaining about the replacement referee fiasco had started before Monday night’s N.F.L. game got even ESPN’s Jon “Everyone’s Doing a Great Job!” Gruden all riled up. The line was headed right to the gilded — and now probably fortified — door of Commissioner Roger Goodell, whose baronial arrogance makes him so easy to blame for just about anything. But the ending to that dreadful game Monday night may be his crowning achievement.

headline: Adding Up the Government’s Legal Bills for Fannie and Freddie
text: The government’s takeover of the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in 2008 may turn out to be a very expensive proposition.

headline: In West Bengal, Cashless Microfinance Opens Doors for Women
text: CANNING, West Bengal — A debt crisis in India’s microfinance sector in Andhra Pradesh in 2010 revived the question of how to help the hard-core poor without forcing them into a debt trap. Now it appears that microfinance institutions may have had an alternative all along.

headline: No Thank-You Note, but Several Lawsuits for a Pepper-Spraying Inspector
text: Never mind the celebratory demonstrations last week. This Monday was the important anniversary for Occupy Wall Street. On that day a year ago, the movement truly kicked into gear. It owed an enormous debt to a police deputy inspector named Anthony Bologna, who has received not a word of thanks for having put it on the map.

headline: Home Prices Rise Again, This Time on the Low End
text: The housing market continues to gather strength, and the biggest gains in price now appear to be among the least expensive homes, whose values fell the most in the downturn and have weighed against any would-be recovery.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: It’s Showtime’s Time, and N.F.L.’s Monday Night Hangover
text: The Emmy awards won by the tense, terrorism-centric Showtime series “Homeland” could not have come at a better time for the network, or the series, Brian Stelter writes. The awards — including best drama, best actress (Claire Danes), best actor (Damian Lewis) — represent a coming of age for the network, which had never received a series prize for comedy or drama and has long been in the shadow of the Emmy-award-laden HBO. With the second season of “Homeland” beginning on Sunday, the subscription network was immediately setting out to capitalize on the wins. “I think there might be some extra activity at the call centers this week,” said David Nevins, president for entertainment at Showtime.

headline: Rare Trout Survives in Just One Stream, DNA Reveals
text: The rare greenback cutthroat trout, Colorado’s state fish, is even more imperiled than scientists thought, a new study suggests. By analyzing DNA sampled from cutthroat trout specimens pickled in ethanol for 150 years, comparing it with the genes of today’s cutthroat populations, and cross-referencing more than 40,000 historic stocking records, researchers in Colorado and Australia have revealed that the fish survives not in five wild populations, but just one.

headline: Absurd Ending Fuels Disgust With Replacement Refs
text: SEATTLE — The play that best defines this N.F.L. season occurred at the end of another game in which replacement officials looked less like actual referees and more like the Keystone Kops. It was bizarre enough to almost defy description.

headline: Report Cites High Civilian Toll in Pakistan Drone Strikes
text: A new report on targeted killing by C.I.A. drones in Pakistan’s tribal area concludes that the strikes have killed more civilians than American officials have acknowledged, alienated Pakistani public opinion and set a dangerous precedent under international law.

headline: Can Vegans and Carnivores Get Along? Moby Thinks So
text: “I’ve been a vegan for 24 years,” Moby, the musician, told me on the phone the other day. “With two lapses. I had yogurt in 1992, and I have to say, it was really good. And then I was at a friend’s restaurant in Portland, Oregon, a few years ago, and they made me some vegan sushi, but they accidentally brought me crab sushi. So I had a bite of crab sushi, and then my friend who ran the restaurant came running out yelling, like, ‘No! It’s got crab!’”

headline: How I Made My Memoir: Book Coming From Neil Patrick Harris
text: By now Neil Patrick Harris’s bucket list must be short enough to fit on a Post-it note: host the Academy Awards; write a memoir; get the Criterion Collection to release a special cinephile edition of “Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle.” And he can cross one more item off that agenda: the Crown Archetype imprint of Random House’s Crown Publishing Group is expected to announce on Tuesday that it has acquired a new nonfiction book from Mr. Harris, the stage and screen performer; Emmy Award-winner; host of the Emmys, Tonys, TV Land Awards and Spike Video Game Awards; and star of CBS’s “How I Met Your Mother.”

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Times: Spain, which has one of the world’s best cuisines, also has an unemployment rate of over 50 percent among young people, and many have resorted to foraging through the trash for food. — Emily Weinstein

headline: In Munich, Classing Up Oktoberfest
text: Ah, autumn. That traditional time of pigskin, piping hot pretzels, copious quantities of beer and blitzed bonhomie. No, we’re not talking about college football season. We’re talking about Oktoberfest, another fall tradition that’s not exactly known for its high quotient of class. There you are, sitting cheek-by-jowl with a bunch of lederhosen-ed Bavarians — or, more likely, stag-partying Britons and study-abroad Americans — on a wooden bench in a frigid tent in some biergarten in the middle of Munich, slogging through steins and trying to hail the dirndl-clad beermaid (bierfrau?) to get another wurst. It’s the worst.

headline: U.N. Leader Opens General Assembly on Somber Note
text: The leader of the United Nations formally opened its annual General Assembly on Tuesday with a speech conveying a broad sense of crisis because of pressing problems including armed conflict in the Middle East, disruptive climate change and religious intolerance.

headline: New York City Schools Provide Morning-After Pills
text: In 13 New York City schools, the morning-after pill is available to students without parental permission, although parents are given the opportunity to opt their teenagers out of the health program (and the provision of any contraceptives) at the beginning of the school year.

headline: Trampoline Injuries Down, but Caution Is Urged
text: Trampoline injuries, which rose steadily through the middle of the last decade, appear to be on the downswing, according to a new study in the journal Pediatrics that looked at trampoline-related emergency room visits. But the drop in injuries appears to be a result of a decrease in trampoline sales rather than greater awareness of the dangers of trampolines and safer use, the authors said, and the American Academy of Pediatrics continues to advise against recreational trampoline use, a position it has taken since 1977.

headline: As the People’s Priest, He Fought for the Forgotten of the Bronx
text: The Rev. John C. Flynn could have been a monsignor, but as he told the story in later years, he refused the elevation because he already held a title more to his liking: the people’s priest.

headline: Small Presses Take Brooklyn
text: The Brooklyn Book Festival, which ended Sunday, was a showcase for the many small presses that have sprouted in Brooklyn.

headline: Some Bettors Get Relief on Game Decided by Botched Call
text: While it remains to be seen what, if anything, Commissioner Roger Goodell and the N.F.L. are going to do about the controversial ending to the game Monday night between the Seattle Seahawks and the Green Bay Packers, the gambling world — which was boosted by the replacement referees’ decision on the game’s final play, as significant money was bet on the Packers — appears to be showing at least a little compassion.

headline: Comparing the Job Losses in Financial Crises
text: For a while I was regularly updating a chart each month showing how far employment plummeted in the latest recession and how little ground has been recovered since the recovery began in June 2009. Compared with other recent recessions and recoveries, the last few years have looked especially disastrous:

headline: A Critical View of the Financial Crisis
text: Sheila C. Bair on her harsh history of the financial crisis. | Ericsson’s chief, Hans Vestberg, on surviving disruption. | The Times’s James B. Stewart and Peter Lattman look at big law’s future.

headline: Hit-and-Run Driver Kills Cyclist in Queens
text: The police are looking for a driver who fatally struck a 38-year-old bicyclist on Queens Boulevard on Tuesday morning and drove off. The collision occurred around 6 a.m. near the intersection of Hoover Avenue in Kew Gardens, the police said. The cyclist, whose name was not immediately released, was pronounced dead at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. No information about the driver’s vehicle was immediately available.

headline: Business Day Live: Ex-Regulator Has Harsh Words for Bankers and Geithner
text: Sheila C. Bair on her harsh history of the financial crisis. | Ericsson’s chief, Hans Vestberg, on surviving disruption. | The Times’s James B. Stewart and Peter Lattman look at the future of big law.

headline: Romney Urges Attaching Certain Strings to Foreign Aid
text: 3:39 p.m. | Updated  Mitt Romney laid out the broad outlines of his plan to foster work opportunities and free enterprise in developing nations on Tuesday morning, suggesting during a speech at the Clinton Global Initiative in New York that he would make foreign aid conditional on progress on these fronts.

headline: Obama’s Speech to the United Nations General Assembly — Text
text: Following is a text of President Obama’s speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday, as released by the White House:

headline: Charting the Success of Early Underdogs in the N.F.L.
text: Chase Stuart writes about the historical and statistical side of football at his site, FootballPerspective.com

headline: Model-Morphosis | Montana Cox at DSquared2
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Montana Cox of IMG before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Charlotte Tilbury and hair by Sam McKnight.

headline: Summer Stretches Into Fall, Held by a Crab Claw
text: WESTPORT, Mass.

headline: Image of the Day: September 25
text: Women working in the unorganized sector demand social security benefits from the government.

headline: Short Film by Target Draws Big-Name Talent
text: Target on Tuesday will announce its most ambitious foray into so-called “branded entertainment,” a 12-minute-long film, “Falling for You,” that will showcase more than 100 home, beauty and fashion items the company is promoting for the fall season.

headline: How Many Government Programs Have You Benefited From?
text: Mitt Romney stirred up a hornet’s nest with his comments about the 47 percent of Americans who he thinks are dependent on the government.

headline: Video Reports From Japan, Taiwan and China on Confrontation Off Disputed Islands
text: As my colleague Hiroko Tabuchi reports from Tokyo, the Japanese Coast Guard fired water cannons on Tuesday at a flotilla of Taiwanese fishing boats off a chain of islands claimed by Japan, Taiwan and China. Japan’s state broadcaster, NHK, captured some of the confrontation on video.

headline: Fashion in 3-D
text: With Lily Kwong as his 3-D model, the photographer Simon Cave imagines a fashion world that is anything but flat.

headline: Man Charged With Hate Crime After Antigay Attack
text: A 44-year-old man has been arrested on charges of hate-crime assault for the antigay slashing last week of a 22-year-old man in a McDonald’s in the West Village, the police said on Tuesday.

headline: Oil and Nature: A Landscape Reconfigured
text: In the stark white space of the Aperture Gallery in Chelsea, billboard-size photographs present an array of haunting scenes. A chemical plant with a cemetery in the foreground. An empty basketball court alongside a turreted oil refinery. A lush swamp filled with trees, one of which has a Shell Oil sign nailed to it.

headline: Producer Hopes to Bring ‘Black Orpheus’ to Broadway
text: The Broadway producer Stephen C. Byrd, who mounted a multiracial “Streetcar Named Desire” last season and an all-black “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof” in 2008, is developing a new stage musical based on the 1959 film “Black Orpheus,” which won the Academy Award for best foreign-language picture in 1960.

headline: Some Things Never Change
text: The International Herald Tribune celebrates its 125th birthday in October, and over the coming weeks we’ll be sharing highlights from our archives.

headline: Sheila Bair’s Critical View of History
text: Times reporter Louise Story talks to Sheila C. Bair, former F.D.I.C. chairwoman, about her harsh history of the financial crisis.

headline: Antibiotic Prescription? It May Depend on Where You Live
text: A new study has found that older men and women in the South are more often prescribed antibiotics than older Americans elsewhere, even though there is no evidence that the South has higher rates of pneumonia and other diseases for which antibiotics are necessary. The findings suggest there are greater rates of antibiotic overuse in that part of the country.

headline: Sept. 24: Deep Red Polling Mystery
text: The FiveThirtyEight forecast was essentially unchanged on Monday, with Barack Obama holding a 77.7 percent chance of winning the Electoral College.

headline: On Eve of Paris Motor Show, Mercedes-Benz Provides Further Details on Yacht Design
text: PARIS — In a sour European automotive market, Mercedes-Benz is diversifying into other forms of mobility. On the eve of the international motor show here, where the German automaker is scheduled to introduce several new automobiles, it shared further details on the designs for a new yacht.

headline: The Count and the Gymnasts
text: During the Battle of Antietam on Sept. 17, 1862, Col. Ernst von Vegesack, the commander of the 20th New York Volunteer Infantry Regiment, sat prominently on horseback, while the unit’s banner, emblazoned with the words “Bahn Frei,” German for “clear the way,” streamed high over a ridge near the Dunker Church.

headline: A Young Immigrant Struggles for a College Education
text: For graduating high school seniors, the months that stretch out between the end of spring and those first signs of fall can be magical — senior prom, graduation, soaking up summer then cramming in the last bits of time with childhood friends.

headline: Delusions of Wonkhood
text: Dave Weigel has some fun with credulous journalists who are sure that Paul Ryan must be a Very Serious Wonk because — wait for it — he uses PowerPoint. With pie charts!

headline: Barnes & Noble to Introduce New Video Service for Nook Devices
text: Barnes & Noble said on Tuesday it would introduce a new video store for its Nook products this fall, the latest expansion of the bookseller’s digital content.

text: From Eurostat.

headline: The Future of Big Law
text: Times columnist James B. Stewart — a former lawyer — and reporter Peter Lattman look at the future of big law.

headline: Chinese Dissident Artist Says the Authorities Still Have His Passport
text: BEIJING — Ai Weiwei, the rebel artist and acid critic of the Chinese Communist Party who was detained by the government last year, said Tuesday that the authorities were still holding his passport, which means he cannot travel to the United States for long-planned artistic events there next month or start a job as a visiting professor in Germany.

headline: Business Day Live: Law Firms Under Pressure
text: James B. Stewart and Peter Lattman of The New York Times look at the pressures facing the legal industry.

headline: N.F.L. Supports Decision Not to Overturn Winning Touchdown
text: The N.F.L. issued a statement Tuesday morning declaring the Packers-Seahawks game result final and supporting the decisions of its replay-booth referees, who did not overturn the controversial call of a game-winning touchdown for the Seahawks.

headline: A Form of Dementia That Is Often Misdiagnosed
text: Lori Roberts’s father, who used to deliver the mail in Mitchell, S.D., has undergone startling personality changes. “He used to be very easygoing,” Ms. Roberts said. “Now he’s gotten kind of physical with my mom and my brother, pushing and shoving.” The other day, when her exhausted mother visited him in the nursing home he had recently entered — by sad coincidence, it was their 53rd wedding anniversary – he loudly insisted that she take him to Mexico, immediately.

headline: If You Like Roy Orbison . . .
text: Each week, Val Haller, the founder of the music Web site Valslist.com, matches music from her baby boom generation to music of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Russia Eases Limits on Visas for Americans
text: Americans traveling to Russia face looser restrictions under a new visa agreement that the two countries reached this month.

headline: First Night of the New Season Has NBC and CBS Swapping Places
text: The first night of the official network television season turned the competition almost on its head as NBC dominated in the advertiser-preferred ratings, ABC dominated with older viewers, CBS saw its Monday lineup take a dive and Fox took a general battering.

headline: One Word: Plastics
text: In an effort to bring something new to the landscape of luxury handbags, the accessories designer Kristine Johannes deliberately avoided the one material that most obviously defines it: leather. “I just got sick of skins,” says Johannes, whose previous stints at J. Crew and Devi Kroell required a good amount of working with hides and exotics. “There are so many amazing man-made materials, I thought, ‘Why does the standard evening bag have to look like X?’ “ Which is how Rauwolf, Johannes’s line of angular plexiglass evening clutches, came to be so Y. Produced in an Italian factory that specializes in accessory parts like belt buckles and shoe heels, the seven bags in the fall collection take their cues from cut gemstones, with sharp lines, reflective surfaces and facets as dizzying as diamonds. “In a way, plexi is like stone,” Johannes says. “It comes in all of these thicknesses and gets carved down and filed down and heat treated to do what you want it to do.” The glassy-blue Shalimar clutch above has a magnetic closure, a sharp hourglass shape and — bonus points — doubles as a mirror for the quick makeup check. $2,300; rauwolfnyc.com.

headline: British Bankers Group May Give Up Control Over Libor
text: LONDON — A British banking group is preparing to give up its control over the interest rate at the center of a recent manipulation scandal, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Romney at the Clinton Global Initiative
text: The Republican nominee’s speech at the Clinton Global Initiative was surprisingly reasonable. Granted, Mr. Romney got in a few digs at President Obama, but they were subtle and almost funny. And he was a bit light on details, but the occasion didn’t really call for granularity.

headline: After Waters Inquiry, House Panel Recommends New Ethics Rules
text: Saying that public trust is at stake, a special House ethics panel on Tuesday called for new rules to prevent lawmakers and their staffs from violating conflict of interest standards and proposed other new measures designed to keep partisan squabbles from undermining future investigations of such wrongdoing.

headline: The Sin of Sowing Hatred of Islam
text: Two weeks ago, on the morning of Sept. 11, I noticed a woman wearing a traditional Muslim head covering on the packed platform of the train station in Scarsdale, N.Y. Her attention was focused on a billboard ad that announced “19,250 deadly Islamic attacks since 9/11/01” and pre-empted those who might dispute that claim with the refrain: “It’s not Islamophobia, it’s Islamorealism.” I could only imagine what she was feeling.

headline: Charbroiling Burgers: An Air-Quality Scourge That May Be Worse Than Diesel Trucks
text: In Freakonomics-like fashion, researchers at the University of California, Riverside, have concluded that producing a charbroiled hamburger emits the same mass particulate matter as a heavy-duty diesel truck traveling 143 miles.

headline: State of the Race: Yankees Facing a Welcome Foe
text: By now we all know the bad news for the Yankees.

headline: AT&T Introduces Security Products for ‘Bring-Your-Own’ Devices
text: AT&T on Tuesday introduced security software and services designed to help businesses protect the smartphones and tablets that employees are bringing into the workplace. The software will work for mobile devices on any cell network.

headline: TCM to Screen ‘Forbidden Planet’ on Land and on the Space Station
text: The Turner Classic Movies cable channel is joining with NASA to give an out-of-this-world opening to a series of film screenings.

headline: Maybe the Monkey Needs a Sports Star’s Name
text: There’s only an hour on Wednesday night between the end of “Animal Practice” on NBC and the start of “The Neighbors” on ABC. That may not be enough time for you to recover from the brain cell loss the first one induced and prepare yourself for the even more severe brain cell loss the second will cause.

headline: Weekly Reader: BPA, Well-Intentioned Teachers, Obesity and the Middle Class
text: Your inner wonk needs to read this Brookings Institution  paper on Pathways to the Middle Class: “Why do some children do so much better than others? And what will it take to create more opportunity?” We don’t, say the authors, have nearly as much economic and social mobility in this country as we’d like to believe.

headline: Video of Obama’s U.N. Address
text: As my colleague Helene Cooper reports, President Obama devoted most of his address to the U.N. General Assembly on Tuesday to the Arab democracy movement and the tension between free speech and mutual respect among cultures and faiths in an era of instant, global communication.

headline: Average A.T.M. Surcharge Reaches New High

headline: Germany Acts to Increase Limits on High-Speed Trades
text: BERLIN — Germany intends to be one of the first countries to try to put the brakes on high-frequency trading, the computer-driven force that has been rattling stock markets across the globe.

headline: Judge Orders DNA Test in Dispute Over ‘Jeffersons’ Star Hemsley’s Estate
text: The legal fight over the estate of Sherman Hemsley, “The Jeffersons” star who died in July, has escalated to a new level of bizarreness, as a judge ruled that a man claiming to be the actor’s brother must undergo DNA testing, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Hedge Fund’s Complex Scheme May Cost It Millions
text: Hedge funds are supposed to be the smart money, but sometimes even they can be outsmarted.

headline: European Solar Group Seeks Wider China Trade Inquiry
text: Solar manufacturers called on European Union regulators to expand an investigation into China because of concerns that it unfairly subsidizes its clean energy industry.

headline: Blasts Hit Syrian School as War Is Focus at the U.N.
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — Insurgent bombs exploded at a Damascus school building on Tuesday, and Syrian government shells landed in the disputed Golan Heights region held by Israel, underscoring the Syrian conflict’s growing scope as it dominated much of the discussion on the first formal day of the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: Search for Lost Leonardo Halted
text: ROME — A project searching for a lost mural by Leonardo da Vinci behind a fresco painted by Giorgio Vasari in the Palazzo Vecchio, now Florence’s city hall, has been suspended and the scaffolding that has covered the fresco for months will be dismantled this week.

headline: Ichimura at Brushstroke
text: Inside the secret sushi bar, tucked away inside of Brushstroke in TriBeCa.

headline: Hidden in a Nook, Mastery in Plain Sight
text: MANY people who love restaurants dream about discovering an extraordinary one that nobody else knows about and keeping it secret. I’d always thought I was one of them until the Friday night not long ago when I ate with a guest in an empty sushi bar in TriBeCa. During the two hours we sat there, no customers arrived to claim the six other counter seats or the four chairs at a nearby table.

headline: Iran Reveals More About What It Calls Foreign Sabotage
text: Iran said Tuesday that it had amassed new evidence of attempts by saboteurs to attack Iranian nuclear, defense, industrial and telecommunications installations, including the use of computer virus-infected American, French and German equipment.

headline: A New Choreographer for ‘Hands on a Hardbody’
text: The Broadway choreographer Sergio Trujillo (“Memphis,” “Jersey Boys”) has taken over musical staging duties on the coming Broadway show “Hands on a Hardbody” from Benjamin Millepied, the producers of the show announced.

headline: From Methane to Plastic to Methane, Without Waste
text: Imagine that you could go online and rent something in your neighbor’s garage rather than buy something new that you will need to use only a few times a year. Or that you could use microwave technology to transform timber residue or other waste biomass into a valuable industrial material like graphite.

headline: A Deadline in the Missouri Senate Race
text: Tuesday is the last day that Representative Todd Akin, a Republican, can drop out of the Senate race against Senator Claire McCaskill in Missouri.

headline: One of a Kind
text: In the eight hotels that Kit Kemp owns with her husband, Tim — among them the Crosby Street Hotel in Manhattan and the Dorset Square Hotel in London — no two rooms are alike. This is because Kemp, who designed the spaces, eschews the common practice of selecting a single scheme to be repeated throughout, instead embarking on a painstaking process of decorating every room to be utterly distinct from the next. She selects each, say, 1960s Lucite lamp, piece of boiled-wool upholstery and Filipino totem sculpture, then pulls them all together in a highly individualized, homey whole that is greater than the sum of its parts. In a new book, “Kit Kemp: A Living Space” (Hardie Grant, $50), Kemp details her approach to design (for residential as well as hotel projects), and sums it up as, “Keep it personal.” Her secret? Finding “little touches — like using a kerosene can, instead of classically cut crystal, as a lamp base in a romantic bedroom.”

headline: In Paris, an Exhibition Dedicated to Hair
text: PARIS — Hair, as the song from the musical goes, can be “long, straight, curly, fuzzy, snaggy, shaggy, ratty, matty, oily, greasy, fleecy.”

headline: BBC Causes Uproar by Reporting Queen’s Opinion
text: LONDON — Succumbing to what appears to have been a disastrous urge to brag about his super-important connections, a BBC correspondent unexpectedly declared in a radio interview on Tuesday that Queen Elizabeth II had once told him she was “pretty upset” about the presence of a radical Islamist cleric in North London.

headline: Romney and the Right’s Divisions
text: In his influential daily e-mail The Transom, which was excerpted yesterday on RealClearPolitics, Ben Domenech took note of the disagreements that have opened up between conservative pundits amid Romney’s post-convention difficulties:

headline: Paul Taylor to Receive Bessie Lifetime Achievement Award
text: The choreographer Paul Taylor will receive a lifetime achievement Bessie, the nickname for the New York Dance and Performance Awards, Dance/NYC, which helps produce the award ceremony, said on Tuesday. Alice Teirstein, the founding director of the Young Dancemakers Company and a longtime faculty member at the Fieldston School, will be honored for service to the dance field. The ceremony will be held on Oct. 15 at the Apollo Theater, hosted by Elizabeth Streb and featuring performances by the Trisha Brown Company and Souleymane Badolo. Presenters include Marina Abramovic, Ron Brown, Brenda Bufalino, Archie Burnett, Bebe Neuwirth, Charles Reinhart, David Thomson, and Wendy Whelan.

headline: Why the Health Care Tax Credit Eludes Many Small Businesses
text: The Agenda has now profiled three small businesses that are struggling in different ways with providing health insurance to employees. The companies are very different — they trade in very different parts of the economy, and couldn’t be located much further apart geographically — but they do have one thing in common: Though all three have fewer than 25 employees, not one has qualified for the tax credit in the Affordable Care Act that was intended to help small businesses pay for health insurance. Indeed, the credit is one element of the controversial health law that has already fallen short of expectations.

headline: Science Times Podcast
text: A fungus that’s killing bats, prescribing antipsychotic drugs, and an artist whose chosen subjects include dark matter — and other mysteries of the universe.

headline: ‘L’Elisir d’Amore’
text: Images of the opera starring Anna Netrebko.

headline: Eighth Grader Says He Broke Congressman’s Office Windows

headline: La Vida Latina: Celebrating Hispanic Heritage Month With The New York Times

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 25
text: A view of the day in sports, with Maria Sharapova winning in Tokyo and celebrities at a pre-Ryder Cup event.

headline: A Tax Shelter Mitt Romney Could Love
text: Gov. Mitt Romney’s 2011 tax return highlights the use of a questionable tax planning technique that may have avoided Medicare tax liability on up to $2 million of services income derived from his past employment at Bain Capital.

headline: State of the Race: How the Cards Haunt the Brewers
text: For the Milwaukee Brewers and their fans, the 2012 season started under a cloud and remained that way pretty much until September, when that cloud parted and a magical run began. Could the Brewers be this year’s Team of Destiny? Could they be the St. Louis Cardinals of last season? As the wins piled up, it seemed inevitable. Ryan Braun is still the league most valuable player, the bullpen remembered how to pitch, the Pirates remembered they are the Pirates. Playoffs, here we come.

headline: Spikes or Soles, It’s a Man’s World
text: THERE is no choice but to address the spikes head on, sharp as they may be.

headline: Is the Sequester Working?
text: The sequester, the widely reviled law requiring indiscriminate spending cuts starting in January, may actually be working as intended: As a spur to action.

text: Few events transcend politics, especially in a campaign year. The National Football League’s lockout of its game officials appears to be one of them.

headline: TimesCast Politics: A Focus on Foreign Policy in New York Speeches
text: Damon Winter/The New York Times

headline: Enjoying the Heat in Brooklyn
text: The Brooklyn Botanic Garden’s celebration of chiles marks its 20th anniversary this year with more peppers than ever. Dozens of varieties are being cultivated in the herb garden, which visitors can tour as part of the fiesta on Saturday. A farmstand will sell the chiles, from the mild aji to the impossibly hot bhut jolokia, or ghost pepper.

headline: As Scandal Grows, Party of Berlusconi Cleans House
text: ROME — The conservative party of Italy’s former prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, announced a series of housecleaning measures on Tuesday following a financing scandal that prompted the resignation of the party’s representative in the important Lazio region on Monday.

headline: Oysters Party Like It’s the ’40s
text: Rifko Meier, a Dutch art dealer and entrepreneur, created the Oyster Girls, a clever idea for parties that met with some success in his native Amsterdam. Now he’s brought them to New York. In place of a stationary raw bar, servers with buckets of oysters on ice hung around their waists circulate in the crowd and open shellfish on the spot for guests. They are also equipped with little containers of various sauces and a pail for shells. Each server can handle 100 oysters, Mr. Meier said.

headline: Bookshelf
text: “The Phaidon Archive of Graphic Design” (Phaidon, $235) is the commercial art canon embodied: 500 topic sheets on everything from a 700-year-old Buddhist text to the album art of Beck’s “The Information.” “Thanks for the View, Mr. Mies” (Metropolis Books, $30) explores how Modernist architecture improves lives in the Lafayette Park section of Detroit, which has the world’s largest concentration of Mies van der Rohe buildings. (It’s also one of the most racially integrated neighborhoods in what might well be America’s most segregated city.) Peter Trachtenberg’s memoir “Another Insane Devotion” (Da Capo, $24) — about love, sex, marriage and especially cats — is a hallmark of brainy discursiveness, set into motion when the author loses Biscuit, a wan cat whose sniffles sound like “a whisk broom briskly sweeping.”

headline: Protesters Take to Street in Madrid
text: MADRID — The pressures facing the government of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy mounted on several fronts on Tuesday, as thousands of demonstrators besieged Parliament and Spain’s two largest regions took steps that underscored their deepening economic troubles and displeasure with his austerity plans.

headline: Taking Processing Out of Take-Away
text: Hu Kitchen, near Union Square, is proof of how far quick take-away food has come. The name sounds Asian, but Hu stands for “human,” and the philosophy is to serve food, most of it prepared on the premises, that puts a minimum on processed ingredients.

headline: Ericsson’s Chief on Surviving Disruption
text: Business Day Live: Hans Vestberg, chief executive of Ericsson, discusses the fast-changing communications industry.

headline: Japanese Look for Alternatives to Apple’s Maps
text: 5:01 p.m. | Updated Adding comment by Google’s chairman in Tokyo and news about open-sourced maps in Japan.

headline: Bleecker Street Station, 1:10 P.M.
text: A connection for uptown No. 6 trains opened Tuesday.

headline: RIM Shows Off New BlackBerry 10 Phones, but Gives No Firm Release Date
text: OTTAWA — Research in Motion said on Tuesday that its coming line of BlackBerry 10 phones would include the company’s popular BlackBerry Messenger service, a feature still absent on its tablet computers.

headline: Pakistani Papers Banned by Afghanistan in East
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the often ill-tempered war of words between Afghanistan and Pakistan, the Afghans have just taken a new tack: outlawing Pakistani words.

headline: Juan Luis Guerra Tops List of Latin Grammy Nominations
text: The veteran Dominican singer-songwriter Juan Luis Guerra leads the list of contenders for this year’s edition of the Latin Grammy Awards, picking up six nominations on Tuesday. In the song of the year category, Mr. Guerra even ended up competing against himself, with two of his compositions vying for that honor. The Mexican brother-sister pop duo Jesse & Joy followed with five Latin Grammy nominations, while the Colombian rocker Juanes, Guatemala’s Ricardo Arjona and the Brazilians Caetano Veloso and Ivete Sangalo were among the artists getting four.

headline: President Obama Addresses U.N.
text: Barack Obama spoke about Iran,the wave of new protests around the Arab world and the recent attacks on American Embassies.

headline: Dumb Baseball Injury Chronicles: Dry Eyeballs?
text: If caffeine addiction were a major sin, a lot of us would be in big trouble. So, it would seem a bit hypocritical to snicker at the Rangers’ Josh Hamilton for revealing that caffeine was at the root of his recent five-game sick leave. On the other hand, not many of us ingest enough caffeine to dry out our eyeballs and give us blurry vision — something rather critical to a baseball player — so all ridicule seems to be fair game.

headline: Candidates Address Class Size and Teachers’ Unions at Education Forum
text: Though education has not been a major focus in the presidential campaign, the charged issue of class size was injected into the race on Tuesday as Mitt Romney said that while governor of Massachusetts, he was able to do more with less during an economic downturn.

headline: Behind a Restaurant Emergency, a Troubleshooter
text: ON a hot and humid Thursday, Brian Follander found himself in a familiar position, sprawled on a restaurant kitchen floor, staring into the nether regions of a stove that would not light.

headline: Past Forward: The Fight Over Fracking
text: With a skeptical eye fixed on industry in an era of rapid technological development two generations ago, Rachel Carson “made a powerful case for the idea that if humankind poisoned nature, nature would in turn poison humankind,” as Eliza Griswold put it in last weekend’s magazine, marking the 50th anniversary of the publication of Carson’s seminal book, “Silent Spring.”

headline: Sea Calls, but So Does Love
text: The warmhearted play “Marius” is a bit short on plot, but this revival, by the Storm Theater Company, doesn’t want for talent. Here, affection takes precedence over action, and the show’s deepest pleasures are reserved for those with patience.

headline: A Musical in Celebration of Saving Face in China, That Booming New Market
text: Over the centuries China has given the world many treasures: Confucianism, pandas, table tennis, a superhumanly synchronized Olympics opening ceremony, pretty much everything ever sold at Walmart.

headline: Which Presidential Candidate Is Better for College Applicants?
text: If you’re a college-bound student who has been (loosely) following the 2012 presidential campaign, this is an excellent time to tune in (and catch up).

headline: The Biggest Controversy, but Far From the First
text: The first three weeks of the N.F.L. season have been defined not by gripping games or outstanding performances, but by the performance of the league’s replacement officials, who many say are turning the sport into a mockery. No calls brought more attention and embarrassment than the ones in the debacle Monday night in Seattle, where the officials awarded the Seahawks a game-winning touchdown as time ran out against Green Bay, despite Golden Tate’s interfering with a Packers defender and then another Packers defender seeming to have initial possession of the ball. But there are plenty of others that have prompted a head scratch — or seven. Here are five that stand out.

headline: In Paris, Restos for Fashion’s Restless
text: Coffee is having something of a fashionable moment in Paris, a city long derided for its substandard roasts. And at the vanguard of the bean revolution are David Flynn and Nicolas Clerc of the hot new cafe Télescope, which proved an instant hit when it opened behind the Palais Royal’s illustrious arcades in April. Clerc, a Parisian photographer, and Flynn, the American co-founder of the monthly barista throwdown Frog Fight, also happen to be very attuned to the city’s evolving culinary scene. They’re as discerning about the food they eat as the coffee they brew and drink.

headline: Qaeda Operatives Killed in Drone Strike, Official Says
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — An Al Qaeda operative of Turkish origin and an Iraqi reported to be a liaison between Al Qaeda and the Taliban were among five people killed on Monday in a United States drone strike in Pakistan’s lawless North Waziristan region, a Pakistani security official confirmed Tuesday.

headline: TV Trends That Deserve the Unwelcome Mat
text: Many of television’s worst infestations — newscasters with hairpieces; reality shows with “Extreme” in the title; commercials featuring talking lizards, cats or infants — began quietly. Early attention or government action might have stopped them, but then ubiquity set in, and suddenly they were a fact of life.

headline: MaryAnne Gilmartin
text: Ms. Gilmartin, 48, is executive vice president for commercial and residential development at Forest City Ratner Companies, which was a development partner of The New York Times’s headquarters. Its Barclays Center arena, part of the Atlantic Yards development in Brooklyn, is to open this week.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bulgaria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Bulgaria, Afghanistan, Syria and Bolivia.

headline: At a Desert Party, Everything Happens
text: It’s a thin line, Chrissie Hynde sang, between love and hate. Reading Lawrence Osborne’s new novel, “The Forgiven,” you may sometimes feel that you are straddling that line in a vertiginous way, like Philippe Petit walking a high wire between the World Trade Center towers.

headline: Obama and Romney Talk Foreign Policy
text: Today was foreign policy day on the campaign trail, as President Obama addressed both the United Nations General Assembly and the Clinton Global Initiative, and Mitt Romney addressed the latter group. And what a day it was not.

headline: With a Push From Google, California Legalizes Driverless Cars
text: California drivers could soon see cars on the road driving themselves, courtesy of Google and the state government.

headline: Vitality Reborn, New Orleans Draws Developers
text: It has been seven years since Hurricane Katrina brought New Orleans to its knees and a month since Isaac threatened to push the city down again.

headline: Rascals to Reunite for Three Shows
text: Steven Van Zandt has been trying to persuade his musical heroes the Rascals – the influential white soul group known for hits like “Good Lovin’ ” and “Groovin’ ” — to reunite since the early 1980s.  But the four original members, who started the band as the Young Rascals in New Jersey in 1965, agreed to perform together only once since – at a private benefit concert in 2010.
