text: Benefits

headline: Grooving to the Beat and Bang of the Subway
text: What is it about a subway ride that ignites a choreographer’s imagination? In recent years the subway-inspired dance has become as frequent as the L train at rush hour. Remember Camille A. Brown’s energetic yet contrived “Groove to Nobody’s Business” for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater? Just about every retelling of what it’s like to experience the New York City subway proves that while there’s a lot to see — stations bustle with constant activity — there really isn’t much to say.

headline: Apple’s Competitors Pile On With Map Critiques
text: Eric E. Schmidt, Google’s chairman, told reporters in Tokyo on Tuesday that the company had done nothing to get its maps back onto the iPhone since Apple removed them in its new iOS 6 operating system for mobile devices. He said Apple should have stuck with Google’s maps, but, according to Bloomberg, he declined to say whether the company had submitted a new maps app to Apple’s App Store.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Estonia Gets Highest Marks for Internet Freedom
text: What’s up with Estonia? The tiny Baltic nation affords its citizens the greatest measure of digital freedom as measured by Freedom House, a Washington  advocacy group.

headline: Music in Review
text: KIMIKO ISHIZAKA

headline: A Veteran of Judson Dance Recalls Its Wild 1960s Heyday
text: Naked men and women gamboling through water and grass; nearly naked people taking pleasure in one another, lolling on the floor in raw chicken and fish. Ah, the ’60s.

headline: Radio-Tagged Socks for the Obsessive
text: How do you know when you have slipped from detail-oriented, past anal-retentive, all the way to obsessive-compulsive?

headline: Efterklang, Tonight at the Apple Store in SoHo
text: I had the great fortune this weekend of seeing the Danish band Efterklang perform at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The band (whose name means “reverberation” or something close to it in Danish) performed with an orchestra, backup singers and a horn section. To reach the theater where the concert was held, you had to meander through the Egyptian exhibit: past ornate sarcophaguses and hieroglyphic friezes. I’d never been to any kind of presentation in a museum, particularly on a Saturday night. I kind of half-expected some crank in the audience (all seated reverently) to rise and declaim his apocalyptic visions, as in ‘‘The DaVinci Code’’ or ‘‘12 Monkeys.’’ That didn’t happen, quite. But for an encore, the singer, Caspar Clausen, exhorted the crowd to stand and groove for at least a few minutes. The crowd obliged.

headline: Q&A: Combining Two Facebook Pages
text: Q.

headline: Pop-Punk Bands, Now Grown Up
text: The iHeartRadio festival is a hootenanny where the biggest acts in every genre convene for a two-day affair presented by Clear Channel, the gargantuan radio conglomerate, in support of its streaming radio application. As concerts or festivals go, it’s not punk.

headline: Insouciant Elegance and Nonchalant Fireworks, Fueled by Ballet Power
text: LONDON — The San Francisco Ballet season at Sadler’s Wells in London, which ended on Sunday, was an impressive, and tactical, display of ballet power. The company arrived with three programs and 10 ballets for its weeklong run —no small feat on the artistic or financial front. With the exception of Balanchine’s 1956 “Divertimento No. 15,” all the dances were created during the past four years. The company’s commitment to new choreography was clear; its technical aplomb and stylistic versatility shiningly apparent.

headline: Vivid Dispatches From Syria’s Front Lines
text: Eighteen months have passed since an adviser to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria scolded a BBC correspondent in Damascus for reporting that video posted on YouTube by activists appeared to contradict official accounts of a crackdown on protesters broadcast on state-run television. “The events are happening in Syria,” Bouthaina Shaaban insisted, one week into the uprising, “therefore, it’s Syrian television who tells the truth, nobody else.”

headline: A Coastal Tax Fight
text: The Times’s Kim Severson travels to Sapelo Island to visit Hog Hammock, population 50. The Gullah-Geechee residents have lived there since slavery, but may have to sell off their land over taxes.

headline: Taxes Threaten an Island Culture in Georgia
text: SAPELO ISLAND, Ga. — Once the huge property tax bills started coming, telephones started ringing. It did not take long for the 50 or so people who live on this largely undeveloped barrier island to realize that life was about to get worse.

headline: Sarah Silverman Talks About Voter ID Ad
text: In a follow-up to her “Great Schlep” video from the last presidential election, Sarah Silverman decided to take on new voter identification laws that could prevent some people from voting this time around.

headline: MoMA Plans to Be Open Every Day
text: Two weeks after the Metropolitan Museum of Art said it was considering staying open seven days a week, the Museum of Modern Art announced that starting in May it would be open every day, including Tuesday, the one day it has traditionally been closed.

headline: In the Studio | Anthony Vaccarello
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Santander’s Mexican Unit Sells U.S. Shares at $12.18 in Dual Listing
text: The Mexican arm of Banco Santander priced the American portion of its initial public offering at $12.18 on Tuesday, within its expected price range, according to a person briefed on the matter who declined to be identified.

headline: A Place of Desperation, Where Both Patients and Patience Are Tested
text: The crowded emergency room of Highland Hospital in Oakland, Calif., is the setting of Peter Nicks’s wrenching documentary “The Waiting Room.” Shot in 2010 over five months, the film, which has no narrator, titles, statistical analysis or overt editorializing, observes a composite day there during which nearly 250 patients — most of them uninsured — pour in.

headline: Parking Rules: Yom Kippur
text: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Wednesday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Folk Stories From Many Lands, Conjured With a Colorful Spin
text: The French animator Michel Ocelot specializes in giving folk tales his own spin, and he does so in “Tales of the Night,” his latest modest, charming offering. A framing device involves a man considered too old for filmmaking and a pair of teenagers too young. In an abandoned theater they conjure stories, each from a different culture and ending with a twist.

headline: What’s Wrong With Blasphemy?
text: Suppose there had not been a single riot in response to the now infamous video “The Innocence of Muslims,” Not a single car burned, not a single embassy breached, not a single human being physically hurt. Would the makers of this risible little clip have done anything wrong? If so, to whom, and why?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hacking Public Transit, and Twitter Rethinking Follower Counts
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Student Accused of Invasion of Privacy at Princeton
text: A Princeton University student has been charged with invasion of privacy after a fellow student accused him of taking sexually explicit photographs of him while he slept.

headline: In Romney-Obama ‘Redistribution’ Debate, a Gray Area
text: Mitt Romney may be right about President Obama’s Robin Hood tendencies. Future historians could well conclude that Mr. Obama led the biggest redistribution of wealth in decades.

headline: The Roses Are a Draw. (So Is the Dress Code.)
text: MALMESBURY, England — Sunday was the last clothing-optional day of the season at Abbey House Gardens in this ancient Wiltshire village, and a cold and torrential rain had confounded many visitors’ clothes-free plans.

headline: Gardner Returns for Pinch-Running Duty
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Brett Gardner still has not taken batting practice on the field, and he might not be ready to hit in a game until next week. But the Yankees need Gardner’s legs more than his bat, and his legs are fine.

headline: Maurice H. Keen Dies at 78; Redefined Chivalry
text: Honorable men, as they were called in the golden age of chivalry, were rich enough to outfit a squadron of knights and brutal enough to lead them into battle, often culminating in the killing and plundering of civilian populations. The code of chivalry defined honor in ways that are familiar to people today — as honesty, loyalty, courage — and in ways that are not. It was honorable, for example, to show mercy to a defeated enemy, but only if the enemy was a social equal.

headline: The Geechees of Sapelo Island
text: Sapelo Island, a tangle of salt marsh and sand reachable only by boat, holds the largest community of people who identify themselves as saltwater Geechees.

headline: Board Votes for Bigger Type on City Ballots
text: Barack Obama and Mitt Romney may soon loom a little larger in the eyes of New York City voters.

headline: Dr. Griffith Edwards, Addiction Specialist, Dies at 83
text: Dr. Griffith Edwards, a psychiatrist who helped establish addiction medicine as a science, formulating definitions of drug and alcohol dependence that are used worldwide to diagnose and treat substance abuse, died on Sept. 13 in a hospice near his home in Greenwich, England. He was 83.

headline: Out of the Pool, Phelps Finds the Water at Medinah
text: MEDINAH, Ill. — Michael Phelps’s wedge shot was a little thin, but it got airborne, giving rise to abundant applause from the fans in the grandstand behind the Medinah Country Club practice range. Phelps, the 22-time Olympic swimming medalist, felt like a fish out of water Tuesday when he swung his clubs alongside golfers who formed a major titleholder’s row.

headline: Tolerance, Up in Flames
text: Washington

headline: Zebra-nomics
text: Oh, the horror: on the greatest national stage we have, in the last second of a close game, a bunch of replacement referees from the Lingerie Football League and other far outposts of the sport took a game away from the rightful winners.

headline: Anticipating Fallout From Lobbyist’s Legal Cooperation
text: ALBANY — The halls of the New York State Capitol have for years provided a happy hunting ground for prosecutors and ethics investigators.

headline: Russia: 2 Police Officers Found Guilty in Police Brutality Case in Kazan
text: A regional court handed down the first guilty verdicts on Tuesday in a police brutality case that exposed the systematic torture of suspects in a police department in Kazan, the capital of the Tatarstan Republic. A judge said two officers, Ilshat Garifullin and Ramil Nigshatzyanov, illegally arrested Sergei Nazarov of Kazan, accused of stealing a cellphone. Mr. Nazarov later died. Four other officers are accused of sodomizing him with a Champagne bottle in an interrogation. Mr. Garifullin was sentenced to two and a half years in prison, and Mr. Nigshatzyanov to two years. The four officers charged in the assault have yet to stand trial.

headline: Executive Change at Yahoo Suggests Thirst for Acquisitions
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As Yahoo’s newly installed chief executive, Marissa Mayer has given employees free cafeteria food, replaced their BlackBerry phones with iPhone and Android smartphones and closed a long-awaited deal with Alibaba that gives Yahoo $625 million.

headline: ‘New Girl’ Watch: A Season Premiere and a Balancing Act
text: A lot of sitcoms these days involve characters struggling against economic, romantic or psychological limitations, but no comedy goes straight for the heart of melancholy quite like “New Girl,” which returned for its second season on Fox with two episodes Tuesday night. Focusing on a group of roommates caught halfway between Judd Apatow-style immaturity and full-fledged adulthood, it’s an ode to vulnerability and confusion, a celebration of inappropriate choices and the fine art of tiptoeing around your friends’ feelings.

headline: Obama at the Clinton Global Initiative
text: President Obama spoke at the annual meeting of the Clinton Global Initiative.

headline: Romney at the Clinton Global Initiative
text: Mitt Romney spoke at the Clinton Global Initiative in New York.

headline: Stuyvesant Students Describe the How and the Why of Cheating
text: The night before one of the “5 to 10” times he has cheated on a test, a senior at Stuyvesant High School said, he copied a table of chemical reactions onto a scrap of paper he would peek at in his chemistry exam. He had decided that memorizing the table was a waste of time — time he could spend completing other assignments or catching up on sleep.

headline: As Libya Presses Some Militias to Disband, Fighters Attack a Hotel in Tripoli
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Libyan militia fighters assaulted a hotel in Tripoli housing members of the newly elected General National Congress on Tuesday, dramatizing the challenge the government faces in enforcing its ultimatum that all unauthorized brigades must submit to its authority or disband by the start of the day.

headline: NBC Unpacks Trove of Data From Olympics
text: ONE afternoon in early August, a 41-year-old working mother in Los Angeles didn’t get much work done.

headline: Sizing Up a Crown That Is Rarely Worn
text: DETROIT — A bronze plaque outside a players’ entrance to Comerica Park honors Ty Cobb as the greatest Tiger of all, a so-called “genius in spikes.” Among Cobb’s achievements was the triple crown, which he won in 1909 by leading the American League with a .377 batting average, 107 runs batted in and 9 — yes, 9 — home runs.

headline: The Internet: Puppet Theater for a New Age
text: Sometimes, there’s nothing like a friend to stick up for you. Even an imaginary friend.

headline: N.F.L. Chief Caught Between Bad Calls and Owners’ Hard Line
text: When Roger Goodell became the commissioner of the National Football League in 2006, he made protecting certain aspects of the sport’s good name his consuming aim. He was concerned with the fan experience at stadiums as well as the behavior of players in bars. Goodell wanted a league populated by upstanding citizens who provided captivating entertainment while, not incidentally, generating great business, too.

headline: Boy Scouts Assert ‘Good Faith Effort’ to Protect Youths
text: The Boy Scouts of America, facing what could be an avalanche of unfavorable attention in coming weeks from the court-ordered release of internal files about inappropriate sexual behavior by youth leaders, issued a report on Tuesday by a professor who reviewed the files and found what she called “a good faith effort” to protect boys from harm.

headline: Former Programmer Demands That Goldman Cover His Legal Fees
text: A former Goldman Sachs programmer charged a second time with stealing valuable computer code from the investment bank is fighting back, demanding that his former employer cover his mounting legal fees.

headline: An Electric Carmaker Struggles as Its Production Lags
text: As Tesla Motors, a maker of electric cars, burns through cash and misses production targets, it is turning to investors and taxpayers for extra financial help.

headline: Amateur Hour in Pro Football
text: Does Roger Goodell really want his legacy as commissioner of the National Football League to be that he allowed a hugely popular and profitable sport to become a laughingstock? Obviously not. Then why isn’t he orchestrating a rapid settlement in the dispute between team owners and the league’s regular referees over paychecks and pensions?

headline: Backlash to the Backlash
text: One of the iron laws of Middle East politics for the last half-century has been that extremists go all the way and moderates tend to just go away. That is what made the march in Benghazi, Libya, so unusual last Friday. This time, the moderates did not just go away. They got together and stormed the headquarters of the Islamist militia Ansar al-Sharia, whose members are suspected of carrying out the attack on the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi that resulted in the death of four Americans, including Ambassador Chris Stevens.

headline: More Children in Homeless Shelters
text: Almost 20,000 children now go to bed every night in New York City’s homeless shelters, up from 16,000 last year. If homelessness is hard on adults, for the young, it can be disastrous, starting a slide into a lifetime of problems. Mayor Michael Bloomberg and Gov. Andrew Cuomo could reduce these numbers by restarting programs that help homeless families move from shelters to permanent rental housing.

headline: In Massachusetts, Brown Attacks Warren’s Character
text: BOSTON — Video emerged on Tuesday showing supporters of Senator Scott P. Brown making tomahawk gestures with their arms and yelling Indian war whoops at supporters of Elizabeth Warren, his Democratic challenger, outside a pub on Saturday. The gestures were meant to mock Ms. Warren’s assertions, for which she has offered no documentation, that she has Native American ancestry.

headline: Abuse of Electronic Health Records
text: The Obama administration has issued a strong and much-needed warning to hospitals and doctors about the fraudulent use of electronic medical records to illegally inflate their billings to Medicare. Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. and the health and human services secretary, Kathleen Sebelius, cited “troubling indications” that some providers are billing for services never provided and vowed to prosecute. They sent a letter to five major hospital trade associations on Monday, two days after an article in The Times described in detail how greater use of electronic records might be making it easier for hospitals and doctors to submit erroneous payment claims.

headline: Comparing the Deficit Proposals
text: President Obama and Mitt Romney have very different approaches to deficit reduction. Figures below are drawn from similar base lines reflecting realistic fiscal situations, as generally agreed to by research organizations and the Congressional Budget Office.

headline: Prosecutor Deals Blow to Stop-and-Frisk Tactic
text: In a significant blow to New York City’s use of stop-and-frisk tactics, the Bronx district attorney’s office is no longer prosecuting people who were stopped at public housing projects and arrested for trespassing, unless the arresting officer is interviewed to ensure that the arrest was warranted.

headline: A G.O.P. Reunion, With Plans for More Togetherness
text: VANDALIA, Ohio — For the first time in almost a month, Mitt Romney reunited on Tuesday with the man who many Republicans thought would charge up the presidential campaign: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the charismatic PowerPoint-wielder who can draw thousands to rallies that are really mostly giant question-and-answer sessions where they can ask “Paul,” in effect, how to save the party, and the country.

headline: President Obama at the U.N.
text: The anti-American violence in the Muslim world demanded a firm push back from President Obama, who finally delivered it on Tuesday in the last United Nations General Assembly speech of his term.

headline: Justices Uphold Map for West Virginia Voting
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that small population variations among a state’s Congressional districts do not run afoul of the principle of “one person, one vote,” even though advances in computer mapping technology have made it possible to achieve near-perfect equality in representation.

headline: Relic of an Era, Revitalized
text: CHICAGO — Once a dormant area of empty warehouses, the River North section of Chicago has evolved into a nexus of dining, night life and, most recently, an aspiring rival to Silicon Valley. Its 45 square blocks are home to the headquarters of Groupon, the Chicago offices of Google and several hundred technology start-ups.

headline: Replacements Face New Scrutiny
text: SEATTLE — The latest, most egregious, least debated replacement referee fiasco prompted dozens of e-mails and thousands of comments in its aftermath. The N.F.L. felt compelled to release a statement in which it included excerpts from its rulebook. Even President Obama weighed in.

headline: New Limits Considered in Airwaves
text: WASHINGTON — From East Hampton to Malibu, the only limit on how much beachfront property one can own is usually however much one can afford.

headline: One Coalition Stays True to Todd Akin: Home-Schoolers
text: HARRISONVILLE, Mo. — On a recent Wednesday, when many teenagers here were doing homework or playing after-school sports, 17-year-old Ania Bishop, in an ankle-length skirt with American flags, was cheering at a political rally for Representative Todd Akin.

headline: Deportation Deferrals Put Employers of Immigrants in a Bind
text: Manuel Cunha has been fighting for three decades to persuade the federal government to provide more legal immigrant workers for farmers in California’s verdant San Joaquin Valley. So he was initially excited when President Obama announced in June that he would suspend the deportations of hundreds of thousands of young illegal immigrants.

headline: Thriving in School
text: To the Editor:

headline: Test for Obama as Deficit Stays Over $1 Trillion
text: WASHINGTON — Four years ago, Barack Obama campaigned for president on a promise to cut annual federal budget deficits in half by the end of his term. Then came financial calamity, $1.4 trillion in stimulus measures and a maddeningly slow economic recovery.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Teenager Joins Bullpen in Orioles’ Playoff Push
text: BALTIMORE — Jim Thome, the Orioles’ 42-year-old designated hitter, has slugged 611 home runs. The creases around his eyes date him, like rings around a tree trunk, and he has earned the right, after 22 seasons, to arrive at the ballpark later than most teammates.

headline: To Save a Life: A Call for More Kidney Donors
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Need of Help, and Grateful for It
text: To the Editor:

headline: Father’s Bribery Case Hangs Over Daughter’s House Bid
text: Grace Meng, a New York assemblywoman campaigning for a seat in Congress, stood in front of the steps of City Hall last month to accept the endorsement of former Mayor Edward I. Koch. She was flanked by nine supporters, each holding aloft a red, white and blue sign that read “Grace.”

headline: Is Alzheimer’s Type 3 Diabetes?
text: Just in case you need another reason to cut back on junk food, it now turns out that Alzheimer’s could well be a form of diet-induced diabetes. That’s the bad news. The good news is that laying off soda, doughnuts, processed meats and fries could allow you to keep your mind intact until your body fails you.

headline: Why Not Debtors’ Prison?
text: So it has come to this:

headline: California: Brown Signs Bills to Keep Parks Open
text: Gov. Jerry Brown signed several bills on Tuesday that will keep California parks open for the next two years and will provide greater oversight of the embattled state park system. Officials discovered this year that parks employees had hidden $54 million, even as 70 parks faced closings because of budget cuts. The bills signed on Tuesday would institute a two-year moratorium on park closings and provide $30 million to finance maintenance and parks at risk of closure, in addition to $10 million to match private donations made this year to keep parks open.

headline: Do Drone Attacks Do More Harm Than Good?
text: Strikes have fueled anti-American sentiment, but also have taken out some terrorist targets. Are they making the U.S. safer or just more hated?

headline: Corrections: September 26, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Nets Have Big Goals to Conquer Heat
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Brooklyn’s Industrial Space Retools for a New Era
text: The hulking industrial buildings that line Sunset Park’s waterfront once bustled with manufacturing and military activity. Elvis Presley deployed to Germany from the Brooklyn Army Terminal in 1958, one of three million troops to pass through the Cass Gilbert-designed building. The area was once so busy that it had its own rail line and police and fire departments.

headline: The Brooklyn Army Terminal Enters a New Era
text: Occupancy rates are up at the 1919 edifice, which was once the largest military supply base in the United States.

headline: House Panel Recommends New Rules on Ethics
text: WASHINGTON — Saying that public trust was at stake, a special House ethics panel on Tuesday called for new rules to prevent lawmakers and their staffs from violating conflict of interest standards, and proposed other measures to keep partisan squabbles from undermining future investigations of possible wrongdoing.

headline: American Airlines Faults Its Pilots for Disruptions
text: Airlines typically try to keep flying through bankruptcy. But simmering labor tensions at American Airlines have boiled over from the negotiating room to the airports in recent weeks, disrupting operations and leaving a trail of delayed and canceled flights that the airline says is the fault of its pilots.

headline: In Afghanistan, American Trainers Keep Their Armor On
text: In the field, where small teams of American advisers are now working with Afghan units, even minor misunderstandings are treated as potentially violent confrontations.

headline: Training Afghan Allies, With Guard Firmly Up
text: BAD PAKH, Afghanistan — When American military advisers fly into Afghan Army outposts like the one nestled on the floor of this forested valley, they keep their body armor on and their weapons loaded.

headline: Here We Go Again
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — This will be a short one, because I will spend tomorrow fasting and atoning for all of my puzzle transgressions and I am cranky about it. It will also be short because while Peter A. Collins is eagerly anticipating the start of FOOTBALL season, I am not a follower of football, so the theme of this puzzle was largely lost on me. Perhaps the football fans out there will pick up the discussion.

headline: Tougher Penalties Sought in Russia for Drunken Driving After Accident
text: MOSCOW — Russian legislators called on Tuesday for stronger measures against drunken driving after a gruesome weekend accident in which a car crashed into a bus stop at 125 miles per hour, killing seven people, five of them teenagers with learning disabilities.

headline: Despite Second-Half Slump, Wright Equals a Milestone
text: David Wright tied Ed Kranepool atop the Mets career hits list Tuesday night when he sent a single to right field during his team’s 10-6 loss to the Pittsburgh Pirates at Citi Field. Kranepool, one of the original Mets, collected 1,418 hits over his 1,853-game career. Wright matched him after 1,255 games.

headline: Fight for Second Wild Card in the National League
text: As the baseball season moves into its final stretch, the story lines are becoming clearer. Three National League teams — San Francisco, Cincinnati and Washington — have clinched spots in the postseason, and Atlanta joined them as a wild-card team with a win Tuesday. That left St. Louis fighting off Milwaukee and the Dodgers for the second wild-card slot.

headline: Seeking Cures, Patients Enlist Mice Stand-Ins
text: BALTIMORE — Megan Sykes, a medical researcher, has a mouse with a human immune system — her own. She calls it “Mini-Me.”

headline: Obama Without Romney
text: Imagine, for a moment, that the 2012 election really was the pure referendum that Mitt Romney’s campaign strategists apparently expected it to be. Imagine that both the Republican challenger and his party were completely invisible on the campaign trail, that the press was allowed only to cover the incumbent, and that on Nov. 6 the choice was whether to vote “up” or “down” on President Obama’s performance. How would the last three weeks have played out for the president?

headline: Suburban Mother Pleads Guilty to Running a Brothel on the Upper East Side
text: A suburban New York mother who became a tabloid and television sensation after she was charged in February with running an Upper East Side brothel pleaded guilty on Tuesday to one count of promoting prostitution.

headline: RIM Keeps on Loving You in a Video
text: In order to persuade consumers to buy its new BlackBerry 10 phones next year, Research In Motion must first convince developers to create apps for its new operating system.

headline: Goodbye, Mr. Goodell
text: Richmond, Va.

headline: Google Working on Maps for iPhone and iPad
text: People pining for a Google Maps app on their Apple devices will get one eventually, but likely not for another couple months or so.

headline: ‘NCIS’ Watch: How to Resolve a Cliffhanger
text: The perennially popular CBS drama “NCIS” ended last season with the ultimate cliffhanger. Practically every major character was set up to be killed off as NCIS headquarters was bombed and the venerable Ducky (David McCallum) suffered a heart attack.

headline: How Exercise Can Help You Master New Skills
text: Can you improve your body’s ability to remember by making it move? That rather odd-seeming question stimulated researchers at the University of Copenhagen to undertake a reverberant new examination of just how the body creates specific muscle memories and what role, if any, exercise plays in the process.

headline: Using Tech Tools at West Virginia
text: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. — Marlon LeBlanc, the head coach of the West Virginia University men’s soccer team, looked up at eight framed, autographed jerseys lining his office walls. Among them are a No. 28 shirt from the Philadelphia Union right back Raymon Gaddis and a D.C. United jersey of the former defender Devon McTavish. The collection comes from W.V.U. alumni who graduated to become professional players.

headline: Word of the Day | traumatic
text: traumatic •\trə-ˈma-tik, trȯ-\• adjective

headline: Yankees Lose Lead and Chance to Expand Edge
text: MINNEAPOLIS — With the Yankees embroiled in what at times has felt like a 22-game playoff series against the Baltimore Orioles, Joe Girardi has asked the left-handed reliever Boone Logan to pitch in 14 of those games. That has pushed Logan’s total appearances this season to 77, a career high, and it also qualifies as the most times Girardi has called on a pitcher in his six seasons as a manager.

headline: Alderson Speaks on Davis Rumors and Future of Wright and Dickey
text: General Manager Sandy Alderson was interviewed by Gary Cohen and Ron Darling of SNY during the top of the fifth inning of the Mets’ game Tuesday night.

headline: Barnes & Noble Tablets Aim for Niche Below iPad
text: In a series of moves meant to expand Barnes & Noble’s digital offerings, the company on Tuesday introduced two new color tablets and said a video store for its Nook products would make its debut this fall.

headline: A Tough Loss for Hughes
text: MINNEAPOLIS — It is tough to be diplomatic when you struck out your last batter, you still felt strong when you left the mound, and the game unraveled in front of your eyes.

headline: Kashmiris, Disabled by Conflict, Battle for Compensation
text: KASHMIR — Shaida Banu attends stitching lessons in Silikot village near the Line of Control on the Indian side of Kashmir. A tailor teaches embroidery and patchwork in a large schoolroom with sewing machines and a chalkboard. Not far is a cordoned-off plot of mines laid out to prevent militants entering from the Pakistan side.

headline: News Quiz | September 26, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Even Panda Diplomacy Isn’t Working
text: HONG KONG — The overhead pictures of Taiwanese and Japanese ships circling each other and shooting off their water cannons have made the seagoing confrontations appear almost playful. Chinese ships have had similar standoffs with the Japanese Coast Guard.

headline: Reformers Do Win Elections in India
text: Mamata Banerjee and other chief ministers who are opposing the new economic policies of the Manmohan Singh government probably have not read Chapter 3 of the latest book edited by two renowned Indian economists Jagdish Bhagwati and Arvind Panagariya.

headline: Belgian Has Come a Long Way to Hit It a Long Way
text: MEDINAH, Ill. — Of the 12 players on the European team this week, only one is a Ryder Cup rookie, Nicolas Colsaerts of Belgium. But that does not mean he is bereft of Ryder Cup experience.

headline: Syrian Insurgents Mount Fierce Attack on Military Compound in Damascus
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — Suicide bombers struck a military headquarters in a busy square in central Damascus on Wednesday morning, the second insurgent assault on a government military installation in two days and the largest attack in the capital since July, when explosions killed several key aides to President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS News polls included a total of 4,153 telephone interviews conducted from Sept. 18 through Sept. 24 with adult residents of Florida, Ohio and Pennsylvania. Of these, 3,771 said they were registered to vote.

headline: Polls Show Obama Is Widening His Lead in Ohio and Florida
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — For weeks, Republicans in Ohio have been watching with worry that the state’s vital 18 electoral votes were trending away from Mitt Romney. The anxiety has been similar in Florida, where Republicans are concerned that President Obama is gaining the upper hand in the fight for the state’s 29 electoral votes.

headline: The Latest Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS Poll
text: The full results of the latest Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS Poll surveyed voters in Florida, Ohio and Pennsylvania.

headline: An Election and Exiles
text: On this day in 1980 the Mariel boatlift came to an end. For me as a reporter, it is one of those events where life intersected with history. And it is the anniversary of the first Kennedy-Nixon debate, which began the ascent of television’s role in politics.

headline: If the Shoe Fits, Don’t Wear It Unless It’s Comfortable

headline: Losing Fear and Learning to See
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — The motor boat cut through choppy waters before reaching Isla de Asia, off Peru’s coast. We arrived half-drenched and shivering to a stunning scene: Quechua-speaking laborers with pickaxes trying to collect hardened guano, the bird dung so coveted in the 19th century as a fertilizer that nations waged wars over the islands where it is found.

headline: What Are Your Sleep Habits?
text: A piece from the Sunday Review about “rethinking sleep” has been on the most e-mailed list all week. It states that getting eight consecutive hours of sleep every night may not be as essential as we think. Instead, the author proposes, taking short naps throughout the day may actually be more beneficial and improve cognitive function.

headline: Mutual Respect, Not Bad Blood, Links Ryder Cup Captains
text: MEDINAH, Ill. — The Ryder Cup, golf’s biggest magnifying glass, has long exposed the cracks between its participants, the captains in particular. They, more than their players, are the real faces of this event, holing none of the putts but bearing the brunt of the attention and promotional burden in the two-year buildup to each Cup.

headline: Rian Johnson Builds a Better Time Machine
text: “Looper” is a film about fate, regret, decisions, revenge and the old maxim that the child is the father of the man, but mostly it’s about time travel, so let’s travel back in time: to 10 years ago, before the director Rian Johnson’s celebrated 2005 debut film, “Brick” (or his follow-up, “The Brothers Bloom”), to the moment he first had the idea for “Looper.” Back then, it was conceived as a short film, about 10 minutes long, which he never actually shot. But the script would eventually provide the opening voice-over for “Looper”: “Time travel has not yet been invented. But 30 years from now, it will have been.”

headline: The Creators of ‘Homeland’ Exorcise the Ghost of ‘24’
text: “Homeland,” the geopolitically astute spy thriller on Showtime, features three bedeviled protagonists: Carrie Mathison (Claire Danes), a brilliant and bipolar C.I.A. agent; Saul Berenson (Mandy Patinkin), her mentor; and Nicholas Brody (Damian Lewis), a former prisoner of war who tried (and failed) to assassinate the vice president. Much of what made “Homeland” successful in its first season was the artful way in which the show plucked from real-time history, a trick that the show’s creators, Howard Gordon and Alex Gansa, honed while working together on “24.” We talked to them about the challenges of writing a show that so closely mirrors the real-world shadow wars.

headline: Andre Braugher Has a Homework Assignment for You
text: How exactly do you prepare to play the defiant captain of a nuclear submarine who goes rogue? If you’re Andre Braugher, you read. “I got a stack of books and tried to figure out who sea captains are, what life on the sea is like and what goes into the making of a captain who can endure this kind of exile,” he says of preparing for “Last Resort,” an ABC series about a sub captain who commandeers a tropical island. “It’s an apprenticeship by proxy.” Should you ever find yourself in a similar position, here is Braugher’s recommended reading list:

headline: What ‘Back to the Future’ and ‘Terminator’ Owe to ‘La Jetée’
text: Chris Marker, who died earlier this year at 91, was an enigmatic figure, reluctant to be photographed and prone to biographical embellishment. A creature of the European postwar avant-garde, Marker would seem an unlikely influence on modern Hollywood. But his 28-minute “photo-novel,” “La Jetée” — a shuffle of mostly still black-and-white images now marking its 50th birthday — has spawned more would-be blockbusters than any comic book or series of fantasy novels.

headline: For Veterans, a Surge of New Treatments for Trauma
text: Suicide is now the leading cause of death in the army. More soldiers die by suicide than in combat or vehicle accidents, and rates are rising: July, with 38 suicides among active duty and reserve soldiers, was the worst month since the Army began counting. General Lloyd Austin III, the army’s second in command, called suicide “the worst enemy I have faced in my 37 years in the army.” This Thursday, the Army is calling a “Suicide Stand-Down.” All units will devote the day to suicide prevention.

headline: What Do You Do With the Brilliant Jerk?

headline: Daily Report: Relic of an Era, Revitalized for Tech Start-Ups
text: Once a dormant area of empty warehouses, the River North section of Chicago has evolved into a nexus of dining, nightlife and, most recently, an aspiring rival to Silicon Valley. Its 45 square blocks are home to the headquarters of Groupon, the Chicago offices of Google and several hundred technology start-ups.

He specifically cited the “failure” of Oscar organizers to take an official position on the incendiary “film.”

Next door, Rei Kawakubo designed the unusual scenography for “Comme des Garçons, White Drama,” which showcases her all-white S/S ’12 collection ensconced in large-scale bubble formations. Through Oct. 7.

headline: Cambodia’s Landless Class
text: PHNOM PENH — In a union office for garment workers on the outskirts of the capital on a recent afternoon, Tith Srey Mom and her sister Mach were pondering what to do next. After losing a 10-year legal battle to keep their 200-square-meter plot of land, they were being evicted. All legal avenues had been exhausted. All they could do was wait for the police to come and forcibly remove them.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: The Nook as ‘iPad Lite,’ and Lessons From the Olympics
text: Roughly 217 million people watched Olympic coverage on NBC networks during the London games and eight million people downloaded NBC’s mobile apps for the Olympics, according to new figures released by the network, part of a vast trove of consumer research based on viewing during the games. Watching video on tablet computers – no surprise – also surged and the most popular events on any device were women’s gymnastics and the women’s soccer final. The good news for the network: the popularity of the live feed during the day didn’t seem to cannibalize viewers from NBC’s primetime package.

headline: A Guy Thing
text: Jonah Takagi’s mixed-media coffee tables and pendant lights can be found at edgy design stores like Matter and the Future Perfect. But the 33-year-old designer’s house is full of Ikea basics and estate-sale finds, not unlike most of his fashionable 30-something guy friends. So it’s with them — and himself — in mind that he started Field (field-online.com), a new male-centric housewares collection designed by, well, himself and his friends, which include Hallgeir Homstvedt, Jonathan Nesci and Oscar Diaz. “I saw an opportunity to make new vintage pieces, ones that will age well and hold their own alongside a cast-iron desk or shop lights,” says Takagi.

headline: A Year Later, the Braves Celebrate
text: Every once in a while the sports calendar reminds us that so much can change as we make only one trip around the sun. On Tuesday night it was the Atlanta Braves marking time and metaphorical distance, putting a mere 12 months between their mesmerizing twin swan dive (with the Red Sox) out of last year’s baseball playoffs and clinching a spot in this year’s. It is instructive to think back over that 12-month stretch, remembering when baseball had a wild-card format that allowed for such thrilling finishes. (Sigh.) And in the N.F.L., remember when fans were giddy to have their favorite game saved from the teeth of a greedy league lockout? The N.B.A.'s was just getting rolling back then and N.H.L. owners were still dreamily planning for their chance to mess up their sport.

headline: Luxury Cosmetics Maker Weighs the Benefits of Selling Items on TV
text: EvePearl is a Manhattan makeup studio, boutique and e-commerce business with 10 employees that sells cosmetics containing skin-care nutrients. The products are developed by the company’s namesake and founder, a 46-year-old Emmy-winning TV makeup artist. She created her first foundation and concealer products seven years ago while working for Barbara Walters, Meredith Vieira, and the rest of the hosts on “The View.”

headline: The Domino Effect in Nature, and Visual Storytelling
text: My friend Randy Olson, the filmmaker and science-communication evangelizer devoted to prodding folks out of the “nerd loop,” has been at it again — this time running one of his three-day video-making boot camps for graduate students in the TerreWEB program (on communication of global-change science) at the University of British Columbia. One student, Megan Callahan, came up with a particularly effective video on the interconnections in ecosystems. Randy sees this film, describing the domino-like relationship of species in an ecosystem, as the best single video to emerge in his years-long coaching effort. I’d like to get your view, and I’m sure he would, too. Here’s his “Your Dot” post, along with a link to more on his blog, The Benshi:

headline: When Parents Can’t Enroll in Medicaid, Children Stay Uninsured
text: The Census Bureau just released new data on poverty, income and health insurance for last year, and the numbers aren’t pretty. Overall poverty remained at the highs we’ve seen for the past three years, with the picture still particularly bleak for children: 15 percent of Americans and 1 in 5 children live in poverty. Lack of insurance is closely tied to that number. Nearly 14 percent of children living in poverty lacked health insurance last year, compared with under 10 percent for children overall, a number that stayed flat despite the decrease in the rate for everyone under 65.

headline: 3 Myths About Booking Travel From the Source
text: FRONTIER AIRLINES caused a stir recently when it announced that travelers who do not book directly with the airline will pay higher fees, receive half as many frequent flier miles and will not be allowed to select a seat in advance of check-in. Whether cutting out the middleman is consumer-friendly is a matter of debate. But the news got me thinking: should travelers assume that the best deals always come from online — even offline — travel agencies?

headline: Trainers in Afghanistan Arm Themselves Against Both Sides
text: In The Times today, Matthew Rosenberg (@mrosenbergNYT) reports from Bad Pakh, Afghanistan, on the new protective strategy used by military advisers to the Afghan Army: keep body armor on and weapons loaded, all the time. He writes of the advisers in a base in Bad Pakh: “Their guard was up even though they were there for a day of training Afghan soldiers without once leaving the confines of a fortified base — even when chatting with the Afghan officers over a lunch of goat meat and yogurt.”

headline: Opening the Religious Tent to All
text: So much has happened in our lifetimes that seemed impossible not so long ago, beside our own aging. Who could have guessed 40 years ago, when a band of gay Jewish men came together in Greenwich Village to worship because they were welcome nowhere else, that today gay marriage would be legal in this state and others? Who could have guessed 20 years later, after AIDS had killed a generation of gay men, faster than they could be properly mourned, that Congregation Beit Simchat Torah would be a “real’’ synagogue, with a lesbian rabbi? Who could have guessed that before long Beit Simchat Torah would be a magnet for both gays and straights, Jews and Christians, especially on the High Holy Days — Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur — when most synagogues are open only to members with tickets? And that their open-door policy would draw crowds so large it meant using New York City’s historic Town Hall for the first holiday and the cavernous Jacob Javits Convention Center for the second? Attending on the first night of Rosh Hashanah, and welcomed as a “practicing heterosexual,’’ I noted that the audience had at least two things in common: A belief that religion could and should be an open tent. And enough years on this earth to know that there is a time to sow and a time to reap, and that the second required both grace and courage. Among the readings was the poem “Autumn” by Yevgeny Yevtushenko.  Here are the first three stanzas, in slightly different translation. A complete version of the poem, in yet another translation, can be found here if you scroll to the bottom.

headline: How to Prepare for Retirement
text: As boomers move toward retirement — the oldest of our generation are now 66 — the complexities of preparing multiply. Unfortunately, matters have become considerably more complicated since the Great Recession. Of all demographic groups, people ages 55 to 64 have suffered the most financially, losing 10 percent of household income. I’ve had several friends say that they’re never going to be able to retire, that they’ll have to work until they drop. Hopefully not. Today’s expert is Doug Wheat, a certified financial planner with Family Wealth Management, based in western Massachusetts. One of the things that drew him to this work was having to manage his mother’s finances after his father died. Among the questions he is prepared to discuss are:

headline: At U.N., Egypt and Yemen Urge Curbs on Free Speech

headline: Clinton Suggests Link to Qaeda Offshoot in Deadly Libya Attack

headline: Will We Scream for Color Control Creams?
text: Can it be that some are already bored with the influx of blemish balm creams, or B.B. creams, into the American market? Get ready for color control creams, or C.C. creams.

headline: Burning a Forest to Save It
text: Controlled burning of grasslands and forests has been used for thousands of years to stimulate plant germination, replenish the ground with valuable nutrients, thin out trees and burn dry pine needles and tree limbs on the ground. When humans were not intentionally setting fires, lightning strikes completed the job.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: Why Credit Scores Aren’t Always What They Seem
text: When consumers buy access to their credit score, there’s a good chance they’re not seeing the same score a lender sees, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau reports.

headline: Carhenge: A Bucket-List Destination for Those With Time, and Gas, to Burn
text: ALLIANCE, Neb. — The first thing I have to report about Carhenge is that to see it, you really have to want to see it.

headline: Producer Announces That ‘Rebecca’ Rehearsals Will Start on Monday
text: The producers of the troubled Broadway musical “Rebecca” notified cast members on Wednesday that rehearsals would begin on Monday morning, yet it remained unclear if the producers had closed the $4.5 million gap in the show’s $12 million budget that they had deemed necessary for rehearsals to start.

headline: Anne Hathaway to Sing at Joe’s Pub
text: Anne Hathaway will perform a one-night-only concert, “Perfectly Marvelous: The Songs of Cabaret With Anne Hathaway and Friends,” on Oct. 24 at Joe’s Pub. The event is to celebrate the recent renovation of the Public Theater in Manhattan. Member tickets went on sale Tuesday and single ticket sales will go on sale next Tuesday.

headline: Blackbird
text: WHEN the beloved music club Lakeside Lounge closed this year, East Village habitués feared it would be replaced by another artisan bar serving $20 cocktails. Luckily, the owners of Blackbird, which opened in August, are honoring the bar’s musical roots.

headline: Egyptian Commentator Arrested for Defacing Ad Calling Israel’s Opponents ‘Savage’
text: An Egyptian-American columnist, who rose to prominence on social media last year for her commentary during the revolution in Egypt, was arrested in the Times Square subway station on Tuesday for spraying pink paint on a pro-Israel poster that calls Islamist opponents of the Jewish state “savage.”

headline: Drawing Inspiration From ‘Silent Spring’ (Or How to Illustrate a 50-Year-Old Book)
text: Last weekend’s article about the influential environmentalist Rachel Carson, written by Eliza Griswold, presented the art department with an unusual task: how to come up with a visual complement without using archival photos? Carson’s seminal book, ‘‘Silent Spring,’’ came out 50 years ago, after all.

headline: TimesCast Tech | Driverless Cars
text: California legalizes driverless cars. | Meg Whitman bets on old and new businesses to revive Hewlett-Packard. | Centrifuges, blowtorches and liquid nitrogen invade the kitchen.

headline: Two Old Friends Prepare a Three-Part Premiere
text: ROCHESTER — Last week the jazz trumpeter and composer Wynton Marsalis walked into an office building here that once housed a Knights of Columbus chapter, rode an elevator to a high-ceilinged studio and discovered his septet, a 12-member modern dance company, a giant spatula and a 21-foot-tall woman.

headline: Malicious Code Can Wipe Out Some Samsung Phones
text: A simple line of malicious code embedded in a Web page can cause some Samsung Galaxy smartphones to lose all their data, security researchers revealed this week. But Samsung says a fix has been out for months.

headline: The Wealth of Washington
text: In a post pivoting off my weekend column on Washington’s extraordinary recent growth, Dylan Matthews of Wonkblog marshals data showing that the soaring wage premium for Washingtonians doesn’t correlate directly with increases in the federal government’s share of G.D.P. The two have spiked together in the last few years, but the D.C. economy achieved separation from national trends in the Reagan and Clinton years and lift-off under George W. Bush, a long three decade period when government’s share of the national income was relatively flat. What does correlate, though, is the growth in Washingtonian wealth and the steady expansion of lobbying: As Matthews notes, “the growth in inflation-adjusted lobbying spending, as measured by OpenSecrets, tracks the D.C. wage premium’s rise since the 1990s quite well.”

headline: Half-Shell Heroes Return to Action
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: The Daily Shoe | Dries Van Noten
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Yankees’ Rodriguez Rests Sore Left Foot
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Alex Rodriguez was not in the starting lineup for the Yankees on Wednesday afternoon because of a sore left foot. Rodriguez fouled a ball off the top of his foot in his final at-bat in Tuesday’s 5-4 loss to the Minnesota Twins, and it swelled. X-rays were not deemed necessary by the Yankees, and Rodriguez said he should be able to play Thursday against the Blue Jays in Toronto.

headline: Brewing Obama’s Ale: So Far, So Good
text: Diner’s Journal has asked Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster at Brooklyn Brewery, to make a batch of White House Honey Ale — President Obama’s home brew — for us to sample and size up. Mr. Oliver started on Sept. 14, and is filing reports on its progress:

headline: Eintracht Frankfurt: Germany’s Surprise Team
text: With no fewer than 24 transfers over the course of the summer off-season, it would have been easy to make the simple assumption that Eintracht Frankfurt Coach Armen Veh thought his squad was not ready for the step up to the Bundesliga. So much so that of the starting 11 that had finished second in the 2.Bundesliga only months before, only 4 remained for the opening game against Bayer Leverkusen. The squad lacked experience, organization and cohesion.

headline: Kids Draw the News: Tornadoes in New York City
text: Children’s drawings of the city’s recent severe weather.

headline: Huffington Post Continues Expansion With Site in Italy
text: PARIS — Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister of Italy who left office last year in the depths of the economic crisis, resurfaced this week in a new place: the Italian-language Web site of The Huffington Post.

headline: In Further Opening, U.S. to Ease Ban on Imports From Myanmar
text: The United States announced Wednesday that it would begin to ease a longstanding ban on imports from Myanmar, one of the last major economic sanctions on the country, because of the advances made by its military-led government in moving toward a more democratic system.

headline: In Ohio, Obama Takes On Romney Over China and Jobs
text: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio — President Obama joined his Republican rival, Mitt Romney, in this crucial swing state on Wednesday, trumpeting his recently filed unfair-trade complaints against China in a bid to shore up support here before Election Day.

headline: Spanish Ire, Symbolized by a Carrot
text: MADRID — As Spanish domestic politics threaten to spin beyond the control of the central government, they are also making it harder for Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy to meet Spain’s financial obligations to the rest of the euro zone.

headline: As Time Wanes, Glencore-Xstrata Deal Hinges on Leadership
text: The $90 billion merger of Glencore and Xstrata is on shaky ground as the two sides struggle to come to terms over the makeup of the combined management team.

headline: Kids Draw the News: 107th Birthday Party
text: New Assignment

headline: More Are Watching Internet Video on Actual TVs, Research Shows
text: No more squinting at YouTube videos or Hulu shows on a tiny laptop or desktop screen. More people are now watching Internet video — everything from cat videos to streaming prime-time shows — on big-screen televisions than on computers, according to a new report from the NPD Group, a market research company.

headline: Paris, With a Slouch or a Sashay
text: New York seems miles away as the Paris collections, the fourth and final stop of the spring 2013 shows, began in a downpour — a literal one, that is. People arrived at Rochas on Wednesday shaking like poodles, and left to face lagoons of water in the streets. One woman came prepared with a beige vinyl sou’wester that matched her skirt. I hugged the sidewalk on the Champs-Élysées, staying under the trees, and got back to my hotel just before it let loose again. I opened a bottle of red wine.

headline: Dean Foods Explores Sale of a Dairy Unit
text: 4:24 p.m. | Updated

headline: Hewlett-Packard Looks for a Turnaround
text: September 26, 2012 - Meg Whitman on her efforts to revive Hewlett-Packard.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Dries Van Noten
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: At Emmys, Fashion Yields to the Heat
text: For some in the business of celebrity dressing, sizzling weather, and perhaps global warming, have played an increasing role for red carpet events.

headline: Hoping for Emmy (or a Breeze)
text: IT’S a good thing Nicole Kidman has options.

headline: Images of Clashes at Anti-Austerity Protests in Europe
text: As my colleagues Liz Alderman and Niki Kitsantonis report, tens of thousands of demonstrators gathered in Athens to protest salary and pension cuts on Wednesday. The rally, which began peacefully, turned violent in the early afternoon when a small group of demonstrators threw Molotov cocktails at police officers and firebombs at government buildings near the Greek Parliament.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 26
text: A view of the day in sports included some dapper Ryder Cup fans and an interesting reward for a Sumo champion.

headline: Scott Brown Says He ‘Regrets’ His Staff’s ‘Unacceptable’ Behavior
text: 8:43 p.m. | Updated BOSTON — Senator Scott P. Brown’s campaign issued a statement Wednesday evening saying he “regrets” what he called “unacceptable” behavior by some staff members who participated in the tomahawk chops and Indian war whoops at a campaign rally.

headline: Climate Change, Metal and Waterways
text: High in the Rocky Mountains, just west of the Continental Divide, metal concentrations in the Upper Snake River have been climbing over the last 30 years, in some cases increasing as much as fourfold. Strong evidence links this trend to climate change, according to a recent study led by the United States Geological Survey and University of Colorado at Boulder.

headline: Richard Rhodes Writes a Play About Reagan, Gorbachev and Nuclear Weapons
text: Richard Rhodes, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of 24 books, has written his first play, and it spins off of his research into the history of nuclear weapons. Mr. Rhodes’s “Reykjavik,” about the historic 1986 meeting between Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev in that city, will have a free staged reading on Thursday at 6:30 pm at the Baruch Performing Arts Center. Mr. Rhodes and several other experts in nuclear disarmament will appear at a panel discussion following the reading.

headline: New Home for Barnes Foundation a Bright Shade of Green
text: Critics have differed on the merits of the new home for the Barnes Foundation, the world-class art collection that was relocated from a Philadelphia suburb to a downtown museum quarter this year after a long-running court battle. But at least one arbiter has now given the museum an unqualified stamp of approval.

headline: A Tory, His Bike and an Ill-Chosen Insult
text: LONDON — For an ambitious politician, it is rarely a good idea to lose your cool — and never with the police. But Andrew Mitchell apparently compounded the error further by deriding police officers as his social inferiors, and that has turned a small incident into a big political headache for Prime Minister David Cameron and his ruling Conservative Party.

headline: 3 Bidders Left to Run World Trade Center Observatory
text: And then there were three.

headline: Sabathia Gives Twins Fits and Bullpen a Rest
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Joe Mauer, a former most valuable player, came into Wednesday’s game with a .326 batting average — second only to Miguel Cabrera in the American League — and was hitting a staggering .418 in September. But by the time his fourth at-bat came around against C. C. Sabathia, he had struck out three times and did not look so dangerous.

headline: Dear Waldorf, Mummy Stole Your Teapot Back in 1935. So Sorry.
text: A silver coffee pot, a couple of knives, a fork, a coaster for a bottle of wine: the goods were spread out on the table the way the police would spread out guns or drugs hauled in from a raid that would make the 11 o’clock news.

headline: TimesCast Tech: Driverless Cars
text: On this week’s show: California legalizes driverless cars. Meg Whitman bets on old and new businesses to revive Hewlett-Packard. Centrifuges, blowtorches and liquid nitrogen invade the kitchen.

headline: Rochas: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: For $10,000, the Allure of Bentley With Room Service
text: The landmark St. Regis hotel in New York has opened its new Bentley suite, designed in a collaboration between the hotel and Bentley’s interior designers. It joins specialty suites at the hotel branded by Christian Dior and Tiffany. Like the cars that inspired it, the Bentley suite is not an inexpensive proposition; rates start at $9,500 a night, excluding taxes.

headline: 2nd Youth Charged in Vandalism at Congressman’s Campaign Office
text: 5:26 p.m. | Updated A second teenager was arrested on Wednesday and charged with vandalizing Representative Michael G. Grimm’s campaign headquarters on Staten Island over the weekend. The boy, Avery Gerena, 16, of Staten Island, told the police that he did not know the office was Mr. Grimm’s when he threw a rock through its window, according to a criminal complaint.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Zoe Colivas at Rochas
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Zoe Colivas of Elite Paris before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Lucia Pieroni for Clé de Peau and hair by Eugene Souleiman for Wella.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Greece, Syria, India and Senegal.

headline: A Map App, as Sleek as iPhone 5, Is Often Off
text: Last week, I used Apple’s new Maps app on my iPhone to guide me to a speaking engagement.

headline: A Maps App With Problems
text: Apple’s new Maps app for iPhones and iPads devices was built from scratch, and it is full of problems.

headline: Musical Memories of Andy Williams
text: To be honest, I wasn’t a fan of Andy Williams. But I wasn’t a critic, either. Coming of age in the 1960s, I was pretty much rock ‘n’ roll, 24/7. Andy Williams, Perry Como, Bing Crosby, Tony Bennett — they blurred together for me. It seemed like they all owned the same cashmere sweater. I had the same problem with Dinah Shore and Doris Day. While it’s true they sang music you could slow dance to — meaning you got to lean against a girl — for me, it was bar mitzvah music, the slow, grown-up stuff you were forced to listen to until the real music came on. Slow dancing for me was John Lennon’s “Julia.”

headline: Andy Williams, a TV Star When Variety Shows Were Just Hanging On
text: In this YouTube clip, Andy Williams is with Antônio Carlos Jobim to sing “The Girl From Ipanema.”

headline: Gareth Pugh: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: A Day of Protest at the United Nations
text: Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s appearance at the United Nations attracted protesters who shared the streets with those representing other causes.

headline: In Louisville, a Mixed Message
text: The city plans to enlarge its downtown highways, even as it hopes to attract 20-somethings and empty nesters with urban amenities.

headline: The Sheltering Dress
text: Both Dries Van Noten and Marco Zanini of Rochas showed a dress style that was eye-catching in its capaciousness. Neither a tent nor a caftan, it swept to the floor. Mr. Van Noten showed his printed chiffon version as a cover for clothes.

headline: It’s Finally Pink on Top of Music Charts
text: This week on the music charts, Pink finally reaches No. 1 and “Gangnam Style” by the South Korean rapper Psy goes from viral-video status to genuine hit single (although its video is still plenty viral).

headline: Finding Fame, and Sometimes Fortune, in Social Media
text: Social media have made it easier than ever to catapult from obscurity to prominence. In recent years, the Web has blossomed into a more egalitarian version of “American Idol,” where nobodies compete for attention alongside somebodies.

headline: The Reguero Theater Gets Its Close-Up
text: We’ve received many comments from readers about the pictures by Andrew Moore that accompanied John Jeremiah Sullivan’s cover story about Cuba. One in particular, from Virgina Schofield, piqued our interest. Schofield, who is 73, grew up in Cuba and has a special connection to the Reguero Theater that Moore photographed in Morón (above). Her maternal grandfather, Miguel Reguero, spent his small inheritance to build that theater, and her mother occasionally played the piano in productions there. When the enterprise bankrupted Schofield’s grandfather, he moved the family to La Gloria, where her mother met Walton Schofield, whose parents were from England. “I always say my last name is Schofield because of that theater,” Schofield says, referring to the circumstances that led her parents to meet.

headline: The Caucus Click: Guarding the National Debt
text: Secret Service members stood watch near a clock showing the national debt at a campaign event for Mitt Romney on Wednesday in Westerville, Ohio.

headline: Video: Street Protests at the United Nations
text: Hundreds of demonstrators gathered outside the United Nations on Wednesday, chanting slogans and beating drums as President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran gave his final address before the General Assembly.

headline: Leaving Polarization at the Door
text: Robert Rauschenberg, who died four years ago after a career as big-spirited and optimistic as any in postwar art, was not considered first and foremost a politically motivated artist.

headline: For the Absent-Minded, a Few Forget-Me-Nots
text: I have a certain notoriety among friends because of my poor memory, which is particularly bad when it comes to to-do lists. It’s so bad, in fact, that I’ve resorted to all sorts of mental and linguistic tricks. It’s not uncommon to hear me leave the house muttering “monkeys, Ferrari, alien death ray” to help me remember to buy peanuts, park the car inside and make an appointment with the doctor.

headline: A Sherlock Holmes, Out of Rehab and Teaming Up With a Lady Watson
text: When CBS added “Elementary” to its fall schedule a lot of people asked whether television really needed another Sherlock Holmes show when the one we already have, courtesy of BBC and PBS, is so good.

headline: Right Place and Sound for a ’70s Time Warp
text: “Let’s do something kind of old, like me?” suggested Dave Chandler of the doom-metal band Saint Vitus on Tuesday night from a stage that had been built more or less in his honor. “I wrote it right around the time that dirt was invented?”

headline: Proposal Sets Circumcision Regulations in Germany
text: BERLIN — Germany’s Justice Ministry took a firm step on Wednesday toward safeguarding the right of parents to circumcise their male children, distributing its proposal to state officials and other experts to be debated before it is drafted into law.

headline: Column on Romney-Ryan Meant as Satire Is Taken as Fact
text: No, Representative Paul D. Ryan has not given the nickname “Stench” to Mitt Romney, despite a host of credulous journalists and bloggers who accepted as fact a column that Politico intended as satire.

headline: Scenes From the London Design Festival
text: Having just marked its 10th year, the festival is poised between being a regional showcase bubbling with spontaneous interventions and a smooth international canvas.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Characters in this month’s selection of new books make great company: a wily ex-con, a master gardener, female Israeli soldiers and the real women who sued Newsweek so they could be writers. Even an abusive father and a hostage taker bring something to the party.
