headline: Answers From Princeton’s Dean of Admission
text: This week, The Choice has invited Janet Lavin Rapelye, the dean of admission at Princeton University, to stop by our virtual Guidance Office and answer your questions about college admissions. Ms. Rapelye, who received a bachelor’s degree from Williams College and a master’s degree from Stanford University, has 30 years’ experience in college admissions.

headline: At Balenciaga, Lots to Talk About
text: PARIS — The Balenciaga show was just over as François Pinault, the art patron and founder of PPR, slipped out of the backstage area, past a throng of waiting guests. A sustained roar followed as the models, still in their new ruffles and tweeds, cheered.

headline: World’s Tallest Ferris Wheel Planned for Staten Island
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Thursday that the world’s tallest Ferris wheel would rise above the Staten Island waterfront. The 625-foot-tall ride will displace the Singapore Flyer, at 541 feet the record-holder of the moment.

headline: Raising Frogs for Freedom, Prison Project Opens Doors

text: Sometimes modern finance has a great need for something, and so bankers invent products that appear to fill that need. When it turns out that the invention was actually something else entirely, people are shocked.

text: A. P. Merillat has spent two decades investigating crimes in Texas prisons, and his testimony about the violence that inmates serving life sentences can inflict has helped send at least 15 murderers to death row.

headline: Detroit’s Lead Is 2; Gonzalez Wins 21st
text: The playoff picture in the American League began to take shape Thursday, as Texas beat Oakland to add to its cushion in the West. The Angels could not make a move on the Athletics, though, losing to Seattle to leave them two games out of a wild-card spot, with Tampa Bay now also two back. Detroit increased its lead in the Central with a win over Kansas City, as the White Sox lost to the Rays. The Yankees lost, but their rival in the East, Baltimore, was off.

headline: Iran Envoy Is Assaulted by Protesters Near the U.N.

headline: The Arab Spring Still Blooms
text: THE violent demonstrations that have spread across the Muslim world in recent weeks have convinced many in the United States and Europe that the Arab revolutions that began in late 2010 are now over and that the democratic project has failed. Bitterness and a sense of impending catastrophe are replacing the enthusiasm that followed the toppling of dictators in Tunisia and Egypt last year.

headline: Growth of Suburban D.C. Is Felt Politically in Maryland
text: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Maryland, the Old Line State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Donald F. Kettl, the dean of the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland; and Theodore F. Sheckels, a professor of communications and English at Randolph-Macon College in Ashland, Va.

headline: When Growth Outpaces Happiness
text: Los Angeles

headline: ‘Sex and the City’ Creator Lists Apartment
text: THE sophisticated glass-sheathed condominium at One Central Park West exudes sensuality, and why not? Since 2005, it has been the East Coast lair of the producer Darren Star, the creator of a string of frothy television series headlined by “Sex and the City,” the cult classic that zeroed in on the high-wire exploits of four romance-addicted New York City career women. He also produced the film version of “Sex and the City” and its sequel.

headline: Farewell to a Mustache Forever Linked to the Mets
text: Without his mustache, would Clark Gable have been as silkily charming when he told Scarlett O’Hara he frankly did not give a damn? Would Groucho Marx have delivered his one-liners with the same zing?

headline: Governors Island and Its Future
text: Governors Island was, for many years, little more than a tantalizing wasteland — a 172-acre chunk of rock and mostly abandoned military structures. Politicians and urban planners dreamed of ways to turn this underused space into a compelling daytime destination for New Yorkers, but nothing really happened until the state, in 2010, ceded most of the island to New York City.

headline: A Big Right Arm and a Little Man on His Shoulder

headline: The Wait for Postal Default
text: While House members are back home campaigning straight to Election Day, voters might want to alert them that the United States Postal Service is about to default on a $5.6 billion loan obligation — mainly because the House took off without allowing the service to modernize its archaic business practices.

headline: Obama Fills in Blanks of Romney’s Plans, and G.O.P. Sees Falsehoods
text: The Obama campaign has run advertisements charging that Mitt Romney’s Medicare plan “could raise seniors’ costs up to $6,400 a year” and that his tax proposal “would give millionaires another tax break and raises taxes on middle-class families by up to $2,000 a year.”

headline: A Duty of Health Care Workers
text: Health care workers should know better than anyone that it is important to get vaccinated against the flu virus to protect their own health and prevent the possibility of infecting patients. There were some encouraging signs in an analysis issued Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that doctors and nurses are beginning to get the message. But other health care workers — a broad group that includes clinical personnel like nurse practitioners and physician assistants and various nonprofessional aides and assistants — show remarkable indifference to performing what ought to be considered their civic duty.

headline: A City Place for Country Doctors
text: FOR years, Gregory Turner wanted a second home in the city.

headline: Europe’s Austerity Madness
text: So much for complacency. Just a few days ago, the conventional wisdom was that Europe finally had things under control. The European Central Bank, by promising to buy the bonds of troubled governments if necessary, had soothed markets. All that debtor nations had to do, the story went, was agree to more and deeper austerity — the condition for central bank loans — and all would be well.

headline: The Geography of Nope
text: SALT LAKE CITY — In a part of Italy where chestnut trees are thick in the Apennine foothills, I once asked a neighbor in the little community where we lived how I might kill a wild boar. This impulse was driven by appetite, mostly — glimpses of those feral beasts on my morning runs that had me dreaming of a blood-red ragu made of local cinghiale.

headline: State Is Trying to Put Brakes on High Cost of University
text: Ashton Curlee, the ambitious daughter of two teachers, received official notification of her acceptance to the new Texas Science Scholar Program at the University of Texas of the Permian Basin on the first day of college.

headline: Man Tied to Anti-Islam Video Held on Probation Charge
text: LOS ANGELES — The man thought to have been behind the crude anti-Islam video that set off deadly protests across the Muslim world in recent weeks was arrested Thursday for violating terms of his probation in a 2010 bank fraud case.

headline: The Psych Approach
text: In the 1990s, Vincent Felitti and Robert Anda conducted a study on adverse childhood experiences. They asked 17,000 mostly white, mostly upscale patients enrolled in a Kaiser H.M.O. to describe whether they had experienced any of 10 categories of childhood trauma. They asked them if they had been abused, if their parents had divorced, if family members had been incarcerated or declared mentally ill. Then they gave them what came to be known as ACE scores, depending on how many of the 10 experiences they had endured.

headline: A’s Fail to Gain Ground In a Showdown Series

The A’s split four games with the Rangers, leaving Oakland in the same position it was in when the series started — four games behind the division leader.

headline: Syrian Rebels Take Their Battle to the Skies
text: In an article published in The New York Times on Thursday, C.J. Chivers (@cjchivers) wrote about the battle for Abu ad Duhur, an air base south of Aleppo, Syria. Rebels have targeted the base to keep its planes from going out on missions. Rebel forces have been trying for months — at times claiming success — to shoot down government planes and helicopters in midflight.

headline: Behind the Padlocks of a New York Apartment

New Yorkers with warm memories of their city in extremis — the era of Jules Feiffer’s black comedy “Little Murders” and an age evoked fondly in recent memoirs by James Wolcott and Edmund White — may feel a rush of nostalgia during the opening scene of “Through the Yellow Hour,” the new B-movie-like play by Adam Rapp.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Is This the Nastiest Election Ever?

Thanks to recent efforts to score political points on violence in Egypt and Libya, and charges of class warfare rising on both sides, this mean and nasty season has only gotten worse.

headline: In Virginia, Nominees Reach Out to Military
text: VIRGINIA BEACH — In case anyone is wondering, Virginia is up for grabs this election. So, with 39 days to go, President Obama and Mitt Romney dueled in the commonwealth on Thursday, both trying to lock up support from voters with ties to the military.

headline: Yankees’ Division Lead Shrinks as Nova’s Slump Persists
text: TORONTO — Ivan Nova lofted an 87 mile-per-hour slider approximately 18 inches higher than the intended target. It came in chest-high to Edwin Encarnacion, who lashed it into the right-field corner for a two-run double that may have determined Nova’s fate for the rest of the season.

headline: N.H.L. to Resume Labor Talks as Preseason Is Canceled
text: Formal negotiations are scheduled to resume Friday between N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman and Donald Fehr, the executive director of the N.H.L. Players’ Association — the first formal bargaining since Sept. 12, three days before the lockout began.

headline: Syrian Rebels Announce Big Offensive in Aleppo
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rebel fighters in the northern Syrian city of Aleppo said Thursday that they had launched a major offensive against government troops in the city, just as the United Nations and humanitarian agencies warned that the number of Syrians fleeing to neighboring countries could surge past 700,000, far exceeding earlier estimates.

headline: An Enduring Ritual of Politics Loud and Close
text: WESTERVILLE, Ohio — By 7 a.m. on Wednesday, supporters hoping to catch a glimpse of Mitt Romney extended for two blocks outside Westerville South High School in this suburb of Columbus, the site of a “victory rally” hastily shifted from an outdoor amphitheater when the forecast called for rain.

headline: At U.N., Myanmar Leader Highlights Steps to Reform
text: The president of Myanmar, a former general who has led the move away from a prolonged era of dictatorship, poverty and isolation, asserted on Thursday in his first United Nations speech that “amazing changes” were transforming his country and could never be reversed.

headline: A Father-Daughter Dance Revives Charges of Discrimination
text: CRANSTON, R.I. — The members of the parent-teacher organization at Stadium Elementary School had no idea that the father-daughter dance they were planning last spring was, in fact, against the law.

headline: Mixed Returns for Endowments

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Scandal’ in an Election Year
text: This season, the critics Neil Genzlinger and Mike Hale are checking out favorite shows and seeing how they hold up. Previous entries in this series include posts on “New Girl” and “NCIS.”

headline: Rover Finds Signs of Old Streambed
text: NASA’s Mars rover Curiosity has spotted pieces of an old streambed where water rushed by billions of years ago, scientists reported at a news conference on Thursday. “It just seemed like someone came along the surface of Mars with a jackhammer and lifted up a sidewalk that you might see in downtown L.A.,” said John Grotzinger, the mission’s project scientist. From the size of the rounded pebbles embedded in the slab, the scientists estimated that water was flowing about a yard a second and was between ankle and hip deep. NASA has found bountiful evidence of liquid water on early Mars when it might have been warmer, but this was the first observation of an ancient streambed. Curiosity is looking for carbon-based molecules which, together with liquid water, could have provided all of the necessary building blocks for life.

headline: Afghanistan: Joint Missions Rise Again
text: The number of missions in which Afghan security forces work in partnership with American and allied troops is growing again, although restrictions ordered after a spate of “insider attacks” have not been lifted, Pentagon and military officials said Thursday. In a significant restriction on a core element of the Western exit strategy from Afghanistan, the American-led military coalition said last week that all joint operations with Afghan forces conducted below the battalion level had to first go through a formal approval process — an effort to stem attacks by members of the Afghan security forces that have killed 51 American or allied service members this year. Officials now say those approvals were being handled efficiently enough that the number of partnered operations was returning to normal. Before the order, about 90 percent of all missions were conducted jointly. The number is now climbing again, said officials, who declined to offer specifics.

headline: Time to Confront Reality, Now That They’re Elected
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Mexico: Suspected Drug Boss Captured
text: The Mexican Navy said Thursday that its marines had captured a top leader of the Zetas drug gang, Iván Velázquez Caballero. Mr. Velázquez Caballero had been feuding with another Zeta leader, Miguel Ángel Treviño Morales, a Navy spokesman said. The feud had caused a surge in violence in parts of northern Mexico. Mr. Velázquez Caballero was caught on Wednesday night in San Luis Potosí, north of Mexico City. The Navy has made several high-profile arrests recently, but experts say that lieutenants quickly rise to take the place of captured crime bosses, bringing struggles that generate new violence.

headline: Irving Adler, Teacher Fired in Red Scare, Dies at 99
text: Irving Adler, a former New York City teacher who became a prolific writer of books on math and science for young people after being forced from the classroom during the Red Scare of the early 1950s, died on Saturday in Bennington, Vt. He was 99.

headline: The Unraveling of Government
text: Frustrated over the inability of political leaders to find common ground on even the most pressing national issues, Americans have developed a long list of people or political practices to blame for the fact that government doesn’t seem to work anymore. But the real problem is something that’s not high on most such lists, something that’s far more crucial.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: China: Dissident Artist Rejects Fines
text: Ai Weiwei, the persecuted artist and critic of the Chinese Communist Party, said Thursday that he would not pay taxes and penalties that the government said he owed. Mr. Ai made his statement after a court in Beijing rejected his appeal of a lower court’s verdict saying he would have to pay back taxes. He was detained for 81 days last year, and after his release, Beijing officials said Mr. Ai owed $2.4 million in back taxes and penalties. Mr. Ai paid a bond of $1.3 million to contest the government order. Tax officials are expected to keep the bond, which means Mr. Ai will owe $1.1 million. It was unclear what would happen if he did not pay. The government still holds Mr. Ai’s passport, and he has been forced to cancel overseas appearances.

text: Enrollment in college is still climbing, but students are increasingly saying no to graduate school in the United States.

headline: Australia’s A-League Banks on Del Piero
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Perhaps it is ordained that Australia, blessed with sun, sea and surf, could not also have the beautiful game in all its glory. For years, soccer has struggled there. A national league folded in 2004 amid bankruptcy and bad feeling, and the shiny new A-League that started a year later has yet to establish a solid foundation.

headline: Inquiry Faults Racing Officials in Horse Fatalities at Aqueduct
text: More than half of the 21 racehorses who had fatal breakdowns at Aqueduct Racetrack earlier this year might have been saved had racing authorities more closely monitored their health and the liberal use of prescription drugs to keep them racing, according to an investigation ordered by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York.

headline: Last Somali Militant Bastion Falls, Kenya Claims

headline: After London Olympics Debacle, Security Firm Shuffles Top Managers

headline: India, Home of the Nonviolent Protest, Embraces More Extreme Dissent
text: Gone are the days when picketing, candlelight vigils, marches or hunger strikes were enough to guarantee your cause a spot on prime-time television in India. No matter how grave or frivolous the cause, modern protesters employ far more creative tactics to draw attention.

headline: John Sununu’s a Teddy Bear
text: You recently described the vaguely Southern accent the president uses in speeches as “phony as his jaunt when he runs up and down Marine One.” What exactly is a phony jaunt?  Every time you see him climbing up or down stairs, he elevates his arms and does this pumping, trying to look like a well-trained and trim dynamic individual. It’s something he does all the time, particularly when he’s climbing up to a podium to speak or address a crowd. This president understands that he got elected on the basis of style and not substance, and I think he’s trying to preserve style.

headline: How a Diner Gets the Most Out of Social Media
text: Squeeze In is a modest little breakfast-and-lunch diner with four locations in the greater Reno, Nev. area. The restaurants are open seven days a week, 7 a.m. to 2 p.m. While online commenters rave about the food, I can’t get over how creatively this little chain has managed its social media. It has a Web site and a custom mobile site. It promotes the business through Foursquare, Twitter, Facebook, Pinterest and Instagram.

headline: Internal Devaluation and the Road to Wigan Pier
text: Greg Ip, in correspondence, directs me to Chapter 3 of the latest IMF World Economic Outlook, which among other things contains an analysis of a case that bears directly on the attempts of euro area countries to restore economic health through fiscal austerity and internal devaluation: Britain’s return to the gold standard after World War I.

headline: Sony Agrees to Acquire Stake in Olympus

headline: Leopard Poaching on the Rise, Group Warns
text: When it comes to the poaching of endangered species, elephants, tigers and rhinos tend to be in the limelight. But a new report sets out to plug the information gap on a different species that is imperiled by a tide of demand related to rising affluence in Asia: leopards.

headline: Ousted From Party in China, Bo Xilai Faces Prosecution

The leaders also said they had scheduled the 18th Party Congress, the climax of China’s once-a-decade leadership transition, to start Nov. 8.

headline: App Smart Extra: More Help Remembering What To Do

headline: A Dangerous Gateway to Mount Everest

This accident is just the latest in a string of recent fatal airline accidents in Nepal, and has once-again raised questions about the safety of air travel to one of the most iconic tourist destinations in Asia.

headline: At the U.N., Agitation, Outrage and Business as Usual
text: Here in the “capital of the world,” which is New York’s characteristically modest description of itself, people seem to have survived their annual immersion in foreign affairs with but the faintest disruption to their lives. We knew all along that they could do it, despite the overblown forecasts of impending disaster, including the menace they were instructed by television to dread most of all: traffic jams.

headline: Uncomfortable Truths

In disbelief, we went straight to our mother. She was surprised: “I thought we were going to wait until they were older.”

headline: Security Fears Hobble Inquiry on Libya Attack

headline: Shotgun Wedding Suburban Jungle
text: Do the self-satisfactions of the middle class and its rituals somehow prove irresistible to a novelist? Is it just too tempting to consider how a big social gathering might go disastrously wrong? Consider Ayelet Waldman’s “Red Hook Road,” in which a young couple meet a tragic end hours after taking their vows, or, in a more playful register, Ali Smith’s “There but for the,” which sends a dinner party spinning out of control when a guest locks himself in a room and refuses to leave. Lisa Zeidner’s funny, chaotic new novel, “Love Bomb,” is pitched in tone somewhere between Waldman’s and Smith’s: realistic in its depiction of sympathetic characters facing a crisis, while edgy in its satire of a well-off New Jersey suburb and its sometimes hapless police force.

headline: Perspective Is at Play in Who Is ‘Better Off’
text: “This president cannot tell us that you are better off today than when he took office,” Mitt Romney said as he accepted the Republican presidential nomination. Since then, “Are you better off?” has become a central theme of the campaign, and is likely to surface next week at the first presidential debate.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: New F.T.C. Rules for Children Online, and Being a Replacement Official
text: The Federal Trade Commission is expected to tighten rules soon about Web sites that collect information about children, Natasha Singer writes, greatly increasing the need to obtain parental permission for common practices like using cookies to track young users’ activities online, or their location via a mobile phone, or accepting photographs submitted by children under 13. The current federal rule, which dates to 1998, requires parental consent before Web sites can collect personal information like phone numbers or physical addresses from children, but those rules can appear antiquated considering how technology has changed over more than a decade.

headline: Potus v. Scotus
text: The Oct. 22, 2007, cover of Time magazine displayed a portrait of Chief Justice John Roberts above the line does the supreme court still matter? “As the dust rises and the opinions, concurrences and dissents pile up, the court turns its attention to ever smaller cases related to ever narrower points of law,” David Von Drehle lamented in the accompanying article. “The court’s ideology is playing a dwindling role in the lives of Americans.”

headline: State of Disunion
text: The Washington Post columnist E. J. Dionne Jr. has ascended to a sufficiently elevated plane of the Higher Punditry that his author’s biography no longer mentions he received a doctorate from Oxford, where he was a Rhodes scholar. Even so, he still comes across as a precocious student, bubbling with boyish charm and enthusiasm for ideas, though sometimes a bit glib and preening. His books are clever, upbeat and interesting, particularly when he examines current political concerns through the lens of history, religion and philosophy. But while readers will admire Dionne’s intellectual dexterity in diagnosing the historical origins of our present political problem of division and dysfunction, they may also wish he could make a more substantive case for how we might move beyond it.

headline: Gay Center to Make Its Village Home More Open and Less Noisy
text: The love that now dares speak its name can still sometimes be hard to hear.

headline: From the Old South to the New Right
text: When Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina died in 2003 at the age of 100, he seemed to embody the term “political survivor.” Think of someone who began his career as a Roose­velt Democrat and finished it as a Reagan Republican, who campaigned for president as a white supremacist and ended up supporting a national holiday for Martin Luther King. Decades passed, one generation replaced another, but Thurmond soldiered on, swapping causes, even political parties, with a juggler’s eye. Where many politicians become objects of contempt or indifference over time, with Thurmond the reverse was true: the longer he lasted, the more revered he became.

headline: Pro-Life, Pro-Left
text: In 1968, Mark Hatfield, one of America’s most prominent evangelical politicians, wanted to abolish the draft and clandestinely wore a Eugene McCarthy pin under his lapel. A Republican senator from Oregon, Hatfield had fans in evangelical churches around the country. When organizers of the 1973 National Prayer Breakfast invited him to address Richard Nixon, Henry Kissinger and other conservative luminaries (the Vietnam War was a “national sin and disgrace,” he told them), he based his remarks on a text written by a renegade seminarian named Jim Wallis — a former member of Students for a Democratic Society who believed that being “pro-life” meant hating war and poverty as much as abortion.

headline: Save Us
text: Steve Stern’s characters — Shimmele, Avi, Fagie, Morty, Mendy, Mushie — are escape artists. They want to escape doting, caviling parents, the injunctions of Mosaic law and a stifling “atmosphere where sedulous study was valued above action.” They want, in other words, to escape Judaism.

headline: Odd Men Out
text: In the American wars of the 20th century, soldiers of the rear echelon were derided as “in the rear with the gear,” or worse. However, the whole concept of a “rear,” predicated on a definable “front,” started slipping in Vietnam and met its official death in Somalia. By the time of the Iraq occupation, the place where clerks did their clerking and infantrymen got a plate of hot chow was no longer in a relatively safe rear area but in the forward operating base, or FOB, smack in the middle of everything, and the soldiers stationed there became known as Fobbits.

headline: Editors’ Choice

headline: Paperback Row
text: ANATOMY OF A DISAPPEARANCE,  by Hisham Matar (Dial, $15.) Matar’s fiction revolves around his parents, and especially his father, a Libyan dissident who was kidnapped by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s agents in Cairo in 1990. In his elegiac second novel, a boy struggles with the mysterious abduction of his father, exiled from an unnamed Arab country, and with his confused, preadolescent desire for his father’s much younger second wife.

headline: Book Burdening
text: I recently started reading a wonderful and compelling book about sports. Before I finished it, I bought a copy and gave it to my 14-year-old nephew. As I got further into the book, I came upon a homosexual relationship that I thought might not be appropriate for my nephew to be reading, as he was brought up in a very religious household. I’m now feeling irresponsible for not having finished the book before giving him a copy. I am inclined to tell his parents my feelings, but he may have already read the book and perhaps thought nothing of it. Do I confess all? KATHRYN KORS-JACOBSON, CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.

headline: Who Made That Trampoline?
text: In 1960, George Nissen rented a kangaroo named Victoria from an animal-supply outfit on Long Island so that he could train her to hop on a trampoline he set up in Central Park. After a week of waltzing with Victoria, clasping her front paws as he taught her to bounce in time with him, Nissen finally produced a mind-bending photograph. In it, Nissen and the kangaroo stare into each other’s eyes as they levitate over the trampoline. The photo was reprinted around the world and helped establish the trampoline as a global phenomenon.

headline: Inside the List
text: PILOT EXPERIMENT: Michael Chabon’s new novel, “Telegraph Avenue” — it’s at No. 7 on the hardcover fiction list — tells the story of two families, one black and one white, in Oakland and Berkeley, Calif. Twelve years ago, when Chabon’s novel “The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay” was starting to make some noise (it went on to win a Pulitzer in 2001), newspaper profiles mentioned that the author was wrapping up another project: a television pilot called “Telegraph Avenue,” about a black family and a white family in Oakland and Berkeley, Calif. How did Chabon get from there to here? “When I first considered the possibility of transforming the script into a novel,” he said via e-mail, “I went through the usual process, apparently requisite to my beginning any novel, of lying to myself about how easy it was going to be. I told myself I would just be able to ‘novelize’ it. Two and a half years later, battered and discouraged and ready to quit, and ready to kill the optimistic idiot who got me into this mess, I belatedly realized my mistake. A pilot is there to set the table. To set it beautifully, and with a proper and adequate complement of utensils for the coming meal. But in terms of nourishment it only really sets out some canapés, maybe a dish of olives. A novel has to serve a full, seven-course meal with sherbet in the middle and maybe a last little passed tray of petits fours. I had to start all over again, and reconceive the entire thing.”

headline: On the Waterfront, Rise of the Machines

At rest beneath a looming row of gantry cranes, the ship had come to port on a half-day call to discharge a load of South American cargo: 421 containers’ worth, each one weighing as much as a family of elephants — or slightly more than 40,000 pounds.

headline: The Bond of Blueberry Jam
text: I started making jam with my daughter, Anna, the summer she was 3 1/2. She’s now a high school senior. That summer we had discovered a small blueberry farm that sold plump, fresh blueberries by the carton during their exceedingly short growing season. We sat at a four-seat counter in a hot, tiny room adjacent to the field and enjoyed the freshest blueberry ice cream we’d have in our lives, before loading the car with berries to take home for jam.

headline: The Dirtiest Part of a Catcher’s Job

headline: Redefining Southern Women With Spine

A three-hanky comedy-drama, it is fondly remembered for female bonding and zippy one-liners about sanity, men and bitchiness. So Kenny Leon, the director known for spinning black stories into critical and commercial gold, was excited about an offer to direct a TV film version with black actresses, but wanted sound artistic reasons to tinker with the material.

headline: Rules of War

headline: Abraham to Zachary
text: One night a few months ago, my 7-year-old son — who during the Republican primaries developed a mildly obsessional interest in presidential history — asked me to rank the American chief executives in order of greatness. With bedtime looming, I resolved to make it quick. Rattling off the successes (George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, Franklin D. Roosevelt) proved easy, as did listing the failures (James Buchanan, Andrew Johnson, Herbert Hoover, Richard Nixon). But filling in the middle drove me crazy. Should William McKinley place higher or lower than Gerald Ford? Martin Van Buren above or below Rutherford B. Hayes? Yawning, and under pressure from my eager son, I randomly plugged in Millard Fillmore, Chester A. Arthur and the Harrisons and called it a night.

text: Each Friday we post three short tasks that Sarah Gross and Jonathan Olsen, New Jersey team-teachers, tried that week with their ninth-grade humanities students.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Censorship
text: David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the turmoil that art and speech can create in the world.

headline: Vatican Says Papyrus Referring to Jesus’ Wife Is Probably Fake
text: VATICAN CITY — The Vatican has raised doubts about a recently released fragment of a Coptic text in which Jesus alludes to having a wife, describing it as “problematic and controversial,” and most likely a fake.

headline: Fracking Suspense Cuts Into Second-Home Sales
text: As I report in the real estate section of The Times, many would-be buyers are deferring purchases of second homes in upstate New York out of concern that hydraulic fracturing might be allowed nearby. For now, no one knows whether Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration will allow this controversial natural gas drilling process to go forward.

headline: Raf Simons and the Remapping of Dior
text: In just six months at Dior, Raf Simons has shown that he’s more than a creative director. He’s a decorator, an architect and a definitive tastemaker. His July couture collection put Dior again in the spotlight. Today, he gave Dior a modern blueprint for its ready-to-wear and accessories.

headline: A Sand Castle Built for Life
text: The “Making It Last” feature profiles couples who have been together at least 25 years. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Sept. 28
text: In today’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the turmoil that art and speech can create in the world.

headline: Knicks Appear Closer to Signing Rasheed Wallace
text: The Knicks appear to be one step closer to signing Rasheed Wallace, who could be the latest and yet another veteran player this off-season to join the team just before training camp. A person with direct knowledge of the situation said Wallace took his physical with the Knicks’ training staff Thursday.

headline: Bolton Calls Obama’s Benghazi Response ‘Limp-Wristed’
text: John Bolton, the former ambassador to the United Nations most famous for saying the 38-floor U.N. headquarters could be 10 floors smaller “and it wouldn’t make a bit of difference,” shared his thoughts today on the recent unrest in the Middle East and North Africa.

headline: How Cheerful Was My Bomb Shelter
text: Every week The Shot offers a photo of the people, places or things of our generation. Do you have memories related to this image? Share them with us in the comments.

headline: Borrowing From Your Family, by Design
text: It’s much tougher than it used to be for young Americans to make their financial way in the world, given the increasing cost of college and the challenge of finding a job with benefits and a wage high enough to cover the basics plus the servicing of any student loan debt.

headline: The Debate Expectations Dance
text: BOSTON — Ripping the stuffing out of your opponent means it is another day on the campaign trail.

headline: Referees Feel the Love, at Least for One Game
text: BALTIMORE — Gene Steratore and his brother, Tony, founded a janitorial supply business in 1988. They still run the company, but during autumn weekends they are usually focused on their part-time jobs as N.F.L. officials.

headline: Viewing the Economy Through Campaign Glasses
text: ACCORDING to numerous economic indicators, the American economy is getting better.

headline: China Alters Its Strategy in Diplomatic Crisis With Japan
text: BEIJING — After allowing anti-Japanese demonstrations that threatened to spin out of control, China has reined them in and turned instead to hard-edged diplomacy over disputed islands in the East China Sea to lessen any potential damage the conflict might have inflicted on the nation’s softening economy and a delicate leadership transition.

headline: Displaying the Dinosaurs of the Digital Age
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Not everyone’s pulse will quicken with a glimpse of a 1956 I.B.M. Ramac actuator and disk stack. For many, too, the 1959 Telefunken RAT 700/2 analog computer will just look like a cross between an antediluvian switchboard and the control panel for a German submarine. And while those of us of a certain age who are technically inclined might recall elegant, finely made slide rules with fondness, can even a hint of nostalgia be summoned for the glowing five-inch screen of a barely luggable, suitcase-size 1981 Osborne computer?

headline: Bill Cunningham | Turnabout
text: Freedom of expression in dress was out in full force during New York Fashion Week.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Great Disconnect
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Mark Lilla reviews “I Am the Change: Barack Obama and the Crisis of Liberalism” by Charles R. Kesler. Mr. Lilla writes that he needs help in understanding the conservative view of the president, whom he sees as “a moderate and cautious straight shooter.” Mr. Lilla continues:

headline: Moving Handel’s Harpischord to the Modern Piano
text: HANDEL: KEYBOARD SUITES

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Justice League of Scientists
text: In all my years of reading comics, I never thought that one of my favorite characters would be the real-life physicist Richard P. Feynman. I learned quite a bit about him last year, when I read the biography “Feynman,” published by First Second. As I said then, “much of the science went over my head, but the story was always captivating as were the scenes from his everyday life.”

headline: Iranian News Agency Plagiarizes The Onion
text: Last Updated: Saturday, 6:13 p.m. Apparently unaware of the unwritten rules of both ethical journalism and satire, an Iranian news agency published an edited copy of a report from The Onion on Friday, without crediting the original or acknowledging that it was fiction.

headline: For Bank of America, More Trouble From Merrill Lynch Merger
text: Bank of America has resolved one of the largest and most embarrassing pieces of litigation related to its merger with Merrill Lynch in 2008. But the settlement comes with a pretty hefty price tag, since the bank has agreed to pay $2.43 billion to end the lawsuit. That monetary award ranks it as one of the largest settlements in a securities class-action case, behind the settlement over the disastrous AOL–Time Warner merger.

headline: F.C.C. Backs Proposal to Realign Airwaves
text: WASHINGTON — The government took a big step on Friday to aid the creation of new high-speed wireless Internet networks that could fuel the development of the next generation of smartphones and tablets, and devices that haven’t even been thought of yet.

headline: Universal Closes on EMI Deal, Becoming, by Far, Biggest of Remaining Big Three
text: The Universal Music Group closed on its $1.9 billion acquisition of EMI Music on Friday, a week after receiving regulatory clearance in Europe and the United States and more than 10 months after it first made the deal with Citigroup.

headline: Surprises in Afternoon Pairings at Ryder Cup
text: After the morning foursome matches, the United States and Europe are tied at the Ryder Cup, 2-2. The captains, Davis Love III and José María Olazábal, will send out the following pairings for the afternoon fourball session. (All times Eastern.)

headline: Morton Feldman: ‘Crippled Symmetry’
text: MORTON FELDMAN: ‘CRIPPLED SYMMETRY’

headline: Photos of The Moment | Rick Owens
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Netanyahu’s Bomb Diagram During U.N. Speech Stirs Confusion in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — When the prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, drew his red line on a cartoonish diagram of a bomb from the podium of the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday, he intended to illustrate in simple terms the point at which Iran’s uranium enrichment program must be stopped, at least in Israel’s view, to thwart a final sprint to a nuclear weapon.

headline: Britten’s ‘War Requiem’ by Gianandrea Noseda
text: BRITTEN: ‘WAR REQUIEM’

headline: Upsides and Downsides of Family Loans
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I provide a primer on creating a family loan pool. The advantages here are many. There is potentially more money available if many family members contribute. Many people can participate in setting the rules and distribution of loans, so emotion is less likely to get in the way. And it may be easier to enforce those rules if an entire clan is standing behind the loan.

headline: Adopting the Classroom as a Stage
text: EVERYONE knows that a dancer’s performance career ends with age. But what about a dance teacher’s? At the School of American Ballet, a generational shift is under way. Not only do former and current New York City Ballet members, including Arch Higgins, Darci Kistler, Katrina Killianand Jonathan Stafford, dominate its staff, but Peter Martins, the artistic director and chairman of faculty at the school, has put programs in place to pump even more new blood.

headline: Quail Is Worth a Second Thought
text: MOST people I know happily order quail in a restaurant, but rarely think of cooking them at home. I often wonder why, because nothing could be easier. If you can roast a chicken, roasting a quail is absolutely no problem, and it is ready in half the time.

headline: Sept. 30 — Oct. 6
text: ABC takes aim at lovers of the macabre on Sunday with the premiere of its drama “666 Park Avenue,” but the creepiest program on television actually comes along on Friday, when Animal Planet’s “MONSTERS INSIDE ME” returns (8 p.m. Eastern).

headline: Rookies Give Americans an Early Edge
text: MEDINAH, Ill. — Clearly the Ryder Cup is not such a steep learning curve, after all.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Le Taste of France on Pier 54, at West Street and 13th Street, celebrates French gastronomy and culture Saturday from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Chefs will prepare special dishes paired with French wines and liquors. A French flea market, live music, wine tastings, games and a French bulldog show are part of the schedule. On Saturday from 6:30 to 11 p.m., Le Soiree turns the event into a big dinner party where guests can meet chefs. Tickets for the day session are $30 in advance, available online or $40 at the door. The Sunday evening program is $149 a person.

headline: New French Budget Focuses on Slicing Deficit
text: PARIS — President François Hollande, a Socialist who was elected this year on a pro-growth platform, presented a budget on Friday that would produce the biggest cut in the public deficit in 30 years while raising the top rate for the wealthiest taxpayers to 75 percent from the current 41 percent.

headline: In Paris, Ford Fiesta Tries On the New Family Face
text: PARIS — The 2013 Ford Fiesta subcompact hatchback arrived here on Thursday bearing signs of the automaker’s unified styling strategy, with a little bit of Fusion, Focus Electric and Evos concept reflected in its face.

headline: Concern Over Fracking in the Catskills
text: September 27, 2012 - Real estate listings languish over fracking fears in Catskills.

headline: Isabel Marant: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: How to Read Like an Economics Columnist
text: Editor’s note: This is the first installment of a new series on the 6th Floor. Once a week, a magazine contributor will be quizzed about books they’re reading or have read or hope one day to finally get around to reading. First up is Adam Davidson, who writes the It’s the Economy column.

headline: (Psst: We Feel Bad About Our Arms)
text: I HAD expected to keep mum about my problem with Michelle Obama until after the election, but my frustration has gotten the better of me. I can contain it no longer.

headline: Rich Rome: The Venues
text: Dine with Colosseum views and visit a chocolate boutique on this well-funded tour.

headline: Revelations in High-End Rome
text: IT was one of those absurdly hot Roman afternoons when the sun-blasted plazas empty out and the sherbet-hued town houses, peach and lemon and lime, look ready to melt into the cobbled streets. Weary of the touristy Tridente district, I crossed the tony Piazza San Lorenzo in Lucina and slipped into a tiny new art-house cinema, savoring the air-conditioning. Within seconds I was lost in a movie that I had never heard of: “Cracker Bag,” a moody coming-of-age film from Australia. The credits rolled and I fixed my eyes on the screen, eagerly awaiting the next movie — another obscure film from another far-off land.

headline: The Beauty of Frugal Rome: Some of the Best Things Are Free
text: THE young waitress, hair tied up and black T-shirt tugged over one shoulder, was marking up the menu with her suggestions for a 10-euro tasting flight at Open Baladin, a spot in the historic center of Rome that serves over 100 Italian-made beers.

headline: Frugal Rome: The Venues
text: Wine, history and more, all for less.

headline: A Spanish SoHo Springs Up in Seville
text: A fashionable moniker is just the beginning of this reinvented neighborhood’s story.

headline: A Soft-Pedaled Escape From Paris
text: IT was easy to imagine that we’d pedaled our bicycles deep into a Pissarro painting, one of his sun-dappled, late-19th-century Impressionistic scenes of riotous summer vegetation outside Paris. Rows of soldier-straight poplars lined the narrow Canal de l’Ourcq, their leaves rustling in a breeze that tempered the warm August air. The surrounding woods smelled heavy and green, and the canal’s still, dark waters reflected the slender poles of a few fishermen on its grassy banks.

headline: Another Voice Had Come Between Us
text: ON a romantic trip through the English countryside, my husband fell in love with another woman. He met her at a car rental agency on the outskirts of London, where she arrived with the upgrade package.

headline: Revisiting Mexican Flavors in a California Surf Town
text: YOU know what doesn’t change in 20 years? The smell of eucalyptus. To some people, that soft, sweet green scent is the smell of massages and yoga classes. To me, it’s teenage angst. To me, the smell of high school, the smell of nervousness, awkwardness, acne, hormones, the smell of being a teenager is all wrapped up in the smell of eucalyptus.

headline: Waves and Wildlife in Costa Rica
text: IT’S not every day that you step out from a sunset surf session straight into a jungle habitat of howler monkeys dangling in leafy guarumo trees, cicadas conducting a symphony, and a pair of white-nosed coati — raccoon-like animals with striped tails and masks — strolling across a dirt road, sending geckos darting out of their path. It was so enchanting that I even forget to swat at the mosquitoes hovering about, getting ready to divebomb my legs.

headline: A World Traveler (57 Times) on the Andes
text: IF there was anyone who could be forgiven for being unmoved by the sight of the Andes Mountains, it would be Bertram van Munster. As executive producer of the Emmy award-winning reality show “The Amazing Race,” whose new season premieres on Sunday, he says he has circled the world 57 times.

headline: Hotel Review: TRYP Hotel in New York
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Restaurant Report: Manfreds & Vin in Copenhagen
text: The disco ball lighting up the glassed-in wine room in the back of Manfreds & Vin, a crowded wine bar in Copenhagen’s fashionably scuffed Norreborro district, doesn’t help much when it comes to making out the labels. But it does set the mood: you’re not here just to navigate a serious collection of hard-to-find natural wines from cult vintners with limited productions, you’re here to have fun.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Pools, Caves and Chocolate” (Sept. 16), I found this article to misrepresent the experience of visiting Semuc Champey, which is a standard stop on the tourist trail in Guatemala. It’s a pity that the author has to recycle tired travel-writing tropes of “discovery” to make her observations seem more exciting. I understand that one of the appeals of Semuc Champey is its remoteness, that it’s not completely overrun with other tourists, but the author seems to be indulging in some kind of fantasy in which she and her boyfriend discover an untouched Eden.

headline: Heather Thompson and Edward Burke
text: EDWARD BURKE was taking photographs of a group of young women from South Africa who were visiting the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African Art, where he is the public affairs specialist. As he framed a shot through the lens, his focus jumped to the chaperon: the tall, lithe Heather Joy Thompson.

headline: Museum Tower in Dallas Says It Is Trying to Solve Glare Problem
text: The 42-story glass-skinned condominium in Dallas known as Museum Tower, which is sending a harsh reflective glare into the nearby Nasher Sculpture Center, addressed the issue in a paid letter printed in Friday’s Dallas Morning News.

headline: Brontë’s Lovers, Facing Even More Storms
text: WITH more than a dozen film versions, Emily Brontë’s “Wuthering Heights” is something of a cultural touchstone for ill-fated love. The title alone conjures up images of a brooding Heathcliff and a delicate Cathy clinging to each other or suffering alone on the Yorkshire moors. For many fans, the characters are synonymous with Laurence Olivier and Merle Oberon in the 1939 movie. And yet, at least when it comes to screen adaptations, the novel may be the most misunderstood book of all time.

headline: Wheelies: The Hot Seat Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: The Morning Sky Hinted at Misery, and Then, It Delivered
text: It was a day that defined gloom. There was the color scheme: An ominous palette of grays and blacks when your too-early alarm clock had you hoping for a primary-color sunrise.

headline: Romney Continues to Hit Obama on Defense Cuts and Foreign Policy
text: RADNOR TOWNSHIP, Pa. — Speaking to his second military group in two days, Mitt Romney on Friday hammered President Obama over cuts to military spending, as well as of his handling of foreign policy issues.

headline: For Brooklyn’s New Arena, Day 1 Brings Hip-Hop Fans and Protests
text: After nine years as the focal point of a pitched confrontation over urban development, power and basketball, the Barclays Center in Brooklyn began its first day of life on Friday with the hip-hop superstar Jay-Z performing at a sold-out concert while activists outside the arena reminded attendees of the unfulfilled promises of the center’s developer.

headline: That’s Some Key
text: THERE are 383 aspirational keys in circulation in the Big City, each of them numbered and coded, all of them equipped to unlock any of four wrought-iron gates offering privileged access to undisturbed siestas or tranquil ambulation inside the tree-lined boundaries of Gramercy Park. At age 181, the only truly private park in Manhattan is lovelier and more ornamental than ever; yes, the colorful Calder sculpture swaying blithely in the breeze inside the fence is “Janey Waney,” on indefinite loan from the Calder Foundation.

headline: Are Americans Better Off?
text: September 28, 2012 — James B. Stewart on which Americans are better off now than four years ago.

headline: Some Analysts Start to Like RIM
text: Investors, perhaps pleased by any bit of good news from Research in Motion, pushed up the beleaguered BlackBerry maker’s share price on Friday almost 7 percent after a quarterly financial report that, while loss ridden, was not as bad as feared.

headline: 'Lawrence,' Before and After Restoration
text: A clip from “Lawrence of Arabia,” showing the look of the scene before the film’s digital restoration and after.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Christian Dior
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Maison Martin Margiela: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: What Sands of Time Did Not Erase
text: NO studio today would make a film like “Lawrence of Arabia” — 227 minutes long, featuring a cast of hundreds riding camels through the desert, shot on location (there were no computer graphics in 1962). Yet Sony Pictures’ new 50th-anniversary restoration — playing at the New York Film Festival on Sunday and in more than 600 theaters nationwide starting Thursday — seems fresh and modern, in its political themes and its stunning visual clarity.

headline: The Party Politics of the Father-Daughter Dance
text: When a Rhode Island P.T.O. set out to plan a “Me and My Guy” dance, as well as a mother-son baseball game, it was unaware that the state and district had concluded that laws prohibiting sex discrimination in “any and all other school functions and activities” meant no father-daughter or mother-son events. One single mother complained, the A.C.L.U. responded, and the school district immediately apologized — the dance took place as scheduled with all genders of parents and children welcome to attend. But the ban itself has become, as Jess Bidgood reported for The Times, a “fiercely debated political flashpoint” with divisions falling along what have become predictable partisan lines.

headline: Project Basement: Receiver Connectors Rule
text: Shopping for a receiver used to be a pretty simple matter. You listened to those in your price range and bought the one that sounded best.

headline: ‘Honey Boo Boo’ Has the Ratings, if Not the Critics
text: When TLC’s reality series “Here Comes Honey Boo Boo” made its debut in August, it was met with such derision by some television critics, that it seemed like the title should be changed to “Look Out! Here Comes Honey Boo Boo.”

headline: Artist’s Foundation Seeks Return of ‘Sphere’ to World Trade Center Site
text: “The chorus voicing a pledge for the return of the ‘Sphere’ to its original place at the W.T.C. has reached as far as Landshut, Lower Bavaria, Germany,” the letter begins. That’s a consequential destination because it is the home of Fritz Koenig, the sculptor of the World Trade Center “Sphere,” and of his museum and foundation.

headline: Spain Needs $76 Billion to Recapitalize Its Banks, Audit Finds
text: The independent banking assessment was well below the potential 100 billion euros, or $128.6 billion, in bailout money Spain negotiated with the euro zone in June.

headline: A ‘Downton Abbey’ Prequel in the Works
text: How did the distinguished Earl of Grantham, Robert Crawley, hook up with the American Countess Cora? Did he marry for love or her inheritance?

headline: Giving With an Eye on the Impact
text: Paul Sullivan’s Wealth Matters column this week discusses philanthropists who not only want their donations to do good, they are looking for a way to measure the impact of their giving.

headline: Norton To Publish Philip Roth Biography
text: W.W. Norton & Company will publish the previously announced authorized biography of Philip Roth, the press announced on Thursday.

headline: Beyond the 6-Speed: More Ratios for Automatic Transmissions
text: Detroit

headline: Till Death, or 20 Years, Do Us Part
text: IT makes little sense to explore a new era of family values based around Hollywood couplings. Or, worse yet, around mere rumors of the way movie stars conduct their marital affairs.

headline: Beets Are Back, With Greens
text: The beet has always been a celebrated treat on Well. We’ve put them in everything from smoothies and lasagna to birthday cake and risotto.

headline: U.S. Move to Give Egypt $450 Million in Aid Meets Resistance
text: The Obama administration notified Congress on Friday that it would provide Egypt’s new government an emergency cash infusion of $450 million, but the aid immediately encountered resistance from a prominent lawmaker wary of foreign aid and Egypt’s new course under the leadership of the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Versatile Housing, in Both Kind and Cost
text: AS it slices east to west through Port Jefferson Station, the thoroughfare called Nesconset Highway, or Route 347, is a dividing line in more than just a physical sense. According to the Census Bureau, the southern portion of town actually has a different name: Terryville.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $17.5 Million
text: Apparently bulletproof when it comes to investing in antique West Village real estate in need of renovation, Kiefer Sutherland, a k a the infamous Jack Bauer of “24” and presently starring in “Touch” on Fox television, has sold his five-story brick town house at 763 Greenwich Street for $17.5 million, in the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: A Little Bit of Hepburn
text: Star Jones, 50, has appeared on television the last two decades. She is currently a panel member on “Today’s Professionals,” a weekly segment of “Today” on NBC, with Donny Deutsch and Dr. Nancy Snyderman. A native of Badin, N.C., Ms. Jones, a former prosecutor, lives in Manhattan.

headline: Charging Ahead on an Electric Highway
text: Los Angeles

headline: One Big Step for Tesla, One Giant Leap for E.V.’s
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: A Quieter Side of Swizz Beatz
text: ON a muggy August morning, the hip-hop producer known as Swizz Beatz stepped from the SoHo apartment he shares with Alicia Keys, and climbed into an S.U.V. with his 5-year-old son. In the front seat was his uncle and bodyguard, a man who spent two decades in prison and has the biceps to prove it.

headline: What’s Going On With My Bank?
text: Wednesday was kind of a busy day, but late in the afternoon I tried to log in to my bank’s Web site to see what checks had posted (I bank with PNC). I couldn’t get in. Web sites don’t load now and then, and I didn’t give it much thought.

headline: Carmakers Try to Figure Out the New Generation
text: PARIS — The digital generation is apathetic about cars. And that’s a problem for automakers.

headline: Paper or Plastic? Some Communities Say Neither
text: Bill Hoffman, owner of Aptos Jewelers in Aptos, Calif., sells bracelets, rings and pendants for thousands of dollars each. He balks at the notion of charging customers an extra 10 cents for a shopping bag, but Mr. Hoffman has no choice. It is the law.

headline: That Loaded Gun in My Carry-On? Oh, I Forgot
text: The list of potentially lethal weapons was certainly eye-opening: 47 guns (38 of them loaded, including six with rounds in their chambers), three inert hand grenades, supplies of black powder, hunting knives, timing fuses and a sword.

headline: Going the Distance
text: No single new model can overhaul the auto industry, but the Model S, along with its charging network for long-distance travel, suggests that Tesla is playing for keeps.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Roland Mouret
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: As Apple’s Maps Stumbles, AOL’s MapQuest Flourishes
text: As Apple struggles to improve its Maps application, which has been irritating and amusing users with its shortcomings and inaccuracies, the company is urging its users to seek transit and traveling directions elsewhere.

headline: Mets Post Third Consecutive Decline in Attendance
text: During their meltdown after the All-Star Game, the Mets tried everything to get fans to go to Citi Field: T-shirts on Tuesdays, half-price tickets for those who brought Pepsi cans and free tickets for children.

headline: A Paris Fashion Week Party at Les Deux Magots
text: Inside the velvet ropes, there were fashion insiders and celebrities including Gareth Pugh, Léa Seydoux and Jean Reno.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 28
text: A view of the day in sports, as the Ryder Cup began.

headline: Post-Runway, at the Brasserie
text: PARIS

headline: A Big Settlement, Flexible Ethics and Special Section on the Law
text: Bank of America agreed to a $2.43 billion settlement. | A British trade group gave up its Libor power. | Andrew Ross Sorkin questioned the flexible ethics of bankers’ new lobbyist. | A special section explored the intense competitive pressures confronting law firms.

headline: Hot-Button Issue: The ‘Hot’ Factor
text: JOHN F. KENNEDY was a striking man — by most accounts, the best-looking person ever to occupy the White House — but he lived in an age before Facebook, Tumblr, YouTube, chat groups and discussion threads made that a subject to debate with as much fervor as health care reform and offshore tax havens. Not so this year’s presidential candidates.

headline: In Florida, Biden Attacks Romney on Social Security and Medicare
text: Campaigning in Florida, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. widened his attack against Mitt Romney on Friday to accuse him of favoring higher taxes on Social Security benefits to pay for tax cuts for the rich.

headline: California Issues 10,000th Rebate for Zero-Emissions Incentive Program
text: Start undressing California’s Clean Vehicle Rebate Project, a program intended to spur the sales and leases of zero-emission vehicles, and front-page topics come into view — reduction of greenhouse gases and job creation chief among them. So when the program recorded its 10,000th rebate earlier this month, it merited some pomp.

headline: West Virginia Displays Art of Quarterbacking
text: From across the room, the teacher heard 3-year-old Geno Smith read a children’s book aloud.

headline: What’s an Allowance For?
text: R. wrote me that she spent the summer feeling like “a constant A.T.M. machine” for her 14-year-old. If a young teenager wants to hang out at the mall, see a movie, or get a smoothie,  inevitably there’s cash involved. Fourteen, she notes, is too young to get a “real job” but not too young to spend what’s adding up to real money.

headline: For Flutist in West Bank, a Rare Chance
text: A LITTLE more than three years ago she was a quiet, serious-minded 16-year-old flutist in the West Bank with posters of the Berlin Philharmonic flute soloist Emmanuel Pahud on her bedroom wall. Travel restrictions made it a struggle to go for lessons in Jerusalem. Finding space to practice in an apartment crowded with four siblings was difficult. Despite her hard work, her prospects seemed limited.

headline: Come Hither, City Quail
text: For this week’s City Kitchen column, I needed a few quail. It turned out that hunting them down in the urban jungle was less complicated than I imagined. Indeed, the first butcher I called had just received a delivery of fresh quail. Out of curiosity, I investigated a handful of other local options.

headline: Friday Night Music: Transatlantic Sessions (Sarah Jarosz)
text: Seems appropriate given my current location:

headline: The Image as Obsession, No Matter the Method
text: PARIS

headline: Filmmaker Sets Focus Very Close to Home
text: UNDERSTANDING one’s parents might be as difficult as fathoming the cosmos, but it’s something most of us try to do, in one way or another. Doing this through the lens of a camera for a documentary film, as a number of children of famous parents have in works like “My Architect,” by the son of Louis Kahn; “William Kunstler: Disturbing the Universe,” by the radical lawyer’s two daughters; and “The Man Nobody Knew: In Search of My Father, CIA Spymaster William Colby,” by Carl Colby, can be an effective, if grandiose method. It allows the filmmaker to use the tried-and-true tools of the profession while also making a very public statement.

headline: Tall in the Saddle in 2 Eras at Once
text: LOUISE BROOKS is barely recognizable in “Overland Stage Raiders,” the 1938 Republic western that would prove to be her last film: the magnetizing star who went to Germany to make “Pandora’s Box” and “Diary of a Lost Girl” (both released in 1929) has let her daringly close-cropped hair grow out into conventional waves, her nose and chin seem sharper, and the fire in her eyes has dimmed. But there she is, providing the perfunctory love interest in a low-budget feature meant for Saturday morning children’s matinees, playing against a good-looking but gawky young man who a few years later would become one of the biggest stars in the business, John Wayne.

headline: Obama Orders Chinese Company to End Investment at Sites Near Drone Base
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, citing national security risks, ordered a Chinese company on Friday to divest its interest in four wind farm projects near a Navy base in northern Oregon where training missions for drone aircraft are conducted.

headline: As It Followed a Car Chase, Fox News Showed a Suicide
text: 6:16 p.m. | Updated The Fox News Channel, in the course of following a car chase live in Arizona, on Friday broadcast the suicide of the man who was being pursued by the authorities.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 28
text: Subjects include an excursion in the Adirondacks with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s visit to New York and a long-awaited subway transfer station in Manhattan.

headline: Roasting Peppers
text: Roasting your own peppers are so much better than what you can buy in a store. Melissa Clark shows how.

headline: Iran Ridicules Netanyahu’s Bomb Theatrics, and Calls on Israel to Renounce Nukes
text: Iran said Friday that Israel’s latest warnings at the United Nations of an impending Iranian atomic weapons threat were baseless theatrics, and called on Israel to disband its own unacknowledged nuclear weapons arsenal and sign the Non-Proliferation Treaty just as Iran had done 44 years ago.

headline: Danger Lurks Between Peppers Sweet and Hot
text: THERE are sweet peppers; there are hot peppers; and then there are those peppers that fall somewhere in between. They are the Russian roulette of peppers, the kinds that you can never be quite sure about until you take a bite.

headline: Inside the Mind of Worry
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Notes for a New Life
text: With help from friends at home and abroad, a young Palestinian flutist has found a way to escape the walls around her West Bank village.

headline: Q & A
text: When a Trust Owns Co-Op Shares

headline: Ex-SAC Analyst Pleads Guilty in Insider Trading Conspiracy
text: 8:31 p.m. | Updated

headline: ‘Peter and the Starcatcher’ To Close in January
text: After flying from downtown to Broadway and winning five Tony awards, “Peter and the Starcatcher” will close, the producers announced on Friday.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Isabel Marant
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Romney Speaks With Netanyahu
text: BEDFORD, Mass. — Moments after finishing a phone call with  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, Mitt Romney told reporters on his private campaign plane Friday that he did not believe military action against Iran would be necessary, but added that he would not “take that option off the table.”

headline: Rose Hartman’s Photographs
text: Surely most people are familiar with the face of Linda Evangelista. But do you remember how that face looked in 1992, when the supermodel, shown below, was in her 20s?

headline: Legends, Then and Now
text: “Incomparable: Women of Style.” By Rose Hartman. With texts by Anthony Haden-Guest, Rose Hartman and Alistair O’Neill. 163 pp., 132 color illustrations. ACC Editions. $49.50.

headline: Wheels Calendar for Sept. 28-30
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: Returning to Cozy Tradition For a Season’s 2nd Welcome
text: When is an opening night not an opening night? Perhaps when it is the second of two.

headline: Barclays Center: An Arena With Many Faces
text: Diagrams of the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, the first new large indoor arena for sports and entertainment built in New York City since 1968.

headline: Video: Last Call for Peppers
text: It’s the end of fresh-pepper season, so if you haven’t had your fill of gorgeous sweet and hot peppers this summer, the time is now. In this week’s video, I show two techniques for roasting and peeling them — both in the broiler and on an open flame on the stovetop. You could also use your grill if the weather is clear in your backyard.

headline: Tim Cook’s Apology Is an Important Step Forward
text: On Friday morning, Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, apologized for releasing the flawed Maps app on iOS 6. I don’t mean a flimsy P.R.-speak apology — I mean a heartfelt one that seems fully cooked.

headline: Advertising Week Begins Monday, Focusing on Technology and Returning Veterans
text: It has been said many times that the most popular words in the advertising business are “new and improved.” But the phrase offers a way to describe changes in store when the ninth annual Advertising Week takes place in New York next week.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Chic in Review | Raf Simons’s New Look
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Baton Rouge Newspaper Sees an Opportunity in New Orleans
text: It’s a Hail Mary pass for New Orleans newspaper lovers dreading the day that the city no longer has a daily paper. Starting on Monday, the first day that The Times-Picayune no longer prints every day, The Advocate from Baton Rouge will offer home delivery of a New Orleans edition.

headline: At Summit Series in Moscow, Canadians Ask, “Where’s the Beef?”
text: In Canada, all that matters is this: we won.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Nepal, West Bank, Spain and Israel.

headline: Even Health Dept. Isn’t Safe From Bedbugs
text: A single bedbug led to fumigation of one floor of the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene’s headquarters in Long Island City, Queens, on Friday.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A three-bedroom lodge in Hopewell, N.J., and a four-bedroom house in Bellmore, N.Y.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Manhattan Valley co-op, a Financial District condo and a Wallabout house.

headline: The ‘Illegal’ Trap
text: A vigorous discussion is taking place online about the word “illegal” as an adjective for certain immigrants. An immigrant activist named Jose Antonio Vargas, a former reporter, is urging news organizations like The New York Times to stop using it. He says the word is inaccurate, improper and demeaning.

headline: Catholic Leader Is Turned Away at Exhibit He Deemed Offensive
text: On Thursday night, William Donohue, the president of the Catholic League, held a news conference outside an art gallery in Midtown Manhattan to denounce one of the works of art on display there: a 1987 photograph of a crucifix immersed in a jar of urine. But, when Mr. Donohue tried to enter the exhibition, the gallery would not allow him in, he said in a blog post on Friday.

headline: Judge Strikes Down a Dodd-Frank Trading Rule
text: Wall Street posted another victory in the battle over regulation on Friday after a federal judge struck down a central piece of the Obama administration’s financial overhaul.

headline: Artists’ Books and Oil Pumps
text: This weekend the seventh annual NY Art Book Fair takes place at MoMA P.S. 1 in Queens. One of the exhibitors is ABC Artists’ Books Cooperative. And one of its featured projects is ABCED, a 33-volume series of artist books created in celebration of the artist Ed Ruscha’s 75th birthday this December. In the 1960s, Ruscha published a series of artist books — collections of his own photographs sold in small editions — that influenced generations of artists, including Mishka Henner, one of the cooperative’s 25 members.

headline: 2012 Paris Motor Show
text: With auto sales bottoming out in Europe, the mood during press previews for the biennial Paris salon reflected a hope that 2013 might mark the beginning of a slow recovery. Here is a look at some of the models that were shown.

headline: Hybrid Strategy: Divide and Conquer
text: BOTH Honda and Toyota are far more committed to the hybrid car than to the battery electric vehicle, a fact that Toyota made clear this month when it scaled back its Scion iQ electric car project. And Honda is so enthusiastic about hybrids that, as its chief executive, Takanobu Ito, outlined in a recent speech, it will have three separate systems with up to three electric motors.

headline: At Dior, Raf Simons Asserts His Authority
text: Is it fair to ask, in the blur of fashion shows, if something can be new?

headline: How to Help Iran Build a Bomb
text: ADVOCATES of airstrikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities have long held that the attacks would delay an atom bomb for years and perhaps even buy Israel enough time to topple the Iranian government. In public statements, the Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, has said that an attack would leave Iran’s nuclear program reeling, if not destroyed. The blow, he declared recently, would set back the Iranian effort “for a long time.”

headline: Lumière | Paris à la Hollywood
text: Not all that we see on-screen of Paris is Paris.

headline: Chloé Gets a Salute in Paris
text: “Chloé Attitudes” is the name of a new exhibition that opened in Paris at the Palais de Tokyo with a cocktail party Friday night during Fashion Week, though there was little attitude in the way you might associate with the fashionista crowd.

headline: The Roman Who Loved the Greeks
text: Being the sex slave of Rome’s gay emperor has its drawbacks.

headline: Hold the Crepes, Bring On the Eggplant
text: WHEN Eddie Ulas Konca and Cevail Sarac first planned to start a restaurant together, they thought it would be a waterfront seafood spot in Huntington. Circumstances changed, and when they opened their restaurant, Mermaid, last year, it was in Hewlett, and nowhere near the water. The name was less apt, but they kept it anyway because they liked it.

headline: A Romantic Who’s Inspired by Streisand
text: Although the singer Ann Hampton Callaway doesn’t sound at all like Barbra Streisand, to whom she paid fervent tribute on Wednesday evening in her new show, “The Streisand Songbook,” at 54 Below, the two share a fundamental, unshakable romanticism. Both favor overarching, dramatic love songs, and both have the vocal equipment to infuse them with fairy tale magic.

headline: In Bridge, Game of Chicago at Regency Whist Club
text: Alan Greenberg, known as Ace, who celebrated his 85th birthday this month, was the chief executive of Bear Stearns for many years. Although he still has board positions with JPMorgan Chase and Viacom, he has more time for bridge now than when he was with Bear Stearns.

headline: 150 Films, and Parking Spaces, Too
text: KAREN ARIKIAN, executive director of the Hamptons International Film Festival, referred to the event as “small” several times in a recent phone conversation. And in comparison to annual festivals in Cannes, Berlin and some other cities, the one on Long Island does seem rather diminutive.

headline: Week in Pictures for Sept. 28
text: Subjects of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include an excursion in the Adirondacks with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s visit to New York.

headline: This Sunday: A Video Introduction to the Inspiration Issue
text: In the magazine’s Inspiration Issue, we tell you about the best books, movies, TV shows, music and art on the horizon, and the stories that led to their creation. Michael Chabon writes about how the O.J. Simpson verdict inspired “Telegraph Avenue,” Alicia Keys describes how she wrote the song “Girl on Fire,” Junot Díaz shares the artifacts that help him write and much more.

headline: California’s Budget
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Crossing the Street
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Vivid Glimpse of a Lost America
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.

headline: In New York, the Ballet and Opera Are Stuffy No More
text: At a time when even the most august cultural institutions are being challenged by an ailing economy, a program or guest list larded with the names of celebrity designers, runway models and athletes can be a powerful draw.

headline: Why the Beaver Should Thank the Wolf
text: San Francisco

headline: Forging Ahead at the Paris Auto Show
text: Despite a faltering economy, big automakers showcase glistening new auto lines in France. Reporter Jerry Garrett talks to auto executives to find out how new offerings will survive the slump.

headline: Going Hollywood
text: WHEN Olivia Palermo sauntered down the red carpet at Lincoln Center a week ago, she seized the occasion, the gala opening of the New York City Ballet, as a glittering photo op, a chance to shine in her multitiered Dior gown — and, oh, incidentally, to offer homage to Valentino Garavani, who stepped out of official retirement to create the costumes.

headline: Should U.S. Stay Out of Mideast Affairs?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The V.A.’s Responsibility to Homeless Veterans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Old Favorite Returns, Freshness Still In Its Step
text: Less than half of the quadruple bill that opens this year’s Fall for Dance season is much good — and yet, like so many Fall for Dance programs over the years, it’s refreshing. This intensely popular annual festival at City Center presents several works by different artists on each program; this year’s, for the first time, are spread over 12 evenings in three weeks. The emphasis is always on the modern and the unfamiliar; even when you decide you don’t care for some offerings, you’re usually still taken somewhere new. (Those of you who need your dance fixes from the “Don Quixote” pas de deux, go elsewhere.)

headline: Reviewing the Tesla Model S
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Bradley Berman reviews the 2012 Tesla Model S in a more thorough manner than any other journalist has yet.

headline: Apple’s Plans for Internet Radio Run Up Against Big Music Publisher
text: The rough news for Apple lately is not just about its much-derided new maps program.

headline: Talent Shows
text: IT was a thoroughly modern economic game, this three-way tiff between N.F.L. owners, players and referees. The N.F.L.’s unionized officials asked for significant wage and pension changes from America’s leading sporting league. In response, the N.F.L. locked out the unionized refs and brought in replacements. The replacement refs struggled. In turn, players spoke out against the replacement refs — especially after an egregious error that ended a marquee game between Green Bay and Seattle. Players, fans and members of the media demanded that the N.F.L. capitulate and pay whatever it took to bring back the regular refs. Finally, a deal was done.

headline: A Diner Redefines Itself
text: THESE days, calling City Limits a diner may be a misnomer. After a four-month renovation, it reopened in August, with the traditional diner counter removed and a new earth-tone color scheme.

headline: The Tip of Putin’s Wedge Between Urban and Rural
text: YEKATERINBURG, Russia

headline: A Look at Computer History
text: The Computer History Museum in Mountain View, Calif., displays more than 1,000 technological artifacts.

headline: At Paris Motor Show, the Home Team Continues to Flout Styling Norms
text: PARIS — The French have historically rebelled against the conventions of automobile design, and for that we have cars like the Citroën 2CV and Renault Dauphine to admire and, at times, revile.

headline: Dazzled by a Cute Picture, More Nannies Fall for Swindle
text: Stephanie Canales, 19, said she had only one hesitation about having her name used in this article. “Please,” she said, “don’t make me look like a moron.”

headline: Oklahoma’s Deal With Fox Sports Worth Nearly $60 Million Over 10 Years
