text: Earlier this month, the University of Oklahoma announced a deal with Fox Sports that broadened the availability of its sports within the state and spread them throughout Texas, Arkansas and Louisiana. A national component was also added.

headline: Waiting for Teixeira
text: TORONTO — It has been a month since Mark Teixeira injured his left calf during a game against the Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium. Going into Friday’s game against the Jays at the Rogers Centre, the Yankees had lost two and a half games off their lead in the American League East during that time.

headline: Nash Hurt in Switzerland
text: 8:09 a.m. Saturday | Update The Rangers reported Friday night that Nash’s injury was related to his shoulder, not his head.

headline: Remembering the Dream Team’s Remarkable Supporting Cast
text: This has been quite the commemorative 20th anniversary year for the 1992 Dream Team, often referred to as the first and only collection of N.B.A. stars worthy of the signature. There was a documentary film shown on NBA TV. There was Jack McCallum’s excellent best-seller — “Dream Team” — that needed no subtitle but tacked on the rather verbose “How Michael, Magic, Larry, Charles, and the Greatest Team of All Time Conquered the World and Changed the Game of Basketball Forever.”

headline: N.H.L. Negotiations Stick With Side Issues
text: League and union negotiators in the N.H.L. lockout, meeting for their first formal bargaining session since Sept. 12, reported modest progress on side issues Friday.

headline: In His Sculptures, Vitality; In His Portraits, Precision
text: Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Beach or No Beach, Bridgewater Is Thriving in Louisville
text: When asked to identify the key to success for the Louisville sophomore quarterback Teddy Bridgewater, most observers mention his poise, his athleticism, his detailed knowledge of the Cardinals’ offense. Yet it is possible that the secret behind Bridgewater’s excellent play, which has landed him on some early Heisman Trophy watch lists, can be found in his socks.

headline: 2 Plead Guilty as Kingpins in Drug Gang
text: Days before the start of a trial that had been expected to last three months, eight members of a large PCP drug ring that operated in Harlem pleaded guilty on Thursday evening to charges that will send some of them to prison for decades.

headline: A Dickens Classic for the Ages
text: Snatches of songs punctuate the action in “Charles Dickens’s Oliver Twist,” but this is not a predominantly upbeat show like Lionel Bart’s musical “Oliver!” The poverty, social hypocrisy and violence that rule Oliver’s world here are relieved only intermittently by streaks of dark humor and, of course, by the boy’s miraculous deliverance.

headline: In Film and Union’s Ads, Dueling Views of Teachers
text: Teachers’ unions have come under fire from politicians like Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago and Mitt Romney in recent months. But rarely has opposition to teachers’ unions worn a face as sympathetic as that of Maggie Gyllenhaal, the Academy Award-nominated actress who plays a crusading parent confronting a bullying, bureaucratic union in a new movie, “Won’t Back Down.”

headline: 2 Democrats, 2 Incumbents and One Tough House Race
text: LOS ANGELES — Howard Berman, the ranking Democrat on the House Foreign Relations Committee, has made more than 150 trips abroad during his three decades in Washington.

headline: Washington Democrats Make a Move on Maine
text: Washington Democrats, after months of sitting on the sidelines, moved into the Maine Senate race on Friday with a sizable advertising buy to attack the Republican seeking to succeed Senator Olympia J. Snowe, the moderate Republican who is retiring at year’s end.

headline: Australians Surge in Quest for New Class of Computer
text: Competing teams of Australian scientists have given that country a significant lead in an increasingly intense international competition to build a working quantum computer.

headline: For Fat Sandwiches, an Uncertain Future
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

headline: Cooperation Is Cited as Lobbyist in Bribery Case Is Sentenced to 3 Months
text: Richard J. Lipsky, the prominent New York lobbyist who pleaded guilty in a political corruption case and had been secretly assisting federal investigators, was sentenced to three months in prison on Friday by a judge who said he deserved “substantial credit for his cooperation.”

headline: Home Protection
text: A look at three techniques that Russell Martin of the Yankees and other Major League catchers use on plays at the plate.

headline: A Father to Baseball
text: It is the end of the regular season, and time for goodbyes. I remember walking off the field in 2002, after we played our last game. One of my Phillies teammates said it was “a sad time” because you will never play with this same group again. So we gave out big hugs, knowing this nuclear family would forever be dispersed.

headline: Overhaul Special Education for Preschool
text: New York State clearly needs to strengthen oversight of the fraud-riddled program that spends $2 billion a year on special education services for preschool children with learning or other disabilities. The State Education Department got off to a good start this month when it issued a preliminary reform proposal.

headline: For Some U.S. Players, Waiting Pays Off
text: MEDINAH, Ill. — They were plenty rested after sitting out the morning matches, and when their turn finally came to show what they could do, Bubba Watson, Webb Simpson, Matt Kuchar and Dustin Johnson broke fast out of the gate at Medinah Country Club.

headline: Lager, I.P.A. or Pilsner, It’s Beer of the Local Variety
text: MENTION craft beer and places like California, Colorado and Oregon, where start-up breweries have thrived for decades, come to mind; not so Connecticut, where small-batch brewing has lagged behind. But with four new breweries — and two more preparing to release beers by year’s end — the way we think about the state’s locally made beer is finally poised to change.

headline: The Economy and the Blame
text: As Mitt Romney sees it, this week’s economic data ought to be bad news for President Obama. The economy slowed to a crawl in the second quarter and the current quarter looks like more of the same. A nascent housing recovery was offset by setbacks in manufacturing. A drop in military spending previewed the pain that is to come if lawmakers don’t find a way to avert even deeper automatic cuts that Republican lawmakers insisted on for 2013.

headline: Seattle’s Tall Secondary Is Batting Away Conventional Wisdom
text: RENTON, Wash. — The youngest, tallest, most underappreciated secondary in professional football consists of two players chosen in the draft’s fifth round, another plucked from the Canadian Football League and another whose diminutive stature almost led to the worst kind of group nickname: Three and a Half Men.

headline: An Unfinished Campaign Against Polio
text: Leaders of the global fight to eradicate polio vowed at the United Nations on Thursday to step up their efforts to eliminate the virus from the three countries where the disease still has a foothold — Afghanistan, Pakistan and Nigeria. The challenge is that those countries are troubled by political unrest, violence and social customs that can interfere with the delivery of vaccines to the children and adults who need protection.

headline: Thoroughbred Survival at the Racetrack
text: An alarming rise in thoroughbred fatalities last winter at Aqueduct Racetrack is prompting a much-needed overhaul of inept, pro-industry regulation of a sport that increasingly puts horses’ lives at risk in the pursuit of profit. A report by a panel of experts said the lives of 11 of 21 horses that died at the track might have been saved if the state had had proper safeguards against overmedicated and substandard horses’ running for purses inflated by profits from the new adjacent casino at Aqueduct.

headline: Breaking Their Fast With a Downtown Twist
text: Kutsher’s Tribeca on Franklin Street was designed for a downtown crowd that still craves Jewish home cooking: it bills itself as a modern Jewish bistro, the hip offspring of the original Kutsher’s Country Club resort in the Catskills. For this year’s High Holy Days, it offered special meals, including a Yom Kippur break-fast menu of smoked fish and other favorites alongside nontraditional touches like duck schmaltz French fries. On Wednesday, families small and large and groups of friends filled the plush booths and tables set between blond-wood panels and glowing lights.

headline: The College Rankings Racket
text: The U.S. News & World Report’s annual college rankings came out earlier this month and — knock me over with a feather! — Harvard and Princeton were tied for first.

headline: One Year Later, Roles Reverse as Red Sox Try to Spoil Orioles’ Playoff Plans
text: BALTIMORE — A year ago Friday, on the final day of the 2011 regular season, the Boston Red Sox played here needing to win to keep their playoff hopes alive. The Orioles, who had lost 93 games, refused to let that happen.

headline: Shifting Reports on Libya Killings May Cost Obama
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s shifting accounts of the fatal attack on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, have left President Obama suddenly exposed on national security and foreign policy, a field where he had enjoyed a seemingly unassailable advantage over Mitt Romney in the presidential race.

headline: Hailing Wheelchair-Accessible Cabs
text: APP WOW Taxi

headline: Cambodia Is Seeking 2nd Statue
text: The Cambodian government has asked the United States to help it recover a 10th-century Khmer sandstone statue from the Norton Simon Museum in California. It says the work was looted from a Cambodian temple complex during the country’s political upheavals in the 1970s.

headline: A Career in Obstetrics, With On-the-Job Training
text: It’s the fall TV season, which means that babies are thick in the air, since childbirth scenes are a sure way to draw “aws” and “ews” from jaded viewers. Babies arrived this week on the premiere of the Fox series “The Mindy Project,” about a young obstetrician, and on the wretched TLC reality show “Here Comes Honey Boo Boo.” Another birth is surely coming on the NBC series “The New Normal,” about a male couple and their mother-for-hire, and the first lady appears to be pregnant on ABC’s “Scandal.”

headline: Hard Times, With Regret But Without Apology
text: WEST ORANGE, N.J. — Bettye LaVette makes no apologies for her life. Sitting cross-legged on an Art Deco chair in her living room here, sipping wine, she was animated and gritty as she talked about the decades she spent singing in clubs and cursing her “buzzard luck,” while her contemporaries, like Aretha Franklin and Diana Ross, became superstars.

headline: Sept. 28: A Circular Relationship Between Political and Economic Views
text: President Obama’s probability of winning the Electoral College fell slightly in Friday’s FiveThirtyEight forecast, from 83.9 percent to 82.7 percent on Thursday.

headline: As Madoff Money Is Distributed, Mets Wonder What Might Have Been
text: Under better circumstances, the owners of the Mets would have an extra $67.3 million in their bank accounts today, money that could help their losing team after another miserable season.

headline: Lavish Home, Corner of Fire and Brimstone
text: How powerful is the Devil? Powerful enough, apparently, to get a not particularly necessary series like “666 Park Avenue” onto network television.

headline: Museum Gathers Piano, Paintings and Video in a Blended Work
text: Some artistic engagements seem inevitable; others, highly unlikely. A brief, intriguing recital presented on Thursday evening by Mikhail Rudy, a Russian pianist born in Uzbekistan and based in France since the 1970s, managed to be both at once.

headline: Forces of Nature: Lightning, Water, Music and Movement
text: A lighthouse guides a ship to safety. A lightning rod diverts a bolt from a structure by providing a direct path to the ground. Still, the opening images of “Lighthouse/Lightning Rod,” a new work by the choreographer Garth Fagan, with loose, exuberant music by the jazz composer and trumpeter Wynton Marsalis, hint at danger as much as at security.

headline: Confirming the Beats Of a Throbbing Pulse
text: George Balanchine and Igor Stravinsky gave ballet a new pulse. When the curtain rises on “Stravinsky Violin Concerto,” it’s as if the five stationary dancers — four men and one woman — were taking a moment to match their heartbeats to the music. The ballerina takes the first step, a bent-knee kick to the side, and in that instant the music and the dance become one.

headline: Russian Parliament Bars Opposition Lawmaker From Speaking
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s Parliament voted Friday to bar a prominent opposition lawmaker, Ilya V. Ponomarev, from speaking on the floor for one month after he called members of the majority party “swindlers and thieves.”

headline: A Little Madhattery in Manhattan, Inspired by Strayhorn
text: The pianist Gerald Clayton began his first set at Jazz Standard on Thursday night with a piece called “Future Reflection,” assigning its annunciatory melody to a front line of trumpet and two saxophones.

headline: Colombia Absolves Kidnapping Victim Accused of Misdeeds
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Bringing to a close a case that stunned Colombia and focused attention on a brutal episode in the country’s long-running guerrilla war, Colombian authorities this week absolved a former state legislator just months after accusing him of helping to arrange his own kidnapping by rebels.

headline: A Bowling Hustler With a Big Left Hook
text: FIVE frames into the match, Rocky Salemmo was taking a beating.

headline: Romney, Appealing to Wider Audience, Recalibrates Message
text: The language Mitt Romney used this week to describe his plan to cut income tax rates was somewhat unusual, at least by the standards of recent Republican presidential campaigns.

headline: 2 Who Rode Casino Bus Tell of Crash
text: The bus swerved. It shook. It veered from one side of the road to the other.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Rethinking Patents, and Too Much Money
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Damages, but No Profits, Awarded for a Song
text: WHEN Peggy Harley of Queens claimed in a lawsuit that a song she had written was recorded without her permission by another singer who was later nominated for a Grammy Award, she demanded millions of dollars in damages and a share of any profits.

headline: Judge Approves New Entrance Exam for City Firefighters
text: A federal judge approved a new entrance exam for New York City firefighters on Friday, ending a long stalemate over hiring practices and increasing the likelihood that the department will hire thousands of minority applicants.

headline: Apple Apologizes for Misstep on Maps
text: IPhone users grew more annoyed all week. When they used Apple’s new mobile maps, they found nonsensical routes and misplaced landmarks. Bloggers and talk-show hosts mocked the sometimes bizarre errors.

headline: More Major-League Players With New York Roots
text: The Fans Have Spoken

headline: Corrections: September 29, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: An Arm and a Leg and Then Some
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — It occurred to me after doing this puzzle that I should probably hand back my GIRLIE GIRL card. Apparently I’m not using it properly, having not been a fan of Barbie dolls as a child.

headline: Braves Honor Jones, as Eyes Turn to Mets’ Wright
text: ATLANTA — It only made sense that on the night Chipper Jones was honored by the Atlanta Braves for his exceptional career, it was the Mets who got a front-row seat for the ceremony. After all, Jones helped build his Hall of Fame resume by demolishing their pitching. He has a lifetime .311 batting average against the Mets, with 49 homers and 159 runs batted in in 242 games.

headline: At Annual U.N. General Assembly, a Stage for All the World
text: UNITED NATIONS — The annual United Nations General Assembly debate, which comes to a close on Monday with a final flurry of speeches, might be called a convention of knotty causes, some of them distinct long shots.

headline: Federal Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Against Ex-Gov. Spitzer
text: A federal judge on Friday dismissed a libel lawsuit against former Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the online magazine Slate for a column Mr. Spitzer wrote in 2010 about an insurance bid-rigging scandal.

headline: Finding Joys Close to the Nest
text: Dogs and sons and work and a city that loves to be loved — are there really enough hours in a Sunday for more than that? For the documentary filmmaker Ric Burns, 57, whose “Death and the Civil War” had its premiere on public television this month, Monday often arrives before he has begun to exhaust that quartet. Mr. Burns, best known for his 1999 series “New York: A Documentary Film,” hews mainly to the Columbia University neighborhood where he has lived since 1976 — these days with his wife and collaborator, Bonnie Lafave; their two sons, Adam, 12, and Simon, 14; and their three dogs, the newest a Gordon setter puppy named Fiona.

headline: Marines Train to Protect Embassies
text: Fleet Antiterrorism Security Team Marines trained for close-quarters combat this week in Chesapeake, Va.

headline: Training for Consulate Attacks, in Case There’s a Next Time
text: CHESAPEAKE, Va. — The “riot” erupted suddenly on the Virginia-North Carolina border in a remote pocket of marshland and pine. “Go back to America!” the protesters shouted, hurling rubber rocks at a large plywood structure meant to be a United States consulate. “We don’t want you here! This is our country!”

headline: Lottery Numbers
40 Days of Night
text: Mitt Romney is losing badly. And he has only himself to blame.

headline: Files Offer Glimpse Into Shooting Suspect
text: DENVER — Two months after a gunman killed 12 people inside a Colorado movie theater, a very heavily redacted trove of legal documents in the case was unsealed on Friday, offering a few new details — including allegations from prosecutors that the defendant made a threat toward his psychiatrist several weeks before the shooting.

headline: Same-Sex Couples Granted Protection in Deportations
text: The Department of Homeland Security has stated in writing that foreigners who are same-sex partners of American citizens can be included under an Obama administration policy suspending deportations of some immigrants who pose no security risk.

headline: Execution Halted for Killer Claiming Abuse by Victim
text: PHILADELPHIA — A Pennsylvania judge on Friday granted a stay of execution and a new sentencing hearing to a convicted murderer who was scheduled to die by lethal injection on Wednesday.

headline: College Football Matchups
text: There is a paucity of top 25 matchups this weekend, which raises the question: why rank just 25 teams? If 75 teams, say, or even all 124 were ranked, then every game would feature two “ranked teams,” and we could dispense with pretending that No. 14 Ohio State versus No. 20 Michigan State is some sort of epic collision.

headline: Three Paths to Higher Mileage
text: Honda Plans to offer three hybrid systems, using one, two or three electric motors depending on the vehicle’s intent.

headline: Human Faces of ‘The Backlog’ at the Department of Veterans Affairs
text: It’s a story about putting faces to numbers. In his Page 1 article in today’s paper James Dao (@jimdao) lays out:

headline: Brian De Palma on 'Passion'
text: Brian De Palma, the director of “Passion,” discusses his film starring Noomi Rapace and Rachel McAdams playing at the New York Film Festival.

headline: Education Department Report Shows More Borrowers Defaulting on Student Loans
text: The percentage of borrowers who defaulted on federal education loans within the first three years of payments rose to an average of 13.4 percent last year — 22.7 percent for those who attended for-profit colleges — according to statistics released on Friday by the Department of Education.

headline: Citizen Held After 9/11 Wins Right to Be Tried
text: A federal judge in Idaho has ruled that the United States, after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, wrongly imprisoned an American under a law designed to keep trial witnesses from fleeing and that since there was evidence that the government may have willfully misused the law against him, his case should go to trial.

headline: Seeing the Beauty in the Bronx
text: Daniel Hauben, 56, a painter who grew up in the Bronx, infuses his scenes of the oft-maligned borough with a touch of whimsy.

headline: Battered and Beautiful: His Bronx
text: AFTERNOON sunlight splashed down into the main reading room of the Bronx Community College’s new library, where nearly every desk was occupied, the enthusiasm of the semester still as fresh as the paint.

headline: Opening Night in Brooklyn
text: The Barclays Center in Brooklyn began its first day of life on Friday with a performance by Jay-Z and protests outside the arena.

headline: Romney Team Tries Hanging a Jimmy Carter Label on Obama
text: WASHINGTON — A president struggling simultaneously to cope with anti-American tumult in the Middle East and fix stubborn economic trouble at home: Is President Obama replaying the one-term presidency of Jimmy Carter?

headline: On the Second Day, Tiger Sits
text: MEDINAH, Ill. — For the first time in his Ryder Cup career, Tiger Woods is sitting out a match. The United States captain, Davis Love III, benched Woods and Steve Stricker for Saturday’s foursomes after the pair lost both their matches Friday. They will be replaced by Webb Simpson and Bubba Watson, who will be in the first group out, against the European duo of Justin Rose and Ian Poulter.

headline: The Growing Role of Kurds in Syria
text: The Syrian government gave control of some areas to local Kurdish militias in exchange for their support.

headline: Robert Newton, Maker of Racing Tires, Dies at 85
text: Robert Newton, who with his wife, Joyce, founded Hoosier Racing Tire, the Indiana company whose tires have become fixtures at car-racing tracks around the country, died on Wednesday at his home in Lakeville, Ind. He was 85.

headline: Chastened King Seeks Redemption, for Spain and His Monarchy
text: MADRID — With Spain mired in an economic slump, many Spaniards are questioning their king, long revered for his role in bringing democracy to the nation but now being scrutinized for his deluxe lifestyle and opaque fortune.

headline: Chris Economaki, Rumbling Voice of Auto Racing, Dies at 91
text: Chris Economaki, whose gravelly broadcast voice and prolific pen — specifically, his manual Royal typewriter — narrated the rise of auto racing from county-fair dirt tracks to a global multibillion-dollar business, died on Friday in a nursing home in Wyckoff, N.J. He was 91.

headline: Schedule of Debates
text: Debates will take place from 9 to 10:30 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: Kurds Prepare to Pursue More Autonomy in a Fallen Syria
text: DOHUK, Iraq — Just off a main highway that stretches east of this city and slices through a moonscape of craggy hills, a few hundred Syrian Kurdish men have been training for battle, marching through scrub brush and practicing rifle drills.

headline: From Jordan’s Playbook: When Down, Sit Out
text: MEDINAH, Ill.

headline: Debate Advice From the Beltway
text: Political insiders weigh in on what they think Mitt Romney and President Obama need to accomplish in the first debate.

headline: Presidential Debate Moments
text: Sam Tanenhaus, editor of the Book Review, talks about some of the most memorable presidential debate moments of the televised era.

headline: Before Debate, Tough Crowds at the Practice
text: WASHINGTON — In a conference room at the Democratic headquarters, President Obama has been preparing for the debate next week, but the reviews of his staff are already in. Too long, they tell him. Cut that answer. Give crisper explanations. No one wants a professor; they want a president.

headline: In the Bronx, Throwing $97 Million Down 18 Holes
text: Were we to commit ourselves to making a master list of what New York City needs more of, it is fair to say that many of us would wear a third or fourth pencil down to the nub before settling on an 18-hole golf course and the increased presence of Donald J. Trump. And yet, with the renovation of a major portion of Ferry Point Park in the southeastern section of the Bronx, this is what New Yorkers will receive.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Keeping Pace With Orioles, the Yankees Bounce Back
text: TORONTO — The lopsided tally from Baltimore beamed on the out-of-town scoreboard on the right-field wall of the Rogers Centre and, as early as the first inning, the Yankees could see they would get no help from the Red Sox. The Orioles were on their way to an easy victory over Boston, and the pressure rose on the Yankees to keep pace with Baltimore.

headline: To Fight Crime, a Poor City Will Trade In Its Police
text: CAMDEN, N.J. — Two gruesome murders of children last month — a toddler decapitated, a 6-year-old stabbed in his sleep — served as reminders of this city’s reputation as the most dangerous in America. Others can be found along the blocks of row houses spray-painted “R.I.P.,” empty liquor bottles clustered on their porches in memorial to murder victims.

headline: New York May Restart Review of Gas-Drilling Rules
text: New York State appears to be further slowing its effort to produce rules governing fracking, shorthand for the suite of drilling methods used to extract natural gas from deep shale deposits. The pressure to drill has fallen sharply along with gas prices, and in the face of inevitable litigation. [Sept. 30, 11:13 p.m. | Updated | Danny Hakim describes the reaction of drilling supporters and foes to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s latest move on fracking.]

headline: For Rays and White Sox, One More Reversal in Upside-Down Year
text: CHICAGO — The September narratives for the White Sox and the Tampa Bay Rays seemed written Friday morning. The Rays were in the midst of a late-season charge for the second straight year, winners of eight straight to trim a six-game deficit on Sept. 18 to two in the American League wild-card race.

headline: Yemen’s Leader Praises U.S. Drone Strikes
text: WASHINGTON — The president of Yemen gave an unqualified endorsement of American drone strikes in his country during a visit here on Friday, cementing his status as a favored counterterrorism partner of the United States.

headline: X-Rays for Cano
text: TORONTO — Robinson Cano was struck in the back of the left hand with a pitch in the sixth inning of Friday’s 11-4 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays. He remained in the game, which was a good sign, but he wasn’t able to get an X-ray until late on Friday, so there was no definitive word on the extent of the injury immediately after the game.

headline: Greek Premier Sees Hope, but Only if Europe Helps
text: ATHENS — He waited his whole life for this moment, and many European leaders see him as Greece’s last best hope for stability. But for Antonis Samaras, leading his country is no fun at all. “Do you think anyone can be happy being prime minister of Greece?” he asked in a low voice in an interview here on Friday, placing his elbows on his knees. “This is the toughest job in the world. It’s just pain.”

headline: Iranian Group Now Off Terror List
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton formally removed an Iranian opposition group from the State Department’s list of designated terrorist organizations on Friday. The decision, first reported last week, is expected to make it easier to find new countries for more than 3,000 members of the group, the Mujahedeen Khalq, who are currently in Iraq. The department took into account the group’s public renunciation of violence and “the absence of confirmed acts of terrorism” by the group, known as the M.E.K., for more than a decade. But the department said it would not forget the M.E.K.’s past acts of terrorism, “including its involvement in the killing of U.S. citizens in Iran in the 1970s and an attack on U.S. soil in 1992.” It also expressed “serious concerns” about accusations that the group had committed abuses against some of its own members.

headline: France: Roma Camp Burned
text: A mob set fire to an encampment of 35 foreign Roma in a Marseille neighborhood on Thursday night, the French authorities said. Local officials and rights groups were outraged, but there were no arrests, a police spokesman said. Residents of a housing project forced the Roma, also known as Gypsies, out of an adjacent field, the spokesman said, before setting fire to their possessions. Residents told local news media that they were responding to several recent thefts that they attributed to the camp’s inhabitants. As many as 20,000 foreign Roma are said to live in France, most of them Romanians or Bulgarians.

headline: Government Can Decide How to Allocate Natural Resources, Supreme Court Rules
text: NEW DELHI–India’s Supreme Court upheld the government’s right to sell natural resources as it sees fit, saying it wasn’t necessary for the administration to use auctions.

headline: Honey Producers Lament a Bad Season for Bees
text: LONDON — It’s been another bad year for bees.

headline: The Weekend Word: Exposure
text: Today’s Times

headline: Vidya Balan and Jairam Ramesh Team Up For Toilets
text: NEW DELHI– A traveling village fair is scheduled to kick off next week in India, but instead of cotton candy and tchotchkes, it will sell an important message: Use soap to wash your hands, and don’t defecate in the open.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Chief Minister Omar Abdullah dismissed reports of a brewing “battle” between himself and Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party over the issue of providing security to sarpanches, the elected heads of village councils, Kashmir Live reported. A group of  sarpanches from Kashmir met with Mr. Gandhi in New Delhi on Thursday to discuss security concerns after the killing of three village council members in the Kashmir valley earlier this week.

headline: Accusations of Football Bounties for 10-Year-Olds
text: The allegations against leaders of a youth football team in California sound so outlandish that they seem to be from a “Saturday Night Live” skit. Imagine the former Saints defensive coordinator Gregg Williams telling a group of 10-year-olds that there may be a trip to Dairy Queen after the game, “but only after you affect the head, kill the head.”

headline: Jay-Z Comes Home to Repay a Debt to Brooklyn
text: For many years, Jay-Z closed out his concerts with “Encore,” a soothing, triumphant number from “The Black Album,” which at the time of its release in 2003 was billed as something of a retirement. “From Marcy to Madison Square,” he rapped, sketching an arc that had taken him from a Brooklyn housing project to headlining the most symbolically important arena in the country.

headline: Ristretto | Paris is Brewing
text: Finally, Paris has a coffee scene. The city has always been the paradox of the industry, a great cafe town where an otherwise discerning audience happily throws back watery shots of ashy swill. I first wrote about Paris coffee in 2010, and after returning to the topic last year I decided to sit on my hands until somebody in the city figured out what it was missing.

headline: A Champions League Sojourn
text: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — I have to admit, I looked up Serbia on the map when I found out we would be going there for Champions League. This was a business trip, like any time I’ve traveled to play a game, but it turned out to be a fascinating experience, leaving me wishing I could extend my stay and be a tourist for a couple days.

headline: Arthur O. Sulzberger, Publisher Who Transformed The Times for New Era, Dies at 86
text: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, who guided The New York Times and its parent company through a long, sometimes turbulent period of expansion and change on a scale not seen since the newspaper’s founding in 1851, died early Saturday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 86.

headline: Remembering Arthur Ochs Sulzberger
text: As publisher of The New York Times, Arthur Ochs “Punch” Sulzberger saw the paper through a trying strike, expanded its sections and printed the Pentagon Papers.

headline: Junya Watanabe: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: In Syria’s Largest City, Fire Ravages Ancient Market
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Fire swept through the old central souk, or marketplace, of Aleppo, Syria, on Saturday, damaging a vast and well-preserved labyrinth of medieval storehouses, shops, schools and ornate courtyards as fierce clashes between security forces and insurgents vowing to carry out a “decisive battle” for the city continued.

headline: Haider Ackermann: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: A Guitar Maker Aims to Stay Plugged In
text: IN 1948, a radio repairman named Leo Fender took a piece of ash, bolted on a length of maple and attached an electronic transducer.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Lanvin
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Political and Class Issues Complicate a Colorado Land Dispute
text: PAONIA, Colo. — This is a story of a quiet billionaire and a middle-class mountain town, of class divisions, small-town quarrels and competing visions of the future of the West. But at its core, like so many stories here in the aspen-dappled hillsides, it is really all about land.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: College Football Saturday
text: The Times is back today to host the best college football watch party in the country. Mike Huguenin will offer up his own analysis and insights on all of the big games and a lot of the not so big ones.

headline: The New Stars in Republican Commercials Attacking Obama: Babies
text: Attack ads have come to this: President Obama makes babies cry.

headline: From Two Great Showmen, Straightforward Hollywood Glamour
text: This was one of those rare seasons when the designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren of Viktor & Rolf went for straightforward fashion, instead of the conceptual variety. While it was not the usual three-ring circus, this collection, loosely themed around Hollywood glamour, offered a good opportunity to reiterate the signatures of the house. It was also a reminder that Mr. Horsting and Mr. Snoeren, besides being great showmen, are in the business of selling clothes.

headline: Bound to Sea but Buried in Debt, Spain’s Fishermen Blame Bloc’s Policies
text: CÁDIZ, Spain — Millions of Spaniards took advantage of cheap financing to buy new houses during Spain’s decade-long economic boom and housing bubble beginning in the late 1990s. The country’s fishermen, many encouraged by European Union subsidies, did much the same for their own homes away from home: new boats.

headline: Soriano’s Renaissance Gives Cubs a Quandary
text: CHICAGO — Alfonso Soriano arrived in the big leagues as a gangly second baseman for the mighty Yankees. Fourteen years later, he is an aging left fielder for the Cubs, a team approaching 100 losses this season.

headline: Viktor & Rolf: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Sole Canadian Held at Guantánamo Bay Is Repatriated
text: OTTAWA — Omar Khadr, the only Canadian citizen held at the Guantánamo Bay detention center in Cuba, was returned to Canada early Saturday morning, the Pentagon and the Canadian government announced.

headline: Triple Crown Would Paint a Clearer M.V.P. Picture
text: Let’s answer the big question right away: if Miguel Cabrera wins the triple crown, he should be the American League’s most valuable player. To lead the league in batting average, homers and runs batted in and not be named M.V.P. simply does not feel right.

headline: Bettman Undisputed N.H.L. Enforcer
text: How much power does N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman have? Is he merely the instrument of the owners, taking orders and doing what he is told, or is it the other way around?

headline: ‘Punch’ Sulzberger, R.I.P.
text: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, better known as Punch, transformed this newspaper and had a vast impact on journalism. He oversaw the emergence of an array of feature sections that put this newspaper on a solid financial footing, and he risked everything when he defied the White House and published the top-secret Pentagon Papers from the Vietnam War. But on hearing just now that he passed away overnight at the age of 86, I kept thinking of Punch mostly as a really good and decent man who oozed likability as well as leadership. (Here’s his obituary)

headline: Variety: An Artsy Diagramless
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — O.K., so I stretched things a bit. That’s not the first time that has happened here at Wordplay.

text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: At the Stedelijk, Tales of 2 Staircases
text: AMSTERDAM—When the Stedelijk, the Amsterdam museum for modern and contemporary art and design, recently reopened here after having been shut for nine years, it was both a resuscitation of an old hangout and the birth of a new stage for art.

headline: Holmes Has Become Focus by Design and by Necessity
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Santonio Holmes says life would probably be even better if penalty yardage on defensive backs could be tacked onto his statistics, and he would be awarded touchdowns on defensive pass-interference calls in the end zone.

headline: Cacharel: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: A Freeway’s Closing Fails to Scare All of Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — Last year, before a 10-mile stretch of the nation’s busiest freeway, Interstate 405, was closed for an entire weekend in July, city officials warned of potentially endless gridlock (or more endless than usual). Carmageddon, they called it. And Angelenos listened. For one weekend in this city of cars, everyone walked. The city’s roads had never felt emptier. It was, most thought, kind of nice.

headline: Islamist Rebels Flee Key Port City in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Under the cover of darkness, the Shabab militant group withdrew from the port town of Kismayu early Saturday, abandoning its last major stronghold and vowing to take the war underground.

headline: Mr. Sulzberger, Publisher and Projectionist
text: In 1995, at the funeral of the extraordinary journalist James Reston, I watched Arthur Ochs Sulzberger of The New York Times escort Katharine Graham of The Washington Post up the long aisle of the National Cathedral in Washington. I was struck by their grace and dignity, by how symbolic they were of great journalism, and by how much our profession owed to the man who had published The Times for nearly 30 years.

headline: Supreme Court Faces Weighty Cases and a New Dynamic
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court returns to the bench on Monday to confront not only a docket studded with momentous issues but also a new dynamic among the justices.

headline: Resurgent Driver Returns to Scene of Only Win
text: DOVER, Del. — Another miserable day for Martin Truex Jr. had included a bad pit stop and a crash, and there was nothing left for him to do but punch his trailer. Just seven races into the 2011 Nascar Sprint Cup Series, Truex was flailing, his career stalled.

headline: Faced With Strengthened Rivals in Atlantic Division, Celtics Load Up
text: WALTHAM, Mass. — Wyc Grousbeck has been the head of the Boston Celtics ownership group for a decade. In that span, he has presided over a team that lost 18 straight games, a team record, and over another that lost 16 games in an entire season en route to an N.B.A. championship.

headline: A Trans-Atlantic Trip Turns Kafkaesque
text: You, American Airlines, should no longer be flying across the Atlantic. You do not have the know-how. You do not have the equipment. And your employees have clearly lost interest in the endeavor. Like the country whose name graces the hulls of your flying ships, you are exhausted and shorn of purpose. You need to stop.

headline: Short Political Memories
text: Busy day, so not much time for posting. Just a note about the oddly short memories of many people commenting on this final stretch of the presidential campaign.

headline: San Francisco’s New Archbishop Worries Gay Catholics
text: SAN FRANCISCO — At Most Holy Redeemer Catholic Church in the Castro, this city’s largest gay district, about 20 of the faithful gathered for 8 a.m. Mass recently, clustering in the middle pews. Led by a visiting priest from nearby Oakland, the parishioners joined in celebrating the 30th anniversary of a gay couple.

headline: Jets Among Elite Company in Replacing the Irreplaceable
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The day after their Darrelle Revis sustained a season-ending knee injury, the 2008 New England Patriots heard their coach say his name — Tom Brady — once, but not again for four months.

headline: Pope’s Former Butler on Trial in Theft of Personal Papers
text: VATICAN CITY — Pope Benedict XVI’s former butler, Paolo Gabriele, went on trial on Saturday on charges of stealing the pope’s confidential papers and leaking them to the press, an unprecedented security breach that set off an embarrassingly public airing of back-room intrigue and allegations of corruption at an institution known for its secrecy.

headline: Main Street’s Landlord
text: Cleveland Heights, Ohio

headline: Return of Referee Known for Big Arms Is Welcomed With Open Arms
text: It was just a few hours after the N.F.L. had ended its labor dispute with locked-out game officials, and Ed Hochuli was already back to work.

headline: Obamanomics: A Counterhistory
text: Washington

headline: Janet H. Brown
text: As executive director of the nonpartisan Commission on Presidential Debates, Janet H. Brown is responsible for organizing and orchestrating the quadrennial verbal smackdowns that can define candidates. The first 2012 presidential debate will be televised live on Wednesday night. Ms. Brown has led the commission since its founding in 1987 and previously worked in staff positions at the White House, the Office of Management and Budget, the State Department and the Senate.

headline: The Conservative Case for Obamacare
text: Washington

headline: Better Off Than They Were in Years Past, Georgian Voters Ask: At What Cost?
text: TBILISI, Georgia — Ten days ago, after the release of video clips showing brutal abuse in a Georgian prison, the members of a soulful, apolitical indie-rock band called Landmark sat down to write a new kind of song. It was an anthem of defiance to the country’s law-enforcement system, building to the angry refrain, “The system must be destroyed!”

headline: Why Obama Is Winning
text: LAST winter, I had lunch with a junior White House official who works on economic issues. The unemployment rate had just dipped to 8.3 percent, and I asked if he was encouraged by the figure, and hopeful that it might be down another point by Election Day.

headline: The World We’re Actually Living In
text: FOR the first time in a long, long time, a Democrat is running for president and has the clear advantage on national security policy. That is not “how things are supposed to be,” and Republicans sound apoplectic about it. But there is a reason President Obama is leading on national security, and it was apparent in his U.N. speech last week, which showed a president who understands that we really do live in a more complex world today — and that saying so is not a cop-out. It’s a road map. Mitt Romney, given his international business background, should understand this, but he acts instead as if he learned his foreign policy at the International House of Pancakes, where the menu and architecture rarely changes.

headline: It Goes With Everything, Even Blue Hair
text: SAVANNAH, Ga.

headline: Kill the Indians, Then Copy Them
text: Los Angeles

headline: New Mexico Offers Look at U.S. Elections of the Future
text: LAS VEGAS, N.M. — The volunteers fanned out in pairs last week, swarming the heart of this old settlers’ outpost in the north central part of the nation’s most Hispanic state.

headline: Who Controls the Story?
text: JEREMY PETERS was doing a routine reporting job earlier this year when he stumbled across something that, as he put it, “smelled funny.”

headline: Fullback May Soon Have More Carries Than Nicknames
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was as innocuous as an N.F.L. play gets. The quarterback took a shotgun snap, handed the ball to the player next to him and watched the runner hop a few steps through the line before being tackled for a 3-yard gain. The crowd barely stirred. The television announcers gave the sequence little more than a cursory mention. There was not even a replay shown.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: The Honorable Clan of the Long-Distance Runner
text: As amateur marathon runners for nearly 50 years, we were surprised when our sport made headlines recently for an unusual reason.

headline: Ukraine Ex-Premier Airs Video
text: MOSCOW — In a rare video message, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the jailed former prime minister of Ukraine, lashed out against President Viktor F. Yanukovich, who is widely viewed as responsible for her imprisonment, and urged voters to defeat Mr. Yanukovich’s party in parliamentary elections next month.

headline: Dempsey Scores for Spurs
text: Video: Dempsey scores to give Spurs 3-1 lead

headline: Three Muffled Syllables
text: IN a few days, as you may have heard, Barack Obama and Mitt Romney will go head-to-head in their first presidential debate. What I most want from it isn’t fireworks, though I’m as big a fan of political theater as the next hack. It’s a word, one that has gone sadly out of vogue over recent decades and been mostly absent from this campaign.

headline: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, a Times Publisher, Dies
text: Mr. Sulzberger shaped the destiny of The New York Times for 34 years as its publisher and as chairman and chief executive of its parent company.

headline: Away From Cities, a Life Laced With Violence for Syrians
text: RUWEIHA, Syria — The children slept on the floor of a school on a mountain slope.

headline: Vivienne Westwood: Spring 2013 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Keeping the Music Alive
text: Electric guitars, huge as they are, have lost some of their old magic in this era of Jay-Z, Kanye West and “The Voice.”

headline: Shots Falling and Spirits Rising, U.S. Puts Europe in Deep Hole
text: MEDINAH, Ill. — The skywriting planes that have been working the pale blue skies above Medinah Country Club this weekend have been relentlessly Eurocentric and optimistic.

headline: The Caucus Click: Biden in Florida
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden stopped at Mel’s Diner in Fort Myers, Fla., as he finished up a two-day tour of the swing state.

headline: Heartbeat of Rock ’n’ Roll
text: Fender is the world’s largest manufacturer of guitars. But the recession, inexpensive manufacturers and the shift toward synthesizers and drum machines have threatened Fender’s profit margins.

headline: With Good News About His Hand, Cano Stays in the Yankees’ Lineup
text: TORONTO — Yankees Manager Joe Girardi was not too worried Friday night that there was anything structurally wrong with Robinson Cano’s hand.

headline: The Myth of Male Decline
text: SCROLL through the titles and subtitles of recent books, and you will read that women have become “The Richer Sex,” that “The Rise of Women Has Turned Men Into Boys,” and that we may even be seeing “The End of Men.” Several of the authors of these books posit that we are on the verge of a “new majority of female breadwinners,” where middle-class wives lord over their husbands while demoralized single men take refuge in perpetual adolescence.

headline: October Term, 2012
text: On Monday, the Supreme Court opens a new term with a menu of important cases that deal with affirmative action, criminal justice, the right of defendants to effective counsel and more. The court may soon choose to hear a controversial case that could redefine voting-rights law, and, later in the term, one or more cases involving same-sex marriage.

headline: Matchup: 49ers (2-1) at Jets (2-1)
text: 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

headline: Petrova Wins Wild Tokyo Final
text: When the spinning finally ended, the veteran Nadia Petrova of Russia fell to her knees having won a dizzying final at the Toray Pan Pacific Open in Ariake Coliseum in Tokyo, defeating the defending champion, Agnieszka Radwanska of Poland, 6-0, 1-6, 6-3. The title at the Premier 5-level tournament ties the biggest of Petrova’s career and is her second in 2012 and 12th over all.

headline: Democracy in the Former Soviet Republics
text: No leader of the former Soviet republics has been more pro-Western than President Mikheil Saakashvili of Georgia. He moves easily in Washington and dreams of bringing his country into full NATO membership. But his government’s handling of prisons and its approach to parliamentary elections set for Monday are raising doubts about his commitment to democracy and reform.

headline: 30 Seconds With Brad Richards: Locked Out but Dialed In
text: Before the N.H.L. lockout, the Rangers’ Brad Richards was hoping to build on his performance in last season’s playoffs. The alternate captain in his first season with the team, he had six goals and nine assists in 20 postseason games. During the regular season, Richards compiled 25 goals and 41 assists. He won the Stanley Cup with the Tampa Bay Lightning in 2004, when he was awarded the Conn Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player during the playoffs.

headline: Can Opium or Illness Explain a Keats Poem?
text: On Sept. 21, 1819, John Keats wrote to his brother George that he was “scarcely content to write the best verses for the fever they leave behind. I want to compose without this fever.” The fever is no metaphor. In another letter dated that same day, he had sent a friend a copy of his poem “To Autumn,” written just then, one of the greatest poems in the English language and the last of Keats’s great odes. For Keats, poetry was never emotion recollected in tranquillity, as it was for Wordsworth. It was often tranquillity refigured by his fevered mind.

headline: What I Learned From Playing the Gipper
text: WHEN Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic nominee for president in 1984, asked me to help him prepare for his debates with President Ronald Reagan by playing the Reagan role, I accepted with enthusiasm.

headline: Tension, Though No Violence, as Protestants Parade in Belfast
text: BELFAST, Northern Ireland — The parades to celebrate the centenary of the signing of the Ulster Covenant — the 1912 petition against home rule that helped lead to the partition of Ireland — passed peacefully on Saturday amid the biggest police operation here in more than 20 years.

headline: Peter Praeger, a Surgeon With a Health Food Company, Dies at 65
text: Dr. Peter Praeger, a heart surgeon who saved a man’s life and as a result wound up owning a gefilte fish company — and who as a result of that wound up starting a successful natural-foods company — died on Sept. 22 in Hackensack, N.J. He was 65.

headline: Ex-South Korea Leader Haunts Presidential Bid
text: SEOUL, South Korea — No matter how South Koreans cast their ballots in the Dec. 19 presidential election, one thing is certain: Their decision will depend at least in part on their view of a former president who has been dead for 33 years.

headline: To Encourage Biking, Cities Lose the Helmets
text: ONE spectacular Sunday in Paris last month, I decided to skip museums and shopping to partake of something even more captivating for an environment reporter: Vélib, arguably the most successful bike-sharing program in the world. In their short lives, Europe’s bike-sharing systems have delivered myriad benefits, notably reducing traffic and its carbon emissions. A number of American cities — including New York, where a bike-sharing program is to open next year — want to replicate that success.

headline: Potentially Deadly Virus Related to SARS Appears to Be Not Easily Spread
text: A new strain of a potentially deadly virus related to SARS, which has killed one man in Saudi Arabia and left a Qatari man critically ill in London, does not appear to spread easily from person to person, the World Health Organization says.

headline: Women as Priests
text: REFORMERS within the Roman Catholic Church have been calling for the ordination of women as priests. The Vatican, however, refuses to consider the possibility and uses its power to silence those who speak out. Catholic clergy in Europe, Australia and the United States who have voiced public support for female ordination have been either dismissed or threatened with removal from administrative posts within the church.

headline: Women as Priests
text: Photographs of women who have rebelled against the Roman Catholic Church’s decree that females cannot be priests.

headline: Valium’s Contribution to Our New Normal
text: IT wasn’t funny, really, but everybody laughed at the scene in the 1979 film “Starting Over” when Burt Reynolds’s character had a panic attack in the furniture department of Bloomingdale’s (something to do with terror at the prospect of buying a couch). “Does anyone have a Valium?” his brother called out as Burt hyperventilated. The punch line: Every woman in the store reached into her purse and pulled out a little vial of pills.

headline: From Farm to Landfill
text: Feeding the planet is nearly always discussed as if it were mainly a matter of growing more food. It is not going to be that simple. In 2012 this planet will produce a record grain yield of 2.4 billion tons. That is a 1 percent increase over last year, a number slightly smaller than expected because of a devastating drought in this country that will result in a harvest 70 million tons short of earlier projections. One percent is a slender margin of growth when it comes to feeding a global human population where at least one in seven people go hungry.

headline: Escaping One’s Own Shadow
text: Before we get started, you should know this about me: I’ve written short stories, news articles, essays, reviews and a couple of nonfiction books. In pursuit of my ambitions, I’ve put in long hours of reading, writing and rewriting. But because life unfolds the way life does, I also have a day job as a think tank researcher, where I spend about half of my time writing or reading in genres and styles that are — how can I put this? — less juicy than the ones I practice and aspire to produce.

headline: Gaultier Pays Tribute to ’80s Pop Stars

headline: End of the Line for the Senators, and a Childhood
text: In 1989, my 10-year-old son, Brendan, asked if I would take him and his younger brother Patrick to a trading card show. When I was Brendan’s age, in 1955, I boasted the largest card collection in my Washington neighborhood — hundreds filling two large boxes. The cards in those days were not for collecting. They were for bartering, trading and learning the career statistics of favorite players.

headline: Lifting Schools, via Healthier Food
text: I GREW up in San Antonio, and loved to spend time at my grandparents’ cattle ranch about 90 miles away in Hunt, Tex.

headline: Follow a Career Passion? Let It Follow You
text: IN the spring of 2004, during my senior year of college, I faced a hard decision about my future career. I had a job offer from Microsoft and an acceptance letter from the computer science doctoral program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. I had also just handed in the manuscript for my first nonfiction book, which opened the option of becoming a full-time writer. These are three strikingly different career paths, and I had to choose which one was right for me.

We should strive to get the “lowest possible tax rates on the broadest base,” as five well-known conservative economists put it recently.

headline: Car Talk
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Even when my car’s battery kicked the bucket in the middle of a raging snowstorm with no notice, I still swore my allegiance to her (yes, it’s a “her”). Seemingly spontaneous flat tires, a “Report for service now” gauge that lit up randomly, causing me to spend an unusual amount of time at the dealership service center … no matter. We were partners in my quest to See Everything Within Driving Distance. She has delivered me and my kids to emergency rooms in the middle of the night, and borne the burden of a houseful of camp paraphernalia as I drove my kids to camp.

Cooley, whose name is almost always accompanied by the description “world-famous heart surgeon.”

headline: Spring Crush in Paris

Using sports fabrics like mesh and nylon, Mr. Watanabe created a collection as simple as it was innovative, with neon-bright mini dresses and jackets with an array of zipped vents, cool shifts made from interlocking pieces of mesh and jersey, and some lovely fluted dresses with slivered insets. About 25 percent of the fabrics came from Puma for a one-time collaboration with Mr. Watanabe. On Saturday, former New York Gov. David A. Paterson led a ceremony at Helsinki Hudson, a restaurant in Hudson, N.Y.

text: Christopher Kevin Linn and José David Montalvo were married Saturday at the Midtown Loft and Terrace, an event space in New York. The Rev. Dean Patrick Broadhurst, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

text: Edward Chang Yim and Erick Clark Neher were married Thursday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, a member of the Office of the City Clerk, officiated. On Saturday, Michael Starr, a friend of the couple, led a ceremony that included poetry and vows before family and friends at the General Theological Seminary in Manhattan.

headline: Bethany Perskie, Jason Shelly

Perskie of Margate, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Jason Edward Shelly, a son of Marjorie Shelly and Edward Shelly of Rochester. The bride’s father, a retired New Jersey Superior Court judge, officiated at One Atlantic, an event space in Atlantic City.

headline: Amy Pierce, John Alvino

The Rev. Timothy Jay Patterson performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Greensboro, where he is the church’s rector.

Piekarski of Wayside, N.J. Rabbi David J. Gelfand officiated at the weekend home of the bride’s family in Chilmark, Mass., on Martha’s Vineyard.

The author argues that the lack of timely government intervention has intensified the effect of such disasters. He writes:

headline: In Defense of the Doormat Dad
text: If Benjamin, my 2-year-old, has a meltdown because we’re leaving a park, I let him stay longer. If he wants to jump on our kiddie trampoline until 11 p.m. instead of going to bed, I indulge him. If he insists on taking a 60-minute bath, I sit there beside the tub.

headline: ‘Hotel Transylvania’ Leads Weekend Box Office
text: Pent-up demand for a new animated movie and a long and lively marketing campaign powered Sony’s “Hotel Transylvania” to No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend. The film, which cost at least $85 million to make, outperformed expectations to take in about $43 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. (An elated Sony e-mailed reporters on Sunday morning to announce “a monster hit on our hands!!!!!!”)

headline: Turning Up the Volume on Global Poverty
text: Cranked-up guitars and sobering statistics shared a Central Park audience of more than 60,000 people on Saturday at the Global Citizen Festival, a five-hour concert on the Great Lawn devoted to ending extreme poverty worldwide. The concert was also webcast internationally.

headline: Ryan Sees ‘Media Bias’ in Campaign Coverage

Ryan of Wisconsin, suggested on Sunday that part of the problem might be in getting the message past the mainstream news media.

headline: A Mockumentary Pulls In Real Players
text: TORONTO — During the Jan. 3 broadcast of ABC’s “World News Tonight” Diane Sawyer introduced a heartbreaking segment from the Iowa caucus, featuring a distraught voter being consoled by Mitt Romney. “Save the small families of America,” she begged through tears, as Mr. Romney hugged her and promised he would.

headline: Teixeira Is Set to Rejoin the Yankees

headline: Disgraced Chinese Official’s Son Defends Him

headline: Attacks on 6 Banks Frustrate Customers

headline: As Kenyan Forces Press Militants Across Border, a Church Is Attacked Back Home
text: MOMBASA, Kenya — A 9-year-old boy was killed and several other children were wounded on Sunday when a grenade was hurled into a church in Kenya’s capital, Nairobi, two days after Kenyan forces invaded the last major stronghold of the Shabab militant group in Somalia.

headline: Purveyors of Office Space and Lively Arts
text: One recent Monday morning the pianist Taka Kigawa took his place at a keyboard in the lobby of 1 Liberty Plaza, an office building near Wall Street, and worked through Debussy’s Preludes, Book II. A small audience — perhaps a dozen people at first, more than 100 an hour later — sat at tables or stood on the periphery, sipping coffee, listening to Mr. Kigawa and watching the parade of businessmen and tourists drift past the large window to the pianist’s left.

headline: ‘Rebecca’ Faces Broadway Postponement
text: 4:35 p.m. | Updated An executive involved with the Broadway musical “Rebecca” said on Sunday that the show would be postponed because its lead producers were unable to close a $4.5 million gap in its $12 million budget.

text: SAN FRANCISCO — The composer Samuel Carl Adams said, not really joking, that the San Francisco Symphony is “partially responsible for my existence.” His parents — the composer John Adams and the photographer Deborah O’Grady — met while working at the orchestra. More recently the younger Mr. Adams, 26, has been living in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where he pursues his wide-ranging interests, including playing bass in new-music groups and creating sound designs for multimedia works.

headline: Being Where the Interceptions Are

Not as readily apparent was the depth of understanding, attention to detail and level of experience that led Boley, an eight-year veteran, to be ideally positioned for each play.

headline: For Yankees, a Playoff Berth and Unfinished Business
text: TORONTO — Two hours before the Yankees took the field Sunday afternoon, the stereo in the visitors’ clubhouse at Rogers Centre blared an old De La Soul tune called “The Magic Number,” but few of the players even noticed the significance.

headline: Following an Artist’s Footsteps in the Sand
text: The Spanish director Isaki Lacuesta clearly set out to create an art movie with “The Double Steps,” a self-conscious exercise set in Africa, largely by swapping one set of cinematic conventions for another. The movie won top honors at 2011 San Sebastián Film Festival (and feels very much as if it was made for the festival circuit). It hinges on an American-born artist and writer, François Augiéras (1925-71), who lived and worked in the Sahara and who covered an abandoned army bunker in frescoes, hoping, as some introductory text puts it, to make it “the Sistine Chapel of the desert.” “Today,” the on-screen text continues, “some travelers are preparing to find, finally, Augiéras’s lost frescoes.”

headline: Putting Philippine Justice on Trial
text: The miscarriage of justice recounted in “Give Up Tomorrow,” filmed over six years, is so comprehensive as to be disorienting. Paco Larrañaga, a Filipino-Spanish student from a privileged family who was convicted in 1999 as the ringleader of a 1997 double murder and rape of two sisters in the Philippines, was, for starters, miles away on a different island when the crimes took place, according to 35 witnesses.

headline: Winners Named for Dayton Literary Peace Prize
text: The novelist Andrew Krivak, who wrote “The Sojourn” (Bellevue Literary Press), and Adam Hochschild, the author of “To End All Wars” (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt), have won the 2012 Dayton Literary Peace Prize for fiction and nonfiction. The runners-up are Ha Jin, for “Nanjing Requiem” (Pantheon Books), and Annia Ciezadlo for “Day of Honey” (Free Press).

headline: Cool and Complex: Many Moving Parts Running Smoothly Askew
text: The audience gave such lusty applause to all four offerings in Fall for Dance’s program on Saturday night at City Center that it sounded as if for each piece the theater was populated solely by the performers’ friends and family. Afterward, however, while leaving the theater, you could hear people discussing ardently which items had worked for them, which they’d tolerated and which they hadn’t cared for. I was relieved to find that I wasn’t the only person who hadn’t loved everything.

headline: Orioles’ Party Is Put Off, but Only for a Few Hours

headline: Frank Gehry Joins Toronto Development

headline: A Gypsy, Fiery Yet Cool
text: To say that the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of the Richard Eyre production of Bizet’s “Carmen” on Friday evening got off to a slow start wouldn’t be quite right. Michele Mariotti, conducting in his Met debut, tore into the prelude, honoring the precedent set by Yannick Nézet-Séguin when the production was new, in 2009.

headline: Slipping Into and Out of Something Comfortable

headline: Rangers Lock In Playoff Spot and Help Others, Too
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Texas Rangers have proved dominant and resilient during their nearly season-long occupation of first place in the American League West. But anxiety was beginning to build at the Ballpark here, and after the Rangers dropped the first game of a doubleheader Sunday, the calendar couldn’t flip fast enough for them.

headline: Analysts Weigh In on Getting Anthony and Stoudemire in Sync
text: A curious off-season in which the Knicks let young players go and replaced them with veterans will end on Monday, when the team gathers for media day, marking the official opening of training camp. For the Knicks, the big question will be whether the added experience will add up to something special.

headline: Reubin Andres, an Advocate of Weight Gain, Dies at 89
text: Dr. Reubin Andres, a gerontologist who advanced the study of diabetes but gained his widest attention for arguing controversially that weight gain in older people increases longevity, died on Sept. 23 at his home in Baltimore. He was 89.

headline: Eddie Bert, Jazz Trombone Player, Dies at 90
text: Eddie Bert, a jazz trombonist whose virtuosity and versatility allowed him to fit comfortably in a wide range of musical contexts, from the infectious swing of Benny Goodman to the wild experimentation of Charles Mingus, died on Thursday at his home in Danbury, Conn. He was 90.

headline: Kodak Plans to End Line of Inkjet Printers
text: As part of its bankruptcy reorganization, Eastman Kodak is planning to wind down sales of consumer inkjet printers next year, products that were once called a crucial part of its turnaround effort.

headline: Video: Meg Whitman on Fixing Hewlett-Packard
text: Few leadership attributes are as important as clear self-definition and a strong sense of direction. Meg Whitman, whose company I wrote about in Sunday’s New York Times, is among the clearest. In this video interview, she explains everything she needs to tell Wall Street at this Wednesday’s analyst meeting.

headline: Tired Cries of Bias Don’t Help Romney
text: In the last few days, conservatives have become agitated about Mitt Romney’s drop-off in the polls. So did they think the stumble was because of the ill-fated “47 percent” slip of the lip, or the hasty effort to gain a political edge after the death of an American ambassador in Libya, or more problematically, a campaign that can’t seem to stop pratfalling no matter what the news?

headline: California Is First State to Ban Gay ‘Cure’ for Minors
text: California has become the first state to ban the use for minors of disputed therapies to “overcome” homosexuality, a step hailed by gay rights groups across the country that say the therapies have caused dangerous emotional harm to gay and lesbian teenagers.

headline: Soft Sales Crimp Outlook for Electric Cars
text: PARIS — Many auto executives were not that enthusiastic about battery-powered cars at their outset, and now that sales of electric vehicles made by Tesla and Renault have been disappointing, some carmakers are playing down the technology.
